title: Posner cueing specifically modulates attention, but not expectation: Behavioral and neural evidence
abstract:
Attention and expectation are cognitive processes that help us navigate our environment efficiently. Each can modulate observers’ perceptual sensitivity (d’), decisional criteria (c), or both. Standard “attention” tasks involving probabilistic attention cues (e.g Posner cueing task), are hypothesized to conflate the effects of these two processes on behavior. 

We tested this hypothesis by having the same set of n=19 subjects perform two tasks: a standard Posner cueing task (two-alternative detection/2-ADC task) and a two-alternative forced-choice (2-AFC) task. We replicated a previous study (Wyart et al, PNAS, 2012, DOI:10.1073/pnas.1120118109) in which subjects performed an detection 2-AFC task with independent probability (expectation) and relevance (attention) cues. Our task overcame key limitations of this previous study, and confirmed that signal probability modulated criteria alone whereas relevance modulated d’ alone. 

Next, the same subjects who performed the 2-AFC task also performed a 2-ADC (Posner cueing) task with spatial probabilistic cues. Subjects were cued to the most probable location of an upcoming target event (change in orientation) and indicated whether they perceived the change at the cued location, at the uncued location, or not at all. In this task, probabilistic cueing modulated both d’ and criteria. 

Nevertheless, only d’ modulations (difference in d’ between cued and uncued locations) were correlated across subjects between the 2-ADC and 2-AFC tasks (r=0.63, p<0.01, n=19 subjects) whereas criterion modulations were uncorrelated (r=-0.13, p=0.56). In addition, relevance cues (but not probability cues) in the 2-AFC task, and Posner cues in the 2-ADC task systematically modulated the power of EEG steady state visually evoked potentials (SSVEPs) and alpha-band oscillations. 

Our results provide direct behavioral and neural evidence indicating that probabilistic cues, such as Posner cues, serve as attention, rather than expectation, cues.
coauthors: Kavya Rajendran, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore; Devarajan Sridharan, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Lysergic acid diethylamide (LSD) increases social behaviour and bursting activity in medial prefrontal cortex neurons.
abstract: Social behaviour (SB) encompasses a plethora of complex interactions among individuals. The medial prefrontal cortex (mPFC) exerts a pivotal role in the modulation of SB in mammals since mPFC dysregulation has been demonstrated to be involved in the pathogenesis of impaired SB phenotypes. In the past 15 years, psychedelic drugs have been investigated as potential therapeutics in psychiatry. Lysergic acid diethylamide (LSD) in humans has been shown, in clinical settings, to produce feelings of happiness, trust, closeness to others, and enhanced emotional empathy. Despite these positive results, the ability of LSD to modulate SB has not been investigated, and the neuronal mechanisms underlying LSD's behavioural effects remain elusive. Here, we dissected the ability of acute and repeated LSD to exert prosocial effects and to modulate neuronal activity of the mPFC in mice. We found that repeated (30ug/kg per day, for 7 days), but not acute LSD treatment significantly increased the time spent interacting with an intruder mouse in the Direct Social Interaction Test. Similarly, repeated LSD treatment increased sociability and the preference for social novelty in mice subjected to the Three-Chambers Sociability Test. These behavioural results are paralleled with our electrophysiological findings. Using in-vivo extracellular single-unit recordings, we found that acute LSD treatment had no significant effect on the spontaneous firing nor the bursting activity of mPFC neurons, but repeated LSD treatment significantly increased the bursting activity of these neurons. Ultimately, our results demonstrate the ability of LSD to produce pro-social effects that are coupled with an increase in mPFC neuronal bursting activity.
coauthors: Dr. Antonio Inserra, McGill University; Dr. Danilo De Gregorio, McGill University; Prof. Gabriella Gobbi, McGill University.
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: A new non-Hominid primate network highlights the singularity of the human default mode network
abstract:
The human default mode network (DMN) is particularly involved in high cognitive abilities such as self-directed thoughts. In humans, one of the typical functional features of this network includes a strong correlated activity between the posterior cingulate cortex (PCC) and the medial prefrontal cortex (mPFC). Although these connections are generally assumed to be present in other primates, recent studies highlight poor connection between these two regions in marmosets but strong correlations between PCC and dorso-lateral prefrontal cortex (dlPFC; 8Ad). This disparity of the DMN connectivity has not yet been studied in other primates and no comparison was directly made with human data. Here, we aim to determine whether the humans DMN carries a connectivity pattern that distinguishes it from other primates. Moreover, we aim to identify the non-hominid primate network in which the mPFC is involved at rest. 
In the current study, we compared the resting-state network functional organisation in humans, macaques, and mouse lemurs. We discovered a network involving mPFC that was highly similar in both non-hominid primates but was not identified in humans. We also detected a non-hominid primate “DMN-like” dissimilar to that of humans that did not involve mPFC but dlPFC regions such as 8Ad. We created a functional atlas for each species and compared the fingerprint pattern and connectivity magnitude between various clusters of interest. We found strong correlation between PCC and mPFC in humans but not in mouse lemurs and macaques. These findings diverge from the current literature that propose strong similarities between primates and human’s DMN. Altogether, our results suggest that high order networks in non-hominid primates display closer characteristics between themselves than to humans. These findings suggest that important events may have occurred during the hominid evolution. We propose that a reorganization/fusion of the fronto-temporal/parietal network is an element of the singularity of the human DMN.
coauthors: Clément M.Garin, Department of Neurobiology and Anatomy, Wake Forest University School of Medicine, Winston-Salem, NC 27157; Christopher T. Whitlow, Department of Radiology, Wake Forest School of Medicine, Section of Neuroradiology, Winston-Salem, North Carolina, United States.; Finnegan J Calabro, Department of Psychiatry, University of Pittsburgh, Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania; Department of Psychology, University of Pittsburgh, Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania. Electronic address: lunab@upmc.edu.; Beatriz Luna, Department of Psychiatry, University of Pittsburgh, Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania; Department of Psychology, University of Pittsburgh, Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania. Electronic address: lunab@upmc.edu.; Marc Dhenain, Centre National de la Recherche Scientifique (CNRS), Université Paris-Sud, Université Paris-Saclay UMR 9199, Neurodegenerative Diseases Laboratory, 18 Route du Panorama, F-92265 Fontenay-aux-Roses, France; Christos Constantinidis, Department of Neurobiology and Anatomy, Wake Forest University School of Medicine, Winston-Salem, NC 27157
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Sleep does not facilitate human fear memory consolidation
abstract:
Introduction
The positive effects of sleep on the consolidation of declarative memories are generally well known. The role of sleep in consolidation of fear memories has not received as much attention. Moreover, only a few studies in humans have used physiological indices of conditioning, and none used central physiological measures. In the current study we investigated how sleep affects (1) consolidation of fear memories on behavioral level and (2) central measures of fear conditioned response by means of EEG.
Methods
In our experiment event-related brain potentials (ERP) were recorded during a fear conditioning procedure presented twice, before and after sleep or control intervention in 18 healthy young individuals. The procedure involved pairing of a neutral tone (CS+) with a highly unpleasant sound (UCS+). As a control, another neutral tone (CS-) was paired with a neutral (for some subjects slightly pleasant) sound (UCS-). The two sessions of conditioning were separated by approximately 2.5 hours when: on one experimental day subjects watched a silent movie for 2h (wake intervention); on another day the participants had 2h sleep opportunity (sleep intervention). The two days were separated by at least two weeks and counterbalanced in respect to the stimulus mapping. 
Results
In EEG differential conditioning manifested itself in the contingent negative variance (CNV)-like slow ERP component. Both period of sleep and wakefulness resulted in increased amplitude of the CNV to CS+ (main effect of contingency F(1,17) = 17.6, p < 0.001) without a significant difference between the type of intervention. The same effect was obtained on the behavioral level, with Valence ratings of CS+ were more negative as compared to CS- (F(1,17) = 14.9, p < 0.001). The intervention (sleep/wake) followed by a block of extinction learning. Relearning of fear after the extinction elicited stronger differential response in CNV (main effect of Time (before-after comparison) F(1,17) = 6.5, p = .02) but not in the behavioral ratings (F(1,17) = 0.66, p = .426).
Conclusions
The data indicate that fear memories are consolidated with the course of time with no beneficial effect of sleep or a period of wakefulness.
coauthors: Yuri G. Pavlov, University of Tuebingen; Boris Kotchoubey, Univesity of Tuebingen
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Motor cortical control of vocal behavior in neotropical singing mice
abstract: Using sounds for social interactions is common across many taxa. Humans engaged in conversation, for example, take rapid turns to go back and forth. This ability to act upon sensory information to generate a desired motor output is a fundamental feature of animal behavior. How the brain enables such flexible sensorimotor transformations, for example during vocal interactions, is a central question in neuroscience. Seeking a rodent model to fill this niche, we are investigating neural mechanisms of vocal interaction in Alston’s singing mouse (Scotinomys teguina) – a neotropical rodent native to the cloud forests of Central America. We discovered sub-second temporal coordination of advertisement songs (counter-singing) between males of this species – a behavior that requires the rapid modification of motor outputs in response to auditory cues. We leveraged this natural behavior to probe the neural mechanisms that generate and allow fast and flexible vocal communication. Using causal manipulations, we recently showed that an orofacial motor cortical area (OMC) in this rodent is required for vocal interactions. Subsequently, in electrophysiological recordings, I find neurons in OMC that track initiation, termination and relative timing of songs. Interestingly, persistent neural dynamics during song progression stretches or compresses on every trial to match the total song duration. These results demonstrate robust cortical control of vocal timing in a rodent and questions the current dogma that motor cortical control of vocal output is evolutionarily restricted to the primate lineage.
coauthors: Michael Long, NYU;
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Dissecting Transient Burst Events
abstract:
Neural activity recorded from the scalp [magneto-/electroencephalogram (M/EEG)], cortical surface [electrocorticogram (EcoG)], or inside the brain [local field potential (LFP)] is traditionally analysed by averaging tens to hundreds of trials. The trial-wise average of spectrograms commonly shows periods of sustained high or low spectral power. The underlying single trial activity may manifest as oscillations (i.e., sustained rhythmic fluctuations of synchronous spiking activity) or burst-like events. Burst-like events are intermittent, transient periods of synchronous spiking activity. 
Events have a temporal, spectral, and spatial domain. However, most work so far has focussed on temporal event characteristics. Events are thereby compressed to a singular dimension, by reducing the spatial and spectral domains of their underlying signals. Domain reduction can have several un- wanted consequences. First, different domain reduction methods likely result in differences in event characteristics. Second, domain reduction can obscure interactions (e.g. temporal-spatial interaction also known as traveling wave) between domains, which may lead to ambiguous inferences and conclusions drawn from these analyses.
Considering all three domains will yield a more accurate description of individual event characteristics and their interactions. This is likely to underpin identification of more precise fingerprints of mechanisms underlying differences in population activity measures, such as spectral power. In turn, this can guide development of rational and mechanistically grounded treatments that target neurological and psychiatric conditions.
coauthors: Andrew J Quinn, University of Oxford; Lydia C Mardell, UCL; Nick S Ward, UCL; Sven Besmann, UCL
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Paired Stimulation in the Human Limbic System Induced Functional Connectivity Changes Consistent with Spike-Timing-Dependent Plasticity
abstract: Many neurological disorders can be attributed to abnormal neural dynamics at the network level, which arise from anomalous neural connectivity. As a result, spatially and temporally specific brain stimulation protocols can be designed to take advantage of our brain’s natural plasticity, reorganize selected neural connections, and serve as a potential therapy for various brain disorders. One of the proposed mechanisms for inducing targeted functional changes in the brain is spike-timing-dependent plasticity (STDP), which suggests that long-term potentiation (LTP) will be induced in two connected neurons when presynaptic spikes lead postsynaptic spikes by 0 to 20 ms. Although strong evidence of STDP has been found for synapses in vitro, its presence at the network level in awake human brains remains unclear. To investigate the relevance of STDP in humans, we applied paired-pulse electrical stimulation with different time delays, and recorded local field potentials (LFPs) from multiple epilepsy patients using implanted depth and electrocorticography (ECoG) grid electrodes. We assessed the functional connectivity between recorded brain regions in the limbic system as quantified by the coherence between LFPs. Our results showed that both stimulation paradigms significantly altered the functional connectivity between brain regions compared to control. Meanwhile, paired stimulation with 10-ms delay led to greater increase in LFP coherence compared to that with 100-ms delay across multiple frequency bands. These results support the role for an STDP-like process in the emotion processing regions of the human brain.
coauthors: Kira Evitts, University of Washington; Samantha Sun, University of Washington; Ankit Khambhati, University of California, San Francisco; Kristin Sellers, University of California, San Francisco; Edward Chang, University of California, San Francisco; Azadeh Yazdan-Shahmorad, Washington National Primate Research Center, University of Washington, and University of California, San Francisco
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Batch Effects are Causal Effects: Applications in Human Functional Connectomes
abstract: Batch effects, accidental sources of variance across multiple experiments, present a substantial hurdle for statistical inference. These batch effects have been implicated in multiple widespread problems, including the reproducibility crisis. Typical batch mitigation strategies, which normalize each dataset individually, view batch mitigation fundamentally as a statistical problem. We turn this view on its head, and cast batch effects as a causal problem, namely, the experimental site causes additional sources of variation, over and above the sources of variation within site. We applied this strategy to 24 datasets in the “Consortium for Reliability and Reproducibility”. We illustrate that typical approaches amount to testing for independence, and therefore fail to address confounding variables. Such approaches are estimating the wrong estimand, and therefore, are invalid for quantifying batch effects when viewed from the causal perspective. Combining a causal view of batch mitigation with classical approaches (such as ComBat) yields satisfactory batch estimation and mitigation, while also preserving statistical patterns of interest. This framework can be applied to improve our understanding of the sources of batch effects, and enable more effective data aggregation strategies.
coauthors: Eric W. Bridgeford, Johns Hopkins University; Michael Powell, Johns Hopkins University; Anton Alyakin, Johns Hopkins University; Brian Caffo, Johns Hopkins University; Joshua T. Vogelstein, Johns Hopkins University
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: A motor adaptation paradigm to strengthen implicit learning
abstract:
When our intended movements have unintended outcomes, the human motor system can quickly adapt future movements. Motor output is modified in a way such that motor errors, that is, the difference between the expected and the perceived consequences of any motor output, are reduced. Both explicit and implicit neural processes play key roles in adaptation. Explicit processes, such as the effortful use of conscious strategies to counter a perturbation, can be quickly employed and allow for flexibility in rapidly changing conditions. Implicit processes on the other hand, such as the unconscious updating of internal models, supposedly arise slowly but do allow for reliable, persistent changes in the motor system. When adapting reaching movements, implicit components of adaptation have been demonstrated to have an upper boundary in the amount by which they alter future movements, regardless of the size of the experienced perturbation [1]; that is, they are thought to be limited in scope. Here, we allow participants to adapt to small, consistent errors, and when they have done so, introduce further small errors. Consequently, we show that the proposed upper boundary on implicit adaptation can be overcome. We also show that the additional implicit learning observed is not caused by simply gradually increasing the perturbation to prevent explicit strategies. This suggests that while additional implicit adaptation is difficult to achieve during tasks with large, salient errors, and in tasks with slowly introduced errors, it may be achievable by evoking multiple distinct error correction steps.

1. 	Bond KM, Taylor JA. Flexible explicit but rigid implicit learning in a visuomotor adaptation task. J Neurophysiol. 2015; doi:10.1152/jn.00009.2015
coauthors: Shanaathanan Modchalingam, York University; Marco Ciccone, York University; Bernard Marius ’t Hart, York University; Denise Henriques, York University
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Development of autophagy-inducing peptides as a potential therapy for motor neurone disease
abstract: The pathological hallmark of a range of neurodegenerative diseases, including Motor Neurone Disease (MND) is the presence of protein inclusions and aggregates in affected neurons. Aggregates progress continually from the site of onset to disturb cellular processes, ultimately resulting in neuron degeneration1. The only intracellular degradative pathway that can purge the cells of these misfolded proteins, aggregates, and dysfunctional organelles is autophagy. Since impaired/reduced autophagy may contribute to MND pathogenesis; upregulating autophagy offers a potential therapeutic option. This study aimed to develop and synthesize novel pharmacological agents that have non-toxic autophagy-inducing properties in motor neuronal NSC-34 cells. A series of peptides analogues of the evolutionary conserved domain of Beclin1 protein, the master regulator of autophagy, were designed and synthesized. In order to enhance the cellular uptake and increase the cytosolic bioavailability, the peptides were cyclized, and conjugated to a cell-penetrating peptide domain, and an endosomal escape domain. The autophagy-inducing effect of the peptides was determined by measuring the level of autophagosome-associated LC3-II, a marker of macroautophagy, in NSC-34 cells. We have shown that the peptides are capable of inducing autophagy at 5 micromolar concentration, which is 10-fold more potent than the previously reported Beclin-1 analogues. More importantly, the most potent peptide analogue significantly decreased aggregate-prone MND-associated protein levels and reduced their toxicity. This study provides in vitro evidence for a novel peptide-based approach to enhance autophagy as a unique and safe treatment modality with potential therapeutic benefit in MND and other proteinopathies.
coauthors: Nirma Perrera, Florey Institute of Neuroscience and Mental Health; Bradley Turner, Florey Institute of Neuroscience and Mental Health; Fazel Shabanpoor, Florey Institute of Neuroscience and Mental Health
institution: Florey Institute of Neuroscience and Mental Health (grid.418025.a)
theme: Theme A: Development, Neurodegenerative Disorders and Injury

title: Memory suppression and fear extinction related to emotional cues
abstract:
Background
Disparate research in animals and humans have shown reduced influence of fearful memory as an automatic process and a volitional process. It’s unclear whether volitional emotional memory suppression largely involves the same neural circuitry as automatic fear extinction.

Objective
To validate an examination of neural associations/dissociations between volitional memory suppression and fear extinction, we behaviorally tested both memory suppression and fear extinction. We aimed to identify what components of the memory are consciously reduced during suppression.

Methods
Participants (N=24) first learned 32 pairs of pictures: neutral human faces with either neutral images (NEU) or fearful scenes (NEG). Next, a neutral face would be shown and participants would be asked to either think about (THINK), suppress (NO THINK), or neither think about nor suppress (EXTINCT) the paired image; some faces weren’t shown (BASELINE). Participants then rated each face on how pleasant or unpleasant it made them feel and were asked to remember if the associated picture was negative or neutral.

Results
Within the ratings, there were significant main effects of Valence (p<.001), Condition (p<.001), and a significant interaction of Condition by Valence (p=.02). Think NEG showed that valence is lower than Baseline NEG (p = .012), while Extinction NEG showed that valence is higher than Baseline (p = .011).
Within the recall, there was a significant interaction of Condition by Valence (p=.02). NEG Think has the highest recall (92.71%) and there is a significant difference between NEG Think and NEG No Think (92.71 vs. 70.83%, p=.001) Additionally, NEG Think is significantly above baseline (p=.006), while NEG No Think is below baseline (although n.s., p=.38).
 
Conclusions
 Think related to enhancement in memory recall and the most negative ratings of the paired neutral faces. No Think was associated with worsened recall, but valence ratings were right around baseline. Extinction did not alter memory, but valence became less negative.
coauthors: L. Knight, University of Louisville; B. E. Depue, University of Louisville
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: The hippocampus promotes formation of long-term memory for objects in rats by preventing sensory interference after learning
abstract: Damage to the medial temporal lobe, notably the hippocampus, often leads to anterograde amnesia for declarative memories, but it remains unresolved how this deficit arises. Addressing this issue, we have proposed in our active decay theory that the hippocampus supports long-term memory formation by protecting against ongoing sensory stimulation which interferes with the stabilisation of newly formed content representations residing in extra-hippocampal areas. Efficient pattern separation within the hippocampus is predicted to promote resistance to interference and representation overlap. Thus, without a functioning hippocampus, ongoing sensory stimulation will lead to states of catastrophic interference in these brain regions, manifesting behaviourally as anterograde amnesia. Here, we report our results testing this hypothesis with an object recognition task in rats as a model for human declarative memories. Importantly, expression of long-term object recognition memory requires the perirhinal cortex, not the hippocampus in rats. We found (1) that inactivating hippocampus prior to object learning with intrahippocampal injections of GABAA and -B agonists (muscimol+baclofen) impaired object recognition tested 24 h after learning. (2) This deficit was absent when we placed rats into a highly familiar dark chamber right after object learning to reduce sensory stimulation during the memory stabilization period. Our findings support our theoretical model and suggest that anterograde amnesia due to hippocampal damage arises from heightened vulnerability to interference from ongoing sensory stimulation during phases of memory stabilization.
coauthors: Daisy Arkell, University of Edinburgh, Centre for Discovery Brain Sciences and Simons Initiative for the Developing Brain; Emma Wood, University of Edinburgh, Centre for Discovery Brain Sciences and Simons Initiative for the Developing Brain; Oliver Hardt, McGill University, Patrick Wild Centre and Simons Initiative for the Developing Brain
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Assessing Limitations of Three-Factor Hebbian Learning Relative to Deep Reinforcement Learning
abstract:
Three-Factor Hebbian Learning (also known as Reward-Modulated Hebbian Learning) is an important framework for neuroscientists because it provides a biologically relevant framework for modeling learning in the brain. However, the effectiveness of Three-Factor Learning, which specifies that synaptic plasticity is driven only by presynaptic activity, postsynaptic activity, and a global neuromodulator, is limited. By contrast, Deep Reinforcement Learning (DRL) provides more computationally powerful learning rules that typically use an additional factor related to the influence of the synapse or neuron towards the action taken by the agent. However, the biological relevance of these rules is less well understood. The primary goal of this project is to better understand the specific network and task conditions that cause Three-Factor Learning agents to fail, and the specific features of DRL algorithms that can overcome these problems and thus could potentially have relevance to learning in the brain.

We consider four primary challenges that the brain must overcome to learn effectively. The first is adding uncertainty to the time of stimulus onset on each trial, which is typically used in real-world learning tasks but less often in simulations. The second is adding multiple stimulus dimensions and changing which one is relevant for learning at a given time. The third is network complexity, including simply moving from a simple linear network that is used in many simple modeling exercises to a multi-layer network needed to solve more complex problems. The fourth is additional forms of plasticity, such as a perceptual learning-like mechanism that can affect the input to the network, that must interact synergistically with other learning in the network to produce appropriate outputs. Preliminary results suggest that each of these challenges are overcome more effectively by DRL algorithms than Three-Factor Hebbian rules, implying a potential role for those algorithms in the brain.
coauthors: Joshua Gold, University of Pennsylvania; Konrad Kording, University of Pennsylvania; Blake Richards, McGill University; Vijay Balasubramanian, University of Pennsylvania
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Social gradients: Cross-sectional and longitudinal evidence of differential functional embedding and plasticity of the social brain
abstract: Social interaction is key to human survival and has been proposed to be linked to the organization of the cerebral cortex. In a sample of healthy adults (N=332) we determined that task-based networks implicated in attention, empathy, and ToM-processing are topologically ordered along a social gradient from internal to external cognitive functions and have differentiable behavioral, functional, and genetic associations. We found domain-specific change in functional topology following a mental training intervention addressing attention and interoception, socio-affective skills, and socio-cognitive skills respectively. Attention-based practice resulted in segregation of cortical association networks, whereas socio-cognitive training resulted in their integration, reflecting a dissociation between cognitive quiescence and active thought. Socio-affective training had balancing effects on functional network organization, related to the regulating function of emotion. Together, our results show that social interaction involves a modifiable balance of network integration and segregation embedded along a social gradient from external to internal cognitive functions.
coauthors: Philipp Kanske, TU Dresden, Germany; Bo-yong Park, MNI, Canada; Seok-Jun Hong, Sungkyunkwan University, South Korea; Anne Böckler-Raettig, University of Hannover, Germany; Fynn-Mathis Trautwein, University of Freiburg, Germany; Boris C. Bernhardt*, MNI, Canada; Tania Singer*, Social neuroscience lab, Germany
institution: Max Planck Institute for Human Cognitive and Brain Sciences (grid.419524.f)
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Neuromatch 3.0 Opening Session
abstract: Welcome to Neuromatch Conference 3.0! This year has been full of challenges and new opportunities. The neuromatch team is excited to welcome you to the meeting and highlight some of our ideas and experiments toward making the future of neuroscience conferences as open, accessible, and exciting as possible.

title: Epigenetic signature of FKBP5 is associated with structural changes in emotion regulatory brain circuits
abstract: Disturbances in regulatory brain circuits involved in neural stress and emotion processing are commonly observed across many psychiatric disorders. Prominently, the anterior cingulate cortex (ACC) and medial prefrontal cortex (mPFC) serve as convergence sites for genetic and environmental risk factors. Epigenetic disinhibition of FKBP5, a regulator of the HPA-axis, might be a biological mechanism that translates environmental influences into altered brain function. Two specific DNA-Methylation (DNAm) loci have recently been identified as being particularly relevant for the epigenetic regulation of FKBP5. Here, we investigate the brain structural correlates of these epigenetic loci. In total 395 (194 women; age:28.12±10.45) healthy caucasian subjects underwent structural T1 MRI-Scans. Data was preprocessed using the CAT12 toolbox (in SPM12) following standard procedures. DNAm was assessed using the Illumina EPIC array and residualized for sex, age, cell composition, smoking and the first 10 PCs. The DNAm of the two loci of interest, cg20813374 and cg00130530, were averaged. Two General Linear Models on grey matter volume with (i) FKBP5 DNAm [n=395] and (ii) the trait version of the State and Trait Anxiety Inventory (STAI-T) [n=224] as predictors were build. Region-of-interest (ROI) analyses with ROI comprising  ACC, mPFC, Hippocampus and Amygdala were conducted. FKBP5 DNAm was significantly associated with grey matter volume in the medial Orbitofrontal Cortex (T=4.37, p=.030 Family-wise error (FWE)-corrected in ROI). Within the FKBP5-dependent morphometric changes trait anxiety was negatively associated with perigenual ACC volume (T=-3.61, p=.044 FWE-corrected in ROI). We demonstrate that DNAm of key loci in FKBP5 and established risk markers for affective disorders converge on the same regions within a well-known brain circuits underlying neural stress processing, highlighting the importance of brain circuits in translating epigenetic into psychological risk.
coauthors: Thomas Leon Kremer, University Heidelberg; Urs Braun, University Heidelberg; Junfang Chen, University Heidelberg; Anais Harneit, University Heidelberg; Kristina Schwarz, University Heidelberg; Janina I. Schweiger, University Heidelberg; Markus Reichert, University Heidelberg; Emanuel Schwarz, University Heidelberg; Andreas Meyer-Lindenberg, University Heidelberg; Heike Tost, University Heidelberg
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Emergent Sequential Task Learning Facilitates Convergence in Recurrent Neural Networks
abstract: Neuronal networks can learn to maintain stimulus information in order to solve working memory tasks. Here, tasks are defined by their loss function that is optimised to solve the task. Loss functions can vary in difficulty, and various machine learning strategies have been developed to catalyse learning, such as drop-out, adaptive learning rates and various gradient descent methods. But these are all technical improvements of the involved algorithms, and do not inform us of how animal learning might be improved. Instead, we have identified a different, non-trivial strategy to improve learning, by adding a second, easier task to the loss function. Our original task requires a recurrent neural network to report the trial type at the end of each trial, by accumulating information throughout the trial. This is a difficult task to learn, and networks often fail to converge. This changes when an additional component is added to the loss function that requires networks to make short-term predictions throughout the trial, thus informing them of the trial structure. Networks emerge to learn to solve the second task first, thereby changing the functional profile of their neurons, after which they also learn to minimise the first component of the loss function. This unsupervised, sequential learning behaviour provides a new perspective on task optimisation. It shows that networks can decompose a loss function and learn its parts in an optimal sequence. This principle could potentially be applied to other difficult tasks, arguing that they may be solved by using additional, easier tasks, serving as a warm start to the network.
coauthors: Sanjay Manohar, University of Oxford; Tim Vogels, IST Vienna;
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Ethical considerations for vocal biomarker research
abstract:
Over 30 million Americans – roughly 8% of the U.S. population - are affected by psychiatric and neurological diseases (PaNDs). Despite this high prevalence, few cost-effective tools exist to objectively diagnose PaNDs early. As a result, PaNDs are usually treated only after advanced symptoms appear, leading to high costs and poor patient outcomes. There is thus a strong need to create low-cost and highly accurate biomarkers to streamline early-stage PaNDs diagnosis.

Perhaps the most promising area for early diagnosis of PaNDs is through vocal biomarkers. There are multiple benefits to this approach including: 1) the cost to acquire and process voice data is low (~$0.03/sample); 2) the tools to collect voice data are widely accessible (68% of US population owns a smartphone); and 3) voice-based machine learning models are highly accurate at detecting symptoms of PaNDs up to five years earlier relative to the standard of care (e.g. in Alzheimer’s disease).

Despite great promise, the potential rapid growth of the voice space raises a host of early neuroethical concerns.  As the voice tech space grows, individuals may become subject to algorithmic bias. Algorithmic bias has manifested in the facial recognition space, for example, due to the lack of diversity in datasets. The shortcomings of these datasets result in a spectrum of unwanted bias - from not unlocking your own phone to being falsely arrested as a wanted criminal. 

The voice space can prevent algorithmic bias early on by monitoring the data collected and use of technology. Rather than collecting as much data as possible to train initial predictive algorithms, the voice space must ensure that the data is representative of diverse populations in order to mitigate harmful biases.
coauthors: Jim Schwoebel
theme: Theme F: History, Education and Society

title: Modulating RPTPσ promotes functional recovery in experimental models of multiple sclerosis
abstract:
Changes in chondroitin sulphate proteoglycans (CSPGs) following neural injury or as part of a neurodegenerative process lead to the inhibition of myelin repair. In Multiple sclerosis, CSPGs are deposited at the border of active and expanding demyelinating lesions and may create a barrier for regeneration and contribute to neurodegeneration. CSPG inhibition of axonal regeneration is partially mediated by the protein tyrosine phosphatase sigma (PTPσ) receptor. PTPσ is also the main player of CSPG inhibition of oligodendrocyte (OL) outgrowth and myelination. Intracellular sigma peptide (ISP) binds to PTPσ and relieves CSPG-mediated inhibition and has been used to promote regeneration after spinal cord injury. Identification of PTPσ as a functional receptor for CSPGs presents a promising avenue of investigation to rescue OL activity and promote recovery in demyelinating lesions.

Here we show that ISP treatment can improve functional recovery in animal models of multiple sclerosis and highlight cellular changes involved in the process. The EAE mice treated with ISP significantly recovered hindlimb function, and showed considerably reduced neuroinflammation and immune infiltration, smaller demyelinating lesion sites, and significantly more neurofilament sparing. After systemic demyelination, mice that received ISP showed motor and cognitive improvements that correlated with increased remyelination and decreased neuroinflammation.  We further demonstrate that delaying ISP administration by two weeks in a chronic disease model leads to a lesser degree of functional and histological improvements while still significantly improving the condition, highlighting the importance of modulating CSPG signalling at an incipient stage of the disease. In vitro, astrocytes, microglia and OPCs exposed to CSPGs showed inhibitory responses that were ameliorated by ISP addition .  Overall, our results suggest an exciting avenue for regeneration by targeting RPTPσ, supporting further consideration for therapeutic usage.
coauthors: Li Rong, School of Biomedical Sciences, LKS Faculty of Medicine, The University of Hong Kong, Hong Kong; Rong Liu, School of Biomedical Sciences, LKS Faculty of Medicine, The University of Hong Kong, Hong Kong;  Haitao Sun 2 Department of Neurosurgery, Zhujiang Hospital, Southern Medical University, Guangzhou, China;  Jiandong Huang, State Key Laboratory of Brain and Cognitive Sciences, The University of Hong Kong, Hong Kong and School of Biomedical Sciences, LKS Faculty of Medicine, The University of Hong Kong, Hong Kong; Wutian Wu, Joint Laboratory for Brain Function and Health (BFAH), Jinan University and The University of Hong Kong, Guangzhou, China and Re-Stem Biotechnology Co. Ltd., Jiangsu, China
theme: Theme A: Development, Neurodegenerative Disorders and Injury

title: Network principles predict motor cortex population activity across movement speeds
abstract: Learned movements can be skillfully performed at different paces. What neural strategies produce this flexibility? Can they be predicted and understood by network modeling? We trained monkeys to perform a cycling task at different speeds, and trained artificial recurrent networks to generate the empirical muscle-activity patterns. Network solutions, combined with the principle that noise-robust dynamics require low trajectory tangling, yielded quantitative and qualitative predictions. To evaluate predictions, we recorded motor cortex population activity during the same task. Responses supported the hypothesis that the dominant neural signals reflect not muscle activity per se, but network-level strategies for generating muscle activity across speeds. Single-neuron responses were better described when regressed against network activity than when regressed against muscle activity. More deeply, population-level neural trajectories were structured differently from muscle trajectories. Neural trajectories had an organization that maintained low trajectory tangling within and across speeds, matching the structure of network solutions.
coauthors: Abigail Russo, Princeton University; John Cunningham, Columbia University; Mark Churchland, Columbia University
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Sensorimotor beta activity is transient even during sustained motor output
abstract: Recently, it has been suggested that beta-frequency patterns of neural activity (13-30Hz) are transient rather than sustained. However, to date, this has been demonstrated predominantly in studies with non-sustained task demands. Here, we revisited the transient vs. sustained nature of sensorimotor beta activity in an isometric contraction task designed to yield sustained behavioural output. During sustained muscle contraction, beta activity in sensorimotor cortices is known to become coherent with the muscle, resulting in cortico-muscular coherence (CMC). We hypothesised that if CMC is responsible for sustained motor contraction, beta activity should be sustained in this context. We measured magnetoencephalography (MEG) and electromyography (EMG) while participants (N = 18) performed a sustained motor task (gripping). To accurately disentangle the burst vs. sustained oscillation scenarios, we analysed MEG time-series in motor channels with Empirical Mode Decomposition (EMD) – a data-driven signal decomposition method with high temporal resolution. We replicated the finding that beta activity is modulated by global task structure: beta power in motor brain areas and the muscle was particularly prominent while participants held a steady grip. Correspondingly, we observed beta CMC during gripping. Nevertheless, at the single trial level, beta activity in the brain and the muscle appeared transient. When collapsing all periods of high and low beta power in the brain (beta ON and OFF periods), we confirmed that transient ON periods in the brain were paralleled by a corresponding short-lasting increase in beta power in the muscle and by a similarly time-limited CMC, despite sustained motor output. These transient beta ON periods were not due to transient changes in participants’ grip. We finally found that beta “bursts” during gripping were of similarly short duration as those recorded in the same participants during rest. Together, these findings show that beta activity and connectivity is “bursty” even during sustained motor output.
coauthors: Andrew J. Quinn, Oxford Centre for Human Brain Activity, Wellcome Centre for Integrative Neuroimaging, Department of Psychiatry, University of Oxford, Oxford, United Kingdom; Nahid Zokaei, Oxford Centre for Human Brain Activity, Wellcome Centre for Integrative Neuroimaging, Department of Psychiatry, University of Oxford, Oxford, United Kingdom, Department of Experimental Psychology, University of Oxford, OX1 3UD Oxford, United Kingdom; Freek van Ede, Institute for Brain and Behavior Amsterdam, Department of Experimental and Applied Psychology, Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam, The Netherlands; Anna C. Nobre, Oxford Centre for Human Brain Activity, Wellcome Centre for Integrative Neuroimaging, Department of Psychiatry, University of Oxford, Oxford, United Kingdom, Department of Experimental Psychology, University of Oxford, OX1 3UD Oxford, United Kingdom
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: BRAIN Initiative Alliance Tools, Tech, Theory, and Trainee Series: Tech (part 2)
abstract:
The BRAIN Initiative Alliance (http://www.braininitiative.org/) is hosting a virtual series in collaboration with Neuromatch 3.0 to highlight cutting-edge tools, technology, and theories emerging from the US BRAIN Initiative. The event is divided into three session to focus on 1) Tools (probes, optics, cellular, molecular), 2) Tech (software, hardware), and 3) Theory (modeling, computation),  with trainees integrated in each session. Each session will include five brief talks/demos showcasing new tools, techniques, or theories from US BRAIN Initiative toolmakers followed by a moderated discussion with Q/A.

This is session 2/3, focused on Tech (software, hardware).

Moderator:
- Jacob Robinson, PhD (Rice University)

Talks:
- "Closed-loop deep brain stimulation approaches using wearable sensors"
Stephanie Cernera, BS (University of Florida)

- "Polymer Implantable Electrode Arrays"
Ellis Meng, PhD (University of Southern California)

- "Deep-brain connectomics on functionally-identified neurons:application to grid cells"
Alexander Riordan, MA (Princeton University)

- "Advances in Multi-Electrode Arrays for Single Motor Unit Recordings"
Sam Sober, PhD (Emory University), Bryce Chung, PhD (Emory University) and Muneeb Zia, PhD (Georgia Institute of Technology)

- "Non-invasive, Deep Brain, and Focal Neuromodulation in Nonhuman Primates"
Taylor Webb, PhD (University of Utah)
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Amodal statistical completion of occluded objects
abstract: It is well known that the visual system amodally completes occluded edges in a display. But real-world objects have more complex edges and yet, we have no trouble recognizing them even when they are occluded. Does our visual system extrapolate more complex types of information based on the statistics of the visible portion of an object? To answer this question, we performed a series of visual search experiments. We created occluded displays in which a shape was occluded in its top-left corner, and two alternative shapes whose contours were identical in the unoccluded portion but differed in the occluded portion such that one appeared to be the more likely object behind the occluder, and the other more unlikely. We then asked whether perceptual dissimilarities measured using visual search in the occluded conditions were correlated with the perceptual dissimilarities of the likely pairs or unlikely pairs. Across different sets of shapes organized on candidate features for perceptual completion (here: ‘numerosity’ of protrusions,  ‘curvature’ between straight edges etc.), we observed that occluded dissimilarities were more correlated with the likely shape dissimilarities (r = 0.90, p < 0.0005 for ‘numerosity’ set and r = 0.89, p < 0.0005 for ‘curvature’ set’) compared to unlikely shape dissimilarities (r = 0.68, p < 0.0005 for ‘numerosity’ set and r = 0.80, p < 0.0005 for ‘curvature’ set’). Taken together, our results show that amodal completion is far more complex than is believed, in that it can not only extrapolate simple edges but use statistical properties to complete occluded portions of objects.
coauthors: SP Arun, Indian Institute of Science
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Comparative Study of Fruit Fly Brain Circuit Models with FlyBrainLab
abstract:
Comparison of circuit models, either among versions developed by one’s own, or among those published in literature, is the critical but often neglected step towards discovering the functional logic of brain circuits. Three types of comparisons are of particular interest. The first is, starting from a given dataset and after building a number of circuit models published in the literature, to analyze and compare them under the same evaluation criteria. The second is to automate the construction of executable circuits from datasets gathered by different labs and, to analyze, evaluate and compare the different circuit realizations. The third is to analyze, evaluate and compare brain circuits at different developmental stages.

We recently developed the FlyBrainLab interactive computing platform whose main capabilities include 1) 3D exploration and visualization of fruit fly brain data, 2) creation of executable circuits directly from the fly brain data explored in step 1), and 3) interactive exploration of the functional logic of the devised executable circuits. Consequently, FlyBrainLab automates and greatly simplifies the construction of and the comparison between executable fly brain circuits.

To demonstrate the comprehensive capabilities of the FlyBrainLab, we present, respectively, three comparative studies of fruit fly brain circuit models. In the first example, we compare three circuit models of the fruit fly central complex from the literature, all based on the FlyCircuit dataset. In the second example, we demonstrate the effect on modeling the Antenna and the Antennal Lobe circuits developed upon, respectively, the FlyCircuit and the Hemibrain datasets. In the third example, we investigate the differences in odorant encoding and processing in the Drosophila early olfactory system at two different developmental stages, the adult and larva, based on the Hemibrain dataset and the Larva L1EM dataset, respectively. Each example is supported by a FlyBrainLab Circuit Library developed to facilitate the exploration of the neural circuit/subsystem of interest.
coauthors: Aurel A. Lazar; Tingkai Liu; Mehmet Kerem Turkcan; Yiyin Zhou;
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: A zebrafish fmr1 mutant reveals early developmental changes in behavior and sensory coding
abstract: Fragile X syndrome (FXS) is the most common inherited form of autism spectrum disorders (ASDs), and is caused by a mutation of the fragile X mental retardation 1 (fmr1) gene. Some of the key characteristics of FXS include visual processing abnormalities, visual-motor function deficits and social deficits. However, little is known about the developmental trajectory of FXS, particularly early visual processing and its effect on visually driven behaviours. Utilizing the unique advantages of the zebrafish model system, here we used behavioural recordings of zebrafish hunting events combined with in vivo 2-photon calcium imaging of the optic tectum to assess functional changes between fmr1-/- and fmr1+/- larval zebrafish at 5, 9 and 14 days post-fertilisation (dpf). fmr1-/- fish showed early deficits in natural hunting behaviours, delayed development of neural coding in the optic tectum, and altered development trajectory in tectal network properties. However, these metrics improved in the fmr1/- fish when they were exposed to reduced sensory stimulation during development. We then assessed social behaviour at 28 dpf, and found that fmr1-/- fish displayed increased social preference compared to wild-type fish but slower reactions to conspecific movement. Together these results help reveal how fmr-/- changes the early development of vertebrate brain function, and how manipulating the environment could potentially help reduce these changes.
coauthors: Michael McCullough, The University of Queensland; Zac Pujic, The University of Queensland; Jordan Sibberas, The University of Queensland; Biao Sun, The University of Queensland; Bianca Bucknall, The University of Queensland; Lilach Avitan, The University of Queensland; Geoffrey J Goodhill, The University of Queensland.
theme: Theme A: Development, Neurodegenerative Disorders and Injury

title: The Influence of Individually Ventilated Cage Conditions on Rats’ Anxiety-Related Behaviours
abstract: In recent years, many animal research facilities have transitioned from using traditional open-top cages (OTCs) to using individually ventilated cages (IVCs) to house rodent colonies. Although the use of IVCs has clear benefits, there have been unanticipated drawbacks. Some research has suggested that IVCs may lead to increased rodent stress levels, however, the exact cause for this increase remains unknown. One cage-condition that is unique to IVCs, and may be responsible for increasing stress levels, is the air pressure environment inside the cage. IVCs can be operated under negative or positive pressure, however, little is known about how air pressure might influence behaviour. The social housing of rodents in OTCs is known to buffer rodents’ responses to stress, and is a well-validated phenomenon termed “social buffering”. At present, it is unknown if this phenomenon carries over to rodents housed in IVCs, and if this “social buffering” response is dependent on the type of air pressure. Rats were randomly assigned to single- or paired-housing in IVCs under negative or positive pressure. Five weeks after housing assignment, rats’ anxiety-like behaviour was measured in the elevated plus maze (EPM), and their brain tissue was processed to examine oxytocin-immunoreactivity (OT-ir) in the hypothalamus. The anxiety-reducing effects of pair-housing were only evident in rats housed under positive pressure. Although there were no differences in the number of OT-ir cells in the paraventricular nucleus (PVN) of the hypothalamus between single- and pair-housed animals, a higher number of OT-ir cells in the PVN was significantly correlated with decreased anxiety-like behaviour. These findings suggest that IVCs may be altering well-validated behavioural profiles in rodents, and this may be in part due to the unique cage-conditions that IVCs present. As such, this research aims to improve the welfare of laboratory rodents by refining and improving their housing conditions.
coauthors: Emma Littler, Queen's University; Jessica MacKay, Queen's University; Janet Menard, Queen's University
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: How trial correlations and feedback shape sequential decision-making
abstract: To make the best decisions, organisms must flexibly accumulate information, accounting for what is relevant, and ignoring what is not. However, many decision-making studies focus on sequences of independent trials in which the evidence gathered to make a choice and the resulting actions are irrelevant to future decisions. An important and naturalistic aspect of such experiments is a probabilistic schedule of rewards, in which sometimes correct responses are not rewarded and sometimes incorrect responses are. For example, birds may correctly identify a fruitful tree but have difficulty harvesting the fruit. Normative theory has been developed for such tasks when reward is the sole evidence (e.g., two-armed bandit tasks), but less is known about how an observer should integrate probabilistic rewards that are interspersed with noisy evidence to inform their decisions in correlated trials. To understand decision-making under more natural conditions, we propose and analyze models of ideal observers who accumulate evidence to freely make choices across a sequence of correlated trials and receive uncertain feedback. We extend drift-diffusion models to obtain the normative form of evidence accumulation in a series of trials with the correct choice evolving as a two-state Markov process. We analyze three different feedback cases: no trial-to-trial feedback, probabilistic trial-to-trial feedback, and probabilistic reward as feedback. Ideal observers integrate noisy evidence within a trial until reaching a decision threshold and bias their initial belief depending on the evidence accumulated and feedback received on previous trials. Ideal observers optimize their reward rate across trials by adjusting their sequence of decision thresholds to deliberate longer on early decisions and respond more quickly in later trials. We show how conflicts between feedback and accumulated evidence are resolved, and under which conditions one of them dominates. Our findings are consistent with experimentally observed response trends.
coauthors: Kresimir Josic, University of Houston; Zachary Kilpatrick, University of Colorado Boulder
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Cell-Autonomous and Non-Autonomous Mechanisms Controlling Projection Neuron Migration
abstract: Concerted  radial  migration  of  newly  born  cortical  projection  neurons,  from  their  birthplace  to  their  final target  lamina,  is  a  key  step  in  the  assembly  of  the  cerebral  cortex.  The  cellular  and  molecular  mechanisms regulating  the  specific  sequential  steps  of  radial  neuronal  migration  in  vivo  are  however  still  unclear.  Recent evidence  suggests  that  distinct  signaling  cues  act  cell-autonomously  but  differentially  at  particular  steps during  the  overall  migration  process.  Functional  MADM  (Mosaic  Analysis  with  Double  Markers)  analyses in  comparison  to  global  knockout  also  indicate  a  significant  degree  of  non-cell-autonomous  and/or community  effects  in  the  control  of  cortical  neuron  migration.  Non-cell-autonomous  effects  may differentially  affect  cortical  neuron  migration  in  distinct  compartments  and  thus  regulate  critical  steps  in the  migration  process.  It  is  therefore  not  only  essential  to  determine  the  nature  of  the  interplay  of  cellautonomous  and  non-cell-autonomous  mechanisms  but  also  how  they  control  cortical  neuronal  migration. Here  we  established  a  MADM-based  experimental  strategy  for  the  analysis  of  cell-autonomous  versus  nonautonomous  gene  function  and/or  community  effects.  We  pursued  subtractive  phenotypic  analysis  of genetic  mosaics  (wild-type/heterozygote  background)  with  conditional  and/or  global  knockout  (mutant background),  both  coupled  with  sparse  fluorescent  MADM-labeling  of  homozygous  mutant  neurons,  to trace  the  sequential  steps  of  migration  in  4D.  Using  these  experimental  paradigms  we  define  so  far  unknown cell-autonomous  functions  of  candidate  signaling  pathways  intersecting  with  non-cell-autonomous  effects to  coordinate radial neuron migration.
theme: Theme A: Development, Neurodegenerative Disorders and Injury

title: Machine Learning methods for predicting conversion from mild cognitive impairment to Alzheimer’s disease. A systematic review.
abstract: Increase in life-span in our society is a double-edged sword that entails a growing number of patients with neurocognitive disorders, being Alzheimer’s disease (AD) the most prevalent. Advances in medical imaging and computational power, allow new methods to detect and hopefully prevent cognitive decline, especially in patients with mild cognitive impairment (MCI), a condition that might be considered a prodromal stage of AD. We conducted a systematic review following PRISMA guidelines of studies where Machine Learning (ML) was applied to neuroimaging data obtained from public databases in order to predict the progression from MCI to AD. We selected 30 studies and assessed their model performance based on its accuracy, sensitivity, specificity, and area under the receiver operating characteristic curve, to determine which algorithms combined with which neuroimaging techniques achieved better predictions. Results show that the best method to detect group differences between healthy, MCI (progressive and stable), and AD subjects is using large samples with multimodal and multidimensional data (neuroimage, clinical, cognitive, biological, and behavioral data) combined with Deep Learning models (as compared with other ML models such as Random Forest or Support Vector Machine). Although performance of the different models still have room for improvement, the results are promising and this methodology has a great potential as a support tool for clinicians and professionals from health institutions.
coauthors: Raquel Viejo-Sobera, Universitat Oberta de Catalunya
theme: Theme A: Development, Neurodegenerative Disorders and Injury

title: Reach-relevant somatosensory signals modulate the neural correlates of tactile suppression
abstract: Tactile signals arising from goal-directed movements are typically suppressed. This results mainly from an internal model predicting sensory consequences of the movement, and attenuating those feedback signals matching the predictions. Feedback signals are, however, important to successfully control goal-directed movements requiring a flexible modulation of these signals. Despite behavioral evidence supporting such modulations of tactile suppression, the neural implementation of this modulation is not clear. Here, we investigated the neural correlates of tactile suppression during reaching movements targeted either to a static finger (somatosensory reach) or to a touchscreen (external reach). In the latter case, reach-relevant signals arose only from the moving hand, while in the former case additional feedback signals from the target hand were available. To probe tactile suppression, participants received brief vibrotactile stimuli to the moving finger prior to reach. Somatosensory and external reaches resulted in tactile suppression compared to resting (baseline), with stronger suppression during somatosensory than external reaches, as expected. At the neural level, BOLD activation associated with suppression was modulated by the reach goal: processing of probes during somatosensory reaching led to distinct BOLD deactivations in fronto-parietal regions compared to baseline and external reaching. These deactivations were more pronounced during somatosensory than external reaching in regions linked with somatosensory processing (postcentral gyrus, anterior insula), and sensorimotor prediction and integration (supplementary motor area, supramarginal gyrus). Our results suggest modulation of movement-related somatosensory signals in regions associated with predictive and feedback processing.
coauthors: Belkis Ezgi Arikan, Experimental Psychology, Justus Liebig University Giessen; Dimitris Voudouris, Experimental Psychology, Justus Liebig University Giessen; Hanna Voudouri-Gertz, Experimental Psychology, Justus Liebig University Giessen; Katja Fiehler, Experimental Psychology, Justus Liebig University Giessen
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Differences between representations shaped by supervised and unsupervised learning rules
abstract: How the brain adjusts the synapses of individual neurons to support learning is an essential question in neuroscience. Backpropagation is the current most efficient solution for this problem in deep neural networks, and may be approximated by the brain to some extent. On the other hand, unsupervised learning rules like various forms of Hebbian learning are experimentally well supported, and are critical both during circuit development and learning from sensory information without supervision signals. The combination of supervised and unsupervised learning rules has therefore the potential to produce plasticity mechanisms that are both biologically plausible and can exploit their advantages. Here we study a learning rule combining backpropagation of gradients and an unsupervised Hebbian rule with competition between neurons, in a network receiving natural images as stimuli. The backpropagation objective is the image classification accuracy, while Hebbian learning causes emergence of typical visual receptive fields such as edge detectors, as well as less structured, random-looking kernels.  Results suggest while combined learning has similar classification performance with backpropagation alone, changes due to backpropagation may be small compared to changes of unsupervised learning. Structured receptive fields shaped by unsupervised learning result in a sparser contribution of neurons to correct prediction. When initialised from both random and structured kernels, random kernels tend to get more changes during backpropagation. Though unsupervised learned kernels seem to be slightly hindering the efficiency of backpropagation, they can better support transfer learning between classes. These suggest that top-down influences on early sensory receptive fields may generally be weak and experimentally hard to detect. The work is a first step in studying how to combine supervised and unsupervised learning rules to bring out respective advantages as well as learn in a more biologically plausible manner.
coauthors: Matthias Hennig
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Hippocampal Modulation of the Stress Response
abstract:
An essential adaptive function of the nervous system is to organize appropriate physiological and behavioral responses in the face of stressful situations. However, this process can become dysregulated in psychiatric disease. Characterizing the neural circuits that modify the adaptive stress response is essential to understand how the brain regulates responses to stressful stimuli and how that regulation can go awry. 
Here we use optogenetics, DREADDs, and in vivo calcium imaging to investigate whether the hippocampus modulates hypothalamic CRH stress responses. Our results suggest how the ventral hippocampus (vHPC) exerts top-down control over the paraventricular nucleus of the hypothalamus (PVN) to regulate responses to a stressful foot shock stimulus.
coauthors: Mazen Kheirbek, UCSF
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: A miniature microscope  for neuro + vascular imaging in freely moving animals
abstract:
Imaging multiple variables that characterize brain function in neuroscientific and preclinical animal models permits a better understanding of neurophysiology and its disruption in disease. However, multi-variable imaging systems need to acquire images with multiple contrasts, and therefore require inclusion of many optical components which make them large and stationary. Moreover, such systems are often custom designed, expensive, and restrict experimentation due to the need for anesthesia or animal head fixation. To overcome these challenges, we developed a portable, low-cost, miniature optical microscope capable of imaging three optical contrasts over a 3x3 mm2 field of view at 5 µm resolution. The microscope consists of a fluorescence (FL) channel for imaging neural activity (e.g. via GCaMP) or fluorescently tagged cells (e.g. 9L-GFP cancer cells); an intrinsic optical signal (IOS) channel for imaging hemoglobin absorption (i.e. cerebral blood volume); and a laser speckle contrast (LSC) channel for imaging perfusion (i.e. cerebral blood flow). Weighing 3g after strain relief, it can be used to conduct neuroimaging in freely behaving mice. 

First we compared images acquired via the miniature microscope for each channel with those acquired from a non-miniaturized imaging system, and demonstrated a high degree of correlation. We then used it to interrogate neurovascular coupling in an awake mouse auditory cortex in relation to two distinct sound stimuli at 4 kHz and 24 kHz, and characterized the unique spatial and temporal relationship between neuronal, vasodilatory and blood flow responses to each stimuli. We also used our microscope to investigate in vivo the progression of a brain tumor throughout the tumor’s life-cycle and mapped the stages of angiogenesis and the establishment of patent blood flow within the tumor microenvironment. 

We are working on the next generation of our microscope and looking for strategic partners to enable exciting discoveries in both basic neuroscience and preclinical research.
coauthors: Nitish V. Thakor; Arvind P. Pathak
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: The SNARE regulator Complexin 3 is a target of the cone circadian clock
abstract: Almost all living organisms have evolved rhythms of behavior and physiology to allow them to occupy temporal niches. One such rhythm is a circadian rhythm which allows organisms to preemptively adapt to changes in environment conditions driven by the daily light/dark cycle. Rhythms are generated by cell autonomous molecular clocks which drive rhythmic cell processes. BMAL1 is a core component of the mammalian circadian clockwork. Removal of BMAL1 from the retina significantly affects visual information processing in both rod and cone pathways. To identify potential pathways and/or molecules through which BMAL1 alters signal transmission at the cone pedicle, we performed an RNA‐seq differential expression analysis between cone‐specific Bmal1 knockout cones (cone‐Bmal1−/−) and wild‐type (WT) cones. We found 88 genes differentially expressed. Among these, Complexin3 (Cplx3), a SNARE regulator at ribbon synapses, was downregulated fivefold in the mutant cones. The purpose of this work was to determine whether BMAL1 and/or the cone clock controls CPLX3 protein expression at cone pedicles. We found that CPLX3 expression level was decreased twofold in cone‐Bmal1−/− cones. Furthermore, CPLX3 expression was downregulated at night compared to the day in WT cones but remained constitutively low in mutant cones both day and night. The transcript and protein expression levels of Cplx4—the other complexin expressed in cones—were similar in WT and mutant cones; in WT cones, CPLX4 protein level did not change with the time of day. In silico analysis revealed four potential BMAL1:CLOCK binding sites upstream from exon one of Cplx3 and none upstream of exon one of Cplx4. Our results suggest that CPLX3 expression is regulated at the transcriptional level by the cone clock. The modulation of CPLX3 may be a mechanism by which the clock controls the cone synaptic transfer function to second‐order cells and thereby impacts retinal signal processing during the day/night cycle.
coauthors: Zhijing Zhang, The University of Texas Health Science Center at Houston, Houston, TX; Christophe P. Ribelayga, The University of Texas Health Science Center at Houston, Houston, TX
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Socializing reduces distress-associated behavior in mice
abstract:
Lipopolysaccharide (LPS) induced neuroinflammation is a shared symptom for most neurodegenerative diseases. One of the harmful outcomes of presence of LPS in the brain is the cognitive impairment which is a result of a downstream inflammatory responses that had been initiated in the gut.
In animal models these cognitive impairments include lethargy, arched or curled body posture, inactivity, and reduced consumption. Socialization in animals is positively correlated with physical and mental, learning, and reduced mortality. The main goal of this study is to investigate if socialization through co-housing has a direct therapeutic effect on LPS induced neuroinflammation.
We utilized an LPS-induced endotoxemia model for our experiments. A total of 24 mice C57/BL6 mice were divided into two groups: socially isolated mice or co-housed mice.
Continuous seventy-two hours recording sessions were performed and videos were analyzed and scored. We found that co-housing mice not only reduced the recovery time but also decreased the duration of exhibition of the sickness behavior. Analysis showed that the single-housed mice displays sickness behavior, including extended hunched posture, for about thirty-five minutes following the LPS injection, while the co-house mice only spent twelve minutes displaying sickness behavior. In addition, there was a significant weigh loss in the LPS injected mice. Motion tracking analysis revealed that socially isolated LPS injected mice remained stationary for hours compared to co-housed mice. 
In conclusion, our findings show that co-housing mice post endotoxemia endotoxemia demonstrate therapeutic which could be further exploited for translational studies.
coauthors: Haohan  Wei, New York University ; Ayo Adewakun, New York University ;  Robert C. Froemke , New York University School of Medicine ; Jhimmy Talbot, New York University; Dan Littman, New York University
institution: New York University Langone Medical Center (grid.240324.3)
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Modeling Task Effects on Meaning Representation in the Brain via Zero-Shot MEG Prediction
abstract: How meaning is represented in the brain is still one of the big open questions in neuroscience. Does a word (e.g., bird) always have the same representation, or does the task under which the word is processed alter its representation (answering “can you eat it?” versus “can it fly?”)? The brain activity of subjects who read the same word while performing different semantic tasks has been shown to differ across tasks. However, it is still not understood how the task itself contributes to this difference. In the current work, we study Magnetoencephalography (MEG) brain recordings of participants tasked with answering questions about concrete nouns. We investigate the effect of the task (i.e. the question being asked) on the processing of the concrete noun by predicting the millisecond-resolution MEG recordings as a function of both the semantics of the noun and the task. Using this approach, we test several hypotheses about the task-stimulus interactions by comparing the zero-shot predictions made by these hypotheses for novel tasks and nouns not seen during training. We find that incorporating the task semantics significantly improves the prediction of MEG recordings, across participants. The improvement occurs 475 − 550ms after the participants first see the word, which corresponds to what is considered to be the ending time of semantic processing for a word. These results suggest that only the end of semantic processing of a word is task-dependent, and pose a challenge for future research to formulate new hypotheses for earlier task effects as a function of the task and stimuli.
coauthors: Mariya Toneva, Carnegie Mellon University; Otilia Stretcu, Carnegie Mellon University; Barnabas Poczos, Carnegie Mellon University; Leila Wehbe, Carnegie Mellon University; Tom Mitchell, Carnegie Mellon University
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Aging affects attentional span and perception in the periphery
abstract: Aging has been associated with decline in perceptual and cognitive function, but the findings remain inconclusive. Here we tested how attentional window, i.e. how widely we can distribute our attention around a certain fixation location when searching for an item among distractors, changes with aging. Specifically, we investigated whether aging resulted in a decrease in attentional window during easy or parallel visual search (global processing). We also tested whether performance in visual search was related to perceptual visual function with a contrast detection task and two motion tasks (local and global motion perception) at two different eccentricities (5° and 10° eccentricity). We measured the size of the attentional window using different sized gaze-contingent visible windows in 12 younger adults and 11 older adults during a pop-out visual search task. Older adults showed a significantly smaller attentional window (M = 19.4°, SD = 3.3°) compared to younger adults (M = 23.2°, SD = 2.3°). They also had significantly higher contrast detection thresholds (M older = 9.3%, SD older = 5.1%; M younger = 4.5%, SD younger = 2.8%) and required longer durations to estimate global motion (M older = 442.8 ms, SD older = 214.2 ms; M younger = 181.4 ms, SD younger = 75.3 ms). In contrast, we found no difference in local motion perception thresholds between groups. Taken together, our results suggest interactions between attentional and perceptual deficits may explain impaired visual function in older adults.
coauthors: Noémie Redureau, University of Montreal; Laure Pisella, ImpAct, INSERM UM1028, CNRS UMR 5292, University Claude Bernard Lyon 1; Aarlenne Z. Khan, University of Montreal
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Emotional Metacognition: Stimulus Valence Modulates Cardiac Arousal and Metamemory
abstract: Emotion alters how we feel, see, and experience the world. In the domain of memory, the emotional valence and arousal of memorized stimuli can modulate both the acuity and content of episodic recall. However, no experiment has investigated whether arousal and valence also influence metacognition for memory (i.e., the process of self-monitoring memories). In a pre-registered study, we applied a novel psychophysiological design together with computational models of metacognition to assess the influence of stimulus valence and arousal on the sensitivity, bias, and efficiency of metamemory. To estimate the role of physiological arousal in mediating these effects, we recorded cardiac measures through pulse oximetry. We found that negative valence globally and substantially decreased both memory performance and subjective confidence, in particular for low-arousal words. Simultaneously, we found that emotional valence modulated both heart rate and heart-rate variability (HRV), indicating a robust effect of negative valence on physiological arousal during recognition memory. Exploratory trial-level analyses further revealed that subjective confidence was encoded in instantaneous heart-rate fluctuations, and that this relationship was modulated by emotional valence. Our results demonstrate that both recognition memory and metacognition are influenced by the emotional contents of encoded items and that this correlation is in part related to cardiac activity.
coauthors: Nicolas Legrand;  Camile Correa;  Nanna Kildahl Mathiasen;  Niia Nikolova; Francesca Fardo;  Micah Allen
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: EDEN: A high-usability, high-performance, general-purpose neural simulator
abstract:
In-silico neuroscience is an important tool to define the conceptual models of neural networks, to deeply explore the emerging features of these models, and to guide subsequent in-vitro and in-vivo experiments.
We present EDEN, a novel neural simulator that can run all types of neural network models in the NeuroML v2.0 specification, and drastically reduces the required simulation time.
There is no model-specific programming required to run the models.
EDEN also performs full validation of the NeuroML models in use, and explains the causes of possible errors.
The simulator setup is integrated with the Python and Docker infrastructure. This way, EDEN can be effortlessly deployed on interactive Python notebooks, for a single person or a whole class.
Simulations are automatically further sped up with multi-core execution within a single PC, or throughout HPC clusters.
This way, even larger and more detailed models can be investigated in a practical timeframe.
coauthors: Harry Sidiropoulos, Erasmus University Medical Center; George Smaragdos, Erasmus University Medical Center; Mario Negrello, Erasmus University Medical Center; Dimitrios Soudris, National Technical University of Athens; Christos Strydis, Erasmus University Medical Center
