theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Long-lasting effects of starvation experience on fly activity and place preference
abstract: Animal behavior and actions are demonstrably governed by sensory stimulation and internal states like hunger. Depending on starvation levels, priorities shift between diverse energy-expensive activities and foraging/feeding. Flies are known to execute efficient path integration strategies during foraging. However, the long-term activity pattern for both hungry and satiated flies in conditions of foraging remain to be better understood. Similarly, little is known about how chronic contact chemosensory stimulation affects locomotion. To address these questions, we have developed a novel, simplistic fly activity tracking setup – the Panopticon. Our assay allows recording of walking behavior, of several flies in parallel, each surrounded by a uniform substrate layer. Individual animals are placed for >24 h in agarose-coated sectors of a 3D-printed Petri dish inset. We employ Fiji-based video tracking, followed by a custom-built MATLAB analysis framework, which allows multifaceted assessment of fly activity patterns, including representation of walking trails and location probability as a function of time.
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Teaching causality to neuroscientists
abstract: The standard curriculum for neuroscientists does not include a formal definition of causality, or any formal treatment of what methods exist to estimate a causal effect. Since a great number of neuroscientific questions are causal in nature – including questions of mediation, of connection, and of mechanism – we developed a fast, one-day curriculum to provide neuroscientists a working concept of how causality can be treated formally. In the third week of Neuromatch Academy, we presented these materials in an interactive problem-solving format, interspersed with video instruction, to over 1,700 students. Students from around the globe worked through this curriculum in live video conferencing in groups of around 10, each guided by a teaching assistant. After conclusion of the academy, we evaluated the success of these materials and their presentation with surveys provided to students and teachers. This talk will present our educational goals and approaches in consideration of what was most and least successful. The full academy curriculum is published online and openly available for re-use.
coauthors: Ari Benjamin, University of Pennsylvania; Tony Liu, University of Pennsylvania; Sofia Triantafillou, University of Pittsburgh; Eleanor Batty, Harvard University; Madineh Sarvestani, Max Planck Florida Institute; Konrad Kording, University of Pennsylvania;
theme: Theme F: History, Education and Society

title: Ethical Issues in Human Brain Organoid Research
theme: Theme F: History, Education and Society

title: A Method for Distinguishing Between Feedforward and Feedback Influences on Neural Responses
abstract: This neural activity of sensory neurons is not just the result of external stimuli - what may be thought of as a feedforward drive - but is also influenced by feedback signals reflecting internal variables. Distinguishing between the effects of external and internal influences on neural responses is therefore an important question for neural coding and in particular understanding the nature of response covariability (“noise correlations”). In prior studies, changes in neural covariability between different behavioral contexts were taken as evidence for the influence of feedback signals (Cohen & Newsome 2008, Bondy et al. 2018). Here, we propose a method to estimate the magnitude of task-related feedback without the need for data on a second task, by comparing neural variability in the task-relevant direction with the neural variability in other, equivalent directions in neural population response space. We validate our method using a model of realistic covariability induced by shared feedforward noise based on Kanitscheider et al. (2015). We extend that model by incorporating learnt receptive fields as well as variable feedback whose strength acts as ground truth for validating our method. In addition to a detailed analysis of the resulting correlation structure, we identify failure modes of the proposed method and perform a power analysis to obtain estimates of how much data is needed to reliably distinguish feedback from feedforward sources depending on the strength of the feedback injected.
coauthors: Samuel Alvernaz, University of Rochester; Richard Lange, University of Rochester; Ralf Haefner, University of Rochester;
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Activation of 5-HT2A receptors reconfigures cortico-limbic functional connectivity in rats
abstract:
5-HT2a receptor activation may contribute to the potential antidepressant effects of psychedelics.  5-HT2a agonists have been shown to induce High Frequency Oscillations (HFO, 125-145Hz) in diverse brain regions, but the mechanisms and relevance of these oscillations remain unclear.  Here, we quantify the effects of a selective 5-HT2a agonist 25I-NBOH (25I) on functional connectivity in the cortico-limbic system of behaving rats.  
5 adult male Wistar rats were implanted with local field potential recording electrodes in basolateral amygdala (BLA), dorsal hippocampus (dCA1), infralimbic (IL) and prelimbic (PrL) cortex.  Baseline recordings in a familiar open field were followed by intraperitoneal injection of 25I (2mg/kg) or vehicle.  LFP power, coherence and pairwise spectral multivariate granger causality (GC) were analysed for pre-injection, early post-injection (5-10 minutes) and late post-injection (35-40 minutes) periods. 
25I reduced movement and increased the proportion of time spent at the open field perimeter.  25I induced reductions in broadband spectral power across all four regions, but increases in high-gamma (65-80Hz) in the BLA and HFO in BLA, IL and PRL.  HFO peaks were most pronounced in IL.  High-gamma and HFO coherence between IL, PRL and BLA increased; coherence between CA1 and other regions showed only a slight increase in the HFO range. 
25I caused a marked increase in high-gamma GC from IL to BLA relative to pre-injection or vehicle, and a marked increase in HFO GC from IL to PRL.  In the early post injection period, there was an increase in HFO GC from dCA1 to BLA.
Our data evidence a 5-HT2A receptor-mediated increase in functional connectivity between the prefrontal cortex and amygdala with an increase in “top down” control of the amygdala by the IL. These changes may contribute to the network basis of antidepressant effects of psychedelic drugs including psilocybin and ketamine.
coauthors: Daniel Titheradge, University of Bristol, School of Physiology, Pharmacology & Neuroscience, Faculty of Life Sciences, University Walk, Bristol BS8 1TD; Flavie Kersante, University of Bristol, School of Physiology, Pharmacology & Neuroscience, Faculty of Life Sciences, University Walk, Bristol BS8 1TD; Jesper L. Kristensen, University of Copenhagen, Department of Drug Design & Pharmacology, Universitetsparken 2 342, Copenhagen, Denmark; Martin Hansen, University of Copenhagen, Department of Drug Design & Pharmacology, Universitetsparken 2 342, Copenhagen, Denmark; Matt W. Jones, University of Bristol, School of Physiology, Pharmacology & Neuroscience, Faculty of Life Sciences, University Walk, Bristol BS8 1TD
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Synaptic scaling requires a balance between stability, efficiency, and accuracy in realistic neuron morphologies
abstract:
Synaptic scaling is a homeostatic normalization mechanism that preserves relative synaptic strengths by adjusting them with a common factor.  This multiplicative change is believed to be critical, since synaptic strengths are involved in learning and memory retention.  Further, this homeostatic process is thought to be crucial for neuronal stability, playing a stabilizing role in otherwise runaway Hebbian plasticity.  Synaptic scaling requires a mechanism to sense total neuron activity and globally adjust synapses to achieve some activity set-point. This process is relatively slow, which places limits on its ability to stabilize network activity.  We show that this slow response is inevitable in realistic neuronal morphologies. Furthermore, we reveal that global scaling can in fact be a source of instability unless responsiveness or scaling accuracy are sacrificed.

A neuron with tens of thousands of synapses must regulate its own excitability to compensate for changes in input.  The time requirement for global feedback can introduce critical phase lags in a neuron’s response to perturbation.  Realization of the phase lag instability requires a unified model of synaptic scaling, regulation, and transport.  We present such a model with global and local feedback in realistic neuron morphologies.  This combined model shows that neurons face a tradeoff between stability, accuracy, and efficiency.  Global feedback is required for synaptic scaling but favors either system stability or efficiency.  Large receptor pools improve scaling accuracy in large morphologies but worsen both stability and efficiency.  Local feedback improves the stability-efficiency tradeoff at the cost of scaling accuracy.  This project introduces unexplored constraints on neuron size, morphology, and synaptic scaling.  We describe the interplay between global and local feedback mechanisms required to balance accurate synaptic scaling with neuron stability.
coauthors: Adriano Bellotti, University of Cambridge; Saeed Aljaberi, University of Cambridge; Fulvio Forni, University of Cambridge; Timothy O’Leary, University of Cambridge;
theme: Theme B: Neural Excitability, Synapses, and Glia

title: Social: Movie Watch Party of "Back to the Future"
abstract:
Neuromatch Movie Watch Party! Come have fun and relax with everyone over the time-travel classic, ‘Back to the Future.’ We will use the service Scener as a virtual movie theater to watch the film together using your Netflix account. Note that you must have an individual Netflix account to participate. Go to https://scener.com/ and create a free account before showtime.

We’ll be interacting in the chat while the movie airs, so join in with colleagues and friends from the past and make some future ones!

title: TASER (Temporally Adaptive SourcE Reconstruction)
abstract: Source reconstruction is a ubiquitous yet complex and critical pre-processing step in MEG and EEG analysis. Existing approaches have enjoyed great success, but nearly always assume stationarity in the source space covariance, a constraint which confounds the accuracy of source localisation (Barratt et al., 2018). Here we present TASER (Temporally Adaptive SourcE Reconstruction), a fully unsupervised algorithm which learns time-point specific reconstruction weights to build source space images. Specifically, we infer regularised time-varying data and noise covariance matrices at the same temporal resolution of the data. This is achieved by employing a stochastic gradient variational Bayesian inference framework, featuring gated recurrent unit neural networks. We show in simulation that TASER improves upon conventional static (minimum norm and beamformer) estimates in 3 out of 4 criteria. Applying the algorithm to real data, we show that TASER is able to uncover task-relevant physiological dynamics in an unsupervised fashion, negating the need to manually segregate data into different trial conditions. By automatically accounting for differences in covariance between timepoints, we replicate the findings of Barratt et al. (2018) and map the post movement beta rebound of digits 1 and 5 in motor cortex using MEG data, demonstrating the increase in spatial resolution over conventional static approaches to source reconstruction. This new unsupervised technique has exciting potential applications to datasets where there is little to no pre-supposed task structure e.g. during the resting state.
coauthors: Ryan C. Timms, University of Oxford; Andrew J. Quinn, University of Oxford; Alexander Skates, University of Oxford; Cameron J. Higgins, University of Oxford; Usama Pervaiz, University of Oxford; Evan J. Roberts, University of Oxford; James Bonaiuto, Institut des Sciences Cognitives Marc Jeannerod; Stephen M. Smith, University of Oxford; Matthew J. Brookes, University of Nottingham; Gareth R. Barnes, University College London; and Mark W. Woolrich, University of Oxford
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Novel Function of Brain Tissue-Specific MicroRNA-124 in Regulating Mesodermal Cell Fate
abstract: MicroRNA-124 (miR-124) has a highly conserved role in regulating the intricate balance between proliferation and differentiation during neurogenesis. The objective of this proposal is to investigate the novel role this neuron-specific microRNA (miR-124) in regulating mesodermal cell specification as well as its conserved function during neurogenesis. Our lab uses the sea urchin as a model due to its high fecundity, well-documented gene regulatory networks (GRN), and the fact that it contains a single miR-124, making it a simplified model to incorporate miR-124’s function into the GRN. MiR-124 has been observed in an array of species to directly suppress Notch to promote the neuronal linage. In sea urchin, Notch signaling is important for neurogenesis later in development while its earlier function is to modulate the specification of the mesoderm. We bioinformatically identified one or more potential miR-124 binding sites of Notch, Nodal, Ese (blastocoelar specific transcription factor), and Gcm (pigment cell specific transcription factor). The sea urchin Delta/Notch signaling pathway initiates specification of mesodermally-derived blastocoelar and pigment cells and later Nodal signaling ensures proper segregation of these cells to perform immune functions. We have determined that miR-124 directly suppresses Nodal, Notch, and blastcoelar specific transcription factor Ese to mediate proper specification and development of these immune cells. More recently we aim to reveal the molecular mechanism by which miR-124 impacts neurogenesis. We have observed that when we inhibit miR-124 that there is a significant decrease in mature neurons as well as an overall decrease in levels of serotonin expressing neurons. This decrease in specified neurons in miR-124 knockdown embryos as also resulted in slower-moving larval behavior. Due to our results and literature I predict that miR-124 directly inhibits Notch to mediate neurogenesis. I propose to test this by using a modified oligo designed to flank the binding site of miR-124 identified within Notch. By removing miR-124 suppression of Notch I will be able to determine if this proposed mechanism explains the overall decreased specified neurons in my miR-124 knockdown embryos. Our results have revealed a vital role of miR-124 in mesodermal cell specification, in addition to testing its conserved function in promoting neural differentiation in sea urchin.
coauthors: Santiago Suarez, University of Delaware; Jia L. Song, University of Delaware
theme: Theme A: Development, Neurodegenerative Disorders and Injury

title: Neuroscience education from home: Challenges and opportunities
abstract: Despite the growing popularity of neuroscience, courses with significant neuroscience components are not part of most high school curricula. In addition, providing high school students with research experience can complement classroom learning, and is particularly helpful for underrepresented groups. The COVID-19 pandemic, and the transition to virtual learning that has accompanied it, presents unique challenges as well as opportunities for neuroscience education initiatives. At Columbia University’s Zuckerman Institute, our summer high school internship program, BRAINYAC (Brain Research Apprenticeships in New York at Columbia), was upended this past March by COVID-19, forcing us to migrate our teaching online and to assess the efficacy of the program in a virtual context. While the difficulties of virtual education are clear, virtual learning has also been touted as a solution to making quality education more accessible. As neuroscience researchers and educators, it is essential that we collectively take a critical look at our practices in this moment so we can continue to provide high school students with rigorous and engaging neuroscience curricula. In an interactive talk, we will discuss how we pivoted a hands-on, lab-based program to a purely virtual format that utilized both synchronous virtual teaching and asynchronous resources and projects focused on multimedia science communication, computational skills, and community building. We will also provide a forum for others who facilitate neuroscience education initiatives to share their own experiences. Some discussion points we will pose to others include the challenges faced in both the abrupt transition to online learning and online learning itself, as well as how virtual teaching presents an opportunity to make neuroscience education more engaging and accessible than it was before.
coauthors: Benjamin M. Silver, Department of Psychology, Columbia University; Diana H. Li, Zuckerman Institute, Columbia University; Alyssa Mayers, Zuckerman Institute, Columbia University; Paula L. Croxson, Zuckerman Institute, Columbia University
theme: Theme F: History, Education and Society

title: Distinctive signatures of information seeking during changes of mind in controllable environments
abstract: The ability to flexibly adjust our confidence and change our mind in light of new information is a hallmark of human cognition. Using perceptual decision-making as a model system, previous work has focused on situations in which participants are observers adapting their decisions to incoming evidence. However, in many real-life settings, subjects exert active control over their environment when sampling information for decision-making. Here, we examined how being in control over evidence sampling influenced changes of mind and the associated confidence, as compared to uncontrollable environments. Across five variants of the same experiment (N=113 human participants), we found that changes of mind required more evidence against current beliefs in controllable environments. These changes of mind were also associated with reduced confidence, but were more likely to be confirmed on the next trial. Computational modelling revealed that in controllable environments, more stable beliefs, rather than a reduced sensitivity to evidence explained these differences. At the neurophysiological level, changes of mind in controllable environments were associated with a stronger involvement of a dorsal attentional network in MEG, and were followed by an increased pupil-linked arousal during decision evaluation. Together these findings characterise specific signatures of human information seeking in controllable environments.
coauthors: Marion Rouault, Department of Cognitive Studies, Ecole Normale Superieure de Paris, France; Aurélien Weiss, Department of Cognitive Studies, Ecole Normale Superieure de Paris, France; Jun Seok Lee, Department of Cognitive Studies, Ecole Normale Superieure de Paris, France; Jules Bouté, Department of Cognitive Studies, Ecole Normale Superieure de Paris, France; Jan Drugowitsch, Department of Neurobiology, Harvard Medical School, Boston, MA 02115, USA; Valérian Chambon, Department of Cognitive Studies, Ecole Normale Superieure de Paris, France; Valentin Wyart, Department of Cognitive Studies, Ecole Normale Superieure de Paris, France
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Temporal expectation of probabilistic rhythms
abstract: The environment surrounding the human brain is full of rhythm and temporal regularities which can be extracted to improve perception and ultimately survival. Many studies have suggested that neural oscillations may be a candidate mechanism for processing and predicting such rhythms particularly in the auditory domain. However, such studies are often limited by a narrowing scope, studying only perfectly isochronous rhythms that are unlikely to be found in the natural world (cf. speech). How might such an oscillatory mechanism behave in a more probabilistic rhythmic environment? We designed a behavioral experiment to study how humans make predictions under these more ambiguous conditions. Participants listen to a train of tones drawn from gaussian distribution around perfect isochrony and report whether the final tone is early or late relative to their expectation. We found that the method for calculation of temporal expectation depends critically on the stimulus rate (from 1 Hz – 4 Hz). We compared our behavioral results with two models of temporal prediction at different levels of explanation: a Wilson-Cowan model of oscillatory behavior from a neural perspective and an ideal observer Bayesian model. Our analysis studies the potential (if any) for oscillatory behavior to be used as a mechanism for a rhythmic prior in the Bayesian sense even under uncertain rhythmic scenarios
coauthors: M. Florencia Assaneo, Instituto de Neurobiologia, UNAM; Luc Arnal, Institut Pasteur; David Poeppel, New York University
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Comparing decision-making across social, emotional, and perceptual tasks
abstract: Every day we are making decisions that have associated uncertainty. They range from the perceptual, sensorimotor ones (e.g. grabbing a cup of coffee) to high-level, social ones (should I trust this person?). However, while considerable research has been done within each domain, how the decision-making at the perceptual/sensorimotor level relates to decisions at higher levels is still largely unknown. Furthermore, existing research suggests that, for certain psychiatric disorders, there may be decision-making differences already at a perceptual level (e.g. autism; schizophrenia). However, the extent to which this happens in different conditions and pre-clinical traits is still not well understood. My research combines perceptual, sensorimotor, emotional and social decision-making to better understand the connection (or lack thereof) between these different decision-making levels. In addition, we analyze how decision-making at different levels is affected by psychiatric conditions and personality traits. In our more recent, pre-registered study, we analyzed people’s behavior in a perceptual task (dot-motion), an emotion recognition task (the Reading the Mind in the Eyes test, RMET), and a social decision-making task (trust game), in a Midwest community sample (Minnesota State Fair goers, n = 123). We found no correlation between participants' performance across tasks. However, we found a strong positive correlation of decision confidence across tasks: participants more confident in their responses in a perceptual task also tended to be more confident in their responses on the emotion-recognition task and social task. Furthermore, reported confidence across tasks correlated negatively with participant’s alexithymia scores (a subclinical trait characterized by low emotional awareness). Altogether, our results suggest that confidence in one’s decisions is a personality trait that spans different types of decisions, and that it may be related to the degree of emotional awareness one has.
coauthors: Nathan Torunsky
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: An implantable kinematic headplate for sub-micron skull positioning in mice
abstract: Head immobilization is widely used in neuroscience studies to facilitate sensory stimulus control, behavioral monitoring, and neurophysiological recordings. Head-fixation strategies that combine mechanical stability and repeatable positioning over time or across instruments are particularly important for cellular resolution imaging or manipulation experiments. Headplates using kinematic coupling principles have been developed for precise micron-scale stability and position repeatability in rats (Scott et al. 2013, Rich et al. 2018). Here, we sought to extend this technology to a system small enough to be worn by mice (weighing <2 grams) and capable of submicron registration accuracy. To achieve these goals, we designed a headplate and clamp based on the Maxwell kinematic coupling system. The clamp was an anodized aluminum mount with three vee grooves, oriented at 120 degrees relative to each other. The headplate was a stainless steel triangle with three half spheres at the triangular vertices. Neodymium magnets attached to the clamp were used to provide the clamp force. We assessed the registration accuracy of the system using super resolution two-photon imaging of fluorescent microspheres (1μm diameter) fixed to the headplate following repeated attachments of the headplate. In initial experiments, registration accuracy (root mean square displacement) was 1.35μm in x, 1.42μm in y, and 0.28μm in z. Surgically implanted mice tolerated the headplate well and behaved normally. Scanning electron microscopy of the half spheres revealed mesoscale ridges and grooves in the metal surface. We replaced the stainless steel half spheres with precision ruby spheres. This improved repositioning accuracy to 0.17μm in x, 0.32μm in y, and 0.21μm in z. We anticipate that our system may facilitate experiments in mice where high precision and stability are required, such as imaging experiments using voluntary head restraint, time-lapse developmental studies, and registration of the same subject across multiple instruments.
coauthors: Su Jin Kim, Boston University Neurophotonics Center;Benjamin B. Scott, Boston University Center for Systems Neuroscience
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Spinal Cord Circuits for Motor Control
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: An evaluation of models for estimating the electroencephalogram (EEG) from networks of spiking neurons
abstract: The electroencephalogram (EEG) has been a mainstream tool for non-invasively studying large-scale brain dynamics, and linking those dynamics to cognition, brain function, and dysfunction. Large-scale simulations using simple point neurons are an important tool for studying and understanding how network dynamics implement neural computations. Given that the EEG is generated by spatially separated transmembrane currents, it cannot be computed directly from point neurons. Here, we asked the question whether a combination of quantities defined in point-neuron network models could accurately approximate the EEG. We evaluated different candidate “EEG proxies”, i.e., firing rates, membrane potentials, synaptic currents, and compared their outputs with the EEG generated when spikes produced by the point-neuron network serve as synaptic input to a population of mutually unconnected multicompartment model neurons with realistic morphologies. We found that a new class of proxies, based on an optimized linear combination of time-shifted AMPA and GABA currents, provided the most accurate estimate of the EEG over a wide range of network states of the point-neuron network. The performance of the new proxies was evaluated under different assumptions about properties of the multicompartment-neuron network, i.e., cell morphologies, distribution of presynaptic inputs and position of the recording electrode. We explored the application of a convolutional neural network (CNN) as an alternative approach to predict the EEG from synaptic currents. The substantial increase in complexity of the CNN provided a minimum improvement of the estimation performance showed by linear proxies. Our results can be used to easily calculate a biologically realistic EEG signal directly from point-neuron simulations and thereby facilitate quantitative comparison between computational models and experimental EEG recordings.
coauthors: Pablo Martínez-Cañada, Neural Coding Laboratory, Istituto Italiano di Tecnologia, Genova, Italy, Neural Computation Laboratory, Center for Neuroscience and Cognitive Systems @UniTn, Istituto Italiano di Tecnologia, Rovereto, Italy and Optical Approaches to Brain Function Laboratory, Istituto Italiano di Tecnologia, Genova, Italy; Torbjørn V. Ness, Faculty of Science and Technology, Norwegian University of Life Sciences, Ås, Norway; Gaute T. Einevoll, Faculty of Science and Technology, Norwegian University of Life Sciences, Ås, Norway and Department of Physics, University of Oslo, Oslo, Norway; Tommaso Fellin, Neural Coding Laboratory and Optical Approaches to Brain Function Laboratory, Istituto Italiano di Tecnologia, Genova, Italy; Stefano Panzeri,  Neural Coding Laboratory, Istituto Italiano di Tecnologia, Genova, Italy and Neural Computation Laboratory, Center for Neuroscience and Cognitive Systems @UniTn, Istituto Italiano di Tecnologia, Rovereto, Italy
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Discrete and continuous dynamics of neural state space during decision making
abstract:
Perceptual decision-making tasks involve transforming continuous sensory inputs into discrete decisions and continuous actions (Parr & Friston, 2018). This transformation occurs across a large network of brain areas. In mice performing such a task, neurons encoding choice are localized in forebrain and midbrain regions, while neurons encoding action initiation are distributed across the brain (Steinmetz et al. 2019). Whether the representation of brain-wide neural activity during such a transformation evolves in a continuous or discrete manner remains unclear (VanRullen & Koch, 2003). Hidden Markov models (HMM) can be used to assess neural dynamics when latent neural states are assumed to be discrete. Here, we compare this approach with that describing smooth evolution of states by decoding behavior following either HMM, or independent component analysis (ICA) using data collected by Steinmetz et al (2019).
Discrete state representation via HMM had similar decoding accuracy when decoding visual stimulus (present or not) compared to that obtained via continuous state via ICA. In contrast, continuous representation yielded greater accuracy in decoding action (go vs no-go) compared to discretized state reduction. Across sessions, discretized states mapped onto different behavioral epochs, potentially due to differences in the brain regions sampled, how individual mice approach the task, or between-day variability of a given mouse. We used a generalized linear model (GLM) to refine the discrete state representation in light of this variability. Coupling of neural spiking rate to behavior was used as a proxy for neurons’ contribution to behavior. We use insights from the GLM to refine the comparison of discrete and continuous models for decoding behavior. These results suggest a quick/almost instant change in neural dynamics in response to visual stimulus and a slow changing dynamics, when leading to action.
coauthors: Sunandha Srikanth, Department of Biological Sciences, Institution: University of California, San Diego;  Tanvi Ranjan, School of Engineering and Applied Sciences, Harvard University; Frances S. Cho, Dept. of Neurology, University of California San Francisco; Jun Ye, NMA
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Cortical Attention and Default Mode Networks in Focused Attention Meditators Assessed with fMRI
abstract: Meditation experience correlates with improved performance on behavioral assessments of attention, but the neural bases of this improvement are unknown. Two prominent, competing attention networks exist in the human cortex: a dorsal 'focused attention' network and a ventral 'circuit-breaker' network by which stimuli can capture attention. Additionally, a third network, the default mode network, demonstrates deactivation during demanding tasks. Here, we used functional magnetic resonance imaging to contrast cortical network activation between experienced vipassana meditators and controls. Participants performed two standard attention tasks during scanning: a sustained attention task and an attention-capture task. Meditators demonstrated increased magnitude of differential activation in the dorsal attention vs. default mode network in a sustained attention task, relative to controls. In contrast, attentional reorienting did not reveal behavioral or attention network differences between meditators and controls. These results demonstrate increased stability in sustained attention processes without an associated attentional capture cost in meditators.
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Neural and Biomechanical Correlates of Post-Stroke Gait Retraining
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: The Massive Report Paradigm: Assessing the richness of conscious visual experience
abstract: To most of us, our experience of the world seems extremely rich in detail. However, some researchers claim this feeling of richness is an illusion. We developed several tasks to estimate the richness of perceptual experiences based on information theory, in an approach we call the “Massive Report” paradigm. First, we simply showed participants (in lab N=10, in MTurk N>600) a brief glimpse (SOA=67, 133 or 267ms before being masked) of one natural scene picture (we used 580 images in total) and asked for 5 nouns/adjectives/verbs that describe the scene. Second, we compiled a large pool of descriptors for the set of images as potential “alternatives” and performed classical discrimination tasks with confidence ratings. The novelty of the paradigm is that we interrogated the phenomenology associated with a single image with a “massive” set of questions (between 20 and 80640 questions per image).  The results of these experiments suggest that subjects can discriminate a huge repertoire of scene characteristics; in information theoretic terms, the bandwidth of differentiation measures at > 1500 bits per second (compared to previous estimates of <40 bits per second). Our results suggest that a moment of experience is much richer than previously considered.
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Analysing inter-regional neuronal connections at the single neuron-level
abstract: Recent improvements in in-vivo neuronal recording technologies allow large-scale recordings of individual neurons within and between multiple brain regions simultaneously. Such large-scale recordings potentially allow questions about brain network communication rules between neurons during behavioural tasks to be meaningfully addressed. However, analytic approaches to such datasets are currently lacking. We consider here the expected number of connections that might be recorded between neurons in these brain regions with current technology, to guide what the correct analytic approach to such recordings might be. We consider an ‘inductive’ argument, with multiple neurons in multiple brain regions and a simplified connection mapping between these neurons. Using the hyper-geometric distribution, we derive a probability distribution for the number connections recorded between the neurons of anatomically connected regions. This mathematically derived distribution is validated by Monte Carlo simulations of directed graphs. Our method is applied to simulated graphs with several neurons, based on counts in rat brain regions, and connection matrices from the Blue Brain project’s model of the mouse neocortex connectome. We conclude that the probability of simultaneously recording directly connected pairs of neurons in anatomically connected regions can approach zero, given current recording technology. Approaches summing neuronal activity over larger scales (such as local-field potentials) may offer considerable promise, especially if combined with other approaches (such opto- or chemogenetics), and simultaneously recorded neuronal activity.
coauthors: Shane O'Mara; John Aggleton
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Adult-born Neurons Inhibit Developmentally-born Neurons
abstract: Recent reports indicate that lateral inhibition plays a powerful role in selecting which dentate gyrus (DG) neurons are recruited during memory formation. This raises the question of whether developmentally-born and adult-born DG neurons have distinct roles for inhibition, particularly in vivo when neuronal ensembles are selected during memory encoding. To address this we combined chemogenetics and immunohistochemistry for BrdU+Fos to silence and measure activity in developmentally and adult-born neurons as rats learned a spatial water maze task. Specifically, retrovirus was injected into the DG of male rats at 6 weeks of age to express the inhibitory DREADD receptor, HM4Di, in neurons born in adulthood. The same rats were also injected with BrdU to label developmentally or adult-born neurons. At 10 weeks of age rats were injected with either the HM4Di agonist CNO or vehicle, then trained in the water maze. We found that silencing a subset of adult-born neurons (aged 4 weeks) increased activity levels in the developmentally-born neuron population. However, silencing adult-born neurons did not affect activation in other adult-born neurons within the DG, suggesting limited interaction amongst the adult-born population. As well, we have examined activation of interneurons (PV+ and SST+) within each treatment group to determine if silencing neurons at different ages impacts downstream activity in inhibitory interneurons. Our recent findings implicate PV+ interneurons in the modulatory subcircuit between neuron populations within the DG.
coauthors: Elena Regele-Blasco; Erin Chahley; Desiree Seib; Jason Snyder, UBC
theme: Theme A: Development, Neurodegenerative Disorders and Injury

title: Dynamics of history-dependent perceptual judgment
abstract: Perception is not the mere encoding of instantaneous physical features. A main determinant of perceptual choices is the pre-existing state of the subject as shaped by recent events. In other words, perceptual systems exhibit the important feature of being history-dependent. In a recent study (https://www.biorxiv.org/content/10.1101/2020.07.12.199489v1), we focused on the role of stimulus history and its updating dynamics. We trained rats to classify whisker-mediated vibrations according to their mean speed, assigning each stimulus to one of two possible categories, “strong” or “weak”. Rats showed a response bias that was inversely correlated to stimulus values received in the preceding trials, but not dependent on previous choices or rewards. Specifically, receiving a high-speed stimulus led to a lower probability of classifying upcoming stimuli as “strong”, and vice versa, an effect which lasted for several trials. Surprisingly, the repulsive bias in a given trial n, following a stimulus in trial n-1, increased with the time interval between the two. The same key results were obtained by testing human subjects in an analogous tactile discrimination task. We modeled subjects’ perceptual judgments as the result of a history-dependent shift in decision criterion applied to sensory input, outperforming an ideal observer model based on current sensory information only. We also discuss mechanistic hypotheses concerning the neuronal correlates of this phenomenon, that we are currently investigating.
coauthors: Sebastian Reinartz, International School for Advanced Studies; Romain Brasselet, International School for Advanced Studies; Alisea Stroligo, International School for Advanced Studies; Mathew Diamond, International School for Advanced Studies
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Intrinsic dynamic landscape of the brain shaped by multiscale structural constraints
abstract: The brain is a complex, nonlinear system, exhibiting ever-evolving patterns of activities even without external inputs or tasks. Such intrinsic dynamics plays key roles in cognitive functions and psychiatric disorders. A challenge is to link the intrinsic dynamics to the underlying structure, given the nonlinearity. Here we use a biophysically constrained, nonlinear-dynamical model to show how the complexity of intrinsic brain dynamics, manifested as its multistability and temporal diversity, can be sculpted by structural properties across scales. At a local level, multistability and temporal diversity can be induced by sufficient recurrent excitatory connectivity and its heterogeneity. At a global level, such functional complexity can also be created by the synergistic interaction between monostable, locally identical regions. Coordination between model brain regions across attractors in the multistable landscape predicts human functional connectivity. Compared to dynamics near a single attractor, cross-attractor coordination better accounts for functional links uncorrelated with structural connectivity. Energy costs of cross-attractor coordination are modulated by both local and global connectivity, and higher in the Default Mode Network. These findings hint that functional connectivity underscores transitions between alternative patterns of activity in the brain---even more than the patterns themselves. This work provides a systematic framework for characterizing intrinsic brain dynamics as a web of cross-attractor transitions and their energy costs. The framework may be used to predict transitions and energy costs associated with experimental or clinical interventions.
coauthors: Manish Saggar, Stanford University;
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Pattern Separation performance and hippocampal neurogenesis in aged female rats
abstract: Aging is associated with impaired performance in behavioral pattern separation (PS) tasks based on similarities in object features and in object location. Hippocampal dentate gyrus (DG) neurogenesis plays an important role in PS. In order to evaluate the effect of aging on discrimination of overlapping memories of object location or features, we assessed three groups of Sprague-Dawley rats: Young (Y, 4-5 mo., n=25), Middle-Aged (MA, 18 mo., n=32), and Senile (S, 28 mo., n=13). Spontaneous Location Recognition (SLR) and Spontaneous Object Recognition (SOR) were assessed in the three age groups. The testing chambers for SLR and SOR were black circular and white triangular arenas, respectively. Morphometric analysis revealed a significant age-related reduction in doublecortin (DCX) cell number and diameter in the DG. In the SLR, the discriminatory performance was markedly deteriorated in the MA and S rats as compared with Y rats. In the SOR, S rats presented deterioration in memory disambiguation but MA rats showed a preserved memory as compared with Y rats. Our findings reveal the existence of a significant vulnerability of DCX neurons to age in rats and deficient object location discrimination, likely related to deficient DG neurogenesis. Furthermore, the overlapping memories involving object location are more sensitive to age than overlapping memories involving features. A possible explanation for this observation is that the process of discriminating memories related to features is under the control of another pattern separator node, possibly the Prh, which is less affected by age. Our next goal is to study this region to evaluate the differences between the age groups in it.
coauthors: Priscila Chiavellini, INIBIOLP; Marianne Lehmann, INIBIOLP; Rodolfo G. Goya, INIBIOLP; Gustavo R. Morel, INIBIOLP
institution: Biochemistry Research Institute of La Plata (grid.473303.0)
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: What is the nature of representation in the tool-selective areas in the parietal cortex? Effects of category, shape, and spatial frequency
abstract: When we perceive an object (e.g., a hammer), much information about the object is processed (e.g., its shape, kind, or function). To what extent such information is processed in the category-selective regions? We have previously shown that tool-selective regions in the occipitotemporal cortex primarily contain categorical information about tools, compared with visual information (e.g., shape or spatial frequency, He et al., 2020). Here we examined the extent these information may be represented in other tool-selective regions, particularly in the parietal cortex. Using fMRI, tool-selective regions in left superior and inferior parietal lobules (SPL/IPL) were defined in a separate localizer with images of animals and tools with naturally variable image statistics. We then tested the nature of representations in these regions with images of animals and tools that were either round or elongated, and either in low or high spatial frequencies (LSF/HSF). Importantly, the images of the two categories shared comparable gist statistics, minimizing low- or mid-level visual differences across the two categories. Using representational similarity analysis (RSA), a model of tool category (tools were correlated with each other and not correlated with animals, and animals were not correlated with each other) and a model of HSF were most correlated with the neural patterns in SPL, whereas an interaction model of elongation and HSF was most correlated to the neural patterns in IPL. Functional connectivity analysis further suggested that the tool representation in SPL might be related to the stronger connectivity between tool-selective left medial fusiform gyrus and SPL, compared with IPL, and that the elongation representation in IPL might be related to the stronger connectivity between tool-selective left premotor region and IPL, compared with SPL. Together, these results revealed how different aspects of information are represented in various regions in the tool-selective network to support recognition and potential action planning.
coauthors: Olivia S. Cheung, New York University Abu Dhabi
institution: French Institute of Health and Medical Research
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Symposium on family, risk, and fear in decision
abstract:
Ann Clemens - neural circuits of kinship behavior

Christine Constantinople - risk and value representations in decision 

Bianca Jones-Marlin -  maternal circuits and trauma 

Liz Phelps -  emotion processing and regulation
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: The inseparability of featural and configural visual processing in dyslexia
abstract: While dyslexia is typically described as a phonological deficit, recent evidence suggests that ventral stream regions, important for visual categorization and object recognition, are hypoactive in dyslexic readers who might accordingly show visual recognition deficits. But what exactly these visual recognition problems are, is still unknown. If dyslexic readers‘ problems are visual, they could be restricted to visual word processing or they might generalize to other visual categories – all or only some, as face recognition is assumed to require domain-specific mechanisms. There are two different approaches to visual recognition; featural and configural processing. Featural processing is generally assumed to be important for word recognition while configural processing is often considered the hallmark of face processing. By manipulating featural and configural information in faces and houses, we investigated whether dyslexic readers are disadvantaged at recognizing certain object classes or utilizing particular visual processing mechanisms. We recruited 34 dyslexic readers and 34 matched typical readers.  Dyslexic readers found it harder to recognize objects (houses), suggesting that visual problems in dyslexia are not completely domain-specific. Mean accuracy for faces was equivalent in the two groups, compatible with domain-specificity in face processing. However, univariate analyses of accuracy miss that even though no overall group differences were found for featural vs. configural accuracy, this does not mean that the tasks were solved using similar representations or the same underlying mechanisms. Representational similarity analysis (RSA), which originates in systems neuroscience, can provide a fuller description of the structure of information representation in each group. RSA on our behavioral data revealed that featural and configural processes were clearly separable in typical readers, while dyslexic readers appeared to rely on a single process. We speculate that reading deficits in some dyslexic readers reflect their reliance on a single process for object recognition.
coauthors: Árni Kristjánsson1, Department of Psychology, University of Iceland; Heida Maria Sigurdardottir, Department of Psychology, University of Iceland
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Disorder- and emotional context-specific neurofunctional alterations during inhibitory  control in generalized anxiety disorder and major depressive disorder
abstract:
Background: Major Depressive Disorder (MDD) and Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD) are highly debilitating and co-morbid disorders. Previous case control studies in either MDD or GAD patients suggest shared emotional and cognitive dysregulations, particularly exaggerated attention to negative information, yet partly separable alterations in cognitive control. However, common and disorder-specific alterations in the interaction between emotion and inhibitory control are poorly understood. 
Method: In order to determine disorder-specific behavioral and neurofunctional alterations in this domain the present study examined emotional context-specific inhibitory control in unmedicated, treatment-naïve, first episode MDD (n = 37) and GAD (n = 35) patients and healthy controls (n = 35) by employing a validated affective go/no-go fMRI paradigm. 
Result: On the behavioral level, we found evidence for supporting the disorder-specific alterations, such that MDD but not GAD patients exhibited impaired inhibitory control irrespective of emotional context (indexed through accuracy rates of no-go trials). On the neural level specifically MDD patients demonstrated attenuated recruitment of a broad bilateral network encompassing inferior/medial parietal and posterior frontal as well as mid-cingulate regions during cognitive control in the negative context (pFWE<.05, whole-brain). Further examination of disorder-specific alterations and potential compensatory recruitment on the neural level revealed that GAD patients exhibited a stronger engagement of the left DLPFC relative to MDD patients and that within the group of GAD patients better cognitive control in negative contexts associated with higher recruitment of this region (pFWE<.05, whole-brain), possibly reflecting a compensatory mechanism on the neural level that facilitates intact performance in GAD. 
Conclusion: Findings from the present study suggest disorder- and emotional context-specific behavioral and neurofunctional deficits in inhibitory control in MDD in negative emotional contexts and may point to a depression-specific neuropathological mechanism. In contrast, GAD patients may maintain intact performance via compensatory recruitment of prefrontal regulatory regions.
coauthors: Congcong Liu, Xiaolei Xu, Yuanshu Chen, Fei Xin, Benjamin Becker, University of Electronic Science and Technology of China
institution: University of Electronic Science and Technology of China
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Neural bases of risky decisions involving nicotine vapor vs. monetary reward
abstract: Current studies of addiction involve decision making tasks with money or other non-drug rewards. However, previous research has shown that addiction changes response to drug vs non-drug rewards. Studies using drug reward have not given drugs as an instrumental reward directly in the MRI scanner. In this study, we looked at the neural representations of risk and reward associated with nicotine vs. money. We used a modified e-cigarette to deliver nicotine vapor to subjects with nicotine dependence inside the fMRI scanner. Our novel gambling task orthogonalized the gamble characteristics: variance in outcomes, probability of failure, and the expected value of the outcomes. This allowed us to evaluate their effects separately. The outcome in the case of a nicotine gamble was the duration of nicotine vapor inhalation and in the case of money gamble, it was the amount of money in dollars. We found an effect of greater nicotine reward anticipation in the cingulate gyrus and caudate. Regions in the motor cortex were active during nicotine inhalation, as was expected. The psychophysiological interaction analysis with these motor regions as seeds revealed increased functional connectivity with right middle temporal gyrus during inhalation. We also observed a striking reversal of effects in the cingulate cortex between money and nicotine rewards, in distinct but overlapping clusters. Activation was greater for monetary loss than win, but in contrast, activation was greater when subjects obtained nicotine than when they failed to obtain it. Activities correlating with the variance and probability of loss of a monetary gamble were found in various regions in the frontal cortex and temporal lobe. The results contribute to our knowledge of regions involved in decisions about nicotine when the nicotine reward could be realized immediately and provide insights into the limitations of non-drug rewards in studying addiction.
coauthors: Christian Hutslar, Indiana University; Rebecca Polk, Indiana University; Emily Atkinson, Indiana University; Jon Macy, Indiana University; Laurie Chassin, Arizona State University; Clark Presson, Arizona State University; Peter R. Finn, Indiana University; Joshua W Brown, Indiana University
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Theory of Neuronal Perturbome: Linking Connectivity to Coding via Perturbations
abstract: To unravel the functional properties of the brain, we need to untangle how neurons interact with each other and coordinate in large-scale recurrent networks. One way to address this question is to measure the functional influence of individual neurons on each other by perturbing them in vivo. Application of such single-neuron perturbations in mouse visual cortex has recently revealed feature-specific suppression between excitatory neurons, despite the presence of highly specific excitatory connectivity, which was deemed to underlie feature-specific amplification. Here, we studied which connectivity profiles are consistent with these seemingly contradictory observations, by modelling the effect of single-neuron perturbations in large-scale neuronal networks. Our numerical simulations and mathematical analysis revealed that, contrary to the prima facie assumption, neither inhibition-dominance nor broad inhibition alone were sufficient to explain the experimental findings; instead, strong and functionally specific excitatory-inhibitory connectivity was necessary, consistent with recent findings in the primary visual cortex of rodents. Such networks had a higher capacity to encode and decode natural images in turn, which was accompanied by the emergence of response gain nonlinearities at the population level. Our study provides a general computational framework to investigate how single-neuron perturbations are linked to cortical connectivity and sensory coding, and paves the road to map the perturbome of neuronal networks in future studies.
coauthors: Claudia Clopath
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Sensitivity versus criterion mechanisms underlying the attentional blink
abstract:
Attention enables us to select behaviorally relevant, stimuli for enhanced sensory processing and decision-making. We investigate neural mechanisms of the “attentional blink”: the impaired ability to select the second (T2) of two targets, when it occurs within close temporal proximity (200-500 ms) of the first (T1). 

Does attentional blink affect the selection of T2 for enhanced sensory processing (sensitivity, d’), for decision-making (criterion, c) or both? Specifically, does it affect d’ and c associated with detecting T2, with discriminating its features, or both? We addressed all of these questions using a single, novel psychophysical task with concomitant EEG (electroencephalography) recordings in 23 human participants. 

Two target stimuli (Gabor gratings) embedded in a stream of plaid distractors appeared in a 10-Hz rapid serial visual presentation (RSVP) paradigm. On each trial, subjects discriminated the orientation of a T1 stimulus (cardinal/diagonal) with a 2-AFC (two-alternative forced-choice) response. They also indicated the presence, as well as the orientation of a T2 stimulus with a 3-AFC response (clockwise/counterclockwise of vertical, or absent). We developed a novel, multidimensional signal detection model to analyze subjects’ multialternative behavioral choices; the model quantified d’ and c for both detection and discrimination of T2 stimuli. 

Significant reductions in both detection and discrimination d’ parameters were observed during the blink. On the other hand, the blink produced virtually no effect on either detection or discrimination criteria. Event-related potentials, including the visual P2 over occipital electrodes and P3b over parietal electrodes modulated in amplitude in a manner that closely resembled detection d’ changes. 

Our study introduces a novel task and framework to investigate behavioral and neural mechanisms underlying the attentional blink, and suggests that selection deficits associated with attentional blink may reflect d’ rather than criterion mechanisms.
coauthors: Dr.Sridharan Devarajan, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Social transmission of maternal behavior
theme: Theme B: Neural Excitability, Synapses, and Glia

title: How Microglia Wire and Unwire the Brain
theme: Theme B: Neural Excitability, Synapses, and Glia

title: Replication of two computational models of locomotion of Caenorhabditis elegans in Brian 2
abstract:
The nematode Caenorhabditis elegans has a simple nervous structure yet displays complex behaviours
mediated by a sensation-action loop. We report on replicating two experiments based on two different
models of the locomotion neural circuits of C. elegans [1, 2].

Both articles present point-neuron models that consider the graded nature of the electrical activity
in C. elegans, as opposed to spiking-neuron models—yet both are different. In the first case a
non-dimensional model is used for a small subnetwork in which the values of free parameters are
found by applying constraints with a genetic algorithm. The second model is based on physiological
parameters for cells and synapses, therefore no optimization is needed and almost the complete
connectome of C. elegans is simulated—279 out of 302 neurons. The replications are performed in the
simulating platform Brian 2, which is available as a Python module and is different from the
original methods used.

We were able to verify the main hypothesis proposed by each article. In the first case, the
production of intrinsic network oscillations by central pattern generators (CPGs) along the ventral
nerve cord of the worm. In the second, the existence of a bifurcation in the model state-space
produced by a constant sensory input that creates oscillatory behaviour. Nevertheless, we were
unable to replicate exact quantitative results for the first model, and obtained contradictory
results when performing neural ablations on the second network model. The source code generated, and
data used are made publicly available in code repositories [3].

[1] E. O. Olivares, E. J. Izquierdo and R. D. Beer, 'Potential role of a ventral nerve cord central
pattern generator in forward and backward locomotion in Caenorhabditis elegans', Network
Neuroscience, vol. 2, no. 3, pp. 323-343, 2018. DOI: 10.1162/netn_a_00036.

[2] J. Kunert, E. Shlizerman and J. N. Kutz, 'Low-dimensional functionality of complex network
dynamics: Neurosensory integration in the Caenorhabditis elegans connectome', Phys. Rev. E, vol. 89,
p. 052805, 5 May 2014. DOI: 10.1103/PhysRevE.89.052805.

[3] https://github.com/ivan-ea/celegans_brian2_replications
coauthors: Francisco J. Valverde-Albacete, Carlos III University of Madrid; Carmen Peláez-Moreno, Carlos III University of Madrid
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Instantaneous Modulation of Gamma Rhythm by  the difference of Time Constants of Inhibitory/Excitatory synapses
abstract: The human brain and all other mammal brains have a distinguished gamma activity during tasks that underlie higher cognitive functions such as awareness, learning, memory, and decision making. Although numerous studies tried to clarify a mechanistic explanation of generation and modulation of brain rhythms, yet many aspects are not still well-known. In this computational study, we simulated a network of excitatory and inhibitory neurons which generates rhythmic activities in a range of slow oscillations (1-20 Hz) as well as a faster oscillation in the range (30-100 Hz). We verified a noticeable correlation between synaptic decay time constant and amplitude-frequency correlation in cycle-by-cycle population activity. Our results showed that the greater the difference of time decay of inhibitory synapses compared to that of excitatory synapses, the stronger the amplitude-frequency correlation of population activity. We also observed a change in the correlation sign of the phase of slower oscillation with the amplitude of faster oscillation depending on the difference between the decay time of excitatory synapses compared to inhibitory synapses. These results indicate that the difference between the decay time of excitatory and inhibitory synapses plays an important role in tuning of oscillatory activity of the cortical circuits.
coauthors: Nosratullah Mohammadi, Alireza Valizadeh
institution: Institute for Advanced Studies in Basice Sciences
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Are primates just big frogs? Forelimb force direction and amplitude are independently controlled by spinal motor modules
abstract:
Modular organization of the spinal motor system is thought to reduce the cognitive complexity of
simultaneously controlling the large number of muscles and joints in the human body. Although modular
organization has been confirmed in the hindlimb control system of several animal species, it has yet to be
established in the forelimb motor system or in primates. Expanding upon experiments originally
performed in the frog lumbar spinal cord, we examined whether co-stimulation of two sites in the
macaque monkey cervical spinal cord results in motor activity that is a simple linear sum of the responses
evoked by stimulating each site individually. Similar to previous observations in the frog and rodent
hindlimb, our analysis revealed that in most cases (77% of all pairs), the directions of the force fields
elicited by co-stimulation were highly similar to those predicted by the simple linear sum of those elicited
by stimulating each site individually. A comparable simple summation of EMG output, especially in the
proximal muscles, suggested that this linear summation of force field direction was produced by a spinal
neural mechanism whereby the forelimb motor output recruited by co-stimulation was also summed
linearly. We further found that the force field magnitudes exhibited supra-linear (amplified) summation,
which was also observed in the EMG output of distal forelimb muscles, implying a novel feature of
primate forelimb control. Overall, our observations support the idea that complex movements in the
primate forelimb control system are made possible by flexibly combined spinal motor modules.
coauthors: Amit yaron NCNP; David Paul Kowalski, NCNP\Drexel ; Hiroaki Yaguchi, NCNP ; Tomohiko Takei, NCNP\Kyoto University;  Kazuhiko Seki, NCNP
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: A spatial developmental generative model of human brain structural connectivity
abstract: The complex wiring of the human connectome is thought to support integrated brain function and adaptive behaviour. Yet the mechanisms leading to the emergence of this connectome topology are unknown. Generative network models have begun to shed light on these mechanisms by showing that stochastic wiring rules, subject to simple constraints based on a trade-off between the wiring cost and putative functional value of a connection, can reproduce many key topological features of empirical connectome data. However, recent evidence suggest that they may not accurately capture the way in which these properties are spatially embedded. One potential reason for this limitation is that current models assume a fixed geometry based on the adult brain, ignoring the major changes in shape and size that occur early in development, when connections form. Here, we propose a new generative network model that proposes a new cost-value trade-off formulation, and which can readily incorporate developmental changes in brain geometry, informed by structural MRIs obtained from a public database of foetal scans acquired from 21–38 weeks gestational age. Using a cross-validated procedure to fit these models to connectomes generated from 100 healthy adults with diffusion MRI, we show that our new model more accurately reproduces the topological properties of empirical data than existing models, but that developmental changes in brain shape and size do not lead to major gains in model fit. Critically, none of the models accurately capture the spatial embedding of network topology, being unable to reproduce the observed spatial topography of hubs. Our results suggest that generative models based on stochastic wiring rules can capture statistical properties of brain networks, but that they may be insufficient to comprehensively explain the way in which these properties are spatially embedded.
coauthors: Ben Fulcher, The University of Sydney; Kevin Aquino, Monash University; Aurina Arnatkevičiūtė, Monash University; Rosita Shishegar, Monash University; Alex Fornito, Monash University
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Neurocorrelates of Free Will Revisited
abstract:
Neither science nor neuroscience explain free will. Some research shows humans have no free will, that it may be an illusion, [1], while other identifies networks of brain areas, including the pre-supplementary motor area, the anterior prefrontal cortex and the parietal cortex, that underlie voluntary action and cause distinctive conscious experience of intending to act and then controlling one's own actions, concluding that volition consists of a series of decisions regarding whether to act, what action to perform and when to perform it [2]
New findings identify networks of brain areas, including the pre-supplementary motor area, the anterior prefrontal cortex and the parietal cortex, that underlie voluntary action. These areas generate information for forthcoming actions, and also cause the distinctive conscious experience of intending to act and then controlling one's own actions.
The peak of evolution of human consciousness manifests at psychological and behavioural level with the ability to exercise conscious actions with less conditioning, particularly in the form of control over one's thoughts and emotions,
Such evolution of consciousness  can be observed within certain network dynamics and could even visibly manifests in the morphology of the cortex, 

The ability to make choices according to values and intents, and the awareness that animal instincts are determined by mechanical and biological responses to external stimuli, is what distinguishes human behaviour, develops awareness, consciousness and possibly drives evolution. This research  revisits historical hypotheses based on recent findings, and proposes a novel interpretation of  recent findings A theory of consciousness and free will as factors impacting consciousness and evolution is formulated. 

[1]  http://www.nature.com/news/2011/110831/full/477023a.html
[2]https://www.nature.com/articles/nrn2497#:~:text=Modern%20neuroscience%20rejects%20the%20traditional,open%20decisions%20between%20alternative%20actions.

 [3] https://www.nature.com/articles/nrn2497)
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Serotonin functions as a bidirectional guidance cue regulating growth cone motility
abstract: The neurotransmitter serotonin is implicated in a range of mental health disorders that are associated with altered neuronal connectivity during development. Remarkably, serotonin is synthesized and secreted in the embryonic brain prior to the formation of most synapses, thus before neural circuits become fully functional. This suggests serotonin could regulate neuronal connectivity through a process known as axon guidance, which enables neurons to form accurate connections. Growth cones, the leading tips of neurons, are guided in the developing brain by instructive molecules called guidance cues that enable neurons to reach and connect to their targets. We hypothesized that serotonin acts as a novel guidance cue, regulating growth cone motility and hence, axon guidance during early stages of brain circuit formation. Using a growth cone motility assay and a range of pharmacological tools, we found serotonin acts bimodally, attracting and repelling growth cones, through the binding to specific serotonin receptors 5HT2a and 5HT1b, respectively. Using high resolution imaging of growth cones exposed to microgradients of serotonin, we showed serotonin-induced bidirectional motility is underpinned by two distinct signalling mechanisms: 5-HT2a-induced attraction is mediated by calcium release, while 5-HT1b-induced repulsion is driven by cAMP signalling. Optogenetic manipulation of 5-HT2a signalling altered growth cone trajectories away from serotonin, further demonstrating the specificity of secreted serotonin as an axon guidance cue. Unravelling how serotonin functions to regulate the normal wiring of the brain will allow us to better understand how dysfunction in serotonin signalling during development could contribute to the onset of neurodevelopmental disorders.
coauthors: Lisa Foa ; Rob Gasperini
theme: Theme A: Development, Neurodegenerative Disorders and Injury

title: Translating time from temporal variation in transcription and structure in humans and chimpanzees
abstract: How the unique capacities of human cognition arose in evolution is a question of enduring interest. It is still unclear which developmental programs are responsible for the emergence of the human brain. The inability to determine corresponding ages between humans and apes has hampered progress in detecting developmental programs leading to the emergence of the human brain. I harness temporal variation in anatomical, behavioral, and transcriptional variation to determine corresponding ages from fetal to postnatal development and aging, between humans and chimpanzees. This multi-dimensional approach results in 137 corresponding time points across the lifespan, from embryonic day 44 to ~55 years of age, in humans and their equivalent ages in chimpanzees. I used these data to test whether developmental programs, such as the timeline of prefrontal cortex maturation, previously claimed to differ between humans and chimpanzees, do so once variation in developmental schedules is controlled for. I compared the maturation of frontal cortex projections from structural magnetic resonance (MR) scans and from temporal variation in the expression of genes used to track long-range projecting neurons (i.e., supragranular-enirhced genes) in chimpanzees and humans. Contrary to what has been suggested, the timetable of prefrontal cortex maturation is not unusually extended in humans. This dataset, which is the largest with which to determine corresponding ages across humans and chimpanzees, provides a rigorous approach to control for variation in developmental schedules and to identify developmental programs responsible for unique features of the human brain.
coauthors: Christine Charvet, Delaware State University
theme: Theme A: Development, Neurodegenerative Disorders and Injury

title: The dynamics of body category and emotion processing in high-level visual, prefrontal and parietal cortex.
abstract: Recent studies provided an increasingly detailed understanding of how visual objects like faces or bodies are categorized. What is less clear is how attributes like the emotional expression are represented, whether the coding of the expression is influenced by the task and influences the category representation. Using functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) and multivariate methods, we measured BOLD responses while participants viewed whole body expressions and performed an explicit (emotion) and implicit (shape) recognition task. Our results show that the type of task can be decoded in extrastriate body area (EBA), ventrolateral prefrontal cortex (VLPFC) and inferior parietal lobule (IPL) with higher activity for the explicit task condition in the first two areas and no evidence of emotion specificity processes in any of them. During the task of explicit recognition of the body expression, category representation would be strengthened while action related information would be suppressed. These results provide evidence that body representations in high level visual cortex and frontoparietal cortex are task sensitive and differentially contribute to expression representation based on their different anatomical connectivity.
coauthors: Maarten J. Vaessen, Maastricth University; Beatrice de Gelder, Maastricth University, University College London;
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Pitfalls in quantifying exploration in reward-based motor learning
abstract:
Movements are variable. It is unclear how much different variability sources contribute to this variability and how these contributions can be quantified. These questions are especially of interest in studying reward-based motor learning, where people are thought to add exploratory variability to their inevitable motor noise to discover which movements lead to reward. Whether variability promotes or hampers learning is however controversial. To clarify this relation between variability and learning, it is important to separate variability caused by exploration from motor noise. 

We developed the additional trial-to-trial change (ATTC) method for quantifying exploration as the additive variability following non-rewarded movements over variability following rewarded movements. Here, we aimed to validate the ATTC method by simulating learning using existing models of reward-based motor learning. This is important because we developed the method in a random reward paradigm, in which participants cannot use the feedback to improve their performance. Furthermore, learning contributes to trial-to-trial changes in behavior in a systematic, rather than random, manner, and may hence influence the quantification of exploration. We calculated the similarity between input exploration and exploration estimated from model behavior, for four models and their parameters.

The fairly simple rationale behind the ATTC method is that exploration is higher following reward absence, which is a key feature of all models, too. Nevertheless, similarity is sensitive to the ratio of input motor noise and exploration, and exploration is generally underestimated.

Our results reveal two important pitfalls in quantifying exploration based on trial-to-trial changes. Firstly, performance-dependent reward causes considerable correlations in samples of motor noise, thereby affecting estimates of exploration depending on the ratio of the learners’ exploration and motor noise. Secondly, using trial-to-trial changes to quantify exploration results in an underestimation of exploration since the exploration relative to which the change is calculated is unstable.
coauthors: K. van der Kooij, Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam; J.B.J. Smeets, Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Examining the relationship between externalizing and internalizing behaviour and the cortico-amygdalar network in children with neurodevelopmental disorders: A multi-modal dimensional study
abstract:
Purpose: Children with neurodevelopmental disorders (NDDs) including autism spectrum disorder (ASD), obsessive compulsive disorders (OCD) and attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) exhibit high rates of externalizing and internalizing behaviours. These behaviours have been linked to variation in cortico-amygdalar circuitry in typically developing children (TDC). Here, we examine whether cortico-amygdalar variation relates to internalizing and externalizing behaviours in children with different NDDs.
Methods: Using data from the Province of Ontario Neurodevelopmental Disorder (POND) Network, we analyzed T1 weighted, resting state fMRI and diffusion weighted data from a transdiagnostic sample of children and youth (ages 6-18 years, n=157-346) with a primary diagnosis of ASD, ADHD, or OCD, and TDC. Cross-sectional behavioral assessments from the parent-report Child Behavioral Checklist (CBCL) and multi-modal imaging were used. Associations between externalizing or internalizing behavior and cortico-amygdalar network connectivity indices (i.e. structural covariance, functional connectivity white matter connectivity) were examined using linear regressions, controlling for age, gender, and modality specific covariates. 
Results: No significant associations (or diagnostic group-by-behavior interaction effects) were found between externalizing or internalizing behavior and any of the connectivity indices examined.
Conclusions: The null results of the current study do not provide evidence of a shared relationship between cortico-amygdalar network connectivity properties and externalizing or internalizing behavior across a transdiagnostic sample of children and youth. Using larger sample sizes, comprehensive behavioral batteries, and shifting the theoretical framework for examining brain-behavior relationships in transdiagnostic samples may be necessary for delineating such relationships.
coauthors: Hajer Nakua, Centre of Addiction and Mental Health, University of Toronto; Colin Hawco, Centre of Addiction and Mental Health, University of Toronto; Natalie Forde, Centre of Addiction and Mental Health, University of Toronto; Grace Jacobs, Centre of Addiction and Mental Health, University of Toronto; Michael Joseph, Centre of Addiction and Mental Health, University of Toronto; Aristotle Voineskos, Centre of Addiction and Mental Health, University of Toronto; Anne L.
