These methods enable simultaneous analysis of multiple connectomes across different scales of network topology, facilitating the discovery of hierarchical brain structures that vary in relation with phenotypic profiles. We validated these methods through extensive simulation studies, as well as synthetic and real-data experiments. Using a set of high-resolution connectomes obtained from genetically distinct mouse strains (including the BTBR mouse — a standard model of autism — and three behavioral wild-types), we show that these methods uncover valuable latent information in multi-subject connectomics data and yield novel insights into the connective correlates of neurological phenotypes.
coauthors: Vivek Gopalakrishnan, JHU;  Jaewon Chung, JHU;  Eric Bridgeford, JHU; Jesús Arroyo, JHU; Benjamin D. Pedigo, JHU; Carey E. Priebe, JHU; Joshua T. Vogelstein, JHU;
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Myelination of parvalbumin interneurons shapes the function of cortical sensory inhibitory circuits and mouse whisker-mediated behaviour
abstract:
Oligodendrocyte precursor cells (OPCs) represent the only non-neuronal cells that receive bona fide synapses from neurons. In the developing somatosensory cortex, we previously showed that OPCs are highly innervated by fast-spiking parvalbumin-expressing (PV) interneurons (Orduz et al., 2015, eLife; Orduz*, Benamer* et al., 2019, Nat Commun). Interestingly, the PV interneuron subtype represents the largest proportion of myelinated GABAergic neurons in the cerebral cortex. Despite several studies on neuron-OPC synapses, the function of these synapses remains poorly understood. In a recent work, we genetically inactivated γ2-mediated GABAergic synaptic signaling of OPCs to disturb PV interneuron-OPC synapses. We found that PV interneuron-OPC synapses does not highly affect OPC proliferation, oligodendrocyte differentiation and the developmental myelination pattern of the somatosensory cortex (Balia et al., 2017, Glia). Nonetheless, it has remained unclear whether neuron-OPC synapses could guide the correct myelination of the presynaptic neuron, impacting its function in neuronal circuits. 
Here, we demonstrate that the disruption of GABAergic synaptic signaling of OPCs prior to myelination onset resulted in severe PV interneuron myelination defects characterized by longer internodes and nodes and proximal axon malformation. Consequently, high-frequency PV interneuron discharges as well as PV interneuron-dependent postsynaptic latencies and strengths of excitatory neurons were reduced during postnatal cortical development. These dysfunctions generated a strong excitation-inhibition imbalance that was correlated with whisker-dependent texture discrimination impairments. We concluded that, during cortical development, the inactivation of γ2-mediated OPC synapses have profound consequences in the myelination of PV interneurons, affecting the function of mature cortical inhibitory circuits. Our data reveal that PV interneuron-OPC synaptic activity during postnatal development constitute a key step in the construction of cortical circuits involved in rapid and strong inhibition during sensory processing (Benamer et al., 2020, Nat Commun, In Press).
coauthors: Najate Benamer, Marie Vidal, Maddalena Balia, María Cecilia Angulo Institut of Psychiatry and Neurosciences of Paris (IPNP), INSERM U1266, Paris, France
institution: Institut of Psychiatry and Neurosciences of Paris
theme: Theme B: Neural Excitability, Synapses, and Glia

title: Recognition of Harmonic Sound Sequences Investigated By Behavioral And Electrophysiological Studies
abstract: Consonance rating when listening to the two consecutively or simultaneously presented sounds is associated with the ratio of their fundamental frequencies. The simpler ratio is perceived as more consonant. Most of the previous studies investigated the neural mechanism of the harmony perception of simultaneously presented complex tones and emphasized the role of auditory system in subcortical level. However, there is still little known about harmony perception of sequentially presented pure tones and its relation to the short-term memory. Earlier studies which investigated the role of harmonic intervals on recognition performance mostly compared tonal and atonal melodies in Western music with both musicians and nonmusicians, and the results were contradictory (Dewar et al., 1977; Krumhansl, 1979; Schulze et al., 2011;  Schulze et al., 2012). In those studies, melodies that were compared had different notes and contours. In this study, two melodies that consist of the same 10 tones were generated. Melodies had the same contour but differed order of tones, forming different harmonic relations between consecutive tones. Non-musician participants were asked to choose which melody (harmonic or inharmonic) was more consonant. The results showed that even though the ratings for in/harmonic melodies were not significantly different, it was easier for them to notice the same amount of frequency change in one note of the harmonic melody. An EEG experiment was conducted to test the working memory load hypothesis. The sustained anterior negativity (SAN) was compared as a measure of working memory load but amplitude of SAN did not reveal a significant difference. However, nonmatching stimulus elicited a P3b signal with higher amplitude for the harmonic condition. This result suggests that a higher level expectation occurs for harmonic condition since all the other parameters that affect P3b signal were well controlled in the experiment.
coauthors: Funda Yildirim
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: The role of delayed maturation of GABA-A receptor function in schizophrenia
abstract: Unlike positive and negative symptoms of schizophrenia, cognitive abnormalities of this disorder are manifested very early and are present in the prodromal period in preadolescent children. An imbalance in excitatory/inhibitory transmission in the prefrontal cortex (PFC) unrelated to synaptic pruning may underlie this preadolescent manifestation of cognitive deficits. In the normal brain, GABA binding to GABA-A receptors causes depolarization during early development then becomes hyperpolarizing owing to the changes in KCC2 and NKCC1 expression and function. Interestingly, premature ablation of the subplate (SP) layer of the developing visual cortex resulted in delayed upregulation of KCC2 causing a continued depolarizing effect of GABA in the cerebral cortex. Our laboratory described that neonatal ablation of the SP layer of the PFC in rat results in multiple behavioral and neuropathological abnormalities relevant to schizophrenia. In order to study the effects of a delayed GABA functional switch on cognitive function and PFC pathology of schizophrenia, we sought to ablate the SP layer of the developing PFC in postnatal day 1-old rats. Lesioned and sham-operated pups were sacrificed at different time points between P5 and 3 months, and coronal sections through the PFC were processed for immunohistochemical labeling of GAD67, parvalbumin, KCC2, and NKCC1.
coauthors: Kyla Gaeul Lee, Schulich School of Medicine and Dentistry, Western University; Raj Rajakumar, Schulich School of Medicine and Dentistry, Western University
theme: Theme A: Development, Neurodegenerative Disorders and Injury

title: Mechanism of Temporal Interference stimulation using in-vitro and in silico model of hippocampal gamma oscillation
abstract: It has been suggested that transcranial electrical stimulation using Temporal Interferential (TI) stimulation can be leveraged in neuromodulation of deep brain regions where the two high-frequency (kHz) electric fields intersect, and form Amplitude-Modulated waveform with low beating frequency (tens of Hz). However, superficial regions are exposed to higher magnitude but unmodulated sine waveform with a steady amplitude. The mechanisms through which CNS could be sensitive to Amplitude-Modulated with kHz carrier frequency but not unmodulated sinusoidal waveform is not yet understood. Explaining the cellular mechanism of Amplitude-Modulated high-frequency stimulation is thus of interest in developing rational optimized stimulation strategies. The effect of Amplitude-Modulated high-frequency electric fields on ongoing network activity was evaluated in carbachol-induced gamma oscillation in CA3a region of rat hippocampal slices. Extracellular local field potentials were analyzed before, during and after 2 s of stimulation. We tested unmodulated sine waveforms with low frequency (i.e. 5 Hz), kHz frequency (i.e. 1 and 2 kHz) and 5 Hz Amplitude-Modulated waveforms with 0.1, 1, and 2 kHz carrier frequencies. A validated MRI-derived head model predicted both peak electric fields in the cortex and depth of Amplitude-Modulation at deep regions during TI. We further developed a computational model of excitatory/inhibitory neuronal network with conductance-based synaptic interactions to explain the experimental results. Both experiment and model confirmed the hypothesis that spatial selectivity of temporal interference stimulation depends on the phasic modulation of neural oscillations only in deep brain regions. Adaptation mechanism (e.g. GABAb) enhanced sensitivity to amplitude modulated waveform in contrast to unmodulated kHz and produced selectivity in modulating gamma oscillation. Selection of carrier frequency strongly affected sensitivity to amplitude modulation stimulation. The TI sensitivity (current required at the scalp) depends on the active neuronal membrane time-constant approaching the kHz carrier frequency.
coauthors: Greg Kronberg, City college of New York; Davide Reato,Champalimaud Centre for the Unknown, Neuroscience Program, Lisbon, Portuga; lucas C parra, city college of New York; Marom Bikson, city college of New York
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Influence of the BDNF Val66Met Polymorphism on Modulation of Functional Brain Networks
abstract: Human brain-derived neurotrophic factor (BDNF) is an important protein responsible for the development and maintenance of neurons. Polymorphisms (i.e., genetic variations) of the BDNF protein have been implicated in overall reduction of functional connectivity (FC) within and between large-scale functional brain networks. Specifically, the well studied Val66Met BDNF polymorphism has been shown to impact connectivity of the default mode network (DMN), a group of brain regions critically involved in internally focused cognition. Furthermore, this polymorphism of BDNF protein has been shown to influence the effectiveness of non-invasive brain stimulation (NIBS) techniques, such as repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS). This presents a potential problem in using NIBS to modulate FC of brain networks in experimental and clinical settings (e.g., treatment of depression). We used resting-state functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) in combination with intermittent and continuous theta burst rTMS in young adults to evaluate the influence of the Val66Met polymorphism of BDNF on baseline FC of large-scale intrinsic functional networks, and the ability to modulate within and between-network FC using NIBS. The rTMS target stimulation site selected was the left inferior parietal lobule (IPL), a core node of the DMN, and was identified individually for a Val homozygote and a Met homozygote through functional task fMRI data. Resting-state fMRI data were collected before and after administering rTMS to the IPL. Results showed a reduction in baseline FC for a Met homozygote compared to a Val homozygote, both within the DMN and between the DMN and other large-scale brain networks. Furthermore, we found the ability to modulate within and between-network FC through rTMS was improved for a Val homozygote compared to a Met homozygote. These findings suggest that differences at the cellular level can influence differences in large-scale brain networks that impact the efficacy of rTMS methods according to individuals’ genotype.
coauthors: Vicente Alba Suarez, York University; Katherine M. Newman, York University; Caitlin Mullin, York University; Georg R. Zoidl, York University, Mark Halko, Harvard Medical School; Gary R. Turner, York University; & W. Dale Stevens, York University
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Social Transmission of Maternal Behaviors through Observation
abstract:
Oxytocin is a peptide hormone important for maternal physiology and social behaviors (Jurek & Neumann Physiol Rev 2018). One behavior influenced by central oxytocin signaling in rodents is pup retrieval (Marlin et al. Nature 2015; Scott et al. Nature 2015). When mouse pups are out of the nest, they emit vocalizations that prompt dams to fetch the pup back to the nest. Virgin females do not initially retrieve pups, but can learn to retrieve after several days of co-housing with an experienced mother and pups in a manner that may involve visual observational learning of dams interacting with the nest and pups (Carcea et al. BioRxiv 2019). 
To explore what aspects of maternal behavior are socially transmitted, we showed audio-visual movies to head-fixed awake virgins that initially did not retrieve. It allows us to manipulate the sensory stimuli presented to the virgins and further explore experience-related effects on behavior and neural activity. Our data (n=11) shows that virgins can learn to retrieve in the virtual setup, while virgins presented with dark background did not learn to retrieve (n=14). Alternatively, virgins presented with videos of maternal mistakes (out of the nest retrievals; n=4) or non-maternal behaviors (video of conspecific; n=8) lead to decreased performance. This setup is an essential step towards understanding which visual stimuli are informative for retrieval learning. It will allow us to manipulate sensorial experience, and employ electrophysiological and optogenetical techniques to further explore the role of oxytocin on social behavior.
coauthors: Naomi Lopez Caraballo; Robert Froemke
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: What is the cerebral cortex? A perspective from reptiles and amphibians
abstract: Vertebrates emerged more than 500 million years ago, and colonized water, land and air. Despite their diverse life histories, vertebrates share the same overall brain architecture, which is established during early embryonic development. Are correspondences, or homologies, extending beyond coarse brain regions, to the level of cell types and circuits? To address this question, we are studying cell types in the telencephalon, a brain region where the dramatic expansion of neuronal diversity in evolution is associated to morphological and functional novelties. We used single-cell transcriptomics to identify cell types in the simple three-layered cortex of reptiles, the sister group of mammals, and we are starting new work on an amphibian, the Spanish ribbed newt Pleurodeles waltl. Our quantitative comparison of single-cell transcriptomes across species sheds new light on the evolution of the mammalian six-layered neocortex. The transcriptomic signature of glutamatergic neurons in non-mammals suggests that mammalian neocortical layers are made of new cell types generated by diversification of ancestral gene-regulatory programs. By contrast, we find that the transcriptomes of cortical GABAergic neurons are conserved to an exquisite detail, suggesting that developmental or functional constraints shape the evolution of these cell types.
theme: Theme A: Development, Neurodegenerative Disorders and Injury

title: Integration of information in the perceptual decision making task
abstract: Perceptual decision making describes a process of deciding between available options based on the information from their senses. Recently, progress has been made to relate this behaviour to neural data. A number of computational models have been proposed to explain various aspects of the perceptual decision. Typically, those studies consider only a single dimensional binary decision. The multi-attribute decision-making research often focuses on multi-modal stimuli, ie. with different accumulation rates between attributes. Moreover, the evidence from animal studies shows that the brain tends to sum reward predictions from multiple cues. The details of the combination of evidence have not been studied in details in the perceptual decision paradigm, especially among the human subjects. In this study, we test whether the human brain combines the input from two information sources linearly (additively). We modify the classical random dots motion discrimination task by adding an additional axis of dots movement. We show that there are significant differences in terms of accuracy and reaction time between decisions made from the same amount of information provided by a single and two axes. In the congruent condition the accuracy and reaction times were lower when participants had to combine the data, but for the incongruent condition, participants were faster (but less accurate) when exposed to two axes. The angle between the access did not have a significant effect on analysed behaviour.
coauthors: Jiaxiang Zhang
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Transcriptomic contributions to the cytoarchitectonic parcellation of the human cerebral cortex.
abstract:
Abstract: 
Transcriptomic contributions to the functional and anatomical parcellation of the human cerebral cortex has become a major interest in systems neuroscience in the last decade. Recent research shows that active transcription of a small set of genes contributes to large-scale gradients and functional hierarchies in the human cerebral cortex (1,2). The combination of our previous findings has shown that different sets of genes contribute to the positioning of cortical areas within functional hierarchies (2) and the organization of functional maps within each cortical area (3). Here, we tested if either set of genes previously identified better explained the recent identification of over 88 cytoarchitectonic areas (4). Using a data-driven approach, we show that the genes previously identified to explain the functional organization of the visual processing hierarchy in human cortex better explains the arealization of these 88 cytoarchitectonic areas than the genes explaining functional maps within each visual area. Importantly, follow-up analyses show that an additional set of genes contribute to the cytoarchitectonic parcellation of the human cerebral cortex beyond those genes contributing to the parcellation of the human visual processing hierarchy. These results support a novel hypothesis that there is a nested spatial relationship among transcriptomic, anatomical, and functional parcellations of the human cerebral cortex at the level of maps (mm; areal), gradients and hierarchies (cm; within lobes), and networks (several cm; across lobes). We conclude by showing that a microanatomical substrate supporting this hypothesis across spatial scales is cell density. 
References:
1. Burt JB, Demirtaş M, Eckner WJ, Navejar NM, Ji JL, Martin WJ, et al. Hierarchy of transcriptomic specialization across human cortex captured by structural neuroimaging topography. Nat Neurosci. 2018. 21(9): 1251–1259.
2. Gomez J, Zhen Z, Weiner KS. Human visual cortex is organized along two genetically opposed hierarchical gradients with unique developmental and evolutionary origins. PLoS Biology. 2019. 17(7). e3000362.
3. Zhen, Z. Gomez, J., & Weiner, K. S. Opposing transcriptomic gradients explain orthogonal maps in human visual areas. bioRxiv. 2019. 
4. Amunts K, Mohlberg H, Bludau S, Zilles K. Julich-Brain: A 3D probabilistic atlas of the human brain's cytoarchitecture. Science. 2020. 369(6506): 988-992.
coauthors: Leana King, Helen Wills Neuroscience Institute, University of California Berkeley, Berkeley, California;  Jesse Gomez, Princeton Neuroscience Institute, Princeton University, Princeton, NJ; Zonglei Zhen,Beijing Key Laboratory of Applied Experimental Psychology, Beijing Normal University, Beijing, China, Faculty of Psychology, Beijing Normal University, Beijing, China; Kevin S. Weiner, Helen Wills Neuroscience Institute, University of California Berkeley, Berkeley, California, Psychology Department, University of California Berkeley, Berkeley, California.
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: When are open- and closed-loop control necessary for causal inference in neural circuits?
abstract:
Many hypotheses about neural circuits are best stated in terms of causal relationships: “Activity in this region causes an observed change in that downstream region.” Furthermore, the development of effective therapeutic interventions requires knowledge of the causal relationship between potential therapies, markers of disease states, and patient outcomes. However, in experiments where interventions such as lesioning are unavailable, a key ambiguity remains as to whether activity is correlated across two populations because of a structural feedforward connection, or instead arises through recurrent connections or unseen, confounding common inputs. Closed-loop approaches appear to be a promising solution because they can hold regions constant, decoupling them from confounding feedback pathways while maintaining naturalistic activity levels.
However, despite the increasing interest in closed-loop control from the systems neuroscience community, it is still poorly understood in which settings these approaches are necessary, and how best to design interventions. What is needed is a characterization of how and when closed-loop control improves identification in representative simulations of neural circuits. 
In this work we (1) summarize and integrate the existing understanding of network identification across several fields: systems neuroscience, control theory, and causal inference; (2) present a simplified approach for predicting whether two circuit hypotheses may be distinguished from data collected with passive, open-loop or closed-loop experiments; and (3) use a small network simulation of integrate and fire neurons to illustrate how network properties, including synaptic strength and internal time constants, impact how well the underlying causal structure of a circuit can be reconstructed.
	While this work examines a simple set of circuits, we hope that it facilitates a broader discussion around how to design interventions, and how to understand the limits of causal identification across a broad range of neural systems.
coauthors: Adam Willats, Georgia Institute of Technology & Emory University; Matthew O'Shaughnessy, Georgia Institute of Technology; Kyle Johnsen, Georgia Institute of Technology & Emory University; Christopher Rozell, Georgia Institute of Technology
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Modulation of deep mesencephalic nucleus to locomotor control in walking monkey
abstract: The deep mesencephalic nucleus (DpMe), also termed the midbrain locomotor region (MLR), is a large area within the midbrain reticular which plays a key role in integrating and processing sensory, cognitive, and limbic inputs and in turn translating this information into a motor command adapted to our current environment. DpMe cells have been shown to respond to passive vestibular (rotational) stimuli, which suggests that this region plays an important role in vestibulo-motor control. However, DpMe responses to active movements, such as locomotion have not yet been characterized. Here we recorded continuous single unit extracellular activities from the DpMe in rhesus monkeys. First, we applied passive translations and rotation to characterize the vestibular responses of neurons in the DpMe. Head-mounted 3Dgyroscopes/3Daccelerometers were used to record the head motion, and neural sensitivities to passive vestibular modulation were computed. Second, we recorded from the same DPME neurons during head-fixed treadmill walking.  Four high-speed cameras were used for motion recording synchronously. Deep-learning computer-vision toolbox (DeepLabCut) were used to extract the animals' 3D posture for gait analysis. We found that, when compared to resting activities, DpMe cells demonstrated a significant overall increase in activity during head-fixed treadmill walking. Notably, DpMe cells demonstrated phase-dependent modulation during walking, even in the absence of vestibular stimulation. Modulation patterns varied between DpMe cells- some cells demonstrated peak activity during swing phase, and others during stance. Taken together these results suggest that DpMe neurons play a critical role in processing multi-sensory input during the complex sensorimotor activities generated in everyday life, such as walking. In addition, our findings also advance our knowledge of the neural circuits that coordinate gait and balance and thus have important implications for the development of novel treatments and interventions.
coauthors: Erez Gugig, Johns Hopkins University;Oliver Stanley, Johns Hopkins University; Kathleen Cullen, Johns Hopkins University
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Modeling center-surround antagonism in neurons for potential application in the optogenetic gene therapy of retinal degeneration
abstract:
Retinal degenerative diseases lead to the death of photoreceptor cells and, ultimately, to blindness. Using optogenetics, it is possible to express light-activated membrane proteins (opsins) in survived retinal neurons to create artificial photoreceptors. A promising approach is to model center-surround antagonism in retinal neurons to partly restore visual information processing. In our study we used pyramidal neurons of mice and rats as a model system to model center-surround antagonism for possible use in the treatment of retinal degeneration.
  
We created a genetic construct carrying the genes of excitatory (CHR2) and inhibitory (GtACR2) light-activated proteins. A mutant IRES sequence was inserted between two genes to ensure an accurate two-gene expression ratio in each cell and to reduce the expression of the inhibitory opsin gene. In addition, excitatory opsin was targeted to the somatic region of cells using the Kv2.1 motif. We conducted transfection of mouse cortical neurons and primary cultures of rat hippocampal neurons with this genetic construct. Electrical activity of transfected neurons in primary cultures and brain slices was recorded by whole-cell patch-clamp. Blue light stimulation was applied to the central or peripheral area of a neuron. 

It was shown that light stimulation of the central area of the transfected neuron leads to cell activation. In contrast, light stimulation of the peripheral area of the neuron causes suppression of neuronal activity.

In our study, the center-surround antagonism was successfully modeled in neurons. The genetic construct containing genes of two light-activated proteins could have potential application in the therapy of retinal degeneration by delivery to retinal neurons using viral vectors.
coauthors: Petrovskaya L.E., Shemyakin-Ovchinnikov Institute of Bioorganic Chemistry; Roshchin M.V., Institute of Higher Nervous Activity and Neurophysiology; Smirnova G.R., Institute of Higher Nervous Activity and Neurophysiology; Balaban P.M., Institute of Higher Nervous Activity and Neurophysiology; Malyshev A.Y., Institute of Higher Nervous Activity and Neurophysiology.
institution: Institute of Higher Nervous Activity and Neurophysiology (grid.418743.d)
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: A 3D Parylene-based multi-electrode array for large-scale recordings from the rat hippocampus
abstract: Large-scale monitoring of resolvable neuronal activities from multiple hippocampal sub-regions of behaving animals provides valuable insights into neurobiological mechanisms underlying learning and memory. However, current state-of-the-art probes such as microwire and silicon electrodes are much stiffer than brain tissue, which largely increases the chance of inflammation, and therefore makes it difficult to consistently record high-quality signals over long period of time. Parylene C is a promising alternative structural and insulation material for building neural probes with reduced mechanical mismatch between tissue and implants. In our previous work, a 64-channel Parylene-based multi-electrode array with 8 shanks was developed and applied to chronic recording of the hippocampus in behaving rats. In our current work, a novel 3D Parylene-based probe consisting of 16 (2x8) shanks with a 250um spacing was developed. Each shank contains 8 platinum electrodes and thereby has a total of 128 electrodes. To aid insertion, dissolvable polyethylene glycol (PEG) brace was employed to temporarily support the flexible probe. The 3D Parylene probe was implanted at 2.6mm posterior to the bregma and 2.4mm lateral to the midline at a depth of 4.4mm. 59 units of neuronal activities were recorded immediately after the implantation. 6 shanks recorded 8 units from CA1 while 9 shanks recorded 51 units from CA3. Histology showed that the shanks were straightly inserted within the 2.5mm depth and began to split after this depth, which was due to the different dissolving rates on the surface of the PEG block. This preliminary result demonstrated the feasibility of implanting 3D flexible polymer probe to deep brain structures for large-scale recordings. In the next step, different insertion methods will be investigated to ensure straight insertion of the probes. The large-scale 3D Parylene probe will be tested both acutely and chronically for recording from multiple hippocampal regions in behaving rats.
coauthors: Xuechun Wang, University of Southern California; Huijing Xu, University of Southern California; Ellis Meng, University of Southern California; Dong Song, University of Southern California
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Transmitter switching contributes to two environmental models of  neurodevelopmental disorders
abstract:
Early environmental factors play a key role in emergence of neurodevelopmental disorders and cortical neurotransmitter imbalance is a convergent phenotype seen across different types of disorders. Neurotransmitter switching involves loss of one transmitter and gain of another often changing the sign of the synapse from excitatory to inhibitory or vice versa and altering behavior (Spitzer, 2017). We are testing the hypothesis that transmitter switching contributes to these disorders in mouse models. We treat pregnant females with either Poly Inosine:Cytosine (Poly I:C) or valproic acid (VPA)  at embryonic day E12.5 and assess the progeny for molecular and behavioral changes.
    Both treatments cause a transient decrease of 6000 GAD67+ neurons and an equal increase of vGluT1+ neurons in the mPFC at postnatal day (P)10 in experimental mice compared to controls that disappears by P90. These changes do not result from altered number of precursors or apoptosis and occur specifically in PV+ and CCK+ neurons. P90 animals demonstrate enhanced stereotypy and deficits in social interaction compared to controls.  
    Stereotaxic injection of P9 PV-Cre/CCK-Cre Poly I:C-treated mice with Cre-dependent HSV-GFP revealed vGluT1+GFP+ neurons in the neonatal mPFC at P13 demonstrating expression of vGluT1 in a subset of PV-Cre/CCK-Cre neurons, providing evidence for transmitter switching in single neurons.
    To test the role of the transmitter switch in emergence of behavioral deficits, we stereotaxically injected P9 male and female PV-Cre/CCK-Cre mice with Cre-dependent HSV-GAD1-GFP. This restored GAD67+GFP+ neurons in PV and CCK cells in experimental mice and prevented gain of vGluT1 in GFP+ neurons by P13 unlike Poly I:C-treated controls injected with HSV-GFP. Restoring GAD67 also rescued altered behavior in P90 experimental male mice. Our results add to growing evidence that alteration in signaling in the nervous system during the early stages of its construction can be detrimental to the function of the mature brain.
coauthors: Nicholas C Spitzer, University of California San Diego
theme: Theme A: Development, Neurodegenerative Disorders and Injury

title: Back to Reality: Differences in Learning Strategy in a Simplified Virtual and a Real Throwing Task
abstract: Virtual environments have been widely utilized in motor neuroscience and rehabilitation as they afford tight control of sensorimotor conditions and readily afford visual and haptic manipulations. However, typically studies have only examined performance in the virtual testbeds, without asking how performance in the virtual environment compares to behavior in the real world. To test whether performance in the virtual environment is a valid representation of corresponding behavioral features in the real world, this study compared throwing in a virtual set-up with realistic throwing where the task parameters were precisely matched. Even though the virtual task only required a horizontal single-joint arm movement, similar to many simplified movement assays in motor neuroscience and also modeling, throwing accuracy and precision was significantly better in the real task; only after three practice days did success rate and error reach same levels. To gain more insight into the structure of the learning process movement variability was decomposed into deterministic and stochastic contributions. Using the Tolerance-Noise-Covariation decomposition method revealed distinct stages of learning: Tolerance was optimized first in both environments but was higher in the virtual environment, suggesting that more familiarization and exploration is needed in the virtual task. Covariation and noise showed far fewer and only contributions late in practice of the real task, indicating that subjects reached the stage of fine-tuning of deterministic and stochastic aspects of variability only in the real task. These results showed that while the tasks were precisely matched, the simplified movements in the virtual environment required more time to be successful. These findings resonate with the reported problems in transfer of therapeutic benefits from virtual to real environments and alert that the use of virtual environments in research and rehabilitation needs more caution.
coauthors: Zhaoran Zhang, Columbia University; Dagmar Sternad, Northeastern University
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: “I listen for your voice”: The Influence of art/design on parental stress, experience and engagement in the Neonatal Intensive Care Unit
abstract: Current research indicates a strong correlation between parental involvement in the Neonatal Intensive Care Unit (NICU), and better health outcomes for babies.  Healthcare Interior Designers are responsible for designing spaces that not only meet all current standards and best practices, but also consider the experiences of the people who inhabit these spaces.  With the focus of healthcare design shifting towards an evidence-based approach, there is opportunity to expand the current body of knowledge with further research, to help guide the design of facilities and have a positive impact on the health and wellbeing of patients, visitors and staff.  My thesis focuses on the idea of integrating environmental graphic art installations in the NICU to provide a medium through which messages can be communicated to parents to support, educate and encourage them to spend more time with their babies, potentially leading to better health outcomes.  Research will incorporate findings from Contemporary Western Art/Architectural History, specifically looking at art in hospitals, Environmental Psychology to investigate how we are affected by the built environments that surrounds us, and Visual Communication to understand how text, image and content can be used to convey a message with the goal of affecting human behaviour.  This is a unique and exciting research opportunity that extends across disciplines, where a gap in the research exists.  If this contribution bridges the gap, there is the potential to have significant impact on the health and wellbeing of people in the NICU.
coauthors: Laurena Clark, York University; David Scadding, York University; Dr. Upali Nanda, University of Michigan; Dr. Joseph DeSouza, York University
theme: Theme F: History, Education and Society

title: Autonomic Dysfunction in Parkinson’s Disease: An Application of Machine Learning for Clinical Diagnosis
abstract:
Background: Parkinson’s Disease (PD) is a progressive neurological disorder characterized by cardinal motor symptoms including tremor, rigidity, and slowness of movement. Today, diagnosis relies on the presence of motor symptoms when predominant lesions have already occurred peripherally and centrally. However, nonmotor symptoms such as autonomic dysfunction appear prior to motor symptoms and have the potential to serve as biomarkers for prodromal PD. The goal of the current study is to assess autonomic dysfunction as a possible biomarker in patients with Parkinson’s Disease. 

Methods: We measured subjective autonomic symptoms as well as heart rate variability and blood pressure in patients with PD and healthy subjects. The clinical data was analyzed to discriminate between the parkinsonian and healthy state using a suite of machine learning algorithms. The relative importance of different biomarkers was extracted to determine which features of autonomic dysfunction are most predictive of PD. 

Results:  Machine learning algorithms attained high accuracy (F1 > 0.80) in classifying between PD and control subjects. Nonlinear features of heart rate variability were the most important features, including Approximate Entropy and the Hurst Exponent. Statistical analysis confirmed significantly lower levels of entropy in patients with PD. PCA achieved lower accuracy (76%) in comparison to the machine learning ensemble. PCA showed that Hurst Exponent and High Frequency spectral power were positively correlated with the parkinsonian state, while Median Instantaneous Frequency and Entropy were negatively correlated with the parkinsonian state. 

Conclusions: Machine learning analysis revealed that autonomic dysfunction was highly predictive of PD. The high-ranking performance of nonlinear features suggests that autonomic control is more complex than antagonistic interactions between sympathetic and parasympathetic nervous systems. Additionally, the effective performance of nonlinear features suggests their utility as biomarkers for early stage PD.
coauthors: Olivier Darbin, University of South Alabama
theme: Theme A: Development, Neurodegenerative Disorders and Injury

title: Machine Learning Framework for Fully Automatic Quality Control of Registrations in Big Data brain MRI
abstract:
In analysis of brain structural magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) data, rigid and affine registration of individual subject’s brain to a reference brain is a vital step in pre-processing stage. In general, the registered images could be checked manually or semi-manually for quality of alignment. However, this visual quality control becomes a tedious process when we deal with big data MRI processing containing thousands of images. Therefore, there is a strong need to fully automate this quality checking process. Hence, I propose to develop and deploy different machine learning (ML) classifiers for quality checking of both rigid and affine registrations. 
Firstly, the cost functions such as normalized cross-correlation, normalized mutual information and correlation ratio are computed by comparing the subject’s registration to the template with the template. These cost values are computed locally at a 3x3x3 volume of interest (VOI) and further moving this VOI with a stride of 3. Final cost value is the average of cost values obtained in each VOI. Further, these are also the features used for training different ML classifiers including linear discriminant analysis, support vector machine, kNN, random forest, Gaussian naive bayes. These ML classifiers are 5-fold cross validated on a subset of T1-weighted MRI data from autism brain imaging data exchange (ABIDE I) consisting of 220 images. These images were rigidly and affinely transformed to the template by using the FSL interface in Nipype. Further, 220 incorrectly registered images were generated by changing the values in transformation matrices and then applying these modified matrices to register the image to the template. 
All ML classifiers achieved a testing accuracy of 99.9 % for both rigid and affine registrations. Eventually, these trained ML models  could be deployed for automatic quality checking of image registrations involving big data there by eliminating the need for manual intervention.
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: An ROI-based fMRI Study of Schizophrenia for Identification of Affected Brain Regions
abstract: Schizophrenia, a severe psychological disorder, is very prevalent in the world. The research on schizophrenia using machine learning techniques and neuroimaging is an active area of study. The functional Magnetic Resonance Imaging (fMRI) helps to identify the brain activity in voxels, consisting of measured changes in blood-oxygen-level-dependent (BOLD) signals over time. Based on the fMRI data of 34 schizophrenia patients and 34 healthy controls, we performed a Region of Interest (ROI) study on the identified brain regions for studying hundreds of literature over the last 30 years. Besides, we parcellate the brain into four levels of hierarchy, Hemisphere, Gyrus, Lobes, and Cell type (Broadmann Areas). We applied statistical feature selection techniques, such as t-test and Pearson's Correlation on the preprocessed data to identify the significant regions in each level. The selected features were used for training several machine learning classifiers to analyze the prediction performance of affected brain regions. As for the machine learning approach, we used various classifiers such as K-nearest Neighbor, Naive Bayes, Decision Tree, Random Forest, Support Vector Machines, and Extreme Learning Machines. We achieved the highest classification accuracy of around 84 % on the Pearson's correlation selected Lobe's data, 84 % on the Broadmann areas' data, and similarly 81 % on the Gyrus data and Hemisphere data. Furthermore, we performed backtracking of the statistically significant selected features and visualized them better to understand the affected brain areas in schizophrenia patients. The reviewed papers depicted region-wise changes in schizophrenia confirm our findings. With the result of our work, we examined the previous research conclusions on an ROI-based approach. Also, we found some affected brain regions, which were never reported before in the literature on schizophrenia. These new findings may open up a possible way of understanding schizophrenia patients' brains from different perspectives.
coauthors: Lea Baumgärtner, Hochschule der Medien, University of Applied Science, Stuttgart - 70569, Germany;
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Expectations can boost the encoding of specific features of noisy speech
abstract:
Expectations about our environment can help us extract meaningful signals from noisy sensory inputs. In some cases, our brain can even replace what is missing, a phenomenon called perceptual filling-in. However, it is still unclear whether perceptual filling-in changes the encoding of information or acts on post-encoding processes.

Here, we investigated auditory perceptual filling-in in 19 participants who listened to two categories of noisy speech: (1) noise vocoded speech (NVS), in which spectral features are replaced by amplitude-modulated band-limited noise, and (2) sine-wave speech (SWS), in which formants are replaced with sinusoids. Both SWS and NVS were created from intelligible speech. Participants were instructed to rate the clarity of NVS and SWS stimuli before and after seeing the original sentence (prior+), a different sentence (prior-), or nothing at all (prior0). High-density EEG was recorded throughout the task.

Displaying the correct (prior+) or incorrect (prior-) sentence induced a state of active listening, characterised by an increase in alpha oscillations. However, only the display of the original sentence (prior+) had a positive effect on clarity (perceptual insight). To investigate how expectations shaped sensory encoding, we used a technique designed to reconstruct auditory features (envelope, spectrogram, phonemes, etc) from the EEG recorded during sound presentation. Stimulus reconstruction was more efficient following the presentation of the correct (prior+) compared to the incorrect sentence (prior-). This increase in stimulus reconstruction was accompanied by a desynchronization within the theta band. These results suggest that perceptual filling-in directly acts on the encoding of auditory information, with the amplification of low-level features of auditory inputs such as the acoustic envelope.
coauthors: Andrew Corcoran, Monash University; Ricardo Perera, Monash University; Matthieu Koroma, Ecole Normale Supérieure; Sid Kouider, Ecole Normale Supérieure; Jakob Hohwy, Monash University; Thomas Andrillon, Monash University
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Hippocampal representations emerge when training recurrent neural networks on a memory dependent maze navigation task
abstract: Can neural networks learn goal-directed behaviour using similar strategies the brain uses to combine the relationships between the current state of the organism and the consequences of future actions? Recent work has shown that recurrent neural networks trained on goal based tasks can develop representations resembling those found in the brain, entorhinal cortex grid cells, for instance. Here we explore the evolution of the dynamics of their internal representations and compare this with experimental data. We observe that once a recurrent network is trained to learn the structure of its environment solely based on sensory prediction, an attractor based landscape forms in the network's representation, which parallels hippocampal place cells in structure and function. Next, we extend the predictive objective to include Q-learning for a reward task, where rewarding actions are dependent on delayed cue modulation. Mirroring experimental findings in hippocampus recordings in rodents performing the same task, this training paradigm causes nonlocal neural activity to sweep forward in space at decision points, anticipating the future path to a rewarded location. Moreover, prevalent choice and cue-selective neurons form in this network, again recapitulating experimental findings. Together, these results indicate that combining predictive, unsupervised learning of the structure of an environment with reinforcement learning can help understand the formation of hippocampus-like representations containing both spatial and task-relevant information.
coauthors: Matthias Hennig, University of Edinburgh
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Grouped single-unit activity in a cortical avian nucleus supports a population model of birdsong production in Serinus canaria
abstract:
Birdsong requires fine coordination of the muscles in the vocal organ and respiratory system. The song system, which is the neural architecture dedicated to song production in oscine birds, poses a beautiful opportunity to model the activity of a circuit of interconnected neural nuclei for the production of complex behaviour.

Such a model has been developed previously by our laboratory. Our model makes specific predictions about the timing of population neural activity in different nuclei needed to produce song and can reproduce respiratory patterns observed in canary song phrases of different types.

In this work, the model was used to generate respiratory patterns that correspond to two types of phrases of canary song, given a proposed sparse activity in nucleus HVC (proper name), one of the nuclei involved. This telencephalic nucleus plays a key role in the production of motor commands, but the neural code it uses is still under debate.

We put our model to the test by recording extracellularly from nucleus HVC in singing canaries, isolating single-units that fire during particular phrase types and analyzing at which song instances these neurons fire.

We found that grouped activity across animals is in good correspondence to the population activity that can produce realistic respiratory patterns in our model for the two types of phrases studied. Furthermore, the experimental data show activity in additional song instances that will enrich further iterations of the model.
coauthors: Santiago Boari, Dpto. de Física, Facultad de Ciencias Exactas y Naturales, Universidad de Buenos Aires, Buenos Aires, Argentina and Instituto de Física de Buenos Aires, IFIBA-CONICET, Buenos Aires, Argentina; Gabriel B. Mindlin, Dpto. de Física, Facultad de Ciencias Exactas y Naturales, Universidad de Buenos Aires, Buenos Aires, Argentina and Instituto de Física de Buenos Aires, IFIBA-CONICET, Buenos Aires, Argentina; Ana Amador, Dpto. de Física, Facultad de Ciencias Exactas y Naturales, Universidad de Buenos Aires, Buenos Aires, Argentina and Instituto de Física de Buenos Aires, IFIBA-CONICET, Buenos Aires, Argentina
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: An Application of Wavelet Transforms to Identify the Spatial Scale of Multivariate Activity Patterns in Functional MRI data
abstract: The brain is hierarchically organized across different spatial scales. In occipital cortex, the question of whether visual information is represented at a fine or coarse spatial scale remains debated. Common methods for analyzing functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) data, such as multivariate pattern analysis (MVPA) techniques, often neglect the spatial structure of brain activity patterns. Past approaches to investigating spatial scales, such as smoothing, do not allow individual spatial scales to be stringently confined. In this study, we applied a method for quantifying spatial scales –the wavelet transform– that overcomes these limitations. With this technique, we define a set of features that take scale and directionality information into account to represent activity patterns using a dual-tree complex wavelet transform (dt-CWT). We classified these features from fMRI data collected as participants viewed four visual categories (faces, places, artifacts, fruits) using the XGBoost algorithm, for each of five spatial scales generated by the wavelets. In occipital cortex, we were able to decode visual categories based on the features generated using the wavelets at coarser but not finer spatial scales. These results suggest visual categories differ more in their spatial organization at lower frequencies in occipital cortex. The categories could not be decoded based on their spatial scales in ventral temporal cortex, suggesting they may be represented at similar spatial scales.
coauthors: Heather Bruett, University of Pittsburgh; Marc N. Coutanche, University of Pittsburgh
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Building a convolutional neural network to study the combination of allocentric and egocentric information
abstract:
Both behavioural (e.g. Byrne et. al, 2010; Klinghammer et. al, 2017) and physiology (e.g. Bharmauria) studies have shown that allocentric and egocentric information are combined for goal-directed movements toward visual targets. Nevertheless, the intrinsic coordinate representation and underlying processes for this combination remain a puzzle, mainly due to inadequacy of current theoretical models to explain data at different levels (i.e. behaviour, single neuron, or distributed networks). In response, we aim to build a theoretical framework to tackle this challenge. In particular, we propose a physiologically inspired neural network with two major components. First, a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) to extract the allocentric and target information: Our CNN performs repeated convolution, rectifications, and normalization to first extract low level features from input images. With the features extracted, the challenge is to combine them to generate an abstract representation (allocentric cues and target position). We address this challenge by training a feature pooling layer at the end of our CNN network. Second, a Multi-Layer Perceptron network (MLP), which combines the allocentric information, here extracted feature maps from the CNN, with egocentric information, here initial gaze position, and generates the final gaze position: Our MLP consists of three fully connected hidden layers. These three layers incrementally transform the separately input allocentric and egocentric representations into an integrated motor response. Finally, following the MLP, an additional layer transforms motor responses into final gaze positions. We were able to train these physiologically-inspired networks to achieve good correspondence with test dataset (MLP: R2 = 0.99). These results suggest that our framework provides a suitable tool to study the underlying mechanisms of allocentric and egocentric integration.
We would like to thank Vista for funding this research.
coauthors: Richard Wildes; Douglas Crawford
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Developmental differences in white matter tracts between and within the dorsal and ventral streams
abstract: A relatively unexplored group of white matter tracts that connect cortical regions associated with the ventral and dorsal visual streams have recently been described and made available for scientific investigation. We utilized diffusion MRI and reproducible, cloud-computing methods to characterize the development of these vertical white matter tracts in a cross-sectional sample of 24 children (5-8 years old) and 12 adults (18-22 years old). We then compared the development of these posterior vertical tracts to the development of horizontal tracts within the ventral and dorsal visual streams. Horizontal tracts within the ventral stream had FA that was more adult-like than horizontal tracts in the dorsal cortex, consistent with prior work. The development of the posterior vertical tracts was more similar to the development of the horizontal tracts in the ventral visual stream than tracts in the dorsal cortex, with higher FA values found in adults than in children. In one tract, the pArc, FA was predicted by performance on a perceptual matching task in the child sample. Our results suggest that posterior vertical tracts develop later than ventral stream tracts, but earlier than tracts in the dorsal cortex, and that the development of posterior vertical tracts may be related to the influence of perceptual processing on dorsally-mediated action in childhood.
coauthors: Vinci-Booher, S., Indiana University; Bullock, D., Indiana University;  Caron, B., Indiana University; James, K.H., Indiana University; Pestilli, F. , Indiana University, University of Texas
theme: Theme A: Development, Neurodegenerative Disorders and Injury

title: Impact of developmental dysfunction of parvalbumin interneurons on  neural circuit function
theme: Theme A: Development, Neurodegenerative Disorders and Injury

title: Cortico-cerebellar networks as decoupled neural interfaces
abstract:
The brain solves the credit assignment problem remarkably well. For credit to be correctly assigned across multiple cortical areas a given area should, in principle, wait for others to finish their computation. How the brain deals with this locking problem has remained unclear. Deep learning methods suffer from similar locking constraints both on the forward and backward phase. Recently, decoupled neural interfaces (DNI) were introduced as a solution to the forward and backward locking problems.
Here we propose that a specialised brain region, the cerebellum, helps the cerebral cortex solve the locking problem closely matching the computations and architecture of DNI. In particular, we propose that classical cerebellar forward and inverse models are equivalent to solving the backward and forward locking problems, respectively. We tested the cortico-cerebellar-DNI (CC-DNI) model in a range of sensorimotor and cognitive tasks that have been shown to be cerebellar-dependent. First, we show that the CC-DNI unlocking mechanisms can facilitate learning in a simple target reaching task. Next, by building on the sequential MNIST task we demonstrate that these results generalise to more complex sensorimotor tasks. Our cortico-cerebellar model readily applies to a wider range of modalities, to demonstrate this we tested the model in a cognitive task, caption generation. Models without the cerebellar-DNI component exhibit deficits similar to what has been observed in cerebellar patients in both motor and cognitive tasks. Finally, we introduce a CC-DNI model with highly sparse connectivity as observed in the cerebellum, which substantially reduces the number of parameters while improving learning through decorrelation.
Overall, our work offers a novel perspective on the cerebellum as a brain-wide decoupling machine for efficient credit assignment and opens a new avenue of research between deep learning and neuroscience.
coauthors: Ellen Boven; Rui Ponte Costa; Richard Apps
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Neural flexibility and the propensity to change opinions following online media consumption
abstract: Digital persuasive media have a profound effect on decision-making. Recent communication neuroscience research shows a significant relationship between frontal brain regional activity and opinion change. Despite these findings, the neural dynamics that give rise to this relationship and the extent to which these effects extend beyond the laboratory are largely unexplored. Here, we utilize a network science approach -- dynamic community detection -- to extract brain network dynamics, and extend this method to data that mirrors neural activity of digital media consumers today. We investigate the dynamic coactivity of neural correlates of opinion change, as prompted by consumption of online persuasive media. Electroencephalographic (EEG) activity was collected from 240 healthy and diverse participants while interacting with biased content in a social media environment. Before and after interacting with the platform, participants were asked their opinions on vaccinations, capital punishment, corporate investment practices and politics. After calculating opinion change scores, we estimated the statistical relationship of the bandpassed EEG data (delta: 1-3Hz, theta: 4-7Hz, alpha: 8-12 Hz, beta: 13-25Hz, gamma: 30-40Hz) between electrodes with a weighted phase-lag index (wPLI). These connectivity matrices were then subjected to the dynamic community detection algorithm to extract network metrics that quantify the propensity of “nodes” (electrodes, here) to change their network affiliation across time.  We show that network flexibility and promiscuity of frontal nodes, specifically within gamma and alpha bands, during engagement with persuasive digital content, are significantly associated with opinion change. These results indicate that coactivation of the frontal brain region with other network communities explains, in part, an individual’s likelihood to alter their position on a sensitive issue. Our results highlight the importance of neural coordination in our decision making process and provide support of the importance of frontal regions in shaping our opinions, not only in the laboratory, but also in a real-world scenario.
coauthors: Kristen Flaherty, US CCDC Army Research Laboratory, Aberdeen Proving Ground, MD, Northeastern University, Boston, MA; Italo’Ivo Pinto, US CCDC Army Research Laboratory, Aberdeen Proving Ground, MD; Aditi Periyannan, US CCDC Army Research Laboratory, Aberdeen Proving Ground, MD, Tufts University, Medford, MA; Amir Meghdadi, University of California, Santa Barbara, Santa Barbara, CA, Advanced Brain Monitoring, Carlsbad, CA; Christian Richard, Advanced Brain Monitoring, Carlsbad, CA; Chris Berka, Advanced Brain Monitoring, Carlsbad, CA; Kanika Bansal, US CCDC Army Research Laboratory, Aberdeen Proving Ground, MD, Department of Biomedical Engineering, Columbia University, New York, NY; Javier Garcia, US CCDC Army Research Laboratory, Aberdeen Proving Ground, MD
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Neural Stem Cell Lineage Progression in Developing Cerebral Cortex
theme: Theme A: Development, Neurodegenerative Disorders and Injury

title: Obesity impairs cognitive function via metabolic syndrome and cerebrovascular disease: an SEM analysis in 15,000 adults from the UK Biobank
abstract: Chronic obesity is associated with several complications, including cognitive impairment and dementia. However, we have piecemeal knowledge of the mechanisms linking obesity to central nervous system damage. Candidate mechanisms are metabolic syndrome, consisting of inflammation, hypertension, dyslipidemia and insulin resistance. While there have been several neuroimaging studies linking adiposity to changes in brain morphometry, a comprehensive investigation of the relationship has so far not been done. Here we use structural equation modelling in 15,000 individuals from the UK Biobank to identify the causal chain linking adiposity to cognitive dysfunction. We found that body mass index and waist-to-hip ratio were positively related to higher plasma C-reactive protein, dyslipidemia, occurrence of hypertension and diabetes, all of which were in turn related to cerebrovascular disease as measured by volume of white matter hyperintensities on magnetic resonance imaging. White mater hyperintensities were associated with lower cortical thickness and volume and higher subcortical volumes, which were associated with cognitive deficits. We also observed that white matter dysconnectivity, as measured by fractional anisotropy and mean diffusivity, was a major cause of impaired cognition. Our results have clinical implications, supporting a role for the management of adiposity in the prevention of late-life dementia and cognitive decline.
coauthors: Mahsa Dadar, Laval University; Alain Dagher, McGill University
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Audio-visual training in older adults: 2-Interval-Forced Choice Task improves performance
abstract: A growing interest in ameliorating multisensory perception deficits in older adults arises from recent evidence showing that impaired multisensory processing, particularly in the temporal domain, may be associated with cognitive and functional impairments. Older adults exhibit an extended temporal binding window (the timeframe during which the brain integrates inputs from different senses into a multisensory percept) which has been associated with mild cognitive impairment and falls-risk. Perceptual training has proved successful in improving multisensory temporal processing in young adults, but few studies have investigated this training approach in older adults. In the present study we used a simultaneity (or synchronicity) judgement task with feedback, to train the audio-visual abilities of community-dwelling, cognitively healthy older adults. We recruited 23 older adults (M = 74.17, SD = 6.23)  and a group of 20 young adults (M = 24.20, SD = 4.23) who served as a comparison. Participants were tested before and after perceptual training using a 2-Interval Forced Choice Task (2-IFC); and the Sound-Induced Flash Illusion (SIFI). After three days of training, participants improved on the 2-IFC task, with a significant narrowing of the temporal window of integration found for both groups. Generalisation of training effects was not found, with no post-training differences in perceptual sensitivity to the SIFI for either group. These findings provide evidence perceptual narrowing can be achieved in older as well as younger adults after three days of perceptual training. This research contributes to mounting evidence that multisensory processing deficits in older adults’ can be modified through targeted perceptual training. Perceptual training could potentially represent a novel intervention avenue for populations whose impairments are associated with underlying multisensory processing difficulties (e.g. fall-prone older adults).
coauthors: Annalisa Setti, University College Cork; Jason Chan, University College Cork
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Identifying learning rules from neural network observables
abstract:
The brain modifies its synaptic strengths during learning in order to better adapt to its environment.
However, the underlying plasticity rules that govern learning are unknown.
Many proposals have been suggested, including Hebbian mechanisms, explicit error backpropagation, and a variety of alternatives.
It is an open question as to what specific experimental measurements would need to be made to determine whether any given learning rule is operative in a real biological systems.
In this work, we take a "virtual experimental" approach to this problem.
Simulating idealized neuroscience experiments with artificial neural networks, we generate a large-scale dataset of learning trajectories of aggregate statistics measured in a variety of neural network architectures, loss functions, learning rule hyperparameters, and parameter initializations.
We then take a discriminative approach, training linear and simple non-linear classifiers to identify learning rules from features based on these observables.
We show that different classes of learning rules can be separated solely on the basis of aggregate statistics of the weights, activations, or instantaneous layer-wise activity changes, and that these results generalize to limited access to the trajectory and held-out architectures and learning curricula.
We identify the statistics of each observable that are most relevant for rule identification, finding that statistics from network activities across training are more robust to unit undersampling and measurement noise than those obtained from the synaptic strengths.
Our results suggest that activation patterns, available from electrophysiological recordings of post-synaptic activities on the order of several hundred units, frequently measured at wider intervals over the course of learning, may provide a good basis on which to identify learning rules.
coauthors: Sanjana Srivastava, Stanford University; Surya Ganguli, Stanford University; Daniel Yamins, Stanford University
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Prefrontal and Parietal Neuronal Activity Mediates Working Memory Judgments
abstract: The dorsolateral prefrontal cortex plays a critical role in spatial working memory and its activity predicts behavioral responses in delayed response tasks. Here we addressed if this predictive ability extends to other working memory tasks, and if it is present in other brain areas. We trained monkeys to remember the location of a stimulus and determine whether a second stimulus appeared at the same location or not. Neurophysiological recordings were performed in the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex and posterior parietal cortex. We hypothesized that random drifts causing the peak activity of the network to move away from the first stimulus location and towards the location of the second stimulus would result in categorical errors. Indeed, for both areas, in non-matching trials, when the first stimulus appeared in a neuron’s preferred location, the neuron showed significantly higher firing rates in correct than in error trials, and vice versa, when the first stimulus appeared at a non-preferred location, activity in error trials was higher than in correct. The results indicate that the activity of both dlPFC and PPC neurons is predictive of categorical judgments of information maintained in working memory, and neuronal firing rate deviations are revealing of the contents of working memory.
coauthors: Sihai Li, Department of Neurobiology & Anatomy, Wake Forest School of Medicine; Christos Constantinidis, Department of Neurobiology & Anatomy, Wake Forest School of Medicine; and Xue-Lian Qi, Department of Neurobiology & Anatomy, Wake Forest School of Medicine.
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: A functional hierarchy for choice in medial prefrontal cortex
abstract: Hierarchical approaches to functional neuroanatomy propose that choice-relevant brain regions have overlapping functions and can be organized into a series that progressively transforms information about options into choices. Here, we examined responses of neurons in four regions of the medial prefrontal cortex as macaques performed two-option risky choices. All four regions encoded economic variables in similar proportions and showed putative signatures of key choice-related computations. We found evidence for a hierarchical organization proceeding from areas 14→25→32→24. Specifically, we found that decodability of eight distinct task variables increased along that path, consistent with the idea that hierarchically later regions make these variables more separable. We also found longer intrinsic timescales in the same series, further supporting the idea of a hierarchy. Together these results highlight the importance of the medial wall in choice, endorse a specific hierarchical organization, and argue against a modular functional neuroanatomy of choice.
coauthors: Tyler Cash-Padgett, Maya Wang, Benjamin Hayden, Sarah Heilbronner, Jan Zimmermann
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Equilibrium Propagation for Complete Directed Neural Networks
abstract: Artificial neural networks, one of the most successful approaches to supervised learning, were originally inspired by their biological counterparts. However, the most successful learning algorithm for artificial neural networks, backpropagation, is considered biologically implausible. We contribute to the topic of biologically plausible neuronal learning by building upon and extending the equilibrium propagation learning framework. Specifically, we introduce: a new neuronal dynamics and learning rule for arbitrary network architectures; a sparsity-inducing method able to prune irrelevant connections; a dynamical-systems characterization of the models, using Lyapunov theory.
coauthors: Matilde Tristany Farinha, INESC-ID Dept. of Mathematics, IST, University of Lisbon, Portugal; Sérgio Pequito, Dept. of Industrial and Systems Engineering, RPI, Troy (NY), USA; Pedro A. Santos, INESC-ID  Dept. of Mathematics, IST, University of Lisbon, Portugal; Mário A. T. Figueiredo, Instituto de Telecomunicações, IST, University of Lisbon, Portugal;
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: The social brain: Interacting networks enabling the understanding of others
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Predictive Sensing: The Role of Motor Signals in Sensory Processing During Active Self-Motion
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Cortical Endogenous Opioids and Repetitive Behaviors in Deer Mice
abstract:
Goal: Our research aims to understand the pathophysiologic mechanism(s) underlying human movement disorders. 

Background: Repetitive movement disorders, such as tics and stereotypies, are common in the pediatric population. Although alterations in cortical-basal ganglia-thalamo-cortical circuits may be involved, there are numerous unanswered questions. Deer mice (Peromyscus maniculatus) provide a non-pharmacologically induced model for studying underlying mechanisms. 

Methodology: Investigative approaches, to date, have included stereological studies designed to identify anatomical alterations in the cortex, striatum, and cerebellum, and techniques that quantify regional neurotransmitters (e.g., LC-MS and RNAscope).  
Results: Stereological studies have identified a significant negative correlation between cell count in the ventral striatum and repetitive activity. Neurochemically, a significant negative correlation was observed between the repetitive activity of deer mice and the LC-MS/MS quantified endogenous opioids (leu-enkephalin (enk) and dynorphin-A (dyn-A) in the frontal cortex (FC) [Augustine et al. 2020]. Based on these findings, we have postulated that endogenous opioids in the cortex regulate the balance of activity within cortical-striatal pathways, either via goal-directed/habitual pathways, direct/indirect systems, or inhibitory circuits. For example, the FC originates habitual behaviors via cortical projections to striatal medium-spiny-neurons (MSNs) that participate in the DRD1-expressing (direct) and DRD2-expressing (indirect) motor pathways. 

Current Studies: Studies in progress, using in-situ mRNA hybridization, are designed to examine the dopaminergic and endogenous opioid systems in the striatum and FC. To date, we have quantified the mRNA expression levels of DRD1/DRD2 and the mu, delta, and kappa opioid receptors (MOR, DOR, and KOR, respectively) in the FC and striatal regions. Preliminary data shows a negative correlation between the repetitive behavior activity and mRNA expression of dyn-A and enk in the FC, further supporting our initial report proposing a role for endogenous opioids as an underlying mechanism for repetitive behaviors.
coauthors: Shawn Doss, Johns Hopkins University; Harvey S. Singer, Kennedy Krieger Institute and Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine
institution: Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine (grid.471401.7)
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Building a hierarchically controlled robot arm for real world behavior
abstract: Motor control research often relies on computational modelling, aiming at plausible and biologically relevant results in simulated environments. In contrast, robotic approaches must work in the real world with delays, nonlinearities and noise - posing a greater challenge on the proposed architectures, and promising greater insight. Commercially available robots with pre-programmed control systems are an appropriate solution to perform certain tasks from the get-go. From a theoretical perspective, however, this can be limiting since alternative control architectures cannot be tested. Here we built a simple robot arm with two shoulder joints, elbow and wrist, from the ground up, 3D printed arm segments, DC motors as actuators; potentiometers, pressure and tilt sensors and a webcam for sensory input. We programmed the control architecture for visual and kinesthetic arm control on a PC and an Arduino-compatible microcontroller. The robot performed a planar reaching task and a tracking task following a continuously moving visual reference, while simultaneously maintaining constant pen pressure and angle of tilt. While modest in speed and precision, the robot arm successfully performed these tasks, showing biologically relevant movement features, such as bell-shaped speed profiles, isochronous rise times, and the emergence of the speed-curvature power law at high speeds. Next, we imposed movement constraints and perturbations such as inclining the writing surface, displacing the visual marker, blocking the wrist, and rotating the visual field. Without any learning algorithms or parameter adjustments, the robot performed successful reaching and tracking. In sum, while maintaining computational simplicity, the proposed architecture is capable of integrating several modalities of sensory information and coordinating multiple degrees of freedom in real-world tasks, demonstrating how some observed biological movement invariances might emerge not from a complex plan, but from the interaction of brain, body and environment
coauthors: Alex Gomez-Marin
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: The development of the brain circuitry of conscious awareness in infancy
abstract: One of the great frontiers of consciousness science is understanding how early consciousness arises in the development of the human infant. The reciprocal relationship between the default mode network (DMN) and dorsal attention network (DAN)/executive control network (ECN) has been suggested as a key feature of the brain mechanisms of conscious awareness. Nevertheless, it is poorly understood whether this relationship is present in new-born infants, or indeed whether DMN, DAN and ECN are developed at birth. We used resting-state fMRI data collected from preterm infants before (gestational age at 34.2 ± 2.0 weeks, N = 73) or at term-equivalent age (TEA, 40.9 ± 2.1 weeks, N = 73), and term infants (41.2 ± 1.7 weeks, N = 282) from the developing Human Connectome Project (dHCP), and adults (22–36 years, N = 176) from the Human Connectome Project 1200, as a reference group to investigate these questions. We calculated the within- and between-network functional connectivity (FC) in DMN, DAN and ECN and captured their internal structure using hierarchical clustering analysis for each group. We found: 1) Infants did not exhibit higher within- relative to between-network FC in DMN and DAN until TEA, suggesting that these networks are underdeveloped before TEA. 2) The three networks were already developed in infants born at TEA. However, they were less cohesive and more atypical in their nodal structure than the adult networks. 3) Infants did not show lower FC in the DMN-DAN pairing relative to other pairings until TEA, suggesting the third trimester is a key period of the development of this reciprocal relationship. 4) Birth at or prior to TEA differentially impacted to the development of these networks and their relationship. Our study sheds light on the development of the brain circuitry that supports conscious awareness in infancy.
coauthors: Rhodri Cusack, Trinity College Institute of Neuroscience, School of Psychology, Trinity College Dublin, Dublin, Ireland; Lorina Naci, Trinity College Institute of Neuroscience, School of Psychology, Trinity College Dublin, Dublin, Ireland; Global Brain Health Institute, Trinity College Dublin, Dublin, Ireland.
theme: Theme A: Development, Neurodegenerative Disorders and Injury

title: Mind, Brain, and Education (MBE) science: How translational research is improving education
abstract: Mind, Brain, and Education (MBE) science is a transdisciplinary field that blends psychology, neuroscience, and education with the goal of improving the practice of teaching and learning. MBE was started at Harvard University but now it has practitioners around the world. In this unconference session I would like to share some of the work that my colleagues and I have been conducting over the past decade to bring MBE science to educators through academic conferences, workshops, and publications.  Furthermore, I would like to explore the possibility of connecting the Neuromatch Conference/Academy community with our MBE community.
coauthors: Tom Gorham, Rissho University
theme: Theme F: History, Education and Society

title: Voluntary temporal attention affects the timing reliability of visual cortical responses
abstract:
