[Goal] Visual attention fluctuates across both space and time. Voluntary temporal attention is the goal-directed prioritization of visual information at specific points in time. Temporal attention selectively improves perceptual sensitivity at attended times. Here, we investigated the neural mechanisms underlying these perceptual improvements using MEG. We assessed how voluntary temporal attention affects the timing reliability of human visual cortical responses. 

[Methods] Observers performed an orientation discrimination task. On each trial, two grating targets (T1 and T2) appeared sequentially at the fovea for 100 ms, separated by a 300 ms stimulus onset asynchrony. A precue tone (75% validity) instructed observers to attend to T1 or T2. A response cue tone after the targets instructed them to report the orientation (CW/CCW) of either T1 or T2. Thus, on each trial, one target was attended and the other was unattended. The targets were embedded in 20 Hz flickering noise. The flicker generated a 20 Hz steady state visual evoked field (SSVEF) response in visual cortex, which served as a probe of visual cortical responses throughout the trial. We used a wavelet analysis to measure 20 Hz stimulus-locked oscillations across time. We calculated the intertrial phase coherence (ITPC) of the SSVEF signal, which indexes neural timing reliability. 

[Results and Conclusion] Temporal attention improved orientation discrimination performance, more for T1 than T2. Each target was followed by a brief change in ITPC, which we call the evoked ITPC response. Temporal attention increased the magnitude of the evoked ITPC response for T1 but not T2. In conclusion, voluntary temporal attention affected the timing reliability of the T1 response.
coauthors: Rachel N. Denison, New York University and Boston University; Karen Tian, New York University and Boston University; David J. Heeger, New York University; Marisa Carrasco, New York University
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Coexistence of fast and slow gamma oscillations in one population of inhibitory spiking neurons
abstract: Oscillations are a hallmark of neural population activity in various brain regions with a spectrum covering a wide range of frequencies. Within this spectrum γ oscillations have received particular attention due to their ubiquitous nature and their correlation with higher brain functions. Recently, it has been reported that gamma oscillations in the hippocampus of behaving rodents are segregated in two distinct frequency bands: slow and fast. These two gamma rhythms correspond to different states of the network, but their origin has been not yet clarified. Here we show theoretically and numerically that a single inhibitory population can give rise to coexisting slow and fast gamma rhythms corresponding to collective oscillations of a balanced spiking network. The slow and fast gamma rhythms are generated via two different mechanisms: the fast one being driven by the coordinated tonic neural firing and the slow one by endogenous fluctuations due to irregular neural activity. We show that almost instantaneous stimulations can switch the collective gamma oscillations from slow to fast and vice versa. Furthermore, to draw a connection with the experimental observations, we consider the modulation of the gamma rhythms induced by a slower (theta) rhythm driving the network dynamics. In this context, depending on the strength of the forcing and the noise amplitude, we observe phase-amplitude and phase-phase coupling between the fast and slow γ oscillations and the theta forcing. Phase-phase coupling reveals on average different theta-phase preferences for the two coexisting γ rhythms joined to a wide cycle-to-cycle variability.
coauthors: Hongjie Bi, Université de Cergy-Pontoise, France, Okinawa Institute of Science and Technology, Japan; Marco Segneri, Université de Cergy-Pontoise, France; Matteo di Volo, Université de Cergy-Pontoise, Information et Complexité, France; Alessandro Torcini, Université de Cergy-Pontoise, France.
institution: Okinawa Institute of Science and Technology (grid.250464.1)
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Differential effect of auditory and visual associative cues on perceptual inference
abstract:
Background: It is a widely held assumption that the brain performs perceptual inference by combining sensory information with prior expectations, all being weighted by their uncertainty. It has been shown that priors influencing perception of ambiguous stimuli can be manipulated with associative learning. Here, we investigate the differential effect of auditory vs. visual associative cues on visual motion perception and we also examine the reliability of individual differences.

Methods: Healthy individuals (N=29; 14 men, age[SD]=26.6[5.5]) performed a perceptual inference task twice with a one-week delay. They indicated the perceived direction of illusory motion of dot pairs (640 trials). A visuo-acoustic cue preceded the target stimulus and probabilistically predicted the direction of the motion. In 30% of the trials, motion direction was ambiguous, and in half of these trials, the auditory and the visual dimension of the cue predicted opposing directions. Cue-stimulus contingency could change every 40 trials. 

Results: Responses were slower to ambiguous, relative to non-ambiguous stimuli. The impact of associative learning on perceptual decisions was evidenced by slower responses to less predictable, relative to more predictable non-ambiguous stimuli and by the increased rate of cue-congruent decisions on ambiguous trials. Importantly, when the visual and the auditory dimensions of the cue predicted conflicting directions of motion on ambiguous trials, participants made more decisions congruent with the prediction of the acoustic dimension. Furthermore, all the above effects had substantial inter-individual variability which showed high test-retest reliability (rs > 0.6).

Discussion: Overall, priors based on auditory information seem to have a stronger weight during the perception of illusory visual motion, although the data suggests large and stable differences in perceptual learning and/or decision making. Computational modelling combined with neuroimaging could allow testing hypotheses regarding the potential mechanisms causing these behavioral effects (e.g. characteristics of visual vs. auditory processing, attention and uncertainty).
coauthors: Bertalan Polner PhD, Department of Cognitive Science, Budapest University of Technology and Economics; Kinga Farkas MD PhD, Department of Psychiatry and Psychotherapy, Semmelweis University
institution: Budapest University of Technology and Economics (grid.6759.d)
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Neural similarity in BOLD response and multi-unit recordings
abstract: One fundamental question is what makes two brain states similar. For example, what makes the activity in visual cortex elicited from viewing a robin similar to a sparrow? There are a number of possible ways to measure similarity, each of which makes certain conceptual commitments. In terms of information processing in the brain, interesting questions include whether notions of similarity are common across brain regions and tasks, as well as how attention can alter similarity representations. With multi-unit recordings, additional questions like the importance of spike timings can be considered. We evaluated which of several competing similarity measures best captured neural similarity. One technique uses a decoding approach to assess the information present in a brain region and the similarity measures that best correspond to the classifier’s confusion matrix are preferred. Across two published fMRI datasets, we found the preferred neural similarity measures were common across brain regions, but differed across tasks. In considering similarity spaces derived from monkey multi-unit recordings, we found that similarity measures that took into account spike timing information best recovered the representational spaces. In both fMRI and multi-unit data, we found that top-down attention, which highlighted task relevant stimulus attributes, had the effect of stretching neural representations along those axes to make stimuli differing on relevant attributes less similar. These effects were captured by a deep convolutional network front-end to a Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) network that tracked changes in task context and whose representations stretched in a task-driven manner that paralleled patterns of neural similarity changed with task context.
coauthors: Marilena Lemonari, UCL; Scott L. Brincat, MIT; Markus Siegel, University of Tübingen; Earl K. Miller, MIT; Bradley C. Love, UCL and The Alan Turing Institute
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: The role of Kv2 and Nav1.6 in Adaptive Firing in Place Fields within the CA1 region of the Hippocampus: A Computational and Experimental Approach
abstract:
Objective: The hippocampus is an area of the brain important in learning and spatial navigation. Within the hippocampal CA1 region, some pyramidal cells function as place cells, firing preferentially when an animal is in an area of its environment, its place field. As an animal enters its place field, the sensory input creates a bump in excitatory synaptic input, that decreases as an animal leaves the place field. We simulate this as a triangular current ramp applied to the soma or proximal dendrites (~200 μm from the soma). In a familiar place field, CA1 pyramidal cells fire more on the up ramp than down ramp, even though the ramp is symmetric.  This phenomenon, adaptation, is more pronounced in the dendrites. Spike height also significantly decreases in the dendrites. Slow inactivation of the voltage gated sodium channel increases with distance from the soma along the apical dendrite. Our objective is to model this inactivation as a possible mechanism behind adaptation and decrease in spike height in the dendrites.

Methods: We inserted a five state Markov model of Nav1.6 into an existing multicompartmental model implemented in NEURON. We calibrated this model to fit the time, voltage and spatial dependencies of slow inactivation according to the literature and data from our experimental collaborators. We later updated this model with the addition of the voltage gated potassium channel Kv2.

Results: After inserting the Markov model into the existing multicompartmental model, our simulation results included doublets that were inconsistent with our experimental results, until the addition of Kv2. In line with this prediction, blocking Kv2 produced doublets in our experimental ramps. With the addition of Kv2 and the Nav1.6 Markov model, the model successfully simulates adaptive firing, which is more pronounced in the dendrites, and decreased spike height in the dendrites.
coauthors: Crescent Combe, Department of Neuroscience, Christopher Knowlton, Department of Cell Biology and Anatomy, Sonia Gasparini, Department of Neuroscience, Carmen Canavier, Department of Cell Biology and Anatomy
theme: Theme B: Neural Excitability, Synapses, and Glia

title: EEG signals during relative depth judgments: Effect of image display techniques
abstract:
Different three-dimensional visualization technologies are developed to provide users with a high-quality experience. To identify the effect of new image display technique on user cognitive demands, one should assess depth perception and underlying neurophysiological processing of digital information. Whilst many fundamentally different three-dimensional image display techniques exist, the previous research has mainly focused on comparative assessment of brain activity in subjects viewing three-dimensional images and two-dimensional images leaving a gap in understanding the user cognitive demands associated with novel displays.  
In this study, we aimed to identify and compare the effects of image display techniques on the relative depth judgements. The third dimension of image was generated in two ways – stereoscopic technique and volumetric technique. The visual stimulus contained four constant angular size circles, one of which was demonstrated closer to the subject. The subject’s task was to identify the closest circle. Electroencephalography was employed to record the brain activity during the visual task. 
As a result, the relative depth judgments were fast and accurate for both image display techniques. The analysis of event related potentials showed a significant difference in late processing, but not in early processing. Specifically, the parietal lobe was more activated at 250-400 ms after the onset of three-dimensional visual stimulus comparing the stereoscopic visualization with volumetric visualization. Moreover, differences in the parietal lobe reflected in the event-related desynchronization of upper alpha oscillations. The considerably higher activity in the continuous waves of beta frequencies was observed in half of the participants. Based on the obtained results, we suggest that the depth perception and visual task completion might require a higher neural activity for the stereoscopic image viewing than for the volumetric image viewing.
coauthors: Tatjana Pladere, University of Latvia; Gunta Krumina, University of Latvia
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Framework for Information Theoretical analysis of Electrophysiological data and Statistics (FRITES)
abstract: We present analysis pipelines that aim at characterising the dynamics of cortico-cortical interactions underlying cognitive brain networks. Our hierarchical Functional Connectivity (FC) approach is able to isolate first regions whose linear correlation and mutual information (i.e., the total interdependence between neural signals) increases transiently or statically in relation to task conditions, then parses the relative direction of this influence using covariance-based Granger causality methods. Covariance-based Granger causality measures are particularly suited, because they are computationally simple to estimate, provide an intuitive link between directed and undirected FC measures and can be used on short neural signals (e.g., single-trials) and large networks (e.g., hundreds of brain areas). The workflows are applied to human source-level high-gamma activity (HGA) estimated from MEG data (Brovelli et al, JNeurosci 2015; JNeurosci 2017). The workflows exploit an anatomical atlas named MarsAtlas (Auzias et al, Human Brain Mapp 2016), and provide single-trial and ROI-based estimates of HGA time courses. Statistical analysis searching for task-related modulations in FC and group-level inference is performed using gaussian copula mutual information approaches combined with cluster-based statistics and permutation tests. The end results are time-resolved and task-related information routing patterns characterising the dynamics of cognitive brain networks.
coauthors: Etienne Combrisson,  Institut de Neurosciences de la Timone, UMR 7289, Aix Marseille Université, CNRS, 13385 Marseille, France; Michele Allegra, Institut de Neurosciences de la Timone, UMR 7289, Aix Marseille Université, CNRS, 13385 Marseille, France; Ruggero Basanisi, Institut de Neurosciences de la Timone, UMR 7289, Aix Marseille Université, CNRS, 13385 Marseille, France; Robin A.A Ince, Institute of Neuroscience and Psychology, University of Glasgow, Glasgow, UK; Bruno L. Giordano, Institut de Neurosciences de la Timone, UMR 7289, Aix Marseille Université, CNRS, 13385 Marseille, France; Andrea Brovelli, Institut de Neurosciences de la Timone, UMR 7289, Aix Marseille Université, CNRS, 13385 Marseille, France;
institution: Institut de Neurosciences de la Timone (grid.462486.a)
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Temporal dynamics of neuronal responses in human visual cortex
abstract: Cortical responses to visual stimuli exhibit complex temporal dynamics, including sub-additive temporal summation, adaptation, and slower dynamics for suboptimal stimuli. Multiple computational models have been proposed to account for these dynamics in several measurement domains, including single-cell recordings, psychophysics, and fMRI. It is challenging to compare these models because of differences in model form, test stimuli, and instrument. Here we present a new dataset that is well-suited to compare neural models of temporal dynamics. The dataset is from electrocorticographic (ECoG) recordings of human visual cortex, which measures cortical population responses with high spatial and temporal precision. The stimuli were large, static contrast patterns that varied systematically in contrast and duration for single-pulse trials, and in inter-stimulus interval (ISI) for paired-pulse trials. Time-varying broadband responses were computed using the power envelope of the band-pass filtered voltage time course (50-170 Hz) recorded from 126 electrodes in total across eleven epilepsy patients, covering earlier (V1-V3) and higher-order (LO, TO, IPS) retinotopic maps. In all visual regions, the ECoG broadband responses show several non-linear features: peak response amplitude saturates with high contrast and long stimulus durations; response latency decreases with increasing contrast; and the response to a second stimulus is suppressed for short ISIs and recovers for longer ISIs. These non-linear response features were well predicted by a model consisting of a small set of canonical neuronal operations: linear filtering, rectification, exponentiation, and delayed normalization. These results demonstrate that a simple computational model captures a wide range of temporal and contrast-dependent neuronal dynamics at millisecond resolution. Finally, we present a software repository that implements models of temporal dynamics in a modular fashion, enabling the comparison of many models fit to the same ECoG data and analyzed with the same methods.
coauthors: Giovanni Piantoni, University Medical Center Utrecht; Stephanie Montenegro, New York University School of Medicine; Adeen Flinker, New York University School of Medicine; Sasha Devore, New York University School of Medicine; Orrin Devinsky, New York University School of Medicine; Werner Doyle, New York University School of Medicine;  Nick Ramsey, University Medical Center Utrecht; Natalia Petridou, University Medical Center Utrecht; Jonathan Winawer, New York University
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Spiking Time-Dependent Plasticity implements self-organized resonances
abstract:
Neural populations exposed to a certain stimulus learn to represent it better. However, the process that leads local, self-organized rules to do so is unclear. We address the question of how can a neural periodic input be learned and use the Differential Hebbian Learning framework, coupled with a homeostatic mechanism to derive two self-consistency equations that lead to increased responses to the same stimulus. Although all our simulations are done with simple Leaky-Integrate and Fire neurons and standard Spiking Time Dependent Plasticity learning rules,
our results can be easily interpreted in terms of rates and population codes.
This talk is mostly theoretical, but during the interactive part I would like to discuss biological predictions and neurorobotic implementations.
coauthors: Pau Vilimelis Aceituno, ETH Zürich
institution: Max Planck Institute for Mathematics in the Sciences (grid.419532.8)
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Automatic model descriptions in a neural network simulator
abstract: Computational neuroscience simulations are often written as scripts that make use of a neural simulator package. The details of a model implemented in such a script might not be obvious to a reader not familiar with the simulator. When a researcher presents such a model in a publication, they will therefore rather describe it with text and equations. Creating such a description, however, is error-prone, since it is up to the researcher to make sure that it accurately presents the simulated model. We therefore propose that it would be very useful if the simulator itself could generate a model description automatically. Here we present a prototype of such a system for the Brian simulator. It is built on the same framework that powers Brian's code generation process and is therefore guaranteed to give results that are consistent with the actual simulation. The new model description framework provides a basic exporter that generates a machine-readable representation which abstracts away all the details of Brian's internal representations and takes care of more subtle issues such as the meaning of referred constants and the order of variable assignments. This exporter is meant to be used as a base for other types of exporters. As a proof of concept, we show an export to the Markdown format, providing a human-readable description of a model. Such a description can be useful to exchange with other researchers that are not familiar with the Brian simulator, as a basis for a model description shared as part of a publication or website, or simply as a means for debugging a model. Finally, we discuss the limitations of such descriptions and the possibility of annotating it with additional semantic information derived from the model.
coauthors: Vigneswaran C, Indian Institute of Technology Madras, Chennai
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Variability and stability of folding patterns across cortical development and evolution
abstract:
Folding patterns are very characteristic of different species. Most quantification methods focus, however, on the estimation of the degree of folding – the description of their pattern remaining mostly qualitative. We developed a method to generate folding graphs which summarise the folding pattern of an individual brain. We illustrate the application of our method by computing folding graphs for several different mammalian species, as well as throughout their development.
We manually segmented the cerebrum and reconstructed 3D surfaces for all specimens. Based on mean curvature, we built gyral skeletons for each specimen and several developmental stages. The lines in the skeleton represent the axis of each gyrus, providing information about their orientation and width. We then simplify these lines into a graph and represent the folding pattern as an adjacency matrix where each cell corresponds to an encounter point between 2 or more gyri. We finally flatten the gyral skeletons.
Here, we will illustrate the flat skeletons for different primate species and developmental stages for several of the species. The complexity of the folding patterns increases rapidly with increasing brain volume leading to the development of a shared pattern which emerges even across different branches of the phylogenetic tree. Similarly, decreases in brain volume lead to a simplification of the folding pattern which occurs in a similar manner across different branches. A first comparison of folding patterns using graph edit distance leads to a clustering of species which reflects their brain volume more than a clade-specifc pattern.
Fold graphs can become a useful complement to estimations of the degree of folding, and provide a new perspective on the study of phylogenetic diversity.
coauthors: Katja Heuer, Center for Research and Interdisciplinarity; Mathieu Santin, Institute for Brain and Spinal Cord; Marc Herbin, National Museum of Natural History; Roberto Toro, Institut Pasteur
theme: Theme A: Development, Neurodegenerative Disorders and Injury

title: Temporal dynamics in Drosophila taste coding influence synaptic plasticity
abstract:
The taste system ensures that animals consume nutritious foods and avoid ingesting toxins. Taste also modulates responses to other stimuli; for example, animals learn to avoid cues that are associated with bitter taste. The timing of neural activity is a key feature of neural encoding in many systems, but few studies have investigated the temporal dynamics of taste responses. Using calcium imaging, we found that Drosophila taste sensory neurons show striking differences in their response dynamics. Most classes of taste neurons show a sustained response throughout the stimulus presentation that rapidly diminishes upon stimulus removal. However, some bitter-sensing neurons show strong, transient responses at both the onset and offset of the stimulus. Moreover, with repeated bitter stimulation the onset response rapidly habituates while the offset response remains strong.

We observed the same bitter response dynamics in a set of downstream neurons, the PPL1 dopaminergic neurons (DANs). PPL1 DANs innervate the mushroom body, the learning and memory center of the fly brain, and mediate aversive olfactory learning. Studies have shown that PPL1 DANs are activated by aversive stimuli and drive learning by inducing synaptic depression at synapses onto mushroom body output neurons. Unexpectedly, we found that repeatedly pairing odor with bitter taste induced synaptic potentiation, not depression, at these synapses. However, synaptic depression could be induced by pairing odor with bitter removal. By combining calcium imaging with optogenetic stimulation to mimic PPL1 DAN activity, we found that these unexpected plasticity effects could be explained by the combination of two factors: 1) intrinsic timing rules that govern mushroom body plasticity, and 2) the dominance of the bitter offset response during repeated bitter exposure. These results demonstrate the importance of taste response dynamics and reveal unexpected complexity in how dopaminergic modulation drives plasticity in the primary learning center of the fly.
coauthors: Julia U. Deere, Columbia University; Bei Sun, Columbia University; Richard Axel, Columbia University
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Modeling the temporal dynamics of neurons in the IT cortex
abstract: Understanding the neural mechanism of image processing in the visual brain is one of the main efforts in system neuroscience. The ventral stream is thought to function as a series of hierarchical stages that encode visual information increasingly in successive cortical areas. Recent electrophysiological studies have been suggested that the early and late phases of neural response encode multiple levels of hierarchical abstractions, i.e. an earlier representation of mid-level categories in the IT responses compared with superordinate-level and subordinate-level categories. However, the neural mechanism of this temporal category representation at multiple levels is poorly understood. To address this, we applied a combination of convolutional neural networks and a partial least squares regression (PLS) model to predict firing rates of IT neurons in response to the stimuli. To train a model, in the first phase, the feature vectors of images are extracted from a convolution neural network. Then, the feature vectors used as input to  PLS regression to predict the dynamics of neural response. We found that the predicted firing rates are highly correlated with the neuron’s actual firing rates. Furthermore, the encoding of predicted neural responses illustrated an earlier representation of mid-level category representation. The suggested model proposes a neural mechanism for temporal dynamics of category representation in the IT cortex. Moreover, the trained model can be applied to extract informative feature vectors for machine vision applications.
coauthors: Ahmad Kalhor , School of Electrical and Computer Engineering, College of Engineering, University of Tehran, Tehran, Iran ; Mohammad-Reza A. Dehaqani , 1- School of Electrical and Computer Engineering, College of Engineering, University of Tehran, Tehran, Iran , 2- School of Cognitive Sciences, Institute for Research in Fundamental Sciences, Tehran, Iran.
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: The Nuclear GAPDH-HMGB cascade in cortical microglia regulates cognitive flexibility
abstract:
Glyceraldehyde dehydrogenase (GAPDH) is a key enzyme in glycolysis. Beyond its fundamental role in metabolism, GAPDH can get post-translationally modified in response to cellular stressors and subsequently translocate to nuclei to exert transcriptional control [the nuclear GAPDH (N-GAPDH) cascade]. We hypothesized that this cascade might play a critical role linking stress and behavior.

In this study, we discovered a novel mechanism that controls the response of microglia to stress through the N-GAPDH cascade and regulates animal adaptive behavior. Specifically, activation of the N-GAPDH cascade solely in cortical microglia and cognitive inflexibility were observed in a Lipopolysaccharide (LPS)-treated mouse model. Such cognitive deficits were blocked through pharmacological treatment or microglia-specific genetic intervention targeting the initial steps of the N-GAPDH cascade. To understand how the N-GAPDH cascade in microglia causes the cognitive deficits, we performed a ChIP-Seq analysis against N-GAPDH using ex-vivo microglia from the LPS-treated mice. We found upregulation of High-mobility group-box (HMGB) that can be secreted from microglia and binds to N-Methyl-d-aspartate (NMDA) receptors on glutamatergic neurons, causing their hyperactivation which turns to cognitive deficits. In summary, this study defined a new mechanism of microglia-neuron interaction though which stress-activated immune cells regulates neural system via a key metabolic molecule, GAPDH. 

On-going studies: The ChIP-Seq analysis further revealed that the N-GAPDH cascade transcriptionally regulated the expression of GAPDH by itself and controlled proteostasis in microglia in a cell autonomous manner. The relevance of the N-GAPDH cascade in peripheral blood mononuclear cells (in particular monocytes) is under study in order to find possible molecular based biomarkers to predict behavioral inflexibility in the clinic. Among those candidates, we found autofluorescence reflects the activation of the N-GAPDH cascade in preclinical studies. Using a cohort of patients with schizophrenia and healthy controls we found cellular autofluorescence in blood cells negatively correlates with behavioral flexibility.
theme: Theme B: Neural Excitability, Synapses, and Glia

title: Prediction of Human Intelligence from Time-Resolved Brain Connectivity
abstract: Spontaneous interactions between brain regions contain pertinent information about the neural bases of human behavior and cognition. Previous studies predicting cognitive abilities like intelligence have mostly focused on time-averaged (static) brain connectivity, derived from resting-state functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI). Recent work decomposed dynamic brain connectivity into states of high and low co-fluctuation and demonstrated that only a small fraction of high co-fluctuation states is sufficient to approximate the general structure of the brain’s functional network architecture. Of note, such high co-fluctuation states have been shown to capture information that uniquely identifies individuals suggesting their relevance for stable individual differences in behavior and thought. Here, we use fMRI resting-state data (N = 281) to test whether the 5% of time points that index the moments of highest co-fluctuation can predict individual levels of general intelligence (WASI, Wechsler Abbreviated Scale of Intelligence). To this aim, we developed the Covariance Maximizing Eigenvector-Based Prediction framework (CMEP) that combines eigendecomposition-based feature construction with cross-validated ElasticNet prediction. The constructed features identify brain-wide patterns of network interactions reflecting a linear relationship between functional brain states and individual variations in intelligence. Surprisingly, functional connectivity reconstructed from highest co-fluctuation states could not reliably predict intelligence (correlation observed vs. predicted IQ scores: r = 0.14; p = 0.06). In contrast, functional connectivity reconstructed from the remaining 95% time points (excluding highest co-fluctuations) yields a significant prediction of intelligence (r = 0.38; p < 0.001). Finally, we reveal a different strategy for selecting critical time points and show that significant prediction of intelligence is indeed possible with only 5% resting-state fMRI data. The results are replicated in a completely independent sample (N = 831) and we conclude that the analysis of spontaneous brain network interactions may contribute to further understand individual differences of human cognition.
coauthors: Maren Wehrheim, Department of Computer Science and Mathematics Goethe University Frankfurt am Main Germany; Joshua Faskowitz, Department of Psychological and Brain Sciences Indiana University Bloomington USA; Olaf Sporns, Department of Psychological and Brain Sciences Indiana University Bloomington USA; Christian J. Fiebach, Department of Psychology Goethe University Frankfurt am Main Germany, Brain Imaging Center Goethe University Frankfurt am Main Germany; Kirsten Hilger, Department of Psychology Goethe University Frankfurt am Main Germany, Julius Maximilian University Würzburg Germany; Matthias Kaschube, Department of Computer Science and Mathematics Goethe University Frankfurt am Main Germany, Frankfurt Institute for Advanced Studies Frankfurt am Main Germany;
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: The influence of active removal from working memory on serial dependence
abstract: Flexible control of the contents of working memory (WM), necessary for many aspects of behavior, includes the ability to remove no-longer-relevant information. Although simply withdrawing attention is one likely mechanism, many empirical results suggest that it is possible to actively remove information from working memory. We tested evidence for a specific mechanism for active removal: modulating the gain of the sensory channels that encode the stimulus-specific features (Lorenc et al., 2020; an efficient coding mechanism (c.f., Fritsche et al., 2020)). Subjects performed paired doublets of trials, the first being multi-item WM with retrocuing and updating, the second being 1-item delayed recall, with measures of serial dependence of the latter on various items from the former as the primary dependent variable of interest. The first trial of each doublet presented two sample Gabor patches, followed by a retrocue that implicitly designated the uncued item as an irrelevant memory item (IMI). Next a third item was presented, and finally memory for either the cued or the third item was tested. The critical manipulation was whether or not the third item was presented at the same location at which the IMI has appeared, with overlap between the two expected to prompt the active removal of the IMI from WM, whereas nonoverlap might require nothing more than the withdrawal of attention. Results indicated that whereas the IMI exerted the attractive bias on 1-item delayed recall in the no-overlap condition (consistent with a withdrawal of attention), but a repulsive bias in the overlap condition. Because repulsive serial dependence effects have been attributed to an efficient encoding mechanism (Fritsche et al., 2020), this result suggested the active removal of information from WM could be implemented by modulating the gain of the sensory channels that encode the features of IMI.
coauthors: Jiangang Shan, University of Wisconsin-Madison; Bradley R. Postle, University of Wisconsin-Madison
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Oscillatory entrainment mechanisms and anticipatory predictive processes in autism spectrum disorder (ASD)
abstract:
ASD is a neurodevelopmental condition that has striking effects on social communication. A less studied family of symptoms that defines it includes rigidity of routine, inflexibility of behavior and an intense desire for sameness. Studies have shown that sensory perception in this population is not flexibility adjusted to changes in the environment, and that their behavior is not influenced by prior knowledge or contextual cues. As of today, little is known about the neuronal substrates that are involved. 
Using EEG on children with ASD, we found that neuronal oscillations are less in-synch with the visual periodic pictures, and show an altered anticipation for them, compared to controls. In a subsequent study on ASD adults, visual / auditory stimuli are presented in rhythmic patterns with different degrees of predictive value. Preliminary results show reduced entrainment to the central stimulation rhythm in the ASD group, in conditions where this rhythm is jittered. 
We propose a neural account for the ASD phenomenology of rigidity and insistence on sameness, which could be crucial to the application of a behavioral training for children with ASD. Moreover, it can open a window for future investigation on the associated cellular and sub-cellular physiological mechanisms involved in it.
coauthors: Shlomit Beker; John Foxe, Sophie Molholm
theme: Theme A: Development, Neurodegenerative Disorders and Injury

title: Transferring generalized neural decoders across participants and recording modalities
abstract: Advances in neural decoding have enabled brain-computer interfaces to perform increasingly complex and clinically-relevant tasks. However, such decoders are often tailored to specific participants, days, and recording sites, limiting their practical long-term usage. Therefore, a fundamental challenge is to develop generalized neural decoders that can robustly train on pooled, multi-participant data and fine-tune to new participants. Here we introduce  HTNet, a decoder architecture that fuses deep learning with neural signal processing insights. Specifically, HTNet augments a pre-existing convolutional neural network decoder with two innovations: (1) a Hilbert transform that computes spectral power at data-driven frequencies and (2) a layer that projects electrode-level data into predefined brain regions. This projection is critical for intracranial electrocorticography (ECoG), where electrode locations are not standardized and vary widely across participants. We trained HTNet to decode arm movements using pooled ECoG data from 11 of 12 participants, testing performance on unseen ECoG or scalp electroencephalography (EEG) participants; these pretrained models were later fine-tuned to each test participant. We show that HTNet significantly outperformed state-of-the-art decoder accuracies by 8.5% when tested on unseen ECoG participants and by 14.5% when tested on unseen participants that used a different recording modality (EEG). We then used transfer learning and fine-tuned these trained models to unseen participants, even when limited training data was available. Importantly, we fine-tuned trained HTNet decoders with as few as 50 events and still achieved decoding performance approaching that of randomly-initialized decoders trained on hundreds of events. Furthermore, we demonstrate that HTNet extracts interpretable, neurally-relevant features. By generalizing to new participants and recording modalities, robustly handling variations in electrode placement, and fine-tuning with minimal data, HTNet can be used across a broader range of neural decoding applications than current state-of-the-art decoders.
coauthors: Steven M Peterson, University of Washington; Zoe Steine-Hanson, University of Washington; Nathan Davis, University of Washington; Rajesh P N Rao, University of Washington; Bingni W Brunton, University of Washington
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Peripheral cardiovascular hypersensitivity and blunted ventromedial prefrontal cortex reactivity in generalized anxiety disorder
abstract: Generalized anxiety disorder (GAD) is characterized by apprehensive expectation of aversive bodily states, yet the link between GAD and autonomic arousal is unclear. We investigated potential cardiorespiratory interoceptive dysfunction in GAD using peripheral adrenergic stimulation with the adrenaline analog isoproterenol (0.5, 2 mcg) and saline during BOLD fMRI. Infusions were randomized and double-blinded. GAD (n=29) and HC (n=29) females, matched for age and BMI, rated cardiorespiratory sensation intensity throughout infusions using a dial. Chronotropic dose 25 estimates, an indirect measure of beta-adrenergic receptor sensitivity, showed that GADs exhibited greater heart rate (HR) responses to isoproterenol than HCs (p=0.04, Cohen’s d=0.55). Linear mixed-effects (LME) models for HR revealed this effect to be driven by the 0.5 mcg dose (p=0.002). Sensation ratings were also amplified at this dose (p<0.01). GADs retrospectively reported heightened anxiety across doses (p≤0.005), and heightened heartbeat (p<0.001) and breathing (p≤0.001) intensity at 0.5 mcg. GADs showed significantly attenuated neural responses in the ventromedial prefrontal cortex (vmPFC) at 0.5 mcg relative to HCs (p<0.05 corrected). We corroborated these results in separate region-of-interest time-series analyses using multivariate Functional Principal Components Analysis (mFPCA), which characterizes the major modes of variation around smoothed mean trajectories. LMEs on coefficients obtained from the mFPCA showed time-course differences for GADs during the 0.5 mcg dose for HR (p=0.02), dial ratings (p=0.01), and BOLD responses from salience and default mode network regions, including the vmPFC (p=0.01). In summary, adrenergic stimulation in GAD females revealed evidence of autonomic hypersensitivity, which was accompanied by heightened cardiorespiratory interoception, anxiety, and attenuated neural responses in the vmPFC, a region important for self-referential processing and visceromotor control. Our results provide strong evidence that, in females, 1) GAD constitutes deficits in appraisal and regulation of sympathetic arousal, and 2) both autonomic and central nervous systems contribute to interoceptive pathophysiology in GAD.
coauthors: Maria Puhl, Laureate Institute for Brain Research, Tulsa, Oklahoma; Rachel C. Lapidus, Laureate Institute for Brain Research, Tulsa, Oklahoma, Department of Psychology, University of Tulsa, Tulsa, Oklahoma; Valerie Upshaw, Laureate Institute for Brain Research, Tulsa, Oklahoma; Rayus T. Kuplicki, Laureate Institute for Brain Research, Tulsa, Oklahoma; Jerzy Bodurka, Laureate Institute for Brain Research, Stephenson School for Biomedical Engineering, University of Oklahoma, Norman, Oklahoma; Justin S. Feinstein, Laureate Institute for Brain Research, Tulsa, Oklahoma, Oxley College of Health Sciences, University of Tulsa, Tulsa, Oklahoma; Wesley K. Thompson, University of California San Diego, San Diego, California; Martin P. Paulus, Laureate Institute for Brain Research, Tulsa, Oklahoma, Oxley College of Health Sciences, University of Tulsa, Tulsa, Oklahoma; Sahib S. Khalsa, Laureate Institute for Brain Research, Tulsa, Oklahoma, Oxley College of Health Sciences, University of Tulsa, Tulsa, Oklahoma
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: A Spiking Neural Network Model of the Motor Cortex
abstract: How do networks of neurons in the motor cortex produce coordinated movements? Electrophysiological recordings in the motor areas show irregular spontaneous firing at rest and transient oscillations in neurons during movement preparation and onset. Excitatory and inhibitory activity must occur together in a balanced state to prevent chaotic dynamics. I have built a physiologically inspired, large scale spiking neural network model which replicates the spontaneous neural activity in the motor cortex using the Brian2 simulator toolbox and based on the work of Esser, et al., 2005.
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Leveraging spatial connectivity for more efficient planning in naturalistic scenarios
abstract: The brute-force approach to planning, where the number of possible futures grows exponentially with the number of possible moves per step, fails to be tractable when the number of steps is large. There are methods to subsample the tree of possibilities to make the calculation tractable in such cases. These include Monte-Carlo tree search and variants like UCB1. In this talk, we present the results of a different strategy motivated by recent work in our group that indicates where plan-based action selection is most useful. Consider a discretized space being planned over, with some cells containing barriers/occlusions/gateways, and other cells being open. Rather than each possible position in a space being considered during planning, the agent plans over locations in the space where there is a transition in the graph connectivity. In the real world these transitions include barriers, corridors, gateways, and bottlenecks where the prey can hide. These locations are where the largest potential reward value changes happen. To bridge between these locations during plan execution, shortest path trajectories are calculated. This method enables planning a number of steps ahead that is several orders of magnitude larger than planning where every location of the space is considered. We present results in an idealized predator-prey scenario where we show that this method provides similar survival rates for the prey as UCB1 but with far fewer compute steps. In future work we will be deploying this method for guiding mobile robots that are interacting with animals in real time.
coauthors: German Espinosa, Malcolm A. MacIver
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: De-noising EMG using dynamical systems models of muscle population activity
abstract: Precise coordination of the activity of groups of muscles is critical for motor function. However, a major barrier to understanding how the brain coordinates muscle activation is that recordings of electromyographic (EMG) activity from muscles are a noisy measure of muscle activation, making them difficult to evaluate on a moment-to-moment basis. The standard approach to processing EMG (i.e., rectification and smoothing) treats high frequency features in EMG signals as noise. Here, we describe dynamically-estimated EMG (deEMG), a method to de-noise EMG signals recorded simultaneously from multiple muscles. Our working model is that, during movement, the coordinated activity of muscles is the output of an underlying dynamical system, and that accurately modeling these dynamics using recurrent neural networks might substantially de-noise EMG, while preserving any complex, high-frequency components that are present in multiple muscles. We tested deEMG using intramuscular EMG recorded from 12 muscles from two model systems: (1) rat hindlimb muscles during locomotion and (2) monkey forearm muscles during an isometric center-out wrist force task. deEMG had significant advantages over standard smoothing. When applied to the rat data, the model’s nonlinear filtering properties produced single-trial representations of muscle activity that improved decoding of joint kinematics and preserved behaviorally-linked, high frequency EMG features that are suppressed by linear filters. Similarly, when applied to the monkey data, deEMG enabled more accurate prediction of measured forces and was substantially more informative about simultaneously-recorded motor cortical activity, suggesting that deEMG-inferred representations better reflect descending cortical commands. Additionally, deEMG revealed unexpected high frequency oscillations that correlated with oscillations in the recorded force data but were not apparent after standard smoothing. Ultimately, this method opens new avenues to studying the coordination of multiple muscles and their precise control by upstream brain areas.
coauthors: Jonas F. Braun, École Polytechnique Fédérale de Lausanne, Technical University of Munich; Mohammad Reza Keshtkaran, Emory University and Georgia Tech;  Juan Alvaro-Gallego, Imperial College of London, Northwestern University; Cristiano Alessandro, University of Pavia, Northwestern University; Matthew C. Tresch, Northwestern University; Lee E. Miller, Northwestern University; Chethan Pandarinath, Emory University and Georgia Tech
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Characterizing Neuronal Activation of Melanotan II, a Novel Pharmaceutical Drug with the Potential to Enhance the Efficacy of Autism Therapy
abstract: There is no effective pharmaceutical drug that can palliate the social deficits caused by autism spectrum disorder (ASD). Oxytocin (OT), a neuropeptide, promotes pro-social behaviors making it a potential candidate for pharmacological treatment. Melanotan II (MTII) is a compound of interest that evokes endogenous OT release in the paraventricular nucleus (PVN). Regions of the social salience network (SSN) coordinate to process social information. MTII primes PVN to release OT throughout the (SSN). MTII combined with social stimulus, increases OT releases throughout the SSN. MTII- induced pattern of brain activation was investigated across the SSN with social exposure. Twenty-four prairie voles received MTII doses ranging from 0.1 nmol to 1 pmol into lateral ventricles and were exposed to social or non-social stimuli. To observe activation, immunolabelling was performed to label for OT expression and c-FOS, an immediate early gene protein used as proxy for neuronal activation. Behavioral side effects were observed: stretching, spinning, scratching, grooming, and ambulating. Decrease in side effects was observed with decrease in dosage. To analyze c-FOS expression an online machine learning program, DeepFLaSH was used. Results suggested no behavioral difference between vehicle and 1 pmol group making it a viable dose for future experiments. However, a quantitative analysis of c-FOS expression suggested there was no significant difference in expression at different doses. We concluded the behavioral differences observed at different doses were not correlated with increased c-FOS expression in the PVN. In future, we will examine MTII-induced activation of c-FOS expression in other regions of the SSN.
coauthors: Charles L. Ford, Anna A. McDonnough, Jamie LaPrairie, Larry J. Young
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: A GRAB sensor for spatially resolved endocannabinoid dynamics in vitro and in vivo
abstract: Endocannabinoids (eCBs) are retrograde lipid neuromodulators involved in many physiologically important processes, yet their release and dynamics in the brain remains largely unknown, in part due to lack of probes capable of reporting eCBs with sufficient spatiotemporal resolution. Here, we developed a new G protein-coupled receptor (GPCR) Activation Based eCB sensor GRABeCB2.0 using the human CB1 receptor fused with a circular permutated EGFP (cpEGFP). GRABeCB2.0 exhibits ~second kinetics and robust fluorescence increase in response to eCBs (ΔF/F0 ~800% to 2-AG; ~550% to AEA in neurons), and does not elicit detectable G protein and arrestin coupling. Using GRABeCB2.0, we detected evoked eCB dynamics in both cultured neurons and acute mouse brain slices. Interestingly, we also observed spontaneous compartmental eCB transients that spread ~11 μm in culture neurons, suggesting constraint local eCB signaling. By expressing GRABeCB2.0 in vivo, we readily observed foot-shock elicited and running triggered eCB transients in mouse amygdala and hippocampus respectively. Lastly, using GRABeCB2.0 in a seizure model, we observed a spreading eCB wave following a calcium wave in mouse hippocampus. In summary, GRABeCB2.0 is a powerful new probe to resolve eCB release and dynamics under physiological and pathological conditions.
coauthors: Ao Dong, Peking University; Kaikai He, Peking University; Barna Dudok, Stanford University; Jordan S Farrell, Stanford University; Wuqiang Guan, Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory; Daniel J Liput, National Institute of Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism; Henry L Puhl, National Institute of Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism; Ruyi Cai, Peking University; Jiali Duan, Peking University; David M Lovinger, National Institute of Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism; Bo Li,  Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory; Ivan Soltesz, Stanford University; Yulong Li, Peking University
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Expectation, In and Of Choice
abstract: Expectations guide choice. Scientists repeat the sensory conditions in which a choice is made so as to statistically sample an underlying expectation. The statistics of a process can be deduced in this manner if it is ergodic, that is if a collection of samples at one time captures the dynamics of the process at all times. Popular models of choice treat expectation as ergodic within a trial, subject to change between trials. We analyzed the temporal dynamics of expectation in a free choice saccade task, and found that expectations evolved within as well as between trials. We embedded reinforcement learning into an Ornstein-Uhlenbeck (OU) process to model expectation as a continuous dynamic. The OU process reaches a steady-state at a predicted time of choice, rather than at true sensory onset, accounting for empirical history effects in anticipatory behaviour. The model suggests that expectations should be understood as a predictive dynamic interacting with an environment, rather than a stationary parameter locked to choice onset. We provide normative arguments for the cost and benefit of different reinforcement strategies in this model.
coauthors: Brandon Caie, Queen's University; Paul Schrater, University of Minnesota, Aarlenne Khan, Universite de Montreal; Gunnar Blohm, Queen's University
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Single circuit in V1 capable of switching contexts during movement usingVIP population as a switch
abstract: As  animals  adapt  to  their  environments,  their  brains  are  tasked  with  processing  stimuli  in  different  sensory contexts.  This suggests that neural architectures have evolved to respond flexibly to a range of stimulus conditions and  statistics.   As  the  number  of  possible  contexts  is  virtually  infinite,  making parallel  circuits  for  each  context unfeasible, a crucial question is what architectures permit implementation of multiple related computations within a single circuit.  Here, we address this question in the specific case of the circuitry of the visual system, focusing on the role of distinct cell types in context integration of visual scenes.  We show that a population of inhibitory neurons, the VIP cells, can enable such context integration — defined as the integration of feedforward and surround information across visual space — in two different contexts, in which the viewer is static vs.  moving.  Moreover, the VIP population is efficient, requiring only a relatively small number of neurons to switch contexts.  Our findings shed light on a minimally complex architecture that is capable of switching between two naturalistic contexts using few switching units.
coauthors: Stefano Recanatesi; Brian Hu; Eric Shea-Brown; Stefan Mihalas
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Mathematics Ability vs. Mathematics Disability
abstract: In 1904, Spearman used the term general intelligence “g” as a measurement or success in a various form of cognitive tasks (Spearman, 1961). General intelligence is one of the most heritable behaviour traits, with heritability rising from 40% from childhood to 80% in adulthood (Kropnik et al., 2016).  Mathematics ability(MA) is an important indicator of human intelligence (Chen et al., 2017). Basic arithmetic calculations and related numeracy skills are essential part of the normal brain operation (Docherty et al., 2010). The genetic complexities of MA might explain the fundamentals of general intelligence both at genetic and neurobiological level. On the other hand, American Psychiatric Association (1994) defines mathematics disability(MD) as receiving arithmetic scores at least 2 years below expected grade level. The studies show that 6% of school children face with MD. One of the well-known mathematical disorders as known dyscalculia is an important impairment that may cause severe problems in an individual’s life but with the help of better understanding of neurobiological and genetic aspects of the cases with proper arrangements in environmental factors would help to reduce the effects of the disorder. In the last two decades, rising interest on applications of neuroscience studies increased interventions of the studies in educational context. In this talk, I will present the genetic and neurobiological components of MA and MD as well as introducing Genome Wide Association Studies(GWAS) related to the research field. In addition, I will discuss the environmental factors that effect Mathematics ability and developmental disorders such as dyscalculia. The role of the society with some example of educational policies from the past, today’s applications and connection to genetics and neuroscience research will be explained. Finally, the future of the neuroscientific studies in educational setting will be discussed.
theme: Theme F: History, Education and Society

title: How mice recognize shapes: sensorimotor strategies and neuronal representations
abstract: Humans and other animals can identify objects by active touch, requiring the coordination of exploratory motion and tactile sensation. Both the motor strategies and neural representations employed could depend on the subject’s goals. We developed a shape discrimination task that challenged head-fixed mice to discriminate concave from convex shapes. Behavioral decoding revealed that mice did this by comparing contacts across whiskers. In contrast, mice performing a shape detection task simply summed up contacts over whiskers. We recorded populations of neurons in the barrel cortex, which processes whisker input, to identify how it encoded the corresponding sensorimotor variables. Neurons across the cortical layers encoded touch, whisker motion, and task-related signals. Sensory representations were task-specific: during shape discrimination, neurons responded most robustly to behaviorally relevant whiskers, overriding somatotopy. Thus, sensory cortex can be dramatically reconfigured for the task at hand.
coauthors: Nogueira, Ramon; Pil, Christina; Greeman, Esther; Fusi, Stefano; Bruno, Randy
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: The generalized drift diffusion model enables high-throughput screening of perceptual decision-making strategies
abstract:
Since the late 1970s, the drift-diffusion model (DDM) has been an important tool in the cognitive neuroscientist's toolbox, providing a way to quantify evidence accumulation during decision-making and link behavioral data to neural recordings.  However, methodological challenges have limited the ability to expand the DDM to test new decision-making strategies.  Specifically, the complexity of defining new models and the time required to fit them to data have prevented widespread exploration of variants on the DDM.  Additionally, the DDM can only represent a limited set of experimental designs.

Here, we describe our recent work on the generalized drift-diffusion model (GDDM), a framework for building and fitting DDM extensions, and a software package (PyDDM) which implements the framework (Shinn et al., 2020, eLife).  Our framework makes previously intractable high-throughput approaches possible with a 100-fold or more speedup compared to standard methods.  It also makes it easy to reuse different aspects of these DDM extensions, facilitated by our growing online database of model mechanisms (https://pyddm.readthedocs.io/en/latest/cookbook/index.html) to promote reproducibility and open science.

Our framework allows experimentalists to fit models to more complex experimental paradigms, and theorists to conveniently formulate models and efficiently fit them with the latest methodology.  We demonstrate this flexibility by analyzing a sophisticated decision-making task using a high-throughput approach to explore decision-making strategies.  We presented monkeys with a perceptual decision-making task with noisy evidence extended over time that included both timing and reward manipulations.  Our modeling approach discovered the key characteristics of decision-making strategies which can account for the reward and timing biases exhibited by the monkeys (Shinn et al., 2020, J Neurosci).  Overall, we show that the GDDM in conjunction with PyDDM enables new possibilities for understanding decision-making.
coauthors: Maxwell Shinn, Norman Lam, Daeyeol Lee, Hyojung Seo, John D. Murray
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Quantifying causality with quasi-experiments
abstract: Causality is at the heart of many important questions in science, as the goal is often to either inform decision making or understand the underlying mechanisms of a system. Though causal ground truth is typically obtained through conducting experiments, experimentation can often be impractical or infeasible, and we would like to be able to obtain causality from observational data if possible. Econometrics has, over decades of focused work, developed a rich toolkit for estimating causal effects from non-experimental data exploiting (quasi) random variation in existing data, so-called quasi-experiments. Here we review such approaches and how they can be combined with machine learning to answer causal questions across domains such as medicine, society, and neuroscience.
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Altered hippocampal neural dynamics in a rodent model of chronic stress
abstract:
Adverse effects of chronic stress include anxiety, depression, and learning and memory deficits. Some of these deficits are mediated by stress-induced impaired hippocampal functionality at multiple levels of neural organization including dendritic shrinkage and neurogenesis and impaired synaptic plasticity. In agreement, studies in awake behaving rodents have reported that chronic stress alters place cell activity and disrupts global remapping which is the generation of distinct representations (place maps) across different surroundings. Surprisingly, it is not known if and how chronic stress alters hippocampal information processing during offline behaviour states, including quiet wakefulness/sleep, during which information consolidation takes place during sharp-wave ripples (SPW-Rs or ripples), high frequency (100-200 Hz) oscillatory events  in the CA1 region.
Here, we employed tetrode recordings in mice and subjected them to chronic immobilization stress (CIS), a well-established rodent model of chronic stress and assessed pyramidal cell activity and SPW-Rs in the dorsal CA1 of the hippocampus. Contrary to our expectations, we noticed a net decrease in pyramidal cell activity during the first exposure to a stress compared to the prior quiet wakefulness/sleep state. We also noticed lower firing rates and decreased participation by pyramidal cells during SPW-Rs, though pyramidal cell co-activity was enhanced during stress exposure. Interestingly, after repeated exposure to same stress, some of these stress-phenotypes were noticed during the rest-state on the last day of CIS, when no overt stress was delivered. These data indicate that repeated exposure to stress alters hippocampal neural dynamics and that disrupted ripple-spike interactions may underlie the impaired learning observed in chronically stressed subjects.
coauthors: Denis Polygalov,Laboratory for Circuit & Behavioral Physiology, RIKEN Center for Brain Science, 2-1 Hirosawa, Wako-shi, Saitama, Japan 351-0021; Sumantra Chattarji, National Centre for Biological Sciences, Bellary Road, Bangalore, 560065, India; Thomas J. McHugh, Laboratory for Circuit & Behavioral Physiology, RIKEN Center for Brain Science, 2-1 Hirosawa, Wako-shi, Saitama, Japan 351-0021
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Transsaccadic integration of object orientation vs. identity in human cortex: An fMRI paradigm
abstract: Recently, Dunkley et al. (Cortex, 2016) showed modulations in parietal cortex (i.e., supramarginal gyrus, SMG) for transsaccadic changes in object. However, this result did not generalize to other features, such as spatial frequency (Baltaretu et al., J Vis, 2016). We hypothesized that the fundamental difference between these results was the detection of transsaccadic changes in object orientation vs. identity. To test this, we used a double-dissociation fMRI task. Participants fixated a small cross 15.4° left or right of centre, where an object was subsequently presented (rectangle, barrel-shaped, or hourglass-shaped), oriented at ±45° from vertical. After this, the fixation cross either remained in the same position (Fixation condition) or shifted to the other side (Saccade condition). Then, either the same object would appear with the opposite orientation (Orientation change condition) or one of the other two objects would appear at the same orientation (Identity change condition). Button press was used to indicate whether object identity or orientation had changed. Results indicate that cortical modulations were larger for saccades (than fixations) when orientation changed in medial early occipital regions (e.g., V1) extending into later occipitotemporal regions. Activation for changes in identity were larger for saccades (than fixations) for identity change in regions similar to those for orientation change, but also in medial parietal regions (e.g., precuneus and superior parietal lobule). When looking for a feature (Orientation > Identity) change specifically in cortical regions showing a Saccade > Fixation preference, we found this activation within medial occipital/occipitotemporal cortex extending toward the border with parietal regions as well. These preliminary results suggest that differences in object features that occur across saccades also appear at the cortical level (largely within medial occipital cortex, extending both towards parietal and temporal cortex). Further controls will be applied to confirm that these results are task- and feature-specific.
coauthors: Bianca R. Baltaretu [Centre for Vision Research, York University, Toronto, ON, CA; Vision, Science to Applications (VISTA) program, York University, Toronto, ON, CA; Department of Biology, York University, Toronto, ON, CA]; W. Dale Stevens [Centre for Vision Research, York University, Toronto, ON, CA; Vision, Science to Applications (VISTA) program, York University, Toronto, ON, CA; Department of Psychology, York University, Toronto, ON, CA]; Erez Freud [Centre for Vision Research, York University, Toronto, ON, CA; Vision, Science to Applications (VISTA) program, York University, Toronto, ON, CA; Department of Psychology, York University, Toronto, ON, CA]; J. Douglas Crawford [Centre for Vision Research, York University, Toronto, ON, CA; Vision, Science to Applications (VISTA) program, York University, Toronto, ON, CA; Departments of Biology, Psychology, Kinesiology & Neuroscience Diploma Program, York University, Toronto, ON, CA];
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Hierarchical stochastic block modeling in the Drosophila connectome
abstract: A connectome describes functional interactions or structural connections between regions of interest in the brain. The Drosophila connectome has been studied extensively in the literature and modeled as a complex network to understand the relationship between brain functionality and animal behavior. Similar to human connectomes, Drosophila connectomes also exhibit modular structure despite their relatively small sizes where cluster-like regions in the brain can be further divided into subclusters based on functional or structural similarity. Built upon an automatic Gaussian mixture modeling technique, we introduce a hierarchical stochastic blockmodel clustering algorithm which recursively clusters a network to obtain sub-clusters that can be approximated as stochastic blockmodels. We demonstrate the hierarchical structure of the mushroom body of Drosophila connectomes revealed by the proposed algorithm.
coauthors: Tingshan Liu, Johns Hopkins University; Benjamin D. Pedigo, Johns Hopkins University; Thomas L. Athey, Johns Hopkins University; Joshua T. Vogelstein, Johns Hopkins University
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Mental compression of spatial sequences  in human working memory  using numerical and geometrical primitives
abstract: How does the human brain store sequences of spatial locations? The standard view is that each consecutive item occupies a distinct slot in working memory. Instead, we formulate and test the alternative hypothesis that the human brain compresses the whole sequence using an abstract, language-like code that captures the numerical and geometrical regularities of the sequence at multiple nested levels. We exposed participants to spatial sequences of fixed length but variable regularity, and asked them to remember the sequence in order to detect deviants, while their brain activity was recorded using magneto-encephalography. Using multivariate decoders, each successive location could be decoded from brain signals, and upcoming locations could be decoded prior to their actual onset. Crucially, sequences with lower complexity, defined as the minimal description length provided by the formal language, and whose memory representation was therefore predicted to be more compressed, led to lower error rates and to increased anticipations. Furthermore, neural codes specific to the numerical and geometrical primitives of the postulated language could be detected, both in isolation and within the sequences. These results suggest that the human brain detects sequence regularities at multiple nested levels and uses them to compress long sequences in working memory.
coauthors: Sébastien Marti, Liping Wang, Marie Amalric, Stanislas Dehaene
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Reconsolidation of a threat memory in humans: A highly demanding working memory task interfere the re-stabilization and its biases processing towards threat.
abstract:
Consolidated memories can be reactivated into a labile state by the presentation of a reminder. The reactivation of the memory trace is followed by a process of re-stabilization known as reconsolidation. In most of reconsolidation studies, a second task, with similar characteristics to those of the target memory, is used as an amnesic agent.
Anxiety manifest as a persistent and  generalized  defensive  system,  activated  when  predicted  aversive events  are  perceived  as a threat and uncertain. In laboratory, threat conditioning has been taken as the paradigm for assessing fear memories and anxiety related disorders. In the framework of the reconsolidation the idea that this process would allow to modify this type of maladaptive memories has been proposed. 
Here we aim to interfere the re-stabilization of an implicit aversive memory in humans using a high demanding working memory task, which aimed to overload this transient memory system. To reach such goal, we designed a 3 day protocol, and compared a trained threat conditioning group, that 24hs later had or not a reminder, or a fake working memory task; 48hs after, all 3 groups performed an extinction follow by a reinstatement and several tasks targeting cognitive bias towards threat. We revealed that the memory reconsolidation interference is effective for the implicit memory retention but not for the declarative memory. Finally, we showed how the interference reduced biased processing towards threat.
coauthors: Fernandez Rodrigo, IFIBYNE -CONICET - UBA; Pedreira M. Eugenia, IFIBYNE - UBA - CONICET
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Genetic link between impaired homeostatic plasticity and neurodevelopmental disorders
abstract:
Homeostatic plasticity is an evolutionarily conserved form of neuromodulation. It has been hypothesized that loss of homeostatic plasticity will make the nervous system more susceptible to disease. But, this has yet to be clearly demonstrated, particularly with respect to the homeostatic modulation of synaptic function in the central nervous system and brain disorders. To address this fundamental question, I use different model organisms (fly, mouse and IPSc-derived neurons) and combine genetic screening, electrophysiological and transcriptomic analysis methods. With this approach, I recently identified a novel class of autism-gene modifiers causing homeostatic plasticity to fail. This defines a model, where de novo risk mutations impair the robustness of neuronal activity when combined with the modifier mutations lurked in the genetic background. This validated approach helps us identify new genetic and molecular mechanisms, thereby providing a new framework for advancing our understanding of neurogenetic diseases. 
It seems plausible that restoring the buffering capacity of homeostatic plasticity could be broadly relevant to the treatment of neurological disorders of any genetic origin. In the central nervous system, several neurological disorders such as Parkinson’s, manifest impaired neuronal function before the onset of the neuronal degeneration. Thus, this is an important stage when neurons cope with genetic and environmental insults by engaging homeostatic protective mechanisms, thereby maintaining the functional well-being. Using mammalian models, my current and future research aims to generate mechanistic insights on how homeostatic plasticity is compromised in neurological disorders including neurodegenerative diseases, stroke and neurovascular abnormalities. With this information, I hope to develop interventional strategies that will boost the homeostatic capacity of the brain to stabilize the neuron and circuit function.
coauthors: Graeme Davis, UCSF; Stephan Sanders, UCSF; Joon An, Korea University; Richard Fetter, UCSF, Giulia Zunino, UCSF; Yelena Kulik, UCSF
theme: Theme B: Neural Excitability, Synapses, and Glia

title: Emergence of collective oscillations in balanced neural networks due to intrinsic fluctuations
abstract:
We report a transition from asynchronous to oscillatory behavior in balanced  inhibitory sparse neuronal networks with instantaneous synapses. Collective oscillations emerge for sufficiently connected networks. Their origin is understood in terms of a recently developed mean-field model for sparse balanced neural networks. Collective oscillations are induced by irregular microscopic neural firing, due to balance. The same mechanism induces in balanced excitatory-inhibitory networks quasiperiodic collective oscillations.

di Volo, M., & Torcini, A. (2018).  Physical review letters, 121(12), 128301.
coauthors: Di Volo Matteo, LPTM, University of Cergy Pontoise, Cergy, France; Torcini Alessandro, LPTM, University of Cergy Pontoise, Cergy, France
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Ventral Tegmental Area projecting dopaminergic neurons, as a neural substrate for flexible adaptation of goal directed behaviors
abstract:
Several psychiatric conditions such as drug addiction or schizophrenia are marked by an impairment in the ability to optimally acquire and/or express goal-directed actions. Such alterations in executive control have been associated with a dysfunction of the medial prefrontal cortex (mPFC), possibly linked to an alteration of dopamine (DA) transmission. However, preclinical data regarding the implication of DA signalling in executive control remain controversial. Here, we used a chemogenetic approach to selectively and reversibly inhibit DA neurons of the ventral tegmental area (VTA) and assess the effect on distinct components of goal-directed behavior using the outcome devaluation task that allows assessing the ability of animals to flexibly adapt goal-directed actions. 
We found that while inhibition of VTA-DA neurons during outcome devaluation had no effect, the same manipulation during reversal of the instrumental contingencies resulted in a deficit in a subsequent outcome devaluation test. Our data provide clear evidence regarding the implication of VTA-DA transmission in the capacity to flexibly adapt goal-directed behaviors. These findings support the idea that alteration of VTA-DA transmission could participate to the aetiology of cognitive symptoms in psychiatric disorders.
coauthors: Pierre Trifilieff, University of Bordeaux; Andrea Contini, University of Bordeaux
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Accuracy, Confidence and Decision-time of Perceptual Decisions in Discrete vs Continuous Environment
abstract:
In many cases, decisions require information integration from pieces of evidence with discrete time intervals. Yet, the neural mechanism underlying these decisions is uncertain.
This research has mainly concentrated on accuracy, confidence, and decision-time of double-pulse vs single-pulse stimulus. To inspect the concept, behavioral and electroencephalography (EEG) data have been analyzed.
Accordingly, we applied a perceptual decision-making experiment using Random Dot Motions (RDM) paradigm. Participants had to indicate the predominant direction of motion of a cloud of moving dots (left or right) by saccadic eye movement to the chosen target after receiving one or two pulses of 120 ms of information. Both direction and strength of the motion changed trial by trial. Moreover, the interval of two pulses is selected randomly from 0, 120, 360, and 1080 ms. Healthy adult subjects were tested and meanwhile, we used a 32-channel amplifier for the EEG signal recording. Here, we searched for the relation of accuracy, confidence, decision-time, and their ERP (Event-related potential) characterizations in a more real-life like decision-making.
Results from behavioral and the ERP have shown that participants develop similar behavior but with some differences in the discrete vs continuous environment. Subjects’ performance and confidence were independent of the intervals up 1 s. However, unlike the confidence, accuracy improved considerably in double-pulse trials. Moreover, when participants had better accuracy, their decision-time (the time between response cue and saccadic response) decreased. Interestingly, the decision-time of single-pulse trials was significantly longer compared to double-pulse trials. The grand-average ERP results showed a peak observed around 300 ms after the stimulus offset. This peak was identified to be related to decision-making and significantly increased in faster decisions.
To summarize, it seems, along with the continuous environment, accuracy, confidence, and decision-time could be tracked from ERPs component during decision-making in a discrete environment.
coauthors: Zahra Azizi, Institute for Cognitive Science Studies, Tehran, Iran; Reza Ebrahimpour, Cognitive Science Research lab., Department of Computer Engineering, Shahid Rajaee Teacher Training University, Tehran, Iran; Sajjad Zabbah, School of Cognitive Sciences, Institute for Research in Fundamental Sciences (IPM), Tehran, Iran
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Engagement of active dendritic integration in neuronal circuit computations
