theme: Theme B: Neural Excitability, Synapses, and Glia

title: Retinal waves prime visual motion detection by simulating future optic flow
abstract: The ability to perceive and respond to environmental stimuli emerges in the absence of sensory experience. Spontaneous retinal activity prior to eye-opening guides the refinement of retinotopy and eye-specific segregation, but its role in the development of higher order visual response properties remains unclear. Here, we describe a transient developmental window during which the spatial propagation of spontaneous retinal waves resembles the optic flow pattern generated by forward self-motion. We show that wave directionality requires the same circuit components that form the adult direction-selective retinal circuit and that chronic disruption of wave directionality alters the development of direction-selective responses of superior colliculus neurons. These data demonstrate how the developing visual system patterns spontaneous activity to simulate ethologically relevant features of the external world to instruct self-organization.
coauthors: Xinxin Ge, UCSF (formerly at Yale); Kathy Zhang, Yale; Ali Hamodi, Yale; Alex Gribizis, Max Plank Florida Institute for Neuroscience; Aude Martinez Sabino, University of Technology of Compiègne
theme: Theme A: Development, Neurodegenerative Disorders and Injury

title: The Dendrograms of Neuron Morphologies exhibit Asymmetrical Motifs
abstract: Despite the beauty of neuron morphologies and their potential contributions to computation, we lack a geometric understanding of their structure. A common way of describing trees is in terms of their dendrograms, raising the question of how they may differ across neuron types. Here we characterize the distribution of dendrogram motifs. We construct generative models of trees that allow asymmetric, as well as depth dependent growth. Across many neuron types, we find that an asymmetric model outperforms a symmetric one. We also find strong differences in asymmetry across species. We suggest that neuroscience needs to understand the structure of neuron morphologies if it is to understand computation in the brain.
coauthors: Roozbeh Farhoodi, David Rolnick, Konrad Paul Kording
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Cerebellar nuclei evolved by repeatedly duplicating a conserved cell-type set
abstract: How have complex brain regions, circuits, and cell types evolved from simple origins? Here we investigate brain region evolution at cell-type resolution in the cerebellar nuclei, the output structures of the cerebellum. We applied single-nucleus RNA sequencing in chickens, mice, and humans, STARmap spatial transcriptomic analysis in chicken and mice, and whole-CNS projection mapping in mice. Our work revealed a conserved cell type set containing three classes of region-invariant inhibitory neurons and two classes of region-specific excitatory neurons. This cell type set forms an archetypal cerebellar nucleus that was repeatedly duplicated to create new regions. In excitatory neurons, duplication was accompanied by divergence in gene expression and shifts in projection patterns (neofunctionalization). By contrast, inhibitory neurons maintained their gene expression signatures (isofunctionalization). Interestingly, the excitatory cell class that preferentially funnels information to lateral frontal cortices in mice becomes predominant in the massively expanded human Lateral CN. Our data provide the first characterization of CN transcriptomic cell types in three species and suggest a model of brain region evolution by duplication and divergence of entire cell type sets.
coauthors: Justus M Kebschull, Stanford University; Noam Ringach, Stanford University; Ethan B Richman, Stanford University; Drew Friedmann, Stanford University; Sai Saroja Kolluru, Chan Zuckerberg Biohub; Robert C Jones, Stanford University; William E Allen, Harvard Univeristy; Ying Wang, UC Davis; Huaijun Zhou, UC Davis; Seung Woo Cho, Stanford University; Howard Y Chang, HHMI and Stanford University; Karl Deisseroth, HHMI and Stanford University; Stephen R Quake, Chan Zuckerberg Biohub and Stanford University; Liqun Luo, HHMI and Stanford University;
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: The Fronto-Parietal Network Is Not a Flexible Hub  During Naturalistic Cognition
abstract: It has been argued that the fronto-parietal network (FPN) is a flexible hub, in that it reconfigures its connectivity with other brain regions, to a greater extent than other networks. Cocuzza et al. (2019) and Cole et al. (2013) administered a set of difficult tasks during fMRI and found between-network variability in functional connectivity was larger for the FPN than for ten other networks. A limitation of this study is that the tasks were designed to be difficult and engage the FPN. It is unclear, therefore, whether the FPN is a flexible hub in general, or only in the context of challenging tasks. We therefore tested whether the FPN is a flexible hub during naturalistic cognition. In Experiment 1, we analysed data from 15 people watching a movie, Forrest Gump (www.studyforrest.org). We found that the variability in connectivity of the FPN was no different from other networks, providing no evidence that it acted as a flexible hub. As naturalistic movies do not have a regular block design over which to examine changes in connectivity, we investigated a range of temporal window sizes from 30-240 s. The results generalised across these. However, it is possible that Forrest Gump engaged the FPN less than everyday life, and the dataset only has 15 subjects. In Experiment 2, therefore we analysed a larger dataset (n=647, www.cam-can.org) of people watching a suspenseful clip known to strongly engage the FPN (Naci et al., 2014). Again, we found that the FPN was no more flexible than other networks. These results suggest that during naturalistic cognition, the FPN does not act as a flexible hub any more than other networks in the brain, suggesting it is not a trait of the FPN, but rather just a state during sets of difficult tasks.
coauthors: Rhodri Cusack, Trinity College Dublin
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Spatiotemporal Dynamics of Mesoscale activity in Sensory Cortex
abstract:
Synchrony in the activity of neuronal circuits is one of the topics of interest in modern systems neuroscience. The Spatiotemporal dynamics of the synchrony in the spontaneous activity at different scales may carry information about the organization, circuitry of neuronal populations as well as the local processes and function of these circuits.
Here, to quantify the extent to which the dynamics of synchronous spontaneous activity predicts the neuroanatomical structure, we recorded local field potentials (LFP) and spiking activity of cluster of neurons in the somatosensory cortex of anesthetized rats in using a 10x10 microelectrode array.
We did the experiments on the somatosensory cortex of awake and anesthetized rodents (rats and mice). We calculated different measures of within and cross-frequency coupling (in terms of phase-phase, phase-amplitude, amplitude-amplitude coupling) in frequency bands of interest (<0.1 Hz, δ, θ, α, β, γ) between pairs of electrodes. We observed a gradual decrease in the strength of coupling with the distance between electrodes, especially at higher frequencies. Specifically, while the decline was not so evident for  <0.1 Hz and δ band, where the couplings varied insignificantly with distance, it became more profound for higher frequencies.
A multidimensional scaling analysis (MDS) on the strength of couplings revealed the spontaneous activity predicts the position of electrodes. Applying machine learning based on T-distributed Stochastic Neighbor Embedding (t-SNE) lead to similar findings.
coauthors: Mehdi Adibi, Sayed Jalal zahabi, Ehsan Yazdian
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Odor identification in novel olfactory environments is selectively impaired in a mouse model of autism
abstract: Aversion to novel stimuli in autism affects quality of life. We developed a behavioral paradigm to study the effect of novel background odors on odor discrimination in mouse models of autism. We trained wild type mice to discriminate target odors in known background odors. When tested, mice could discriminate known targets in novel background odors, a task similar to the visual CAPTCHA used to distinguish humans from computers. Using glomerular imaging data, we showed that WT mice used an algorithm that required less training data than a linear classifier or nearest neighbor classifier. The Cntnap2-/- mouse model of autism matched wild type mice performance in the presence of known backgrounds, but performance fell almost to chance levels in the presence of novel backgrounds. Wild-type mice use a robust algorithm for detecting odors in novel environments and this computation is selectively affected in a mouse model of autism.
coauthors: Yan Li, Mitchell Swerdloff, Tianyu She,  Asiyah Rahman, Naveen Sharma, Reema Shah, Michael Castellano, Daniel Mogel, Jason Wu, Asim Ahmed,  James San Miguel, Jared Cohn, Nikesh Shah, Gonzalo H Otazu
institution: New York Institute of Technology, College of Osteopathic Medicine
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Long non-coding RNA – Transcription factor regulatory networks in mammalian neural stem cells
abstract:
With the advent of new generation technologies, a growing list of formerly unknown regulatory RNA species have come into spotlight. Among them, long non-coding RNAs (lncRNAs) have been found to control stem cell pluripotency, carcinogenesis, development and function of several tissues and organs. Although thousands of lncRNAs are expressed in adult mammalian brain in a highly patterned and specific manner, they remain poorly characterized and their roles in brain development have not yet been studied.
To tackle this question, we initially performed RNA-Seq analysis in the developing nervous system of mouse embryo. Based on this analysis, we identified many lncRNAs highly expressed in neural cells. We focused on lncRNAs, which are transcribed from genomic loci in close proximity with protein coding genes, encoding for critical transcription factors (TFs) in brain development. We hypothesized that these lncRNAs may be implicated in the regulation of neighboring TF genes.
To this end, we characterized the changes in the expression profiles of a number of lncRNAs-TF pairs during development of mouse brain. In this study, we further focused on the functional role of lncRNA TCONS_00034309 in the differentiation of neural stem cells and its relation to Tbr2 transcription factor by in vitro and in vivo overexpression and knock-down studies, using CRISPR-dCas9-KRAB Effector System.
To conclude, our data suggest critical roles for this lncRNA in neuronal differentiation and astrogliogenesis during brain development. Our study provides insights into the involvement of lncRNAs in organogenesis and shows how lncRNAs and protein-coding genes form regulatory networks with important functions in neural stem cells.
coauthors: Artemis Michail, Panagiotis Politis
institution: Biomedical Research Foundation of the Academy of Athens (grid.417975.9)
theme: Theme A: Development, Neurodegenerative Disorders and Injury

title: Multiplane Mesoscope reveals distinct cortical interactions following expectation violations
abstract: Cortical columns interact through dynamic routing of neuronal activity. To monitor these interactions, we developed the Multiplane Mesoscope which allow simultaneous imaging of 8 cortical planes. The Multiplane Mesoscope allowed us to study cortical column interactions in excitatory and inhibitory subpopulations in behaving mice. We found that distinct cortical subnetworks represent expected and unexpected events, suggesting that expectation violations modify signal routing across cortical columns, and establishing the Multiplane Mesoscope as a unique platform to study signal routing.
coauthors: Natalia Orlova*, Dmitri Tsyboulski*, Sam Seid, Sara Kivikas, India Kato, Marina Garrett, Doug Ollerenshaw, Shawn R. Olsen, Peter Groblewski, Peter Saggau#, Jérôme Lecoq#
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Contribution of descending modulation to load-dependant reduction of pain by working memory
abstract: Working memory (WM) engagement produces pain inhibition. However, it remains unclear whether higher WM load increases this effect. The aim of this study was to investigate the interaction between WM load and pain inhibition by WM and examine the contribution of descending inhibition. Thirty-eight healthy volunteers were assigned to one of two n-back groups for which WM load was different (2-back or 3-back). The experimental protocol comprised five counterbalanced conditions (0-back, n-back, pain, 0-back with pain, and n-back with pain). Pain and the nociceptive flexion reflex (NFR) were evoked by transcutaneous electrical stimulation of the sural nerve. Pain was significantly different between conditions, but not between n-back groups. Both the 0-back and n-back tasks reduced pain compared with pain alone, but the n-back task produced stronger pain inhibition compared with the 0-back task. NFR amplitude was significantly different between conditions but not between n-back groups. NFR was inhibited by the 0-back and n-back tasks, with no difference between the two tasks. These findings indicate that pain inhibition by WM is increased by WM load, but only to a certain point. NFR inhibition by WM suggests that inhibition of pain by WM depends, at least in part, on descending inhibition.
coauthors: Isabelle Blanchette; Mathieu Piché
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: TRPA1 mediates cold nociception in Drosophila melanogaster larvae
abstract:
Nociception is the process by which an organism detects potentially harmful stimuli, driving behavioral responses that minimize incipient damage and promote organismal survival. Nociception relies on specialized channel receptors to detect these stimuli. Thermal nociception is responsible for the detection of noxious thermal stimuli at either extreme. Transient receptor potential (TRP) channels play a crucial role in thermal nociception. However, there is little knowledge regarding how they mechanistically function in the regulation of noxious cold detection. TRPA1 is a polymodal channel that is conserved among vertebrates and invertebrates. Human TRPA1 has been implicated in mediating cold nociception, though its functional role in this process remains poorly understood. In Drosophila larvae, TRPA1 has been identified in polymodal nociceptive neurons in which it mediates chemical, high heat, and mechanical nociception. Recent neurogenomic analyses have identified TRPA1 expression in cold nociceptive sensory neurons (Class III; CIII), which suggests the possibility that this channel is also involved in the mediation of noxious cold detection. We have employed neurogenetic and behavioral techniques to dissect the role of TRPA1 in this process.
Whole animal TRPA1 mutants displayed a decrease in the characteristic contractile behavior in response to noxious cold temperatures; this was also observed in CIII-specific TRPA1 knockdown larvae. The requirement for TRPA1 was observed to be isoform specific. Optogenetic and behavioral analyses attested that TRPA1 is required for stimulus transduction rather than for action potential propagation. These findings provide insights into the underlying mechanism of cold detection while also raising questions regarding the polymodality and evolutionary role of TRPA1 channels. A better understanding of how the nociceptive phenomenon works could provide information that will aid in the development of better treatments for neuropathies, such as allodynia and hyperalgesia.
coauthors: J.M. Lechter, Georgia State University; N. J. Himmel, Georgia State University;  A. Sakurai, Georgia State University; D. N. Cox, Georgia State University.
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: The impact of short-term motor imagery training on the brain
abstract:
Background: in recent years, the combined application of motor imagery and brain computer interface (BCI) technology has attracted extensive attention and obtained good research results in the field of neural rehabilitation. However, this BCI-based motor imagery therapy with real-time neural feedback has not been deeply explored. This paper will analyze the brain changes before and after the motor imagery training mission in a short time from the two perspectives of brain ERD attenuation and ERP connectivity.
Method: The subjects were trained with or without visual feedback. Firstly, we analyze the changes of EEG signal attenuation during motor imagery based on brain ERD phenomenon in a short period of time. Then we introduce the connectivity index of brain network based on graph theory, and discuss the influence of motor imagery training with or without neural feedback on the brain in three scales (single node scale, regional scale and whole brain scale).
Results: we found that the attenuation of EEG signal increased before and after motor imagery training whether or not nerve feedback was introduced. In the analysis of brain network, we found that the group with neural feedback has more obvious connectivity attenuation than the group without feedback.
Conclusion: we discussed the influence of BCI motor imagery with or without nerve feedback on brain from two aspects of ERD attenuation degree and ERP connectivity change. The results showed that the changes of indexes in the group with nerve feedback were more obvious and had more uniform trend attributes. This provides a good reference for the follow-up research.
coauthors: Youhao Wang
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Weak signatures of audiovisual integration in mouse visual cortex
abstract:
Sensory cortices are increasingly thought to encode multisensory information. For instance, mouse primary visual cortex appears to be influenced by auditory inputs, which have been suggested to provide global inhibition or loudness and frequency specific information. However, sounds can also evoke behavioral responses. Such behavioral responses are now known to elicit neural activity across the brain. Thus, a potential confound between acoustic-related and movement-related activity could exist in multisensory studies. 

To investigate this issue, we measured the neuronal responses to natural movies and natural sounds in primary visual cortex (V1) using chronically implanted Neuropixels probes, thus recording the activity of hundreds of units.

First, we replicated previous results showing that sounds could evoke neural activity in V1. Sound-evoked responses were weak compared to video-evoked responses, but we could still significantly decode sound identity from population activity. Second, we observe that mice showed stereotypical, unsolicited behaviors in response to the sounds (from startling to more complex behaviors). Third, we show that removing movement-related activity from V1 population activity drastically reduced the responses to sounds. We conclude that a significant part of sound-evoked responses in V1 comes from indirect behavioral responses. Analysis of  changes in behavioral states is thus required for a careful characterization of auditory inputs to other sensory areas.
coauthors: Timothy Sit, UCL; Anna Lebedeva, UCL; Philip Coen, UCL; Kenneth Harris, UCL; Matteo Carandini, UCL
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Neural modulation to direction and speaker in spatial multi-talker speech perception
abstract: Humans can easily attend to the speech of a single talker in a mixture when the talkers are spatially separated. However, the neural mechanisms in the human brain that enable this ability are unclear. Specifically, it is not known how spatial separation affects the neural representation of the speech mixture, and how attention to either the location or the identity of a talker modulates the cortical response. We recorded intracranially from the human auditory cortex while subjects listened to spatial talkers either presented stand alone or in a mixture. We demonstrate that the neural encoding of phonemes is unaffected by the location of a talker presented in isolation, but narrows to the speech of the contralateral talker when presented in a mixture. Further, we show that attention to the spatial location and the talker identity have differential neural effects: attention to location modulates the overall baseline of neural response level while attention to talker identity modulates spectrotemporal selectivity.  Our results reveal how the human auditory cortex adjusts its neural tuning to enable listeners to attend to a talker in a spatially separated mixture, with implications for more accurate neurophysiological models of speech processing.
coauthors: Stephan Bickel,Hofstra Northwell School of Medicine; Jose L. Herrero,Hofstra Northwell School of Medicine; Ashesh D. Mehta,Hofstra Northwell School of Medicine; Nima Mesgarani, Columbia University
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Reward-specific activation  in prefrontal cortex  during a gambling task
abstract: Numerous neuroimaging studies have investigated that orbitofrontal cortex (OFC) and ventromedial prefrontal cortex (vmPFC) are strongly implicated in higher-order cognitive functions, such as decision making and reward processing. In 2013, Human Connectome Project (HCP) (Barch et al.) measured the functional connectivity of healthy adult human brains during cognitive, emotion, motor, and sensory processing-related tasks via task-based functional magnetic resonance imaging (tfMRI). Using the HCP dataset, we investigated the brain activation differences in OFC and vmPFC during the gambling task. We found a strong correlation between the magnitude of brain activation and gambling condition (win and loss). In line with past studies, this finding shows the involvement of the prefrontal reward area in reward processing. These findings may have implications for understanding the process of addiction such as pathological gambling.
coauthors: Thomas Karner;Karim El Salim;Ecem Aydin
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Just-in-time computations by non-normal attractor dynamics in the prefrontal cortex
abstract: Prefrontal cortex plays a central role in working memory maintenance. However, both the neural circuit mechanisms supporting this role and the precise computational objective underlying those mechanisms remain unknown. There have been two distinct proposals for what circuit dynamics may underlie memory maintenance: attractor dynamics giving rise to stable (persistent) activities, or feed-forward dynamics resulting in sequential (time varying) activities. Here, we analyze multiple datasets recorded in monkeys performing memory-guided saccade tasks across multiple task epochs. We show that neither of the previously proposed dynamical regimes alone accounts for experimentally observed neural activities, which instead display a rich combination of both sequential and stable dynamical motifs. Specifically, we found strongly dynamic transitions and hence sequential neural activity between different task epochs, together with stable activity during the delay epoch. We propose a novel unifying model that explains these puzzling findings. Our model combines two dynamical regimes that have hitherto been studied in isolation: non-normal feed-forward and attractor dynamics. Critically, in our model, optimal stimulus inputs are orthogonal to stable activity patterns, naturally producing strongly sequential stimulus-to-delay activity followed by stable delay activity, as seen in experiments. To understand the computational function of these dynamics, we trained recurrent neural networks for different objectives: to produce target activities at the time of the response, or throughout the delay period, or “just-in-time” (before the response, at the end of the delay period). Using these objectives, we respectively recovered either of the classical dynamics (sequential and stable), or their combination as observed in data. These results also generalised to neural responses recorded in a task involving distractor stimuli. In summary, our results identify a new class of non-normal attractor network dynamics, unifying sequential and stable motifs, and suggest that they serve a new functional objective: just-in-time computation.
coauthors: Jake P. Stroud, University of Cambridge; Kei Watanabe, Osaka University; Takafumi Suzuki, National Institute of Communication and Information Technology Osaka; Mark G. Stokes, University of Oxford; Mate Lengyel, University of Cambridge and Central European University Budapest
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: The left temporoparietal junction causally supports goal emulation in observational learning
abstract: Humans learn from their own trial-and-error experience and observing others by inferring their goals. Previous studies have established a comprehensive neurocomputational account of the integration between directly earning and observational learning. Crucially, these studies have identified that bilateral temporoparietal junction (TPJ) is functionally associated with goal emulation. However, the causal role of bilateral TPJ in such processes remains unclear. Here, employing continuous theta-burst stimulation (cTBS) over bilateral TPJ as well as vertex, we tested how the TPJ supports goal emulation in a probabilistic reversal learning task (N = 31). Participants on each trial were first required to choose between two stimuli, after they have seen the choices from four other co-players, they had the opportunity to adjust their choices. A probabilistic reward was then delivered given their second choice. Notably, participants were instructed that they would play this game with four “intelligent computers,” and choices from those computers were in fact generated from our computational algorithm model (reported elsewhere), such that they matched with actual human behavior. To increase ecological validity, we used human faces to indicate each computer. Behavioral results indicate that disrupting activity in the left TPJ resulted in reduced choice switch probability and longer response time when confronted with opposing social information, as opposed to the right TPJ and vertex conditions. In addition, choice accuracy was declined when participants actually switched their choices in the left TPJ condition. No significant difference was observed between trials across stimulation sites. Computational modeling with the hierarchical Bayesian approach suggests that the corresponding parameter quantifying social information significantly decreased in the left TPJ condition, as compared to the right TPJ and vertex conditions. Together, our results provide evidence for the causal role of left TPJ in supporting goal emulation in human observational learning.
coauthors: Lei Zhang, University of Vienna; Farid I. Kandil, University Medical Center Hamburg-Eppendorf; Claus C. Hilgetag, University Medical Center Hamburg-Eppendorf; Jan Gläscher, University Medical Center Hamburg-Eppendorf
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Remembrance of things practiced: Fast and slow learning in cortical and subcortical pathways
abstract: The learning of motor skills unfolds over multiple timescales, with rapid initial gains in performance followed by a longer period in which the behavior becomes more refined, habitual, and automatized. While recent lesion and inactivation experiments have provided hints about how various brain areas might contribute to such learning, their precise roles and the neural mechanisms underlying them are not well understood. In this work, we propose neural- and circuit-level mechanisms by which motor cortex, thalamus, and striatum support motor learning. In this model, the combination of fast cortical learning and slow subcortical learning gives rise to a covert learning process through which control of behavior is gradually transferred from cortical to subcortical circuits, while protecting learned behaviors that are practiced repeatedly against overwriting by future learning. Together, these results point to a new computational role for thalamus in motor learning and, more broadly, provide a framework for understanding the neural basis of habit formation and the automatization of behavior through practice.
coauthors: James M Murray, University of Oregon; G Sean Escola, Columbia University
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Automated Screening to Assist a Systematic Living Summary of Primary In Vivo Focal Cerebral Ischaemic Stroke Research
abstract:
Introduction: The failure to plan new research based on a systematic assessment of the existing literature is an important source of research waste. Systematic reviews of primary in vivo focal cerebral ischaemic stroke research have informed improvements in research quality and translation of findings to the clinic[1]. However, the process is time-consuming and, by completion, the results are often out of date. We aim to develop a workflow to automatically identify reports of this research to allow a systematic living summary of the literature[2].
Methods: We trained the machine-learning algorithm using a random sample of PubMed records from a search of terms relevant to focal cerebral ischaemia supplemented with relevant studies identified from previous systematic reviews[3]. In August 2020, we conducted a systematic search of PubMed and Embase and passed the unique studies through the algorithm to identify all primary in vivo focal cerebral ischaemic stroke research.
Results: Our random sample (N=4,000) identified 130 (3.3%) primary in vivo focal cerebral ischaemic stroke studies. We trained the machine-learning algorithm with 4,786 studies (4,000 random sample plus 786 identified from previous systematic reviews). The algorithm identified relevant studies with sensitivity at 95%, specificity at 98% and precision at 92%. Our systematic search of PubMed and Embase identified 752,494 unique studies duplicate removal. Of this, the algorithm identified 27,269 (3.6%) primary in vivo focal cerebral ischaemic stroke studies.
Conclusions: Automated screening of search results in systematic review will save substantial resources, especially where the yield of relevant studies is low. Preliminary machine-learning results suggest that this machine-learning algorithm is highly accurate in identifying primary in vivo focal cerebral ischaemic stroke research and could be used in an automated systematic living summary workflow curating such research.

References
[1] McCann et al. (2016) doi: 10.1007/s12975-016-0489-z
[2] Wilson et al. (2020) Retrieved from https://osf.io/ek6df/, Aug 2020
[3] CAMARADES Focal Ischaemic Stroke Database. Retrieved from https://camarades.shinyapps.io/SRMed/, Aug 2020
coauthors: Florenz Cruz, Charité-Universitätsmedizin Berlin; Joly Ghanawi, Independent Researcher; Jing Liao, University of Edinburgh; Sarah McCann, Charité-Universitätsmedizin Berlin; Malcolm Macleod, University of Edinburgh; Emily Sena, University of Edinburgh
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: PREDICTING AGE IN 8-TO-24-MONTH-OLDS USING RESTING-STATE FUNCTIONAL CONNECTIVITY MRI
abstract: Resting-state functional connectivity (rsFC) measured with functional MRI has been used to predict phenotypes such as chronological age and clinical diagnoses in typically and atypically developing adults and children. However, its utility for predicting phenotypes in infants and toddlers is less well-characterized. Here, we use fMRI data from the Baby Connectome Project sample to predict the age of 110 infants and toddlers age 8-24 months old using data collected during natural sleep. Successful prediction could provide initial evidence that rsFC in infancy is reliable and informative of chronological age, and thus potentially predictive of other measures of interest in this group such as language or motor development with age. Using 10-fold cross-validation, we trained and tested support vector regression (SVR) models to predict age-at-scan using whole-brain rsFC constructed from 333 cortical parcels. Models successfully predicted novel infants’ age with ±4.1 months error and predictive R2=0.32. To characterize the anatomy of predictive networks, we grouped connections into 11 infant-specific or 12 adult-defined canonical resting-state functional networks (e.g., the default mode network). We found that connections between regions of the same networks—i.e., within-network connections—predicted age as well as or better than the full functional connectome (RMSE=±4 months error and R2=0.35 for within-infant-network connections). Furthermore, control analyses confirmed that results are not driven by head motion. Looking ahead, the current findings can help characterize changes in functional brain organization across development and inform work predicting measures of cognitive development in infants.
coauthors: Omid Kardan, University of Chicago; Sydney Kaplan, Washington University in St. Louis School of Medicine; Muriah D. Wheelock, Washington University in St. Louis School of Medicine; Dominique Meyer, Washington University in St. Louis School of Medicine; Adam T. Eggebrecht, Washington University in St. Louis School of Medicine; Lucille A. Moore, Oregon Health & Science University; Eric Earl, Oregon Health & Science University; Eric Feczko, University of Minnesota; Óscar Miranda-Domínguez, University of Minnesota; Kathy Snider, Oregon Health & Science University; Alice Graham, Oregon Health & Science University; Marc G. Berman, University of Chicago; Sooyeon Sung, University of Minnesota; Kamil Uğurbil, University of Minnesota; Essa Yacoub, University of Minnesota; Jed T. Elison, University of Minnesota; Christopher D. Smyser, Washington University in St. Louis School of Medicine; Damien A. Fair, University of Minnesota; Monica D. Rosenberg, University of Chicago
theme: Theme A: Development, Neurodegenerative Disorders and Injury

title: Efferent and afferent estimates of hand location do not optimally integrate
abstract: The central nervous system (CNS) can rely on at least two sources of information in order to localize limb position in the absence of vision: (1) proprioceptive afferents from receptors in the limb, and (2) an efference copy of the motor command used by the cerebellum to generate a prediction of sensory consequences. To produce a reliable, single estimate about the location of the limb, these two sources of information could be optimally integrated using Bayesian integration, or maximum likelihood estimation (MLE). While some work has been done to investigate whether the CNS optimally combines visual and proprioceptive cues, less is known for the integration of non-sensory signals for limb estimates (i.e. efferent signals) given the difficulty of isolating them from the ever-present proprioceptive afferent signals. Here, we use our new paradigm to isolate efferent-based estimates of hand position from proprioception, by having over 200 healthy participants, both younger and older adults (55+), localize their hand after actively reaching in a self-chosen direction (active localization), or after being passively moved by a robotic manipulandum (passive localization). We then investigated if estimates of hand location based on both efferent and afferent signals (active localization) are more precise than those based only on proprioception (passive localization). According to the MLE rule, or other straightforward Bayesian mechanisms, variance should be lower in the localization condition where two signals are combined (active localization; prediction and proprioception) and higher with only a single source of information (passive localization; proprioception only), but we found no evidence in support of this. Further, we looked at whether weaker proprioceptive priors lead to greater learning-induced shifts in hand localization as would be predicted by Bayesian (optimal) inference. But we did not find that noisier, highly variable estimates were more susceptible to larger proprioceptive recalibration following adaptation to a perturbation suggesting a non-Bayesian mechanism for integration. Together, these findings make it less likely that the CNS uses optimal integration to combine efferent-based predicted sensory consequences and proprioceptive afferents when estimating and updating the final limb position.
coauthors: Marius 't Hart, Denise Henriques
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Conflict detection in a sequential decision task is associated with increased cortico-subthalamic coherence and prolonged subthalamic oscillatory response in the beta band
abstract: Making accurate decisions often involves the integration of current and past evidence. Here we examine the neural correlates of conflict and evidence integration during sequential decision making. Patients implanted with deep-brain stimulation (DBS) electrodes and age-matched healthy controls performed an expanded judgement task, in which they were free to choose how many cues to sample. Behaviourally, we found that while patients sampled numerically more cues, they were less able to integrate evidence and showed suboptimal performance. Using recordings of Magnetoencephalography (MEG) and local field potentials (in patients) in subthalamic nucleus (STN), we found that beta oscillations signalled conflict between cues within a sequence. Following cues that differed from previous cues, beta power in the STN and cortex first decreased and then increased. Importantly, the conflict signal in the STN outlasted the cortical one, carrying over to the next cue in the sequence. Furthermore, premotor cortico-subthalamic beta coherence increased during the initial power decrease. These results extend our understanding of cortico-subcortical dynamics of conflict processing, and do so in a context where evidence must be accumulated in discrete steps, much like in real life, leading to a more nuanced picture of conflict monitoring systems in the brain and potential changes due to disease.
coauthors: Zita Eva Patai, Tom Foltynie, Patricia Limousin, Harith Akram, Ludvic Zrinzo, Rafal Bogacz*, Vladimir Litvak*
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Aiming evokes explicit motor adaptation
abstract: In recent years it has become exceedingly clear that explicit learning plays an important role in motor adaptation. The most used method to measure explicit adaptation is aiming: participants are asked to indicate what angle, relative to the target, they will aim at for their next reach. While useful and straightforward, this method may also reveal the nature of the manipulation to participants, by forcing them to consider reach direction on every trial. This may evoke explicit adaptation where normally there wouldn’t be any. To test this we had three groups of participants adapt to a 30° rotation. These were an instructed group (N=24) who were explained the manipulation and given a strategy to counter it, an aiming group (N=24) who pointed an arrow at where they said they would aim their reach on the next trial (without landmarks or reminder instructions) and a control group (N=24) who neither received instructions nor did aiming. Except for an initial benefit of instructions, each group adapted similarly. In all three groups we measured explicit and implicit contributions at the end of adaptation by asking people to either include (explicit+implicit) or exclude (implicit only) whatever strategy they thought they had. As expected, there was no difference between these two measures in the control group indicating fully implicit adaptation. The two measures differed in the instructed group, indicating partially explicit adaptation. The distribution of differences was uni-modal in these two groups, but in the aiming group, the distribution was bi-modal, with one peak around zero, akin to the control group, and one peak lined up with the peak of the instructed group. This shows that in about one third of participants aiming has the same effect as an instruction, so that aiming not only measures, but also causes explicit adaptation.
coauthors: Urooj Taqvi, York University; Raphael Q. Gastrock, York University; Jennifer Ruttle, York University; Shanaathanan Modchalingam, York University; Denise Y.P. Henriques York University;
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Adding dendrites to spiking neural networks in Brian 2 using Dendrify
abstract: Prior research generally confirms that dendritic properties have a pronounced effect on synaptic input processing and neuronal activity. However, the potential contribution of dendritic computations to network responses has remained relatively unexplored. Biophysically detailed neuron models are computationally expensive, thus not recommended for large-network simulations. Conversely, simplified yet realistic models require expertise and often a significant amount of effort to build. To address these issues, we developed Dendrify, a free, open-source Python package that facilitates the creation of spiking network models with compartmental neurons in Brian 2. Dendrify, through simple and intuitive commands, automatically generates all the equations and parameters needed to describe reduced neuron models, including a broad range of synaptic and dendritic mechanisms. Such models provide an efficient alternative for studying dendritic phenomena at the network level while achieving a reasonable balance between simulation performance and biological validity. Here we illustrate how Dendrify helps to effortlessly build simple neuron or network models, accurately reproducing a wide variety of experimental observations. Based on established theoretical work, we further discuss practical guidelines on effectively designing reduced neuron models that are utmost faithful to their biological counterparts.
coauthors: Michalis Pagkalos, University of Crete Dept. of Biology AND IMBB-FORTH; Spyridon Chavlis, IMBB-FORTH; Panayiota Poirazi, IMBB-FORTH
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Functional Representation of Vocal Musculature in the Motor Cortex of Mice
abstract: Vocalizations are a dynamic and complex behavior that can be innate or learned. Vocal learners, animals that learn to imitate or modify vocalizations, use top-down input from the forebrain to provide fine motor control over vocal musculature. These forebrain circuits coordinate sub-cortical networks during, and after, learning to precisely execute these learned behaviors. Currently, we do not have genetically tractable mammalian models for speech and vocal learning.  However, behavioral and anatomical findings from our lab and others’ have shown that the ultrasonic song system of mice exhibits rudimentary features consistent with advanced features of vocal learners, including multisyllabic structure that varies with social context, and a small pool of cortical neurons in posteromedial M1 that projects directly to vocal motor neurons in the brainstem. To test if these M1 neurons can functionally activate vocal muscles, and possibly provide fine motor coordination, we used intracortical microstimulation (ICMS) paired with electromyography (EMG) from vocal muscles in the larynx of anesthetized mice. We use latency from stimulation to EMG response to estimate the number of synapses between the cortex and the muscles, with shorter latencies meaning there are fewer neurons in the circuit (i.e. more direct connectivity). Using this approach, we found a representation of laryngeal musculature in posteromedial M1, consistent with our anatomical tracing, but also a second representation in anterolateral M1. The two regions have distinct latency and stimulation thresholds from one another. The anterolateral region, corresponding to orofacial motor cortex (OFC), has shorter latencies-to-response from stimulation and lower current injection thresholds. Conversely, the posteromedial region has longer latencies and higher thresholds. These two representations possibly underlie different functions of the laryngeal musculature in different behaviors, such as voluntary swallowing, breathing, or vocalizing. These results are the first characterization of the functional representations of laryngeal musculature in the rodent motor cortex.
coauthors: Elena Waidmann, The Rockefeller University; Erich D. Jarvis, The Rockefeller University and Howard Hughes Medical Institute
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Mice learn multi-step routes by memorizing subgoal locations
abstract: Animals must rapidly gather spatial information about new environments so that they can quickly reach food or safety even when direct paths are unavailable. The behavioral strategies used to implement multi-step routes to goals in naturalistic settings are unknown. Here we show that mice spontaneously learn a subgoal memory strategy while escaping to shelter or seeking food in an obstructed environment. We first investigated how mice navigate to shelter in response to threats when the direct path is blocked by a wall. Initially, mice ran straight toward the shelter and circumvented the obstacle using sensory cues. Over the course of 20 minutes, however, they switched to a spatial memory strategy to execute spatially efficient paths. Efficient escape routes were not learned by reinforcing egocentric actions or by constructing an unbiased internal map during exploration. Instead, mice used a hybrid strategy: they memorized specific subgoal locations encountered during previous running movements toward the obstacle. We then found that the same behavioral strategy is also used in a reward-seeking task. These results show that spontaneous memorization of local subgoals is a fundamental strategy by which rodents execute efficient multi-step routes to goals in novel environments.
coauthors: Phillip Shamash, UCL; Sarah Olesen, UCL; Panagiota Iordanidou, UCL; Dario Campagner, UCL; Banerjee Nabhojit, UCL; Tiago Branco, UCL
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Development of Hearing in Neonatal Rats:  Cortical Responses to Air- and Bone-Conducted Sound.
abstract: In rats, sensitivity to environmental sounds emerges at around P11-13. However, morphological studies suggest that for a few days before that, the hearing function is constrained mainly by the immaturity of structures responsible for sound conduction. In accordance with that, it was shown that the bone-conducted (BC) sounds, which bypass the immature outer and middle ear, can evoke auditory brainstem responses already from P7. Whether these early responses reach the auditory cortex, and what are their spatio-temporal features remain largely unknown. Using epidural uECoG arrays and intracortical silicone probes, we showed that, starting from P8, responses evoked by the BC-sound involve thalamus-mediated activation of the auditory cortex. The evoked potentials had the initial positive and the following negative peaks, the latencies and amplitudes of which significantly changed with age. These responses largely overlapped with the responses evoked by electrical stimulation of the cochlea and the inferior colliculus as well as with the responses to normal intensity air-conducted sound (70 dB) after the onset of hearing (>P13). Topographic mapping revealed that BC-evoked responses co-localize with high-frequency sound representations in the auditory cortex. In addition, we showed that BC-evoked responses can be eliminated by bilateral cochlear ablation. We also found that similar cortical responses to the airborne stimuli of high intensity (>100 dB) can be evoked starting from P8, suggesting that the onset of sensory function highly depends on the sound conduction. Our main finding is that the earliest responses evoked by BC and high-intensity airborne stimuli reach the auditory cortex and undergo significant improvement over the second postnatal week. We suggest that this stimulus-evoked activity can potentially cooperate with spontaneous activity in the formation of auditory circuits during the pre-hearing period. Besides that, our study reveals remarkable similarities in the major developmental milestones of the auditory and visual systems.
coauthors: Mikhail Sintsov, Laboratory of Neurobiology Kazan Federal University Kazan Russia; Guzel Valeeva, Laboratory of Neurobiology Kazan Federal University Kazan Russia; Pavel Starikov, MIPT The School of Electronics Photonics and Molecular Physics Moscow Russia; Dmitriy Negrov, MIPT The School of Electronics Photonics and Molecular Physics Moscow Russia; Roustem Khazipov, Laboratory of Neurobiology Kazan Federal University Kazan Russia and INMED INSERM UMR1249 Aix-Marseille University Marseille France;
theme: Theme A: Development, Neurodegenerative Disorders and Injury

title: Elucidating brain mechanisms for the context-dependent control of vocal communication
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Attentional Sampling Strategies in Multi-Attribute Decision Making
abstract:
Many everyday decisions require us to consider multiple options, each comprised of a number of shared or different attributes. In such situations, optimal decisions require the simultaneous integration and comparison of a large amount of information. This complexity is thought to tax limited cognitive resources, requiring the use of attention to select a limited subset of information, upon which the decision is then based. To better understand the role of attention in decision making, subjects participated in multi-attribute decision making tasks in which we systematically varied the complexity of choices by increasing the number of options, or attributes, or both. Our task design uses eye position as an overt measure of attention while subjects choose between gambles that systematically cover the decision space. Each attribute's magnitude is masked by an opaque disk whose color indicates the attribute type. The attribute value is only revealed when the disk is actively fixated upon. Subjects freely inspect the attributes with no time constraint, before indicating their choice with a keypress. The resulting eye movements provide detailed temporal and spatial information about subjects' focus of attention during the attribute sampling process. 

We find that human participants mainly deploy two strategies for sampling decision-related information. When only few options are available, participants most frequently use an exhaustive strategy to sample all attributes of each option independently, before examining the next one (2-Option, 2-Attribute: 68% of subjects, 2-Option, 4-Attribute: 66%). This is an effective strategy because all information is examined. However, when more options are available, participants most commonly employ a filtering strategy. They first compare their most important attribute (which differs between subjects) across all options to identify the one or two best ones, and then sample all attributes of those best options (4-Option, 2-Attribute: 75% of subjects, 4-Option, 4-Attribute: 68%). This strategy reduces the amount of information that needs to be processed but can lead to suboptimal choices. Importantly, which strategy is used depends on the number of options, but not the number of attributes. Thus, increasingly complex decision problems evoke strategic shifts in the direction of attention during the search for the preferred option. Because our new task design provides detailed information over the temporal order of sampling the attributes, it retains the ability to control task requirements typical for laboratory designs, while still capturing important aspects of real-world decision making in complex environments. Thus, this task allows us to explore the neuronal mechanisms underlying the different strategies.
coauthors: Jacob Elsey, Johns Hopkins University; Ernst Niebur, Johns Hopkins University; Veit Stuphorn, Johns Hopkins University
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Mutliple bouts of high intensity exercise and its effect on resting state functional connectivity and implicit motor learning in healthy older adults
abstract: Older adults show both age-related decreases in resting state functional connectivity and sensorimotor function. Aerobic exercise has emerged as a potential intervention that may mitigate or even reverse these age-related declines. However, studies that have touted the impact of exercise on resting state functional connectivity or motor learning have done so focusing on one of these two dependent measures alone. Here we sought to understand whether exercise influences both resting state functional connectivity, and motor acquisition and learning in the same population of older adults. Forty-two healthy older adults rested or completed high intensity aerobic exercise for 23 minutes, then immediately practiced a complex, implicit motor task with their non-dominant hand across five separate sessions. Participants were also scanned before the first and after the fifth day of practice, and returned 24-hours and 35-days following their fifth day of practice to complete short- and long-term retention tests of behavioural change. Independent component analysis revealed increased connectivity in the frontoparietal network, the dorsal attentional network, and the cerebellar network in the exercise group. Seed-based analysis revealed strengthened connectivity between the limbic system and right cerebellum, between right lobule 9 and the right middle temporal gyrus, and between right lobule 10 and bilateral middle temporal gyri. There were no group implicit motor learning differences during acquisition or at either retention test. Overall, these data suggest that either exercise alone, or exercise paired with a novel implicit motor learning task augment resting state functional connectivity but do not enhance behavioural change beyond that stimulated by skilled motor practice in older healthy adults.
coauthors: Brian Greeley, University of British Columbia; Briana Chau, University of British Columbia; Christy C. Jones, University of British Columbia; Lara A. Boyd, University of British Columbia
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Advantageous inequity awareness in young children: the role of late positive potential (LPP) and emotional reactivity.
abstract: “Inequity aversion” (IA) is the natural tendency to avoid unfair outcomes. IA can take two forms: disadvantageous inequity (DI) aversion (i.e. when one avoids receiving less than a peer), or advantageous inequity (AI) aversion (i.e. when someone denies receiving more than a peer). Usually DI aversion is prevalent since early ages, while AI aversion has an appearance in later developmental stages. Despite existing evidence about this topic from behavioural developmental studies, there is an increasing need to add a neurobiological perspective to bridge the gap between IA and its underlying neural processes. To better understand the relationship between this behaviour and emotional reactivity, we employed a Montecarlo approach with cluster-based permutation testing to analyze electroencephalographic (EEG) recordings of seventeen 3- to 6-years-old children while they participated in a child-friendly Dictator Game (DG) task that included three types of offers: advantageous unequal (AI), disadvantageous unequal (DI) and fair (FA). After each offer, we asked children about their feelings. We observed that participants felt more sad with DI offers when compared to AI and FA offers. We also found higher late positive potential (LPP) amplitudes for AI offers when comparing to FA offers. These high LPP amplitudes after offer onset were related to the positive emotional responses to the offers. Therefore, we interpret that EEG amplitudes within LPP boundaries in pre-schoolers are an indicative of high emotional sensitivity to advantageous offers, which may explain the low levels of AI aversion in young children.
coauthors: Nastassja L. Fischer, National University of Singapore; Changrun Huang, National University of Singapore; Elizabeth B. Kim, National University of Singapore; Nawal Hashim, Duke-NUS; Jean Yeung, National University of Singapore; Rongjun Yu, National University of Singapore
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Neural Circuitry of Water Seeking in Drosophila
abstract: Thirst is an evolutionarily ancient motivational state that is hard-wired and critical for survival. How thirst circuits in the brain coordinate the appropriate goal-directed behavior, and how it can do so in the presence of opposing behavioral states such as hunger, is not well understood. We show that a persistent state of thirst is evoked by the precise activation and inactivation of overlapping central brain neuronal circuit elements in Drosophila. In a neuronal activation screen, we identified a subset of glutamatergic neurons that evoke robust thirst-related behaviors, including water seeking and intake; we named these neurons Durstig, the German for thirsty.These central brain neurons function downstream of sensory input and internal osmotic sensors to drive seeking to either open orin accessible water.Importantly, activation of Durstig neurons overrides food seeking in water replete but hungry flies. Thus, neural circuit elements that regulate hunger and thirst are tightly integrated. These studies provide an entry point for mapping the fundamental homeostatic thirst neurons and the hierarchical wiring of neural circuits that encode opposing motivational states.
coauthors: Dan Landayan, Stanford; Jennifer Zhou, UC Merced; Brian Wang, UC Merced; Fred Wolf, UC Merced
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Mathematical representation of neuron-glia networks.
abstract: Classical synapses are one-one. However, astrocytes play an active role in synapses, tripartite synapse. Besides, astrocytes are organized in networks, building a neuron-glia network. We propose three mathematical representations of a neuron-glia network: upsilon-family, upsilon-multiset, and upsilon-multidigraph. We represent synapses as graphs of a relation on a set of general neurons and define an upsilon-family as an indexed family of them. Then, we generate a multiset from upsilon-family to simplify it. Analogously to multidigraphs, we define isomorphism for upsilon-multisets. As a final simplification, we unnest the upsilon-multiset, getting the upsilon-multidigraph. Although upsilon-multidigraph has not multiple connections, we conjecture that it preserves isomorphism. From edges vertex of an upsilon-multidigraph, we generate a multi-topology of proper submultisets. Additionally, we create a network descriptor from a quasimetric defined over the vertex set of an upsilon-multidigraph. Finally, we roughly create a geometric realization of an upsilon-family in a three-dimensional Euclidean space. We concluded that neuron-glial network representations have a rich mathematical structure.
coauthors: Nelson Castro, Instituto de Matemática Pura e Aplicada
institution: Universidad Nacional Mayor de San Marcos
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Overcompensation of lens-accommodation in case of Convergence Insufficiency- A theoretical Model
abstract:
In this submission, I will present the theoretical computational model of a Non- Strabismic Binocular Vision Anomaly- an Adaptive Accommodation excess in case of Convergence Insufficiency (CI). Normally when a person perceives a target, ciliary and extraocular muscles are managed by the oculomotor nerve to clear the blur. The blur and disparity are corrected by altering the accommodation and vergence, respectively. 
CI is characterized by an inability to maintain binocularity while working at distances closer to the body, experienced usually as intermittent double-vision when focusing at a target. People with CI often complain of the inability to concentrate while doing near work and complain of headaches, double- vision, and strain - caused due to the fatigue of the extraocular and ciliary muscles. The neural feedback system of accommodation and vergence are co-dependent, in that they are connected via a closed-loop pathway. Physiologically, this is evident in the form of an ”Accommodation Triad” which consists of Accommodation, Convergence, and Pupil constriction. The accommodation triad describes an exceptional adaptation acquired as neural feedback in some subjects (despite fatigue) as an excess of accommodation to compensate for CI. I will present the neural mechanism and the theoretical computational model of this adaptive process.
coauthors: Ashwin Badrinath Pothiadia Irungovel, SUNY College of Optometry ; Bradly Alicea, Orthogonal Research and Education Laboratory
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Combining hierarchical latent-mixture and evidence accumulation-based models of cognition with fMRI data
abstract: We show how the functional resolution of mapping neural circuit features to distinct cognitive and behavioral components of decision-making process can be improved, by combining hierarchical latent-mixture and evidence-accumulation based models with neural (fMRI) data. These models are implemented within a Bayesian inference framework. Theory based and structural assumptions are used to develop evidence accumulation models whose parameters are hierarchically governed by cognitive subsystems, such as performance monitoring, belief updating, error-feedback, and executive control. Such models explicitly account for the temporal dynamics and learning associated with repeated decision making. They dissociate between different potential cognitive processes and strategies that may be used on a trial-by-trial basis, and account for the hierarchical process of strategy switching. The hierarchical cognitive processes and subsystems are characterized by cognitive parameters that potentially capture and mediate the relationship between neural (fMRI) and behavioral data. Such neuro-cognitive modeling allows us to differentiate between theories, provide insights into the developmental maturation of brain networks, and improve the identification of differential brain feature characteristics associated with different cognitive processes in clinical and neuro-diverse populations. Applications include identifying the joint neural and behavioral basis of individual differences in mathematical decision making, response inhibition, and perceptual decision making tasks.
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Is attention modulating alpha oscillatory activity focally for task-related locations or globally also to task-irrelevant locations?
abstract: Research on endogenous attention suggests that spatial and temporal expectations influence the processing of visual stimuli in part by hijacking ongoing alpha-band oscillatory activity in brain areas involved in visual perception. However, it is not known if this top-down modulation of alpha is selective for the circuits that represent the focus of spatial attention, or if it is also deployed for the active control of processing at non-target locations. To answer this question, we manipulated spatial and temporal predictability during a Posner-style visual discrimination task, in which, within a block, stimuli could only appear in two of the four cardinal locations (i.e., only left-right target locations during some blocks, only top-bottom targets during others). This allowed us to distinguish “ignored” locations (i.e., not cued on a particular trial) from “irrelevant” ones (never cued during a particular block). We used inverted encoding modelling to generate topographic filters to isolate the alpha oscillatory activity associated with each of the four target locations. Behavioral results showed an influence of spatial expectations on both discrimination performance and eye-movement patterns, with hints of a weaker influence of temporal expectations. In addition to the standard pattern of “alpha desynchronization” at the locus of attention, the EEG results revealed no difference in the effects of spatial or temporal expectations on the alpha-band dynamics associated with ignored versus irrelevant locations. These results do not find evidence that alpha-band dynamics are differently controlled for ignored versus irrelevant locations, but instead suggest that they reflect a more global phenomenon that covers all representations of visual space outside the focus of attention.
coauthors: Pietrelli, M., University of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison; Samaha, J., University of California, Santa Cruz; Postle, BR., University of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: A system-theoretic approach to synaptic scaling
abstract:
A closed-loop biophysical model of synaptic scaling is proposed and analyzed using tools from control theory:
- We show that the system is stable and converges to a unique parameter-dependent equilibrium, which means that the neuron’s averaged activity is regulated to the desired level (homeostasis).
- We also show the system is robust to parametric uncertainties, such as trafficking rates, degradation, and neurite size or length. This is done using classical feedback control approaches based on transfer functions and Nyquist stability criterion.
- We discuss the modeling of synaptic scaling, developing a comparison between coarse and fine models. We use the $H_{\infty}$ norm to capture the worst case error between the two models. Our findings show that the coarse model provides a good fit and captures the qualitative behavior of the complex fine model.
Based on these findings, we map complex topologies of real morphologies to coarse/reduced models and we show how to use these reduced models to predict the behavior of real neuronal morphologies without the need of computationally expensive simulations.
coauthors: Saeed Aljaberi, Adriano Bellotti, Fulvio Forni, Timothy O’Leary (University of Cambridge)
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Neuroscientific investigation of police perception, cognition, and behaviour
abstract: Police and other law enforcement personnel are tasked with serving and protecting our communities. As a result, officers are routinely exposed to uncertain, unpredictable, and potentially violent encounters. Resulting physiological stress responses have a pervasive influence on all aspects of police work and bear significant consequences on the health and safety of both officers and the public. An understanding of the neurophysiological mechanisms underlying these errors in perception, judgement, and behaviour is lacking in the response to countless examples of excessive use of force by police. Through our investigations of these mechanisms, we have contributed to a growing body of research that supports evidence-based use of force training and practices. In this interactive talk, we will begin by synthesizing the current state-of-the-art on neurophysiological investigations of perception, cognition, and behaviour among police populations. Relevant research topics include: situational awareness (i.e., sensory perception, attention, threat assessment, prediction); memory (i.e., encoding, consolidation, retrieval); decision-making (e.g., shoot/no-shoot); and skilled motor performance. We will also briefly discuss practical challenges to conducting empirical research in applied police settings, and the fine balance between maintaining experimental control and ecological validity.  We invite feedback from attendees in a wide range of disciplines to stimulate an active yet focused discussion. Through this discourse, we hope to identify important gaps in knowledge, future areas of inquiry, and innovative methodological approaches. The insights yielded during this talk and from the research discussed will also highlight the broader impacts of applied neuroscientific police research on health, policy, and society.
coauthors: Judith P. Andersen, University of Toronto
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Exploring the relationship between functional ultrasound and neuronal activity
abstract:
Functional ultrasound imaging (fUSi) is an appealing method for measuring blood-volume signals from the brain. However, the blood-volume signal measured by fUSi bears an unclear relationship to the underlying neuronal firing. Is this relationship linear, and stable across brain regions, subjects, and time?

To answer these questions, we performed simultaneous fUSi measurements and Neuropixels recordings in awake mice. Eight recording sessions were performed across four mice (~4 coronal slices per session). We inserted one or two Neuropixels probes per session, and related firing recorded from these probes to fUSi signals from the corresponding regions of interest (ROIs).

A linear model provided a good estimate of fUSi signals based on neuronal firing. We measured the multi-unit activity (MUA) from the Neuropixel probes and convolved it with a hemodynamic filter (4.2 s causal window). The filter was estimated using a linear regression model using half the data from one recording, and tested on the second half. Model predictions were accurate (r > 0.5). Furthermore, this model generalized across mice: it increased prediction accuracy relative to an instantaneous MUA model with no delay in all sessions in all three held-out mice. The hemodynamic filter resembled one measured optically, peaking ~1.5 s after neural activity (Pisauro, et al., J Neurosci 2013).

These results indicate that the relationship between neuronal firing and fUSi is stable and linear. Our current efforts aim to optimize the processing of fUSi signals so that they best capture variations in neuronal firing across both time and space.
coauthors: Michael Krumin, UCL; Charu B Reddy, UCL; Gabriel Montaldo, KU Leuven and NERF; Alan Urban,  KU Leuven and NERF; Kenneth D Harris, UCL; Matteo Carandini, UCL
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Spatial connectivity matches direction selectivity in visual cortex
abstract:
The selectivity of neuronal responses arises from the architecture of excitatory and inhibitory connections. In primary visual cortex, the selectivity of layer 2/3 neurons for stimulus orientation and direction is thought to arise from similarly-selective intracortical inputs. A neuron’s excitatory inputs, however, can have diverse stimulus preferences, and inhibitory inputs can be promiscuous and unselective. We revealed that excitatory and inhibitory intracortical connections to a layer 2/3 neuron accord with its selectivity by obeying precise spatial patterns. We used rabies tracing to label and functionally image the excitatory and inhibitory inputs to individual pyramidal neurons of mouse visual cortical layer 2/3. Presynaptic excitatory neurons spanned layers 2/3 and 4 and were distributed coaxial to the postsynaptic neuron’s preferred orientation, favouring the region opposite to its preferred direction. By contrast, presynaptic inhibitory neurons resided within layer 2/3 and favoured locations near the postsynaptic neuron and ahead of its preferred direction. The direction selectivity of a postsynaptic neuron was unrelated to the selectivity of presynaptic neurons but correlated with the spatial displacement between excitatory and inhibitory presynaptic ensembles. Similar asymmetric connectivity establishes direction selectivity in the retina, suggesting that this circuit motif might be canonical in sensory processing.
We are currently discovering similar patterns in the morphological reconstructions of the postsynaptic neurons, whose dendritic trees extended preferentially along the neurons’ preferred orientation. These results suggest a link between the dendritic architecture and the function of V1 neurons: by extending towards the appropriate inputs, dendrites may provide a morphological substrate for the emergence of visual selectivity.
coauthors: Kenneth D. Harris; Matteo Carandini
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: A Novel Quantitative Method Assessing EEG Reactivity in Comatose Patients on ECMO
abstract:
Objective:
Electroencephalogram (EEG) reactivity, defined as a change in EEG frequency or amplitude due to external stimulation, is used to assess responsiveness in comatose patients. We present a quantitative method to analyze EEG data from patients on extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) support. 

Methods:
EEG was acquired from 22 ECMO patients using a standardized stimulation paradigm that included auditory, noxious touch, and nostril stimulation. Data were divided into 111 total epochs and assessed using two metrics: spectral power and permutation entropy. We classified epochs based on increase or decrease of each metric in response to stimulation and computed scores for each epoch, both overall and for each spectral sub-band. Scores were grouped and validated against visual analysis of raw EEG. 

Results:
Variations were found to occur in all cerebral regions for both metrics. The mean overall scores for all types of stimulation for those patients identified by visual analysis as reactive were significantly higher than for those identified as unreactive: auditory (50.03 ± 46.11 vs 25.14 ± 12.27, p < 0.05), noxious touch (50.93 ±  33.32 vs 22.48 ± 11.45, p < 0.001), and nostril (48.64 ±  13.56 vs 19.61 ± 13.80, p < 0.01). Although nostril stimulation induced the largest difference on our metrics, it also resulted in the most epochs disqualified due to artifacts. 

Conclusion:
Our findings provide preliminary support for the validity of a quantitative (rather than qualitative) EEG scoring system assessing the response to stimulation using our qEEG metrics. To our knowledge, this is the first study to apply qEEG methods in the assessment of EEG reactivity in patients on ECMO support. We anticipate that further validation of this quantitative method on larger patient populations will enable new avenues of investigation and test its prognostic value.
coauthors: Autumn Williams, Johns Hopkins University Department of Biomedical Engineering; Romergryko G. Geocadin, Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine; Janaka Senarathna, Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine; Nirma Carballido Martinez, Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine; Jay Bronder, Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine; Nitish Thakor, Johns Hopkins University Department of Biomedical Engineering; Eva K. Ritzl, Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine; Sung-Min Cho, Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine;
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Decoding Covert Attention on an Orientation Perception Task from EEG Alpha Activity
abstract:
Alpha oscillations (8-14 Hz) were the first electroencephalograph (EEG) frequency band identified and are thought to have a critical role in visual perception and attention. However, despite its long history, it is unclear whether alpha power alone or alpha’s modulation of other frequency bands best accounts for attentional and perceptual task performance. To address this question, we plan to use quadratic discriminant analysis (QDA) classifier to test whether covert attentional states can be decoded from alpha power alone or from alpha modulated gamma activity prior to target onset. 
The data to be analyzed was collected from 34 participants performing a cued orientation detection task while EEG was recorded simultaneously. The task consisted of an informative cue (indicating right or left side) or uninformative cue (pointing towards both the left and right), then a target on the left or right pointing in one direction followed by a backward mask, a short delay, and then a response screen where participants used the mouse to rotate the pointing stimuli so that it matches the orientation of the target. Participants were instructed to use covert attention only. Errors on each trial were quantified as the difference between the target orientation and the orientation of participants’ response.
coauthors: Mathewson, Kyle E.
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Modeling the neurodevelopmental disorder Tuberous Sclerosis using human brain organoids
theme: Theme A: Development, Neurodegenerative Disorders and Injury

title: VMAT2 is expressed in human astrocytes and contributes to OCD-like behaviours in mice
theme: Theme B: Neural Excitability, Synapses, and Glia

title: pMA as a model to study the somatotopy of the interhemispheric interaction
abstract:
Physiological mirror activity (pMA) is an involuntary muscle activity in one limb muscles that happens when muscles of the opposite limb are strongly contracted. This phenomenon reflects the interhemispheric balance in the motor system. We hypothesize that pMA may serve as a model for studying the somatotopy of the interhemispheric interactions. We assume that pMA would be more prominent in the homologue muscles of the opposite hand compared to non-homologue muscles.
We obtained the  preliminary results from 11 healthy right handed participants (7 females, 19 to 28 y.o.). Surface EMG was recorded from the abductor pollicis brevis, first dorsal interosseous, abductor digiti minimi from both hands. Extensor carpi ulnaris and flexor carpi ulnaris were used as control muscles. Subjects performed three motor tasks (thumb abduction, index finger extension, little finger abduction) in a pseudo-random order with their right hand while pMA was measured in the left.

We observed pMA in the left hand muscles in 9 out of 12 participants with presence of < 50% of the trials. pMA tended to increase with the repetitions in the experiment course. Average pick-to-pick amplitude of pMA was 150 μV, while pMA latency varied between 50ms to 4500 ms. With regard to the pMA somatotopy, the phenomenon was more prominent in homologues muscles than in non-homologues ones. 

One of the obstacles we faced was that in some subjects in the active hand the isolated isometric contraction of one muscle without other co-located muscles was not possible. Further analysis, relating to demixing of EMG signal from the closely located muscles,
will be developed and performed.
coauthors: Kseniia Kozlova 1, Maria Mitina1,  Pavel Novikov1, Vadim Nikulin1,2 and Maria Nazarova1,3, 1 Higher School of Economics, Moscow, Russia; 2 Max Planck Institute, Leipzig, Germany , 3 Federal State Budgetary Institution «Federal center of brain and neurotechnologies»  of the Ministry of Health of the Russian Federation
institution: National Research University Higher School of Economics (grid.410682.9)
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Manipulating a Whip: Motor Control beyond Reach?
abstract:
Over the past decades much of motor neuroscience research has focused on unconstrained reach-like movements under highly controlled conditions.
