title: Enhancing classification of autism spectrum disorder using resting-state fMRI with machine learning approach and dimensionlity reduction
abstract: Autism spectrum disorder is a condition related to brain development that impacts how a person perceives and socializes with others. Early diagnosis of autism disorder involves in-depth behavioral observation and testing, which can be time consuming, expensive, and affected by clinician diagnostic bias. Early diagnosis of ASD using non-behavioral measurements can lead to improved outcomes for children with ASD. We developed algorithms to classify ASD based on publicly available brain-imaging datasets (ABIDE), including brain scans from people with and without ASD diagnosis. Using a multilayer perceptron neural network, we classified preprocessed data from 200 regions of interest (atlas of craddock 200) into binary categories of ASD positive or negative. To overcome overfitting of the training dataset, we used a novel approach to determine the most relevant subset of the preprocessed data. This led to a significant increase in our held-out testing accuracy. Our results indicate that brain imaging data alone, without any behavioral assessments, can be used to classify ASD diagnosis using dimensionality reduction and machine learning techniques. This has the potential to improve early diagnosis of ASD.
coauthors: Seyedeh Parisa Dajkhosh,Amirkabir University of Technology, Mehrnaz Hosseinzadeh, Fasa University of Medical Sciences,Yousef Ghanbari,University of Tehran
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Within and across domain effects of choice-induced bias
abstract:
Recent evidence suggests choices influence evaluation, giving rise to choice-induced confirmation bias. It is however unknown whether this phenomenon is constrained to the domain of choice, or spans across domains, allowing a decision to influence evaluation of unrelated item-specific information. 
Here, we intermix value-based and perceptual choices and evaluations of a set of appetitive stimuli to study both within and across domain effects of choices on value estimation. In a set of 5 experiments (4 preregistered, total of 425 participants) we find strong and consistent evidence for both within and across domain effects of choice induced bias in both domains. This means perceptual choices influenced subjective appetitive value, and value-based choices influenced perceived size.
The effect is stronger for value-based estimations, and for domain-congruent choices. The bias is driven to a greater extent by devaluing rejected items, is specific to endogenous (self-generated) choices, and cannot be explained by positive evidence bias. Our generative model of choice-driven value fluctuation reveals that only within-domain effects are long lasting. 
These findings reveal that the act of free choice influences the estimation of  both choice-relevant and irrelevant attributes of the chosen item, providing further insight into how choices shape internal values.
coauthors: Wojciech Zajkowski, Cardiff University; Jiaxiang Zhang, Cardiff University
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Cerebellar modulation of midbrain freezing-related circuitry
abstract: Innate defensive behaviors promote survival by allowing animals to detect and respond to threats within their environment, such as predators. Although innate, these defensive behaviors show a remarkable amount of flexibility and are subject to robust habituation, suggesting that the circuitry underlying defensive behaviors is subject to modulatory control. Using a combination of viral tracing and slice electrophysiology, we show that the cerebellum may provide one source of afferent modulatory influence within the periaqueductal gray by preferentially synapsing onto local dopaminergic neurons within the vlPAG. In turn, vlPAG dopamine neurons altered the relative strength of synaptically evoked inhibition and excitation onto transgenically identified freezing premotor neurons in the vlPAG. More specifically, activation of postsynaptic D2 receptors increased the strength of inhibition and decreased the strength of excitation. Such modulation is predicted to increase spike threshold and alter the gain of the input-output relationship, thereby changing the integrative properties of freezing premotor neurons. Together, these results suggest that locally released dopamine within the vlPAG modulates synaptic integration in freezing related neurons, which is controlled, at least in part, by input from the cerebellum.
coauthors: Spencer T Brown, Northwestern University; Indira M Raman, Northwestern University
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Structures and functions of sleep circuits in the brain
abstract:
Sleep is an essential biological need. Yet, its origin and functions are subject of intense experimental research (and debates). is My research interests aim at investigating the wiring, firing dynamics and plasticity of the neural circuits regulating brain states in normal and pathological states using in vitro and in vivo optogenetics combined to genetics and electophysiological, an now cell network imaging methods. These research goals have been driven by questions such as: What define a sleep/wake circuit? What are sleep oscillations good for? What is the neural coding of sleep and brain plasticity during sleep in health and diseases (narcolepsy, insomnia, stroke)? 
My laboratory has identified hypothalamic cells controlling rapid-eye movement (REM) sleep and arousal, a septo-hippocampus circuit supporting theta rhythm generation and contextual memory consolidation during REM sleep and a thalamus sleep-wake switch. My current projects focuses on the orchestration of sleep oscillations (slow waves, spindles, theta, etc.) in space and time and their roles in brain plasticity after stroke, sleep-dependent memory consolidation, and maintenance of hypothalamic-based feeding (innate) behavior.
coauthors: Carolina Gutierrez Herrera; Mattia Aime; Markus Schmidt
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Rediscovering the Pathways in Schizophrenia in Essence of Neurotransmitters and Antipsychotics
abstract:
Schizophrenia is among the most widely recognized mental disorders. As per WHO and DSM-V, it is a severe chronic mental disorder characterized by aggravations in thought, recognition, and behavior. Different reports present its causes,symptoms, medications, particularly its pathways and neurotransmitters' involvement. Studying several papers, we can see that the most tedious step is to examine all the pathways, and their adjusted or changed pathways in the wake of consuming the endorsed medications. Changes in the neurotransmitters' synapse with or without the administration ofdrugs are still under observation. The interconnections of various pathways like dopamine, serotonin, and GABA is in the measure. In this study, we aim to present a novel perspective by identifying some new pathways, which are changed due to various chemicals on neurotransmitters. We have studied multiple articles from all the directions, and in this paper, we reveal the potential causes and symptoms of the disorder, the role of neurotransmitters, and various brain pathways. The pathways of synapses like dopamine, serotonin, and GABA across multiplebrain locales before and after consuming medications are also discussed.Additionally, we have examined similar brain areas for healthy human subjectsand discovered some strong confirmations that the areas such as prefrontal cortex, limbic hippocampus, and ventral tegmental zone are the brain's most affected regions schizophrenia.We hypothesize that there may be unfamiliar pathways in these areas, as other than dopamine, there are similar synapses like serotonin and GABA, present in these areas. Along thisway,this understanding of schizophrenia may mark a novel path for some further investigations of such unfamiliar pathways.
Keywords: Schizophrenia, Neurotransmitters, Pathways, Mental Disorder, Neurochemistry
coauthors: Indranath Chatterjee
theme: Theme A: Development, Neurodegenerative Disorders and Injury

title: Striatal D1 collaterals to the GPe act as a second direct pathway to regulate motor coordination
abstract: In the classical model of the basal ganglia two segregated and functionally opposing pathways arise from the striatum to regulate motor control. Direct pathway striatal projection neurons (dSPNs) expressing dopamine D1 receptors (D1R) project monosynaptically to the substantia nigra (SNr) to promote movement while indirect pathway SPNs (iSPNs) expressing D2R project monosynaptically to the globus pallidus externus (GPe) to oppose movement. Recent functional studies, however, reveal that during native movements both pathways are activated. Moreover, anatomical and physiological studies have put into question the organization of the basal ganglia. For instance, we and others have shown that a large fraction of dSPNs possess axon collaterals within the GPe. These “bridging” collaterals are plastic in the adult animal and regulated by D2Rs and neuronal activity. These findings, though indirect, suggested an important role of dSPN bridging collaterals in regulating the balance of the direct and indirect pathway and motor function. Here, we used a combination of genetic targeting, calcium in vivo imaging, dSPN terminal-specific manipulations and behavioral tracking (DeepLabCut) to determine the role of dSPN bridging collaterals in motor function. We found that dSPN bridging collaterals were activated during specific movements in the rotarod. dSPN terminal inhibition also decreased locomotion and impaired rotarod performance. Recent physiology work shows that dSPNs preferentially target the non-canonical, striatal-backprojecting, arkypallidal Npas1 neurons in the GPe. We here found that stimulation of dSPNs inhibited Npas1 neurons in awake behaving mice. Finally, we found that Npas1 stimulation recapitulated the effects of dSPN inhibition by decreasing locomotion and rotarod function. We propose a model by which dSPN bridging collaterals support movement via inhibition of Npas1 neurons in the GPe. Thus, direct pathway GPe terminals act in concert with the canonical terminals in the SNr by inhibiting a potential stop signal going back to the striatum.
coauthors: Marie A. Labouesse, Columbia University; Joseph Villarin, Columbia University; Arturo Torres, Columbia University; Xiaoiao Sun, Columbia University; Fernanda de Carvalho, Columbia University; Sherry Lam, NIH/NIDA; Jordi Bonaventura, NIH/NIDA, Michael Michaelides, NIH/NIDA; Savio Chan, Northwestern University; Ofer Yizhar, Weizmann Institute of Science; Christoph Kellendonk, Columbia University
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Cognitive Impairment and Rehabilitation in Alzheimer’s Disease
abstract: A wealth of evidence emphasizes on the link between Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and cognitive impairment (CI). CI is generally accepted as a decline in memory, learning capacity, concentration, or decision-making, leading to functional impairment. The role of mild cognitive impairment (MCI) as a predictive factor of AD and the CI linked to the establishment and progression of AD have been discussed in the context of epidemiology, genetics, pathophysiology, pathology, and clinical practice. AD-associated CI has been also addressed as a source of socioeconomic burden urging for the development of therapeutic interventions. Cognitive rehabilitation (CR) is a complementary non-pharmaceutical treatment for AD consisting of cognitive stimulation and training methods. Based on the neuronal plasticity concept, CR aims at increasing AD patients’ functional status and retarding their mental decline. Although the method has encouraging results in several studies, there is still controversy as far as its efficacy is concerned and further research ought to be conducted before incorporating CR in AD’s treatment plan globally. CR drawbacks should be addressed and counteracted in this context, while the current CR approach may be ameliorated through errorless learning techniques.
coauthors: Theodoros Angelopoulos, Dorothy Martha Scordilis, Christos Tsagkaris
theme: Theme A: Development, Neurodegenerative Disorders and Injury

title: Neural processes underlying contextual influences on decisions
abstract: Our everyday social interactions affect not only our own decision making process and actions, but also the spread and evolution of information. As social interactions become increasingly online through social media, information consumed through this medium shapes how we think. We examined the neural underpinnings guiding the impact of information and context (e.g., social vs cyber) on decision making, where information credibility varies greatly. In this study, 240 healthy participants answered a questionnaire surrounding a variety of current issues (e.g., vaccinations, capital punishment, etc.) at three points in the study: (1) before interacting with a simulated social media environment that presented news articles including real and fake information, (2) following the social media platform interaction, and (3) after talking to other participants in a group. Electroencephalography (EEG) was measured during interactions with the social media platform. Participants were then scored based on how much they changed their opinion and categorized as “cyber influenced”, “socially influenced”, both, or neither, in order to evaluate the hypothesis that variability in opinions is linked to variability in neural behavior. Neural variability was analyzed using two methods: (1) traditional power analysis and (2) connectivity strength using a network approach that measures statistical relationships among nodes (EEG electrodes). Results show the respective neural pathways of information processing via digital interaction and in-person social interaction were not statistically different, suggesting that similar neural processes may serve both types of decisions to change their opinion, regardless of context. We further investigated this finding using more sensitive approaches to aggregate network changes, differentiating individuals that are more susceptible to information presented through a social media platform. Our results suggest different scales of neural processing underlying decision making are at play when individuals are presented with a variety of reliable and unreliable information in different contexts.
coauthors: Italo’Ivo Pinto, US CCDC Army Research Laboratory, Aberdeen Proving Ground, MD; Kristen Flaherty, US CCDC Army Research Laboratory, Aberdeen Proving Ground, MD, Northeastern University, Boston, MA; Amir Meghdadi, University of California, Santa Barbara, Santa Barbara, CA, Advanced Brain Monitoring, Carlsbad, CA; Christian Richard, Advanced Brain Monitoring, Carlsbad, CA; Chris Berka, Advanced Brain Monitoring, Carlsbad, CA; Kanika Bansal, US CCDC Army Research Laboratory, Aberdeen Proving Ground, MD, Department of Biomedical Engineering, Columbia University, New York, NY; Javier Garcia, US CCDC Army Research Laboratory, Aberdeen Proving Ground, MD
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Role of interneurons in populations’ neural coding and network properties in auditory cortex
abstract:
Cortical neuronal networks are comprised of multiple types of excitatory and inhibitory neurons, which
perform specific computations. In the auditory cortex (AC), excitatory neurons receive the sound input and
transmit the processed signal to other areas, whereas the inhibitory neurons dynamically help shape the
response of the excitatory neurons. In the last decade, we have learned specific functions of distinct
inhibitory neurons, yet how different interneuron subpopulations affect network dynamics remains
unexplored. To establish the role of different interneuron subpopulations within the cortical network, we
stimulated specific interneuron subpopulations, while imaging the network responses to sounds in the AC.
We monitored the activity of populations of hundreds of neurons using two-photon calcium imaging and
simultaneously increased the activity of a subpopulation of interneurons using optogenetic stimulation. We
focused on VIP and SOM inhibitory neurons, which have previously been found to shape cortical responses
in a context-dependent fashion (Natan et al, 2015; Pi et al, 2013). Response of neurons activated by sound
were enhanced when VIPs were activated but reduced upon activation of SOMs. Using Non-Negative Matrix Factorization, we identify subgraphs of neurons with increased connectivity when the activity of VIP or SOM interneurons is increased and describe their network properties. Our results suggest that the differential role of inhibitory neuron types on cortical activity extends from affecting not just single neuron responses, but also cortical function at the network level.
coauthors: M. Tobin, UPenn; K Wood, UPenn; J Stiso, UPenn; D Bassett, UPenn; M N Geffen UPenn;
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Decoding explicit and implicit representations of food health and taste attributes in the human brain
abstract: Visual food cues are constantly encountered in everyday life and are closely related to dietary decisions. The processing of these cues involves two key attributes: taste and health. This study aimed to examine whether and when these attributes are represented in the brain during the viewing of food images a) while making explicit health/taste judgements, and b) while implicitly considering food attributes for consumption decisions. We used multivariate support vector regression to determine whether spatiotemporal patterns of event-related potentials occurring in the first 1200 ms after the presentation of a food image could predict ratings of tastiness and healthiness on a trial-by-trial basis. In Experiment 1, participants (N = 37) were directly instructed to rate the tastiness and healthiness of various food items. The results showed that taste and health ratings could both be predicted significantly above chance, with taste (530-640 ms, 680-770 ms, 820-980 ms) becoming decodable slightly earlier than health (640-710 ms). In Experiment 2, a different sample of participants (N = 89) rated how strongly they would like to consume various food items, with no explicit instruction to consider tastiness or healthiness. Using the same analysis approach, we found that taste (740-1190 ms) and health (530-830ms) ratings could again be predicted significantly above chance. We could also predict the decision strength (830-920 ms), which might reflect the integration of taste and health information for decision-making. Taken together, our results suggest that taste and health information is decodable from electroencephalography data during dietary decisions, even when participants are not explicitly instructed to consider these attributes. This finding provides an exciting path for future studies to investigate potential alterations of taste and health representations following interventions, such as health warning messages, aimed at improving dietary choices.
coauthors: Elektra Schubert, University of Melbourne; Daniel Rosenblatt, University of Melbourne; Djamila Eliby, University of Melbourne; Yoshihisa Kashima, University of Melbourne; Hinze Hogendoorn, University of Melbourne; Stefan Bode, University of Melbourne
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Playing magic tricks to deep neural networks untangles human deception
abstract: Magicians have been in the business of hacking people’s minds for centuries. Some cognitive scientists, mainly those interested in attention and perception, have tried to explain why and how magic works, usually in laboratory conditions and using conventional psychophysical techniques and wisdom. Here we take a step in the opposite direction and ask not what neuroscience can do for magic but what magic can do for neuroscience in order to better understand human cognition. To that end, we studied the sleights of hand of a professional magician in the real world, upon several tricks where coins appear, disappear, multiply, and translocate. Using DeepLabCut, an AI-based pose-estimation system, we measured precisely the motor skills of the magician. We also trained the deep neural network to follow the coins, even when they were not visible. In other words, we transformed a tracking neural network into an artificial spectator. Can we fool it? Given that the neural network was trained by a human, what does it absorb and reflect about our own cognitive biases? The algorithm itself is indifferent to the speed of the magician’s performance and unaffected by change or inattentional blindness. However, just like a human spectator, the machine might still wrongly assume that a coin is in a closed fist, be uncertain, or even get “confused” when discovering it is not there. Overall, we find that the network possesses but also lacks some of the key human brain priors that grant illusionism its effectiveness. Our approach thus shows how it might be possible to use magic techniques to target the development of adversarial cognitive tricks at humans by choosing AI models that match human cognition as closely as possible. We can learn from what machines learn from us, creating a new powerful mirror to look into ourselves.
coauthors: Miguel Ángel Gea; Jordi Camí; Luis M. Martínez; Alex Gomez-Marin
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Better together: Let’s improve the culture in neuroscience
abstract:
Neuroscience is a wonderful field, full of excitement, mutual support, and learning from one another. However, the interactions we are having do not always feel positive. People are being bullied, some exploit their privilege, some are being talked down as stereotypes are used. This session is to hear from a number of people how it sometimes does not feel good. And which changes we should make as a field to neuroscience (starting with NMC) move forward productively while being whole more inclusive, positive, and fun.

Moderators: 
- Yiota Poirazi, PhD (Institute of Molecular Biology and Biotechnology of the Foundation for Research and Technology Hellas)

- Konrad Kording, PhD (University of Pennsylvania)

title: Auditory Corticothalamic Neurons are Recruited by Motor Preparatory Inputs
abstract:
During active sensing, neural responses to sensory inputs directly generated by our own movements are suppressed. In the auditory cortex (ACtx), self-initiated movements elicit corollary discharge from secondary motor cortex (M2) that suppresses pyramidal neuron (PyrN) spiking via recruitment of local inhibitory neurons. Using single unit electrophysiology, we observed that ACtx layer (L)6 PyrNs were also activated hundreds of milliseconds prior to movement onset, at approximately the same time as fast spiking inhibitory neurons. Most L6 PyrNs were corticothalamic (CT) cells, which all expressed FoxP2, a protein marker enriched in brain areas that integrate sensory inputs to control vocal motor behaviors. Using a combination of two-photon calcium imaging and optogenetically targeted single unit recordings, we found that L6 CTs were strongly activated prior to orofacial movements, but not locomotion. The specific recruitment by facial movements suggests that L6 CTs may receive a different source of motor input, beyond M2. Monosynaptic rabies tracing revealed that L6 CTs received ten times more direct inputs from the basal ganglia than M2. 
Our prior work found that optogenetic activation of L6 CTs reset the phase of low-frequency ACtx oscillations, modified sensory tuning in the thalamus and cortex, and switched perception into modes of enhanced detection or enhanced discrimination. Here, we show that preparatory facial movements can act like an optogenetic pulse, possibly priming cortical circuits for vocal feedback monitoring. These findings identify new pathways and local circuits for motor modulation of sound processing and suggest a new role for CT neurons in active sensing.
coauthors: Kameron Clayton, Harvard Medical School; Ross Williamson, University of Pittsburgh; Gen-ichi Tasaka, Hebrew University of Jerusalem; Adi Mizrahi, Hebrew University of Jerusalem; Troy Hackett, Vanderbilt University Medical Center; Daniel Polley, Harvard Medical School;
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Preparatory eye movements reveal prior knowledge and intended interaction in VR
abstract:
Most studies on human cognitive behavior are performed in controlled laboratory settings, limiting the validity and understanding of cognition in more naturalistic settings. The study of eye-movements in naturalistic tasks has revealed that the eyes precede the hands during an action. However, it is unclear how anticipatory and task-oriented eye movements are affected by prior knowledge about objects. The present study aims to investigate eye movement behavior while interacting with familiar and unfamiliar objects in a virtual environment. 
In this experiment, we study the gaze dynamics during interaction with 12 three-dimensional tool models in a virtual environment. We introduce a 2x2x2 factorial design with factors task, familiarity, and orientation. Participants were instructed to either lift or use a given familiar or unfamiliar tool. We presented the tools in two different orientations where the tool handle was presented either on the left or right side.
We used linear mixed models, with a random slope and intercept for subject and stimulus items, to model the odds of fixations on the tool effector before grasp initiation based on task, familiarity, and orientation. The results suggest that subjects fixate more on the tool effector when the tool is unfamiliar and during the use task.  Also, during the lift task, fixations on the tool effector and handle were equally likely. Additionally, we did not find any effect of the orientation of the tool. 
These findings suggest that the given task and the available knowledge about an object influence a person’s gaze control strategy during object interaction. Finally, the effect of prior knowledge and task type in a naturalistic setting lends further evidence towards eye movements predominantly driven by higher-level cognitive functions.
coauthors: Ashima Keshava; Nina Gottschewsky; Farbod Nosrat Nezami; Peter König
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Sensory versus culturally shaped expectations in the neural processing of music
abstract: When listening to music, we constantly attempt to predict the sounds that will follow. For example, quite often we end up humming, singing along or tapping our foot to the beat, and find pleasure in listening to pieces we know very well. However, the nature and brain basis of musical predictions or expectations remain poorly understood. Concretely, we do not know the extent to which these expectations arise from adaptation to the sensory properties of sounds or from a more cognitive and culturally shaped learning of the statistics of musical pieces and styles. In this presentation, I will address this issue by showing MEG data and modeling work in which the neural correlates of melodic expectations are investigated. I will show comparisons between the performance of a cognitive model of music statistical learning (IDyOM) and simpler metrics of acoustic similarity between tones (e.g. pitch distance, cosine similarity) in predicting neural responses to sounds. For this, an encoding model based on regularized linear regression was used. Preliminary results show that, across listening conditions, datasets and types of listeners, acoustic similarity models outperform cognitive models, thus suggesting a prominent role of sensory expectations in shaping neural responses to musical sounds. Potential neuronal mechanisms will be discussed, as well as the relationship of our findings with behavioral studies suggesting a preponderance of cognitive over sensory expectations during music listening.
coauthors: Marina Kliuchko, Technical University of Denmark; Niels Chr. Hansen, Aarhus Institute of Advanced Studies & Center for Music in the Brain, Aarhus University, Denmark; Andreas Højlund, Center for Functionally Integrative Neuroscience, Aarhus University, Denmark; Marcus Pearce, School of Electronic Engineering and Computer Science, Queen Mary University of London, UK; Elvira Brattico, Center for Music in the Brain, Aarhus University; Peter Vuust, Center for Music in the Brain, Aarhus University
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Adult Zebrafish Possess Two Phenotypically and Functionally Distinct Microglial Populations
abstract: Microglia are the tissue-resident macrophages in the central nervous system and are critically involved in immune defense, neural development and function, and neuroinflammation. The versatility of microglia has long been attributed to heterogeneity. Recent studies revealed possible heterogeneity in human but not murine microglia, yet a firm demonstration linking microglial heterogeneity to functional phenotypes remains scarce. Here, we identified two distinct microglial populations in adult zebrafish that differ in morphology, distribution, development, and function. The predominant population – phagocytotic microglia, which expresses ccl34b.1, is broadly distributed, amoeboid in shape, highly mobile and phagocytotic. The other white matter-enriched ccl34b.1- population, termed regulatory microglia, possesses ramified protrusions but has limited mobility and phagocytosis capability. Their functional differences are further supported by distinct transcriptomes and responses to bacterial infection, where ccl34b.1+ microglia function in tissue clearance and ccl34b.1- microglia release immune regulators. Our study sheds light on the heterogeneity and functional diversification of microglia.
institution: Hong Kong University of Science and Technology (grid.24515.37)
theme: Theme B: Neural Excitability, Synapses, and Glia

title: BRAIN Initiative Alliance Tools, Tech, Theory, and Trainee Series: Tools (part 1)
abstract:
The BRAIN Initiative Alliance (http://www.braininitiative.org/) is hosting a virtual series in collaboration with Neuromatch 3.0 to highlight cutting-edge tools, technology, and theories emerging from the US BRAIN Initiative. The event is divided into three session to focus on 1) Tools (probes, optics, cellular, molecular), 2) Tech (software, hardware), and 3) Theory (modeling, computation),  with trainees integrated in each session. Each session will include five brief talks/demos showcasing new tools, techniques, or theories from US BRAIN Initiative toolmakers followed by a moderated discussion with Q/A.

This is session 1/3, focused on Tools (probes, optics, cellular, molecular).

Moderator:
- Ute Hochgeschwender, MD (Central Michigan University)

Talks:
- "Idenification of lipid heterogeneity and diversity in the developing human brain"
Aparna Bhaduri, PhD (University of California San Francisco)

- "MR-active nanosensor: A tool to visualize biological condition/chemical"
Heather Clark, PhD (Northeastern University) and Hyewon Seo, PhD (Northeastern University)

- "Building a Toolbox of Enhancer-AAVs for Cell-Population Selective Gene Expression Across Species"
Boaz Levi, PhD (Allen Institute)

- "Free cloud platform for secure neuroscience data analysis"
Franco Pestilli, PhD (University of Texas Austin)

- "Neurotechnology design features' impact on identity and function of reactive astrocytes"
Ti'Air Riggins, MS (Michigan State University)
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Transforming Sensory Cues into Aversive Emotion via Septal-Habenular Pathway
abstract: Emotions evoked by environmental cues are important for animal survival and life quality. However, neural circuits responsible for transforming sensory signals to aversive emotion and behavioral avoidance remain unclear. Here, we found that medial septum (MS) mediates aversion induced by both auditory and somatosensory stimuli. Ablation of glutamatergic or GABAergic MS neurons results in impaired or strengthened aversion, respectively. Optogenetic activation of the two cell types results in place avoidance and preference, respectively. Cell-type-specific screening reveals that glutamatergic MS projections to the lateral habenula (LHb) are responsible for the induction of aversion, which can be antagonized by GABAergic MS projections to LHb. Additionally, the sensory-induced place avoidance is facilitated by enhanced locomotion mediated by glutamatergic MS projections to the preoptic area. Thus, MS can transmit innately aversive signals via a bottom-up multimodal sensory pathway and produce concurrent emotional and motional effects, allowing animals to efficiently avoid unfavorable environments. Zhang et al. reveal a circuit for processing innately aversive sensory signals, with glutamatergic projections from MS to LHb and POA to generate the emotional and a motional effect, respectively. This role of MS in mediating aversion is previously unrecognized.
coauthors: Zhang, Guang Wei; Shen, Li; Zhong, Wen; Xiong, Ying; Zhang, Li I.; Tao, Huizhong W.
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Emergence of Non-Linear Mixed Selectivity in Prefrontal Cortex after Training
abstract: Neurons in the prefrontal cortex (PFC) are typically activated by different cognitive tasks, and different context within a task. The selectivity of single neurons for the same stimulus dimension often changes depending on its context, a phenomenon known as nonlinear mixed selectivity (NMS).  It has previously been hypothesized that nonlinear mixed selectivity (NMS) emerges as a result of training in Working Memory (WM). In this study, we tested this hypothesis by examining neuronal responses at different PFC areas, before and after monkeys were trained to perform different WM tasks involving visual stimuli location and/or shapes. We found that training induces a modest increase in the proportion of neurons with NMS only for spatial, but not shape feature working memory task, with area 9/46 undergoing the most significant change in NMS cell proportion. Furthermore, we also found that higher working memory task complexity, in the form of requiring to remember location and shape combinations, does not increase the degree of nonlinear mixed selectivity for stimulus shape with other task variables. Lastly, in contrast to previous finding, we saw little evidence that NMS is predictive of task performance. Our results thus provide new insights on the representation of stimuli and task information in neuronal populations in WM.
coauthors: Russell J.Jaffe, Wake Forest School of Medicine;Xue-Lian Qi, Wake Forest School of Medicine; Christos Constantinidis, Wake Forest School of Medicine
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Terpsichore in Isolation: A study on the Correlation between Online Dancing and Telehealth during COVID-19 Pandemic on People with Parkinson's Disease
abstract:
Terpsichore, one of the nine Muses and the Goddess of the dance, is known for playing her lyre and leading the dance. My interest in the lyre was enhanced upon learning of the “healing” properties” of David’s lyre as presented in the Old Testament. A new window opens and the concept of art serving a function betony mere enjoyment becomes as magical as the mythology itself. “Dancing with Parkinson’s” expands the participants perception of music and dance within the studio and occurs in more than 25 countries all over the world. Parkinson’s disease (PD) is a degenerative neurological disorder with no known cure and no disease modifying treatments. The rising tide of 60,000 Americans with PD per year presents a huge challenge for society for affected individuals, medical professional and care givers. The disease demands intense patient care while negatively impacting quality of life on all those involved. Our group conducts research on the impact of dance upon individuals diagnosed with PD since 2013 (Bearss, Desouza, 2017). Weekly dance classes for people with PD, a dance choreographer, and a pianist have been occurring for seven years. We sample all people’s data through multimodal brain imaging scans, behaviour analysis, clinical tests and self-reported questionnaires. Results indicate promising positive effects of participating in dance (Bearss et al 2017; DeSouza and Bearss, 2018; Ciantar et al 2019). The Covid-19 Pandemic diminished the possibility of continuing the classes although the program administrators tried to maintain the spirit of this long running program via online sessions. No additional tests can be run on studying the effects of virtual dance classes on the participants’ brains but collecting data through online questionnaires can help studying the correlation between on-line dancing and telehealth. The desire of patients for continuing the online delivery is a definite sign of some benefits.
References
Bearss, K., Mcdonald, K., Bar, R., & DeSouza, J. (2017). Improvements in balance and gait speed after a 12 week dance intervention for Parkinson’s disease. Advances in Integrative Medicine, 4(1), 10-13. doi:http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.aimed.2017.02.002  
Ciantar, S., Bearss, K., Bar, R., Levkov, G., & DeSouza, J. (2019). Investigating Affective and Motor Improvements with Dance in Parkinson’s Disease. Biorxiv,
 Katayoun Ghanai
 PhD3 Music, Neuroscience Graduate Diploma, York University, Canada
 Centre for Vision Research, Psychology, Interdisciplinary graduate studies, VISTA, York
 University, CAPnet, Toronto, Canada
 Michael Coghlan
 Department of Music, AMPD, York University, Toronto, Canada
doi:https://doi.org/10.1101/665711  
DeSouza, J., & Bearss, K. (2018). Progression of Parkinson’s disease symptoms halted using dance over 3-years as assessed with MDS-UPDRS. Neuroscience Meeting Planner. San Diego: Society for Neuroscience Abstracts. Online, doi:https://abstractsonline.com/pp8/#!/4649/presentation/22209
coauthors: Joseph FX Desouza, Centre for Vision Research, Psychology, Interdisciplinary graduate studies, VISTA, York  University, CAPnet, Toronto, Canada; Michael Coghlan, Music Department, AMPD, York University, Toronto, Canada
theme: Theme A: Development, Neurodegenerative Disorders and Injury

title: Neural dynamics underlying the coding of location and running speed in the medial entorhinal cortex
abstract:
Memory-guided navigation and path integration require accurate coding of location and running speed. In mammals, path integration relies on memory circuits in the medial entorhinal cortex (MEC), where grid cells are proposed to provide a metric for space. The linear and positive modulation of firing rates observed in MEC speed cells has been proposed to provide a running speed signal for updating grid cell firing and supporting path integration.
In the first part of my talk, I will demonstrate that rate coding of running speed by speed cells in the MEC differs across time scales and works best at seconds-long time scales. I will further present data that such a slow and linear rate code is insufficient for accurate real-time coding of running speed as required by current computational models of grid cell firing and path integration.
Spatially periodic grid cell firing in the MEC relies on inputs from the medial septum. The second part of my talk will examine the role of medial septum inputs for theta oscillatory activity and speed cell firing in the MEC. 
The last part of my talk will examine the time course of changes in spatiotemporal accuracy of grid cell firing after transitions between light and dark conditions. Data will show that slow changes in grid cell stability on a time scale of tens of seconds are accompanied by slow changes in the local field potential theta frequency vs. running speed relationship, a proposed oscillatory speed signal. Furthermore, darkness results in large changes in the firing rates of many neurons including speed cells that explain the observed changes in the slopes of speed tuning curves. In summary, data suggest that the representation of space by grid cells in the MEC may be a function of velocity signals integrated over past time.
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Investigating spatial specificity in the interaction between working memory and visual perception
abstract: Content in visual working memory has been shown to impact ongoing visual processing in a stimulus-specific manner, suggesting a common neural substrate supporting both visual perception and working memory maintenance. However, it remains unclear whether working memory for visual features retains a representation of its spatial location at encoding or whether the representation of the feature is abstracted away from the spatial context in which it is encountered. The current study investigated whether spatial location modulates working memory’s interaction with perception through a set of three psychophysical experiments. In Experiment 1, subjects performed a perceptual discrimination of orientation while concurrently holding an orientation in working memory. Memory content boosted the perceived contrast of the discriminandum when the two matched in orientation, but only when their location also overlapped. Conversely, memory precision declined when the location of memorandum and discriminandum mismatched, suggesting that location mismatch might disrupt context binding in working memory. To ensure that this observed effect reflects low-level perceptual interaction, in Experiment 2 the task demands in the memory and perceptual tasks were set to be entirely orthogonal and thus removing potential decision biases. We found that this location-specificity held in both the contrast perception and the memory report. Finally, Experiment 3 tested whether context-binding demand influences the spatial extent of this interaction. We introduced a condition that discouraged the binding of feature and location by shifting the memory probe to a non-matching, central location, and found that working memory content enhanced contrast perception of the discriminandum at both overlapping and non-overlapping positions, suggesting a spatially non-specific effect. Overall, these results demonstrate that, depending on the context-binding demand, working memory of features can be optimized to either retain a representation of its spatial location or not, and highlight the flexible encoding of working memory.
coauthors: Brad R. Postle, University of Wisconsin-Madison
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: NeuroGraphMatch
abstract: A network is defined as a set of nodes connected by a set of edges. In neuroscience, the structure of the brain (connectome) can be modeled as a network, where neurons or regions of interest are thought of as nodes, and the connections between these regions are thought of as edges. Through the use of functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) as well as diffusion tensor imaging (DTI), one can estimate the presence of “nodes” and “edges”in the brain, thus representing it as a graph. Additional advancements in methodologies involving electron microscopy have allowed for the ability to capture information on individual neurons and synapses. This has made the use of network statistics important in the study of brains. Specifically, the graph matching algorithm (also known as the quadratic assignment problem) seeks to quantify the underlying similarity between two networks, determining an alignment of nodes between them.  This analysis can be utilized to quantify similarities in inter- and intra-species connectomes, or to predict homologous neuron pairs across brain hemispheres. Through the use of available and simulated data, we will demonstrate the efficacy of our Fast Approximate Quadratic assignment algorithm (FAQ) Python implementation (now in SciPy and graspologic), and showcase it’s applications in the fields of computational neuroscience and, more broadly, combinatorial optimization.
coauthors: Benjamin D. Pedigo, Johns Hopkins University; Youngser Park,  Johns Hopkins University; Carey E. Priebe,  Johns Hopkins University;  Joshua T. Vogelstein, Johns Hopkins University
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Extrinsic factors tuning human neurogenesis
theme: Theme A: Development, Neurodegenerative Disorders and Injury

title: Categorical representation by suppression or enhancement of auditory stimuli during perceptual learning
abstract:
Perceptual learning reliably enhances cortical representations of task-relevant stimuli in trained animals. However, these neural changes have predominantly been observed outside of behavioral context and regardless of learning rate. Our lab found that engagement in behavior alters auditory cortical responses via local inhibition and cholinergic signaling (Kuchibhotla et al., 2017). Here, we examined how sensory representations in both excitatory and inhibitory neurons change over auditory perceptual learning in mice on a two-alternative forced-choice (2AFC) task. 

We performed simultaneous 2-photon imaging of excitatory and inhibitory neurons in auditory cortex throughout 2AFC auditory conditioning in head-fixed mice. To obtain water reward, animals learned to lick a left lick port for tones of a single, target frequency (11-16 kHz) and right for tones of all other frequencies. Discrimination between target (left) and surround (right) frequencies improved over 9-21 days. While animals were task-engaged, ~50% of stimulus-responsive excitatory neurons exhibited a categorical response, not encoding the frequency of the stimulus, but rather the behavioral choice on that trial. We observed two distinct population-level tuning in experienced animals; animals exhibited either a relative enhancement or suppression of the frequencies reported as target. 

Using chronic two-photon imaging to track neurons longitudinally, we examined when these response profiles emerged during learning. We could detect whether an animal would likely exhibit enhancement or suppression as early as day 6 in behavioral learning. We developed a network model of excitatory and inhibitory neurons to explore what may account for these individual differences and how they arise over learning.
coauthors: Kathleen A Martin, New York University School of Medicine Skirball Institute of Biomolecular Medicine, New York University Center for Neural Science, New York University School of Medicine Neuroscience Institute; Colin Bredenberg, New York University Center for Neural Science; Eero Simoncelli, New York University Center for Neural Science; Cristina Savin, New York University Center for Neural Science; & Robert C Froemke, New York University School of Medicine Skirball Institute of Biomolecular Medicine, New York University Center for Neural Science, New York University School of Medicine Neuroscience Institute, Howard Hughes Medical Institute Faculty Scholar
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Network-based R-statistics for longitudinal (unbalanced) samples: an R package
abstract:
The connectome models the brain as a set of interacting elements, allowing to characterize the brain from a systems perspective using network science. In particular, Zalesky et al. (2010) proposed Network-based Statistics (NBS) a mathematical approach that allows statistical inferences at the (sub-)network level, with a trade-off between false positive control and higher statistical power than mass univariate approaches (e.g. FDR). Nevertheless, NBS is based on general linear hypothesis testing (GLHT) which potentially limits its application to longitudinal samples, particularly, with an unbalanced sample, i.e., with a variable number of sessions per subject. We implemented a publicly available software R package, NBR (Network-Based R-statistics), that performs linear mixed-effects models (LME) in the NBS framework, allowing the exploration of unbalanced longitudinal samples.
We tested GLHT- and LME-NBS in the public dataset INDI-SLIM, which includes 333 participants (145 males; 17-28 y.o.) with two (n=212) or three (n=121) sessions each. All sessions include a resting-state fMRI scan and psychometric data. State anxiety scores and connectivity matrices between brain lobes were extracted. GLHT and LME tested the edgewise brain-behavior relationship for balanced (424 matrices) and unbalanced (787 matrices) samples, respectively.
The LME approach found a significant subnetwork, which includes the cingulum, frontal, parietal, occipital, and cerebellum (pFWE = 0.001), while GLHT found no significant results (pFWE = 0.355).
In summary, we developed an R package that implements LME for NBS. We showed that LME-NBS overpowers GLHT-NBS when dealing with unbalanced longitudinal samples. This is important given that missing data is very common in longitudinal samples, and balanced testing could dramatically undermine statistical power. Hence, considering the growth of longitudinal samples in neuroscience, we anticipate this method being potentially useful in the field.
coauthors: Sarael Alcauter, National Autonomous University of Mexico
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Atypical pupillary response to novel auditory stimuli in children with autism spectrum disorder
abstract: Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) is characterized by impaired social interaction and interpersonal communication. Researchers have suggested that aberrant attentional function to exogenous stimuli contribute substantially to social deficits among individuals with ASD. The attentional function is modulated by locus coeruleus (LC) and its noradrenergic projections throughout the brain, and the LC activity has been shown abnormal among the ASD population. As an index of LC-NA activity, PDR provides a convenient and non-invasive measure for studying attentional deficits. However, previous research has focused on examining PDR when individuals with ASD process social stimuli (e.g., face pictures) or engage in complicated cognitive tasks. Here we used a simple auditory oddball task to test children with ASD and their age-matched typically-developed controls (TD group). Participants were required to listen to the stimuli without task responses while their PDR was continuously monitored. Compared to standard stimuli (pure-tone beeps), deviant stimuli induced phasic PDR in both groups. Social (laughter) and non-social (noise) deviants elicit similar PDR. Importantly, the ASD group exhibited significantly smaller PDR than the TD group. Controlling for age and IQ, we observed a strong negative relationship between PDR and ASD symptom severity across groups and a weak correlation within the ASD group. Our results suggest that aberrant attention function among individuals with ASD is not limited to social stimuli but probably include stimuli without social or affective content. Reduced LC-related responsivity to novel stimuli has important implications for affected attention orientating that has been proposed as a fundamental problem for social development in ASD.
coauthors: Yajie Liu, School of Psychological and Cognitive Sciences, Peking University, Beijing, China; Linlin Gong, School of Psychological and Cognitive Sciences, Peking University, Beijing, China; Sijia Zhao, Department of Experimental Psychology, University of Oxford, Oxford OX1 3PH, UK; Kunlin Wei, School of Psychological and Cognitive Sciences, Peking University, Beijing, China
theme: Theme A: Development, Neurodegenerative Disorders and Injury

title: Exploring Latent Structures of Cognitive Tasks Using PCA
abstract:
Intro: It is established that aspects of cognition are overlapping in terms of their neural representation. We wanted to explore the latent structure across different cognitive tasks within the human connectome project (HCP) using PCA.
Methods: We applied PCA to task-evoked functional activity. The analytical pipeline was as follows: Time series for each task were extracted from the dataset. Each task was broken down into their separate sub-conditions (e.g., 0-back and 2-back working memory conditions.) Each condition for each task was then decomposed into a functional connectivity matrix. Finally, PCA was applied to each condition across each task. 
Results: PCA components were extracted for each of the tasks in the HCP dataset. Initially, we examined how many components would best characterize the variability across tasks. Some tasks required many components to explain 95% of the variance (e.g., gambling, motor, emotion) whereas others required fewer (working memory, social) Across tasks, four components would be able to explain 95% of the variance. 
Discussion: Our findings reveal that fewer components are needed to explain the variance in complex working memory and social tasks than in seemingly simpler tasks (e.g. motor). This may be due to the added noise of cognitive tasks, leading to a more distributed variance across components. It could also be due to mind-wandering during simpler tasks. In datasets like HCP which incorporate many types of tasks, PCA can be a helpful tool to project the functional connectivity patterns into spaces in which tasks are distinguishable. PCA is also a useful dimensionality reduction tool in fMRI data to reduce the size of the data without losing much of the variance within the dataset.
coauthors: Davide Momi, University "G. d'Annunzio" of Chieti ; Nora Bradford, University of California, Irvine; Ladan Shahshahani, University of Western Ontario; Corey Richier, University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Network Activity in the Development of Inhibitory Circuits
theme: Theme A: Development, Neurodegenerative Disorders and Injury

title: Human control of complex objects: Stochastic optimal feedback control and beyond
abstract:
For several decades, goal-directed reaching in the horizontal plane has served as testbed to gain insight into human control and adaptation of movements. A prominent model that has successfully accounted for a variety of observations is stochastic optimal feedback control that minimizes muscular effort and kinematic accuracy given signal-dependent noise. This body of research simplified the movement to free pointing tasks, excluding any real-world interactions with objects and the environment. Our research extends the sensorimotor challenge and examines ‘reaching’ while transporting a non-rigid object, such as carrying a cup of coffee. Safe control of such underactuated objects need to predict, preempt or compensate for self-generated perturbations of the liquid that presents forces acting back onto the hand. 
In our experiment, participants transported a semicircular cup with a heavy ball rolling inside (simulating the sloshing coffee) in a virtual environment, interfaced with a robotic manipulandum. They moved the cup-and-ball on a horizontal line to a target box. Due to the internal dynamics, the cup trajectory significantly deviates from a bell-shape velocity profile common in unconstrained movements. It also deviates from the two-peaked profile that is predicted by an effort-minimizing optimal controller that minimally intervenes with forces generated by the rolling ball. To reproduce the observed cup velocity profile (which has small positive acceleration in the middle), two modifications of the optimal feedback controller were needed: First, hand impedance accounts for the participants’ compliant behavior when facing perturbations (included as a linear spring/damper at the cup). Second, the controller seeks to regulate the zero-force trajectory of the spring/damper with maximal smoothness. As long as the object dynamics is simple, as for a rigid object, both the original and the modified control models result in bell-shaped velocity profiles. However, when coping with interaction forces from the object, the dynamically-informed smoothness criterion is superior as it penalizes changes in cup velocity. These findings show that to gain insight into human control, we need to go beyond the highly simplified tasks to gain insights into human behavior with real-life challenges.
coauthors: Rashida Nayeem, Northeastern University; Mohsen Sadeghi, Northeastern University; Salah Bazzi, Northeastern University; Dagmar Sternad, Northeastern University;
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Can single neurons solve MNIST? The computational power of biological dendritic trees
abstract: Physiological experiments have highlighted how the dendrites of biological neurons can nonlinearly process distributed synaptic inputs. This is in stark contrast to units in artificial neural networks that are generally linear apart from an output nonlinearity. If dendritic trees can be nonlinear, biological neurons may have far more computational power than their artificial counterparts. Here we use a simple model where the dendrite is implemented as a sequence of thresholded linear units. We find that such dendrites can readily solve machine learning problems, such as MNIST or CIFAR-10, and that they benefit from having the same input onto several branches of the dendritic tree. This dendrite model is a special case of sparse network. This work suggests that popular neuron models may severely underestimate the computational power enabled by the biological fact of nonlinear dendrites and multiple synapses per pair of neurons. The next generation of artificial neural networks may significantly benefit from these biologically inspired dendritic architectures.
coauthors: Konrad Kording, Univeristy of Pennsylvania
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Architecture to learn untrained joints in macaques and other species
abstract: Pose tracking of animals is of utmost importance in systems neuroscience and related fields like neuroethology. It is also of growing importance in fields that use behavioral assays in model organisms, such as addiction and mental health research. While off-the-shelf solutions exist for many laboratory animals, monkeys have proven especially challenging and require a bespoke solution. We recently developed a tracking system for rhesus macaques called OpenMonkeyStudio (Bala et al., 2020). Like other supervised approaches, our system makes use of machine learning based on carefully annotated example datasets. However, like other approaches, ours has a major limitation: it cannot generalize to new joints that were not explicitly trained through annotated examples. Here we describe two novel approaches that can do this. First, the prediction of novel 2D key points via 3D MLP augmentation and second, a 50-layer convolutional neural network (CNN) with point rendering supervision to perform full 3D segmentation of our macaque subjects. We then project the 3D voxel space into a mesh space using the marching cubes algorithm and overlay the 2D image textures. Our initial supervised training set used 13 joints; our new approach can track arbitrarily many, including a deformable mesh grid for the entire body of arbitrary density. For example, we demonstrate a version with 30,000 points on the subject’s body. One benefit of this approach is that we can perform high resolution head position and orientation tracking, thus giving us a rudimentary estimate of gaze direction. While our focus is on macaques, our approach can readily be applied to other species as well.
coauthors: Praneet Bala, Hyun Soo Park, Jan Zimmermann
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Motion extrapolation in the flash-lag effect depends on perceived, rather than physical speed
abstract: In the flash-lag effect (FLE), a flashed object in spatiotemporal alignment with a moving object is often misperceived as lagging behind the moving object. One proposed explanation for the illusion is based on predictive motion extrapolation and argues that the visual system constantly predicts the position for the moving object in the present moment, in order to compensate for the time required for neural transmission and processing. In this interpretation, the visual system uses an estimate of the object’s velocity to generate a prediction, which implies that the FLE should rely on an explicit neural representation of velocity. By contrast, alternative explanations of the FLE based on differential latencies or temporal averaging should not be dependent on such a representation of velocity. Here, we test the extrapolation hypothesis by investigating the effect of illusory changes in perceived speed on the magnitude of the FLE in two experiments. In Experiment 1, we manipulated perceived speed by adding temporal noise to a rotating wedge stimulus, and in Experiment 2 we manipulated perceived speed by changing the luminance contrast of the wedge. We show for both manipulations, differences in perceived speed corresponded to differences in FLE magnitude: both perceived speed and perceived flash-lag increased when the wedge contained dynamic noise relative to static noise, and when it was presented in low relative to high contrast. Moreover, this effect was consistent across two different textures. Our findings therefore indicate that the FLE depends on an explicit neural representation of velocity, consistent with the motion extrapolation hypothesis.
coauthors: Jane Yook, Melbourne School of Psychological Sciences, The University of Melbourne, Cognitive Neuroscience, Institute of Neuroscience and Medicine (INM-3), Forschungszentrum Jülich, Department of Psychology, Faculty of Human Sciences, University of Cologne; Lysha Lee, Melbourne School of Psychological Sciences, The University of Melbourne; Simone Vossel, Cognitive Neuroscience, Institute of Neuroscience and Medicine (INM-3), Forschungszentrum Jülich, Department of Psychology, Faculty of Human Sciences, University of Cologne; Ralph Weidner, Cognitive Neuroscience, Institute of Neuroscience and Medicine (INM-3), Forschungszentrum Jülich; Hinze Hogendoorn, Melbourne School of Psychological Sciences, The University of Melbourne
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: The Gradient Clusteron: A model neuron that learns via dendritic nonlinearities, structural plasticity, and gradient descent
abstract: Synaptic clustering on neuronal dendrites has been hypothesized to play an important role in implementing pattern recognition. Neighboring synapses on a dendritic branch can interact in a synergistic, cooperative manner via the nonlinear voltage-dependence of NMDA receptors. The single-branch clusteron learning algorithm (Mel 1991) takes advantage of this nonlinearity to solve classification tasks by randomly shuffling the locations of "under-performing" synapses on a model dendrite during learning (“structural plasticity”), eventually resulting in synapses with correlated activity being placed next to each other on the dendrite. We propose an alternative model, the gradient clusteron, or G-clusteron, which uses an analytically-derived gradient descent rule where synapses are "attracted to" or "repelled from" each other in an input- and location- dependent manner. We demonstrate the classification ability of this algorithm by testing it on the MNIST handwritten digit dataset and show that, when using a softmax activation function, the accuracy of the G-clusteron on the All-vs-All MNIST task (86.5%) approaches that of logistic regression (88.9%). In addition to the synaptic location update plasticity rule, we also derive an learning rule for the synaptic weights of the G-clusteron (“functional plasticity”) and show that the G-clusteron with both plasticity rules can learn to solve the XOR problem.
coauthors: Menachem Kalmenson, Hebrew University of Jerusalem; Idan Segev, Hebrew University of Jerusalem
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: No evidence for entrainment: endogenous gamma oscillations and rhythmic flicker responses coexist in visual cortex
abstract:
Oscillatory brain activity in response to rhythmically presented stimuli is widely utilised in neurocognitive research to investigate visual perception. It has been suggested that endogenous neuronal oscillations can synchronise to rhythmic stimulation, a phenomenon widely termed entrainment.
 Motivated by the plethora of studies showing the involvement of neuronal gamma oscillations (~30-100 Hz) in cognition, we aimed to study to what extent photic stimulation at frequencies >50 Hz drives ongoing gamma oscillations in the human brain. To this end, we systematically investigated oscillatory responses to a rhythmic flicker in absence and presence of endogenous gamma oscillations using magnetoencephalography (MEG). Utilising a high-frequency projector, we superimposed the photic stimulation, with frequencies ranging from 52 to 90 Hz, onto an invisible circular patch and moving grating stimuli known to reliably induce gamma oscillations, respectively. Power and phase-locking were found to decrease approximately linearly with increasing flicker frequency; with no amplification at individually preferred frequencies, suggesting that the visual system did not resonate within the stimulation range. Unexpectedly, this was also the case when gamma oscillations were induced. Moreover, the rhythmic stimulation did not appear to modulate the frequency or phase of the gamma oscillations. Rather, the results indicate a co-existence of both responses, with the sources of the flicker response and the gamma oscillations peaking at significantly different locations in visual cortex. As there was no modulation of endogenous oscillations by visual stimulation, our findings challenge the notion that the phenomenon of neuronal entrainment generalises to gamma oscillations.
coauthors: Tjerk P Gutteling, Centre for Human Brain Health, School of Psychology, University of Birmingham; Christoph S Herrmann, Experimental Psychology Lab, Department of Psychology, European Medical School, Cluster of Excellence “Hearing for All”, Carl von Ossietzky University, Oldenburg, Germany; Ole Jensen, Centre for Human Brain Health, School of Psychology, University of Birmingham
theme: Theme B: Neural Excitability, Synapses, and Glia

title: PaSClass: A Machine Learning Pipeline to classify excitatory and inhibitory neurons of the rat Parasubiculum.
abstract: The parasubiculum (PaS) is a small brain region that belongs to the parahippocampal formation, lying between the presubiculum and the medial entorhinal cortex.  PaS neurons are divided into 3 main classes: WFS1 positive excitatory neurons, Reelin positive interneurons, and parvalbumin (PV) interneurons. Using in vitro patch-clamp recordings, we analyzed the electrophysiological profile of more than 500 PaS neurons. Immunolabelling information was available only for ~50% of the dataset. Of this, the vast majority were WFS1+ positive neurons.  A small proportion was Reelin-positive that exhibited similar electrophysiological properties to WFS1, while the least represented class was PV interneurons. For such a multiclass and imbalanced dataset with similar electrophysiological features for the WFS1 and Reelin classes, the commonly used threshold analyses or clustering approaches were inefficient to predict the class of the remaining neurons. Thus, we designed and developed a machine learning classification pipeline to predict the class of our PaS neurons. Firstly, we implemented and tested multiple classification algorithms, including Support Vector Classifier, Complement Naive Bayes Classifier, Logistic Regression, K-Nearest Neighbor classifier, Multilayer Perceptron Model (MLP), and the Random Forest Classifier (RF). Using exclusively the dataset where the immunolabelling information was available, we used stratification and cross-validation, to test the performance of the models. Appropriate class weights were added where applicable. RF and MLP yielded the highest accuracy scores across multiple trials. We continued by training and extensively testing the performance of our two best models, the RF and MLP. Finally, we used them to label the neurons lacking immunolabelling data. Tested models returned identical labels for 90% of the 244 cases. Cells with different predicted labels were excluded. The whole approach was performed using the open-access Python Sklearn package. We consider this pipeline as a new tool for predicting the staining of neurons when immunolabelling and morphological information is limited.
coauthors: Rosanna P. Sammons ; Dietmar Schmitz
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Fully reproducible EEG analyses with EEGLAB and LIMO EEG
abstract: Reproducibility is a cornerstone of scientific communication without which one cannot build upon each other's work. Because modern human brain imaging relies on many integrated steps with a variety of possible algorithms, it has however become impossible to report every detail of a data processing workflow. In response to this analytical complexity, community recommendations are to share data analysis pipelines (scripts that implement workflows). Here we show that this can easily be done using EEGLAB and tools built around it. BIDS tools allow importing all the necessary information and create a study from EEG-Brain Imaging Data Structure compliant data. From there preprocessing can be carried out in only a few steps using EEGLAB and statistical analyses performed using the LIMO EEG plug-in. Using Wakeman and Henson (Wakeman & Henson, 2015)  face dataset, we illustrate how to prepare data and build different statistical models, a standard factorial design (faces * repetition) and a more modern trial based regression approach for the stimulus repetition effect, all in a few reproducible command lines.
coauthors: Cyril Pernet, University of Edinburgh, Ramon Martinez-Cancino, Dung Truong, Scott Makeig & Arnaud Delorme, University of California San Diego
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Emergent decision-making behaviour and rhythm generation in a computational model of the ventromedial nucleus of the hypothalamus
abstract: Neurons of the ventro-medial nucleus (VMN) of the hypothalamus play an essential role in energy homeostasis, possibly implementing decision making between different motivational states. Analysis of spike interval histograms of extracellular recordings of these cells identifies several distinct types based on firing pattern, including varied features such as doublets, long refractory periods, and oscillations in excitability, in particular a distinct 3Hz oscillation. We have been using integrate-and-fire based modelling in an attempt to determine whether these variations are more likely based on varied intrinsic electrophysiological properties, or may be a result of network interactions. Some cell types can be matched by single neuron models. The more complex types appear to require a network. A homogeneous network of random synaptically connected model neurons with long duration hyperpolarising after-potential (HAP), was able to reproduce some of the more complex cell types, including rhythm generating behaviour. Adding a depolarising afterpotential to the neurons, the network could also reproduce bistable behaviour that might underlie decision making mechanisms. However the homogeneous network could not match the oscillatory cells, which do not show the long HAP necessary to generate the rhythm. The solution was to use a network population of two distinct cell types, one with a short HAP and the other with a long HAP. The slow HAP cells synchronise to produce a 3Hz rhythm. This forms a network input signal to the fast HAP cells, producing firing that closely, and consistently, matches recorded oscillatory cells.
theme: Theme B: Neural Excitability, Synapses, and Glia

title: Too salty? Your amygdala-thalamus gain network may need to loosen up a bit.
abstract: Peripheral sources of individual variation in taste intensity perception have been well described. The existence of a central source has been proposed but remains unexplored. Here we used functional magnetic resonance imaging in healthy human participants (20 women, 8 men) to evaluate the hypothesis that the amygdala exerts an inhibitory influence that affects the “gain” of the gustatory system during tasting. Consistent with the existence of a central gain mechanism (CGM), we found that central amygdala response was correlated with mean intensity ratings across multiple tastants. In addition, psychophysiological and dynamic causal modeling analyses revealed that the connection strength between inhibitory outputs from amygdala to medial dorsal and ventral posterior medial thalamus predicted individual differences in responsiveness to taste stimulation. These results imply that inhibitory inputs from the amygdala to the thalamus act as a CGM that influences taste intensity perception.
coauthors: Michael C. Farruggia, Department of Psychiatry, Yale School of Medicine, New Haven, Connecticut, US; Xiao Gao, Faculty of Psychology, Southwest University, Chongqing, China; Yuko Nakamura, The UTokyo Center for Integrative Science of Human Behavior, Tokyo, Japan; Barry G. Green, The John B. Pierce Laboratory, New Haven, Connecticut, US; Dana M. Small, Department of Psychiatry, Yale School of Medicine, New Haven, Connecticut , US
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Astrocytic mitochondria regulates astrocytes morphogenesis and supports synaptogenesis
abstract: The mechanisms controlling the postnatal maturation of astrocytes play a crucial role in ensuring a correct synaptogenesis. Here we explore the functional significance of mitochondrial activity for post-natal maturation of astrocytes in vitro and in vivo. We show that postnatal morphogenesis of astrocytes is critically dependent on the transient up-regulation of metabolic regulator PPARγ co-activator 1α (PGC-1α) which is required for determining the highly interconnected functional network of mitochondria and then for providing an efficient bioenergetic supply in the developing astrocytes. The integrity of the elongated mitochondrial network depends on the metabotropic glutamate receptor 5 (mGluR5) via a direct modulation of PGC-1α. We also report that perturbation of mitochondria network and function by ablation of the PGC-1α or of the mGluR5 in the developing astrocytes leads to a delayed morphogenesis of astrocytes and an impairment in the formation and function of neighbouring synapses, whereas genetic re-expression of PGC-1α in astrocytes restores mitochondrial functions and ameliorates both astroglial and neuronal defects. Together with the finding of the development-associated enhancement of mitochondrial function in astrocytes, our results uncover mitochondria activity as a novel mechanism controlling astrocyte morphogenesis and supporting synaptogenesis, thus identifying the mitochondrial function of the developing astrocytes as potential target to ameliorate the formation and function of synapses. Support contributed: Swiss National Foundation NCCR “Synapsy” (51NF40-158776) and “Transcure” (51NF6240-16) to PB, SNFS (26074366) to PB.
coauthors: Tamara Zehnder, Department of Fundamental Neurosciences, Faculty of Biology and Medicine, University of Lausanne, Rue du Bugnon 9, CH-1005 Lausanne, Switzerland; Francesco Petrelli, Tamara Zehnder1, 1. Department of Fundamental Neurosciences, Faculty of Biology and Medicine, University of Lausanne, Rue du Bugnon 9, CH-1005 Lausanne, Switzerland; Jennifer Romanos, Institute of Pharmacology and Toxicology, University of Zurich, CH-8057 Zurich, Switzerland; Eva C. De Oliveira Figueiredo, Department of Fundamental Neurosciences, Faculty of Biology and Medicine, University of Lausanne, Rue du Bugnon 9, CH-1005 Lausanne, Switzerland; Tommy L. Lewis, Aging & Metabolism Program, Oklahoma Medical Research Foundation, Oklahoma City, OK 73104, USA; Nicole Déglon, Department of Clinical Neurosciences, Laboratory of Neurotherapies and Neuromodulation (LNTM), Lausanne University Hospital (CHUV) and University of Lausanne, CH-1011 Lausanne, Switzerland; Neurosciences Research Center (CRN), Laboratory of Neurotherapies and Neuromodulation (LNTM), Lausanne University Hospital and University of Lausanne, CH-1011 Lausanne, Switzerland; Franck Polleux, Department of Neuroscience, Columbia University, New York, NY 10032, USA, Mortimer B. Zuckermand Mind Brain Behavior Institute, New York, NY 10032, USA; Mirko Santello, Institute of Pharmacology and Toxicology, University of Zurich, CH-8057 Zurich, Switzerland; Paola Bezzi, Department of Fundamental Neurosciences, Faculty of Biology and Medicine, University of Lausanne, Rue du Bugnon 9, CH-1005 Lausanne, Switzerland
theme: Theme B: Neural Excitability, Synapses, and Glia

title: Gaze Behavior changes following motor learning in a gait training task
abstract: Vision plays a vital role in motor task execution and motor planning. During walking, where an individual looks and the distribution of their fixation locations provides insight into the preferred motor control strategies. Fixation distributions are well characterized in healthy adults and show consistent differences among individuals with gait deficits (who emphasize fixations involved in motor execution) and elite athletes (who emphasize fixations involved in motor planning). However, how individuals change their gaze distribution and the relationship to motor performance, is not understood. The present study examines how healthy young adults shift their gaze behavior during a locomotor learning task. Participants completed a treadmill-based sequence stepping task where they had to continuously step onto projected targets. The targets appeared in a repeating 6-step sequence of different step lengths which participants implicitly learned over multiple trial blocks. We hypothesized that participants would shift their gaze location forward (e.g. 2-3 steps ahead), emphasizing motor planning, as they learned the sequence. Our results did not support this hypothesis. With practice participants did learn the 6 step sequence and reduce their step error, however their gaze shifted closer to their feet, with participants spending more time fixating on the current target and immediate step path. This finding suggests that participants emphasized motor execution over motor planning while learning the task. Possible explanations for this result include a change in confidence, as awareness of their step errors may change step performance, or a change in information value, such that by learning the sequence, participants did not need visual information to plan their steps and could focus on optimizing stepping execution. Future studies should expand on these results with more complex stepping sequences, by artificially challenging participants’ confidence, and by disrupting visual informational value to see if gaze can be shifted in the opposite direction.
coauthors: Keith Gordon, Northwestern University
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: What is the potential of decoding?: A time course comparison between ERP and machine learning classification analyses
abstract: Neural decoding is a popular method in cognitive research.
