With decoding, neural data from individual trials or batches are categorized by a statistical classifier (e.g. support vector machines, SVM, or deep neural networks). However, neural decoding analyses stand in contrast to traditional event related potential (ERP) analyses, which average EEG data across same-condition trials to enhance voltage signals related to a particular experimental manipulation. This study set out to assess the differences in the timecourse of voltage signals obtained via task-based ERP versus the  information gain obtained via item-based neural decoding analyses. To do so, participants completed two target identification tasks (targets could be a face or body) under different visual presentations (Single vs RSVP presentation), which have previously been shown to elicit latency differences in target-related ERP components like the P3 (Craston, Wyble & Bowman, 2006). Recorded data was analyzed using conventional ERP techniques as well as machine learning classification techniques (in this case, a linear SVM trained to classify face from body trials within presentation format). The two analyses provided different conclusions about the influences of presentation format on cognitive processes, with ERP replicating the previously observed differences in P3 amplitudes and latencies whereas machine learning  demonstrated no substantial differences in classification accuracy or latency between formats. Overall, these results highlight the importance of comparing ERP and decoding analysis techniques in EEG. If decoding is driven by the voltage signals present in ERPs, one might have assumed that differences in ERP latencies would be reflected in the temporal profile of classification. However, this was not true.  The failure to find a clear correspondence between condition differences in the timecourse of  ERPs and decoding profiles suggests that classifiers are finding statistical regularities in target-related scalp voltages that are not scaling with traditional task-based ERPs measures.
coauthors: Brad Wyble, Pennsylvania State University
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Using Functional Connectivity to Predict Working Memory Performance in the Human Connectome Project
abstract:
Introduction: A central goal of neuroscience is predicting behavior based on features of the brain. Resting state functional connectivity (rsFC) and task evoked functional connectivity are both commonly utilized measures of in vivo brain function. Utilizing data from the HCP, our project sought to explore their potential as a predictor for various other aspects of neural function and behavior. We attempted to predict working memory task performance based on patterns of task evoked activity and rsFC. We theorized that task based activity would be more predictive than rsFC.

Methods: In a subset (n = 338) of the Human Connectome Project, we used the Glasser parcellation to establish functional connectivity patterns during resting state as features to model. As the first preprocessing step, we generated a functional connectivity matrix for all parcels across all participants. Separate matrices were created for each task and resting state separately. We then utilized connectome parametric mapping (CPM, Shen et al, 2017) to model the prediction of working memory performance.

Results: Resting-state was found as a better predictor (R2= 13%) of behavioral performance respect to task-evoked working memory (R2= 0.5%) activity. However, the overall predictive power of either model was not high. Nodes belonging to the default mode and frontal parietal network were found to better predict working memory performance. 

Discussion: Interestingly, resting state was a better predictor of WM performance than the WM task activity, but overall performance was not high. Nodes belonging to the frontal-parietal network were more engaged in the working memory task than nodes in the default mode network. The narrow differences between task evoked and rsFC may partially explain the difference in model performance. Another potential contributing factor is the comparatively smaller amount of task-evoked activity to the rsFC. These factors have considerations for building predictive models using fMRI data.
coauthors: Corey Richier, University of Illinois at Urbana Champaign; Nora Bradford, University of California, Irvine; Ladan Shahshahani, University of Western Ontairo; Davide Momi, University "G. d'Annunzio" of Chieti
institution: University of Illinois at Urbana Champaign (grid.35403.31)
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Neural, cogntive and cultural foundations of navigaiton ability
abstract: Some people are very good at navigating, others find it a significant challenge. What determines whether someone will succeed or fail to navigate successfully? This talk will briefly explore what might make someone a good navigator looking at demographics, cultural background and brain structure and function. Data from the mobile app video game Sea Hero Quest project will be presented revealing world-wide patterns in navigation ability of 3.9 million people and the potential for tracking subtle cognitive markers for Alzheimer’s disease.
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Parallel pathways of odor processing in the lateral entorhinal cortex
abstract: Layer II principal cells in lateral entorhinal cortex (LEC) receive olfactory sensory input from the olfactory bulb and piriform cortex and relay this information to the hippocampus. Distinct types of layer II cells direct information via two parallel pathways: fan cells send direct projections to the dentate gyrus and pyramidal cells project to CA1. However, little is known about the role of the LEC in the processing of odor information. Here we use acute optogenetic silencing in head-fixed mice performing two-alternative-forced-choice (2AFC) tasks to show that the LEC is necessary for rapid (<300 ms of odor inhalation) discrimination of odor identity and intensity. Consistent with these rapid behavioral responses, simultaneous silicon probe recordings in the awake state from the LEC and hippocampus reveal that virtually all olfactory-evoked activity occurs in a brief time window coupled to odor inhalation. Using brain slice recordings, we show that direct input from the olfactory bulb preferentially targets LEC fan cells, whereas input from the piriform cortex equally targets fan and pyramidal cells. This results in faster onset of odor evoked activity and more selective responses in fan cells, as well as better odor discrimination at the population level.
coauthors: Sebastian H. Bitzenhofer, Center for Neural Circuits and Behavior, Department of Neuroscience, School of Medicine, University of California, San Diego, La Jolla, California, USA; Jeffry S. Isaacson, Center for Neural Circuits and Behavior, Department of Neuroscience, School of Medicine, University of California, San Diego, La Jolla, California, USA
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Age-related double dissociation of fast and slow theta oscillations in children and adolescents
abstract:
Neuronal oscillations are ubiquitous and associated with processes ranging from physiological to cognitive to pathological. These periodic rhythms change considerably during development, making understanding their development fundamental to understanding brain development. However, typical scalp EEG does not access medial brain areas directly and offers low spatial resolution of the lateral areas it does access. Noninvasive EEG therefore offers a limited window into brain development and, as we consider here, the development of cognitive processes such as declarative memory which rely on the medial temporal lobe (MTL) and its connections to specific lateral prefrontal (PFC) areas. To circumvent this issue, we capitalized on a unique opportunity to record EEG directly from the brains of pediatric neurosurgical patients undergoing invasive clinical monitoring for seizure management. 

In this study, 21 children and adolescents (5.9-20.5 years) undergoing direct cortical monitoring (i.e., ECoG) attended to visual scenes in preparation for a memory recognition test. We isolated ECoG signals from 80 channels in MTL and 357 channels in PFC. We focused on theta rhythms, which are defined by a frequency of 3-8 Hz and consistently linked to memory processes in the MTL of adults as well as animal models. After disentangling oscillatory components from aperiodic 1/f activity, we detected at faster rhythm ~7 Hz which sped up with age and a slower rhythm ~3 Hz which slowed down with age. These results reveal that: (1) recent findings of fast and slow theta rhythms in the adult MTL extend to children; (2) both rhythms are also evident in PFC; and (3) development is associated with the functional differentiation of theta oscillations. Further analyses show that both theta oscillations support MTL-PFC functional connectivity patterns predictive of subsequent memory formation, suggesting that the functional differentiation of theta oscillations relates to the development of declarative memory.
coauthors: Qin Yin, Wayne State University; Lingfei Tang, Wayne State University; Eishi Asano, Wayne State University; Noa Ofen, Wayne State University
theme: Theme A: Development, Neurodegenerative Disorders and Injury

title: Distinct synaptic plasticity timescales enable engram (de-)maturation in systems consolidation
abstract: In a contextual fear conditioning experiment, prefrontal cortex engram cells are formed in a silent state but undergo a process of maturation as a result of systems consolidation. In contrast, hippocampal engram cells are initially generated in a mature state and later withstand de-maturation. It has been proposed that these engram dynamics are not restricted to fear memories but instead are characteristic of episodic memory engrams. However, the exact mechanisms underlying engram (de-)maturation have not been investigated yet. Here, we present a spiking network model of systems consolidation that exhibits both maturation of cortical and de-maturation of hippocampal engram cells. Our model contains individual subnetworks for the thalamus, cortex, and hippocampus with excitatory and inhibitory synapses within and between these regions being subject to plasticity mechanisms at different rates. In this model, cortical engram cells are initially silent in recent recall but mature and become active in remote recall after a consolidation period. Inversely, hippocampal engrams are active in recent but not in remote recall and, hence, de-mature. Hippocampal engram cells as well as spontaneous synchronized reactivations in the three brain regions in our model were crucial for systems consolidation of memories. Importantly, the above engram dynamics and interdependencies displayed by our model are aligned with previous experimental findings. Our model also makes the following experimentally testable predictions: engram cells in mediodorsal thalamus (MD) are active in recent and remote recall and are essential for the maturation of prefrontal cortex (PFC) engram cells, PFC inhibitory engram cells become selective to stimuli with systems consolidation, and the coupling between MD and PFC prior to consolidation is predictive of the retrograde amnesia curve induced by hippocampal damage. Overall, our modelling results suggest that a variety of synaptic plasticity mechanisms operating over distinct timescales across brain regions is coordinated to promote systems consolidation.
coauthors: Sadra Sadeh, Imperial College London; Claudia Clopath, Imperial College London
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Role of Electrode Preparation on Static Impedance in Electroconvulsive Therapy
abstract: Electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) has long been recognized as an effective treatment for neurological disorders; chief among them is major depressive disorder. The preparation of skin and electrodes for ECT is an important procedure, but there is significant variability in electrode preparation protocols used and questions about which steps are important. Static impedance, measured by the ECT device prior to administration of ECT, is used to indicate the quality of electrode setup. The current pilot study examined the contributions of skin preparation on static impedance in healthy subjects. Using adhesive ECT electrodes, six electrode placements procedures were considered: saline skin preparation with conducting gel PRE TAC, 70% isopropyl alcohol skin preparation, saline skin preparation with PRE TAC and 50% electrode contact area, 70% isopropyl alcohol skin preparation with PRE TAC, saline skin preparation with 1% PVP-K90 application, saline skin preparation with 1% PVP-K90 application plus KCL. Electrodes were placed in the bifrontal position on the forehead. Static impedance was measured every minute using two commercial ECT machines for 17 minutes, or until impedance stabilized. All preparations containing an adhesive, namely PRE TAC and the PVP-K90 solutions, had improved adhesion of electrode onto skin, resulting in lower static impedance. The absence of adhesive (alcohol skin preparation only) drove up static impedance. These results suggest that even under apparent full electrode coverage the quality of electrode-skin contact impacts static impedance. Intentionally reducing contact area of electrode to skin by ~50% increased impedance by a factor of ~2x. The results also demonstrate significant difference among individuals, even under our tightly controlled experimental conditions with optimal preparation, indicating that head impedance contributes to impedance measurements. Improving adhesion of the electrode to skin reduces impedance despite this variability.
coauthors: Gozde Unal, Department of Biomedical Engineering, The City College of New York, CUNY, New York, NY; Mohamad Fallah Rad,Department of Biomedical Engineering, The City College of New York, CUNY, New York, NY; Marom Bikson, Department of Biomedical Engineering, The City College of New York, CUNY, New York, NY
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Hyperscanning: A Valid Method to Study Neural Inter-brain Underpinnings of Social Interaction
abstract: Social interactions are a crucial part of human life. Understanding the neural underpinnings of social interactions is a challenging task that the hyperscanning method has been trying to tackle over the last two decades. Here, we review the existing literature and evaluate the current state of the hyperscanning method. We review the type of methods (fMRI, M/EEG, and fNIRS) that are used to measure brain activity from more than one participant simultaneously and weigh their pros and cons for hyperscanning. Further, we discuss different types of analyses that are used to estimate brain networks and synchronization. Lastly, we present results of hyperscanning studies in the context of different cognitive functions and their relations to social interactions. All in all, we aim to comprehensively present methods, analyses, and results from the last 20 years of hyperscanning research.
coauthors: Sara Eustergerling, Institute of Cognitive Science, Universität Osnabrück, Osnabrück, Germany; Anne Lang, Institute of Cognitive Science, Universität Osnabrück, Osnabrück, Germany; David Menrath, Institute of Cognitive Science, Universität Osnabrück, Osnabrück, Germany; Michael Gerstenberger, Institute of Cognitive Science, Universität Osnabrück, Osnabrück, Germany; Susanne Schuberth, Institute of Cognitive Science, Universität Osnabrück, Osnabrück, Germany; Felix Schreiber, Institute of Cognitive Science, Universität Osnabrück, Osnabrück, Germany; Zadkiel Zuluaga Rendon, Institute of Cognitive Science, Universität Osnabrück, Osnabrück, Germany; Peter König, Institute of Cognitive Science, Universität Osnabrück, Osnabrück, Germany, Institut für Neurophysiologie und Pathophysiologie, Universitätsklinikum Hamburg-Eppendorf, Hamburg, Germany;
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Top-down and bottom-up information flow in visually responsive neural populations: a Granger causality analysis on high-frequency broadband amplitude from intracranial electrodes.
abstract: How does information flow among visually-responsive neural populations along the visual cortex hierarchy? We address this question by estimating transfer entropy from state-space Granger causality modeling on intracranial EEG (iEEG) data. In an exploratory analysis, we conduct pairwise and groupwise conditional Granger causality on a high-frequency broadband envelope of iEEG signals recorded from 10 epileptic patients. The high-frequency broadband envelope has been shown to be highly correlated with local neural population firing rates, and so is a relevant biomarker of local neural activity. We model information flow between visually responsive populations in three distincts conditions: a resting state condition, a place stimulus presentation and a face stimulus presentation. In each of these conditions we examine the magnitudes of top-down and bottom-up information flow between visually responsive neural populations in both higher and lower areas of the occipito-temporal cortical hierarchy. Signals are treated as multivariate, multiple-trial time series, for which we show that state space modeling yields stable models from which Granger causality can be inferred - a difficult challenge given the non-stationarity of the signals involved. From these state-space models, we first infer groupwise conditional Granger causality between visually responsive functional groups of channels, to model information flow between functional regions along the occipito-temporal hierarchy. We then run a pairwise-conditional Granger causality analysis between individual visually responsive channels in these groups, to further explore modes of information transfer in local neural populations between and within visually responsive sites. The aim of this exploratory study is to motivate hypotheses about distinct modes of top-down and bottom-up information flow between face and non-face selective regions of the visual cortex.
coauthors: Guillaume Corlouer, Sackler center for consciousness science and Department of Informatics, University of Sussex,  Falmer,Brighton, BN1 9QJ, UK; Yitzhak Norman, Department of Neurobiology, Weizmann Institute of Science, 76100, Rehovot, Israel;   Rafael Malach; Department of Neurobiology, Weizmann Institute of Science, 76100, Rehovot, Israel, CIFAR Program on Brain, Mind, and Consciousness, Toronto, Ontario, Canada; Lionel Barnett, Sackler center for consciousness science and Department of Informatics, University of Sussex,  Falmer,Brighton, BN1 9QJ, UK; Anil Seth, Sackler center for consciousness science and Department of Informatics, University of Sussex,  Falmer,Brighton, BN1 9QJ, UK, CIFAR Program on Brain, Mind, and Consciousness, Toronto, Ontario, Canada; Ashesh D. Mehta, Department of Neurosurgery, Donald and Barbara Zucker School of Medicine at Hofstra/Northwell, and Feinstein Institute for Medical Research, Manhasset, NY, 11030, USA
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Ultra-sparse spike sequences for automatic recognition of auditory objects
abstract:
In the last few years, Deep Learning has tremendously improved the performance of automatic speech recognition (ASR) systems. It has also been applied to related tasks, such as birdsong syllable recognition [2]. However, this success comes at the expense of large amounts of training data and computational power. When data is scarce, the performance tends to decrease rapidly. This hinders applications where high accuracy is required from a limited amount of labeled exemplars.

Here we explore a radically different approach to the task of auditory object recognition from continuous sound streams. Our approach is inspired by how the auditory system represents auditory objects. Namely, that neurons in high auditory areas fire sparsely and in patterns that correlate with specific auditory objects. In addition, these patterns are also seen to be robust against noise.

We train feature-detecting neurons that respond to acoustic structures within short-time windows of about 50 ms. Together, these neurons transform the sound input into a continuous stream of spikes. This spike representation is ultra-sparse and precisely timed. Auditory objects consisting of well defined spectrotemporal structures are then stored as templates of spike sequences. During testing, a template matching algorithm performs the search, discovery and classification of spike sequences in the continuous sound input.

Our contribution is two-fold. First, we demonstrate our approach in the task of segmenting and classifying Bengalese finch syllables from continuous birdsong recordings. We show that our system generalizes well even when only a few syllables are available for training. Second, we make available to the community a new open-source software for audio data annotation, which we call BASS. Our software is designed to allow users to quickly mark, compare and classify segments extracted from spectrograms. We find it particularly useful for manually annotating large sets of birdsong data.

[1] Tavares and Jin. Ultra-sparse spike sequences for automatic recognition of auditory objects. In preparation.
[2] Y. Cohen et. al. 2020. TweetyNet: A neural network that enables high-throughput, automated annotation of birdsong. bioRxiv doi: https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.08.28.272088
coauthors: Dezhe Jin, Pennsylvania State University
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Recording from the same cortical neurons over months with Neuropixels probes
abstract: For many studies, especially those focusing on learning and plasticity, it is important to track the activity of neurons over prolonged periods. Prolonged recordings can be achieved with two-photon imaging, but this method is difficult in deep brain structures and has limited temporal resolution. Here we asked whether neurons could be reliably tracked across recordings with Neuropixels probes, which allow access not only to the cortex but also to deep brain structures and can resolve individual spikes. We implanted mice with novel Neuropixels 2.0 probes that can have one shank or four shanks, and have more tightly spaced recording sites compared to commercially available Neuropixel 1.0 probes. We implanted the probes vertically through primary visual cortex and cemented them to the cranium. For recordings, mice were head-fixed in front of computer screens. Recordings were performed at regular intervals. Recordings yielded many neurons across >6 months, but there was substantial drift across sessions. To compensate for it, we used a modified version of Kilosort2 algorithm. To characterize the neurons, during each recording we presented a library of natural images. Many V1 neurons responded to these images and showed a pattern of preferences that constituted a unique signature. Using this signature we followed the activity of these neurons over the course of days, weeks and months. The ability to follow large populations of individual neurons over extended periods opens new possibilities in the study of learning and plasticity.
coauthors: Nicholas Steinmetz, University of Washington; Marius Pachitariu, Janelia Research Campus; Jai Bhagat, UCL; Kenneth Harris, UCL; Matteo Carandini, UCL; Michael Okun, University of Leicester
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Regulation of neuronal propagation delays in health and disease by node of Ranvier morphology, receptors and ion channels
theme: Theme B: Neural Excitability, Synapses, and Glia

title: Dopamine and excessive behaviours: impulse control disorders in Parkinson disease
abstract: Dopamine mediates a wide range of reward processes and when dysfunctional, excessive behaviours may be encountered. Under dopaminergic treatments, Parkinson´s disease (PD) patients may develop impulse control disorders (ICDs) resulting in excessive behaviours towards appetitive items, hence representing an optimal human model to study addiction. The wide spectrum of excessive approach tendencies towards appetitive options include primary and secondary rewards such as binge eating, hypersexuality, pathological gambling or compulsive shopping. In addition, the neurocognitive profile of ICD is marked by preference of immediate gratification and lack of adaptation to negative outcomes paralleled by enhanced signalling of the mesocortical valuation system. To date, the precise behavioural and neural changes involved in ICD are unclear. More precisely, is unclear whether ICD is a deficit of impulsive choice or impulsive actions that cannot override excessive desire of appetitive items. Here, evidence will be presented to put forward the field on one specific ICD (i.e. hypersexuality) in choice behaviour and action impulsivity (using fMRI and computational modelling). Ultimately, preliminary findings may support a transfer towards clinical consequences that will impact ICD with neuromodulation techniques. Our findings give rise to a new neurocognitive and imaging profile on one ICD subtype to open new research avenues and bridge our findings into clinical contexts.
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Wandering minds, sleepy brains: lapses of attention and local sleep in wakefulness.
abstract: Attentional lapses are ubiquitous and can negatively impact performance. They correlate with mind wandering, or thoughts that are unrelated to ongoing tasks and environmental demands. In other cases, the stream of consciousness itself comes to a halt and the mind goes blank. What happens in the brain that leads to these mental states? To understand the neural mechanisms underlying attentional lapses, we cross-analyzed the behavior, subjective experience and neural activity of healthy participants performing a task. Random interruptions prompted participants to indicate whether they were task-focused, mind-wandering or mind-blanking. High-density electroencephalography revealed the occurrence of spatially and temporally localized sleep-like patterns of neural activity. This “local sleep” accompanied behavioral markers of lapses and preceded reports of mind wandering and mind blanking. Furthermore, the location of local sleep distinguished sluggish versus impulsive behaviors, mind wandering versus mind blanking. Despite contrasting cognitive profiles, attentional lapses could share a common physiological origin: the appearance of local islets of sleep within the awake brain.
coauthors: Angus Burns, Monash University; Teigane MacKay, Monash University; Jennifer Windt, Monash University; Naotsugu Tsuchiya, Monash University
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Insights from single cell sequencing of Drosophila circadian neurons
abstract:
See https://www.nobelprize.org/prizes/medicine/2017/rosbash/facts/

In our cells an internal clock helps us to adapt our biological rhythm to the different phases of day and night. Jeffrey Hall, Michael Rosbash and Michael Young studied fruit flies to figure out how this clock works. In 1984 they managed to identify a gene that encodes a protein that accumulates during the night but is degraded during the day. They also identified additional proteins that form part of a self-regulating biological clockwork in the fruit fly's cells. The same principles have been shown to apply to other animals and plants.
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Cell-type specific nonlinearities in frontal-sensory integration in the parietal cortex
abstract: Top-down influences, including memory and attention, strongly affect sensory processing. Yet, synaptic interaction of cognitive and sensory information streams remains largely undescribed. Non-linear interactions have been frequently observed during multisensory processing, however, technical challenges so far prohibited the mechanistic exploration of how top-down and bottom-up afferents interact. Here, we employ a dual-color optogenetic strategy to determine the spatiotemporal features of multi-modal synaptic integration in the mouse posterior parietal cortex (PPC). We expressed a red light sensitive channelrhodopsin variant in the primary auditory cortex (A1) and a blue light sensitive opsin in the anterior cingulate cortex (ACC), a frontal region commonly associated with attention and working memory. This opsin combination allowed independent control of sensory and frontal inputs to the PPC. Using whole-cell patch clamp recordings in acute brain slices we show that the PPC receives direct, monosynaptic inputs from both A1 and ACC. Similarly to other cortical areas, layer 5 principal cells in the PPC show heterogeneity in their firing patterns. We found that two classes of pyramidal neurons, intrinsically bursting and regular spiking, have distinct patterns of frontal-sensory integration. Intrinsically bursting cells displayed a supralinear enhancement of coincident input from ACC and A1, an effect that diminished with increasing delays between inputs. Conversely, regular spiking cells showed maximal enhancement when afferents were activated with delay, and robust suppression of coincident inputs. Intriguingly, we also found that co-activating frontal and sensory inputs significantly enhanced sustained activity in the PPC microcircuit, indicating a potential role in working memory processes. Our data suggest that frontal-sensory integration has cell-type specificity in the PPC, and begins to unravel the circuit architecture of multi-modal integration.
coauthors: Daniel Y. Rindner, UC Irvine
theme: Theme B: Neural Excitability, Synapses, and Glia

title: Prolactin-induced changes in the primary auditory cortex plasticity
abstract:
During pregnancy and lactation there are multiple adaptive changes in the mother’s brain that
are essential for the survival of the progeny. Clinical and experimental evidences indicate that
prolactin (PRL), present during lactation, can contribute to the development of these adaptive
modifications. While the importance of the endocrine system on the activity of neuronal
network in critical stages of life is well stablished, the role of PRL on the remodeling of the
auditory cortex (AC) in response to sound stimuli emitted by the pups during lactation is still
unknown. Therefore, the aim of this project is to study the modifications on neural activity of
the AC in a model of hyperprolactinemia. To reach this objective, we used electrophysiological
techniques with chronic electrode implants in the primary auditory cortex (A1) in order to record
auditory evoked potentials (AEPs). The recordings were conducted in awake animals treated
with domperidone (as the model of hyperprolactinemia) and in control animals treated with a
vehicle. For the auditory stimuli we used recordings of pup’s vocalizations during lactation
(wriggling calls), as well as trials of pure tones at different frequencies. Our data suggest that an
increase in serum levels of PRL modifies the AEPs registered in A1. Specifically, there is a loss of
the fundamental frequencies within 0.1-20 Hz band of the AEPs following stimulations with
pups’ vocalizations. This result suggests that PRL induces changes in mother’s auditory pathway
that may be relevant to the survival of the offspring.
coauthors: Julio Esparza, Instituto Cajal; Eduardo Martin, Instituto Cajal
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Characterizing the adaptation of motor output and sensory input in locomotion
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Cerebellar molecular layer interneurons play a role in go-no go split second decision making
institution: University of Colorado Anschutz Medical Campus
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Motifs for Processes on Networks
abstract: The study of motifs in networks can help researchers uncover links between structure and function of networks in biology, ecology, neuroscience, and many other fields. To connect the study of motifs in networks (which is common, e.g., in biology and the social sciences) with the study of motifs in dynamical processes (which is common in neuroscience), we propose to distinguish between ``structure motifs'' (i.e., graphlets) in networks and ``process motifs'' (i.e., structured sets of walks) on networks. Using as examples the covariances and correlations in a multivariate Ornstein--Uhlenbeck process on a network, we demonstrate that the distinction between structure motifs and process motifs makes it possible to gain new, quantitative insights into mechanisms by which dynamics on networks contribute to functional connectivity.
coauthors: Mason Porter, University of California Los Angeles
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Multi-animal pose estimation with DeepLabCut
abstract: Many experiments in biology require measuring interactions between multiple individuals. Nonetheless, whereas deep learning powered pose estimation recently showed remarkable performance on single animal, the solution to the multi-animal problem is far from trivial. Detected body parts must first be connected and associated with animals, which is a costly combinatorial task. Animals’ motion must then be tracked frame by frame, and the resulting trajectories stitched together to ensure dynamic feasibility and disambiguate overlaps and identity switches. Here we introduce DeepLabCut 2.2, a framework built onto the open-source pose estimation toolbox DeepLabCut to address the multi-animal scenario. We discuss our implementation of bottom-up animal assembly and robust motion trackers, as well as our novel solution to tracklet stitching and identity prediction directly from an image. We will demonstrate its utility on a collection of behaviors (from fish to mice). Taken together, DeepLabCut 2.2 thus provides users with an efficient solution to the multi-animal problem that is seamlessly integrated into the existing workflow and user interface, and requires just as little (if any) programming experience.
coauthors: Alexander Mathis, Swiss Federal Institute of Technology; Mackenzie Mathis, Swiss Federal Institute of Technology
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Horizontal connections for enhancing machine visual grouping
abstract: Evidence from biological vision supports the hypothesis that horizontal interactions in the early visual cortex facilitate low-level grouping. We explore whether such recurrent nonlinear horizontal connections enhance the grouping abilities of deep convolutional networks (DCNs) optimized to solve contour integration problems. We introduce V1Net -- a bio-inspired recurrent unit implementing linear and nonlinear excitatory-inhibitory (E-I) lateral connections; spatial convolutional layers in DCNs can be substituted with V1Net to create a V1Net-DCN. We compare the performance of a shallow V1Net-DCN against 15 carefully selected feedforward and recurrent neural architectures (including state-of-the-art DCNs) on the MarkedLong and Pathfinder challenges -- two synthetic image classification tasks based on low-level grouping with 1 million images each. Our results demonstrate that a compact 3-layer V1Net-DCN matches or outperforms the test accuracy and sample efficiency of all comparison models with varied capacity and architectural diversity. Our experiments are suggestive of the importance of implementing recurrent long-range E-I horizontal connections to enhance the low-level grouping abilities of feedforward deep learning models. Our ablation studies highlight interesting differences in the relative importance of linear and nonlinear horizontal connections. In the future, we are interested in exploring whether this enhanced grouping utility of V1Net translates to more data efficient image segmentation methods.
coauthors: Virginia R. de Sa, University of California San Diego
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: A Unilateral Cortical Resection of Both Visual Pathways Alters Action but not Perception
abstract: Cortical resection, a treatment for humans with pharmaco-resistant epilepsy, provides a unique opportunity to advance our understanding of the nature and extent of cortical (re)organization. Previous studies have found that pediatric patients with resections of the ventral visual pathway still retain normal visuoperceptual abilities. It is not clear whether visuomotor computations, carried out by the dorsal pathway, follow a similar behavioral pattern. To address this outstanding issue, we examined visuomotor and visuoperceptual behaviors in a pediatric patient TC, who has a cortical resection that includes portions of the left ventral and dorsal pathways.  TC used her right and left hands to estimate perceptually the width of blocks that varied in width and length (but not in overall size), and, in a separate condition, to grasp the same objects across their width. Consistent with previous studies, TC’s perceptual performance was comparable to that of controls.  In contrast, TC was markedly impaired in her visuomotor sensitivity to object shape but only when she grasped the objects with her contralesional right (and not ipsilesional left) hand. These results provide novel evidence for a striking difference in the reorganization profiles of the two visual pathways. This difference might be attributed to a greater degree of hemispheric specialization of the dorsal pathway, or, alternatively, to differential maturation rates of the two pathways, such that the dorsal pathway maturation precedes that of the ventral pathway.
coauthors: Zoha Ahmad, York University; Marlene Behrmann, Carnegie Mellon University; Christina Patterson, University of Pittsburgh; Erez Freud, York University
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: A reach trajectory can be learnt using binary reward feedback
abstract: Binary reward feedback on movement success is sufficient for learning some simple sensorimotor mappings in a reaching task, but not for some tasks in which multiple kinematic factors contribute to performance. The critical condition for learning in more complex tasks remains unclear. Here, we investigate whether reward-based motor learning is possible in a multi-dimensional trajectory matching task and whether simplifying the task by providing feedback on one factor at a time (‘factorized feedback’) can improve learning. In two experiments, participants performed a trajectory matching task in which learning was measured as a reduction in the error. In Experiment 1, participants matched a straight trajectory slanted in depth. We factorized the task by providing feedback on the slant error, the length error, or on their composite. In Experiment 2, participants matched a curved trajectory, also slanted in depth. In this experiment, we factorized the feedback by providing feedback on the slant error, the curvature error, or on the integral difference between the matched and target trajectory. In both experiments, participants learnt the multidimensional task: they reduced errors in the matched trajectory. There was no evidence that the factorization of feedback improved learning. We conclude that multiple kinematic factors can be learnt in parallel.
coauthors: van Mastrigt, N.M.; Smeets, J.B.J.
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Chronic Recording from Multiple Hippocampal Sub-Regions in Free Moving Rats with a Flexible Parylene-Based Multi-Electrodes Array
abstract: Hippocampus is a subcortical brain structure that is essential for the formation of long-term memories. Obtaining stable, chronic recording of unitary activities from multiple sub-regions of the hippocampus in behaving animals is crucial for studying the biological basis of memoryformation and is also the foundation for developinghippocampal memory prosthesis. However, severe immune response caused by micro-motion between stiff implants and brain tissue often limits the lifetime of penetrating neural probes. To reduce the stiffness mismatch between recording devices and brain tissue, we developed and tested a flexible, Parylene-based multi-electrode array for recording from multiple sub-regions of the rat hippocampus and used this array to collect chronic neural activities from free moving rats. The 64 channels, Parylene multi-electrode array has eight shanks arranged in series with 250μmspacing. On each shank, eight recording electrodes were divided into two groups targeting at the CA3 and the CA1 sub-regions, respectively. The layout of recording sites is specially designed to conformto the curvature of the hippocampal cell body layers.Stereotactic surgery is conducted to chronically implant the flexible array. A dissolvable brace that temporarily reduces effective probe length is used to insert the bare array without buckling.Signals were monitored during the insertion and after recovery, while the animal is exploring freely in an open field. Eleven animals were implanted with the Parylene array. 70 out of 78(90%) implanted functional shanks recorded from at least one sub-region and 50% shanks recorded spike activities from both the CA1 and the CA3 sub-regionsduring the implantation. Insevenanimals, neural activities were monitored immediately post-implantation and on average 70.1±15.8 (23.9±14.2 CA1 and 46.3±13.0 CA3) units were identified from individual animals. After recovery, 90 units (11.3±3.1 per animal) with SNR greater than threewere recorded from eight animals over durationsranging fromthree weeks to eleven months. One Parylene array has recorded stable unitary activities for over 11 months.
coauthors: Ahuva Hirschberg, USC; Wenxuan Jiang, USC; Kee Scholten, USC; Xuechun Wang, USC; Ellis Meng, USC; Dong Song, USC
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Neural processing and perception of speech in children with mild to moderate sensorineural hearing loss
abstract:
Mild (21-40 dB HL) or moderate (41-70 dB HL) sensorineural hearing loss (HL) can lead to persistent changes to the cortical processing of speech sounds (Calcus et al., 2019). However, to date no studies have examined speech processing at the subcortical level in children with HL. Moreover, the effects of amplification on the neural encoding of speech remain poorly understood, with previous data suggesting a benefit at the subcortical but not the cortical level.
Here, I will present a study aiming to investigate (1) the subcortical and cortical processing of speech sounds in children with HL, and (2) the effects of amplification on the neural processing of speech, in children with HL. Subcortical and cortical EEG activity evoked by speech stimuli were simultaneously recorded in n = 18, 8- to 16-year old children with HL and n = 15 age-matched NH controls. The frequency-following-response (FFR) and MMN were used as indices of speech processing at the subcortical and cortical levels, respectively. For the HL group, stimuli were presented both unamplified (70 dB SPL), and with a frequency-specific gain (without compression) based on their individual audiograms. 
At the subcortical level, children with HL showed a smaller FFR than NH controls’ in the unamplified condition. With simulated amplification, the FFR of the HL group was comparable to that of NH controls. At the cortical level, there was no significant MMN in children with HL presented with either unamplified or amplified speech. 
The neural processing of unamplified speech may be impaired at both subcortical and cortical levels in children with HL. Moreover, amplification may benefit auditory processing at subcortical but not cortical levels in this group. I will offer two alternative explanations for our findings: increasing multi-sensory integration at successive levels of the auditory system, and/or later maturation of the auditory cortex compared to the inferior colliculus. The relationship with behavioural measures of language perception will be discussed.
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Control network for an insula-to-BNST stress coping circuit reveals a novel path for motor cortical control of affective circuitry
abstract: All life forms must respond to stress to adapt and survive. Active stress coping responses involve motor planning and execution, and physical activity is known to modulate affective behavior. The impact of physical activity on affective behavior has been proposed to rely on peripheral metabolic feedback. Here we identify an insular cortex to BNST (insula→BNST) neuronal circuit recruited during active stress coping that modulates affective behavior. We outline a functional control network for this synapse, which is heavily represented by motor cortical regions, demonstrating a pathway by which motor circuitry and primary motor signals can regulate emotional or affective behavior through a feedforward rather than feedback process.
coauthors: Joseph R. Luchsinger; Tracy L. Fetterly; Kellie M. Williford; Gregory J. Salimando; Jose Maldonado; Richard B. Simerly; Danny G. Winder; Samuel W. Centanni
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: A common error creates competition between parallel sensorimotor learning systems
abstract: During sensorimotor adaptation, the brain can rely on two separate learning systems: an intentional explicit system that responds to instructions, and an implicit system that is largely unconscious. However, it is unclear whether these putative systems learn independently from separate kinds of error, or compete to learn from the same error. Here, we mathematically express these two possibilities and consider their diverging predictions. When we test these predictions, we find that implicit and explicit systems share a common error; increases in explicit strategy siphon error away from the implicit system, thus impairing its learning. This negative interaction can mask changes in implicit learning such as savings and interference, that can be unveiled by suppressing explicit strategy. Together, the data suggest that in most cases, implicit and explicit systems are in competition to learn from a single error: task outcome. Cases that violate this rule suggest a second error source that also drives implicit adaptation, but leads to competition between two implicit learning modules. Altogether, the data show that patterns of implicit adaptation are shaped by competition between parallel learning systems.
coauthors: Jihoon Jang; Adrian Haith; Gonzalo Lerner; Valeria Della-Maggiore; John W. Krakauer; Reza Shadmehr
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: A connectomic substrate of credit assignment in basal ganglia reinforcement learning
abstract:
How is experience used to improve performance? In both biological and artificial systems, the optimization of parameters that affect the system’s behavior requires a credit assignment process that determines whether a parameter affects the outcome and then allows its modification.
Here we show, by combining high-throughput volume electron microscopy with flood-filling neural networks and automated synaptic connectivity inference, that the synaptic architecture of songbird basal ganglia supports a form of local credit assessment (related to node perturbation) proposed in a model of songbird reinforcement learning. Specifically, we demonstrate that the model’s major three predictions hold true: first, cortical feedback axons that encode exploratory motor variability terminate predominantly on dendritic shafts of spiny neurons. Second, cortical axons that encode timing terminate on dendritic spines, which enable calcium-based coincidence detection and appear to be capable of creating and storing eligibility traces. Third, synapse pairs that pre-synaptically share a cortical timing axon and post-synaptically a medium spiny dendrite are substantially more similar in size than expected, indicating a history of Hebbian plasticity. Consistent with the model, we then propose a novel role for cortical feedforward inhibition (FFI) in the striatum and test its anatomical predictions by directly identifying and analyzing triplet connectivity motifs in the connectome.
Finally, we performed numerical simulations of the proposed Hebbian 3-factor learning rule (context, action feedback and reward) and show that our model can learn to imitate a simple template in a realistic number of iterations. Combined with our connectomic data, this provides strong evidence for a model of vertebrate basal ganglia reinforcement learning with a biologically plausible credit assignment mechanism.
coauthors: J Kornfeld, MIT; M Januszewski, Google Research; P Schubert, MPI of Neurobiology; V Jain, Google Research; W Denk, MPI of Neurobiology; MS Fee, MIT
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Effects of Anti-Hebbian learning on the synchronization and structure of directed networks with pure and hybrid inhibitory and excitatory couplings
abstract: The interplay between structure and dynamics of the complex networks has been vigorously investigated in recent years. It has been shown that directed acyclic graphs are optimal structures for the synchronization of identical oscillators. However, feedback loops are required for noise-resistant synchronization of non-identical oscillators. On the other hand, the interaction structures of many real networks vary over time according to their dynamics. Here we employ a rewiring strategy based on an anti-Hebbian learning rule to modulate the structure of directed networks of Kuramoto oscillators. The results show that the anti-Hebbian learning rule leads to the global synchronization of the networks. Indeed, information flow is created from the nodes with average frequencies to the nodes with low or high frequencies in the emerged optimal structure, where the nodes with average frequencies are engaged only in the feed-forward loops, but the nodes with low and high frequencies are mostly joined together with the feedback loops. Similar results were also found in the Hybrid Excitatory-Inhibitory networks of oscillators. In the previous studies, the balance between neural excitation and inhibition has been shown to be crucial for brain computations. Here, we found that excitatory and inhibitory in-degrees of each oscillator are approximately balanced in the evolved network.
coauthors: Abolfazl Ziaeemehr, Institute for Advanced Studies in Basic Sciences; Mir Mohammad Ebrahimi, Institute for Advanced Studies in Basic Sciences; Mina Zarei, Institute for Advanced Studies in Basic Sciences
institution: Institute  of advanced studies in basic science
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: A Frame-Based Approach to Submovement Decomposition
abstract: Mounting evidence from human motor control suggests that discrete submovements underlie continuous human actions. This has motivated the development of algorithms to “extract” submovements from human experimental data. Fast decomposition algorithms, e.g. based on zero-crossings of progressively higher derivatives, result in spurious decompositions. Other algorithms, such as a scattershot algorithm (using stochastic Monte-Carlo methods) make fewer assumptions, but are not computationally efficient enough to handle the long data records common in continuous human actions (> 10 s). This work developed a modified stochastic algorithm to decompose long data profiles into discrete submovements. The modified algorithm broke long data profiles into uniform frames which were then decomposed using the scattershot algorithm and recombined.  To validate the frame-based algorithm, it was compared to the scattershot algorithm when long, synthetic data records were decomposed. We found that the frame-based approach achieved comparable performance to the scattershot algorithm while decreasing the run time to an approximately linear dependence on data length, compared to an exponential dependence for the scattershot algorithm. This new frame-based algorithm will make the decomposition of long data records with many submovements feasible in future human motor control experiments.
coauthors: James Hermus, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, Massachusetts; Neville Hogan, Department of Mechanical Engineering and Department of Brain and Cognitive Sciences, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, Massachusetts
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Activation and disruption of a neural mechanism  for novel choice in monkeys
abstract: The neural mechanisms mediating the ability to make value-guided decisions have received substantial attention in both humans and animal models. Experiments in animals typically involve long training periods. By contrast, real-world decisions often need to be made spontaneously between novel options. It is therefore possible that neural mechanisms targeted in animal studies differ from those required for novel decisions typically revealed in human imaging studies. Here we show that primate medial frontal cortex (MFC) has a causal role in novel inferential choices when options have not previously been experienced. Macaques spontaneously inferred values of new options via similarities with component parts of previously encountered options. Functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) suggested this ability was mediated by MFC, an area rarely investigated in monkeys; MFC activity reflected a different process of comparison for novel versus familiar options. A second fMRI experiment found that multidimensional option representations in MFC employed a grid-cell-like coding scheme, well known in the context of spatial navigation, to integrate dimensions in this non-physical space when making novel choices. By contrast, orbitofrontal cortex held specific object-based value representations. In a third experiment, minimally invasive ultrasonic disruption of MFC, but not adjacent tissue, altered estimation of novel choice values.
coauthors: Davide Folloni, University of Oxford; Lennart Verhagen, University of Oxford; Jérôme Sallet, University of Oxford; Miriam Klein-Flügge, University of Oxford; Matthew Rushworth, University of Oxford
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Cellular mechanisms for rapidly dynamic neural code in spatial navigation
abstract:
Navigation usually involves complex tasks that require neural representation of environments, with the flexibility to respond to rapidly dynamic behavioral or cognitive variables. For instance, in the hippocampus, a brain area important for navigation, relatively small changes in cues can quickly modulate the neural representation of space. Besides, animals also learn to form such neural maps incorporated with task-relevant information. Remarkably, these processes can happen as promptly as in no more than a few seconds.

Dynamic hippocampal coding likely supports a hallmark complexity of spatial cognition, but the cellular mechanisms are poorly understood. In this talk, I will discuss our recent findings that the rapid and flexible formation and adaptation of place-dependent neural firing could be mediated by nonlinear subcellular integration or via synaptic plasticity, through experiments applying whole-cell patch-clamp recording to CA1 pyramidal neurons in acute hippocampal slices and in awake, behaving mice, as well as computational modeling. These results suggest a cellular and biophysical basis for neural computations fundamental to flexible and adaptive behavior.
coauthors: Xinyu Zhao, Janelia Research Campus; Aaron Milstein, Neurosurgery Department, Stanford University School of Medicine; Nelson Spruston, Janelia Research Campus
theme: Theme B: Neural Excitability, Synapses, and Glia

title: Contrast between biological and artificial neural network
abstract:
This talk will be about the differences between ANNs and BNNs. Artificial Neural Network (ANN) is a computing system whose fundamental composition is analogous to biological neural networks. Where a node acts as soma, input acts as dendrites, weights or Interconnections acts as the synapse and the output acts as axon.Despite ANNs being a manifestation of the BNNs there exist a lot of differences.
The primary difference between ANNs and BNNs is different topologies: Instead of a network with asynchronous computing nodes, the ANNs compute one by one. Recurrent feedbacks are simulated in Long short-term memory (LSTM) networks and Recurrent neural networks but general neural networks compute the state & weights of a layer of the neural network then use the result to compute the next layer while in backpropagation the weights are improvised.  Layers aren’t connected to non-neighbouring layers .IN BNNs the neurons can fire asynchronously parallelly, having dense neurons hubs and a large amount of lesser connected ones, partially following the power law (for the large values of k, the fraction P(k) of nodes in the network having k connections to other nodes as P(k) ~ k -z  where z generally lies from 2 to 3, although may lie outside these bounds ). Due to their topology the BNNs are better at fault and ambiguity tolerant as there is no central part, they can heal and are self-regenerated to some extent.The size of ANNs and BNNs also vary,there are 10 11 neurons in the brain whereas computational considerations limited ANNs nowadays to 10 5 neurons. As far as the energy consumption is concerned the human brain has nearly 20 watts of power consumption whereas a GPU (graphics processing unit) used for training artificial neural networks consumes somewhere from 150 to 250 watts, Human brain is highly efficient in comparison to the GPUs.Different between the ANNs and BNNs are (but not limited to) topologies,fault tolerance,size and energy consumption prominent differences between the BNNs and ANNs
coauthors: bradly alicea, orthogonal lab,usa
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Neurotransmitter switches regulate motor learning and stress response
abstract:
Neurotransmitter switching, involving the loss of one neurotransmitter and gain of another in the same neuron, is a form of plasticity that regulates E/I balance and behavior (Li & Spitzer, 2020; Spitzer, 2017). We have identified neurotransmitter switching and its behavioral consequences in both healthy and stressed brains during adulthood. 
We find that one week of voluntary wheel running enhances the acquisition of motor skills in healthy adult mice. Running for one week also induces switching from acetylcholine to GABA expression in neurons in the midbrain pedunculopontine nucleus. Using viral vectors to override transmitter switching, either by expressing the enzymes for acetylcholine synthesis, or short hairpin RNAs interfering with the gain of enzymes for GABA synthesis, blocks the beneficial effect of running on motor skill learning (Li & Spitzer, 2020). These results show that neurotransmitter switching provides the basis by which sustained running benefits motor skill learning.
Under conditions of stress, we find that transmitter switching occurs following a traumatic fear experience. Two and four weeks after intense footshock stress, a subset of serotonergic neurons in the lateral wings of the dorsal raphe (lwDR) of adult mice have switched their co-transmitter from glutamate/vGluT3 (vesicular glutamate transporter type 3) to GABA/GAD67 (glutamic acid decarboxylase 67). At both time points, shocked mice show fear-related passive behaviors as they reduce exploration and increase freezing in a novel environment. We are now using Cre-dependent adeno-associated viruses (AAVs) to express vGluT3 or suppress expression of GAD1 that encodes GAD67 in serotonergic lwDR neurons and testing the impact on the stress-induced sustained fear responses.
Our studies suggest that neurotransmitter switching, as a form of brain plasticity, links prior experience to subsequent alterations of behavior. We expect this research to lead to new insights into development of therapeutic methods for treating movement disorders and mental illnesses.
coauthors: Wuji Jiang, University of California, San Diego; Cong Chen, Ludwig Institute for Cancer Research, University of California San Diego; Don Cleveland, Ludwig Institute for Cancer Research, University of California San Diego; Nicholas C. Spitzer, University of California, San Diego
theme: Theme B: Neural Excitability, Synapses, and Glia

title: Mapping the building blocks of face processing in individuals with and without autism using microstate analysis
abstract:
Face processing undergoes significant changes during early development. Difficulties in facial processing and variability in neural processing of faces are common in individuals with autism across development. It remains unknown whether this individual variability in face processing between individuals with and without autism is better explained by qualitative differences in the involvement of different neural processing pathways or by quantitative differences in the neural processing of similar neural pathways.
In this study, we investigated spatial and temporal characteristics of face processing using electroencephalography in children with and without autism (N’s = 53 and 40), adolescents with and without autism (N’s = 79 and 68), and adults with and without autism (N’s = 90 and 74) from the Longitudinal European Autism Project. We applied multi-channel data-driven analyses to the event-related responses to upright and inverted faces (modulating configural face processing) and tested for qualitative differences in scalp topography with topographic analyses of variance and for quantitative differences in strength of these topographies with global field power comparisons. Next, we extracted distinct spatiotemporal microstates to examine neural timings for responses to faces for the different orientations and diagnostic groups. 
The neurotypical groups displayed distinct temporal and topographic profiles with different strengths for the upright and inverted faces. Topography and strength of the scalp profiles showed subtle differences between individuals with and without autism in the adolescents, but not in the children and adults. The microstate approach revealed quantitative differences between diagnostic groups during the early temporal stages of face processing, and qualitative differences between diagnostic groups during the later temporal stages of face processing across all age groups. 
Our findings demonstrate the importance of multi-channel spatiotemporal analytic approaches in investigating neural responses in neurodevelopmental disorders. Alterations emerging at early stages of development in autism may result in compensatory processes later in development.
coauthors: Luke Mason, Birkbeck University of London United Kingdom; Pilar Garces, Roche Pharma Research and Early Development Basel Switzerland; Anna Gui, Birkbeck University of London United Kingdom; Tony Charman, King’s College London United Kingdom & South London and Maudsley NHS Foundation United Kingdom; Mark H. Johnson, Birkbeck University of London & University of Cambridge United Kingdom; Emily J.H. Jones, Birkbeck University of London United Kingdom; the EU-AIMS LEAP team
theme: Theme A: Development, Neurodegenerative Disorders and Injury

title: Altered dynamic architecture of functional connectivity for predicting recovery of consciousness in behaviorally unresponsive patients
abstract: The brain is an inherently dynamic and time-varying organ, whose functionality is based on patterns of spatially and temporally differentiated activity. In individuals with disorders of consciousness (DOC), the dynamic properties of functional connectivity of their brain networks are altered. Accurate assessment of level of consciousness in unresponsive patients and their potential to recover requires further understanding of the dynamic architecture of functional connectivity. In this study, we investigate the diagnostic and prognostic value of dynamic properties of functional connectivity in individuals in an unresponsive or minimally responsive state. Time-resolved functional connectivity was estimated from high-density EEG using the weighted phase lag index (wPLI). The spatial-temporal organization of wPLI connectivity was assessed with a K-means clustering analysis and compared between 1) healthy adults; 2) DOC patients who recovered consciousness; 3) DOC patients who remained unresponsive; and 4) patients showing cognitive-motor dissociation. The robustness of the results was further evaluated using a hidden Markov model. We demonstrate that the dynamic organization of functional connectivity varies widely in DOC patients, and that these patterns differs from those which are observed in healthy adults. We demonstrate that the degree of preserved dynamic organization of time-resolved functional connectivity distinguishes unresponsive patients according to their state of consciousness and potential to recover consciousness. Our findings provide evidence for altered spatial-temporal patterns and dynamic properties of functional connectivity in unresponsive individuals. The maintenance of the brains inherently dynamic and time-variable organization contains valuable information for the accurate assessment of an individual's level of consciousness and the potential to recover consciousness.
coauthors: Stefanie Blain-Moraes, School of Physical and Occupational Therapy,  McGill University Montreal
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: The Boolean dendrite: Intrinsic computation of wide range of Boolean func- tions by dendritic branches
abstract:
Recent studies investigating the physiology of the human neurons have provided un-
expected findings regarding the modus operandi of single neurons [1-3]. One of these
studies found calcium mediated dendritic action potentials (dCaAPs) in layer 2/3 pyra-
midal neurons [2]. Here, we further explore the computational properties of the
dCaAPs, using a machine learning approach. Specifically, we used a non-monotonic
activation function derived from the properties of the dCaAPs as measured in the ex-
periments; dCaAP’s amplitude was zero for subthreshold inputs, maximum (1) at
threshold and decayed exponentially with further increasing the input strength (Fig-
ure). In this study, we show how a single dendritic branch implements all the Boolean
functions, including the non-linearly separable XOR and XNOR. We identify the combi-
nations of biologically inspired inputs that solve each of these Boolean functions. This
work provides insights into the range of computations a dendrite can perform.
coauthors: Athanasia Papoutsi, Institute of Molecular Biology and Biotechnology, FORTH, Heraklion, Greece; Albert Gidon,  Institute for Biology, Humboldt-Universität zu Berlin, Berlin, Germany; Matthew E. Larkum,  Institute for Biology, Humboldt-Universität zu Berlin, Berlin, Germany & NeuroCure Cluster, Charité – Universitätsmedizin, Berlin, Berlin, Germany; Panayiota Poirazi, Institute of Molecular Biology and Biotechnology, FORTH, Heraklion, Greece
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Tuning movement to optimize information harvesting
abstract: Information about potential fitness enhancers is dispersed in space, which provides a logic to the heterotroph strategy of moving to acquire resources. But how ought animals move to optimally acquire information? Current work on Lévy-flight like trajectories may apply to the context of acquiring resources that are far outside the range of sensory systems, but are not predictive when resources are in range. Entropy minimization approaches like infotaxis provide predictions for how animals ought to move when targets are in sensory range, but these do not agree well with measured trajectories. We present a new approach, energy-constrained proportional betting, and show that it generates trajectories that agree well with measured trajectories of animals localizing targets across four species spanning insects, fish, and mammals. In addition to predicting sense organ movements, the method also performs well for prescribing sensor locations in mobile robots in weak and noisy signal conditions.
coauthors: Chen Chen, Northwestern University; Todd D. Murphy, Northwestern University
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: A Bayesian filtering framework for neural and sensorimotor entrainment
abstract: When presented with complex rhythmic auditory stimuli, most humans are able to track underlying temporal structure (e.g., a ``beat'') with overt movement or covertly while automatically and unconsciously adjusting for timing irregularities. We propose that the problem of overt and covert rhythm tracking is most naturally characterized as a problem of point process filtering: continuously estimating a hidden underlying phase based on the precise timing of temporally localized events that provide (incomplete) information about the phase. Here, we provide several mathematical framings of that problem at different levels of detail. We demonstrate that variational Bayesian solutions to this problem (specifically, point-process Kalman-Bucy filters) can be used to infer tempo as well as phase, and that they reproduce multiple characteristics of overt and covert human rhythm tracking including interval-dependent phase correction and the ``filled interval'' illusion. We point out that this approach to rhythm tracking fits nicely into the theory of predictive processing and active inference, and we discuss its plausibility in the human brain.
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Biological learning of local motion detectors
abstract: Motion detectors in the brain are typically localized, using correlations between light intensities at nearby locations in combination with a small temporal delay. If motion is global, however, in the sense that the same transformation is applied uniformly across the entire field of view, locations arbitrarily far apart can in principle be used for motion detection. One explanation for why this does not happen in the brain is that it would require long-distance connections that would be prohibitively expensive. Here we suggest that, in fact, a normative model that posits that the brain is adapted to natural visual statistics is sufficient to lead to localized interactions, even without considering the costs of long-range connections. Our model further provides a biologically plausible mechanism that can be used to learn the connectivity pattern for local motion detectors. We adapt a method initially designed for learning infinitesimal generators for global motion, and show that, when the training data contains localized patterns and/or localized motion, the learned generators naturally cluster into groups involving small sets of nearby pixels. Our proposed learning algorithm is based on non-negative similarity matching, a normative approach that allows us to use an objective function to derive a biologically plausible circuit that solves the task.
coauthors: Alexander Genkin, NYU; Dmitri Chklovskii, Flatiron Institute
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: State-dependent cortical network dynamics underlying visual perception
theme: Theme B: Neural Excitability, Synapses, and Glia

title: “Metacogmission”: measuring metacognition across the lifespan and over two cognitive domains via an engaging gamified task
abstract:
Background:
Metacognition – or “thinking about your own thinking” – is of increasing interest to cognitive neuroscientists, as a concept with translational potential to real world problems including theories of mental illness, insight into mental health and the capacity for authentic decision-making. Open questions remain about how metacognition develops and functions. There is conflicting evidence about whether metacognition improves or decays with age, and whether it generalises across multiple cognitive domains. Measurement of metacognition has often been limited by confounding effects of an individual’s task performance levels and of their general propensity to be self-confident. Models derived from Type 2 signal-detection theory circumvent these issues by returning a metacognitive “efficiency” parameter, quantifying sensitivity of confidence ratings given a certain level of task performance. However, fitting these models requires high numbers of trials to generate robust parameters, making tasks difficult to use for people who have low concentration or motivation.

Methods:
Working with a technology firm and a mental health service user advisory group, we developed Metacogmission – a gamified metacognitive task. After trialling at 2 public engagement events with over 400 people, we here report a cross-sectional observational study of >300 online volunteers (18 to 83 years), measuring metacognition for memory and visual perception. We use Bayesian modelling to derive metacognitive efficiency (meta-d’/d’), charting metacognition through the lifespan across two domains. 

Results and conclusions:
Metacogmission was acceptable and fun, showing potential for use with clinical groups. Meta-d’ model fits, as assessed with MCMC convergence diagnostics, were robust, returning parameters comparable to those from more extensive laboratory tasks. Preliminary results indicate that as people age, performance on the first order cognitive tasks was preserved, although raw confidence (“bias”) decreased to middle age. Metacognitive efficiency remained largely stable with age, and was correlated across cognitive domains, consistent with a degree of domain-generality for metacognition.
coauthors: Hannah Bibby, Institute of Cognitive Neuroscience, University College London, London, UK; Nikolaus Steinbeis, Department of Clinical, Educational and Health Psychology, University College London, London, UK; Stephen M. Fleming, Metacognition Group, Wellcome Centre for Human Neuroimaging and Department of Experimental Psychology, University College London, London, UK.
institution: Metacognition Group, Wellcome Centre for Human Neuroimaging and Department of Experimental Psychology, University College London; Mental Health, Ethics and Law Research Group, Institute of Psychiatry, Psychology and Neuroscience, King’s College London; Great Ormond Street Hospital for Children, London, UK.
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Interhemispheric communication during haptic self-perception
abstract: When people move their finger across a planar surface, a slight resistance that decreases movement velocity is illusorily perceived as a bump on the surface. If the surface touched is one’s own skin, a bump should also increase the pressure from the finger to the skin surface. Participants made two movements of the right hand while holding a haptic force-control robot. Resistances were added to both, and participants judged “which movement felt more bumpy; first or second?”. The movements were transferred to a second, slave robot, delivering but task-irrelevant stroking touch to the left forearm. The slave robot briefly increased or decreased tactile pressure in synchrony with right hand velocity decrease, consistent with encountering bumps, or holes respectively (blocked factor), during self-touch. We investigated whether left tactile events changes would bias judgement of the bump size perceived with the right hand. Left tactile pressure increases and decreases both increased bump size perceived by the right hand. Tactile information was thus transferred inter-hemispherically, but the sign of tactile information was not respected. In experiment 2, randomising (rather than blocking) tactile pressure increases/decreases abolished these biases. Inter-hemispheric transfer during self-touch is based on consistent models of synchronized events, but omits geometric object information.
coauthors: Gaiqing Kong, UCL Institute of Cognitive Neuroscience, UK; Miruna Nitu, UCL Institute of Cognitive Neuroscience, UK; Antonio Cataldo, Institute of Philosophy, University of London, UK; Hiroaki Gomi, NTT Communication Science Laboratories, Japan; Patrick Haggard, UCL Institute of Cognitive Neuroscience, UK.
institution: Neuroscience Research Centre of Lyon INSERM U1028
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Predicting functional organization and its impact on behavior.
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Sculpting New Visual Concepts into the Human Brain
abstract: Learning requires changing the brain. This typically occurs through experience, study, or instruction. We report a new way of acquiring conceptual knowledge by directly sculpting activity patterns in the human brain. We used a non-invasive technique (closed-loop real-time functional magnetic resonance imaging) to create novel categories of visual objects in the brain. After training, participants exhibited behavioral and neural biases for the sculpted, but not control categories. The ability to sculpt new conceptual distinctions in the human brain, applied here to perception, has broad relevance to other domains of cognition such as decision-making, memory, and motor control. As such, the work opens up new frontiers in brain-machine interface design, neuroprosthetics, and neurorehabilitation.
coauthors: Marius Cătălin Iordan, Princeton University; Victoria J. H. Ritvo, Princeton University; Kenneth A. Norman, Princeton University; Nicholas B. Turk-Browne, Yale University; Jonathan D. Cohen, Princeton University
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Brain-wide mapping of neural activity evoked by different superior colliculus cell-types.
abstract: Neuronal cell-types are arranged in brain-wide circuits to guide behavior. In mice, the superior colliculus is comprised of a set of cell-types that each innervate distinct downstream targets. Here we reveal the networks downstream of four collicular cell-types by combining functional ultrasound imaging (fUSi) with optogenetics to monitor whole-brain activity at a resolution of ~100 ‎μm. Each neuronal group activated distinct, partially overlapping sets of brain nuclei. This included regions not previously thought to mediate defensive behaviors. Electrophysiological recordings support the fUSi findings and show that neurons in the downstream nuclei preferentially respond to innately threatening visual stimuli. This work provides insight into the functional organization of the networks governing defensive behaviors and demonstrates an experimental approach to explore the whole-brain neuronal activity downstream of targeted cell-types.
coauthors: Arnau Sans-Dublanc1,2,3, Neuro-Electronics Research Flanders. Leuven, Belgium1. Department of Biology, KU Leuven. Leuven, Belgium2. VIB. Leuven, Belgium3; Anna Chrzanowska1,2,3; Katja Reinhard1,2,3; Dani Lemmon1,4, Faculty of Pharmaceutical, Biomedical and Veterinary Sciences, University of Antwerp. Antwerp, Belgium4; Gabriel Montaldo1,5 Imec, Leuven, Belgium5; Alan Urban1,2,3,6, Department of Neurosciences, KU Leuven. Leuven, Belgium6; and Karl Farrow1,2,3,5
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior
