title: LiftPose3D, a deep learning-based approach for transforming 2D to 3D pose in laboratory animals
abstract: Markerless 3D pose estimation has become an indispensable tool for kinematic studies of laboratory animals. Most current methods recover 3D pose by multi-view triangulation of deep network-based 2D pose estimates. However, triangulation requires multiple, synchronised cameras per keypoint and elaborate calibration protocols that hinder its widespread adoption in laboratory studies. Here, we describe LiftPose3D, a deep network-based method that overcomes these barriers by reconstructing 3D poses from a single 2D camera view. We illustrate LiftPose3D’s versatility by applying it to multiple experimental systems using flies, mice, and macaque monkeys and in circumstances where 3D triangulation is impractical or impossible. Thus, LiftPose3D permits high-quality 3D pose estimation in the absence of complex camera arrays, tedious calibration procedures, and despite occluded keypoints in freely behaving animals.
coauthors: Semih Gunel, École Polytechnique Fédérale de Lausanne; Marco Pietro Abrate, École Polytechnique Fédérale de Lausanne; Daniel Morales, École Polytechnique Fédérale de Lausanne; Victor Lobato Rios, École Polytechnique Fédérale de Lausanne; Helge Rhodin, University of British Columbia; Pascal Fua, École Polytechnique Fédérale de Lausanne; Pavan Ramdya, École Polytechnique Fédérale de Lausanne
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Collective response of oscillating neuronal population to the applied perturbation: a computational framework
abstract:
Brain oscillations are hypothesized to modulate the inter-cortical communication and control the integration of information. The signal exchange in such processes relies on the response of the networks to the incoming inputs. Characterizing the network’s response with respect to the timing of input’s arrival, though, is crucial to assess the mechanism of cortical communication. In this study, we introduce a computational framework to investigate the collective response of a network regarding the perturbation phase at which it is received.


The role of inhibitory interneurons in generation of brain oscillations has firmly been established. Accordingly, we used a network of 500 inhibitory Integrate and Fire (IF) neurons and applied a brief perturbation to 10% of population at different phases of the LFP oscillation. The transient changes in the cycle period of subsequent oscillations as well as the change in their amplitudes are documented as a function of the perturbation phase. The resulted characteristic curve is called collective Phase (Amplitude) Response Curves (cPRC & cARC).


cPRC and cARC manifest, despite the fact that IF neuron models are type I and characterized by their phase only being advanced regardless of the phase of perturbation, a network consisting of IF neurons produces a delay in phase followed by an advance followed by a delay, depending on the timing of the perturbation. Furthermore, the amplitude of the subsequent cycle undergoes an increase-decrease-increase cycle of changes in its strength. The model then predicts that applying a perturbation at the early and very late phase of the oscillation gives rise to a transient reduction of LFP frequency while applying that at the middle period of oscillation induces a transient increment in that.


Our results suggest that the collective response of the oscillatory inhibitory networks are almost independent of the properties of the constituent neurons. As the collective response curve determine the efficacy of the communication and the signal exchange between the brain areas, this study can serve as an important step in understanding the mechanisms of inter-cortical communications.
coauthors: Alireza Valizadeh, Institute for Advanced Studies in Basic Sciences (IASBS)
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Motor unit firing frequencies are muscle dependent during static contraction: importance of axon distance?
abstract:
The somatic nervous system innervates hundreds of different striated muscles, each comprised of a sub-population of motor units (MU). For any voluntary muscle contraction (to remain static or move the joint) MU activation is required that first involves MU recruitment (i.e. spatial control) and subsequent firing rate modulation (i.e. temporal control) to enable precision in producing tension at the tendon. Because contractile output is affected by structural (fibre type, innervation ration, etc.) as well as synaptic (intrinsic and extrinsic) properties, our aim was to understand which structural factor is most probable to affect the observation of different MU firing frequencies among muscles. Thus, we generated four hypotheses based on: fibre type, innervation type (brainstem vs. spinal), axon distance and anatomical location.
           From an aggregated dataset containing MU firing rates from 15 different muscles and thousands of MU samples from male and female adult participants, post-hoc statistical comparisons were made based on the probability of an observed model (alternative) residing within a simulated distribution of model outputs (null distribution). For each hypothesis test, the simulated distribution was based on a fitted y-intercept with the addition of bootstrapping from studentized residuals of the observed model. We then performed 100 iterations of case bootstrapping for each hypothesis. Statistical significance was determined by a two-sided p-value calculation, where the observed slope coefficient (from the alternative) acted as the alpha value against the simulated distribution estimate. 
          Of the four hypotheses, axon distance to the muscle was the most probable hypothesis to reject the null estimate (q-value < 0.005). Therefore, axon distance as a factor to effect firing rates among muscles was least likely in our dataset to occur by chance, and we speculate that important axon-dependent structures related to internode length and maximum conduction velocity act as important limits on firing rate distributions.
coauthors: Eric A. Kirk, The University of Western Ontario; Charles L. Rice, The University of Western Ontario
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Being in Sync: How Neural Entrainment Affects Attention and Conscious Experience
abstract: Activation of attention-reward centres cause actual patterns of local field potentials across brain regions to become synchronised in their alpha, theta and gamma frequency bands but however, in recent years, research has been more focused on information filtering by partial synchronous spikes in neural populations. In this context, we further investigate the performance prediction estimates from neural synchronisation during the 2AFC task through analyses of power spectrums, time/frequency correlational metrics within and across brain regions, time lagged and phase based analysis of discrete brain wave structures and how these are can be reverse engineered to the respective brain state aka current conscious experience. Neural entrainment in turn has multitude of applications where (a) asychrony is attributed to Alzhimer's disease and Schizophrenia while (b) local network synchrony affects interpersonal communication (language understanding), learning experience (long-term working memory formation) and global fields or transient synchronous assemblies could underlie the basis of phenomenal consciousness where the NMDA-based plasticity, cortico-thalamic projections, and regular oscillatory waves knit with local diverse specialised brain module activity contributes to an integrated conscious experience. In this talk, we intend to explore discrete brain waves properties and associated mental states discussing the effect of synchronisation on consciousness while presenting our unique findings on mice models.
coauthors: Deepak Padamata; Mahdi Mahdavi;
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Do neural responses to heartbeats distinguish self and other in an emotional perspective taking task?
abstract: On a daily basis, we share in each other's joy and frustrations, yet despite the contagious nature of emotions, we are perfectly capable of dissociating our own emotional state to that of someone else. Such a differentiation between self and other might seem trivial, but becomes more puzzling considering that many physiological responses and neural activations are shared between experiencing and observing of emotions. One proposed mechanism in which our sense of self might be anchored is the neural monitoring of heartbeats. The debate on how our emotional experiences are shaped by bodily signals, in particular cardiac signals, is long-standing, yet  this relationship has been mostly explored in how emotions might change cardiac activity. Here, we propose a new avenue of research; how is the neural monitoring of heartbeats related to our emotional experience, and more specifically, does the neural monitoring of heartbeats help differentiate self from other in emotion? To explore this question, participants engaged in an emotional perspective taking task while their brain activity was measured using EEG, and several peripheral physiological measures were recorded (cardiac activity, facial EMG, and Skin Conductance Responses (SCR)). While participants prepared to rate a naturalistic image for either their own emotion or the emotion depicted in the image, Heartbeat Evoked Responses (HER) significantly differed between the self and other condition. Additionally, during exploration of the image, a self-other difference in SCR was found, as well as an interaction for the valence of the image and self-other condition in the facial zygomatic muscle. Observed self-other HER differences were localized to frontal and occipital sources, which correlated with subjective ratings of the images, as well as empathic traits, but not with the effects observed in physiological responses. Our results show that the HER can perform a role in self-other distinction in emotional contexts.
coauthors: Anne Buot, École Normale Supérieure; Julie Grèzes, École Normale Supérieure; Catherine Tallon-Baudry, École Normale Supérieure;
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: The cellular changes occurring in early Alzheimer’s disease
institution:
VIB-KU Leuven Center for Brain & Disease Research & UK Dementia Research Institute
UCL, UK
theme: Theme A: Development, Neurodegenerative Disorders and Injury

title: An Attempt at Co-Clinical Trials of Autism in Mice and Humans
abstract: Despite promise in animal models, novel therapeutics consistently fail in clinical trials of autism. Due to the heterogeneous nature of autism, treatment will likely only ameliorate symptoms in a subset of patients. There is a need to simultaneously test promising new compounds while understanding and predicting which patients will respond to each therapy. To determine what might contribute to response susceptibility, we propose the implementation of co-clinical trials in autism. In co-clinical trials, novel compounds, with established safety profiles, are simultaneously tested in mouse models of autism as well as in Phase 2 trials in humans with autism. A high-throughput protocol for mouse models of autism is discussed, which encompasses chronic treatment over development, multiple magnetic resonance imaging time-points, and behavioural tests before, during, and after treatment. Human subjects also follow an extensive phenotyping protocol, including behavioural testing, as well as genetics and imaging assessments. This multi-modal, multi-species approach is designed to be a rigorous method of assessing treatment effect, with the intention of stratification by response susceptibility. The considerations of the co-clinical trials is discussed, focusing on the trials and tribulations of the model, as well as lessons-learned. The hope is to introduce the concept of co-clinical trials to the field of autism, creating a shift in our current approach to the treatment of the disorder.
coauthors: Adrienne Kinman; Tiffany Chien; Kaitlyn Easson; Monique Stuvie; Darren Fernandes; Eric Chater-Diehl; Michelle Siu; Darci Butcher; Jacob Ellegood; Rosanna Weksberg; Jane Foster; Evdokia Anagnostou; Jason P. Lerch
theme: Theme A: Development, Neurodegenerative Disorders and Injury

title: Intracerebral recordings study of the spatiotemporal dynamics of human exogenous attention
abstract: Our attention is automatically captured by salient events, a process called exogenous attention orienting. We explored the neural basis of two exogenous attention related effects: response time facilitation (RT facilitation) and inhibition of return (IOR). How fast we respond to a stimulus depends on whether it appears in a previously attended location, for example if a target-stimulus was preceded or not by an exogenous cue. However, this cueing effect changes according to the cue-to-target delay: short delays lead to faster responses in cued locations (RT Facilitation), while delays that are only slightly longer inverse this pattern and lead to faster responses to uncued locations (IOR). A method with high temporal resolution is required to study the neural correlates of these fast and dynamic processes. Here, data were recorded from 28 epileptic patients implanted with depth electrodes as a part of their medical treatment (1407 contacts), providing a unique opportunity to directly measure human neurophysiology with excellent spatio-temporal resolution. Patients performed the Posner paradigm with peripheral cues, while their neural responses were recorded. We studied the neural activity through a data-driven clustering approach, to reveal the spatiotemporal patterns of target-related activity. We identified specific neural clusters showing segregated cue and target related responses when the delay was long, but an integrated response to cue and target when the delay was short. Clusters varied in their sensitivity to the stimulus location, stimulus identity (cue or target) and response latency. These clusters may contribute to the computations underlying exogenous attention related effects.
coauthors: Dimitri J Bayle; Alexia Bourgeois; Katia Lehongre; Vincent Navarro; Claude Adam; Jacobo D Sitt; Paolo Bartolomeo
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: The effects of cognitive and mechanical restrictions on modular neuromuscular control in younger and older adults during beam walking
abstract: The manipulation of cognitive and mechanical restrictions affects performance and spatiotemporal parameters of gait. However, it is unclear if such restrictions also influence neuromuscular control of gait or whether age mediates their effect. Hence, we examined the effects of cognitive task and changes in arms position during beam walking in younger and older adults. Younger (YA, 23.8±3.2y, n=17) and older adults (OA, 69±3.9y, n=14) walked along a 6-cm wide beam (2-cm high, 4-m long), with free and chest folded arms, with and without a cognitive task (serial subtraction by 3). We used non-negative matrix factorization to extract muscle synergies from surface EMG recordings of 13 leg and trunk muscles. Differences in modular control complexity were assessed by comparing the number of muscle synergies (nsyn) and the variability accounted for by a single muscle synergy (VAF-1). The number of significantly active muscles per synergy (Wmus) and the sum of significantly active muscles per synergy (Wsum) were also compared to assess muscle coactivity and modular control efficiency. Addition of the cognitive task increased Wmus (without: 3.9±1.2, with: 4.4±1.3, p=0.047), only in YA, indicating increased coactivity in the presence of the subtractions in this group. On the other hand, restricting arm motion increased VAF-1 (folded: 74.5±3.7%, free: 73.2±4.2%, p=0.018), just in OA, suggesting less complexity of modular control with arms folded within older adults. Age was responsible for differences in nsyn (YA:7.0±1.3, OA:6.1±1.2, p=0.038), VAF-1 (YA:68.9±5.6%, OA:73.9±4.0%, p=0.004) and Wsum (YA: 2.1±0.5, OA: 2.5±0.7, p=0.034), implying less complexity and efficiency in modular control in OA. In conclusion, cognitive and mechanical restrictions affected neuromuscular control differently based on age, changing coactivity and complexity in YA and OA respectively. Older adults still exhibited a modular control strategy that was less complex and efficient than younger adults. FUNDING: FAPESP/Brazil (Grants 2018/18081-0 and 2019/00387-9).
coauthors: Andrew Sawers, Department of Kinesiology, College of Applied Health Sciences, The University of Illinois at Chicago, USA; Tibor Hortobágyi, Center for Human Movement Sciences, University Medical Center Groningen, The Netherlands; Renato Moraes, School of Physical Education and Sport of Ribeirão Preto, University of São Paulo, Brazil
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Age and stimulus type influence the association between multi-voxel threat representations and explicit memory during generalization
abstract:
Aberrations in threat generalization may contribute to childhood anxiety. However, few studies have examined threat generalization across development and no developmental studies have compared generalization gradients for social vs nonsocial threat. We used representational similarity analysis and fMRI to assess developmental differences in the association between neural threat representations and explicit memory across social and non-social stimuli.
Twenty adults (Mage = 25.8) and 16 youth (Mage = 14.1) completed one social and one nonsocial threat conditioning and extinction-recall paradigm. During conditioning, the social paradigm paired a woman’s face with a scream and the nonsocial paradigm paired a colored bell with an aversive alarm. Three weeks later, during extinction recall, participants viewed the threat cue (CS+), safety cue (CS-), and generalization stimuli consisting of CS-/CS+ blends. Multi-voxel BOLD patterns were measured in five ROIs (vmPFC, dmPFC, anterior insula, dACC, amygdala) and representational dissimilarity matrices (RDMs) were created for each subject in each ROI and condition. Individuals’ RDMs were correlated with memory ratings matrices, averaged within each age group and paradigm.
A repeated-measures ANOVA revealed a Task x ROI x Age interaction, F(4,136) = 4.47, p = .002. Follow-up t-tests found a higher correlation between both youth and adults’ anterior insular activity patterns and memory ratings in the social than nonsocial task (ps < .002). Additionally, adults’ neural activity was more correlated with memory ratings for the social than nonsocial task in the dmPFC and vmPFC (ps < .004). Finally, youth’s dACC activity was more correlated with memory ratings for the social than nonsocial task, t(15) = 3.61, p = .003. 
These findings indicate that salience of social threats may contribute to greater correspondence between neural activity and memory ratings across age groups. Further, whereas adults may rely on PFC to make categorical distinctions between threat and safety, adolescents may engage salience network structures.
coauthors: Dana E. Glenn, Department of Psychology, University of California, Riverside; Megan A. K. Peters, Department of Cognitive Sciences, University of California, Irvine; Daniel S. Pine, Emotion and Development Branch, National Institute of Mental Health; Kalina J. Michalska, Department of Psychology, University of California, Riverside
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: 3D Human Cortical Organoids to investigate developmental epileptic encephalopathies
abstract: The human cerebral cortex is characterized by an extraordinary complexity of neuronal and non-neuronal cell types wired together for the execution of high-order cognitive functions. Alterations, during fetal development as well as after birth, in the assembly of cortical neuronal circuits can lead to aberrant neuronal activity and abnormal firing patterns, shared signs of neurodevelopmental disorders. Early Infantile Epileptic Encephalopathies (EIEE), a heterogeneous group of devastating childhood epilepsy disorders with a strong genetic component, constitute the most precocious syndromes that can affect infants as early as in the womb. EIEE mutations are associated with a variety of proteins implicated in a wide range of developmental processes, from neuronal migration and cell adhesion to transcriptional regulation and synaptic transmission (i.e. ARX, PCDH19, HCN1, FOXG1, SCN1A, GABAA). Despite the number of genes linked to EIEE is growing the etiology remains unknown for most cases, and it is challenging to decouple the patient-specific genetic make-up from the effect of the aberrant activity per se on brain development. To answer this fundamental question and address unique features of human development, we are exploiting a highly reproducible human cortical organoids (hCOs) system, on which we are inducing acute seizure-like currents, to model infantile/pediatric epilepsy in vitro. To address the implications of activity on circuit assembly, we aim to map at the single-cell level the epigenetic and transcriptional landscape of treated and untreated hCOs, with the final goal of deciphering the epigenetic fingerprints produced by exacerbate activity in distinct classes of cortical neurons. Identification the of aberrant pathways associated with epileptic seizures will constitute an invaluable resource to discover novel anti-epileptic drug targets for infantile/pediatric epilepsy.
coauthors: Sara Mancinelli, Humanitas Clinical and Research Center-IRCCS; Rosalba Olga Proce, Humanitas Clinical and Research Center-IRCCS;Filippo Mirabella, Humanitas Clinical and Research Center-IRCCS; Davide Pozzi, Humanitas Clinical and Research Center-IRCCS; Michela Matteoli, Humanitas Clinical and Research Center-IRCCS; Simona Lodato, Humanitas Clinical and Research Center-IRCCS
theme: Theme A: Development, Neurodegenerative Disorders and Injury

title: Multidimensional analysis and detection of informative features in diffusion MRI measurements of human white matter
abstract:
Tractometry uses diffusion-weighted magnetic resonance imaging (dMRI) to quantify tissue properties along the trajectories of white matter connections (Yeatman et al. 2012). Tractometry results are usually analyzed using mass univariate approaches, computed separately for each point along tracts (Colby et al. 2012), akin to fMRI voxel-wise analysis. Alternatively, an a priori hypothesis is used, where tissue properties are computed for a specific tract of interest. In the present work, we introduce a method based on the Sparse Group Lasso (SGL; Simon et al., 2013) that selects informative features by enforcing sparsity, both at the level of individual tracts and across the entire set of tracts, thereby recovering the minimal set of anatomical features to make accurate predictions. Our method presents a significant departure from previous analysis of tractometry data: rather than providing p-values for each individual location in the brain, the statistical accuracy of this method focuses on the accuracy of the predictions of phenotypic data.

We validated our approach in both regression and classification settings. An example dataset for classification contained data from 24 patients with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) and 24 matched controls (Sarica et al. 2017). An example dataset for regression contained data from 76 healthy subjects, ranging between 6 years and 50 years of age and a validation dataset contained 641 healthy subjects from the Cam-CAN dataset. In the classification setting, we demonstrate that this method competes with previous results without the need for a priori feature engineering. Moreover, it automatically identifies well-known features of the disease. In the regression setting, the data can be used to accurately predict "brain age". Thus, this multivariate approach both (a) achieves high cross-validated accuracy for precision medicine applications of dMRI data and (b) identifies relevant features of brain anatomy to further our neuroscientific understanding of clinical disorders.
coauthors: Jason Yeatman, Stanford University; Noah Simon, University of Washington; Ariel Rokem, University of Washington
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Surprise signals in Frontal Eye Field
abstract: In classic learning theory, surprise is quantified by unsigned prediction error, which determines how much attention is captured by a particular event. Unlike signed reward prediction error, an unsigned prediction error increases with the improbability of an outcome, regardless of its valence. Neurons in the frontal eye field (FEF) are sensitive to reward amount and are involved in the allocation of attention but it is unknown how they respond to surprising outcomes. To address this, we trained  monkeys in a Pavlovian paradigm requiring them to view two images in a probablistic sequence followed by delivery of a reward.  The leading image, depending on its identity, predicted with high probability (p = 0.83) delivery of either a large or a small reward at the end of the trial. The trailing image indicated with certainty that the ensuing reward would be either large or small. The information conveyed by the trailing image usually confirmed, but occasionally violated, the prediction conveyed by the leading image. The key question of the study is whether a given trailing image would elicit differential activity depending on whether it confirmed or violated the expectation created by the leading image. We found that the strength of the response to the trailing image was indeed influenced by surprise. Neurons responded more strongly to a trailing image predicting large reward when the probability of large reward was low than when it was high. Similarly, neurons responded more strongly to a trailing image predicting small reward when the probability of small reward was low than when it was high. Further, we demonstrate that these results depend on presenting the cues in rather than opposite the response field. The results are consistent with the interpretation that cues signaling surprising outcomes capture spatial attention and, in so doing, recruit excitation of FEF neurons.
coauthors: Carl R. Olson, Carnegie Mellon University
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Critical behavior in networks of inhibitory-excitatory spiking neurons with weak synaptic efficacy
abstract: Cortical circuits exhibit a rich dynamical behavior with irregular individual neuron firing rates, global oscillations, synchronization, scale-free fluctuations and high sensitivity to certain stimuli. While classical theories of inhibitory and excitatory (IE) neurons explain these behaviors, they require different synaptic properties. The coexistence of the observed behaviors suggests that the network may be operating at a near-critical regime. A recent study by Girardi-Schappo et. al. portrayed the phase space of IE neurons with binary activation, discrete-time dynamics, and stochastic threshold. The binary model presents qualitatively similar states to those of IE spiking neurons and the authors identified a critical point of the Direct Percolation (DP) universality class, namely a transition between an absorbing and an active network state often associated with a critical branching process. However, the existence and nature of the critical point in the case of more realistic spiking dynamics are still at question. In this work, we return the leaky iterate-and-fire (LIF) model, which was studies in the context of IE networks. We study its mean-field dynamics around the proposed critical point. When the total synaptic efficacy is of the order of the threshold -- a limit not previously studied -- stable activity with slow oscillations persists well into the unstable excitatory regime. This slow-oscillations phase is bounded by SNIC and Hopf bifurcation lines which meet at the proposed critical point. We find that along the Hopf bifurcation, the system exhibits scale-free avalanches with sub-critical scaling exponents that conform with in vivo cortical slice preparations. Importantly, we show that the microscopic dynamics cannot be understood as a critical-branching process. We further discuss our results in relation to sensitivity for perturbation, and to recent experiments of in vivo optogenetic perturbations in the visual cortex.
coauthors: Jonathan Kadmon, Stanford University; Surya Ganguli, Stanford University
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Science fiction and folk knowledge of the brain: insights for science communicators
abstract: In science communication, one of the biggest challenges for scientists steeped in the vocabulary and assumptions of their field can be understanding exactly where expert and non-expert understandings of a particular topic differ. Luckily for neuroscientists, we have a particularly strong and underutilized tool in our belt for better understanding folk conceptions of the mind and brain: science fiction. Since the second century (and probably before) humans have been using speculative fiction to explore biological aspects of human identity. In this talk, I’ll review what classic and contemporary speculative fiction can tell us about the issues in neuroscientific research that loom largest in the public consciousness, like whether the brain is a computer, what aspects of human cognition are required for general artificial intelligence, how personal identity is preserved in an ever-changing biological system, and to what degree genetic factors control social outcomes. Then I’ll discuss how neuroscientists can use the conceptions of brain and mind that science fiction create and reveal as a starting point for communicating their research to non-expert audiences.
theme: Theme F: History, Education and Society

title: Predictive processing by Purkinje cells in the anterior vermis during active versus passive self-motion
abstract:
The ability to distinguish between self-generated (reafference) vs. externally-applied
(exafference) sensory signals is fundamental for ensuring accurate motor control. This is
particularly evident in the context of the vestibular system, in which the same neurons that
receive afferent input also mediate vestibulo-spinal reflexes (VSR). Notably, while VSRs are
essential for postural stability, they can be counterproductive during active motion. Previous
studies by our group have shown that VSR neurons selectively code passive head movements.
Although, the cerebellum is hypothesized to play a role in vestibular reafference suppression,
the exact underlying neural mechanism is unknown. Accordingly, here we recorded from
Purkinje cells in the anterior vermis of the vestibular cerebellum in rhesus monkeys during
passive and active motion. We first recorded neuronal responses to vestibular-only and neck
proprioceptive-only passive stimulation. Simple spike activity encoded both stimuli in a direction-
dependent manner. We then passively applied both vestibular and proprioceptive stimuli
simultaneously (i.e., passive head-on-body rotations) and found that Purkinje cells linearly
integrated these two inputs. However, comparison of neuronal responses to active and passive
head-on-body motion revealed a marked response attenuation for active head motion (~70%,
p<0.01). Accordingly, we next tested whether motor inputs to the Purkinje cells might mediate
the suppression observed during active movements. Most cells receive and encode motor
signals, yet a linear model could not explain response attenuation during active movements.
Finally, we compared the climbing fiber inputs to the Purkinje cells for passive vs. active head
movements and found that the probability of a complex spike firing increased (~60%, p<0.01)
immediately following (~20ms) the onset of passive but not active head movements, suggesting
that complex spikes detect externally-applied versus self-generated vestibular inputs. Taken
together, these results provide new insights into the cerebellar computations performed to
suppress the sensory consequences of self-generated movement to ensure postural stability.
coauthors: Kathleen Cullen
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Identifying Human Postural Dynamics and Control from Unperturbed Balance
abstract:
Upright standing requires control of an inherently unstable multi-joint human body within a small base of support, despite biological motor and / or sensory noise which challenge balance. Without applying perturbations, system identification methods have been regarded as inadequate, because the relevant internal biological noise processes are not accessible to direct measurement. As a result, unperturbed balance studies have been limited to investigation of subjects' behavioral response patterns rather than possible underlying control strategies.
 In this work, we present a mathematically rigorous system identification method that is applicable to study the dynamics and control of unperturbed balance. The method is derived from autocorrelation matrices with non-zero time lags and identifies the system matrix of a discrete-time dynamic system in the presence of unknown noise processes, without requiring any information about the strength of the noise.  
Unlike reasonable `least-squares' approaches, the performance of the new method is consistent across a range of different combinations of internal and measurement noise strengths, even when measurement noise is substantial. We present a numerical example of a model that simulates human upright balancing and show that its dynamics can be identified accurately. With a biomechanically reasonable choice of state and input variables, a state feedback controller can also be identified. 
Our numerical results indicate that the system identification method proposed in this work is applicable to real-world experimental data. Using this method, the dynamics and control of human quiet standing can be studied in depth without concern for adaptation or possible reflex responses evoked by external perturbations, or any need for expensive high-precision measurement equipment. This may enable diagnosis and treatment of individual subjects with impaired balance, and the development of safe and effective assistive and / or rehabilitative technologies.
coauthors: Kuangen Zhang, University of British Columbia; Neville Hogan, Massachusetts Institute of Technology
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Trajectories in Cognition Studies - a focus on embodiment and future frontiers
abstract: The study of cognition contains a vast set of tributaries flowing from "traditional" fields of cognitive science, particularly philosophy and general inquiries into the nature of the mind. What is missing following the last several decades of the cognitive revolution? In this talk, we look at relevant trajectories in the philosophy behind inquiries into cognitive capacity and functioning. In particular, we look at the concept of embodiment and how it shaped discourse, education, and analysis in studying cognition broadly, and in specific arenas such as cognitive neuroscience and computational cognitive science. We also provide guidelines for mapping out the frontier of cognitive studies, particularly examining further integration of embodied & developmental approaches from psychology and biology and their implications for artificial intelligence.
coauthors: Jesse Parent, Orthogonal Research and Education Lab
institution: Western Michigan University, Orthogonal Research and Education Lab
theme: Theme F: History, Education and Society

title: Human Structural Connectomes are Heritable
abstract: Nature versus nurture: who wins? Assessment of heritability of different cognitive, behavioral traits and brain features is a key to this age-old debate. Heritability characterizes the proportion of variation in a given trait within a population that is not explained by the environmental or stochastic events. Recent studies have investigated heritability of complex brain features, including brain shape and connectivity of different brain regions (connectomes). We introduce a dissimilarity metric between a pair of connectomes that is based on statistical network models to assess heritability of human connectomes. Using the Human Connectome Project (HCP) data, we computed the dissimilarity in all pairs of monozygotic, dizygotic, siblings, and unrelated individuals. We show that the distributions of dissimilarity among the four groups are significantly different and are stochastic ordered, from smallest to greatest dissimilarity: monozygotic, dizygotic, siblings and unrelated pairs. Thus, we confirm that structurally-derived estimates of human connectomes are heritable.
coauthors: Jaewon Chung, Johns Hopkins University; Jayanta Dey, Johns Hopkins University; Gregory Kiar, McGill University; Carey E. Priebe, Johns Hopkins University; Joshua T. Vogelstein, Johns Hopkins University;
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Replay slows down with experience
abstract: The hippocampus is implicated in memory formation, and neurons in the hippocampus take part in replay sequences, time-compressed reactivations of trajectories through space the animal has previously explored. These replay sequences have been proposed to be a form of memory for previously experienced places. I will present work exploring how these replays appear and change with experience. By recording from large ensembles of hippocampal neurons as rats explored novel and familiar linear tracks in various experiments, we found that hippocampal replays appear after a single experience and slow down with subsequent experience as greater detail is incorporated. We also investigated hover-and-jump dynamics within replays that are associated with the slow gamma (25-50Hz) oscillation in the LFP and found that replays slow down by adding more hover locations, corresponding to depiction of the behavioral trajectory with increased resolution.  Thus, replays can reflect single experiences, and be rapidly modified by subsequent experience to incorporate more detail, consistent with their proposed role as a basic mechanism of hippocampally dependent memory.
coauthors: Ting Feng, Philips Research North America, Cambridge, MA; Delia Silva, 4 L.E.K. Life Sciences, Boston, MA; Xiaojing Wu, Comprehensive Epilepsy Ctr., NYU Langone Med. Ctr., New York, NY; Ellen Ambrose, Protenus, Baltimore, MD; Brad Pfeiffer, 7 Department of Neuroscience, UT Southwestern Medical Center, Dallas, TX; David Foster, University of California Berkeley
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Microstimulation and optogenetics: A combined stimulation strategy
abstract: It has been well studied that intracortical microstimulation is sufficient to drive action potential generation in cortical neurons of awake behaving animals. However, in certain sensory regions of the brain, microstimulation is difficult to implement due to the overlap of functional regions covered by the spreading electrical current. In the primary somatosensory cortex for example, neurons representing features of tactile perception such as motion or texture are intermixed in functional circuits at the cellular level. Therefore, microstimulation of these regions can lead to the activation of multiple feature-encoding neurons simultaneously, which limits the ability of microstimulation to drive functional haptic perception. In contrast to ICMS, optogenetics is a technique capable of driving units with single-cell precision for both activation (channelrhodopsin) and inactivation (halorhodopsin). Optogenetics however requires direct exposure to light and therefore is limited in spatial depth and reach. The goal of this project is to reduce the ambiguity of artificial sensations by implementing a combined strategy of microstimulation and optogenetics to selectively silence cells activated by microstimulation using a biologically constrained model. A biologically constrained computational model was constructed in MATLab to analyze the population responses to electrical and optogenetic stimuli. The individual current and luminous intensity contributions are summated and included in a Poisson spiking model to determine neural activation. To test our predictions, we first analyzed how a single optoelectrode affects the neural sets within the population. This analysis was expanded to include the interaction of multiple optoelectrodes within the subspace to achieve a desired stimulation pattern. A particle swarm optimization algorithm was utilized to locate optimal stimulus combinations resulting in the best SNR for motion representation.
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Novel functions of oligodendrocytes and myelin in axonal energy metabolism
institution: Max Planck Institute of Experimental Medicine
theme: Theme B: Neural Excitability, Synapses, and Glia

title: Finger stability in precision grips
abstract: Stable precision grips underlie human hand dexterity. However, multi-link chains like our fingers are inherently prone to the mechanical instability of buckling, where the finger snaps into a hyper-extended posture when applying tip forces. How the neuromuscular control suppresses buckling instabilities in healthy fingers remains unknown. Using experiments and mathematical modeling, we show that human fingers maintain stability by using an open-loop strategy based on muscle stiffness, rather than sensorimotor feedback. In an experiment, we instructed people to maximize their index fingertip's forces in self-selected postures. The occasional buckling events were too fast for neural feedback control to stabilize, suggesting that stable finger postures rely on muscle stiffness. However, using a biomechanical model of the index finger activated by seven muscles, we found that muscle stiffness is also insufficient for stable grips at maximal forces unless we add extra stiffness to stabilize the finger joints. We tested this prediction in 23 subjects. Attaching a stiffening splint to the finger increased the maximal force by 69±14% and total muscle electromyography readings from two flexors by 85±23% compared to the finger without splint (mean±standard error). Therefore, people do not apply their true maximal force unless extra stiffness allows their muscles to apply higher force without compromising stability. We calculated the viable space of muscle activities that satisfy the finger's equilibrium and stability constraints using the biomechanical model. The viable activation patterns lie within a six-dimensional convex hyperplane that is embedded in the seven-dimensional space of normalized muscle activations. Within this viable space, muscle co-contraction could stabilize submaximal but not maximal forces. More stiffness aids stability but compromises compliance, essential for the adaptive grasping of complex objects geometries. Thus, we show how the interaction between finger mechanics and neural control of muscle stiffness affects hand function.
coauthors: Neelima Sharma, Yale University; Madhusudhan Venkadesan, Yale University
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: MiniSymposium on Deciding Actions: Will Norton, Oded Rechavi, Dayu Lin
abstract:
Will Norton, Department of Neuroscience, Psychology and Behaviour University of Leicester, "Genetic basis of mirror-induced aggression in zebrafish"

Oded Rechavi,  Department of Neurobiology, Tel-Aviv University, "Inherited memories"

Dayu Lin, Department of Psychiatry, NYU Langone Health Center, New York, "The neural circuit of aggression: innate yet flexible"
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Alpha-beta oscillations in the human substantia nigra signal the anticipation of appetitive and aversive social feedback: evidence from intracranial recordings
abstract: The substantia nigra/ventral tegmental area (SN/VTA) is well known for its involvement in reward anticipation and prediction error signaling. Moreover, recent work in animals shows that the SN/VTA does not only process rewarding but also aversive events. However, direct evidence from human subjects, which often learn through social interactions, is sparse. Therefore, we used intracranial electroencephalography recordings (iEEG) from SN dopamine (DA) neurons in Parkinson’s Disease (PD) patients (n=12, intraoperative, off medication) in combination with a social incentive delay task (SID) including photos of either neutral, approving or disapproving faces. At the behavioral level, patients’ response times did not differ between conditions. Healthy controls (young adults n=51; older adults n=52) and a slightly larger control group of PD patients (n = 19, on and off medication) exposed faster responses when anticipating positive and negative versus neutral feedback. Finally, time-frequency analysis revealed an effect within the alpha-beta range (8-20 Hz) from 300-600 ms after cue onset. Specifically, alpha-beta power significantly increased for positive vs neutral and negative vs neutral cues, but there was no significant difference between positive vs negative cues. As such, our findings provide new evidence for a role of the SN in processing appetitive and aversive social information via specific oscillatory mechanisms in the alpha-beta range.
coauthors: Alexandra Sobczak, Institute of Psychology I, University of Lübeck, Ratzeburger Allee 160, 23562 Lübeck, Germany; Eva M. Bauch, Faculty of Life Sciences, University of Applied Sciences and Medical University, Am Kaiserkai 1, 20457 Hamburg; Kai Heimrath, Departments of Neurology and Stereotactic Neurosurgery, Otto-von-Guericke University, Leipziger Straße 44, 39120 Magdeburg, Germany; Norbert Brüggemann, Klinik für Neurologie, University of Lübeck, Ratzeburger Allee 160, 23562 Lübeck, Germany; Christina Lohse, Klinik für Neurologie, University of Lübeck, Ratzeburger Allee 160, 23562 Lübeck, Germany; Hermann Hinrichs, Departments of Neurology and Stereotactic Neurosurgery, Otto-von-Guericke University, Leipziger Straße 44, 39120 Magdeburg, Germany; Friedhelm C. Schmitt, Departments of Neurology and Stereotactic Neurosurgery, Otto-von-Guericke University, Leipziger Straße 44, 39120 Magdeburg, Germany; Jürgen Voges, Departments of Neurology and Stereotactic Neurosurgery, Otto-von-Guericke University, Leipziger Straße 44, 39120 Magdeburg, Germany; Hans-Jochen Heinze, Departments of Neurology and Stereotactic Neurosurgery, Otto-von-Guericke University, Leipziger Straße 44, 39120 Magdeburg, Germany, Department of Behavioral Neurology, Leibniz Institute for Neurobiology. Leipziger Straße 44, 39120 Magdeburg, Germany; Tino Zaehle, Departments of Neurology and Stereotactic Neurosurgery, Otto-von-Guericke University, Leipziger Straße 44, 39120 Magdeburg, Germany, Department of Behavioral Neurology, Leibniz Institute for Neurobiology. Leipziger Straße 44, 39120 Magdeburg, Germany; Nico Bunzeck, Institute of Psychology I, University of Lübeck, Ratzeburger Allee 160, 23562 Lübeck, Germany
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Graph Quilting: Graph Structure Learning from Non-Simultaneous Neural Recordings
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Mesoscale brain dynamics reorganizes and stabilizes during learning tactile discrimination task
abstract: Adaptive behavior is coordinated by neuronal networks that are distributed across multiple brain regions. How cross-regional interactions reorganize during learning remains elusive. We applied multi-fiber photometry to chronically record simultaneous activity of 12-48 mouse brain regions while mice learned a tactile discrimination task. We found that with learning most regions shifted their peak activity from reward-related action to the reward-predicting stimulus. We corroborated this finding by functional connectivity estimation using transfer entropy, which revealed growth and stabilization of mesoscale networks encompassing basal ganglia, thalamus, cortex, and hippocampus, especially during stimulus presentation. The internal globus pallidus, ventromedial thalamus, and several regions in frontal cortex emerged as hub regions. Our results highlight the cooperative action of distributed brain regions to establish goal-oriented mesoscale network dynamics during learning.
coauthors: Aleksejs Fomins, University of Zurich; Leonardo Novelli, University of Zurich; Fritjof Helmchen, University of Zurich;
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Investigating How Aesthetic Preferences Change Over Time
abstract: Everyday experience suggests that our aesthetic preferences change throughout the course of our lives, sometimes quite abruptly. However, much of the existing research surrounding aesthetic preferences does not consider the impact of such changes. Understanding how and why our preferences may change over time is important not only for fields such as neuroaesthetics, marketing, and neuroeconomics, but for cognitive sciences overall. Here, we investigated how aesthetic preferences for different colored shirts, cars, and phone cases changed over a 4-week period. We measured changes in preferences for these three categories on a weekly basis. Our results showed that aesthetic preferences tended to drift further from their initial starting point as time went on. This effect was consistent for all three categories. We further found that aesthetic stability tended to increase as a function of age, but did not differ across sex. To our knowledge, this is the first study to investigate aesthetic preferences across multiple timepoints as well as categories. Our findings show that aesthetic preferences are not stable even at a weekly interval, stressing the importance of understanding how these changes may be reflected in existing experiments as well as in other domains of cognitive science.
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Effects of practice of meditation on Brain EEG dynamics
abstract:
Background: Humanity is going through unprecedented challenges. Chronic lifestyle diseases and mental health issues have skyrocketed in the last few decades, posing a significant threat to human well-being. Ancient Indian mind and body practices like Yoga and meditation prove beneficial in these times.

Aims: To assess the effects of the practice of Isha Yoga on the Brain using EEG

Methods: EEG data was acquired using a 128-channel Geodesic EEG system, in 7 advanced meditators, 5 novice meditators, and 6 controls (those with no previous history of any meditation). EEG data was recorded in all the three groups for 62 minutes (4 mins rest – 30 mins cognitive task – 4 mins rest – 6 mins of Pranayama – 14 mins of meditation – 4 mins of rest). EEG data preprocessing was done using Makoto’s PREP pipeline in EEGLAB v13.4.4b and MATLAB version R2017a.

Results: There was a statistically significant difference (p < 0.05 with FDR correction) in power spectral plots between the three groups: For Pranayama at 6 – 8 Hz (frontal mid-line and occipital regions) and 30 – 40 Hz (fronto-parietal and occipital regions); For Meditation at 6 – 8 Hz (occipital regions) and 30 – 40 Hz (Frontal and occipital regions)

Conclusion: Advanced practitioners of Isha Yoga had an increased frontal mid-line theta power (indicating greater parasympathetic activation and calmness) and an increased gamma wave power (indicating brain-wide synchronization and a high degree of attentional control). The results indicate that the long-term practice of Isha Yoga leads to greater well-being and higher cognitive control.
coauthors: Prof. Bindu M. Kutty; Dr. John P John; Prof. Seema Mehrotra
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: How the Mind Creates Structure: Hierarchical Learning of Complex Action Sequences
abstract:
Humans have the astonishing ability to learn from small amounts of data in reward-sparse environments, and to efficiently create multi-step goal-directed action plans. How humans aquire the representations that support this ability has fascinated researchers in psychology and artiﬁcial intelligence for decades. We investigate the contributions of two mechanisms: curiosity, the intrinsic motivation to explore the effects actions have on the environment; and hierarchical structure, the representation of goals and actions across multiple levels of abstraction.
To test this hypothesis, we asked 60 undergraduate participants (49 females) to participate in a task in which they operated a star-making machine using their computer keyboard, with the goal of collecting as many stars as possible. 
Participants needed to learn four 4-key sequences that led to 4 different stars. Each 4-key sequence was made up of two successive 2-key sequences. The 2-key sequences were one of four possible shared across stars, and their successful execution was signaled visually (triggering curiosity), but not rewarded. We asked whether participants learned and employed this underlying structure to obtain stars. Indeed, response time (RT) patterns revealed a strong segmentation of participants’ 4-key sequences into two 2-key sequences, with markedly speeded RTs on actions 2 and 4 of the sequence, compared to actions 1 and 3. This suggests that participants learned the 2-key sequences and used them as a basis to explore 4-key sequences. The strength of RT segmentation was related to performance, such that high levels of segmentation—suggesting exploration in the space of 2-key sequences—was related to faster learning. After learning, participants underwent an unsignaled transfer block, in which either 2-key sequences were modified by exchanging component keys (low-level transfer), or 4-key sequences were modified by exchanging component 2-key sequences (high-level transfer). Participants showed faster relearning after high-level than low-level transfer, suggesting that high-level policies were more malleable and low-level policies were more automated. 
This research sheds light on the cognitive processes involved in representation learning for decision making. Faced with the natural world’s combinatorial explosion of possibilities, humans might bootstrap learning by shifting the level of exploration from basic actions to compound action sequences, which are themselves learned through curiosity.
coauthors: Anne CE Collins
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Evaluation of Anti-Parkinson’s activity of Herbomineral (Abhrak bhasma) on Rotenone induced Parkinson’s disease in Drosophila melanogaster.
abstract:
Background and rationale: The study was designed to validate the claims in Ayurveda regarding the efficacy of Ayurvedic drugs in neurodegenerative disorders. It was decided to conduct an efficacy study of a herbomineral drug (Abhrak bhasma) on Parkinson’s disease induced chemically in Drosophila melanogaster (fly). Parkinson’s disease has symptom descriptions in Ayurveda and modern medicine. The latter offers only the symptomatic therapy by replacing dopamine, the neurotransmitter involved, but does not slow down or reverse the loss of dopaminergic neurons.
Methods: Rotenone, in a final concentration of 125 μM, was induced for inducing Parkinson’s disease in Drosophila melanogaster. Table concentration of bhasma samples were selected on the basis of viability assays carried out in our lab. The group serving as negative control will not have the study drugs in the cornmeal medium and the flies from positive control will be fed with L-dopa dissolved in the medium in the concentration of 1 mM. The flies in the bottle will be maintained for a period of 7 days at 25OC. On the 8th day, they will be subjected to climbing assay. The brain tissue of Drosophila melanogaster will be dissected and be subjected to biochemical estimations- Malondialdehyde, Glutathione, Protein estimation and Dopamine estimation.
Results: Climbing assays showed a significant reduction in the climbing/ motor ability between the contrel and disease control groups. There was a significant improvement in the climbing ability of flies fed with l-dopa and study drugs. Inflammatory markers and Dopamine levels were improved in the group fed with the drug. 
Conclusion:  Herbomineral (Abhrak bhasma) were found to be effective in reducing the rotenone induced dopaminergic loss of neurons.
Ethics statement: NA.
Acknowledgement:I would like to acknowledge SAIF dept., IIT Mumbai and our lab members for their support.
coauthors: Arun Shankar Nair; Dr. Nirmala R. Rege; Dr. Snehalata Gajbhiye; Dr, Dinesh Uchil
institution: King Edward Memorial Hospital and Seth G.S. Medical College (grid.414807.e)
theme: Theme A: Development, Neurodegenerative Disorders and Injury

title: Transthyretin and Alzheimer’s disease: Systematic review
abstract:
Introduction:
Prealbumin or transthyretin (TTR), a protein, is found in various tissues, including the brain. [1]
Studies have found a conflicting role of TTR in Alzheimer’s Disease (AD). [1-3]
No systematic review, the highest quality of evidence, currently exists on this. Only narrative reviews exist.

 Material and methods:
1. We conducted the systematic review as per the PRISMA checklist and flowchart
We conducted a search on PUBMED/ MEDLINE database on 15th June 2020.
2. We used the search function: ((transthyretin) OR (prealbumin)) AND (Alzheimer's disease)
3. We found 95 eligible studies after the three steps of screening.
Identification: Records identified through database searching (PUBMED) (n=346). Additional records identified through other sources (n=0). Duplicate Removal: Records after duplicates removed (n=346).
Screening:
  Records screened (n = 346), Records excluded (n=184).
  Full-text articles assessed for eligibility (n =162). Full-text articles excluded, with reasons (n=67).
Included- Studies included in qualitative synthesis (n=95).

Results:
Majority of studies find that TTR has an overall neuroprotective role in AD.
TTR has been found to clear Amyloid-beta (Aβ) peptide molecules and inhibit Aβ aggregation.
TTR is found to influence A-beta levels in a gender-specific manner, its action influenced by testosterone and estradiol.
There is enough evidence to suggest that TTR in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) comes from 3 sources: (1) synthesis by neurons, (2) synthesis by choroid plexus; and (3) serum TTR also diffuses into the CSF.
Studies done in CSF report that TTR levels in CSF are significantly decreased in AD.
In CSF of patients with AD, abundant oxidized iOS forms of TTR are detected.
Studies done in serum also find that TTR levels inversely correlate with disease progression. Serum TTR levels are found to be lowered in AD patients.
Serum levels of TTR have been found to be a good biomarker for AD for diagnostics.

Discussion:
We could not perform quantitative synthesis due to lack of large observational or interventional studies in clinical practice.
We only searched the PUBMED/MEDLINE database, and did not utilise SCOPUS or EMBASE.

References:
1. Pate KM, Murphy RM. Cerebrospinal Fluid Proteins as Regulators of Beta-amyloid Aggregation and Toxicity. Isr J Chem. 2017;57(7-8):602-612. doi:10.1002/ijch.201600078
2.  P, Russo C. Human brain amyloidoses. Nephrol Dial Transplant. 1998;13 S7:33-40.
3. Chodobski A, Szmydynger-Chodobska J. Choroid plexus: target for polypeptides and site of their synthesis. Microsc Res Tech. 2001;52(1):65-82.
coauthors: Ahmad Ozair
theme: Theme A: Development, Neurodegenerative Disorders and Injury

title: Permutation-corrected independence testing for high-dimensional fMRI data
abstract: Making comparisons between populations of brain scans is a difficult task given the high dimensionality of functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) data. Distance correlation statistics are well suited to performing 2-sample tests in the high-dimensional setting, which have a wide range of applications including such fMRI data. However, the common assumption of exchangeability among samples, or equivalence of distribution, under the 2-sample null distribution cannot be made if there are multiple subjects each with multiple scans, as is often the case. If naively performed, distance correlation can yield significant p-values solely due to these known, unaccounted for dependencies. We develop a multi-level generalization of distance correlation to k-sample testing which accounts for the presence of known dependencies by restricting the space of possible permutations. We evaluate this method on a novel data set of expert and novice meditators each with fMRI measurements during rest and during two different meditative states. The measurements are taken over cortical vertices and cortical gradients are extracted using diffusion map embeddings. The results show patterns of differentiability between certain pairs of states in certain levels of expertise and avoid false positives that would have been seen without appropriate corrections. The code is publicly available as part of the Python package hyppo.
coauthors: Ronan Perry, Johns Hopkins University; Loic Daumail, Lyon Neuroscience Research Center INSERM; Jelle Zorn, Lyon Neuroscience Research Center INSERM; Sebastien Czajko, Lyon Neuroscience Research Center INSERM; Daniel S. Margulies, Centre National de la Recherche Scientifique (CNRS); Joshua T. Vogelstein, Johns Hopkins University; Antoine Lutz, Lyon Neuroscience Research Center INSERM
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: When the ventral visual stream is not enough: A deep learning account of medial temporal lobe involvement in perception
abstract: The medial temporal lobe (MTL) supports a constellation of memory-related behaviors. Its involvement in perceptual processing, however, has been subject to an enduring debate. This debate centers on perirhinal cortex (PRC), an MTL structure at the apex of the ventral visual stream (VVS), beset by decades of seemingly inconsistent experimental outcomes. We suggest that these apparent inconsistencies can be resolved by situating experimental behavior in relation to perceptual processing supported by the VVS. To evaluate this claim we leverage a deep learning approach that approximates visual behaviors supported by the VVS. We first apply this approach retroactively, modeling 29 published concurrent visual discrimination experiments: Excluding misclassified stimuli, there is a striking correspondence between a computational proxy for the VVS and PRC-lesioned behavior. Conversely, PRC-intact subjects outperform this model and PRC-lesioned subjects. We corroborate these results using novel, high-throughput psychophysics experiments: PRC-intact participants outperform a linear readout of electrophysiological recordings from the macaque VVS. Finally, in silico experiments suggest PRC enables out-of-distribution visual behaviors at rapid timescales: VVS-like models achieve PRC-dependent accuracy, but only with extensive training, while failing to generalize to out-of-sample stimuli. By situating these lesion, electrophysiological, and behavioral results within a shared computational framework, our work resolves decades of seemingly inconsistent experimental findings surrounding PRC involvement in perception. In doing so, we have identified biologically constraints that may inform future models of human-level visual behaviors.
coauthors: Daniel L.K. Yamins, Stanford Universiry; Anthony D. Wagner, Stanford University
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: The Development of IT domains:  what you see is what you get
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Embryonic Neuronal Activity in the Circuit Assembly of the Mouse Piriform Cortex
abstract:
Throughout development, neuronal activity plays a vital role in the assembly of neuronal circuits. While this has been explored in many afferent sensory circuits, the role of activity in shaping recurrent intracortical networks remains largely unexplored. The mouse piriform cortex is an interesting region to study this as it contains highly recurrently connected neuronal assemblies which respond to different olfactory stimuli. While the time and mechanism of the development of these assemblies is unclear, there is much evidence suggesting neonatal mice have olfactory learning capability at birth and require olfaction to survive. Given the potential ethological importance of these assemblies in early development, the perinatal maturation of these assemblies may elucidate principles of activity-dependent formation of recurrent intracortical circuits.

Using genetic techniques to label active neurons in the developing mouse brain, I found that the piriform cortex is one of the only cerebral cortical regions that is robustly active in late embryogenesis. I propose this embryonic neuronal activity may shape piriform assembly maturation in utero, which may in turn facilitate neonatal olfactory learning and behavior. One possible mechanism is that synchronized in utero activity of piriform neurons may strengthen assembly connectivity through Hebbian plasticity, and well-connected assemblies may promote robust pattern completion to facilitate neonatal olfactory learning. To explore this, I am probing the role of these embryonically labeled piriform neurons with immediate-early gene labeling and neonatal behavior, and the physiological connectivity of assemblies with optogenetics and whole-cell recordings in acute neonatal brain slices.
coauthors: David C. Wang, Stanford University Department of Biology; Jun Ding, Stanford School of Medicine Neurosurgery and Neurology; Liqun Luo, Stanford University Department of Biology
theme: Theme A: Development, Neurodegenerative Disorders and Injury

title: Offline memory replay in recurrent spiking neuronal networks
abstract: When foraging for food, rodents rapidly store memories of sequences of events including visual and sensory landmarks and behavioral choices, often based on a single experience. In parallel with behavioral learning, pyramidal neurons in the hippocampus rapidly acquire selectivity for "snippets of the animal's experience", including selectivity for spatial positions explored in the environment (a.k.a. "place fields”). We recently showed that a special event in the dendrites of pyramidal cells called a dendritic plateau potential can induce bidirectional synaptic plasticity to rapidly shift the location of a cell's place field in a single trial. Interestingly, this rapid plasticity also results in recruitment of these neurons to fire during hippocampal sharp wave/ripple events, which occur during "offline" resting periods, and often feature temporally compressed firing of neurons in the same sequential order that occurred during "online" exploration of the environment. Here we explore the circuit mechanisms of offline memory replay in a recurrent spiking neuronal network model. We tuned a simple network model with an architecture similar to hippocampal area CA3 to exhibit physiological levels of sparsity, selectivity, and rhythmicity, and found that this network can be cued by random input to emit sequences of neuronal firing resembling offline memory replay events.
coauthors: Sarah Tran, Stanford University; Grace Ng, Stanford University; Ivan Soltesz, Stanford University
institution: Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey (grid.430387.b)
theme: Theme B: Neural Excitability, Synapses, and Glia

title: How representations adapt: the role of structure in model-based planning
abstract: Updating a model of the world that is used for planning faces a trade-off between computational efficiency (generalisation across different contexts) on the one hand and context-specific encoding on the other. Humans are exceptionally good at navigating this trade-off, though the neural implementation of this balance remains elusive. We developed a two-stage sequential learning task which allowed us to probe human state transition probability learning across two sets of contexts. One set (dependent blocks) involved two contexts with identical transition probabilities whereas the other set (independent blocks) consisted of two contexts with uncorrelated transition probabilities. We find that participants collapse across contexts in the dependent but not the independent set of contexts, using information from both contexts to inform choices when adaptive, which is confirmed by our computational modelling.  Comparing the neural (fMRI) encoding of model-derived state transition functions and updating between the two contexts in each set allowed us to investigate where in the brain this selective combination or separation of representations is implemented.  Using representational similarity analysis, we find that the pattern of neural activity associated with using and updating transition functions is more similar between contexts in dependent than in independent blocks in parts of the hippocampal formation (including parts of amygdala and entorhinal cortex). This suggests that, in line with recent theoretical proposals, the hippocampus and surrounding structures may be the parts of the brain that allow for an adaptive degree of generalisation and separation of environmental information, enabling us to both plan and learn from experience.
coauthors: Garrett, N.*; Jüchems, K.; Summerfield, C.;
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Hippocampal astrocytes encode spatial information in their calcium dynamics during virtual navigation
abstract: Neuronal place cells encode spatial information through the modulation of their firing rate as a function of the animal’s position in the environment. This process is believed to provide a cellular substrate for spatial navigation. Growing evidence designate astrocytes, the most abundant non-neural cell type in the brain, as circuital elements involved in the processing of sensory information in several brain circuits. However, whether spatial information is exclusively encoded in neuronal hippocampal network or rather encoded in an extended circuit involving also astroglial elements is unknown. Here, we explore the hypothesis that astrocytes encode navigational information in their intracellular calcium dynamics, a major form of cellular signaling in this type of glial cell. To these aims, we trained head-tethered mice to navigate in a virtual linear track and we recorded calcium signals during virtual spatial navigation combining cell-specific expression of genetically encoded calcium indicators with two-photon functional imaging. We found that astrocytic calcium activity was significantly and reliably modulated by the animal’s spatial position in the virtual track. Calcium events accumulated at preferred locations of the virtual track and this phenomenon occurred in subcellular regions of the astrocyte, including the cell soma and proximal processes. Importantly, using a support vector machine classifier, we found that astrocytic calcium signals carried significant single-trial information about the animal’s spatial location. Taken together, these results demonstrate for the first time that non only neurons, but also astroglial networks, carry information about external variables important for performing complex cognitive tasks such as spatial navigation.
coauthors: Jacopo Bonato, Neural Coding Laboratory Istituto Italiano di Tecnologia Genova and Rovereto Italy - Neural Computation Laboratory Center for Neuroscience and Cognitive Systems @UniTn - Department of Pharmacy and Biotechnology University of Bologna Italy; Sara Romanzi, Optical Approaches to Brain Function Laboratory Istituto Italiano di Tecnologia Genova Italy - Neural Coding Laboratory Istituto Italiano di Tecnologia Genova and Rovereto Italy; Stefano Panzeri, Neural Coding Laboratory Istituto Italiano di Tecnologia Genova and Rovereto Italy - Neural Computation Laboratory Center for Neuroscience and Cognitive Systems @UniTn Istituto Italiano di Tecnologia Rovereto Italy; Tommaso Fellin, Optical Approaches to Brain Function Laboratory Istituto Italiano di Tecnologia Genova Italy - Neural Coding Laboratory Istituto Italiano di Tecnologia Genova and Rovereto Italy;
theme: Theme B: Neural Excitability, Synapses, and Glia

title: Action imitation via trajectory-based or posture-based planning
abstract: Movement imitation is a significant daily activity involved in social interaction and motor learning. Although imitation remains poorly understood, recent research suggests that it may be achieved in two distinct ways. In posture-based imitation, movements reproduce how the body should look and feel, and are sensitive to the relative positioning of body parts. In trajectory imitation, movements mimic the spatiotemporal motion path of the end effector. We hypothesized that people can imitate via either mechanism. If true, we would expect to see a switch cost when individuals change from one mechanism to the other. To test this, twenty-five healthy young adults performed a sequential multitasking imitation task. Participants were first instructed to pay attention to the limb postures or the hand path of a video-recorded model. They next performed an intervening motor task that was neutral, congruent, or incongruent with the instructed imitation type. Finally, participants imitated the modeled movement. Spatiotemporal imitation accuracy was greatest after a neutral intervening task, and worst after posture matching. When the primary task involved imitating trajectories, we observed a switch cost: movements following the posture-matching intervening task were less consistent with baseline (neutral) performance, suggesting performance was disrupted by the incongruence. Incongruent primary and intervening tasks also reduced cross-subject consistency. Such effects were not observed when imitating limb postures. In summary, we observed a partial dissociation between posture matching and trajectory imitation as a result of instructions and intervening tasks that is nevertheless consistent with the existence of two computationally distinct imitation mechanisms.
coauthors: Mitchell W Isaacs, Moss Rehabilitation Research Institute; Laurel J Buxbaum, Moss Rehabilitation Research Institute; Aaron L Wong, Moss Rehabilitation Research Institute
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Using topological data analysis to investigate the relationship between population gut microbiome and Parkinson's Disease
abstract: Neurological disorders are the leading global cause of disability, and Parkinson’s Disease (PD) is the fastest growing of them. Thus, finding disease-modifying treatments for this debilitating disorder is becoming ever more pressing. Increasing evidence from animal and human studies points to a central role of gut dysbiosis in contributing to PD pathology, a potential target for novel therapies. However, standard analyses cannot consider the complexity and non-linearity of the gut microbiome, likely missing many subtle relationships. This study is the first to use indirect association with PD on a population gut microbiome dataset, and additionally the first to use Topological Data Analysis (TDA) to analyse an association of the microbiome with disease. For this, countries in a large, open-access microbiome dataset (sample size N=1151) were grouped based on Years Lived with Disease (YLD). The study used TDA to analyse the network structure of the microbiome data and associate it with these disease groups (High or Low YLDs) and other host factors through network enrichment stratification. We found that the PD groups were associated with distinct clusters of the microbiome network, a pattern that covaried with certain phyla. Specifically, the High YLD group was associated with Bacteroidetes, while the Low YLD group was associated with Firmicutes, but also Proteobacteria and Actinobacteria. The latter two are hypothesised to relate to a lower burden of PD through their complex inverse relationship with Firmicutes, which are thought to be neuroprotective. Thus, TDA is a fruitful tool for microbiome analysis and has extended previous findings. Importantly, the study supports the microbiome as a promising candidate target for scalable novel intervention therapies, such as pre-, pro-, or antibiotics, among others. In the future, we aim to replicate these findings in other large datasets and combine the novel methodology with machine learning.
coauthors: Nikhil Sharma, UCL Institute of Neurology
theme: Theme A: Development, Neurodegenerative Disorders and Injury

title: Neural dynamics of stroboscopic stimulation at different stimulation frequencies
abstract: Stroboscopic stimulation has been previously shown to induce visual hallucinations and altered states of consciousness, state by entraining the brain to the driving frequency, similar to those reported under psychedelics; Although little systematic research exists on the effect of specific stimulation frequency on the experience. Previous studies have used different measures associated with consciousness, with psychedelics to quantify and measure such altered states of consciousness (ASC) produced and its effect on consciousness. The present study investigated the effects of different stroboscopic stimulation frequencies (3, 7, 8, 10, 13, 15, 19 Hz) on neural dynamics, using measures such as signal diversity (Lempel-Ziv complexity) and spectral power measured using EEG and attempted to relate these changes to self-reported changes in experiential content. The results indicated the stimulation frequencies within and near the alpha band (8 – 12 Hz) caused the greatest increase across all tested neural measures, with 8 Hz consistently displaying the most pronounced results, relative to baseline. All tested frequencies led to an increase in all experiential dimensions, relative to baseline and produced subjective visual and experiential effects similar to those associated with psychedelics.  The results highlight the rich potential of using stroboscopic stimulation as a means of non-invasive neuromodulation.
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Astrocytes contribute to motor learning, neuronal correlations and movement encoding by motor cortex neurons
abstract: While motor cortex is crucial for learning precise and reliable movements, whether and how astrocytes contribute to its plasticity and function during motor learning is unknown. Here we report that primary motor cortex (M1) astrocytes in mice show in vivo plasticity during learning of a lever push task, as revealed by transcriptomic and functional modifications, particularly changes in expression of glutamate transporter genes and increased coincidence of microdomain calcium events. Astrocyte-specific manipulations of M1 are sufficient to alter motor learning and execution, and neuronal population coding, in the same task. Specifically, mice expressing decreased levels of the astrocyte glutamate transporter GLT1 show impaired and variable movement trajectories. Mice with increased astrocyte Gq signaling show decreased performance rates, delayed response times and impaired trajectories, along with abnormally high levels of GLT1. In both groups of mice, M1 neurons have altered inter-neuronal correlations and impaired population representations of task parameters, including response time and movement trajectories.
