Thus, astrocytes have a specific role in coordinating M1 neuronal activity during motor learning, and control learned movement execution and dexterity through mechanisms that include fine regulation of glutamate transport.
coauthors: Keji Li ;  Jennifer Shih ; Pierre Gaudeaux ; Mriganka Sur
theme: Theme B: Neural Excitability, Synapses, and Glia

title: Distinct higher-order representations of natural sounds in human and ferret auditory cortex
abstract: Little is known about how neural representations of natural sounds differ across species. For example, speech and music play a unique role in human hearing, yet it is unclear how their cortical representations differ between humans and other animals. In a previous study, we found that humans showed selectivity for natural vs. spectrotemporally-matched synthetic speech and music in non-primary regions, that both cannot be explained by lower-level modulation statistics, and do not yet reflect explicit semantic knowledge. Here, we addressed the question of whether such higher-order selectivity is present in other species. Precisely, we measured cortical responses in ferrets to the same set of natural and synthetic sounds previously tested in humans, as well as natural and synthetic ferret vocalizations, using functional Ultrasound imaging, a newly developed wide-field imaging technique. We found that tuning for spectrotemporal modulations present in both natural and synthetic sounds was similar between humans and ferrets, and could be quantitatively predicted across species, consistent with prior findings. But unlike humans, ferret responses to natural and synthetic sounds were similar throughout primary and non-primary auditory cortex even when comparing natural and synthetic ferret vocalizations; and the small differences that were present in ferrets were weak and spatially scattered. This finding reveals that auditory representations in humans and ferrets diverge sharply at late stages of cortical processing, potentially driven by higher-order processing demands in speech and music.
coauthors: Célian Bimbard, UCL Institute of Ophthalmology ;  Charlie Demené, Physics For Medecine; Shihab Shamma, Laboratoire des Systèmes Perceptifs; Sam Norman-Haigneré, Zuckerman Institute for Mind Brain Behavior ; Yves Boubenec, Laboratoire des Systèmes Perceptifs
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Metabolic syndrome effect on olfactory function, memory and neurodegenerative processes in rats
abstract: Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is a neurodegenerative condition characterized by progressive cognitive decline. The main symptom is memory loss but clinical evidence shows that olfactory dysfunction can occur years before any cognitive symptoms. Metabolic syndrome (MS) is an important risk factor for AD development. Experimental research has shown that insulin resistance and oxidative stress (a core MS dysfunction) promote the amyloidogenic pathway, leading to the development of neuritic plaques characteristic of AD. Whether these alterations participate on olfactory dysfunction is still unknown. We evaluated olfactory and memory function, explored insulin pathway activation, amyloid precursor protein (APP) expression, lipid peroxidation and neurodegenerative processes in the olfactory bulb and hippocampus using an MS model induced by a high carbohydrate diet. We found olfactory dysfunction in rats that ate a high carbohydrate diet, but interestingly memory appeared to be better in this group Systemic hyperinsulinemia hyper-activated the insulin pathway and APP was downregulated in the hippocampus. Nonetheless, these effects were not observed in the olfactory bulb, as insulin activation and APP expression remained unchanged. Malondialdehyde, a lipid peroxidation marker, was decreased in the hippocampus and unchanged in the olfactory bulb. We did not find neurodegeneration in these tissues. These results provide novel information about olfactory function in a model of MS induced by high carbohydrate. We propose that insulin resistance showed a differential effect in the hippocampus and olfactory bulb, which could account for the results.
coauthors: Bryan V. Phillips-Farfán, Instituto Nacional de Pediatría
theme: Theme A: Development, Neurodegenerative Disorders and Injury

title: On the generation of theta rhythms and theta-gamma phase amplitude coupling.
abstract: In the hippocampus, the 3-12 Hz local field potential (LFP) theta oscillation is a rhythm strongly correlated with spatial navigation, episodic memory and rapid-eye-movement (REM) sleep. As such, understanding the origin of this rhythm could shed light on the emergence of such cognitive phenomena. However, how the large variety of inhibitory and excitatory cell types form a theta-generating network remains unknown. We use a previously published full CA1 hippocampus model of unprecedented biological detail to understand the generation mechanism of theta rhythms. The model contains eight morphologically detailed interneuron types and pyramidal cells and is constructed based on experimentally derived connectivity. We find that a 400 μm thick, isolated segment (slice) of this hippocampus model, represents the minimum network that can generate theta rhythms. Guided explorations of this computationally tractable model reveal that theta rhythms are initiated by the pyramidal cells but are regularized by inhibitory inputs from parvalbumin positive fast-firing cells, supporting an “inhibition-based tuning” mechanism. We find a strong correlation between the net input current to the pyramidal cells and the resulting theta frequency, inferring that the intrinsic pyramidal cell properties are theta frequency controllers. We next investigate the control of external input drives to the theta rhythms of the segment model, including the recently discovered inputs from the subiculum. Finally, we leverage our insights to explain the termination mechanism of theta bursts and the theta/gamma phase-amplitude coupling in the original full CA1 model.  As modern pharmacological approaches focus on cellular and subcellular targets, our models can be used to identify cellular-specific pathways underlying changes in LFP theta/gamma rhythms. In turn, this opens up avenues for clinical translation.
coauthors: Alexandra Chatzikalymniou, Krembil Research Institute, University Health Network, Toronto ON, CA, Department of Physiology, University of Toronto, Toronto ON, CA; Frances K Skinner, Krembil Research Institute, University Health Network, Toronto ON, CA,  Department of Physiology, University of Toronto, Toronto ON, CA;
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Computer-aided design (CAD) helps build and share design of experimental setups
abstract: Computer-aided design (CAD) became much more accessible and user-friendly. It can be used to virtually assemble experimental setups, such as microscopes, from parts, design and integrate custom parts that can be ordered for fabrication or in-house 3D printing. Designs can be shared almost without limitation. Here we will show some of the features of Autodesk Fusion360 that helped us to design light-sheet microscope for zebrafish whole-brain activity imaging during Covid19 pandemic-related shutdown, and assemble it in less than 3 months, when we were allowed to resume occasional on-campus work. Using CAD software allows rapid design, as well as seamless distribution of designs with publication. Starting with computer-generated designs provides painless generation of figures, schematics, renderings, and animations that will attract attention of your audience and explain your work better. Assembling setup from parts (such as from Thorlabs or Newport) automatically provides list of parts, which is useful for publications and accounting. A lot of commercial software products have free licenses, especially for academics, which should make CAD a standard of practice. There are a lot of nuance when it comes to CAD and 3D design (incompatible formats, licensing, lack of openness, and other issues) but even baseline, naïve (such as author’s) application of CAD will greatly increase value of work.
coauthors: David Prober, California Institute of Technology
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Inductive Biases of Neural Population Codes
abstract: The ability to learn a pattern from a small number of examples is a central component of intelligence. Understanding how and why the brain can learn in such a sample efficient manner remains an open problem for neuroscience and artificial intelligence. In this work, we study how the structure of neural population codes influences the number of sampled stimuli required to learn an accurate linear readout. We find that sample efficient learning requires a population level inductive bias determined by the structure of the inner-product kernel, which measures the similarity of neural responses to two different input stimuli. We demonstrate that the eigendecomposition of the kernel provides information about the strength of the inductive bias as well as the compatibility of the population code with certain tasks. In a model of online learning, trial to trial variability (neural noise) can either facilitate or prevent rapid learning depending on the geometry of responses. We apply our theory of generalization to experimental population responses of mouse V1 neurons, showing how they have a good inductive bias for low frequency orientation discrimination tasks but do not possess an appropriate inductive bias to efficiently discriminate semantic categories of objects from linear readout.
coauthors: Cengiz Pehlevan, Harvard University
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Neural and genetic bases for human ability traits
abstract:
The understanding of human ability, including behavioral and neurological function, is still underexplored. Current attempts are often narrowly defined and lack a comprehensive basis. However, a better definition of a basis for human ability would be invaluable since neuropsychiatric disease diagnoses and symptom severity are commonly related to such differences in performance. Here, we use the framework of the  National Institutes of Health (NIH) Toolbox, which provides a unified assessment of neurologic and behavioral function to identify four underlying ability traits within the NIH Toolbox normative data (n = 1369): 1: Motor-endurance, 2: Emotional processing, 3: Executive and cognitive function, and 4: Social interaction. Using the Human Connectome Project young adult dataset (n = 778) we showed that two traits, Motor-endurance and Executive and cognitive function were reliably associated with specific brain functional networks (r^2=0.305±0.021). Moreover, we showed the biological nature of these ability traits by calculating their heritability (31% and 49% respectively) from twin data.
Therefore, we characterize human ability using the NIH Toolbox as a framework. Looking forward, this framework allows us to determine connections between the trait space and clinical outcomes in different neurophysiological conditions, such as chronic pain.
coauthors: Jannis Bielefeld, Department of Physiology, Northwestern University Feinberg School of Medicine; Rami Jabakhanji, Department of Physiology, Northwestern University Feinberg School of Medicine;Diane Reckziegel,Department of Physiology, Northwestern University Feinberg School of Medicine; James W Griffith, Department of Medical Social Sciences, Feinberg School of Medicine, Northwestern University; Apkar Vania Apkarian, Department of Physiology, Northwestern University Feinberg School of Medicine,  & Center for Translational Pain Research, Feinberg School of Medicine, Northwestern  & Department of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation, Feinberg School of Medicine, Northwestern University & Department of Anesthesiology, Feinberg School of Medicine, Northwestern University.
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: FootSim: Modeling tactile responses from the sole of the foot
abstract: Cutaneous feedback from the foot sole is crucial for balance control and gait, but how relevant information is encoded in neural afferent populations during these behaviours is mostly unknown. Electrophysiological data can be obtained in humans but is limited to single afferents and passive stimulation. Here, we present a computational model that simulates neural spiking responses from a full population of mechanoreceptive afferents innervating the sole of the foot. Our work takes into account the unique mechanics of the skin tissue in the foot (including depth and hardness) and includes all afferent classes (both slowly and rapidly adapting) that signal skin indentation, slip, vibration, and stretch. Single-unit recordings of human afferent responses were used for validation and fitting of the model. We find that simulated afferent firing thresholds, as well as supra-threshold firing rates, match their empirical counterparts well. As a proof-of-concept, we then used the model to recreate neural population responses during walking, based on empirical data of the spatiotemporal pressure distribution on the foot sole. The model predicts sharp rises in neural activity during the initial contact phase as well as during lift-off and suggests that these are spatially constrained and differentially activate different receptor types. The model will help understand tactile feedback during gait and can be employed to reconstruct neural activity for use in prosthetic devices through direct neural interfaces with the lower limb nerves.
coauthors: Rodrigo Kazu Siqueira, Department of Psychology & Sheffield Robotics, University of Sheffield, UK; Natalija Katic, University of Belgrade, Serbia; Leah R. Bent, Department of Human Health and Nutritional Sciences, University of Guelph, Ontario, Canada ; Nicholas D.J. Strzalkowski, Department of Biology, Mount Royal University, Calgary AB, Canada; Stanisa Raspopovic, Department of Health Sciences and Technology, ETH Zurich, Switzerland; Hannes P. Saal, Department of Psychology & Sheffield Robotics, University of Sheffield, UK
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Receptive field geometry shapes information content of the neural code
abstract:
A phenomenon observed in many neural populations, notably vertebrate retina, is the significance of weak pairwise correlations in shaping the collective behavior of the population. Models matching these second-order correlations but assuming no higher-order interactions successfully describe the distribution of population states and capture most of the information content of the neural code. We demonstrate that this phenomenon may largely be a consequence of receptive field geometry in the retina, and may extend to other populations of neurons which encode low-dimensional geometric information, such as place cells.

We show these maximum-entropy models accurately capture the information-theoretic content of the activity of mouse retinal ganglion cells. Moreover, such models successfully describe a population of model neurons with identical receptive fields, driven purely by feed-forward input. In contrast, cells with spatially-scrambled receptive fields retain the same pattern of pairwise correlations, but second-order models capture only a small fraction of the information content of the resulting code, suggesting the specific geometric structure of receptive fields plays a part. We explain these phenomena using the mathematical theory of convex geometry, notably a result known as Helly's theorem.
coauthors: Vladimir Itskov
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Panel discussion: On Free Will
abstract:
Panelists:
- Adina Roskies
- Eddy Nahmias

Moderator
- Sara Goering
theme: Theme F: History, Education and Society

title: The study of auditory-vocal load on drivers’ performance.
abstract: Recent years in all over the world, car accidents are account for many fatalities and deaths. There are several causes for car accidents such as driver distraction, sleepiness, fatigue and etc. In this paper, driver distraction is under focus. On the other hand, role of passengers is neglected in many studies, while in real situation passengers play significant role in drivers' distraction. In this research, conversations between passenger and driver are considered as auditory- vocal load as secondary tasks. Methodology: There are 20 healthy people young and experienced drivers  (23-45 years old) participated in simulated driving experiment. Each of them passed pre-test (baseline driving) and four level of conversation including general, emotional, second language and problem solving in main experiment. Also DALI as a subjective teat carried out to reflect participant attitude toward the test.                                                                                                                              Results: Results demonstrated that speed and reaction time increased under emotional and problem solving conversations there was significant change in speed and reaction time.      Conclusion: secondary auditory and vocal task may result in drivers’ distraction which can negatively affect driver performances.
coauthors: Masoumeh Korousharami, Mohamadsadegh Ghasemi
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Extending the Neurodata Without Borders data standard to handle new data types and use cases
abstract:
Neurodata Without Borders (NWB) is an award-winning, community-driven data standard that provides neuroscientists with a common format to share, archive, use, and analyze neurophysiology data. NWB supports a wide range of neurophysiology data and metadata, including from intracellular and extracellular electrophysiology and optical physiology experiments. NWB is in use by many labs internationally and is integrated with a growing list of popular software tools and services for data processing, analysis, and management.

NWB already supports a wide variety of data types, but neurophysiology experiments are highly diverse and can require the storage of new data types and additional metadata. In addition, research by its very nature outpaces data standardization, and new data modalities, experimental designs, and tools and services can also require the storage of data not supported by NWB. To support these new and specialized data types, NWB enables the creation and sharing of user-defined extensions to the standard.

As particular extensions gain traction within the community, they may be integrated into the core NWB format for broader use and standardization. We developed a formal, community-driven review process for refining the core format so that NWB can adapt to evolving data needs in neuroscience.

To facilitate the development, use, and review of NWB extensions, we developed the Neurodata Extensions Catalog (NDX Catalog), a novel web archive and associated tools. The NDX Catalog provides a convenient web interface for users to search for, discuss, test, and install NWB extensions. Associated tools enable users to easily create, document, and register new NWB extensions. The NDX Catalog currently has several extensions, which extend NWB to support, for example, hierarchical metadata for intracellular electrophysiology, TTL pulses, cortical surface data, and FRET data. We demonstrate the general framework and workflow for extending NWB and refining the core NWB format.
coauthors: Ben Dichter, Andrew Tritt, Oliver Ruebel
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Motor skill learning and execution in a distributed brain network
abstract: The remarkable capacity of the brain to acquire and execute motor skills depends on a distributed motor network. While many components have been identified, less is known about their specific roles and interactions during skill learning and execution. Here we probe this network through the lens of complex, spatiotemporally precise motor sequences we train in rats. We focus on the basal ganglia and the contributions made by their main inputs, from motor cortex and thalamus, respectively. Using electrophysiological recordings, we find that the dorsolateral striatum (DLS), the main motor-related input nucleus of the basal ganglia, encodes the detailed kinematic structure of the learned motor sequences. We further show that a loss of the DLS renders animals unable to execute the learned idiosyncratic motor patterns, causing them to revert to simple species-typical behaviors. In addition, we find that not only the DLS, but also its motor cortical inputs are necessary for learning the skills we train. This very same pathway, however, becomes dispensable after the behaviors are acquired. In line with this, the loss of motor cortical inputs leaves the DLS activity encoding the kinematic structure of the behavior largely unaffected. In contrast, thalamic inputs to the DLS remain crucial for the generation of the learned skills and loss of these inputs disrupts performance akin to DLS lesions, causing a reversion to the same species-typical behavior. Together, our results suggest that the basal ganglia can play a role in the control of complex learned behaviors which goes beyond traditional models of basal ganglia function. They further suggest that motor cortex ‘tutors’ sub-cortical motor circuits during learning, potentially by guiding plasticity at thalamostriatal synapses. Such adaptive reprogramming of lower-level motor circuits may broaden their flexibility and allow them to store and generate complex learned motor skills.
coauthors: Ashesh Dhawale, Harvard University; Raymond Ko, Harvard University; Bence Olveczky, Harvard University
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Sensory thalamus, speech, and predictive coding
abstract: The auditory (medial geniculate body, MGB) and visual (lateral geniculate nucleus, LGN) thalami are key structures of sensory processing in the human brain. Several studies in humans indicate that task-related modulation of MGB and LGN is critical for auditory and visual speech recognition and is reduced in developmental dyslexia. These findings might be explained in a predictive coding framework, where predictions generated  in cerebral cortex are used to optimise the processing of auditory and visual speech in sensory thalami. However, to date it is unclear whether responses in sensory thalami and other subcortical sensory pathway nuclei can be explained by predictive coding or habituation to stimulus statistics. In a novel study, we used ultra-high resolution functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) at 7 Tesla to adjudicate between these two possibilities in the human subcortical auditory pathway. To elicit prediction error, we introduced frequency variations in pure tone sequences and abstract rules that manipulated the predictability of the tones orthogonally to the stimulus statistics. Our results show that predictability entailed in abstract rules drive mesoscopic responses to tones in the medial geniculate bodies and the inferior colliculi of the human auditory pathway. The results provide first unambiguous evidence of predictive coding in a subcortical sensory pathway – a mechanism that might be used during auditory and visual speech recognition.
coauthors: Glad Mihai, TU Dresden; Stefan Kiebel, TU Dresden; Robert Trampel, MPI-CBS Leipzig; Alejandro Tabas, TU Dresden
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: How thalamic network properties shape sensory development.
theme: Theme B: Neural Excitability, Synapses, and Glia

title: Systematic analysis of goal-related movements in alloparental mice during pup retrieval behavior
abstract:
Parenting is an ethologically relevant social behavior consisting of stereotypic behavioral components involving the care and nourishment of young. First-time rodent dams seek and gather wandering/scattered pups back to the nest (pup retrieval), an essential aspect of maternal care. Over the decades, qualitative observations of the behaving animal have been presented in quantitative discrete units. However, systematic analysis of the sequence of goal-related movements that comprise the entire behavior and which would be ultimately essential for understanding the contribution of specific neural circuits and brain regions, is usually not analyzed. Here, we present results from pup retrieval behaviors of alloparental female mice (Surrogates or Sur) of two genotypes; Mecp2-heterozygotes (Het), a female mouse model for a neuropsychiatric disorder called Rett Syndrome and their wild type (WT) siblings. Frame-by-frame analysis over different phases (habituation, isolation and retrieval) was performed manually using DataVyu software. 
We previously showed that SurHet are inefficient at pup retrieval. Here, the sequence of pup retrieval crystallizes over time for SurWT, while it does not for SurHet. Day-by-day analysis shows dynamic changes in goal-related movements in individual animals in response to the same pup stimuli. SurHet behavior in different phases are similar to SurWT, suggesting that atypical dynamic patterns in SurHet behavior is dependent on context. Tactile sensory perception between adult and pups has been previously shown to be important for maternal behavior, by studies in the 1980s. Based on our results, we suggest that tactile stimulation of whiskers/face and somatosensation of the SurWT body may play essential roles in efficient pup retrieval, which might be adversely affected in SurHet. These results suggest atypical sensory processing in this female mouse model for Rett Syndrome.
coauthors: Parker Stevenson; Devin Casenhiser
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Neuromatch Yoga
abstract: Join in for very gentle stretching and meditation to settle your nervous system down before bed. Show some kindness to your body after being stationary all day. Let’s stretch and meditate together with support! No experience, special attire or props needed, and everything can be done seated in a chair if needed.

title: A role of pannexin-1 channels in an experimental zebrafish model for Parkinson’s Disease
abstract: Pannexins (Panx) are a group of channel proteins abundantly expressed in the central nervous system and many vertebrates' tissues. The channels play essential roles in transporting Ca2+ and ATP. Panx1 is implicated in epilepsy, stroke, trauma, inflammation, or pain. A role in Parkinson’s disease has been proposed, but evidence thus far is lacking.  Here, the locomotor activity and visual-motor response of wild-type Tupfel longfin and panx1a knockout zebrafish larvae were tested after treatment with 1-methyl-4-phenyl-1,2,3,6-tetrahydropyridine (MPTP). MPTP is known to induce Parkinson's disease-like effects in the zebrafish by blocking the Complex I in mitochondria. Short term treatment with MPTP caused a decrease in the movement of the larvae. Locomotor activity worsened after incubation with Panx1 inhibitors probenecid and mefloquine. The analysis of biomarker expression levels demonstrated the upregulation of genes in panx1a knockout larvae with known functions in mitochondrial health and dopamine synthesis. A transcriptome analysis authenticated a broad dysregulation of metabolic processes, such as those affecting mitochondrial health. It was concluded that panx1a channels play roles in maintaining metabolic homeostasis in the zebrafish. Loss-of-function contributes to the severity of outcomes in the MPTP model of Parkinson's disease.
coauthors: Georg R. Zoidl, York University
theme: Theme A: Development, Neurodegenerative Disorders and Injury

title: Facilitation of transmission at axonal branch points by nodal GABA receptors: simulations with a reconstructed proprioceptive axon model
abstract:
Large myelinated proprioceptive afferents branch profusely after entering the dorsal spinal cord en route to their postsynaptic targets in the intermediate and ventral lamina of the spinal cord. At each branch point there is a risk that the action potential will fail to propagate (branch point failure). Recent immunolabelling results have found that branch points are near nodes containing both voltage-gated Na+ channels and GABA_A receptors. Historically, GABA receptors on these sensory axons have been associated with presynaptic inhibition mediated by primary afferent depolarization. We used computer simulations of a previously reconstructed axon collateral branching pattern from a cat proprioceptive afferent to answer two questions: 1) how common is branch point failure, and 2) do GABA_A receptors increase the probability of failure? 

The geometry, branching, and myelination pattern of the axon collateral generated large regions of the g_Na/g_K parameter space where action potentials failed to propagate. Branch point failure was a common feature in the absence of GABA_A receptor activation. Coincident activation of GABA_A receptors facilitated transmission of action potentials, rescuing branch point failure rather than exacerbating it. These results are consistent with the emerging idea that transmission along somatosensory axon collaterals in the spinal cord is primed by nodal GABA_A receptors.
coauthors: Jones KE, Neuroscience and Mental Health Institute, University of Alberta; Bennett DJ, Neuroscience and Mental Health Institute, University of Alberta
theme: Theme B: Neural Excitability, Synapses, and Glia

title: A computational examination of the two-streams hypothesis: which pathway needs a longer memory?
abstract: The two visual streams hypothesis is a robust framework that has inspired many studies in the past three decades. One of the well-studied claims of this hypothesis is the idea that the dorsal visual pathway is involved in visually guided motor behavior, and it is operating with a short memory. Conversely, this hypothesis claims that the ventral visual pathway is involved in object classification, and it works using a long-term memory. In this study, we tested these claims by training identical recurrent neural networks to either perform viewpoint-invariant object classification (a task attributed to dorsal stream) or orientation classification (a task attributed to dorsal stream) and measured how much they rely on their memory in each task. Using a modified leaky-integrator echo state recurrent network, we found that object classification requires a longer memory compared to orientation classification. However, when we used long-short-term memory (LSTM) networks, we observed that object classification requires longer memory only in larger datasets. Accordingly, our results suggest that having a longer memory is advantageous in performing ventral stream’s tasks more than their dorsal counterparts, as was originally suggested by the two-streams hypothesis.
coauthors: John Beggs, Indiana University Bloomington; Joshua Brown, Indiana University Bloomington;  Thomas James, Brown Indiana University Bloomington;
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Modulation of synaptic plasticity in single neurons with transcranial direct current stimulation
abstract:
Background: Lasting therapeutic effects of transcranial direct current stimulation are thought to be mediated by synaptic plasticity. Direct current stimulation (DCS) is known to affect synaptic long-term potentiation (LTP) in vitro. We hypothesized that this is the result of a modulation of somatic spiking with DCS in the postsynaptic neuron, as opposed to indirect network effects. Previous studies with population activity provided only indirect evidence for this hypothesis. Here we aim to directly record somatic spiking in a postsynaptic neuron during LTP induction with concurrent DCS. 

Methods: We recorded single-neuron activity by patching the soma of individual CA1 pyramidal neurons in a rodent in-vitro slice preparation. LTP was induced with theta-burst stimulation (TBS) applied concurrently with DCS. To specifically test the causal role of somatic polarization during DCS, we manipulated this polarization via patch pipette current injections. To explain the observed effects, we used a computational multi-compartment neuron model that captures the effect of electric fields on membrane polarization and activity-dependent synaptic plasticity.  

Results: We find that TBS-induced LTP was enhanced when paired with anodal DCS as well as depolarizing current injections. In both cases, somatic spiking during the TBS was increased,  suggesting that evoked somatic activity is indeed the primary factor affecting LTP modulation. However, the boost of LTP with DCS was less than expected given the increase in spiking activity alone. In some cells, we also observed spontaneous somatic spiking during DCS, suggesting that DCS also modulates LTP via spontaneous network activity. The computational model reproduces the observed effects of DCS on LTP and suggests that these effects are driven by both direct changes in postsynaptic spiking and indirect changes due to network activity 

Conclusion: DCS enhances synaptic plasticity by increasing postsynaptic somatic spiking, but we also find that an increase in network activity may limit this enhancement.
coauthors: Greg Kronberg, Department of Biomedical Engineering, The City College of New York, New York, NY, USA; Hysell V. Oviedo, Biology Department, The City College of New York, New York, NY, USA, CUNY Graduate Center, New York, NY, USA;  Lucas C. Parra, Department of Biomedical Engineering, The City College of New York, New York, NY, USA
theme: Theme B: Neural Excitability, Synapses, and Glia

title: Neural correlates of auditory categorization in the supplementary motor area
abstract: Grouping naturalistic auditory stimuli into discrete categories is fundamental for speech recognition in humans and social communication across various species. It has been noted that supplementary motor area (SMA) is part of a circuit that links auditory information into motor commands. We investigated whether SMA is involved in the processing of the categorization of auditory stimuli. We train nonhuman primates in a task of categorizing naturalistic auditory stimuli. Our results demonstrate that SMA, both at the level of single neurons and at the population level, shows a categorical coding related to both auditory signals as well as the motor choices of the subjects. Our results demonstrate that SMA integrates sensory information and links it to categorical processing.
coauthors: Jonathan Melchor, UNAM; Javier Pérez, INR; Tonatiuh Figueroa, UNAM; Luis Lemus, UNAM
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Towards a computational model of sleep-dependent memory consolidation for associative memories
abstract:
Recent reviews suggest complex picture underlying the sleep-dependent memory consolidation effect across many associative memory tasks, finding strong task-dependency and variability in study design thus limiting overall generalizability (Lerner & Gluck, 2019). Whilst there are multiple theories proposed to explain sleeps role in forming optimal schemas and there are many computational models related to memory consolidation (Rennó-Costa, da Silva, Blanco, & Ribeiro, 2019) there appears to be a gap between the two approaches in their target areas of interest and explanatory scope; most models being too complex or too abstract to guide human sleep and memory research. In addition, there is a lack of testable computational accounts addressing sleeps role in forming predictive codes (Hinton et al, 1995; Hobson & Friston, 2012) in behaviourally well studied tasks.

We propose an abstract, neurally-plausible connectionist model of sleep-dependent memory processing of hippocampal generalization to show that offline generative replay provides sufficient conditions for the sleep effect to emerge in indirect association tasks (Ketz, Morkonda & O’Reilly, 2013; Kumaran & McClelland, 2012; Ellenbogen, 2007). We argue that autoencoders provide an ideal framework to study retrieval-based inferential mechanism as well as long-term memory generalization related to sleep-dependent memory consolidation and inform a predictive coding account of the sleep effect.
coauthors: Yihe Lu, Penny Lewis
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: The time course of decision-making: contribution of the electrophysiological version of the monetary incentive delay (e-MID) task
abstract: The Monetary Incentive Delay (MID) task is a popular tool for studying the different stages of economic decision-making. During this task, participants are presented with a cue that signals possible gains/losses. This cue is followed by target detection, which requires a button press to win/avoid losses. Then, feedback reveals the success/failure of the performance. The MID task has been extensively used to investigate neural activity associated with different stages of decision-making. Specifically, the cues elicit affective processes of gain/loss anticipation (anticipation processes), which induce positive/negative arousal, and motivate approach/avoidance behaviors. The output of this process is integrated (integration processes) with further evaluative considerations, feeding in motivation processes that promote subsequent motor actions and decisions. Also, the delivery of the results elicits neural activity associated with the processing of gains and losses. This study exploits the temporal resolution of EEG to identify the neural correlates associated with these processes. To this purpose, 28 healthy younger adults performed a version of the MID task adapted to an ERP technique. The anticipation processes were analyzed through the cue-P3, which is correlated with the engagement of proactive cognitive control that increases in function of the reinforcement amount. The integration processes were analyzed through the Contingent Negative Variation (CNV) elicited by the cue, which is associated with the engagement of effortful processes to future motor responses. The motivation processes beyond motor choice were analyzed through the Lateralized Readiness Potential (LRP) and the target-P3. The LRP reflects the voluntary motor response after the decision threshold, while the target-P3 is elicited by the target and is modulated by the task-relevance and motivated attention. Finally, the feedback processes were analyzed through the frontocentral feedback-related negativity (FRN) and the feedback-P3. These ERPs were elicited by gain, loss and neutral gamble, and were compared in a within-subjects design.
coauthors: Carina Fernandes; Helena Garcez; Ana R. Gonçalves; Fernando Barbosa; João Marques-Teixeira
institution: Faculdade de Psicologia e de Ciências da Educação da Universidade do Porto
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: DNA Methylation Underlies Sexual Differentiation of Cell Type in the Brain
abstract: Most animals display sex-specific behaviors, such as mating, aggression and parental care, that are important for the continuation of the species. These behaviors are controlled by sexually dimorphic groups of neurons that are defined by their gene expression (i.e., neurochemical phenotype) in certain brain areas. Within several hypothalamic regions, for example, females have more neurons that express estrogen receptor alpha (ER𝛼) and kisspeptin than do males. Little is known regarding the biological processes that cause these sex differences to develop, but our research suggests that epigenetic mechanisms play a role. Expression of epigenetic enzymes that place and remove methyl marks is highest during the first week of life in the hypothalamus and differs by sex. This suggests that DNA methylation is a critical mechanism underlying sex differences in brain development. In addition, we find that inhibiting DNA methylation neonatally by injecting zebularine into the cerebral ventricles abolishes sex differences in the number of ER𝛼 cells at weaning in three hypothalamic areas: the preoptic area (POA), ventromedial hypothalamus (VMH), and arcuate nucleus (ARC). Interestingly, however, zebularine disrupts sex differences differently in each brain area. In the POA and VMH, zebularine treatment increases ER𝛼 labeling in males to female-like levels, while in the ARC, zebularine decreases ER𝛼 labeling in females to male-like levels. Effects of zebularine on kisspeptin also differs by region: in the anteroventral periventricular region, kisspeptin cell number is unaffected by inhibition of DNA methylation, but kisspeptin labeling in the ARC is reduced in females after zebularine treatment. Finally, we recently tested the role of demethylating enzymes on sex differences in neurochemical phenotype. We find that early-life knock-down of Tet2 and Tet3 feminizes (i.e., increases) ER𝛼 labeling in the ARC of males. Thus, both DNA methylation and demethylation early in life sculpt sex differences in cell type in the hypothalamus.
coauthors: Carla Cisternas, Georgia State; Damian Mason, Georgia State; Iagn Kenji Cabahug, Georgia State; Nancy Forger, Georgia State
theme: Theme A: Development, Neurodegenerative Disorders and Injury

title: Cortical responses to symmetry: Source localisation of the sustained-posterior negativity
abstract: Visual regularity activates a network of brain regions in the extrastriate cortex. Previous EEG studies have found that this response scales parametrically with proportion of symmetry in symmetry + noise displays. The parametric symmetry response happens in many tasks, but it is enhanced when the task requires active regularity discrimination. However, the origins and time course of this selective enhancement are unclear. Here we answered remaining questions with new source dipole analysis in a reanalysis of the data originally reported by Makin et al. (2020). As assumed, the parametric symmetry response found at the sensor level was generated by a pair of dipoles in the left and right extrastriate cortex, a finding comparable with previous fMRI research. This bilateral activity was itself enhanced during regularity discrimination, in accordance with original findings. However, we identified a third, and later, symmetry response in the posterior cingulate during regularity discrimination. The spatial distribution of this component was characterized by a strong positive potential over the vertex of the scalp at approximately 580 ms. Unlike the extrastriate response, this previously unknown activation only indexes strong, task relevant regularity signals. This clarifies the neural circuits which mediate the perceptual and cognitive aspects of symmetry discrimination.
coauthors: John Tyson-Carr, Department of Psychological Sciences, University of Liverpool, Liverpool, UK; Marco Bertamini, Department of Psychological Sciences, University of Liverpool, Liverpool, UK; Giulia Rampone, Department of Psychological Sciences, University of Liverpool, Liverpool, UK; Alexis D. J. Makin, Department of Psychological Sciences, University of Liverpool, Liverpool, UK
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Quantification of active and passive defense responses in head-fixed mice.
abstract: Animals display a variety of defensive behaviors in response to aversive stimuli. The particular response that an animal selects may depend on the proximity of the threat, competing stimuli, or the animal's internal state. Responses to an aversive stimuli are diverse and dynamic, and capturing this complexity while also collecting neurophysiological data has been a challenge. In the virtual burrow assay, mice display both active and passive learned responses to odorants that have been associated with an aversive stimulus. As previously described, mice in this virtual burrow will actively ingress (entering the burrow enclosure) or passively tremble (leading to small oscillations in the burrow position). Here, we developed a method to compare and quantify ingresses and trembles. We observed tremble responses that consist of a 4-6Hz oscillation. These responses are more prominent during the presentation of aversive conditioned stimuli (both in duration and magnitude). Tremble, like ingress, undergoes extinction, but is not associated with ingress responses and thus seems to reflect a distinct behavioral response.
coauthors: Jozsef Meszaros
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Atypical Functional Connectivity Between the Default, Dorsal Attention, and Frontoparietal Control Networks in Autism Spectrum Disorder
abstract: Autism spectrum disorders (ASD) are characterized by difficulties in social interaction and communication, as well as restricted and repetitive behaviours. Although widely accepted as being neurodevelopmental in nature, the specific abnormalities of brain function which underlie the disorder remain poorly understood. A growing number of studies have investigated the neuropathology of autism using functional connectivity MRI, which investigates the relations among large-scale, functionally specialized brain networks. Research with healthy adults has demonstrated that the antagonistic “default” and “dorsal attention” networks, which subserve internally and externally directed cognition, respectively, are modulated by a third “frontoparietal control” network, which flexibly couples with either the default or dorsal attention network depending upon locus of attention. We investigated resting-state functional connectivity within and between the default, dorsal attention and frontoparietal control networks in a group of 25 adult males with ASD and a control group matched on age, I.Q., and motion parameters. Differentiation of all three networks, reflecting the relative strength of functional connectivity within vs. between nodes of these networks, was reduced in the ASD group. In addition, the number of nodes exhibiting anticorrelation between the default and dorsal attention networks was significantly reduced in ASD. Region-of-interest analyses identified abnormal functional connectivity of the left frontal eye fields, which were hyperconnected to the medial prefrontal cortex and hypoconnected to the insula, which are thought to mediate context-memory binding and salient stimulus detection, respectively. Finally, graph theoretic analysis demonstrated an increase in betweenness-centrality of the left middle frontal gyrus (Brodmann Area 6), a crucial interconnector node, in the ASD group. These results provide evidence that the typical resting-state relationships among the default, dorsal attention, and frontoparietal control networks are altered in ASD.
coauthors: Naail Kahn, York University; W. Dale Stevens, York University; Alex Martin, NIMH
theme: Theme A: Development, Neurodegenerative Disorders and Injury

title: Multiple maps for navigation
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Neural Mechanisms of Object-based Attention: Decoding EEG Alpha When Anticipating Faces, Scenes, and Tools
abstract: Attentional selection mechanisms in visual cortex involve changes in oscillatory neural activity in the electroencephalography (EEG) alpha band (8–12 Hz), with decreased alpha indicating focal enhancement of cortical activity and increased alpha indicating suppression of cortical activity. This pattern has been observed for spatial selective attention and attention to visual stimulus features such as color and motion. We investigated whether attention to categories of objects involves similar alpha-mediated changes in focal cortical excitability. In experiment 1, 20 volunteers (8 males; 12 females) were cued (80% predictive) on a trial-by-trial basis to anticipate different objects (faces, scenes, or tools). Support vector machine decoding of alpha power patterns revealed that late (>500 ms latency) in the cue-to-target foreperiod, EEG alpha differed with the to-be-attended object category, whereas patterns of the theta, beta, and gamma frequency bands were not systematically different across object conditions. In experiment 2, to control for the possibility that decoding of the physical features of cues led to our results, 25 participants (9 males; 16 females) performed a similar task as experiment 1, but with cues that were nonpredictive of the subsequently presented object category. Alpha decoding was now only significant in the early (<200 ms) foreperiod. In experiment 3, to control for the possibility that task set differences between the different object categories led to our experiment 1 results, 12 participants (5 males; 7 females) performed a predictive cuing task where the discrimination task for different objects was identical across object categories. The results replicated experiment 1. Together, these findings support the hypothesis that the neural mechanisms of visual selective attention involve focal cortical changes in alpha power not only for simple spatial and feature attention, but also for high-level object-based selection in humans.
coauthors: Travis Powell, UC Davis; Natalia Khodayari, Johns Hopkins; Diana Olivan, UC Davis; Mingzhou Ding, University of Florida; Ron Mangun, UC Davis
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Frequent nightmares and parasympathetic activity reflected in increased heart rate during sleep
abstract: Nightmare Disorder, a parasomnia generally considered to be related to REM phase, is associated with vivid, emotionally dysphoric dreams commonly resulting in awakening and microarousals, experienced at least on a weekly basis. Poor subjective sleep quality is characterised by pathophysiological features such as abnormal arousal processes and sympathetic influences, which might lead to fragmented sleep. Dysfunctional parasympathetic regulation, especially before and during REM phases, brings about changes in the heart rate and its variability in subjects with Nightmare Disorder. We hypothesised that cardiac variability is attenuated in participants experiencing frequent nightmares as opposed to healthy control subjects during less deep sleep stages. Based on the second-nights’ polysomnographic recordings of 23 Nightmare Disordered (NM) and 29 control (CTL) subjects, we examined heart rate variability (HRV) during pre-REM, REM, post-REM and slow wave sleep periods, separately. In addition, two types of wakeful periods were also included in the analysis – besides resting state before sleep onset, ECG recordings of the participants during an emotional picture rating task were analysed. According to our results, a significant difference was found in the mean heart rate (HR) of the NM and CTL groups in the nocturnal segments but not during resting wakefulness before sleep onset, suggesting autonomic dysregulation, specifically during sleep in Nightmare Disorder. However, despite the accelerated heart rate in the NM subjects at night, they did not exhibit lower HRV. Our findings also show remarkable differences between the examined sleep stages regardless of the group, demonstrating major changes in the autonomic regulation throughout sleep. Regarding the emotional task, we also found a contrast between the NM and CTL subjects’ HR and HRV, which might indicate altered processes of emotion regulation in Nightmare Disorder.
coauthors: Borbála Blaskovich, Max Planck Institute of Psychiatry, Germany; Anna Király, Eötvös Loránd University, Hungary; Richárd Reichardt, Budapest University of Technology and Economics, Hungary; Péter Simor, Eötvös Loránd University, Hungary
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Towards a large-scale model of sleeping brain: sleep spindles in network mass models
abstract: The hierarchical nesting of sleep spindles and slow oscillations is considered a precursor of successful episodic memory consolidation where it, presumably, sets the stage for memory traces migration from short-term hippocampal storage to longer-lasting neocortical sites. Here we take the first steps towards integrating thalamocortical projections into a large-scale brain model and modelling whole-brain cortical slow-wave activity and thalamic spindles as seen in non-REM sleep. We model the thalamus as a node containing one excitatory and one inhibitory mass representing thalamocortical relay neurons and thalamic reticular nuclei, respectively. We found dynamically interesting spindle-promoting regimes and we were also able to control the inter-spindle interval, spindle duration, and shape of spindle envelope. Secondly, we connected the thalamic node to one cortical node, modelled as excitatory and inhibitory adaptive exponential integrate-and-fire neuronal masses. The excitatory mass contains a spike-triggered adaptation mechanism and is parametrised to sit in the limit cycle generating slow oscillations. Moreover, the cortical node is adapted to include perturbation via transcranial current stimulation. Our results when investigating the dynamical repertoire show that, upon connection, the thalamic spindles are imprinted into cortical node activity where they modulate slow oscillation envelope, and that slow oscillation activity of the cortex, in turn, shapes spindling behaviour of thalamocortical relay mass by affecting spindle duration and inter-spindle interval. Our connected model also conserves the phase-phase and phase-amplitude couplings reported in the literature on observed EEG data. Our results suggest that thalamic mass model of spindle activity can be connected to various mass or mean-field models of cortical nodes and, after careful treatment of network connections and delays, we believe that our conclusions would carry over to the large-scale network model.
coauthors: Nikola Jajcay, TU Berlin, Institute of Computer Science, CAS, Prague; Klaus Obermayer, TU Berlin, Bernstein Center for Computational Neuroscience Berlin
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: First-Gen In Neuro: Stories of Science From First-Generation Scholars
abstract:
Science is a winding road of obstacles, struggles, and detours. However, the vast majority of the science we see is presented in its most pristine form. We see the published paper, the perfectly curated powerpoint, the tenure announcement, the notice of award. Rarely do we hear about the journey. In this event, a series of incredibly successful first-generation scholars will tell their personal stories in science. These brief talks will focus on how they became scientists, how they navigated the unfamiliar territory of academia, and the barriers they faced along the way. This will be followed by a panel discussion and Q&A session. These stories will uplift early-career scientists and amplify a community of scholars struggling through a system that is not structured for their success.

Organizers:
- Daniel L. Gonzales, PhD (HHMI Hanna Gray Fellow, Purdue University_

- Caroline Palavicino-Maggio, PhD (Postdoctoral Researcher, Harvard Medical School)

Panelists:
- Steve Ramirez, Assistant Professor, Boston University (http://theramirezgroup.org/team/steve-ramirez)	

- David Jentsch, Empire Innovation Professor of Psychology, Binghamton State University	(https://sites.google.com/binghamton.edu/jentsch-laboratory)

- Michael Burton, Assistant Professor, UT Dallas (https://labs.utdallas.edu/niblab/)	

- Robert Carrillo, Assistant Professor, University of Chicago (https://www.carrillolab.com/)

- Ellen Lumpkin, Professor, University of California, Berkeley	(https://vcresearch.berkeley.edu/faculty/ellen-lumpkin)	

- Diana Bautista, Professor, University of California, Berkeley (https://bautistalab.weebly.com/)

title: The subjective understanding of actions and emotions in the brain involves the interplay of the semantic network and the action observation network
abstract: How brain areas interact to understand other people’s bodily actions and emotions is still poorly understood. Apart from the involvement of the action observation network and areas related to human body perception, evidence of other brain areas’ involvement is still scarce. In this high-resolution 7T fMRI study with representational similarity analysis (RSA), we examined the representational geometry of participants’ subjective understandings of whole body images, using a large set of exemplars of bodily actions and emotions. Besides using conventional univariate/multivariate analysis, we obtained subjective reports of the perceived actions and emotions from the participants, and mapped these individual reports to a common high-dimensional space using pre-trained word embeddings. The representations for perceived action and emotion were high dimensional, both correlated to but not reducible to the predefined action and emotion categories. The perceived emotion representations further contained dimensions for the valence, and for fear and sad expressions.  With searchlight RSA, we found that the left middle superior temporal sulcus (L mSTS) and left dorsal premotor cortex (L PMd) respectively corresponded to these behavioral representations. Further with task-residual functional connectivity and hierarchical clustering, we found that areas in the action observation network and the semantic/default-mode network were functionally connected to these two seed regions, and showed the most similar representations to them. Our study provides direct evidence of the concurrent involvement of both networks in action and emotion understanding.
coauthors: Minye Zhan, NeuroSpin; Rainer Goebel, Maastricht University; Beatrice de Gelder, Maastricht University;
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Neural correlates of computational complexity in a problem-solving task
abstract: Previous studies have characterised a cognitive control network that is modulated by cognitive load. However, these studies have mainly focused on perceptual tasks in which cognitive load can be characterised by the level of conflict or noise in the signal. It remains an open question how cognitive load of computational complex problems affects the cognitive control network. In these problems, cognitive load is arguably driven by a set of features related to the number of computation steps, computational time and memory used. Computational complexity theory has been suggested to provide a general theoretical framework that lends itself to characterising computational requirements of problem-solving. Previous work has shown that complexity affects human performance and time-on-task when solving problems; however, the neural underpinnings of this effect have not been examined. Here we study the effect of computational complexity on neural processes, and in particular, on the cognitive control network. We performed an ultra-high field fMRI study in which participants underwent scanning while solving instances of the knapsack problem, a canonical computational problem strongly associated with models of decision-making. Our behavioural results replicate previous findings on the effect of complexity on human performance. We also find that computational complexity correlates with activation in areas implicated in cognitive control, namely anterior insula (AI) and dorsal anterior cingulate cortex (dACC). Moreover, we find that activity in the angular gyrus (aG), a brain region implicated in numerical cognition, is also modulated by complexity. Overall, our results complement previous findings that use perceptual and probabilistic tasks to study cognitive control. Importantly, we find that computational complexity can be used to quantify cognitive load in problems that are fundamentally different to the ones explored up until now.
coauthors: Peter Bossaerts, University of Melbourne; Carsten Murawski, University of Melbourne
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Value-based decision making in naturalistic vs laboratory settings
abstract: What defines a decision making experimental paradigm as “value-based”? We argue that a number of key features that characterise value-based decision making in naturalistic settings - the types of choices that our brains have evolved to optimise - are greatly overlooked in empirical research in decision making, especially in the experimental setup commonly used in value-based decision making research in laboratory settings, in both psychology and neuroscience. In this talk, we will present the naturalistic constraints that are common to virtually all value-based decisions outside of laboratory settings. Furthermore, we will discuss how failing to include such ecological constraints has important implications for our understanding of decision making. Finally, in view of these claims, we discuss possible new research questions for the future.
coauthors: Fernand Gobet, London School of Economics and Political Science
institution: London School of Economics and Political Science (grid.13063.37)
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Brain-Wide Tracing of Inputs to the LP-ACC Reciprocal Circuit
abstract:
The rodent lateral posterior thalamus (LP) plays an important role in cortical communication through dense reciprocal connectivity with multiple cortical areas. A defining input to the medial subdivision of LP is the anterior cingulate cortex (ACC), which plays an integral role in top-down sensory processing and modulates visual selectivity via LP and the superior colliculus (SC). With broader receptive fields and feature tuning, LP is unlikely to provide precise visual encoding. Instead, LP likely provides ACC neurons with visual inputs filtered for behavioral context and convey top-down behavioral priorities from the ACC to other visual areas. To define the inputs that can ultimately shape this reciprocal interaction, we sought to map brain-wide monosynaptic inputs to the bottom-up LP-ACC and top-down ACC-LP circuits.

Brain-wide inputs to these two circuits differ significantly. Although LP activity is believed to be largely driven by cortical inputs, subcortical structures comprise more than half of input to LP-ACC, many possibly serving as inhibitory modulators. Cortical inputs to LP-ACC neurons largely originate from sensory and associative areas, with somatosensory and auditory inputs comparable to visual inputs. In contrast, most ACC-LP neurons receive inputs from frontal and sensorimotor cortical areas. Notably, both nodes of the reciprocal circuit receive extensive retrosplenial cortex (RSC) input and from higher visual areas AM & PM. Our data also show that SC is the largest single input to LP-ACC. Importantly, these originate from the intermediate and deep layers of the SC, which integrates multimodal information and orienting. This contrasts to posterior LP which receives SC input from superficial layers conveying visual information. This also points to LP as a potential node for SC feedback to the ACC. 

Our brain-wide anatomical mapping of inputs to the reciprocal LP-ACC pathways provide a roadmap to understanding LP’s interaction with frontal areas for attentional control and visuomotor functions. 

Support: NIH grant EY028219
coauthors: Yi-Ning Leow, MIT; Grayson O. Sipe, MIT; Ian R. Wickersham, MIT; Mriganka Sur, MIT
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Flexibility and Predictions in Autism: Findings from EEG, behavior, and machine learning classification
abstract: In stable and predictable environments, the brain generates expectations with high confidence, whereas in unstable environments, this confidence is lowered. Thus, the brain not only makes predictions, but also assigns an expected error rate based on environmental statistics. Individuals with autism resist even trivial changes in everyday life, which is a major phenotype of autism. We hypothesize that their ability to flexibly tune the confidence of their predictions based on changes in the stimulus statistics is impaired. To assess the use of environmental statistics in updating predictions, adults with (N=21) and without (N=20) autism performed a task in which they responded to the completion of a pattern of three sequentially presented shapes. Across blocks of ~120 pattern initiations, the probability of pattern completion varied between 100%, 86%, 66%, and 33%. The ability to infer a change in the probability of pattern completion was assessed with reaction time and high-density electroencephalography (EEG), with a particular focus on CNV and P300 components in the analyses of evoked brain potentials. The modulation of P300 and CNV as a function of stimulus probability was significantly diminished in the autism group. Further, a linear classifier trained to discriminate between individuals with autism and controls based on average brain responses to target trials (at all electrodes and time points) revealed successful classification (~80% accuracy) when all probability conditions are given as input. We also presented a passive auditory oddball paradigm in which the probability of deviant tones was 4%, 8%, or 16% in different blocks. Preliminary analyses of the mismatch negativity (MMN) component suggest that the brain is able to preattentively calculate stimulus statistics in autism. Taken together, these data might indicate that the specific problem with predictive processing in autism is not in registering environmental statistics, but in applying the statistics to making predictions.
coauthors: Seydanur Tikir, Albert Einstein College of Medicine, Bronx, NY, United States of America; Michael J. Crosse, X, the Moonshot Factory, Mountain View, CA, United States of America; Dylan Festa, Albert Einstein College of Medicine, Bronx, NY, United States of America; Jonathan Vacher, Albert Einstein College of Medicine, Bronx, NY, United States of America; Ruben Coen-Cagli, Albert Einstein College of Medicine, Bronx, NY, United States of America; Sophie Molholm, Albert Einstein College of Medicine, Bronx, NY, United States of America;
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: The surface geometry of cerebral cortex induces topological changes of cortical traveling waves
abstract: On the curved surfaces of living and nonliving materials, planar excitable wavefronts frequently exhibit a directional change and subsequently undergo a discontinuous (topological) change; i.e., a series of wavefront dynamics from collision, annihilation to splitting. Theoretical studies have shown that excitable planar stable waves change their topology significantly depending on the initial conditions on flat surfaces, whereas the directional change of the waves occurs based on the geometry of curved surfaces. However, it is not clear if the geometry of curved surfaces induces this topological change. In this study, we first demonstrated that the curved surface geometry induces bending, collision, and splitting of a planar stable wavefront by numerically solving an excitable reaction–diffusion equation on a bell-shaped surface. We determined two necessary conditions for inducing the topological change: the characteristic length of the curved surface (i.e., the height of the bell-shaped structure) should be greater than the width of the wave, and the ratio of the height to the width of the bell shape should be greater than a threshold. As for the geometrical mechanism of the latter, we found that a bifurcation of the geodesics on the curved surface provides the alternative minimal paths of the wavefront, which circumvent the surface region with a high local curvature, thereby resulting in the topological change. These conditions imply that the topological change of the wavefront can be predicted on the basis of the curved surfaces, whose structures are larger than the wave width.
coauthors: Ken-ichi Hironaka, Katsuyoshi Matsushita, Koichi Fujimoto
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: NMDA receptors promote hippocampal sharp-wave ripples and the associated co-activity of CA1 pyramidal cells.
abstract:
Hippocampal sharp-wave ripples (SWRs) support the reactivation of memory representations, relaying information to neocortex during “offline” and sleep-dependent memory consolidation. While blockade of NMDA receptors (NMDAR) is known to affect both learning and subsequent consolidation, the specific contributions of NMDAR activation to SWR-associated activity remain unclear. Here, we combine biophysical modeling with in vivo local field potential (LFP) and unit recording to quantify changes in SWR dynamics following inactivation of NMDAR. In a biophysical model of CA3-CA1 SWR activity, we find that NMDAR removal leads to reduced SWR density, but spares SWR properties such as duration, cell recruitment and ripple frequency. These predictions are confirmed by experiments in which NMDAR-mediated transmission in rats was inhibited using 3 different NMDAR antagonists, while recording dorsal CA1 LFP. In the model, loss of NMDAR-mediated conductances also induced a reduction in the proportion of cell pairs that co-activate significantly above chance across multiple events. Again, this prediction is corroborated by dorsal CA1 single-unit recordings, where the NMDAR blocker ketamine disrupted correlated spiking during SWR. 
Our results are consistent with a framework in which NMDA receptors both promote activation of SWR events and organize SWR-associated spiking content. This suggests that, while SWR are short-lived events emerging in fast excitatory-inhibitory networks, slower network components including NMDAR-mediated currents contribute to ripple density and promote consistency in the spiking content across ripples, underpinning mechanisms for fine-tuning of memory consolidation processes.
coauthors: Anthony J. Blockeel; Hannah Taylor; Matt Jones; Maxim Bazenhov; Paola Malerba
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Endocannabinoid System as an alternative way for neuropathic pain treatment
abstract:
Neuropathic pain is a debilitating condition, which can occur in both the central and peripheral nervous system lesions. Its cost could amount to as much as $160 billion annually in the United States. The magnitude of the cost is associated with scarce effective treatment for this condition. Research made with the Endocannabinoid System are raising its potentiality to be an alternative way for the treatment of this condition. That fact based the production of this review, with systematic reviews and reviews searched via PubMed. 
Clinical evidence has suggested cannabis-based medical extracts may be helpful as an adjuvant treatment for some patients with neuropathic pain symptoms, especially the activation of CB1 receptors by Δ9-Tetrahydrocannabinol (THC). However, side effects related to the activation of CB1 receptors could be harmful, as CB1 is expressed in higher function areas in the central nervous system, representing a threat specially for individuals with a history of neuropsychiatric conditions. Local injection of cannabinoids has shown effectiveness as CB1 receptors are present in peripheral tissue. It has been demonstr ated that oromucosal spray containing equal mixture of THC and Cannabidiol (CBD) induced significant antinociceptive effects in patients with peripheral neuropathic pain and has also suggested the capacity of CDB to reduce THC’s psychotic effects. Furthermore, smoked cannabis has presented better results as a second-line treatment, as it has presented a dose-dependent anti-nociceptive effect capable of attenuating neuropathic pain. The inhibition of endocannabinoids degrading enzymes can lead up to elevated levels of these substances where their actions can produce analgesia. This strategy represents an alternative to the global activation of CB1 receptors, which is associated with adverse effects. Even though the results are promising, the evidence is not strong enough for its disseminated use. There are gaps to be filled, for example the lack of natural versus synthetic compounds comparison.
fullname: João Gustavo  dos Anjos Morais Oliveira
coauthors: Cláudio Henrique Cavalcanti Teixeira, Escola Bahiana de Medicina e Saúde Pública; Cristiana Bello Dultra Nogueira, Escola Bahiana de Medicina e Saúde Pública; Lucca Oliveira Soares Pinto, Escola Bahiana de Medicina e Saúde Pública
institution: Escola Bahiana de Medicina e Saúde Pública (grid.414171.6)
theme: Theme B: Neural Excitability, Synapses, and Glia

title: Statistical tools for nanoscale connectomics: clustering neurons in the Drosophila larva brain and other applications
abstract: Connectomics (the study of neural wiring) is a relatively new discipline in neuroscience. Complete circuit mapping at the synaptic scale (nanoscale) has the potential to inform wide ranging questions in neuroscience, such as understanding how circuit architecture leads to activity, or how genetics or disease affect neural architecture. Recent technological advances are enabling connectomics datasets to scale into the tens or hundreds of thousands of neurons and millions of synapses. Increasingly, learning from and comparing such large connectome datasets will require techniques for statistical learning on network data. Here we describe several examples of such statistical techniques on the Drosophila larva connectome. For example, we present methodology for clustering and model fitting on the connectome, and show that statistical models of networks can be used to inform the clustering process. We show that the connectivity-based clustering is sensible in terms of known cell types, but also suggests new groupings of neurons for investigation. Then, we briefly touch on other statistical techniques and how they can be applied to connectomes. These methods will enable automated analyses of connectomes at scale (such as classifying cells into types based on their connectivity), but also serve as a basis for future work on comparing connectomes across individual, taxa, or disease state, for example. We provide implementations of all of these methods via an open-source Python package, graspologic. For discussion in this interactive session, we also ask the community what analysis techniques will be the most important to develop as the field moves forward.
coauthors: Benjamin D. Pedigo, Johns Hopkins University; Michael Winding, University of Cambridge/MRC Laboratory of Molecular Biology; Ali Saad-Eldin, Johns Hopkins University;  Tingshan Liu, Johns Hopkins University; Albert Cardona, University of Cambridge/MRC Laboratory of Molecular Biology; Marta Zlatic, University of Cambridge/MRC Laboratory of Molecular Biology; Carey E. Priebe, Johns Hopkins University; Joshua T. Vogelstein, Johns Hopkins University
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Hippocampal place cells encode global location but not changes in environmental connectivity in a 4-room navigation task
abstract: Flexible navigation relies on a cognitive map of space, thought to be implemented by hippocampal place cells. In connected environments, optimal navigation requires keeping track of one’s location and of the available connections between subspaces. We examined whether the dorsal CA1 place cells of rats encode environmental connectivity in four geometrically-identical boxes arranged in a square. Rats moved between boxes by pushing saloon-type doors that could be locked in one or both directions. While rats demonstrated knowledge of environmental connectivity, their place cells did not respond to connectivity changes, nor did they represent doorways differently from other locations. Importantly, place cells represented location globally despite the repetitive geometry. These results suggest that CA1 place cells underlie a spatial map that does not explicitly include connectivity.
coauthors: Roddy M Grieves, UCL London; Anyi Liu, UCL London; Selim Jedidi-Ayoub, UCL London; Joanna Holeniewska, UCL London; Adam Harris, University of Oxford; Nils Nyberg, UCL London; Francesco Donnarumma, Institute of Cognitive Sciences and Technologies Rome; Julie M. Lefort, UCL London; Kate J. Jeffery, UCL London; Christopher Summerfield, University of Oxford; Giovanni Pezzulo, Institute of Cognitive Sciences and Technologies Rome; Hugo J. Spiers, UCL London
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Fast-spiking interneurons support the development of symmetrical head-direction tuning curves
abstract:
The postsubiculum (PoSub) is the cortical relay of the head-direction (HD) signal, projecting to the superficial layers of the medial entorhinal cortex, transferring HD inputs from the thalamus. Recent evidence from our laboratory suggests a topographical arrangement of the HD signal within the PoSub, as evidenced by symmetrical tuning of fast-spiking (FS) inhibitory neurons. Specifically, FS cells show a 1-, 2- or 3-fold symmetries in their tuning to HD. The origin of this arrangement is unknown. It could reflect topographical arrangement of local (<200 um) excitatory HD cells. Alternatively, it could result from a transformation of thalamic inputs directly by the inhibitory networks. To address this question, we have investigated the problem from a computational perspective. Here, we developed mechanistic, optimised, and random models to capture the emergence of the fast-spiking interneuron tuning curves based on thalamocortical and inter-inhibitory cell connectivity. 
In a model of structured symmetric inputs to FS cells, constraining tuning curves variance to HD forces the density of each symmetry within the FS cell population to reflect exactly its contribution to input decoding. Conversely, the objective of recreating the inputs leads to a biologically plausible plasticity rule, assuming that (i) FS cells operate in a linear regime and (ii) connections between FS cells are plastic. Although the model accounts for tuning curve and fold distribution, the learning rule did not constraint the latter. Accordingly, a network with random connections that are optimized on the firing modulation of the FS cell tuning curves (range, mean and average but not symmetries) recapitulates the experimental data. Learning of a precise structure of thalamocortical connections seems therefore not necessary. We conclude that FS-FS connections and linear integration of thalamic inputs by FS cells are sufficient prerequisites for the emergence of spatially-symmetric responses in the brain’s navigation system.
coauthors: Adrien Peyrache, Adrian Duszkiewicz
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Visual stimulus-specific habituation of innate defensive behaviour in mice
abstract: Innate defensive responses such as freezing or escape are essential for animal survival. Mice show defensive behaviour to stimuli sweeping overhead, like a bird cruising the sky. Here, we found that mice reduced their defensive freezing after sessions with a stimulus passing overhead repeatedly. This habituation is stimulus-specific, as mice freeze again to a novel shape. This allows us to investigate the invariances in the mouse visual system. The mice generalize over retinotopic location and over size and shape, but distinguish objects when they differ in both size and shape. Innate visual defensive responses are thus strongly influenced by previous experience as mice learn to ignore specific stimuli. This form of learning occurs at the level of a location-independent representation.
coauthors: Azadeh Tafreshiha, Netherlands Institute for Neuroscience; Sven van den Burg, Netherlands Institute for Neuroscience; Kato Smits, Netherlands Institute for Neuroscience; Laila Blomer, Netherlands Institute for Neuroscience
