theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Frontotemporal Coordination Predicts Neural Signatures of Working Memory in Sensory Areas
abstract: Neurons in some sensory areas reflect the content of working memory (WM) in their spiking activity. However, this spiking activity is seldom related to behavioral performance. We studied the responses of inferotemporal (IT) neurons, which exhibit object-selective activity, along with Frontal Eye Field (FEF) neurons, which exhibit spatially-selective activity, during the delay period of an object WM task. Unlike the spiking activity and local field potentials (LFPs) within these areas, which were poor predictors of behavioral performance, the phase-locking of IT spikes and LFPs with the beta band of FEF LFPs robustly predicted successful WM maintenance. In addition, IT neurons exhibited greater object-selective persistent activity when their spikes were locked to the phase of FEF LFPs.  These results demonstrate a key role of coordination between prefrontal and temporal cortex in the successful maintenance of visual information during WM.
coauthors: Ehsan Rezayat, School of Cognitive Sciences, Institute for Research in Fundamental Sciences (IPM), PO Box 1954851167, Tehran, Iran ; Mohmmad-Reza A. Dehaqani, Cognitive Systems Laboratory, Control and Intelligent Processing Center of Excellence (CIPCE), School of Electrical and Computer Engineering, College of Engineering, University of Tehran, Tehran, Iran, School of Cognitive Sciences, Institute for Research in Fundamental Sciences (IPM), PO Box 1954851167, Tehran, Iran; Kelsey Clark, Department of Ophthalmology and Visual Sciences; University of Utah; Salt Lake city, UT   ; Zahra Bahmani, Department of Biomedical Engineering, Tarbiat Modares University, Tehran, Iran ; Tirin Moore, Department of Neurobiology Stanford University, Stanford, California 94305, USA, Howard Hughes Medical Institute, Stanford University, Stanford, California 94305, USA; Behrad Noudoost, Department of Ophthalmology and Visual Sciences; University of Utah; Salt Lake city, UT
institution: Institute for Research in Fundamental Sciences
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Optimal control of approach-avoidance dynamics
abstract:
Animals must continuously adjust their behavior to pursue potential rewards (e.g., chasing prey) while evading potential threats (e.g., avoiding predators). To behave optimally, animals must also use their knowledge about the dynamics of their environment (e.g., a predators’ agility) to guide their actions. The current experiment seeks to develop a computational framework for understanding this goal pursuit.

Computational models of approach-avoid behaviors have been largely limited to describing simplified economic choices, without providing a clear understanding of how continuous actions are controlled across time. Our approach leverages engineering algorithms from Optimal Control Theory, a framework also used in computational models of online motor control. These models are inherently well-suited for describing the continuous dynamics of natural behavior, while being far less computationally demanding than model-based planning over discretized states and actions.

In the current project, we sought to understand how rhesus macaques (Macaca mulatta) played a dynamic predator-prey computer game. Monkeys controlled an avatar with a joystick, chasing a prey avatar to gain juice and evading a predator avatar to avoid a timeout. We used Inverse Optimal Control to infer the valuation of prey capture and predator avoidance that best explained monkeys' actions under a standard optimal control algorithm (iLQR). Our model predicted the monkeys’ full trajectories well above chance, including in held-out trials. The model’s inferred values on prey and predator were also significantly correlated with the amount of reward and punishment at stake, reflecting the animals’ understanding of the task.

Optimal control theory offers rational process models for translating appetitive and aversive goals into extended behaviors, while maintaining computational feasibility. These models make testable predictions about the representations necessary for control and provide a normative baseline against which to compare alternative accounts, catalyzing our understanding of how animals pursue their goals.
coauthors: Amitai Shenhav; Benjamin Hayden; Seng Bum Yoo
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Robustness and circuit dynamics of reciprocally inhibitory neurons to perturbation and modulation
abstract:
Essential rhythmic motor patterns are produced by central pattern generators (CPGs). Half-center oscillators (HCOs) are the building blocks of many CPG networks. They consist of two typically nonoscillotary neurons, or groups of neurons, connected by reciprocal inhibitory synapses. There are two fundamental mechanisms of antiphase oscillations in reciprocally inhibitory circuits: “release” and “escape”. We describe how dynamics of HCOs with “release” and “escape” mechanisms is modulated by their intrinsic properties, neurotransmitters and global perturbations, such as temperature.
One way of exploring how synaptic and intrinsic properties shape motor patterns is to control the parameters critical for production of neural output. Thus, we used the dynamic clamp to create HCO circuits of two pharmacologically isolated biological neurons from the stomatogastric ganglion of the crab. HCO circuits were formed by connecting two neurons with artificial reciprocal inhibitory synapses and adding hyperpolarization-activated inward currents. 
HCOs with “release” and “escape” mechanisms produce alternating bursting for different sets of synaptic and H-conductances. These conductances must be tightly correlated to achieve robust bursting in “escape”, but not in “release” mode. H-current oppositely modulates the cycle frequency of HCOs with different mechanisms, decreasing the frequency in “release”, while increasing the frequency in “escape” mode.
CPGs must be robust to various perturbations. Temperature is a global perturbation that differentially affects all biological processes. We assessed the response of HCOs to temperature changes. Increase in temperature could switch the mechanism of oscillations from “escape” to “release” and, thus, alter the way circuits respond to external stimuli. HCOs with “release” mechanism are less robust to temperature increases.
Our results demonstrate that reciprocally inhibitory circuits with different underlying mechanisms of oscillations are distinctly modulated by the intrinsic conductances, neurotransmitters and external stimuli/ perturbations.
coauthors: Peter Newstein; Eve Marder
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Spatial theta-phase coding in the lateral septum: a theory of allocentric feedback during navigation
abstract: During spatial navigation, the frequency and timing of spikes from spatial neurons including place cells in hippocampus and grid cells in medial entorhinal cortex are temporally organized by continuous theta oscillations (6–11 Hz). The theta rhythm is regulated by subcortical structures including the medial septum, but it is unclear how spatial information from place cells may reciprocally organize subcortical theta-rhythmic activity. Here we recorded single-unit spiking from a constellation of subcortical and hippocampal sites to study spatial modulation of rhythmic spike timing in rats freely exploring an open environment. Our analysis revealed a novel class of neurons that we termed 'phaser cells,' characterized by a symmetric coupling between firing rate and spike theta-phase. Phaser cells encoded space by assigning distinct phases to allocentric isocontour levels of each cell's spatial firing pattern. In our dataset, phaser cells were predominantly located in the lateral septum, but also the hippocampus, anteroventral thalamus, lateral hypothalamus, and nucleus accumbens. Unlike the unidirectional late-to-early phase precession of place cells, bidirectional phase modulation acted to return phaser cells to the same theta-phase along a given spatial isocontour, including cells that characteristically shifted to later phases at higher firing rates. Our dynamical models of intrinsic theta-bursting neurons demonstrated that experience-independent temporal coding mechanisms can qualitatively explain (1) the spatial rate-phase relationships of phaser cells and (2) the observed temporal segregation of phaser cells according to phase-shift direction. In open-field phaser cell simulations, competitive learning embedded phase-code entrainment maps into the weights of downstream targets, including path integration networks. Bayesian phase decoding revealed error correction capable of resetting path integration at subsecond timescales. Our findings suggest that phaser cells may instantiate a subcortical theta-rhythmic loop of spatial feedback. We outline a framework in which location-dependent synchrony reconciles internal idiothetic processes with the allothetic reference points of sensory experience.
coauthors: H. T. Blair, UCLA; Kechen Zhang, Johns Hopkins University
institution: Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine (grid.471401.7)
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Towards optimal source reconstruction of resting MEG of the human brain: performance, precision, and parcellation
abstract:
Non-invasive functional neuroimaging of the human brain at rest can give crucial insight into the mechanisms that underpin healthy cognition and neurological disorders. Magnetoencephalography (MEG) measures extracranial magnetic fields originating from of neuronal activity with very high temporal resolution, but requires source reconstruction to make neuroanatomical inferences from these signals. Many source reconstruction algorithms for task-based MEG data are available. However, no consensus yet exists on the optimum algorithm for resting-state data.

Here, we evaluated the performance of six commonly-used source reconstruction algorithms based on minimum-norm and beamforming estimates. In the context of human resting-state MEG, we compared the algorithms using quantitative metrics, including resolution properties of inverse solutions and explained variance in sensor-level data. Next, we proposed a data-driven approach to reduce the atlas from the Human Connectome Project's multi-modal parcellation of the human cortex. This procedure produced a reduced cortical atlas with 230 regions, optimized to match the spatial resolution and the rank of MEG data from the current generation of MEG scanners.

Our results show that there is no `one size fits all' algorithm, and make recommendations on the appropriate algorithms depending on the data and aimed analyses. Our comprehensive comparisons and recommendations can serve as a guide for choosing appropriate methodologies in future studies of resting-state MEG.
coauthors: Aysegul Ozkan; Maciej J Szul; Jiaxiang Zhang
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Cerebral representation of two languages in the dog’s brain
abstract: Family dogs are exposed to a continuous flow of human speech throughout their lives. However, the extent of their abilities in speech perception is unknown. Our aims were to test the cerebral processing for speech detection and language discrimination in the dog auditory cortex. Using functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) we studied awake and unrestrained dogs (n = 18). As speech stimuli, dogs heard fragments of speech in a familiar and an unfamiliar language, as control we scrambled the same stimuli. We hypothesized that if dogs can extract auditory regularities of speech, and of a familiar language, then the cerebral patterns in the auditory cortex would discriminate between speech and scrambled speech, and also between languages. Using multivoxel pattern analysis (MVPA) we found that the cerebral patterns of activity in the bilateral primary auditory regions discriminated between speech and scrambled speech, this means that the auditory primary cortex performed speech detection; and the secondary auditory regions (the right rostral Sylvian gyrus, the left rostral suprasylvian gyrus, and the left caudal ectosylvian gyrus) were related with language discrimination (i.e. the cerebral patterns of cerebral activity discriminated between familiar and unfamiliar language in the speech condition). No auditory region discriminated between languages based on scrambled speech, this suggests that language discrimination wasn’t based on speaker-related cues. Additionally, we didn’t find a significant effect of the familiarity of the language in the primary auditory cortex response, this could suggest either that speech detection is independent of experience or that dogs extrapolate the rules that they learned in a familiar language to a unfamiliar language. These findings corroborate recent evidence that speech processing is functionally organized in the dog auditory cortex. Our results demonstrate abilities in a non-primate species to extract auditory regularities of a familiar language without explicit training.
coauthors: Raúl Hernández-Pérez, Department of Ethology, Institute of Biology, Eötvös Loránd University, Budapest, Hungary & MTA-ELTE ‘Lendület’ Neuroethology of Communication Research Group, Hungarian Academy of Sciences – Eötvös Loránd University, Budapest, Hungary; Marianna Boros, Department of Ethology, Institute of Biology, Eötvös Loránd University, Budapest, Hungary & MTA-ELTE ‘Lendület’ Neuroethology of Communication Research Group, Hungarian Academy of Sciences – Eötvös Loránd University, Budapest, Hungary; Andrea Deme, Department of Applied Linguistics and Phonetics, Faculty of Humanities, Eötvös Loránd University, Budapest, Hungary & MTA-ELTE “Lendület” Lingual Articulation Research Group, Budapest, Hungary; Attila Andics, Department of Ethology, Institute of Biology, Eötvös Loránd University, Budapest, Hungary & MTA-ELTE ‘Lendület’ Neuroethology of Communication Research Group, Hungarian Academy of Sciences – Eötvös Loránd University, Budapest, Hungary
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Behavioral and neural bases of tactile shape discrimination learning in head-fixed mice
abstract: Tactile three-dimensional shape recognition requires perception of object surface angles. We investigated how object surface angles are represented in the brain, how this representation is constructed from sensory inputs, and how it reorganizes across learning. Head-fixed mice learned to discriminate object angles by active exploration with one whisker. Calcium imaging of excitatory neurons in layers 2-4 of barrel cortex revealed maps of object-angle tuning before and after learning. Three-dimensional whisker tracking demonstrated that the sensory input components that best discriminate object angle (vertical bending and slide distance) also have the greatest influence on object-angle tuning of individual neurons. Despite high turnover in active ensemble membership across learning, both the population distribution of object-angle tuning preferences and individual preferences remained stable. Motor behavior and sensory inputs were not changed across learning, but population response from object-angle-tuned neurons better discriminated object angle after learning. These results show how discrimination training enhances stimulus selectivity in primary somatosensory cortex while maintaining perceptual stability.
coauthors: Jonathan Andrew Cheung; Andrew Erskine; Samuel Andrew Hires
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Minisymposium on "Modern computational techniques for tracking behavior"
abstract:
Talks:
"DeepLabCut: a toolbox for robust animal pose estimation"
Mackenzie Mathis and Alexander Mathis, EPFL Lausanne

"Exploiting unlabeled frames to build better models for behavioral video analysis"
Liam Paninski, E. Kelly Buchanan, Anqi Wu and Matthew Whiteway, Columbia University
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: 3D markerless tracking for human movement science
abstract: Recent advances in computer vision have enabled tracking of 3D body pose in videos as they unfold over time. While movement science is quickly beginning to use 2D pose estimation, few studies use 3D computer vision algorithms with temporal tracking, in part because it is unclear which models would be appropriate for the movements that matter to movement science. Here, we compare state-of-the-art computer vision models on the types of movements (walking, running, reaching, jumping, interaction) and the types of metrics (3D velocity, acceleration, joint angles) important to movement science. We compare models that use different approaches such as GANs, sequence-to-sequence, heatmaps, and algebraic triangulation. Thus, we provide a pipeline for movement scientists to use these models on their video data and provide information necessary to choose between the models by testing them on the types of movements and metrics that are important for movement science.
coauthors: Rachit Saluja*, University of Pennsylvania; Nidhi Seethapathi*,  University of Pennsylvania; Konrad Kording, University of Pennsylvania;
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Investigating the formation and maintenance of a horizontal cell mosaic in the zebrafish retina
abstract: In many parts of the nervous system, the somata of functionally distinct neuronal subtypes are spatially organized in non-random planar arrays. Such mosaic cellular patterns are particularly characteristic for sensory neurons, which in many notable cases additionally exhibit dendritic tiling to ensure complete sampling of afferent information. How such cellular organizations are established during development remains to be fully elucidated. With its stereotypic organization, the vertebrate retina is an attractive model for investigating how such cellular patterns emerge during development. We have been investigating the spatial arrangement of H1 horizontal cells, an inhibitory interneuron subtype located in the outer retina. Using a transgenic line that fluorescently labels H1 horizontal cells we characterized the statistical properties of this sub-mosaic and investigated when during development its mosaic pattern first emerges. Using Nearest Neighbor Regularity Index, Voronoi Domain Regularity Index and Density Recovery Profile, our data suggests that the H1 mosaic is established as early as 3dpf. To visualize the formation of horizontal cell mosaics, we use high resolution in vivo time-lapse imaging and perform comprehensive quantitative analysis on individual cell trajectories dynamics. Preliminary analysis suggests that mosaic formation could be divided into at least 3 phases – proliferation, migration and finally a refinement phase. We hypothesized that cell-cell interaction is crucial in the active migration phase in which cells are sampling the space to ensure maximal spacing to its immediate neighbors. Using these datasets, we are implementing a data driven approach to build an agent-based model to serve as a platform to test various hypotheses of neural circuit formation. Taken together we anticipate that our approach will reveal mechanistic insights into how a distinct horizontal cell subtype establishes and maintains its mosaic arrangement.
coauthors: Leanne Godinho, Institute of Neuronal Cell Biology, Technical University Munich
theme: Theme A: Development, Neurodegenerative Disorders and Injury

title: Differential acute behavioral responses to (±)-DOI injected in a novel or familiar environment
abstract:
Serotonergic psychedelics induce profound changes at multiple levels of neuroplasticity that putatively aid lasting remission from a wide spectrum of neuropsychiatric disorders. In humans, heightened neuroplasticity was linked to heightened environmental sensitivity of acute and long-term psychedelic effects to both emotional/mental and physical context in which the treatment occurs, but such non-pharmacological factors of psychedelic response have been largely overlooked in animal models that remain crucial for discoveries on mechanisms of drug action. 

Familiarity is one of the main environmental factors emphasized in clinical settings. In this study, we investigated whether familiarity of the environmental context during administration of psychedelic (±)-DOI would modulate measures of psychedelic effects in mice – head-twitch (HTR) and ear-scratch (ESR) responses – as well as any changes in locomotive exploration and interaction with novel objects. To do this, one group of wild-type C57BL/6J male mice was habituated to the injection context extensively prior to testing whereas the context was novel for the second group.

2mg/kg (±)-DOI induced a locomotor suppression regardless of injection context, but ESR to 2mg/kg (±)-DOI was higher in the non-habituated than in habituated animals, with a similar trend observable for HTR. Additionally, 2mg/kg (±)-DOI reduced novel object interaction in habituated animals, hypothetically signalling a cognitive shift from external processing of the environment to internal processing of emotional states and mind-generated stimuli. In non-habituated animals, vehicle control group had lower object interaction than habituated controls, likely due to attention competition for exploring both the novel environment and the novel objects, but (±)-DOI did not induce further drops in interaction times.

To the best of our knowledge, this study was the first attempt of investigating the effect of familiarity of the drug injection environment in mice on both the acute behavioural responses to a psychedelic drug and on the accompanying changes in exploration. A subsequent ex vivo imaging study will also be a first attempt to look at environmental effects on brain structure. 

In my presentation I will also outline our future studies investigating whether (±)-DOI can influence structural brain plasticity and cognitive plasticity, referring to an increased capability for flexible cognitive change, in the long-term, after the drug has cleared the system.
coauthors: David Bannerman, University of Oxford; Mark Walton, University of Oxford; Jason Lerch, University of Oxford; Vladyslav Vyazovskiy, University of Oxford
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Supralinear networks with short-term plasticity can account for transient neuronal dynamics in the olfactory system
abstract: The olfactory system is widely believed to implement an autoassociative memory network capa- ble of generating similar representations in response to chemically distinct but functionally related odorants. Classic autoassociative memory models rely on strong recurrent excitatory connec- tions accompanied by attractor dynamics, which exhibit persistent activity even after removing the stimulus. However, multiple experimental studies in the mammalian piriform cortex and in the te- lencephalic area Dp of zebrafish have revealed that odor stimuli evoke transient responses with a precise excitation-inhibition balance. This balance implies that neural circuits may operate as inhibition-stabilized networks during stimulation. Here, we studied how transient responses can arise in networks with supralinear transfer functions by analyzing their behavior in response to external inputs. We found that transient responses can arise when network dynamics switch from stable to unstable by additional afferent inputs and are eventually re-stabilized through short-term plasticity mechanisms. We identified E onto I short-term plasticity as the most promising mech- anism in this process. By contrast, both spike-frequency adaptation and E onto E short-term plasticity were inconsistent with specific aspects of experimental data. In summary, we provide a modeling framework that accounts for transient neuronal dynamics in the olfactory system, which could be applied to other sensory systems.
coauthors: Rainer W. Friedrich, Friedrich Miescher Institute for Biomedical Research; Friedemann Zenke, Friedrich Miescher Institute for Biomedical Research;
theme: Theme B: Neural Excitability, Synapses, and Glia

title: Evidence accumulation in the human brain using a novel continuous dot-motion task
abstract:
Electrophysiological studies in non-human primates have shown that evidence accumulation is characterised by neural ramping activity that scales with sensory evidence. In humans the same ramping activity is reflected in the centro-parietal positivity (CPP) measured with EEG. However, when measuring the CPP subjects typically perform single trials, during which the amount of evidence presented is constant over time. In the natural world, the amount of evidence varies over time and it is not always clear over what timescale evidence needs to be accumulated. 

In this study, we investigated whether we could measure flexible changes in the CPP depending on how far back in time participants should accumulate sensory evidence. We designed a continuous evidence accumulation task in which the amount of evidence varies constantly. Participants have to detect stable phases in which evidence remains consistent for several seconds. Depending upon the statistics of the environment, subjects should vary their kernel of evidence integration. We aimed to retrieve the integration kernel participants used in different task environments directly from the EEG signal and the behaviour. Behavioural results show that participants adapt their strategy depending on the condition. A direct read-out of the integration kernel from the behaviour indicates that specifically the frequency of the stable phases has an effect on the integration kernel. In addition, we show that a centro-parietal signal tracks the continuous update of evidence which differs for different frequencies of the stable phases. This signal seems to be directly related to the decision process as it is much weaker for a distractor stimulus of random dot motion that is shown simultaneously with the decision relevant motion stimulus.
coauthors: Tom Marshall, Department of Experimental Psychology- University of Oxford; Lilian Weber, Department of Psychiatry - University of Oxford; Jill O'Reilly, Department of Experimental Psychology - University of Oxford; Laurence Hunt, Department of Psychiatry - University of Oxford,
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Network Oscillations in Antidepressant Deep Brain Stimulation
abstract: Deep brain stimulation (DBS) has shown use in treating severe psychiatric depression but we don't know how it works when it works. Using modern neural recording interfaces we can study short- and long-term oscillatory changes in the brain related to DBS and to depression. I will present empirical work inferring depression severity from chronic neural oscillations and characterizing the immediate effects of DBS on whole-brain network oscillations. I'll then present a separate thread of computational work, consistent with empirical observations, that seeks to model antidepressant DBS as a control-affine system with both predictive and biophysical dynamics. This work provides a clearer view of how (and where) antidepressant DBS changes brain oscillations and sets a data-congruent foundation for more rational clinical improvements.
coauthors: Vineet Tiruvadi
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: High dimensional neural representations for low dimensional tasks: a compromise between complex discrimination and generalization
abstract: Adaptive behavior in humans, rodents, and other animals requires the combination of sensory cues from multiple input channels. Different neuronal representations of sensory variables can lead to a different discrimination and generalization ability, which entails different behavioral outcomes. In this study, we developed a novel behavioral task that required mice to integrate information from different whiskers to report the convexity of an object. The analysis of high speed videos of the whiskers revealed that the task could be solved by integrating linearly the whisker contacts with the object. This indicates that the task is low dimensional and does not require high dimensional neural representations. However, mouse barrel cortex represented stimuli using high dimensional representations, characterized by non-linear mixing of the different whisker channels. We show that this high dimensional representation would allow the animal to perform a broad class of significantly more complex tasks, with minimal disruption of the ability to generalize to novel situation in simpler tasks. A recurrent neural network (RNN) trained to perform an artificial analogous of the task reproduced both the behavioral and neuronal results from the experiment. Our work thus far suggests that the barrel cortex operates in a regime that represents an efficient compromise between generalization, which is guaranteed by low-dimensional representations, and the ability to perform complex discrimination tasks, which is granted by high-dimensional representations.
coauthors: Chris C Rodgers, Randy M Bruno, Stefano Fusi
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Complexity and 1/f slope jointly reflect cortical states across different E/I balances
abstract: Characterization of cortical states is essential for understanding brain functioning in the absence of external stimuli. The balance between excitation and inhibition and the number of non-redundant activity patterns, indexed by the 1/f slope and LZc respectively, distinguish cortical states. However, the relation between these two measures has not been characterized. Here we analyzed the relation between 1/f slope and LZc with two modeling approaches and in empirical human EEG and monkey ECoG data. We contrasted resting state with propofol anesthesia, which is known to modulate the excitation-inhibition balance. We found convergent results among all strategies employed, showing an inverse and not trivial monotonic relation between 1/f slope and complexity. This behavior was observed even when the signals’ spectral properties were heavily manipulated, consistent at ECoG and EEG scales. Models also showed that LZc was strongly dependent on 1/f slope but independent of the signal’s spectral power law’s offset. Our results show that, although these measures have very distinct mathematical origins, they are closely related. We hypothesize that differentially entropic regimes could underlie the link between the excitation-inhibition balance and the vastness of repertoire of cortical systems.
coauthors: Martín Irani, Pontificia Universidad Católica de Chile; Tomás Ossandón, Pontificia Universidad Católica de Chile; Gonzalo Boncompte, Pontificia Universidad Católica de Chile
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Neural representations of memory and space in freely moving humans
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Accumulation of Salient Perceptual Events Predicts Human Subjective Time
abstract: Human experience of time exhibits systematic, context-dependent deviations from objective clock time. For example, time is experienced differently at work than on holiday. However, leading explanations of time perception are not well-equipped to explain these deviations. We propose that salient changes in sensory dynamics are the units from which we construct our subjective estimates of duration, such that epochs will feel longer when they contain more salient events. We tested this idea in a human model-based neuroimaging experiment with a fully pre-registered analysis pipeline(osf.io/ce9tp). Forty participants watched naturalistic, silent videos and estimated their duration while fMRI was acquired. We extracted moment-to-moment changes in visual cortex BOLD dynamics (“events”), and using computational modelling we show that accumulated events in visual cortex predicted duration biases reflecting human experience of time. We were unable to predict subjective time from two control regions irrelevant for perceptual classification of our silent videos - auditory and somatosensory cortex - despite being able to predict ‘clock time’ from all three areas. Therefore, we show that trial-by-trial subjective duration judgements can be reconstructed purely from human BOLD activity reflecting perceptual classification of the content for which time is being judged. Our results reveal that human subjective time is based on information arising during the processing of our dynamic sensory environment, providing a computational basis for an end-to-end account of time perception.
coauthors: Zafeirios Fountas, Wellcome Centre for Human Neuroimaging, University College London, London, UK;  Anil K. Seth, Sackler Centre for Consciousness Science, University of Sussex, UK; Warrick Roseboom, Sackler Centre for Consciousness Science, University of Sussex, UK
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: BRAIN Initiative Alliance Tools, Tech, Theory, and Trainee Series: Theory (part 3)
abstract:
The BRAIN Initiative Alliance (http://www.braininitiative.org/) is hosting a virtual series in collaboration with Neuromatch 3.0 to highlight cutting-edge tools, technology, and theories emerging from the US BRAIN Initiative. The event is divided into three session to focus on 1) Tools (probes, optics, cellular, molecular), 2) Tech (software, hardware), and 3) Theory (modeling, computation),  with trainees integrated in each session. Each session will include five brief talks/demos showcasing new tools, techniques, or theories from US BRAIN Initiative toolmakers followed by a moderated discussion with Q/A.

This is session 3/3, focused on Theory (modeling, computation).

Moderator:
- Elizabeth Buffalo, PhD (University of Washington)

Talks:
- "Human Brain Organoids and Ethics"
Insoo Hyun, PhD (Case Western Reserve University)

- "SpikeForest: web-based spike sorting validation and analysis"
Jeremy Magland, PhD (Flatiron Institute, Simons Foundation)

- "The Constrained Network-Based Statistic: A New Level of Inference in Neuroimaging"
Stephanie Noble, PhD (Yale University)

- "Uncovering principles of how cortical regions interact to generate behaviors using dynamical systems modeling"
Sridevi Sarma, PhD (Johns Hopkins University)

- "Towards an auditroy-reliant Brain Computer Interface for effector control in individuals with severe motor impairments"
Daniel Thengone, PhD (Brown University)
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Functional connectivity between right frontoparietal and visual networks is linked to visual processing speed
abstract: The neural theory of visual attention (TVA) proposes that visual processing speed depends on the coordinated activity between frontoparietal and occipital brain areas. Previous research has shown that the coordinated activity (i.e., functional connectivity, FC) between the cingulo-opercular network (COn) and the right-frontoparietal network (RFPn) is linked to individual visual processing speed. However, evidence for a link between visual processing speed and the inter-FC of COn and RFPn with visual networks is still lacking. Forty-eight healthy human adult participants underwent resting-state (rs-)fMRI and performed a whole-report psychophysical task. To obtain inter-FC, we analyzed rs-fMRI data within the entire frequency range possible for our data (i.e., 0.01-0.4 Hz) to avoid discarding meaningful neural information. Following previous approaches, we examined the data in separate frequency bins (Hz): Slow-5 (0.01-0.027), Slow-4 (0.027-0.073), Slow-3 (0.073-0.198), and Slow-2 (0.198-0.4). We used the mathematical framework of TVA to estimate an individual, latent-level visual processing speed parameter. We found that the inter-FC between RFPn and visual networks was negatively associated with visual processing speed in Slow-5 and Slow-2, with no corresponding significant association for the inter-FC between COn and visual networks. These results provide first empirical evidence for an association of inter-FC at rest between RFPn and visual networks with the visual processing speed parameter. These findings suggest a direct influence on occipital regions from the right frontoparietal, but not frontoinsular, regions, to support visual processing speed.
coauthors: Svenja Küchenhoff, LMU Munich; Christian Sorg, TU Munich; Sebastian Schneider, TU Munich; Oliver Kohl, LMU Munich; Hermann J. Müller, LMU Munich; Kathrin Finke, Jena University Hospital
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Active probing enhances the extraction of features for predicting seizures in a coupled neural mass model
abstract: Active probing stimuli may be used to uncover underlying system dynamics that would be otherwise unobservable with passive analysis. The use of such approaches could be a way to tackle the challenging and yet unsolved problem of reliably forecasting the occurrence of seizures. That is, electrographic responses to period stimuli could highlight neuronal excitability and synchrony changes involved in the transition from interictal to ictal activity. In this work, we evaluate this hypothesis in two coupled populations of a commonly used seizure-generating neural mass model. Features are extracted while system parameters are slowly shifted from normal towards ictal activity and different scenarios or model settings are evaluated: low-frequency stimuli are applied to the input of one or both populations, while increasing neuronal excitability gain, decreasing slow inhibitory gain, or increasing inter-population coupling. Results show that the use of probing stimuli provided predictive value, as similar feature changes were observed while model parameters were shifted towards ictal activity. Observed changes such as increased lag-1 autocorrelation and increased variance may be related to the phenomenon of critical slowing. These increased recovery times from perturbations could be indicators of the loss of the system’s resilience and are common hallmarks of impending critical transitions. Overall, our results indicate that low-frequency probing stimuli may play a role in uncovering some of the neuronal dynamics leading up to seizure states and assist in designing accurate and reliable seizure forecasting systems.
coauthors: Márcio F.D. Moraes, Universidade Federal de Minas Gerais; Sydney S. Cash, Massachusetts General Hospital; Eduardo Mazoni A.M. Mendes, Universidade Federal de Minas Gerais
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Computational methods for analyzing large-scale neural datasets
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Attention differentially modulates multiunit activity in the LGN and V1 of macaque monkeys
abstract: Attention promotes the selection of behaviorally relevant sensory signals. Attention effects, such as gain modulation of neuronal firing rate, are observed in all visual brain areas, including the visual thalamus (McAlonan et al., 2008; Maunsell, 2015). However, magnitudes of attentional gain modulations within and across visual brain areas differ depending on neuronal types, task, measurement, neuronal feature selectivity, etc. Diversity of attention effects across visual brain areas could suggest that attention effects depend on the functional architecture of a given area. To test this possibility, we evaluated attentional gain modulation in visual areas with distinct functional architectures using an aggregate measure of neuronal activity, multiunit firing rate. We recorded from the dorsal lateral geniculate nucleus (LGN) and primary visual cortex (V1) in macaque monkeys performing a contrast change detection task requiring covert shifts of visual spatial attention. Because multiunit activity reflects pooled signals from neurons embedded in the local functional architecture, we tested specific predictions about the dependence of attentional modulation of multiunit firing rates on functional architecture. We found evidence for unique relationships between multiunit activity and functional architecture in the LGN and V1. Effects were mostly consistent across different thresholds used to sort multiunits and temporal analysis windows. Consistent with single unit measures, attentional modulation of multiunits depended on whether multiunits were tuned to task-relevant visual features. Together these findings suggest that attentional modulation of multiunit activity in visual areas must be considered within the context of the underlying functional architecture.
coauthors: Shraddha Shah, Neuroscience Graduate Program, University of Rochester Medical Center; Marc Mancarella, Department of Neuroscience, University of Rochester School of Medicine; Jacqueline R. Hembrook-Short, Physiology & Neurobiology Department, Geisel School of Medicine at Dartmouth; Vanessa L. Mock, Ernest J. Del Monte Institute for Neuroscience, University of Rochester School of Medicine; Farran Briggs, Department of Neuroscience, University of Rochester School of Medicine, Department of Brain and Cognitive Sciences, University of Rochester, Center for Visual Science, University of Rochester
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Individual Differences in Anxious Temperament relate to Differences in Brain Morphometrics
abstract: Anxiety disorders constitute the most prevalent subgroup of mental disorders in most western societies, with an estimated lifetime incidence of 33.7% in the US. Anxiety can be defined as a prolonged state of apprehension elicited by unpredictable threats, or threats that are spatially or temporally distant. The current study utilized structural images from three studies (N=75) to examine individual differences in different mood and anxiety socioemotional questionnaires (Beck Depression Inventory, Penn State Worry Questionnaire, State Trait Anxiety Inventory, Mood and Anxiety Symptom Questionnaire90, Ruminative Response Scale) and both cortical and subcortical brain metrics using surface-based morphometry. Cortical results indicated that increases in both the STAI and MASQ90 (general anxiety) related to increased grey matter area in the bilateral occipital pole (i.e., pericalcarine cortex, lingual gyrus). While subcortical results indicated that increased bilateral amygdala volume was related to increases in the STAI, MASQ90 (general anxiety) and RRS (rumination). Additionally, increases in bilateral nucleus accumbens volume was related to the positive affect dimension of the MASQ90. Results suggest that individual differences in anxious temperament, as measured by the STAI and MASQ90, may be related to increased visual cortex area, perhaps related to hypervigilance of the environment. Additionally, increased anxious temperament as measured by the STAI, MASQ90 and RRS, appear related to increased volume of the amygdala, again perhaps suggesting, increased threat processing due to hypervigilance. Finally, increased positive affect, as measured by the MASQ90, was related to increased nucleus accumbens volume, possibly indicating the role of dopaminergic ventral-striatal regions in positive mood.
coauthors: Kane, J.M., Schagene, J.D. & Depue, B.E.
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Cortical representations of conspecific sex shape social behavior
abstract: A central question related to virtually all social decisions is how animals integrate sex-specific cues from conspecifics. Using microendoscopic calcium imaging in mice, we find that sex information is represented in the dorsal medial prefrontal cortex (dmPFC) across excitatory and inhibitory neurons. These cells form a distributed code that differentiates the sex of conspecifics and is strengthened with social experience. While males and females both represent sex in the dmPFC, male mice show stronger encoding of female cues, and the relative strength of these sex representations predicts sex preference behavior. Using activity-dependent optogenetic manipulations of natively active ensembles, we further show that these specific representations modulate preference behavior toward males and females. Together, these results define a functional role for native representations of sex in shaping social behavior, and reveal a neural mechanism underlying male- vs. female-directed sociality.
coauthors: Shan Huang; Lyle Kingsbury Lyle; Tara Raam; Letizia Ye; Don Wei; Rongfeng Hu; Li Ye; Weizhe Hong
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: SpikeInterface, a unified framework for spike sorting
abstract: Given the importance of understanding single-neuron activity, much development has been directed towards improving the performance and automation of spike sorting. These developments, however, introduce new challenges, such as file format incompatibility and reduced interoperability, that hinder benchmarking and preclude reproducible analysis. To address these limitations, we developed SpikeInterface, a Python framework designed to unify preexisting spike sorting technologies into a single codebase and to standardize extracellular data file operations. With a few lines of code and regardless of the underlying data format, researchers can: run, compare, and benchmark most modern spike sorting algorithms; pre-process, post-process, and visualize extracellular datasets; validate, curate, and export sorting outputs; and more. In this paper, we provide an overview of SpikeInterface and, with applications to both real and simulated extracellular datasets, demonstrate how it can improve the accessibility, reliability, and reproducibility of spike sorting in preparation for the widespread use of large-scale electrophysiology.
coauthors: Alessio P Buccino, Department of Biosystems Science and Engineering, ETH Zurich, Switzerland; Cole L Hurwitz, School of Informatics, University of Edinburgh, United Kingdom; Jeremy Magland, Flatiron Institute, New York City, NY, United States; Samuel Garcia, Centre de Recherche en Neuroscience de Lyon, CNRS, Lyon, France; Joshua H Siegle, Allen Institute for Brain Science, Seattle, WA, United States; Roger Hurwitz, Independent Researcher, Portland, Oregon, USA; Matthias H Hennig, School of Informatics, University of Edinburgh, United Kingdom
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Effects of the stress hormone cortisol on spontaneous activity in the larval zebrafish tectum
abstract: Early life stress can have lifelong negative health consequences, but we still lack an understanding of the mechanisms that cause this. In the brain, exposure to stress during development is known to affect neural plasticity and excitability in the limbic system. The limbic system in turn is intimately interconnected with sensorimotor systems, which represent key stages in receiving information about the world and coordinating behavioural responses to environmental stimuli including stressors. Yet, how stress affects sensorimotor systems remains largely unknown. Here we used the optic tectum of the larval zebrafish as a model to investigate how exposure to the stress hormone cortisol affects processing in a visual circuit. Specifically, we hypothesized that cortisol would have an effect on tectal physiology and that we would observe differences in tectal population dynamics. We employed two-photon calcium imaging to probe single-cell resolution changes in activity during spontaneous (stimulus free) tectal activity before and after addition of cortisol. We applied machine learning approaches to characterise the dynamics before and after cortisol. Preliminary results suggest that cortisol significantly alters the population dynamics in the larval tectum. These results suggest that the larval zebrafish is a promising model for investigating the effects of stress on sensorimotor physiology and development.
coauthors: Matthew J. Harvey, Kings College London; Martin Meyer, Kings College London
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Inference as Control
abstract: Sensory observations about the world are invariably ambiguous. Inference about the world's latent variables is thus an important computation for the brain. However, computational constraints limit the performance of these computations. These constraints include energetic costs for neural activity and noise for every channel. Efficient coding is a prominent theory that describes how limited resources can be used best. In one incarnation, this leads to a theory of predictive coding, where predictions are subtracted from signals, reducing the cost of sending something that is already known. This theory does not, however, account for the costs or noise associated with those predictions. Here we offer a theory that accounts for both feedforward and feedback costs and noise throughout. We formulate this inference problem as message-passing on a graph whereby feedback is viewed as a control signal aiming to maximize how well an inference tracks a target state.
coauthors: Paul Schrater, University of Minnesota; Xaq Pitkow, Baylor College of Medicine;
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Global Brain Volume is Associated with General Psychopathology in Children
abstract: Childhood is important for the onset of psychopathology and for brain development. Psychopathology is characterized by considerable comorbidity, which is mirrored in its underlying neural correlates. Both common and dissociable variations in brain volume have been found across multiple mental disorders in adult and youth samples. However, the majority of related research has used samples with broad age ranges, which may obscure developmental differences. The present study examined associations between regional gray matter volumes (GMV) and dimensional psychopathology in a large sample (N = 9,608) of children (9-10 years) collected as part of the Adolescent Brain and Cognitive Development (ABCD) Study. A bifactor model identified four dimensions of psychopathology: a general factor, which reflects common variance across disorders, as well as three subfactors measuring specific internalizing, conduct, and ADHD symptoms. Brain volume was acquired using 3T MRI. Results from SEM analyses demonstrate nearly global inverse associations between regional GMVs and the general psychopathology and conduct factors, with significant associations for the ADHD factor as well (p-values ≤ .048, FDR-corrected). Sensitivity analyses including total GMV and intracranial volume as covariates further support this global effect, as region-specific results became non-significant, with the exception of the bilateral hippocampus. Sensitivity analyses controlling for income, parent’s level of education, and medication use as additional covariates yielded largely convergent results. Together, these results suggest that smaller brain volume is a common risk factor for psychopathology across disorders, and possibly for conduct and ADHD symptoms in particular.
coauthors: E. Leighton Durham, Vanderbilt University; Hee Jung Jeong, Vanderbilt University; Tyler M. Moore, University of Pennsylvania; Randolph M. Dupont, Vanderbilt University; Carlos Cardenas-Iniguez, University of Chicago; Zaixu Cui, University of Pennsylvania; Farrah E. Stone, Vanderbilt University; Marc G. Berman, University of Chicago; Benjamin B. Lahey, University of Chicago; Antonia N. Kaczkurkin, Vanderbilt University
theme: Theme A: Development, Neurodegenerative Disorders and Injury

title: Tracking Rhesus Macaque in a semi-naturalistic social enclosure (SNSE)
abstract: An open question in the study of non-human primates is that of relating naturalistic behavior to neural recordings or manipulations to better understand brain function. One way in which we can record naturalistic behavior is through markerless pose estimation. Advances in deep learning have largely improved human pose-estimation algorithms; however, tracking freely moving animals in naturalistic, three-dimensional (3D) environments remains comparatively understudied. The main challenge to successful pose tracking in non-human primates, such as the rhesus macaque, is attaining a sufficiently large and reliably annotated training set, rather than developing the algorithm itself. Here, we take advantage of two recently published training sets, OpenMonkeyPose and MacaquePose, to train a model that reliably tracks the poses of one to two rhesus macaques in a semi-naturalistic social enclosure (SNSE) with DeepLabCut, an efficient tool for high-throughput video analysis. Looking ahead, we aim to integrate wireless optogenetic manipulations and neurophysiological recordings to control behaviorally meaningful volumes of the primate brain in animals free of any physical restraint, permitting the causal dissection of the neural circuits that mediate naturally-occurring primate behaviors relevant for understanding social cognition.
coauthors: Felipe Parodi, University of Pennsylvania; Konrad P. Kording, University of Pennsylvania; Michael L. Platt, University of Pennsylvania
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Visuomotor transformation in the multi-unit activity of the frontal and supplementary eye fields in rhesus monkeys
abstract: Single-unit (SU) activity, the firing of one neuron under a microelectrode, has traditionally been studied to relate neuronal activity to behaviour. However, because neurons work in concert, there is an increasing trend in analyzing multi-unit (MU) activity: the average firing of neurons recorded within the vicinity of a microelectrode.  The goal of this project was to examine the spatial structure embedded in the simultaneously recorded MU activity of the frontal (FEF) and supplementary eye field (SEF) neurons. The spiking activity (visual, memory and motor) of these neurons was recorded during a memory-guided cue-conflict saccade task (where a target-fixed landmark shifted during the delay) by head-unrestrained monkeys (Macaca mulatta). Then, to assess if the MU activity carries the same information as the isolated SU activity, we used a model fitting approach on the MU response fields (RF) along a target (T) to gaze (G) continuum. Similar to the SU activity, the results showed that in both areas: 1) the visual (FEF = 88; SEF = 45) and MU motor (FEF = 90; SEF = 49) activities best coded for target-in-eye (Te) and future gaze-in-eye (Ge) coordinates, respectively. 2) Along the spatiotemporal domain (spanning visual-memory-motor activity), there was a progressive transition from T to G coding. 3) In the FEF, along the T-G continuum, MU activity better predicted the gaze than SU activity (p < 0.05), suggesting the robustness of population signals. In conclusion, these results suggest that: 1) neurons work in coordination with overlapping RFs and 2) the MU activity can be used as a reliable indicator of the visuomotor tasks. This has potential for translational purposes in medical settings to detect functional/dysfunctional sensorimotor transformations.
coauthors: Vishal Bharmauria, 2.	Centre for Vision Research and Vision: Science to Applications (VISTA) Program, 4700 Keele Street, York University, Toronto, Ontario, Canada, M3J 1P3; Adrian Schütz, 3.	Department of Neurophysics, Philipps-Universität Marburg, Karl-von-Frisch-Straße 8a, Marburg, 35032; Frank Bremmer, 3.	Department of Neurophysics, Philipps-Universität Marburg, Karl-von-Frisch-Straße 8a, Marburg, 35032; Xiaogang Yan, 2.	Centre for Vision Research and Vision: Science to Applications (VISTA) Program, 4700 Keele Street, York University, Toronto, Ontario, Canada, M3J 1P3; Hongying Wang, 2.	Centre for Vision Research and Vision: Science to Applications (VISTA) Program, 4700 Keele Street, York University, Toronto, Ontario, Canada, M3J 1P3; J. Douglas Crawford, 4.	Departments of Psychology, Biology and Kinesiology & Health Sciences, York University, 4700 Keele Street, Toronto, Ontario, Canada, M3J 1P3
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Optogenetic activation of the inhibitory nigro-collicular pathway evokes paradoxical contralateral orienting movement in mice.
abstract: The current model for controlling movement initiation proposes that the basal ganglia (BG) plays a permissive role in the generation of movements through the modulation of the amount of inhibition on BG target structures such as the superior colliculus (SC), a key structure involved in orienting control. One of the outputs of the BG, the substantia nigra pars reticulata (SNr), contains GABAergic neurons that primarily project to the ipsilateral SC. The current model suggests that the removal of SNr inhibition, combined with excitatory drive from the cerebral cortex to the SC, produces contralateral orienting movements. This model of action is often referred to as the rate model, where the rate of inhibitory spiking of the SNr onto target structures is what determines the initiation of movement; high rates and inhibition results in no movement, while low rates and less inhibition produces movement. We tested this hypothesis by controlling the rate of SNr activity into the SC using optogenetics. Contrary to the model predictions, optogenetic activation of the SNr terminals into the SC of mice evoked, rather than prevented, contralateral movement. To determine how orienting movements may result from the activation of inhibitory terminals, we performed a series of slice experiments and found that the same optogenetic stimulation that evoked contralateral movements in vivo evoked post-inhibitory rebound depolarization and spiking in the SC output neurons. Only high frequency stimulation evoked contralateral movements in vivo and triggered rebound spiking in vitro. The latency of orienting movements relative to the pulse stimulation in vivo was comparable to the latency of rebound spiking in vitro. These results challenge the current dogma regarding the role of the nigro-collicular pathway in the initiation of orienting movements and may provide new understanding on the progression and pathophysiology of movement disorders associated with the function of the BG.
coauthors: Michelle Basso, Department of Psychiatry and Biobehavioral Sciences, David Geffen School of Medicine, UCLA
institution: David Geffen School of Medicine at UCLA (grid.471398.0)
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Distinct synaptic plasticity mechanisms determine the diversity of cortical neuronal responses during behavior
abstract: Spike trains recorded from the cortex of behaving animals can be complex, highly variable from trial-to-trial, and therefore challenging to interpret. A fraction of recorded cells typically exhibit trial-averaged responses with obvious task-related features and can be considered ‘classically-responsive’, such as pure tone frequency tuning in the auditory cortex. However, a substantial number of cells (including cells in primary sensory cortex) do not appear to fire in a task-related manner and are often neglected from analysis (Olshausen & Field 2006). Even classically-responsive cells lose their stimulus representation during task-engagement without impairing behavioral performance (Otazu et al., 2009). These results suggest that non-classically responsive cells may play an underappreciated role in sensory processing and cognition. Recently, we showed that non-classically responsive cells recorded from auditory cortex and frontal cortex contained hidden task-relevant information while animals performed a frequency recognition task at levels comparable to responsive cells using a novel single-trial spike-timing-based analysis (Insanally et al., 2019). However, the synaptic origins and potential contribution of these cells to network function remain unknown. To address this, we developed a novel class of spiking recurrent neural network models that incorporate both spike-timing-dependent plasticity (STDP; Bi and Poo, 1998; Vogels et al., 2011; D’amour and Froemke, 2015) and FORCE learning (Sussillo and Abbott, 2009; Nicola and Clopath, 2017) to perform an auditory-guided task. We find that (1) this model recapitulates the surprising number of non-classically responsive cells seen in vivo and (2) distinct STDP mechanisms alter single-unit response profiles with heterosynaptic plasticity playing a key role. Finally, our model also makes strong predictions about the synaptic origins of classically and non-classically responsive neurons which we can compare to in vivo whole-cell recordings taken from the auditory cortex of behaving animals.
coauthors: Michele N Insanally, University of Pittsburgh School of Medicine, Department of Otolaryngology, Pittsburgh, PA; Brian DePasquale, Princeton University, Princeton Neuroscience Institute, Princeton, NJ; Saba Fadaei, New York University, Skirball Institute of Biomolecular Medicine, New York, NY; Trisha Gupta, New York University, Skirball Institute of Biomolecular Medicine, New York, NY; Madeline Albanese, Fordham University, Department of Natural Sciences, New York, NY; Kanaka Rajan, Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai, Department of Neuroscience and Friedman Brain Institute, New York, NY; Robert C Froemke, New York University, Skirball Institute of Biomolecular Medicine and Center for Neural Science, New York, NY;
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Aristotle as a neuroscientist: The power of habit and the science of the science of metron
abstract: Both Aristotle and contemporary neuroscientists have investigated habit as an incremental component of memory. Many of Aristotle’s conclusions contradict with existing evidence. However, some of his observations may unlock current stalemates with regard to memory. The purpose of this work is to compare Aristotle’s observations with contemporary neuroscience in terms of habit and discuss their potential connection. While habit has been regarded for year as a non – semantic memory process, Aristotle has emphasized on the conscious and semantic dimension of repetition. Current evidence highlights the rational background of habit in line with Aristotle’s conclusions. The modern terms of  up- and down regulation and withdrawal can be compared with the Aristotelian concepts of thymos and ethismos
theme: Theme F: History, Education and Society

title: Hippocampal replay alterations following moderate prenatal alcohol exposure
abstract: Prenatal alcohol exposure (PAE) is among the most common developmental insults to the nervous system and is characterized by memory impairment. There is a need to identify physiological changes that help explain this memory impairment. Hippocampal sharp-wave ripples (SPW-Rs) and associated replay events are potential candidates as they are the electrophysiological signatures of memory reactivation and consolidation. Here, we tested the hypothesis that SPW-Rs and replay events are altered following PAE. To test this hypothesis, we recorded single-unit and local field potentials from hippocampal subregions CA1 & CA3 of moderate PAE & control rats while they made laps on a linear track and while at rest on a pedestal. Preliminary findings suggest that replay and SPW-Rs are altered following PAE. Specifically, replayed trajectories are truncated and SPW-R frequencies are slowed. The results from these experiments provide a novel framework for investigating hippocampal mechanisms of memory impairment associated with PAE and may also provide potential functional biomarkers following PAE.
coauthors: Ryan E. Harvey, University of New Mexico; Laura E. Berkowitz, University of New Mexico; Benjamin J. Clark, University of New Mexico
theme: Theme A: Development, Neurodegenerative Disorders and Injury

title: Global and local network connectivity structures control rhythmogenesis in the preBötzinger complex
abstract:
The preBötzinger complex generates periodic bursts of neuronal spiking setting the inspiratory rhythm in mammals. We model this complex as a network of leaky integrate-and-fire neurons. Using parameters from the experimentally determined range for both neuronal and network properties, we observe the dynamics of burst initiation, obtaining results that are also consistent with the experiment. Specifically, we examine the probability of burst initiation in response to the controlled stimulation of various numbers of neurons, as is measured by the experiment. Comparing the results of the simulation for different networks, we see that Erdős-Rényi fits experimental data significantly better than other physiologically relevant networks, such as a small-world network or the network with local coupling. Finally, we determine, using a combination of graph theory and machine learning, the structures of the network that lead to a global synchronization. 
To recover the stable oscillation pattern observed in vivo we use dendritic calcium adaptation, that mediates the resistance of the membrane. The oscillation phase appears to be robust, being stable under killing a large fraction of neurons, which is consistent with the experiment. This model, averaged with time is qualitatively equivalent to the firing-rate based model that was studied before. Outside of the steady oscillations phase, neurons in this model demonstrate separation on constantly high firing and low firing states explicitly breaking the mean-field approach to the problem. This separation occurs even for the all-to-all coupled network, thus providing an example of spontaneous symmetry breaking. For sparser networks, the clustering is influenced by k-cores of the underlying network and is exactly controlled by them in a particular limit of the model. We also analyze this separation using a combination of graph theory and machine learning identifying the properties of the network that determine whether it produces rhythm or experience phase separation.
coauthors: Sufyan Ashhad, 2.	Systems Neurobiology Laboratory, Department of Neurobiology, David Geffen School of Medicine, UCLA, Los Angeles, California, 90095, USA; Mihai A Bibireata, Physics and Astronomy, UCLA, Los Angeles, California, 90095, USA;  Taylor Womack, Physics and Astronomy, UCLA, Los Angeles, California, 90095, USA; Jack L Feldman, 2.	Systems Neurobiology Laboratory, Department of Neurobiology, David Geffen School of Medicine, UCLA, Los Angeles, California, 90095, USA; Alex J Levine, Physics and Astronomy, UCLA, Los Angeles, California, 90095, USA. Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry, UCLA, Los Angeles, California, 90095, USA.	Department of Biomathematics, UCLA, Los Angeles, California, 90095, USA;
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Spectral features of an oddball task across modalities
abstract:
P300 complex is associated with cognitive processes such as attention and mem-
ory.An oddball paradigm in which,a deviant stimulus is infrequently presented
amidst a sequence of standard repetitive stimuli,typically exhibits a positive
peak in the event related potential recording via electroencephalogram(EEG)
at a latency of around 300ms from the onset of the stimulus.This study explores
the spectral features of the P3 complex ERP and the underlying cortical areas
involved in its generation,across unimodal and multimodal using 2 stimuli odd-
ball paradigms.Further,we extrapolate to study the spectral changes acquired
through 2 stimuli oddball paradigm,in which both the stimuli are of a different
modalities.Consequently,we compare our empirical results and try to answer
whether the P3 complex is modality specific and how does it vary spectrally
and spatially(underlying cortical generators).
coauthors: Arpan Banerjee, National Brain Research Center
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Zebrafish exhibit visual attentional pop-out effects in their behavior
abstract: Sensory inputs drive our interactions with the world, but the raw sensory inputs contain far more data than could be fully processed by our brain, which is constrained by limited resources. To overcome this processing bottleneck, the brain has evolved attentional selectional mechanisms to select only a fraction of the sensory inputs for deeper processing, and for survival this selection is often rapid and exogenously driven (“bottom-up”) so that it does not require any higher-order (“top-down”) cognitive guidance. Such attentional selection for visual inputs has been studied extensively in mammals, particularly in humans. To study the underlying neural mechanism for bottom-up visual selection, the zebrafish (Danio rerio) is perhaps an ideal model system. They rely on visual input for many behaviors early in development, possess evolutionarily conserved brain regions including a large optic tectum associated with attentional selection, and are amenable to live imaging using genetically encoded fluorescent indicators of neuronal activity. However, bottom-up visual attentional selection behavior has not yet been well characterized in zebrafish. A hallmark of the bottom-up visual selection is pop-out, when a uniquely featured visual item in a background of uniformly featured items, e.g., a red dot among green dots, elicits a rapid orienting behavior. Such orienting can be by gaze shifts (often in humans), and/or by turning of head, limb, tentacles, and body. We first demonstrate the pop-out effect in zebrafish using colored dot stimuli, and measure the orienting responses by shifts in the animal’s body orientation. We characterize the orientation response in relation to the sensory inputs, in particular the colors and spatial configurations of the dots. Our findings suggest conserved mechanisms of visual attention across evolution, and lay the groundwork for imaging studies to describe the underlying neuronal computations.
coauthors: Sarah Stednitz, MPI Biological Cybernetics; Jennifer Li, MPI Biological Cybernetics; Drew Robson, MPI Biological Cybernetics; Zhaoping Li, MPI Biological Cybernetics
institution: Max Planck Institute for Biological Cybernetics (grid.419501.8)
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Predicting attentional engagement during narratives and its consequences for event memory
abstract: As we comprehend narratives, our attentional engagement fluctuates over time. Despite theoretical conceptions of narrative engagement as emotion-laden attention (Bilandzic et al., 2019, Int. J. Commun.), little empirical work has characterized the cognitive and neural processes that comprise subjective engagement in naturalistic contexts or its consequences for memory. Here, we relate fluctuations in narrative engagement to patterns of brain coactivation, and test whether neural signatures of engagement predict later recall. First, in two behavioral experiments, participants rated how engaged they were as they watched an episode of the television show "Sherlock" (n=17) or listened to an audio-narrated story, "Paranoia" (n=21), by continuously adjusting a scale bar on a computer monitor. Self-reported engagement was synchronized across individuals, and the emotional content of the narratives was correlated with engagement when controlling for low-level stimulus features. We next analyzed functional MRI data collected as separate participants watched the same Sherlock episode (Chen et al., 2017, Nat. Neurosci.) or listened to the same story (Finn et al., 2018, Nat. Commun.). In these participants, group-average engagement drove neural synchrony, such that default mode network activity was more synchronized across individuals during more engaging moments of the narratives. Furthermore, time-resolved predictive modeling revealed that dynamic functional brain connectivity, but not BOLD activity patterns, predicted evolving states of engagement. Models not only predicted engagement of novel individuals within a single data set, but also generalized across completely independent samples. Finally, the same functional connections that predicted engagement overlapped with a validated neuromarker of sustained attention (Rosenberg et al., 2016, Nat. Neurosci.) and predicted post-scan free recall of the narratives, suggesting that engagement during memory encoding impacts subsequent event memory. Together, our findings reveal a robust and generalizable neural signature of engagement dynamics and elucidate relationships between narrative engagement, sustained attention, and event memory.
coauthors: Emily S. Finn, Dartmouth College; Monica D. Rosenberg, University of Chicago
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: The role of habitual behaviour in the corticostriatal pathway in a mouse model of Parkinson disease.
abstract:
The cardinal motor features of Parkinson disease (PD) typically, but often ignored, have a focal onset (Vidaihet, M. et al; 1994). However, the prevailing current Braak hypothesis about the beginning of PD fails to explain this important, focal and somatotopic pattern. Increased corticostriatal activity onto the caudal putamen leads to the perfect scenario for increased levels of α-synuclein to become toxic upon axonal dopaminergic endings (Foffani, G and Obeso, JA; 2018). It is noteworthy that corticostriatal stress in humans might be facilitated/mediated by continuous engagement in automatic/habitual motor performance giving rise to damage of dopaminergic axons in the motor striatum (Hernández, LF. et al; 2015; 2019). 

The goal of this project is to unveil the pathological role that habitual behaviour could have in the corticostriatal circuit in a mouse model of PD. To achieve this goal C57BL/6N mice will be used to anatomically define the cortico-striatal circuit of the paw. Then, α-synuclein pre-formed fibrils will be stereotactically injected in this area of the cortex to determine its uptake by dopaminergic striatal terminals. Finally, the role of cortical stress performed by enhanced automatic/habitual behaviour will be studied in these α-synuclein injected mice analysing the electrophysiological activity at the striatal level while animals perform a high demanding automatic/habitual task (FR4 lever press task).

We will describe the results obtained in the anatomical characterization of the corticostriatal circuit of the paw region in C57BL/6N mice.
coauthors: Zaldivar-Diez, J, (1) Centro Integral de Neurociencias A.C. (CINAC); Hernandez, LF, (1); Obeso, JA (1); Roeper, J (2) Institute of Neurophysiology, Goethe University Frankfurt
theme: Theme A: Development, Neurodegenerative Disorders and Injury

title: Plasticity Underlying Contextual Fear Memory in the Schaffer Collateral Synapse
abstract: The hippocampus (HPC) is a key structure for the formation and storage of episodic memory. It is reasoned that place cells in subregions CA3 and CA1 of the hippocampus, which exhibit robust location-specific firing, likely encode the contextual aspect of an episodic memory. Contextual Fear Memory (CFM) in rodents is a hippocampal-dependent example of episodic memory where a specific context is associated with an aversive experience. CA1 place cells receive spatial information from CA3 through Schaffer Collateral (SC) synapses5 and encode the context associated with CFM; in the case of the Inhibitory-Avoidance task on a linear track, this context is identified as the shock zone (SZ). We propose the synapses feeding into the place cells encoding the SZ are thus recruited to the CFM engram6 and participate in the different stages of CFM: acquisition, retrieval, and sleep-mediated consolidation. We hypothesize this recruitment of CA1 place cells to the memory engram occurs through long-term potentiation of SZ-encoding synapses. In vivo evidence of the synapse-specific modifications which recruit CA1 place cells to the CFM engram and mediate their activity during the different stages of CFM is fundamental to the neurophysiological understanding of episodic memory. This study aims to provide such evidence by measuring synaptic efficacy by concurrently stimulating Schaffer collaterals and recording responses in CA1 during CFM acquisition, retrieval, and sleep-mediated consolidation, and identify the plasticity recruiting CA1 place cells to the CFM engram through this key synaptic pathway.
coauthors: Kiara S Vega Bellido, Baylor College of Medicine
theme: Theme B: Neural Excitability, Synapses, and Glia

title: Development of the Functional Assessment of Motor and Process Skills Scale among clients with Acquired Brain Injury
abstract:
BACKGROUND:. Occupational Therapy intervention aims to improve the client’s occupational performance, hence there is a need for occupational therapists to assess the client’s deficits in areas such as cognitive, motor or psychosocial ability. Current tools available for assessing such deficits are not performance based or specific to skills required for occupational performance. 
AIM: To develop and validate a function-based assessment tool – the Functional Assessment of Motor and Process Skills Scale (FUMPS) in order to determine the specific deficits in motor and processing skills required for occupational performance, among clients with Acquired Brain Injury. 
METHODS: The study consisted of 2 phases. The first phase involved tool development and obtaining expert panel’s opinion. The second phase consisted of standardization of the tool. For standardization, the tool was administered on 25 participants with acquired brain injury by two different raters and at two different points of time for finding the inter rater and test retest reliability. For finding concurrent validity, the tool was compared with COVS and MOCA scores of the participants.
RESULTS: FUMPS was found to have good correlation for inter rater reliability for both the motor and process skill components (motor skill - Cronbach’s alpha 0.98 , process skill – Cronbach’s alpha = 0.99) between two raters and was also statistically significant (P = 0.0 for both motor and process skill). It was also found to have good correlation for test retest reliability (motor skill – Cronbach’s alpha = 0.99, process skill – Cronbach’s alpha = 0.97) and was also statistically significant (P = 0.00 for both motor and process skill). While assessing concurrent validity, the tool was found to have good correlation with MOCA (Cronbach’s alpha = 0.83), moderate correlation with COVS (Cronbach’s alpha = 0.78) and was statistically significant (P = 0.00 for both). 
CONCLUSION: From this study it can be concluded that the FUMPS is a reliable and valid measure for finding the specific motor and process skill deficits while performing functional tasks among persons with acquired brain injury.
coauthors: Reetha Janet Sureka; Abraham Peter J.; Samuel Kamalesh Kumar S.; Dr. Judy Ann John
theme: Theme A: Development, Neurodegenerative Disorders and Injury

title: Tools for efficient 3D cell and projection analysis and atlas registration of whole mouse spinal cord.
abstract:
The spinal cord (SC) contains a remarkable and complex variety of interconnected cells that relay and process somatosensory information and execute movement. Classic research on the embryonic and adult SC has identified major classes of neurons, based on embryonic markers, morphology and position within the SC. But recent advances in transcriptional profiling have revealed that the extent of spinal cell diversity far exceeds previous assumptions.
