To achieve better characterization of spinal cell types and the detailed connectivity between cells that form functional circuits, it is necessary to map the spatial relations of neurons and projections. To date, however, unbiased approaches to map positional information in the context of the whole SC are severely limited by a lack of tools for efficient data collection and analysis. Moreover, the absence of a standardized 3D reference atlas for the mouse SC complicates anatomical mapping of data and comparison between samples and results across the field.

Here we present tools for practicable analysis of labelled cells and projections in whole mouse SC in the context of a novel 3D anatomical atlas. We have designed soluble, 3D-printed, ‘Spine Racks’ that guide oriented and parallel embedding of serial tissue segments of the entire SC within a single block for synchronous cryo-sectioning. Spine Racks precisely position tissue pieces within each block section array, permitting automated imaging of slides and rostro-caudal sorting of section images. Additionally, we have developed “SpinalJ”, a user-friendly plugIn for ImageJ, to register section images and to map the reconstructed data to a prototype 3D reference atlas. SpinalJ further combines various tools for manual and automated cell and projection analysis, as well as for data visualization.

Together, these tools capacitate high-throughput comparative analyses of neurons and their projections in whole SC.
coauthors: Luke A. Hammond, Columbia University; Carol A. Mason, Columbia University; Jane Dodd, Columbia University
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Propagation and modulation of information in visual pathway
abstract: How neuronal variability impacts sensory coding is a central question in systems neuroscience, often with complex and model dependent answers.  Many studies explore population models with a parametric structure for response tuning and variability, preventing an analysis of how synaptic circuitry establish neural codes. We study stimulus coding in networks of spiking neuron models with spatially ordered excitatory and inhibitory connectivity.  The wiring structure is capable of producing rich population-wide shared neuronal variability that agrees with many features of recorded cortical activity. While both the spatial scales of feedforward and recurrent projections strongly affect noise correlations, only recurrent projections, and in particular inhibitory projections, can introduce correlations that limit the stimulus information available to a decoder. Using a spatial neural field model we relate the recurrent circuit conditions for information limiting noise correlations to how recurrent excitation and inhibition can form spatio-temporal patterns of population-wide activity.
coauthors: Alexandre Pouget, University of Geneva; Brent Doiron, University of Chicago
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: The metaperceptual function: Exploring dissociations between confidence and task performance with type 2 psychometric curves
abstract: Reports of confidence do not always correlate with perceptual accuracy. This dissociation suggests that distinct computational and neural processes underlie these functions. Recent investigations have therefore sought to experimentally isolate metacognitive processes by creating conditions where perceptual sensitivity is matched but confidence differs (“matched-performance / different-confidence”; MPDC). Although MPDC has been successfully implemented in recent studies, much remains unknown about its underlying causes or how to best induce these effects in experimental settings. Here we developed a principled approach to comprehensively characterizing MPDC effects through analyzing metaperceptual (i.e., type 2 psychometric) functions relating objective performance to subjective confidence across widely varying performance levels and experimental manipulations. We found that MPDC effect magnitude depends on stimulus properties, observers’ sensitivity level, and critically on trial type order (blocked or interleaved across stimulus property variations). Our findings provide the first comprehensive exploration of MPDC effects, offer a prescriptive guide to quantitative metaperceptual analysis, and suggest optimal experimental paradigms for experimentally isolating metacognition and awareness in future studies.
coauthors: Brian Maniscalco, Department of Cognitive Sciences, University of California Irvine; Olenka Graham Castaneda, Department of Cognitive Sciences, University of California Irvine; Brian Odegaard, Department of Psychology, University of Florida; Jorge Morales, Department of Psychological and Brain Sciences, Johns Hopkins University ; Sivananda Rajananda, Department of Bioengineering, University of California Riverside; Megan A. K. Peters, Department of Cognitive Sciences, University of California Irvine
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Oscillatory activity in the STN under PD: do we need to account for aperiodic broadband signal/activity and how it affects our data?
abstract: Oscillatory activity in the basal ganglia is under extensive research as it may contribute to motor dysfunction in Parkinson’s disease (PD). Most of the studies deal with local field potentials (LFPs), which are thought to reflect activity of neuronal populations in the vicinity of the macroelectrode recording contact. The power of oscillations may be assessed using power spectral density estimates in the range of interest. However, every spectra has aperiodic broadband component (commonly viewed as noise) that is usually not taken into account. Recent research (Gao et al., 2017) has suggested that this aperiodic signal may reflect the balance between the excitatory and inhibitory (E/I) projections. Besides, the slope of aperiodic component may affect the amplitude of oscillatory peaks and skew the perceived power of oscillations when measured without slope extraction. We aimed to compare the power of LFP oscillations in several bands using the conventional method and the method accounting for aperiodic component. LFP spectra were recorded in the subthalamic nucleus of parkinsonian patients undergoing DBS surgeries in 2017-2020 in Burdenko Neurosurgery Institute. We performed LFP recordings at rest and during voluntary movement (i.e. fist contraction). We searched for the association between oscillatory activity in several frequency bands and motor signs of PD and their sensitivity to motor tests using both methods. Here we provide the evidence supporting the idea that aperiodic broadband component in LFP spectra may carry meaningful information about E/I balance,  though this aperiodic signal does not affect significantly the associations found for LFP oscillations and motor function in PD.
coauthors: Ulia Semenova, Semenov Institute for Chemical Physics, Anna Gamaleya, Burdenko Neurosurgery Institute, Alexey Tomskiy, Burdenko Neurosurgery Institute, Alexey Sedov, Semenov Institute of Chemical Physics
theme: Theme A: Development, Neurodegenerative Disorders and Injury

title: A cell-type specific understanding of innate defensive behaviors: the collicular perspective
abstract: Animals’ behaviors are governed by distinct neuronal cell-types. In the superior colliculus of mice, there is evidence of a strong relationship between individual cell-types and orienting, hunting and defensive behaviors. Here we use this relationship to determine the contribution each collicular cell-type make on triggering behavior. We show that optogenetic activation of 4 different cell populations each evoked a distinct behavior, including freezing, stopping, hiding and orienting. Additionally, by combining optogenetics with functional ultrasound imaging (opto-fUSi) we mapped the neuronal activity in up to 264 brain regions and unraveled a few novel hubs engaged in defensive behaviors processing. Chemogenetic manipulation of one newly identified area, the posterior paralaminar nuclei of the thalamus (PPnT), revealed the role it plays in mediating habituation to repeated threat-like input from the superior colliculus. This study extends our understanding of how cell-types of the superior colliculus disseminate information across the brain to guide distinct behaviors.
coauthors: Arnau Sans-Dublanc, NERF, KULeuven (Belgium); Katja Reinhard, NERF, KULeuven, VIB (Belgium); Dani Lemmon, NERF, University of Antwerp (Belgium); Gabriel Montaldo, NERF, imec (Belgium), Alan Urban, NERF, KULeuven, VIB (Belgium); Karl Farrow, NERF, KULeuven, VIB, imec
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Probabilistic estimation of correlation matrices from binary spiking data
abstract: To understand how populations of neurons code information together, we need to measure neural correlations. Existing statistical methods don‘t allow for easy estimation of uncertainty on pairwise correlations or correlation matrices from limited data – often the case with in vivo calcium imaging.  I developed a new method for estimating the posterior distribution over correlation matrices given binary spiking neural population data. I show how to extend this method to large populations of neurons by approximating the joint distribution with a latent gaussian. Uncertainty estimates using this method can allow for hypothesis testing and robust inference on correlation matrices.
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Recurrent Neural Networks reveal distinct signal flow in mouse visual cortex following expectation violations
abstract:
A prominent theory in neuroscience has been the predictive coding theory, where top-down inputs provide predictions, which are compared with the bottom-up sensory inputs. Predictions are subsequently updated if they deviate from the actual sensory inputs (Rao & Ballard, 1999). To investigate the neural circuit mechanisms that underlie predictive coding, we need to study brain area interactions while animal’s predictions are violated. To this end, we used Recurrent Neural Networks (RNN’s) to analyze cortical layer and area interactions during a visual task, which involved expectation violations.

In brief, Multiplane Mesoscopes were used to simultaneously image 4 cortical depths of 2 visual areas (V1 and LM), while mice performed an image-change detection task. Three mouse lines, which were tagged for excitatory and two inhibitory subpopulations (VIP and SST), were used in our study. The behavioral task involved repeated and regular presentation of images (expected events), as well as the following two unexpected events: 1) infrequent and random omissions of the visual stimulus; 2) presentation of a novel image set after several days of training with a different (familiar) image set.

We fit the activity of units in an RNN model to the activity of individual neurons (Andalman et al., 2019) to study how unexpected events modify signal flow between cortical layers and areas. By comparing the weight distributions of RNN units, we demonstrate that functional connectivity between visual areas and layers changes following the presentation of novel images. Furthermore, functional connectivity was differentially modified for excitatory and inhibitory cell types.

Overall, our results demonstrate the use of RNN’s to investigate the cortical circuitries that underlie the representation and updating of prediction signals.
coauthors: Farzaneh Najafi
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: A convolutional neural-network model of the human inner-hair-cell and auditory-nerve-fiber complex
abstract:
Analytical descriptions of inner-hair-cell (IHC) and auditory-nerve-fiber (ANF) processing have evolved
over the years, with IHC transduction models shifting from simplified low-pass filters to detailed
conductance models which include basolateral outward K+ currents. State-of-the-art models of the IHC-
ANF synapse complex describe the vibrations of the IHC stereocilia based on the mechanical drive to the
IHC and model ANF spikes or instantaneous firing rates as resulting from the depletion and
replenishment of different neurotransmitter stores. While such sensory models have progressed to
accurately capture the nonlinear and dynamic properties of the neuronal processes associated with
hearing, they typically comprise mechanistic descriptions and coupled sets of ordinary differential
equations, rendering these models slow to compute.
Here, we present a hybrid computational neuroscience - deep neural network (DNN) framework which
simulates auditory IHC-ANF processing, to offer a fast and differentiable model which can be used in
large-scale neuronal network models. Based on a state-of-the-art biophysical model of the auditory
periphery (including human cochlear mechanics, IHC and ANF processing), we trained several
convolutional neural network (CNN) architectures to learn the computations performed by the IHC-ANF
complex (CoNNear IHC-ANF ). We determined the hyperparameters in these architectures (different layers,
filter lengths, input and context windows, activation functions) on the basis of well-known single-unit
IHC and ANF properties derived from experimental neuroscience studies. The model was trained using
an acoustic speech corpus, and its performance evaluated using basic acoustic stimuli which were not
included in the training set.
The final CoNNear IHC-ANF model offers a 70-fold speed-up factor on a CPU and a 280-fold factor on a GPU
when compared to the analytical IHC-ANF model processing computations. When connected to a DNN-
based cochlear model, preferably CoNNear cochlea , population responses (e.g. CAP, ABR wave-I) can be
simulated across a large number of cochlear tonotopic locations, and be used for backpropagation
purposes. Our auditory periphery framework can be applied for the development of large-scale neural-
network circuits aimed to advance our knowledge of unknown neuronal systems such as the brainstem
and subcortical pathways, or the human auditory cortex.

Work supported by European Research Council ERC-StG-678120 (RobSpear)
coauthors: Deepak Baby, Ghent University, Sarah Verhulst, Ghent University
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Minisymposium on Connectomics: a new era of dissemination and discovery (Chair: Sebastian Seung)
abstract:
Over the past fifteen years, the field of connectomics has developed in three overlapping stages. The first two have focused on the technical challenges of data collection and automated reconstruction. Now the third and most exciting stage is picking up speed. This symposium will describe connectomic resources that are being disseminated now, and the discoveries that they are enabling.

Chair:
Sebastian Seung (Princeton University)

Talks:
- "FlyWire: online community for whole-brain connectomics"
Mala Murthy (Princeton University)   

- A connectome-based neural network model of the Drosophila visual system
Srini Turaga (HHMI Janelia Research Campus)    

- Neural coding and dynamics from a brainstem wiring diagram
Mark Goldman (University of California, Davis)

- A surprising new function of oligodendrocyte precursor cells
JoAnn Buchanan (Allen Brain Institute)    

- The mind of a mouse
Jeff Lichtman (Harvard University)
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Understanding transformations between “decision-potent” and “decision-null” representations in visual working memory using demixed PCA
abstract: In the 2-back working memory task the representation of a stimulus item (n) transitions from memory probe (for comparison vs. n - 2) to unprioritized memory item (UMI; while n + 1 is compared to n - 1), and then to prioritized memory item (PMI; for comparison to n + 2). Inverted encoding modeling (IEM) of EEG voltage data (N = 30) revealed “opposite” reconstruction of stimulus representations as UMI relative to their reconstructions as PMI, suggesting that stimulus representations might be rotationally “remapped” with changes of behavioral priority status (Wan et al., 2020). Such rotational remapping has also been observed in the dynamics of a recurrent neural network (RNN; with an LSTM architecture) trained to perform this task. Moreover, only the PMI coding dimensions seemed to align with the dimensions relevant to the RNN's output, presumably facilitating its influence on the decision and response. In the current work, we use demixed Principal Component Analysis (dPCA; Kobak et al., 2016), a dimensionality reduction method, to better understand the representational transformations between UMI and PMI, both in vitro and in silico. Combining the advantages of traditional approaches such as LDA and PCA, dPCA can parse neural representation into a few components related to task parameters (e.g., stimulus, decision, and time), while capturing most of the variance of the data. In both EEG and RNN data, we are using dPCA to identify stimulus- and decision-dependent axes, to characterize how they interact with each other, and to track the representational dynamics along these dimensions as a function of behavioral priority. These analyses will enable us to distill essential mechanisms of how brains and RNNs dynamically transform working memory representations to flexibly guide decisions.
coauthors: Quan Wan, Department of Psychology, University of Wisconsin–Madison; Jorge A. Menendez, Gatsy Computational Neuroscience Unit, University College London, UK; Bradley R. Postle, Departments of Psychology and Psychiatry, University of Wisconsin–Madison
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Social memory responses in macaque medial prefrontal cortex
abstract: Humans have a sophisticated ability to understand other people’s behavior, in terms of knowledge about their personality, personal history, and internal mental states. This ability is thought to be supported by a distributed network of areas within the default mode or apex network, including regions of medial prefrontal cortex (mPFC). To what extent is the neural machinery underlying these abilities evolutionarily conserved, versus uniquely human? Here, we search for potential homologues of human social reasoning areas in the macaque, capitalizing on the observation that in humans, these areas also respond to images of familiar faces. We record fMRI responses from four macaques while viewing images of faces and objects, that are either novel, visually familiar, or personally familiar. Across all four animals, responses to faces over objects are observed in multiple (at least three) subregions of mPFC and superior frontal gyrus. These regions respond over baseline to personally familiar faces, at baseline for visually familiar or unfamiliar faces, and below baseline for objects, indicating a domain-specific, memory-related response. The regions also share characteristic functional properties with socially-responsive regions of human mPFC: 1) They are positioned with the apex network, both in terms of anatomical location and functional connectivity; 2) They respond below baseline to non-preferred stimulus categories; 3) They have a characteristic anatomical organization across mPFC, with alternating regions of socially-responsive and non-responsive cortex spanning ventral to dorsal mPFC. These results demonstrate that macaques have social memory responses in medial prefrontal cortex, with a strikingly similar functional profile to regions implicated in human social reasoning and memory.
coauthors: Sofia Landi*, University of Washington; Winrich Freiwald, Rockefeller University
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Neuroscience Needs Philosophy to Understand Representations
abstract: Typical systems neuroscience experiments vary stimuli and correlate these with firing rates of recorded neurons. Such experiments are commonly taken to reveal that the neural activity is a representation of the stimulus. However, representation is a philosophical concept with a rich history. Within philosophy the concept of a representation goes far beyond correlation, typically implying semantically evaluable content and the possibility of misrepresentation. Here we summarize the standard investigative approach in neuroscience as well as the philosophical notion of representation as relates to understanding the mind. We point out how typical neuroscientific experiments stay well short of establishing what philosophers mean with representation. We then discuss approaches in neuroscience that rely on recording from much or all of an organism's nervous system, and approaches that use Deep Neural Nets to models intelligent behavior. We argue for a way that contemporary philosophy ought to be used to allow neuroscience to rework its approaches to meaningfully get at neural representations within these novel approaches.
coauthors: Ben Lansdell
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Object Categorization and Response Bias Flexibly Change Depending on Cross-Spatial Scale Coherence and Task Demands
abstract: Categorization of visual stimuli at different levels of abstraction relies on the encoding of relevant diagnostic features present at different spatial scales. We used the Eidolon Factory (Koenderink et al., 2017), an image-manipulation algorithm based on the scale-space representation of the early visual cortex that introduces random disarray fields across spatial scales. When the disarray is incoherent, edges become fuzzy and less defined; when it is coherent, the coarser scales dictate where the finer scales end up, leading to warping of the local structure of the image. With this method, we asked: is the brain using the global shape or is it detecting some salient feature to resolve a recognizable object? And, how is the correlational structure of different spatial scales interacting with the task demands? Images of animal faces, human faces and everyday objects were disarrayed coherently or incoherently to create a family of  50  eidolons per image with increasing disarray. Participants (N=217) viewed each family of eidolons in a smooth sequence from maximum disarray to none and performed a category verification task either at the superordinate (any face type) or basic (human face only) levels at different levels of uncertainty. In the first response, they used their gut feeling to respond, for the second response they had to be sure of their decision. When participants used their gut feeling to respond, we observed a basic-level advantage, but not an effect of the type of disarray. When they were sure of their response, we observed a superordinate advantage and stronger disarray effects in the coherent stimulus. Furthermore, participants changed their decision criterion depending on the abstraction level of the task. These results suggest that the visual system flexibly adjusts to the relevant perceptual information depending on task context and that it does not strictly adhere to feedforward processing.
coauthors: Miguel G. E. Santo; Johan Wagemans
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Visual ensemble representations emerge in Deep Neural Networks trained for object recognition
abstract: Humans are able to quickly pool information from across many individual objects to perceive ensemble properties, like the average size of objects, the color diversity of objects, or even the gender ratio in a group of faces. Such ensemble perception in humans is thought to occur extremely efficiently and automatically, but how it arises in the first place is unknown. Does ensemble perception arise because the human visual system must solve many different types of perceptual problems, or are ensemble properties represented even in a system with only the goal of recognizing individual objects?  Here, we used an artificial visual system -- a deep neural network -- to determine whether the ensemble property of color diversity emerges in a network pre-trained to recognize natural objects (using ImageNet). We presented the network with new images that were completely different from its training set: images of letter arrays containing four colored consonants on a black background. The color of each letter within an array was drawn either from a broad sample of 19 colors (high color diversity) or a randomly selected range of six adjacent colors (low color diversity). The ensemble property of interest -- color diversity -- was therefore a summary statistic for the whole array and not recoverable from any individual element. We tested whether a ResNet50 neural network could distinguish high vs. low color diversity arrays by using the activations from different layers as input to a linear classifier (SVM). We found that the network was highly accurate at identifying color diversity, with deeper layers more accurate than earlier layers. This demonstrates the presence of ensemble representations for the first time in deep neural networks, and also suggests that ensemble perception of multiple objects can emerge even in a system only trained to recognize individual objects.
coauthors: Emily Ward, University of Wisconsin–Madison (grid.14003.36)
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Dopamine circuits driving the transition to habit
abstract:
Habits decrease the burden of decision-making by establishing stimulus-response associations that guide
automatic behavior. While this automaticity can improve task performance, it can also lead to
compulsive behaviors seen in substance abuse and obsessive-compulsive disorder. To understand how
initially reward-driven behaviors develop into reward-independent habits, I am investigating a putative
circuit underlying habit formation in mice. Specifically, I am testing the existence of a circuit long
hypothesized to connect the dorsomedial striatum (DMS; required for reward-driven learning) to the
dorsolateral striatum (DLS; required for habit formation). The hypothesis, built from previous anatomical
data, is that DMS neurons indirectly activate DLS-projecting dopamine cells via inhibition of the
substantia nigra pars reticulata (SNr). To test this hypothesis, I am using optogenetics coupled with ex
vivo electrophysiology and in vivo fiber photometry. First, I am characterizing the circuit connecting DMS
to DLS-projecting dopamine cells ex vivo using retrograde labeling, viral-mediated gene delivery, transsynaptic
tracing, and intersectional genetics. Second, I am testing whether DMS activation leads to
dopamine release in DLS in vivo. Finally, I will compare the activity and connectivity of DLS-projecting
dopamine neurons before and after habit training. My ex vivo data is the first functional evidence for a
polysynaptic DMS-SNr-SNc-DLS circuit. Surprisingly, however, my in vivo data suggests that DMS
activation alone is not sufficient to increase dopamine release in DLS. My work will not only help answer
a fundamental question in neuroscience – what is the mechanism of habit formation? – but also provide a
foundation for future translational studies.
coauthors: Priscilla Ambrosi, Northwestern University; Talia N. Lerner, Northwestern University
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Sampling-like representation of prospective locations during hippocampal theta sequences.
abstract:
Predicting the possible future consequences of actions is necessary for efficient planning. In volatile or partially observed environments animals can capitalise on representing the uncertainty associated with those predictions. Representation of and computations with uncertainty has recently gained support in a wide range of cognitive phenomena but whether and how uncertainty is represented in navigation and planning has remained elusive. Here we investigated the neuronal representation emerging in a  goal-oriented spatial navigation task in a neuron population recorded from the hippocampus, a region widely implicated in model-based planning. 

During exploratory behavior the hippocampal population activity repeatedly outlines the trajectory of the animal starting from its recent past towards its possible future positions within each theta cycle (theta sequences). Critically, during a single cycle the uncertainty is expected to increase systematically, thus providing an opportunity to identify how it is encoded in the population activity. We contrasted 4 alternative models: (a) encoding only the most likely trajectory (no uncertainty encoded); (b) encoding the uncertainty by sampling from the distribution of possible trajectories (uncertainty encoded across theta cycles); (c) representing uncertainty via the standard probabilistic population coding (PPC) or (d) via distributed distributional code (DDC).

By decoding hippocampal spikes falling into different phases of the theta oscillation, we confirmed that the location encoded by the activity sweeps ahead of the animal at late theta phases. Consistent with the representation of increased uncertainty, we observed that place fields were largest when estimated from late phase spikes. The population activity typically encoded single locations instead of full distributions with the firing rate being the highest when encoding future locations ruling out distributional population codes (PPC and DDC). Finally, we found that the variability between subsequent theta cycles is larger than that expected from encoding the most likely trajectory, and is consistent with sampling from hypothetical future trajectories.  

Our analysis, being the first to directly contrast alternative frameworks of probabilistic computations, also demonstrates that activity in the hippocampus represents uncertainty and therefore is well equipped to contribute to optimal planning.
coauthors: Gergő Orbán, Computational Systems Neuroscience Lab, Wigner Research Center for Physics, Budapest, Hungary
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Application of Digital Image Analysis Methods for Quantifying Spatiotemporal Neural Dynamics
abstract:
Recent developments in the ability to measure neural activity with surface and penetrating microelectrode arrays have allowed for higher-resolution and higher-dimension measurements of neural activity. With the development of this technology also arises the need for analytical methods to enable interpretation of these measurements in the context of underlying neural dynamics and processes. We examine the application of image analysis methods such as histogram correlation and radial profile analysis, for quantifying the spatiotemporal characteristics of neural dynamics in both simulated and recorded data.
Neural activity can be highly nonlinear and nonstationary, particularly in response to electric stimulation. When analyzing nonstationary data recorded from cortical surface or planar depth electrode arrays, image-analysis methods may be helpful in comparing various spatial and event-related changes in neural activity detected by these electrodes in the plane of a recording array. Since these methods do not depend on time series data, they may have potential application for real-time feedback control of neural activity.
To demonstrate the application of image-analysis based methods in comparing event-related changes in neural activity we used radial profiles to investigate the state-dependent response to cortical stimulation. We used a data set of 67 paired pre- and post-stimulation cortical states recorded from iECoG signals sampled 100 ms prior, and after cortical stimulation from a patient with epilepsy. State-dependence was defined as the conditional probability that pre-stimulation states were similar given the corresponding post-stimulation states were similar. We adopted a criterion thresholds for profile similarity and found that 27 cortical responses were classified as state dependent. To assess the statistical significance of this result, we performed a permutation test by shuffling the order of pre-stimulation states. Under the null hypothesis (N=1000 permutations of pre-stimulation states) we found less state-dependent responses (with a mean of 13.8 and standard deviation of 3.3 across all permutations). The test gave evidence in favor of prestimulation context affecting cortical responses to stimulation. Thus, we propose that using image analysis methods for analyzing multielectrode data has the potential to reveal new patterns in cortical activity.
coauthors: Pawel Kudela, Institute for Computational Medicine and Department of Neurosurgery, Johns Hopkins University; William S. Anderson, Institute for Computational Medicine and Department of Neurosurgery, Johns Hopkins University
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Deletion of beta2-containing nicotinic receptors in striatal neurons leads to behavioral alterations and increased striatal activity
abstract:
Nicotinic acetylcholine receptors (nAChRs) are relatively less expressed by striatal neurons comparing to other brain regions and their expression by individual types of striatal neurons as well as their functional significance is rather elusive. According to the traditional view supported mainly by electrophysiological data, nAChRs are mainly expressed by striatal interneurons while the expression by striatal principal neurons (commonly referred to as medium spiny neurons, MSNs) is very low. Striatal interneurons represent only approximately 5 % of neurons in the striatum and they consist of a group of cholinergic interneurons (CINs) and several different types of GABAergic interneurons (GABAINs). In our study, we reviewed previously published single cell RNA sequencing data1 to investigate the pattern of beta2-containing nAChRs (beta2* nAChRs) expression by striatal neurons. Furthermore, we performed deletion of beta2* nAChRs in striatal neurons to test the effect of the deletion on behavior and neuronal activity. By examining the previously published data, we found no difference in the RNA expression level between striatal interneurons and MSNs. In contrast, the non-specific deletion of beta2* nAChRs in striatal neurons led to increased neuronal activity evaluated by Fos immunofluorescence, both at baseline and after induction with amphetamine. This suggests that the deletion mainly affected inhibitory GABAINs leading to increased MSNs' activity. In addition, mice with the beta2* nAChRs deletion in striatal neurons showed alterations in social preference test and increased anxiety together with mild cognitive alterations and hyperactivity. This behavioral phenotype is less prominent but generally in agreement with the phenotype observed in global beta2-KO mice2.    
References:
1. Munoz-Manchado AB. et al., Cell Rep. 8, (2018)
2. Granon S. et al., Proc Natl Acad Sci USA. 16, (2003)
coauthors: Alice Abbondanza, Institute of Physiology of the Czech Academy of Sciences, Prague, Czech Republic; Martin Modrak, Institute of Microbiology of the Czech Academy of Sciences, Prague, Czech Republic; Jan Elias, Czech Centre for Phenogenomics, Institute of Molecular Genetics of the Czech Academy of Sciences, Vestec, Czech Republic; Trisha Dhabalia, Institute of Physiology of the Czech Academy of Sciences, Prague, Czech Republic;
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Comparison of Cortical Object Representation With Neuroscience-Inspired Deep Neural Networks
abstract:
Simulation of human visual perception stands out amongst the most important purposes of artificial intelligence. Artificial neural network, a computational model of biological neural network, is assumed as being highly inspired by human visual representation. Thus, understanding the cortical object representation would lead us to ameliorate deep neural network structures.

       Understanding the mechanisms of representation of objects in visual ventral pathway is achieved by analyzing the responses of neurons across temporal ventral stream. Layers of a deep neural network are claimed to resemble ventral pathway; theories posit that the DNN first layers and last layers are analogous to Retinal Ganglion Cells and Anterior Inferior Temporal respectively. 

        The main focus of this study is comparison of stages of cortical object representation with neuroscience-inspired deep neural network layers with human object recognition performance. To this end, a dataset comprising of two groups of animate and inamitate line-drawings are divided into three groups: COMP, EDGE, and VERT. COMP group consist of intact line-drawing of animate and inamitate objects, while EDGE  and VERT groups are fragmented images of the same objects with only edge and vertex information respectively.  On one hand, the stimuli have been shown to sixteen 8 to 12 year-olds and they were asked to name the image for each of the three types. On the other hand, the stimuli were fed into a four layer CNN in order to compare their accuracies to human performance.

        The accuracy patterns of CNNs and human were exactly the same, whereas we expected them to have higher accuracies for CNNs on EDGE images. After visualizing representational dissimilarity matrix of images representations we concluded that, this similarity between human vision and modern computer vision is an inductive bias of DNNs.

Keywords: Visual Ventral Pathway; Biological Neural Network; Artificial Neural Network; Deep Neural Network; Cortical Visual Representation
coauthors: Mohammad-Reza A. Dehaqani, School of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Tehan, Tehran, Iran,   School of Cognitive Sciences, Institute for Research in Fundamental Sciences, Tehran, Iran; Babak N. Araabi, School of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Tehan, Tehran, Iran.
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: The Effects of Social Rewards on Incidental Episodic Memory
abstract: Episodic memory is our memory for specific, personally experienced events. Although remembering the “what, where and when” of an instance may be highly beneficial, the brain’s memory capacity is limited and must therefore be selective. Rewards are important enhancers of episodic memory acquisition and storage. Among them, social rewards have been proposed as important drivers of motivated behaviour. Whether the benefits of social rewards on memory still operate on incidental (unplanned) memorization of neutral events has not been tested yet. In this study, we explored the effects of social rewards on memory for neutral scenes that were completely unrelated, except for proximity in time, to the sources of reward (here, the presentation of happy versus neutral faces). One day after the completion of an encoding task, participants were given a surprise memory test that assessed their recollection of spatial or temporal information related to such incidental scenes. Differences in memory for space versus time-related information were observed. Although participants were expected to have better memory for scenes that occurred after delivery of social rewards, this was not the case; possible explanations for this are discussed. However, strong interactions between the anticipated effect and participants’ mood were noted, and our initial hypothesis did hold true in a subset of participants who experienced exceptionally low mood on the day of encoding. These findings hint at the limitations of a reward-driven enhancement of incidental episodic memory and highlight the important role of mood in modulating the extent of such an effect.
coauthors: Charlotte Russell, King's College London
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Quantifying dynamic stability and signal propagation: Lyapunov spectra of chaotic recurrent neural networks
abstract:
Brains process information through the collective dynamics of large neural networks. Collective chaos was suggested to underlie the complex ongoing dynamics observed in cerebral cortical circuits and determine the impact and processing of incoming information streams. While dynamic mean-field theory has uncovered key properties of recurrent network models such as the onset of chaos and their largest Lyapunov exponent, fundamental features of their dynamics remain unknown. In particular, chaotic dynamics in dissipative high-dimensional systems takes place on a subset of phase space of reduced dimension and is organized by a complex tangle of stable, neutral and unstable manifolds. Key topological invariants of this phase space structure such as attractor dimension, and Kolmogorov-Sinai entropy so far remained elusive.

Here we calculate the complete Lyapunov spectrum of recurrent neural networks. We show that chaos in these networks is extensive with a size-invariant Lyapunov spectrum and characterized by attractor dimensions much smaller than the number of phase space dimensions. The attractor dimension and entropy rate increases with coupling strength near the onset of chaos but decrease far from onset, reflecting a reduction in the number of unstable directions. We find that near the onset of chaos, for very intense chaos, and discrete-time dynamics, random matrix theory provides good analytical approximations to the full Lyapunov spectrum. We show that a generalized time-reversal symmetry of the network dynamics induces a point-symmetry of the Lyapunov spectrum reminiscent of the symplectic structure of chaotic Hamiltonian systems. Temporally fluctuating input can drastically reduce both the entropy rate and the attractor dimension. For trained recurrent networks, we find that Lyapunov spectrum analysis provides a quantification of error propagation and stability achieved by distinct learning algorithms. Our methods apply to systems of arbitrary connectivity, and we describe a comprehensive set of controls for the accuracy and convergence of Lyapunov exponents.

Our results open a novel avenue for characterizing the complex dynamics of recurrent neural networks and the geometry of the corresponding high-dimensional chaotic attractor. They also highlight the potential of Lyapunov spectrum analysis as a diagnostic for machine learning applications of recurrent networks.
coauthors: Rainer Engelken; Fred Wolf;  L.F. Abbott
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: The assessment of visually guided reaching in Alzheimer's Disease and Mild Cognitive Impairment
abstract: The onset of cognitive problems associated with Alzheimer’s disease (AD) has recently been shown to be preceded by functional and structural changes in the posterior parietal cortex (PPC). The PPC is important for the visual guidance of actions, and focal damage to this region can cause gross spatial errors when reaching to objects in peripheral vision. Individuals with AD, and possibly pre-clinical AD, might therefore be predicted to show impairments of peripheral reaching, but no prior study has examined this. Our aim was to characterise peripheral reaching in patients with amnestic Mild Cognitive Impairment (MCI) and typical AD, by comparison with age-matched controls (HC). A Peripheral Misreaching Index (PMI) was used to quantify differences in spatial accuracy between peripheral and free (central) reaching. Case-control analyses showed significant peripheral misreaching in a small subset of individuals with AD and MCI, but we found no overall differences between groups. Exploratory analyses revealed that reaching movements were slower and temporally extended in AD and MCI compared to HC, which is consistent with previous findings. Our findings show that, although gross spatial inaccuracy when reaching to peripheral targets is not prominent in AD or MCI, slowed visuomotor processing may be a characteristic feature of prodromal AD.
coauthors: Alexandra G. Mitchell, University of Edinburgh; Stephanie Rossit, University of East Anglia; Annie Warman, University of East Anglia; Suvankar Pal, University of Edinburgh; Michael Hornberger, University of East Anglia; Robert D. McIntosh, University of Edinburgh
theme: Theme A: Development, Neurodegenerative Disorders and Injury

title: How do the blind ‘see’?  The role of spontaneous brain activity in self-generated perception
abstract: Spontaneous brain activity has long been studied, but little is known about its behavioral implications. It has previously been hypothesized that spontaneous brain activity underlies unprompted (internally-generated) behavior. Here, we test whether spontaneous brain activity might underlie internally-generated vision. We test this hypothesis by studying the cortical visual system of five blind individuals who experience vivid visual hallucinations (Charles Bonnet Syndrome, CBS). Neural populations in the visual system of these individuals are deprived of external input, which may lead to their hyper-sensitization to spontaneous activity fluctuations. To test whether these spontaneous fluctuations can subserve visual hallucinations, the fMRI brain activity of CBS participants obtained while they reported their hallucinations (spontaneous internally-generated vision) was compared to the : 1) brain activity evoked by veridical vision (externally-triggered vision) in sighted controls who were presented with a visual simulation of the hallucinatory streams; and 2) brain activity of non-hallucinating blind controls during visual imagery (cued internally-generated vision). All conditions showed activity spanning large portions of the visual system. However, only the hallucination condition in the CBS participants demonstrated unique temporal dynamics, characterized by a build-up of neural activity prior to the reported onset of hallucinations. This build-up was most pronounced in early visual cortex and then decayed along the visual hierarchy. These results suggest that, in the absence of external visual input, a build-up of spontaneous fluctuations in early visual cortex may activate the visual hierarchy, thereby triggering the experience of vision.
coauthors: Meytal Wilf, MySpace Lab, Department of Clinical Neuroscience, Lausanne University Hospital, Lausanne, Switzerland; Boris Rosin, Department of Ophthalmology, Hadassah-Hebrew University Medical Center, Jerusalem 91120, Israel; Marlene Behrmann, Department of Psychology and Neuroscience Institute, Carnegie Mellon University, Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, 15213, USA; Rafael Malach, Department of Neurobiology, Weizmann Institute of Science, Rehovot, 7610001, Israel
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Control over sampling boosts numerical evidence processing in decisions from experience
abstract:
Humans routinely sample information about alternatives before committing to a choice. However, the level of control over the sampling can differ: In some situations, the decision maker can decide what to sample (e.g., from which alternative) and/or how much (when to stop sampling), while in other settings, the provision of decision information is determined by external sources. Behavioral studies indicate that self-controlled sampling can modulate accuracy and recency biases in decisions from sequential numerical samples. However, the neurocognitive underpinnings of these behavioral effects are poorly understood.

Here, we recorded EEG while human participants accumulated numerical evidence about two choice alternatives (two-armed bandits). Before commiting to a choice, participants were free to decide from which alternatives to sample (partial control) or, additionally, when to stop sampling (full control). In matched baseline conditions, sample presentation was entirely pre-determined (no control; yoked conditions).

Behaviorally, we found heightened choice accuracy under full control, but not under partial control, compared to yoked baseline conditions. Unlike in previous work, recency biases were invariantly evident in all conditions under study. Turning to the EEG data, early visual responses (P1/N1) to the number samples did not differ between conditions. However, multivariate analyses revealed that the neural encoding of numerical information (cardinality, approx. 290-600 ms after sample onset), was enhanced under full control, mirroring the pattern in behavioral accuracy. Interestingly, this enhancement of numerical processing was not limited to late samples near the time of stopping, but was evident early on in the sample sequence. Consistently, we found a steeper ramping-up of late parietal signals throughout sequential evidence accumulation under full control.

Together, our findings indicate that control over sampling, and in particular over stopping, can enhance the encoding of numerical information in decisions from experience. The results replicate and extend previous findings of a neural numberline in multivariate EEG signals, and help understand the benefit of self-directed information search in human decision making.
coauthors: Ralph Hertwig, Max Planck Institute for Human Development; Bernhard Spitzer, Max Planck Institute for Human Development
institution: Max Planck Institute for Human Development (grid.419526.d)
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Searching for a neuromarker of spatial attention bias in school-aged children
abstract: Visuo-spatial attention is a fundamental cognitive function that enables us to navigate visual environments efficiently. We recently found that children at ages 6-8 exhibit a preference for the left-hand side of space over the right-hand side when allocating attention. Such leftward attention biases in children gradually diminished with increasing age (manuscript under review). In adults, a subject’s spatial bias indicates an asymmetry in attentional weights generated within the dorsal fronto-parietal attention network (also known as Dorsal Attention Network) to direct attention to the contralateral side (Szczepanski & Kastner, 2013). Thus, leftward biases in children may indicate a hemispheric asymmetry in the developing attention network, which gradually achieves a more balanced control of spatial attention as a function of age. To explore this possibility, we first searched for a neuromarker of attention biases in children by building a functional connectivity-based predictive model (Shen et al., 2017) with a priori regions of interest. We measured spatial biases using a landmark task in school-aged children (age 6-12; N = 37) and collected functional MRI data while children were watching a short movie clip. We identified topographic areas in the frontal and parietal cortices by using a probabilistic atlas (Wang et al., 2015), such as Frontal Eye Fields (FEF) and subregions along the Intraparietal Sulcus (IPS). We were able to build a model that successfully predicted each child’s spatial bias from connectivity patterns across the fronto-parietal areas. Using a whole-brain parcellation scheme (Schaefer et al., 2018), we found that spatial biases were predicted specifically from this attention network, but not from other networks. Future work using this predictive modeling approach to examine the development of the attention network will be discussed. Our study provides a lens to better understand the link between attention behavior and the fronto-parietal attention network in typical and atypical development.
coauthors: Patricia Hoyos, Princeton University; Sabine Kastner, Princeton University
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Glutamate-to-GABA neurotransmitter switching induced by drugs of abuse and its impact on behavior
abstract:
Repeated exposure to drugs of abuse induces plastic changes in the brain that contribute to the appearance of drug-induced behavioral alterations. However, the relevance of some of these plastic changes and the extent of their behavioral impact have not yet been elucidated. An environmentally-induced form of neuroplasticity only beginning to be investigated in the context of drugs of abuse is neurotransmitter switching, which occurs when neurons lose expression of one transmitter and gain expression of another one, often switching the sign of the synapse and causing changes in behavior. 
To determine whether exposure to drugs causes neurotransmitter switching, we chronically exposed mice to either phencyclidine (PCP) or methamphetamine. These two drugs have different targets and mechanisms of action in the brain, but produce similar behavioral alterations such as cognitive deficits, hyperlocomotion and locomotor sensitization. 
We find that repeated administration of either PCP or methamphetamine induces a subset of excitatory glutamatergic neurons in the prelimbic cortex of adult mice to gain an inhibitory GABAergic phenotype, while losing the expression of the glutamatergic marker vesicular glutamate transporter 1. These changes occur in the same neurons as shown using transgenic mice in which glutamatergic neurons are permanently labelled by mCherry. To test the link between this neurotransmitter switch and drug-induced behavioral alterations we prevented the ability of glutamatergic neurons to gain GABA by injecting a Cre-dependent AAV expressing GAD1shRNA in the prelimbic cortex of vGluT1::Cre +/- mice prior to exposure to PCP. This treatment rescues PCP-induced cognitive deficits and locomotor sensitization, establishing a cause-and-effect relationship between the PCP-induced glutamate-to-GABA neurotransmitter switch and the behavioral alterations we have examined. 
We are now investigating the role of brain activity in mediating this neurotransmitter switching, as well as analyzing the downstream targets of switching neurons and other switching events at the whole brain level using Clarity.
coauthors: Nicholas C. Spitzer
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Flexible operation of serial dependence in perceptual decision-making
abstract: Perceptual decision-making can be biased towards recent choices. In many cases, the recent past information stored in working memory is structured (e.g., a continuous attribute with a categorical behavioral-relevant choice). How exactly these information affects the dynamic decision process still remains unclear. We examined this ?attractive? serial dependence using a categorization task with auditory stimuli that vary along two attribute dimensions: gender (male to female, 5 levels) and syllable (?ba? to ?da?, 5 levels). We found that categorization of both gender and syllable exhibited a positive serial dependence on previous choices. However, the underlying dynamic process differed between the attributes. For gender, the amplitude of serial dependence was modulated by the similarity between previous and current stimuli, with participants more likely to follow their previous choice if the previous and current sounds were similar (and they responded more quickly in this case). For syllable, the dependence on previous choice did not depend on similarity between successive stimuli. With the drift-diffusion model, we further showed that in gender categorization, the past history (percept and choice) influenced the evidence accumulation, but in syllable categorization, the past choice mainly biased the starting point of accumulation. Next, participants were asked to rate how much the stimulus sounded male/female and ?ba?/?da?. We found that ratings of gender varied continuously along the male/female dimension but ratings of ?ba?/?da? showed a bimodal distribution. Our results suggest that during the categorization task, the continuous percept and categorical choice of gender are possibly both stored in working memory, but for syllable, perception is same as decision, both categorical. The different structures of recent past information may result in the different operations of serial dependence in perceptual decision-making.
coauthors: Xing Tian, Division of Arts and Sciences, New York University Shanghai, NYU-ECNU Institute of Brain and Cognitive Science, New York University Shanghai, Shanghai, PRC; David Alais, The University of Sydney, School of Psychology, NSW 2006, Australia
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Optimizing spinal cord stimulation for bladder control using evoked nerve and muscle responses
abstract:
Bladder dysfunction is widespread and has a substantial impact on daily life, but effective management strategies remain elusive. Using neurostimulation, it may be possible to recruit the sensorimotor reflexes that control the lower urinary tract and thereby restore bladder function. Epidural spinal cord stimulation (SCS) has clinical precedent for treating back pain, and we have previously shown that it can target the bladder by selectively recruiting lower urinary tract afferents. Additionally, we have effectively produced both inhibition and excitation of bladder contractions. However, the optimal stimulation parameters to evoke voiding or continence can span a wide space, including amplitude, frequency, and stimulation location, and these factors often vary between subjects. Here, we investigate the relationship of stimulation-evoked muscle and nerve activity with evoked bladder pressure changes. 

We placed high-density SCS electrode arrays (MicroLeads Inc, Ripple LLC) to stimulate the sacral spinal cord in cats. To record stimulation-evoked activity on lower urinary tract afferents, we placed nerve cuffs on the pelvic nerve, the pudendal nerve and its branches, as well as the sciatic nerve. To measure muscle activation, we recorded electromyographic (EMG) activity from the external urethral sphincter, external anal sphincter, and the gluteal muscle. Using a catheter in the bladder, we recorded changes in pressure. 

We extracted features from the nerve cuff and EMG recordings, including peak to peak amplitude, time of maximum and minimum amplitudes, length of response, and mean absolute value of several time bins of the recording. After performing a principal component analysis, we determined that it is often possible to distinguish electrodes that do not produce a functional response from those that do, as well as separate the continence and voiding responses based on neural activity.
coauthors: Chaitanya Gopinath, University of Pittsburgh Department of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation; Ritesh Kumar, University of Pittsburgh Department of Bioengineering; Robert Gaunt, University of Pittsburgh Department of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Systematic biases in rare-event inferences
abstract: When choosing between different options we often rely on information of non-uniform frequency and quality. For example, when evidence for one option is rare, these observations are of high quality, while evidence that may be abundant is often less convincing. Moreover, the information available to an observer is often limited, restricting the amount of high-quality evidence that may be obtained.  How do human observers make decisions in situations with asymmetric evidence quality, especially when the amount of evidence is limited? Recruiting over 200 subjects from crowdsourcing platform Amazon Mechanical Turk, we consider how humans approach these decisions with a task in which subjects observe a sequence of red/blue balls drawn with replacement from one of two jars with known ratios of ball colors. Subjects must infer which of the two equally probable jars the balls were drawn from. When both jars have ball ratios that favor the same color (one ball color is rare), subjects show a strong bias toward the jar with the more extreme ratio, even when evidence came from the higher-fraction jar. Notably, these biases are predicted by an ideal Bayesian observer.  However, many human observers show an enhanced bias in line with a Bayesian but not optimal approach. We have attributed this enhancement to subjects underweighing the information gained by a rare ball observation along with an overall preference for the more extreme response. We confirmed these results using model-free information theory metrics that showed a drop-off in the effective use of task information as subjects deviated from the ideal observer. Thus, our study yields new quantitative insights into rare-event inference, which is relevant to both real-world problems (like predicting stock-market crashes) and common laboratory tasks (like inferring rare state changes in dynamic environments).
coauthors: Josh Gold, University of Pennsylvania; Kresimir Josic, University of Houston; Zachary Kilpatrick, University of Colorado Boulder
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: A Bayesian map of the striatal microciruitry reveals different wiring processes for D1 and D2 spiny projection neurons
abstract: Serving as input region of the basal ganglia, a set of interconnected midbrain structures thought to determine action selection, the striatum is mainly made up of spiny projection neurons (SPNs) which fall into two main categories based on the expression of either D1-type dopamine receptors or D2-type dopamine receptors. These distinct neuronal populations project into two different pathways towards the globus pallidus, but also make lateral connections which could constitute feedback inhibition of the circuit. In addition, interneurons in the striatum also connect to these SPNs. This complex microcircuitry is often overlooked in models of the basal ganglia which typically adopt a simple feedforward view of striatal function, when in fact, the connections between SPNs in the striatum could be crucial in determining their output to the globus pallidus. Fortunately for modellers, experimental studies to characterize these connections have been conducted and it seems that D1 neurons make fewer connections than D2 neurons and prefer to connect to other D2 neurons. However, the robustness of these results is undermined by the fact that when reporting these findings, experimenters failed to provide an estimate of the measurement error. We take the opportunity of correcting this oversight to introduce a novel Bayesian approach for estimating and comparing probabilities of connection. This method allows us to easily combine different data sets from different studies, to plug in the results of previous experiments in the form of a Bayesian prior, and to easily compare connection probabilities visually. By applying this method to two previous experimental studies, we find that D1 neurons do indeed form fewer connections than D2 neurons, but that evidence for preferential targeting by D1 neurons of other D1 neurons is currently lacking. We then go on to propose a method for extracting the probability of connection given distance between neurons.
coauthors: Mark Humphries, University of Nottingham
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Automated estimation of morphology of a neocortical neuron using in vivo LFP data
abstract:
New technologies are beginning to provide neurophysiological data at increasing levels of precision and at multiple scales including at single neuron and network levels. In parallel, advances in machine learning-based algorithms and architectures have spurred the development of several automated neural parameter estimation schemes. As an example, statistical inference can be combined with machine learning schemes to provide principled approaches that can integrate multiple data sources to handle variability, quantify uncertainty and incorporate prior knowledge. A specific instance of such a hybrid scheme is sequential neural posterior estimation, which combines the advantages of statistical and mechanistic modeling (SNPE; Goncalves et al., 2020)

We use the approximate Bayesian computation inference algorithm SNPE to infer the morphological parameters of a single neuron from multi-electrode in vivo extracellular voltage recordings. In this inverse modeling scheme, we designed a generic biophysical single neuron model with stylized morphology that had adjustable parameters for the dimensions of the soma, basal and apical dendrites, and their locations and orientations relative to the multi-electrode probe. The model includes simplified biophysics and had a module to estimate extracellular potential at desired locations. We used the SNPE algorithm with the single cell model to infer the posterior distribution of the morphological parameters, given the in vivo extracellular spike waveform of a putative rodent neocortical cell near the electrode as the observed data. Such an approach provides estimation of the morphology that best matches the spatiotemporal profile of the extracellular action potential recorded on a multisite silicon probe (Neuropixel). The next step will involve inference of the parameters related to the biophysics of the neuron, and may need to be performed iteratively with the inference of morphology parameters. Our long-term goal is to develop a publicly accessible toolbox that automates the process of inferring neuronal morphology and parameters from in vivo extracellular voltages.
coauthors: Ziao Chen; Drew B. Headley; Satish S. Nair
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: M1 GABA relates to functional connectivity changes and retention in visuomotor adaptation
abstract: Interacting with our ever-changing physical environment requires continual recalibration of the motor system. One mechanism by which this occurs is motor adaptation. Understanding how motor adaptation is implemented by the human brain, how different regions work in concert to retain adaptive movement accuracy, and how this function is linked to metabolic use of neurochemicals poses an important challenge in neuroscience. In humans, motor sequence learning is related to concentration of γ-aminobutyric acid (GABA) in the primary motor cortex (M1). However, the role of M1 GABA in adaptation - where behaviour is acquired outside M1, but retained within M1 - is unclear. Here, we used an ultra-high field MR multimodal acquisition to address the hypothesis that M1 GABA and M1-Cerebellar functional connectivity would relate to retention of adaptation, but not acquisition of adaptation. As such, we demonstrate higher baseline M1 [GABA] relates to greater retention of adaptation but does not relate to adaptation-acquisition. This relationship is mediated by change in M1-Cerebellar functional connectivity: higher M1 [GABA] relates to a decrease in M1-Cerebellar connectivity, resulting in greater retention. These findings showed anatomical, neurochemical and behavioural specificity: As expected, no relationship was found between retention and a control metabolite, as well as retention and connectivity change between control regions and no relationship was found between M1 [GABA] and behaviour in a control condition. The implication of a mechanistic link from neurochemistry to retention significantly advances our understanding of population variability in retention behaviour and provides a crucial step towards developing therapeutic interventions to restore motor abilities.
coauthors: Caroline Nettekoven, Wellcome Centre for Integrative Neuroimaging, FMRIB, University of Oxford, UK ; Ned Jenkinson, School of Sport, Exercise and Rehabilitation Sciences, University of Birmingham, UK ; Charlotte Stagg, Wellcome Centre for Integrative Neuroimaging, FMRIB, University of Oxford, UK
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Attitudes as Emergent Products of Associative Evaluations, Metacognitive Assessment, and Self-Report: A Computational Approach
abstract: Attitudinal dynamics have been described by dual-process theorists as having two distinct patterns—implicit and explicit. However, the interaction and blending of the two have been poorly understood. There is empirical and theoretical research on the circumstances under which these processes dissociate and align, yet a principled account of their interaction has not been proposed. In this paper, we present a computational model that formalizes the interaction between implicit and explicit attitudinal dynamics, and generates predictions of experimental explicit attitude measurement data based on these dynamics. We employ the Attitudinal Entropy framework by Dalege et al. (2016, 2018) to simulate implicit attitudes. To incorporate dynamics of explicit attitude formation and report, we expand the model by translating it into Bayesian terms, and use the Active Inference framework (Friston, 2010; Friston et al., 2017) to build a higher-level, (minimally) metacognitive module that assesses the real-time implicit level dynamics, stores memory of past assessments and directs self-report. Bidirectional communication among the modules allows to reproduce a variety of empirical phenomena related to self-report. Firstly, we simulate forced choice self-report for various settings that modulate explicit-implicit interactions, showing attitude strengthening effects under functional metacognition but not when metacognitive assessment is overconfident. Secondly, we simulate what happens on the implicit and explicit attitude levels when a person is forced to give a specific report (e.g., due to social pressure). The model sheds light on cognitive mechanisms underlying self-report and lays a foundation for a computational analysis of heterogeneous cognitive processes that combine to produce emergent attitudinal phenomena.
coauthors: Han van der Maas, Department of Psychology, University of Amsterdam; Casper Hesp, Department of Psychology, University of Amsterdam
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: The visual world in the dog brain
abstract: To create representations of the environment, the visual pathway processes stimulus features in increasingly complex stages, from low-level feature detection to high-level object recognition. In primates, the occipital lobe performs the first feature detection steps, while computations required for object recognition take place in the inferior-temporal cortex, a region characterized for having neurons selective towards particular stimulus categories. In dogs, there is conflicting evidence that nevertheless points towards an organization similar to the one found in primates. Our aim was to describe regions in the dog cortex that process visual stimuli similarly to certain primate brain regions, including both low-level feature detection and high-level category selectivity. We hypothesized similarity between the patterns of activity in the dog occipital cortex and a model of the primary visual cortex (V1 model), and between the patterns of activity in the dog temporo-occipital cortex and a model of semantic organization (Category model).  We acquired functional magnetic resonance images while the participants (13 humans, 10 dogs) observed the videos of cars, cats, dogs, and humans. Using representational similarity analysis, we compared the activity patterns of different regions of the human and dog cortex with the two models (i.e. V1 model and Category model). We found a significant correlation between the V1 model and the patterns of activity of a bilateral cluster involving the left parahippocampal gyrus in dogs and a bilateral cluster involving the right intracalcarine cortex in humans. In turn, the Category model correlated with the patterns of activity of a cluster involving the left suprasylvian gyrus in dogs, and a bilateral cluster involving the lateral occipital complex in humans. The finding of comparable cluster locations in the cortex of the two species suggests a similar functional organization for visual object recognition in the human and the dog brain.
coauthors: Laura V. Cuaya; Eduardo Rojas; Eszter Farkas; Attila Andics
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Mouse nucleus prepositus neurons encode eye movement during passive and active head movement
abstract:
The vestibular system plays a crucial role in our everyday life as it ensures gaze and postural stabilization and the sense of self-motion by detecting the head motion in space. Previous work done in rodents (i.e. mice and rats) has led to the view that the nucleus prepositus hypoglossi (NPH) and the supragenual nucleus (SGN) in brainstem relay vestibular information from the vestibular system to head direction (HD) network. However, the NPH has also been long-known to comprise the oculomotor integrator which plays an essential role in eye movement control by holding the eye at an eccentric position in orbit after the saccade. Further, a study in non-human primates (Dale & Cullen, 2013), established that neurons in the NPH predominantly encode eye-related rather than head-related movement signals during both passively-generated and voluntary head movements. To date, however, it remains unknown whether neurons in the NPH of rodents encode eye-related and/or head-related movement signals. 

We hypothesized that NPH neurons in mouse, as in primate, preferentially encode eye-related signals during passive-generated and voluntary movement. Accordingly, we recorded the activity of NPH neurons with both with tungsten electrodes and/or 960 recording-site Neuropixel probes. Eye movement was simultaneously recorded with an AMR magnetic field sensor during behavioral protocols (Beraneck & Cullen 2007;Medrea & Cullen, 2013) designed to dissociate eye and head movement sensitivities (i.e.,  vestibular-ocular reflex (VOR), optokinetic reflex (OKR) and changes in static eye position). Our preliminary single unit recording indicated that neurons in the NPH of mice primarily output eye-related information during both passive and active head movement. Further, eye movement responses were nonlinear; modulation gain decreased with increasing eye velocity. Overall, our preliminary results suggest NPH neurons in mice mainly function to stabilize gaze, consistent with the non-human primate model.
coauthors: Aamna Lawrence, Johns Hopkins University; Kathleen Cullen, Johns Hopkins University
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Correcting for Superficial Bias in 7T Gradient Echo fMRI
abstract: The arrival of submillimetre ultra high-field fMRI makes it possible to compare activation profiles across cortical layers. However, the Blood Oxygenation Level Dependent (BOLD) signal measured by Gradient-Echo fMRI is biased towards superficial layers of the cortex, which is a serious confound for laminar analysis. Several univariate and multivariate analysis methods have been proposed to correct this bias. We compare these methods using computational simulations and example human 7T fMRI data from Regions-of-Interest (ROIs) during a visual attention paradigm. The simulations show that two methods - the ratio of ROI means across conditions and a novel application of Deming regression - offer the most robust correction for superficial bias. Deming regression has the additional advantage that it does not require that the conditions differ in their mean activation over voxels within an ROI. When applied to the example dataset, these methods suggest that attentional modulation of activation is similar across cortical layers within the ventral visual stream, despite a naïve activation-based analysis producing stronger modulation in superficial layers.
coauthors: Marta Correia, University of Cambridge; Catarina Rua, University of Cambridge; Chris Rodgers, University of Cambridge; Richard Henson, University of Cambridge; Johan Carlin, University of Cambridge
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Integrating Whole-Brain Neural Activity Data with Nonlinear and Connectome-Based Models of Neural Circuits for Prediction of Behavior in Freely Moving C. elegans
abstract: In the last few years, it became possible to image the activity of large numbers of neurons in freely behaving specimens and thus to collect data on neural dynamics and behavior simultaneously for a number of model organisms. Such data has been used to design data-driven models that can predict behavior from single neuron scale activity. However, today, these approaches often do not take the nonlinearity of the transformation between neural activity and behavior into account, and similarly do not consider how the connectome computationally enables the generation of this neural activity. We analyze the recently released data on freely moving C. elegans to demonstrate two approaches for attacking this problem: (i) we show that nonlinear models can achieve similar features as and better correspondence to held out data than linear models; (ii) we initialize connectome based neural circuit models and employ activity data to estimate activity in other neurons or the stimulus; we propose this as an approach for closing the gap between activity-based and connectome-driven models to move towards models that are more consistent with existing data and can generalize to different experimental settings.
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Maintenance of refined visual receptive fields through BDNF-TrkB signaling depends on presynaptic GABA levels, not postsynaptic GABAA receptors or the scaffolding proteins gephyrin and PSD-95.
abstract: The development of visual response properties is thought to require early sensory experience, but our previous work showed that visual experience is not necessary, and spontaneous activity is sufficient for visual receptive fields (RFs) in superior colliculus (SC) or visual cortex (V1) to refine. Instead, juvenile visual experience is necessary only to maintain RF size in adulthood via a BDNF-TrkB dependent mechanism that preserves lateral inhibition. RF expansion significantly hampers visual processing ability of dark reared (DR) hamsters, and treatment with a TrkB agonist during a critical period rescues it. In this study, we investigated whether postsynaptic changes could underlie RF expansion in SC and V1 of DR adults. Dark rearing could interfere with the maturation of GABAA receptor (GABAAR) subunit composition, resulting in a higher α2/α1 (immature/mature) subunit ratio, compared to light reared hamsters. The α5/α1 (extrasynaptic/synaptic) GABAAR subunit ratio in DR adults might be higher than normal, resulting in lower phasic inhibition. Alternatively, dark rearing could reduce gephyrin localization at the synapse, reducing the stability of the synaptic GABAA receptors and consequently, the overall inhibitory effect of GABA. Lastly, dark rearing could also result in reduced synaptic accumulation of the scaffold protein, postsynaptic density-95 (PSD-95), resulting in reduced synaptic anchoring of NMDA receptors (NMDARs) and AMPA receptors (AMPARs), potentially affecting long-term potentiation. Using western blotting, we found no significant differences between DR and normal animals in SC or V1 for the synaptic GABAAR subunits, or the scaffolding proteins anchoring the GABAA or glutamate receptors at the synapse. Our results rule out several alternative explanations for the loss of GABAAR function identified by our earlier work, and support reductions in presynaptic GABA rather than postsynaptic alterations as the primary explanation for the loss of RF stability in DR animals.
coauthors: David B. Mudd, Neuroscience Institute, Georgia State University, Atlanta, GA USA;  Nitheyaa Shree, Neuroscience Institute, Georgia State University, Atlanta, GA USA;  Sarah L. Pallas, Molecular and Cellular Biology Graduate Program, University of Massachusetts Amherst, MA USA, Neuroscience Institute, Georgia State University, Atlanta, GA USA.
theme: Theme A: Development, Neurodegenerative Disorders and Injury
