title: Associations of pickleball-play with cognition among older adults: A longitudinal study
abstract:
Inevitably, physical and cognitive abilities decline with age. The population of those over the age of 65 is currently doubling (Passel & Cohn, 2008). Contrary to aerobic exercises, open skill exercise has been shown to improve decision making, RT, and visual capabilities (Guo et al., 2016; Marks, 2006; Jafarzadehpur et al., 2012). Pickleball is rapidly growing and is recommended for older adults because of the court size, interaction, and is easy to learn, yet is moderate in intensity (Ryu et al., 2018). Pickleball can increase physical well-being and life satisfaction, but lacks research on cognition. We hypothesized that older adults who participate in pickleball will show improved cognition through perceptual learning. 
A non-experimental, longitudinal study was used to compare 83 healthy older adults. Groups were based on exercise characteristics (advanced pickleball-AP, novice pickleball-NP, aerobic exercise, inactive). A battery of eight standard and cognitive assessments (Multiple object tracking, Useful Field of View, Flanker, N-back) were given. 
UFOV. The aerobic and AP groups had quicker processing times. Older participants in the AP group had decreased processing times. As pickleball players age, it seems that the continuation of the sport can help maintain processing speed. 
MOT. The aerobic group was more accurate. The reason we may not have found the pickleball groups performing like the aerobic group is that these visual functions may take consecutive years and multiple methods of exercising. 
Flanker. The aerobic group had quicker RT. Playing pickleball more times a week can increase comfort level and familiarity with an unpredictable environment which could be why their RT was quicker.
N-back. In general, aerobic exercise can strengthen WM more than pickleball or that the N-back is not sensitive enough to assess changes in WM. 
Open skilled exercise can potentially maintain and improve cognitive decline in older adults more than traditional aerobic exercise. As the population of older adults grows, it’s important to maximize their quality of life and a game of pickleball could be part of the solution.
coauthors: Inga Sogaard, Rui Ni
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Manipulating a whip: the advantage of primitive actions
abstract:
Humans achieve astonishing dexterity, out-performing contemporary robots despite vastly different wetware (e.g., musculo-skeletal system) and software (e.g., neural information processing). We propose that this is accomplished by encoding movements based on at least three distinct classes of motor primitives --- submovements and oscillations for forward-path control of motion, and mechanical impedances for managing physical interaction. Composing movements in terms of parameterized primitive actions may be an essential simplification required for learning, performance, and retention of complex manipulation skills. To test this hypothesis, we focused on one of the most complex and exotic tools humans can manipulate --- a whip. We tested (in simulation) whether a distant target could be reached with a whip using a (small) number of motor primitives, whose parameters could be learned through optimization.
Regardless of the target location in 3D space, this approach was able to manage the complexity of an extremely high degree-of-freedom (DOF) system (54-DOF yielding a 108-dimensional state-space representation), and identified the optimal upper-limb movement that achieved the task. Detailed equations of motion describing the complex whip dynamics were not needed for this approach, thereby dramatically simplifying the complexity of the control task. 
Simulation results were in good qualitative agreement with experimental observations which indicate that human subjects use a small number of primitive motions to reach a target with a whip. These results support our hypothesis that composing control using motor primitives may be a key strategy which humans use to enable their remarkable dexterity.
coauthors: Aleksei Krotov, Northeastern University; Marta Russo, Northeastern University; Hillary Hoyt, Northeastern University; Reza Razavian, Northeastern University; Mahdiar Edraki, Northeastern University; Joshua C. Sohn, MIT; Dagmar Sternad, Northeastern University; Neville Hogan, MIT;
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Revisiting the correlation between the static and dynamic impedance during electroconvulsive therapy (ECT)
abstract: While static impedance and dynamic impedance has long been recognized as markers of individual difference in electroconvulsive therapy (ECT), their etiology and consequence are undetermined – including how they impact seizure generation. A typically high static impedance is relied on to suggest an expected high dynamic impedance, and hence the need to correct electrode setup. Yet, the correlation between individual static impedance and dynamic impedance has remained elusive, with numerous prior studies suggesting it does not exist. This is a retrospective analysis of static impedance, dynamic impedance, seizure charge threshold, and patient demographic data recorded from a total of 90 patients (with a total of 622 ECT daily sessions and 622 ECT stimulations) involved in two previously published clinical trials.  These ECT courses utilized right unilateral (RUL) or bilateral (BL) montage placements, with either 0.3 ms (ultrabrief) or 1.5 ms (brief) pulse duration. Our results demonstrate a correlation between static impedance and dynamic impedance, evident across clinical trial centers, montages, and pulse durations, considering either across session averages or single stimulations. The strength of correlations varied across these conditions, suggesting how they might have been missed in prior analysis.
coauthors: Gozde Unal; Carliza Canela; Jaiti Swami; Samantha Cohen; Niranjan Khadka; Harold Sackeim; Marom Bikson
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Erasing Fear: Challenges for Decoded Neurofeedback
abstract:
Neural interventions in humans are either anatomically specific but invasive (e.g. ablations of cortical tissue), or non-invasive but with anatomical limited resolution (e.g. TMS). Most of these interventions are functionally non-specific. Decoded Neurofeedback (DecNef) is different: by leveraging fMRI and machine learning, DecNef creates non-invasive, functionally targeted interventions of neural activity. Aided by external reward, subjects unconsciously self-regulate targeted multi-variate patterns of their own BOLD-activity. Subjects self-activate patterns of neural activity indistinguishable from patterns corresponding to seeing images of some target stimulus type (e.g. spiders). Through trial and error and a sophisticated online readout of their neural activity paired with a reward system, subjects learn to create “spider” activity patterns in the absence of spiders. The clinical applications are promising. A popular treatment of phobias and post-traumatic stress disorder is exposure therapy, but it takes an enormous toll on patients who have to endure being exposed to their source of fear and trauma. With DecNef, because patients are unaware of the target, they can be *unconsciously* “exposed” to patterns of neural activity similar to those of their feared target effectively reducing their phobic symptoms without undergoing the emotional labor. Despite its promise for cognitive neuroscience and for the clinic, DecNef’s mechanisms of action remain poorly understood. This raises theoretical questions about our understanding of neural representations and neural intervention that I’ll discuss in this talk:

(1) What is the status of the neural representations targeted by DecNef?

(2) What kind of voxel-to-neural activity mapping can allow its impressive yet mysterious functional-specificity?

(3) Because of its underdetermined and potentially long-lasting effects (up to two months), can harmful or undesirable patterns of activity be activated unbeknownst to subjects. Could new phobias be instilled, precious memories altered or erased, undesired associations created?
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: No evidence for reduced precision-weighting of prediction errors in autistic adolescents' ERPs or behaviour during adaptation
abstract:
Predictive Processing accounts of autism posit that autistic individuals are less biased by expectations than those without autism when interpreting incoming sensory information, most recently formulated as stronger precision-weighting of prediction errors. Since precision-weighting is fundamental to all information processing, any differences between autistic and non-autistic individuals should be domain general and observable in both behaviour and brain responses.

 

The current study uses gaze-direction adaptation as a test case for the theoretical predictions. The current combined EEG and behavioural study with eye-tracking coregistration investigates whether increased precision-weighting of prediction errors is evident through smaller adaptation after-effects in the behaviour and ERP responses of autistic adolescents when compared to non-autistic peers.

 

Participants viewed stimuli used in previous studies (Jenkins et al., 2006; Pellicano, Ewing & Rhodes, 2013; Ward, Braukmann, Buitelaar & Hunnius, 2020) and responded with button presses whether they perceived the gaze direction as left, direct, or right. Ordinal multi-level modelling showed that both autistic and non-autistic adolescents responded consistent with behavioural adaptation (β = -1.49, SE = 0.16, z = -9.32, estimated p < .001), with no effect of group (β = 0.41, SE = 0.30, z = 1.36, estimated p = 0.16) or interaction between group and experimental condition (β = -0.18, SE = 0.18, z = -1.01, estimated p = 0.31).

 

Cluster-based permutation testing of the ERP responses did not show the expected larger reduction in the N170 or P2 components in response to adapted than unadapted stimuli, and no group difference was detected.

 

The current study is one of the first to take advantage of neuroscientific methods to test specific predictions from theoretical accounts of Predictive Processing in autism. Combined with the few other available studies, the current findings raise challenges for the theory and suggest no fundamental difference in precision-weighting of prediction errors in autism.
coauthors: Emma K Ward, Freie Universitaet Berlin, Donders Institute for Brain, Cognition and Behaviour; Jan K Buitelaar, Donders Institute for Brain, Cognition and Behaviour, Radboud University Medical Centre; Sabine Hunnius, Donders Institute for Brain, Cognition and Behaviour
theme: Theme A: Development, Neurodegenerative Disorders and Injury

title: Disrupted Organelle Dynamics in Autophago-lysosomal Pathway in the Drosophila Models of C9-ALS In Vivo
abstract: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a progressive neurodegenerative disorder characterized by preferential death of motor neurons leading to muscle weakness and atrophy. Although the majority of ALS cases are sporadic, a G4C2 hexanucleotide repeat expansion (HRE) in C9orf72 is the most common inherited cause of ALS (C9-ALS). Since ALS displays selective vulnerability of motor neurons with cytoplasmic protein accumulation, we hypothesize that changes in intracellular organelle dynamics relevant to protein degradation pathway by G4C2 HRE may be a critical factor in C9-ALS motor neuronal degeneration. Here, we imaged Drosophila motor neurons expressing 30 G4C2 repeats (30R), and investigated the axonal transport of multiple organelles and endoplasmic reticulum (ER) dynamics. We found that 30R expression reduces the number of axonal autophagosomes (APs), while it causes local accumulation of late endosomes (LEs) and lysosomes in motor axons. Interestingly, 30R expression led to a marked reduction in AP number within motor neuron synaptic boutons, and this deficit was not restored by neuronal excitation with TrpA1. However, the remaining APs in C9-ALS motor neurons underwent normal maturation and development to amphisomes upon successful fusion with LEs during their secure retrograde transport. Since axonal transport of mitochondria was not affected by 30R expression, we hypothesized that the impaired axonal transport specific to the auto-lysosomal pathway is not because of global disruption in axonal transport. Instead, we found the converted ER structure and impaired ER dynamics in 30R motor neurons by showing rigid ER knots and ER tubule discontinuities. Collectively, our results indicate that pathogenic repeats of G4C2 hexanucleotide impair auto-lysosomal pathway by affecting intracellular organelle dynamics, and suggest an important role of ER integrity in axonal transport relevant to auto-lysosomal function for neuronal proteostasis.
coauthors: Thomas E. Lloyd, Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine
theme: Theme A: Development, Neurodegenerative Disorders and Injury

title: Multiple sequential prediction errors during reward processing in the human brain
abstract: Recent developments in reinforcement learning, cognitive control, and systems neuroscience highlight the complimentary roles in learning of valenced reward prediction errors (RPEs) and non-valenced salience prediction errors (PEs) driven by the magnitude of surprise. A core debate in reward learning focuses on whether valenced and non-valenced PEs can be isolated in the human electroencephalogram (EEG). Here, we combine behavioral modeling and single-trial EEG regression revealing a sequence of valenced and non-valenced PEs in an interval timing task dissociating outcome valence, magnitude, and probability. Multiple regression across temporal, spatial, and frequency dimensions revealed a spatio-tempo-spectral cascade from valenced RPE value represented by the feedback related negativity event-related potential (ERP) followed by non-valenced RPE magnitude and outcome probability effects indexed by subsequent P300 and late frontal positivity ERPs. The results show that learning is supported by a sequence of multiple PEs evident in the human EEG.
coauthors: Colin W. Hoy, UC Berkeley; Sheila C. Steiner, UC Berkeley; Robert T. Knight, UC Berkeley
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: A Neuroethics Framework for Global Brain Projects and Neurotechnology
abstract:
During the last two decades, with the development of technology, the small steps in brain science turned into the giant leap for mankind. Millions of bytes of data generated all over the world to break the brain’s code, to understand inner workings of brain function and hope to find treatments to cognitive diseases. Seven brain initiatives launched around the globe, but no single initiative was able to tackle those challenges. In December 2017, seven initiatives came together and formed International Brain Initiative to combine their effort and accelerate the progress of neurotechnological findings.
Implementing data sharing and standardization mechanism was one of the intents of the initiatives. Human body is known as the biggest data platform but human brain homes to most valuable data. All human behaviour could be understood under the illuminated light of this neurodata. Merging of brain initiatives also brings the question of who will capture this neurodata and how to maintain medical ethics.
Neuroethics could be classified under the umbrella of bioethics but it should also be diverse from the point that our minds are the true representatives of who we are. In this poster I will discuss the neuroethical standards that are proposed by brain initiatives so far and discuss the challenges in neuroethics from the window of neurotechnology and brain-computer interfaces. I aim to recommend some new insights for ethical principles for the effective protection of human subjects.
theme: Theme F: History, Education and Society

title: Leveraging postural embedding to identify sub-millisecond organization of behavior in freely-moving macaques
abstract: Complex behavior is driven by internal states, sensory experiences, and prior learning. Sub-components of behavior are organized by the brain, and are repeated and configured as required. The relative prominence of such sub-components across tasks and individuals provides a unique “behavioral fingerprint”, which can be leveraged to understand the underlying, generating neural circuits. Great progress has been made in decomposing the behavior of model organisms such as rodents, flies, and worms, yet progress for higher-order mammals such as macaques has been limited. This is particularly important, because (1) the behavioral repertoire of lower order animals is more limited, and (2) macaque models of the brain have a greater translational potential for humans. To this end, we hypothesized that during self-motivated behavior, macaques have a unique behavioral fingerprint that allows prediction of the underlying task. We recorded synchronized videos across 62 cameras of freely-moving macaques in a large, unconstrained environment under 3 different task conditions; a foraging task with depleting but predictable rewards, a foraging task with random and unpredictable rewards, and no task at all. From these, we reconstructed 3D poses using OpenMonkeyStudio, a freely available deep-learning software suite we have developed that leverages multi-viewpoint, marker-less image acquisition to reconstruct key body landmarks. Embedding poses across different individuals revealed iconic, sub-millisecond behavioral states. The organization of states exhibited both a local and a global structure; similar states were grouped closely together, and transitions tended to occur between similar states, even though states spanned a much larger space. Importantly, the specific configuration of behaviors – a behavioral fingerprint – was predictive of both the underlying task and individual. Revealing the organization of behavior in a naturalistic environment thus holds great promise for future studies probing the underlying neural substrates that give rise to behavioral differences.
coauthors: Benjamin Voloh, University of Minnesota; Benjamin Y. Hayden, University of Minnesota; Jan Zimmermann, University of Minnesota
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Tracking fast and slow changes in synaptic weights from simultaneously observed pre- and postsynaptic spiking activity
abstract: Synapses change on multiple timescales, ranging from milliseconds to minutes, due to a combination of both short- and long-term plasticity. Here we develop an extension of the common Generalized Linear Model to infer both short- and long-term changes in the coupling between a pre- and post-synaptic neuron based on observed spiking activity. We model short-term synaptic plasticity using additive effects that depend on the presynaptic spike timing, and we model long-term changes in both synaptic weight and baseline firing rate using Point Process Adaptive Smoothing. Using simulations, we first show that this model can accurately recover time-varying synaptic weights 1) for both depressing and facilitating synapses, 2) with a variety of long-term changes (including realistic changes, such as due to STDP), 3) with a range of pre and post-synaptic firing rates, and 4) for both excitatory and inhibitory synapses. We also show the importance of tracking fast changes in synaptic weights, slow changes in synaptic weights, and unexplained variations in baseline firing simultaneously. Omitting any one of these factors can lead to spurious inferences for the others. Altogether, this model provides a flexible framework for tracking short- and long-term variation in spike transmission.
coauthors: Ian Stevenson, Department of Psychological Sciences, University of Connecticut
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: The Parameter Mapping Relationship between LIF Model and Artificial Neuron Model
abstract:
Brain science and cognitive neuroscience have always been considered one of the important sources of inspiration to machine learning algorithms. Although the performance of artificial neural networks (ANNs) can reach the human level on many specific tasks, the strong dependence on labeled data and uninterpretability have been hindering its development. In this regard, many methods were proposed, including the spiking neural networks(SNNs), which are considered to be the third generation of neural network. 

As a brain-inspired network, SNNs has the information transmission mechanism, the processing mechanism closer to the brain, and the lower energy consumption. In recent years, in addition to Hebbian learning mechanism, a supervised learning algorithm using backward propagation has also been proved. However, it does not exceed the effect of ANNs in practical application, especially in the field of target detection and target recognition. Our main objectives are as follows: 1. Establish a connection mechanism between ANNs and SNNs, analyze the differences between the two networks, and narrow the gap between the two networks in practical applications; 2. Extend the local unsupervised learning mechanism to the multi-layer network learning mechanism, and establish a deep network structure; 3. Solve the problem of 'vanishing forward-spike propagation' in deep spiking neural networks. we believe that analyzing the relationship between Leaky Integrate-and-fire (LIF) and artificical neuron model (AN), the basic units of SNNs and ANNs, is the key to solve problems. A parameter mapping is given between LIF and AN, which is verified both theoretically and by simulation analyses for various cases, from a single neuron to a three-layer neural network.
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: A Biophysically Inspired Learning Algorithm for Deep Neural Networks
abstract: Backpropagation (BP) of global error has been the only way to learn artificial deep neural networks efficiently. However, BP in the traditional form is not biologically plausible since the feedback path requires symmetric weights of feedforward. Inspired by the Hebbian plasticity idea of learning synaptic weights from neuronal activities, we propose a novel learning algorithm called Feedback Propagation (FP) that uses a feedback network learned by the changes in the local activations. We show that this results in a local negative feedback loop that produces credit assignments in the global gradient direction. We trained deep, fully connected, and convolutional models on MNIST and CIFAR image recognition datasets with BP and FP algorithms and compared the performances and the learned representations. The results show that FP achieves similar generalization error as BP on fully connected models. However, the convolutional models did not learn as well using the FP algorithm.
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Closed-Loop Acoustic Neurostimulation during Sleep: Targeting theta waves
abstract:
Recently there has been an increasing interest in the potential applications of closed loop neuro-stimulation. Most studies are focused on targeting slow waves during NREM sleep, to improve memory consolidation. REM sleep plays a crucial role in emotional processing, which is essential for mental health. Theta is a hallmark of REM sleep, therefore detecting and manipulating theta waves could pave the way towards targeted interventions in clinical and sub-clinical populations. We present the first results on the development of an algorithm able to detect and target precise phases of theta (4-8 Hz), which could be used to further address how targeting can play a role on memory reactivation and memory consolidation.
Data of nine participants that underwent a night of polysomnography and EEG recordings in the lab. Ten minutes of recorded REM epochs from each subject were used to run the closed-loop acoustic stimulation (CLAS) system, targeting the 0-degree phase of theta.
   Targeting procedure involves an oscillatory phase prediction algorithm, based on non-linear sine fitting on the most recent data segment of unfiltered EEG signal. The criteria for stimulus release are: 1) The fitted sine is in a frequency range of interest, 2) The fitting error is below a given threshold & 3) The prediction is within a delimited future time window. The algorithm is implemented within EventIDE software (Okazolab). This method has been applied to the slow oscillation frequency range.
   Across all participants we achieved a mean target phase of 10.85 degrees (3.58 median), standard deviation of 56.74 degrees and made, on average, 163.78 predictions for each separate REM epoch. 

   These results on offline simulations suggest that it is possible to target specific phases of theta oscillations in a closed loop setup. This brings possibilities of a different tool for non-invasive intervention on processes that happen during sleep.
coauthors: João Patriota ; Elsa Juan; Illia Korjoukov; Umberto Olcese; Lucia Talamini
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Mentation rate during resting state fMRI and trait depressive rumination: Is there a difference between depressed and never-depressed individuals? (A CAN-BIND-4 Analysis)
abstract:
Trait depressive rumination (DR) is the tendency to dwell on the causes, meanings, and consequences of distressing feelings, and is a major risk factor for depressive and other psychiatric disorders. DR is usually assessed with the Response Styles Questionnaire, which has two subscales: Brooding measures the tendency to passively compare one's situation with an unachieved standard, while Reflection measures the tendency to engage in cognitive problem solving to alleviate feelings of distress. A conceptually related construct to DR is mentation rate (MR), or the number of discrete thoughts that one has over time. Little is known about how DR is represented in resting state brain activity measured via functional MRI (RS-fMRI) or if people who frequently ruminate also tend to have a higher MR or lower MR. In this analysis, a novel fMRI processing technique was used to objectively assess individuals’ MR based on the rate of simultaneous whole-brain network activity transitions (Tseng & Poppenk, 2020). This technique was useful for studying DR because it prevented metacognition about one’s DR from biasing the assessment of MR (e.g. via self-report).

Archival RSQ and RS-fMRI data from 88 depressed and 63 never-depressed adults, collected as part of the Canadian Biomarker Integration Network for Depression: Stress and Reward in Anhedonia (CAN-BIND-4: SARA) study, were used to assess DR and network transition rate (TR; a metric of MR), respectively. Multiple linear regression was used to evaluate the RSQ-TR association, controlling for age and sex: Brooding, but not Reflection, was associated with a slower resting TR, independent of depression status. This evidence suggests that individuals who report a greater tendency to brood in response to negative feelings also have a smaller number of discrete thoughts during rest, which may provide some explanation for why brooding thoughts tend to be characterized by repetitive thinking and dwelling.
coauthors: Julie Tseng, Queen's University; Mojdeh Zamayadi, Baycrest Health Sciences Centre; Stefanie Hassel, University of Calgary; Stephen Strother, Baycrest Health Sciences Centre; Glenda MacQueen, University of Calgary; Sidney Kennedy, St. Michael's Hospital; Roumen Milev, Queen's University; Kate Harkness, Queen's University; Jordan Poppenk, Queen's University
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: BrainPrint captures stage-specific lateral shape asymmetry in autoimmune limbic encephalitis
abstract:
Limbic Encephalitis (LE) is an autoimmune disease often associated with temporal lobe epilepsy. It is categorized by serological subgroups, that differ in clinical progress, therapy and prognosis.

Our aim is to develop accurate imaging biomarkers for clinical and scientific implementation.

We investigate lateral shape asymmetry of an ensemble of 10 cortical and subcortical structures, by applying BrainPrint, a surface-based method that uses Eigenvalues of the Laplace-Beltrami operator on triangular (boundary) and tetrahedral (volumetric) meshes as shape descriptors. The intraindividual lateral shape asymmetry of each structure is calculated as the Euclidean distance between the shape descriptors.

We are comparing lateral shape asymmetry of patients with antibodies against the glutamic acid decarboxylase 65 (GAD, n=34), leucine-rich glioma-inactivated protein 1 (LGI1, n=15), contactin-associated protein-like 2 (CASPR2, n=9) to age-matched healthy controls (HC, n=41). We divide the sero-groups by disease stage (time between first LE-associated symptoms and date of MRI) into an early stage (below or equal 24 months) and a chronic stage (above 24 months).

We find significant difference in the amygdala volume between the LGI1 patients of the acute group and the HC. Regarding the shape-asymmetry we find differences for the amygdala (LGI1 early), the hippocampus (CASPR2 early, LGI1 chronic), the caudate nucleus (CASPR2 early), the thalamus (GAD and LGI1 early and chronic) and the striatum (GAD, LGI1, CASPR2 chronic).

Our findings mirror the higher sensitivity of shape information as compared to volumetry. Since we already identified sero-specific features in volume differences in earlier studies, we now expect to refine those findings by adding information about shape. Our aim is to develop a decision tree classifier, so that in future MR-imaging analysis will contribute accurately to diagnosis, prognosis and description of progress of LE.
coauthors: Tobias Bauer, Department of Epileptology, University of Bonn Medical Center, Bonn, Germany;Leon Ernst,Department of Epileptology, University of Bonn Medical Center, Bonn, Germany; Bastian David,Department of Epileptology, University of Bonn Medical Center, Bonn, Germany; Bernd Weber,2Institute of Experimental Epileptology and Cognition Research, University of Bonn Medical Center, Bonn, Germany; Albert J. Becker,3Department of Neuropathology, Section for Translational Epilepsy Research, University of Bonn Medical Center, Bonn, Germany;Christian E. Elger,1Department of Epileptology, University of Bonn Medical Center, Bonn, Germany; Martin Reuter,Martinos Center for Biomedical Imaging, Radiology, MGH / Harvard Medical School, Boston, USA, German Center for Neurodegenerative Diseases (DZNE), Bonn, Germany;  Rainer Surges,Department of Epileptology, University of Bonn Medical Center, Bonn, Germany; Theodor Rüber,Department of Epileptology, University of Bonn Medical Center, Bonn, Germany,Epilepsy Center Frankfurt Rhine-Main, Department of Neurology, Goethe University Frankfurt, Frankfurt am Main, Germany,Center for Personalized Translational Epilepsy Research (CePTER), Goethe-University Frankfurt, Frankfurt am Main, Germany;
theme: Theme A: Development, Neurodegenerative Disorders and Injury

title: The effect of familiar size on size perception.
abstract: When interacting with the world around us, we use retinal size information to judge the distance of objects. It is known that this judgment is influenced by familiar size: a soccer ball looks farther away than a tennis ball if their images are equally large on the retina. On the other hand, when we lift a tennis ball and a soccer ball of the same weight, the soccer ball will not feel heavier, but lighter. So, familiarity has opposite effects on perceptual judgments of distance and weight. The effect of familiar properties on perception can thus be in two directions: assimilation or contrast. We here investigate how familiar size influences judgments about the size of images of objects that are presented on a computer screen. The images were about 5 cm in diameter, presented simultaneously 15 cm apart. Seventy participants had to indicate which of two objects appeared larger on the screen in a 2-alternative forced-choice discrimination task. The objects could be balls (tennis or soccer) or coins (10 eurocent or 2 euro). Participants also compared the images of the balls with a grey disk. The average precision of the size comparison was 3.5%, irrespective of the objects. We found that familiar size did indeed bias size perception: the size of the soccer ball was over-estimated by about 5% (assimilation). This overestimation varied considerably between participants. The bias in the comparison between the two balls was equal to the sum of the biases in the comparisons with the grey disk. The bias for the coins was smaller and in the opposite direction (contrast). We conclude that a depicted object’s familiar size can influence the perceived size of its image, but whether it is assimilation or contrast differs between experiments.
coauthors: Pauline Weijs, Eli Brenner
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: EEG fingerprinting as a mean to bridging together the worlds of fMRI- and EEG-based neurofeedback
abstract:
EEG-based neurofeedback has been used for many years, with waxing and waning enthusiasm, because of the inherent difficulties in identifying its neurobiological underpinnings. Conversely, the field of fMRI-based neurofeedback is still at its infancy, and despite its many methodological issues, the localization power in the brain of fMRI has led to convincing results by targeting specific neuronal regions and networks. However, the economical and logistical constraints of NF interventions using fMRI hinder its widespread application.

A recent approach which attempts to bridge the two worlds of fMRI- and EEG-based neurofeedback is based on the identification of EEG fingerprints of localized brain activity as measured by concurrently acquired fMRI data.  This approach aims at transferring fMRI-based neurofeedback interventions to EEG setups, a strategy with the potential for high impact due to the low cost and portability of the latter, thus facilitating the dissemination of neurofeedback interventions in health and disease. 

Here we present our recent advances on this approach for deriving an accurate EEG fingerprint of the fMRI signal from the facial expression processing network. We show that by exploring EEG features from the non-linear domain convolved with a set of hemodynamic response functions peaking at different latencies, our method substantially improves the approximation accuracy achieved by state-of-the-art solutions. Moreover, we discuss the issue of inter- and intra-subject variability inherent to these two neuroimaging modalities and its implications to the generalization of these approaches.
coauthors: Rodolfo Abreu; Paulo-Carvalho; Miguel Castelo-Branco
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Differential gene expression by RNA-seq during Alzheimer’s disease-like progression in the Drosophila melanogaster model
abstract: Alzheimer's disease (AD) is characterized by progressive, irreversible loss of memory and cognitive function. It is know that its pathogenesis is multifactorial, despite not well elucidated. Drosophila melanogaster is an ideal model organism to dissect molecular pathways, here used to dissect the differential gene expression during AD’s progression due to the amylodoigenic pathway using RNA-seq. A total of 1388 genes were found as differentially expressed both as AD progressed and in control flies. The main pathways related to those genes were evaluated using fly genes and human orthologs, linking genomic and higher order functional information. We identified alterations in pathways related to metabolism, ribosomal pathways, proteasome pathways and immune system. Some of those genes were validated by qPCR and in vivo knockdown. The identification of molecular pathway similarities between the transgenic Alzheimer-like fly model identified in this work and its human orthologs may provides new insights for the use of this fly in screening novel anti-AD drugs.
coauthors: Jéssica Regina da Costa Silva, UFU;  Patrícia Tieme Fujimura, UFU; Letícia Leandro Batista, UFU; Serena Mares Malta, UFU; Romualdo Morandi Filho, UFU; Aline Gomes de Souza, UFU;  Ana Paula Mendes Silva, UFU; Luiza Diniz Ferreira Borges, UFU; Victor Alexandre Félix Bastos, UFU; Jamile Fernanda Silva Cossolin, UFV;  José Eduardo Serrão, UFV; Ana Maria Bonetti, UFU; Luiz Carlos Oliveira Júnior, UFU; Carlos Ueira-Vieira, UFU
theme: Theme A: Development, Neurodegenerative Disorders and Injury

title: Computation-Based Feature Representation of Body Expressions in the Human Brain
abstract:
Research on body category representation, action and emotion has provided evidence that the brain is endowed with social perception skills. Yet, the actual visual processes that drive expression perception are still unknown. We went beyond research on high-level emotion representations to discover which mid-level body features drive automatic emotion perception. 
We computed quantitative body features from angry, happy, fearful and neutral whole-body movements. These features represented kinematic (i.e. velocity, acceleration and vertical movement) and postural (i.e. symmetry, surface, the angles between body segments and limb contraction) aspects of affective body movements. Using representational similarity and multivoxel pattern analysis techniques, we investigated whether the (dis)similarity of body posture and kinematics between different emotional categories could explain neural responses to body expressions in and beyond body-selective regions. 
Our results reveal six major findings. First, computationally defined features are systematically related to distributed brain areas. Second, postural rather than kinematic features reflect the affective category structure of body movements. Limb angles and limb contraction were particularly relevant for distinguishing fear from other body expressions and were represented in several regions including affective, action observation and motor preparation networks. Third, the posterior superior temporal sulcus differentiated fearful from other affective categories using limb contraction rather than kinematics, despite this area being known for its involvement in biological motion processing. Fourth, extrastriate and fusiform body area (EBA and FBA) also showed greater tuning to postural features. Although the pattern of feature representation in these areas was similar, the stimuli representation in EBA was very dissimilar to that of FBA, possibly reflecting their different roles in body processing. Fifth, kinematic and postural feature processing was not segregated into dorsal and ventral streams, with the exception of one feature: velocity. Finally, the brain representation of emotional categories showed a distributed pattern.
coauthors: Marta Poyo Solanas, Maastricht University; Maarten Vaessen, Maastricht University; Beatrice de Gelder, Maastricht University.
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Mechanical modifications to carbon fiber electrodes increase recording yield in brain and enable interfacing with peripheral structures
abstract: Carbon fiber electrodes may enable better long-term brain and nerve interfaces by minimizing the tissue response commonly seen with silicon-based electrodes. Our recent modifications to a carbon fiber electrode surface using a laser or blowtorch has increased the recording yield and adaptability of the arrays in the brain and nerve, respectively. Past carbon fiber electrode arrays in the brain exhibited both high fidelity single unit recordings and a healthy neuronal population immediately adjacent to the recording site. We recently showed that using a 532nm laser instead of traditional microsurgical scissors for the creation of the electrode site increased the recording yield to 84% after 7 days and 71% after 63 days of chronic implant with PEDOT:pTS coating (N=45 fibers) (Welle et al., 2020), compared to a ~30% recording yield for scissor cut fibers. The laser cut electrodes created a consistent, sustainable 257 ± 13.8-µm2 electrode with low 1kHz impedance (19 ± 4kΩ with PEDOT:pTS) and low fiber-to-fiber variability. To enable peripheral nerve interfacing, where the insertion problem is more difficult, we used a 3mm butane flame to create sharpened carbon fiber electrodes that successfully inserted through the epineurium of nerve and dorsal root ganglion without a shuttle. The sharpened carbon fibers were on average 224µm in length with 147µm of exposed carbon and a tip angle of 72 degrees (N=24 fibers). We recorded spontaneous neural activity from rat cervical vagus nerve (Jiman et al., 2020) and feline dorsal root ganglion structures. Discernible single units were detected in physiologically relevant experiments, such as brushing and bladder filling. This work suggests that carbon fiber may be a viable material for higher channel count arrays for the peripheral nervous system.
coauthors: Paras Patel, Department of Biomedical Engineering, University of Michigan; Ahmad Jiman, Department of Biomedical Engineering, University of Michigan; Elizabeth Bottorff, Department of Biomedical Engineering, University of Michigan; Tim Bruns, Department of Biomedical Engineering, University of Michigan; Cynthia Chestek, Department of Biomedical Engineering, University of Michigan, Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science, University of Michigan
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Perinatal vasopressin surge may be neuroprotective with implications for neurodevelopment
abstract: A striking surge in vasopressin (VP) accompanies birth in humans, but the neural underpinnings and function of this surge remain unknown. In the current study, first sought to determine whether there is a similar surge in mice by measuring plasma levels of copeptin (a proxy for VP) following either a vaginal or C-sectioned birth. We found that neonates experience a ≥ 50-fold elevation in peripheral copeptin levels compared to adult mice, and that these levels are significantly higher in mice born vaginally compared to those born by C-section. We also found that VP mRNA expression in the hypothalamus significantly increases during the days prior to birth, and that hypothalamic VP neurons are activated at birth based on cFos labeling. Additionally, we observed significantly decreased plasma osmolality at 1 and 3 hours following a vaginal, but not C-section birth, indicating a transient increase in water retention following a vaginal birth. Importantly, our lab has previously shown that neuronal cell death is significantly decreased at 3 hours following a vaginal, but not C-section birth, in several brain regions. We then established a detailed time course of cell death, showing a significant drop in cell death at 3 hours in the PVN, BNSTl, and LS. To test whether perinatal VP release may be neuroprotective, we performed intracerebroventricular injections of VP in C-sectioned mice 3 hours after birth. We observed a significant reduction in cell death in the PVN and AHA in C-sectioned mice that received VP compared to control. Overall, these data suggest that there is a surge in both central and peripheral VP which may be neuroprotective during early brain development.
coauthors: Yarely C. Hoffiz, Ph.D.; Alexandra Castillo-Ruiz, Ph.D.; Taylor A. Hite; Nancy G. Forger, Ph.D.
theme: Theme A: Development, Neurodegenerative Disorders and Injury

title: Knowledge-centric metacognitive approach for solving tasks
abstract: People exhibit general intelligence behaviors in solving a variety of tasks flexibly by reusing and applying high level knowledge acquired over a period of time. But artificial agents lack generalist behaviors. We argue that general intelligence in artificial agents requires a knowledge-centric meta-cognitive approach. Meta-reasoning about next actions and possible next states is more than resource allocation and memory look-up, it allows people to direct their learning and interactions with world objects in a reusable way. Core to our proposed approach is the ability of finding natural decompositions in environments to understand and exploit structured knowledge representations. Our proposal is based on three main principles for solving complex tasks flexibly - natural decomposition and abstractions, interactions and composition of interactions. World environments are composed of entities and categorized by the types of those entities, in essence, they are knowledge graphs of underlying objects and their relationships. To solve tasks, the meta-cognitive process of the agent formulates a graph traversal path of which entities it needs to interact with locally and then solve tasks by composition of these interactions along the traversal path. Therefore, integrating these principles provides us levers and connect points to induce flexibility into the agents’ behaviors. The proposed meta-cognitive approach captures the essence of generalist behaviors and has promise to act as an enabler for artificial general intelligence with implications across domains.
coauthors: Paul Schrater, schrater@umn.edu, University of Minnesota Twin Cities;
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: A deep learning toolbox for noise-optimized, generalized spike inference from calcium imaging data
abstract: Calcium imaging is a key method to record patterns of neuronal activity across populations of identified neurons, but is only an indirect readout of neuronal spiking activity. Inference of temporal patterns of action potentials (‘spikes’) from calcium signals is challenging and often limited by the scarcity of ground truth data containing simultaneous measurements of action potentials and calcium signals. To overcome this problem, we compiled a large and diverse ground truth database from publicly available and newly performed recordings. This database covers various types of calcium indicators, cell types, and signal-to-noise ratios and comprises a total of >20 hours from 225 neurons. We then developed a novel algorithm for spike inference (CASCADE) that is based on supervised deep networks, takes advantage of the ground truth database, infers absolute spike rates, and outperforms existing model-based algorithms. To optimize performance for unseen imaging data, CASCADE retrains itself by resampling ground truth data to match the respective sampling rate and noise level. As a consequence, no parameters need to be adjusted by the user. To facilitate routine application of CASCADE we developed systematic performance assessments for unseen data, and we designed the algorithm such that . We openly release all resources (via https://github.com/HelmchenLabSoftware/Cascade), and we provide a user-friendly cloud-based implementation. A preprint is already available (https://www.biorxiv.org/content/10.1101/2020.08.31.272450v1), but the talk will also cover aspects of the algorithm that are not described yet.
coauthors: Rupprecht, Peter; Hoffmann, Adrian; Friedrich, Rainer; Helmchen, Fritjof
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Representation of Spatial Frequencies in Neural Populations of Human Temporal Cortex
abstract:
Multiple brain areas in temporal lobe, associated with human vision, represent the visual stimuli and regulate object recognition. Moreover, EEG and fMRI studies suggest that brain visual representation of low versus high spatial frequency is significantly noticeable. Recently, SEEGs (stereo-electro-encephalography electrodes), a technique used for invasive recording of brain activity via three dimensional recordings, have been standing out for its clinical applications in seizure surgeries. The high quality of recoding in SEEGs data gives the opportunity to combine Long Time Monitoring (LTM) with controlled stimulus presentation and investigate the neural representation of objects in human brain. Although, massive body of non-invasive imaging studies have been addressed the neural representation of objects in human brain, the neural representation of spatial filtered objects in human brain using intra-cortical recording is poorly understood.
During LTM, a pharmacologically intractable epileptic patient with implanted SEEGs participated in a face and non-face detection visual task. Electrodes were implanted in the right hippocampus, right and left supplementary motor area, right pre-supplementary motor area, and right anterior cingulate gyrus to evaluate an anatomo-electro-clinical correlate in the generation and propagation of seizures. The stimulus set is comprised of 155 grayscale images including 73 animates (face and non-face) and 82 inanimates at different level of frequencies to probe the selectivity of neural population across the five areas of the brain implanted by electrodes. 
Our results support the existence of distinct neural representation of different spatial frequencies for face and non-face stimuli within temporal lobe of human brain. Furthermore, the interaction of category representation and spatial frequencies suggests a major role of spatial dynamics in face and object processing across ventral visual stream at human brain. 
Our findings provide insight into the fine-grained functional architecture within the human brain pertaining to spatial dynamics in face and object processing.
coauthors: Mohammad Rabiei Ghahfarokhi, School of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Tehran, Tehran, Iran; Niloufar Shahdoust, School of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Tehran, Tehran, Iran; Farideh Shakerian, Department of Brain and Cognitive Sciences, Cell Science Research Center, Royan Institute for Stem Cell Biology and Technology, ACECR, Tehran, Iran, Department of Physiology, Faculty of Medical Sciences, Tarbiat Modares University, Tehran, Iran; Mohammad-Reza A. Dehaqani, School of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Tehran, Tehran, Iran, School of Cognitive Sciences, Institute for Research in Fundamental Sciences, Tehran, Iran
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Prosthetic stimulation in the axis corresponding to support surface perturbation improves postural control in a BVL primate
abstract:
Bilateral vestibular loss (BVL) is a debilitating condition that can cause impairments in posture and balance. Studies in human subjects with profound BVL have proven useful in quantifying the contribution of vestibular sensation to posture. Generally, human studies involve the application of dynamic perturbations to support surface during stance. Analysis of the resultant upper body and head motion has demonstrated a shift from a platform-fixed to a head-fixed pattern of compensation around 0.5 Hz in normal subjects. In contrast, BVL subjects have difficulty with this platform-fixed compensation strategy. 

Notably, vestibular prostheses are an emerging technology that improves outcomes in human BVL patients, however continued work in animal models is essential for understanding the current functional limitations of the technology. Accordingly, here we explored postural responses to platform tilts in a normal monkey vs. monkey with profound BVL. Both animals were trained to maintain a relaxed posture within a behavioral chamber mounted on a 6-dof hexapod motion platform. Dynamic perturbations were applied to animal’s support surface in roll and yaw (0.25-10 Hz, maximum velocity 5 deg/s). The BVL animal received vestibular stimulation with a biomimetic transfer function in either the horizontal or posterior semicircular canal. A wireless IMU was placed on the animal’s head, and center of pressure, and joint positions (DeepLabCut) were recorded. Analysis revealed that postural sway decreased from lower to higher frequencies, similar to the platform-fixed to head-fixed strategy shift observed in humans. Further, the BVL monkey demonstrated a relative increase in sway at lower frequencies, which was mitigated by posterior but not horizontal canal stimulation. These results suggest that profound BVL causes detectible impairments in postural compensation, which is partially corrected by a vestibular prosthesis, particularly at lower frequencies.
coauthors: Kathleen Cullen, Johns Hopkins Medicine
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Analyzing Network Connectivity in Aneurysmal Subarachnoid Hemorrhage with MRI
abstract: Aneurysmal Subarachnoid Hemorrhage (aSAH) is a life-threatening form of stroke wherein an aneurysm ruptures, causing bleeding into the subarachnoid space, and for which prognosis is still difficult to predict. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) can provide rich data on anatomical and physiological processes in the brain. In our project, we aim to compare the structural and functional connectomes of aSAH patients, generated from Diffusion Tensor Imaging (DTI) and functional MRI (fMRI), respectively, with those of healthy controls. We hypothesize that structural and functional connectivity, including networks that are necessary for consciousness and other critical processes of the brain, are altered in patients as compared to controls. Further, we hope to show that our DTI and fMRI data improve prognostication in aSAH.
coauthors: Dr. Sarah Nelson, Johns Hopkins Hospital; Dr. Robert Stevens, Johns Hopkins Hospital
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Language processing across childhood and adolescence: an fNIRS study
abstract: Functional and structural neuroimaging have shown that language networks mature during normal development. However, a detailed timeframe of these developmental changes in language processing is still lacking. Therefore, in typically developing school-aged children we investigated receptive and expressive language processing using functional near-infrared spectroscopy (fNIRS). Specifically, 30 healthy native English speakers (12 children, age range: 6 to 10 years old and 18 adolescents, age range: 11 to 16 years old) were recruited.  Neural activity was measured bilaterally over frontal and temporal areas using fNIRS while participants completed computer-administered language tasks. Adolescents showed increased activity over left temporal regions compared to left frontal regions, independent of task performance, which was not observed in younger children. Overall, these findings suggest that language processing within the left hemisphere continues to develop into adolescence, perhaps reflecting an automation in language skills that is yet to mature in younger children. Further longitudinal studies with larger sample sizes are needed to confirm this conclusion.
coauthors: Papoutselou E. NIHR Nottingham Biomedical Research Centre, Hearing Sciences, Division of Clinical Neuroscience, School of Medicine, University of Nottingham; Wiggins I.M., NIHR Nottingham Biomedical Research Centre, Hearing Sciences, Division of Clinical Neuroscience, School of Medicine, University of Nottingham; Hartley D.E.H., NIHR Nottingham Biomedical Research Centre, Hearing Sciences, Division of Clinical Neuroscience, School of Medicine, University of Nottingham, Nottingham University Hospitals National Health Service Trust.
theme: Theme A: Development, Neurodegenerative Disorders and Injury

title: On volition and consciousness in deliberate and arbitrary decisions
abstract:
The results of the Libet experiment have been interpreted as suggesting that the neural correlates of upcoming actions (and in particular the readiness potential) precede participants’ reported conscious awareness of the onset of their decision to move. Some have taken these results to mean that decisions are typically carried out unconsciously or even that consciousness plays no causal role in the formation of decisions. This, if true, may challenge some basic tenants of the notion that humans have free will and with it some key pillars of human social order—like moral and even criminal responsibility. 

However, these dramatic consequences depend on the neural correlates of upcoming decisions being decodable on the fly—online and in real time. We demonstrate such an ability from intracranial recordings in humans. Further, that interpretation rests on the idea that these early, supposedly pre-conscious neural correlates of action reflect decisions rather than mere stochastic biases. But our reanalysis of single-unit recordings in monkeys challenges that interpretation. Further, the free-will debate centers more on deliberate decisions (e.g., which career path to pursue) than on arbitrary ones (e.g., which hand to raise for no reason or purpose). Deliberate decisions are, speculatively at least, more related to consciousness than arbitrary ones. So, we compared arbitrary and deliberate decisions with nearly identical perceptual inputs and motor outputs, on the same subjects, using a novel donation paradigm. We found the expected readiness potential for arbitrary decisions but not for deliberate ones, challenging the generalizability of the Libet results from arbitrary to deliberate decisions. Our results therefore pave the way for a role for consciousness in decisions, especially those that matter, as the neuroscience of volition moves beyond Libet.
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Decoding stimuli in a Visual Working Memory Task
abstract: Decoding information from fMRI data has been shown to be informative in a range of vision, language and motor tasks. More specifically, differences in neuronal activity in task-related brain areas (e.g. prefrontal cortex) and specific phases of information processing are predictive of correct/incorrect recall in related working memory tasks. Subtraction analyses have demonstrated that activation differs depending on the presented stimuli, suggesting that we can also decode stimulus information from the Blood-Oxygen-Level-Dependent signal. In this study, we analyse the published Human Connectome Project (HCP) dataset, which studies brain connectivity in healthy adults. We focus on the Working Memory N-back task, with the specific contrasts: a high working memory load (“2-back”) versus a low working memory load (“0-back”). The already published results showed robust mixed-effects group-level activation in dorsal frontal-parietal and cingulate areas which are linked with working memory. Here we further extend the existing analysis by using non-linear models trained with parcels from different brain areas collectively to predict the type of stimulus. Furthermore, we investigate the role of certain brain areas in distinguishing stimuli by comparing specific parcels. Our analysis shows a close relationship between participants performances and categories of stimuli explained by response times. Our study also reveals that different types of stimuli have distinct brain signatures and a simple SVM classifier with a non-linear kernel can successfully decode stimuli with high accuracy in both Working Memory tasks. Finally, we train a GLM with samples from different brains areas and report that decoding stimuli success rate varies significantly, suggesting that some brain areas are more crucial in decoding stimuli in a working memory task, i.e. Secondary Visual Cortex, 96%(±0.01). *This study was conducted under the umbrella of NMA Summer School - Summer 2020
coauthors: Nikolaos Chrysanthidis, Department of Computational Science and Technology, Royal Institute of Technology, Stockholm, 10044, Sweden; Hande Tunbak, The Wolfson Institute for Biomedical Research, Rockefeller Building,University Street, University College London, United Kingdom; Keerthi Krishnan, Department of Biochemistry and Cellular and Molecular Biology, University of Tennessee, Knoxville, TN 37996;
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: A Tale of Two Trees: Modeling Apical and Basal Tree Contribution to L2/3 V1 Pyramidal Cell Orientation Selectivity
abstract: Pyramidal neurons, a mainstay of cortical regions, receive a plethora of inputs from various areas onto morphologically distinct apical and basal trees. Both trees differentially contribute to the somatic response, thus defining distinct anatomical and possibly functional sub-units. To assess the latter, we modeled the complex response pattern of the L2/3 V1 pyramidal neuron to spatially tuned synaptic input. Our goal was to elucidate the contribution of each tree to the response pattern of the neuron. Towards this goal, we created a morphologically detailed computational model of a single cell, validated against electrophysiological data. We investigated the role of dendritic integration at the basal and apical trees, and its contribution in shaping cell responses. Results indicate that somatic action potentials are generated only when input coincides bilaterally, as unilateral stimuli are generally unable to evoke spiking activity at the soma. In addition, given equal synaptic drive, the responses of the neuron appear to be initiated by the apical tree, as its dendritic spiking activity temporally precedes somatic activity. Finally, basal tree activity, in the form of either depolarization or dendritic spiking, is essential for producing somatic activity, despite the fact that most somatic spikes are apically-driven. This model provides evidence for synergistic computations taking place in the basal and apical trees of the neuron, and emphasizes the role of predictive and attentional feedback input.
coauthors: Konstantinos-Evangelos Petousakis, IMBB, FORTH and Department of Biology, University of Crete; Jiyoung Park, Department of Neuroscience, Baylor College of Medicine; Athanasia Papoutsi, IMBB, FORTH; Stelios Smirnakis, Department of Neuroscience, Baylor College of Medicine and Department of Neurology, Brigham and Women’s H. and JP VA H., Harvard Medical School; Panayiota Poirazi, IMBB, FORTH
institution: Foundation for Research and Technology Hellas (grid.4834.b)
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: A multi-modal fitting procedure to construct biophysically detailed multicompartment neuronal models
abstract:
In computational neuroscience, multicompartment models are among the biophysically most realistic representations of single neurons. 
Constructing such models usually involves the use of the patch-clamp technique to record somatic voltage signals under different experimental conditions. The experimental data are then used to fit the many parameters of the model. While patching of the soma is the gold-standard approach to build multicompartment models, several studies have also evidenced a richness of dynamics in dendritic and axonal sections. Recording from the soma alone makes it hard to observe and correctly parameterize the activity of non-somatic compartments. 
 
In order to provide a richer set of data as input to multicompartment models, we investigate here the combination of somatic patch-clamp recordings with recordings of high-density microelectrode arrays (HD-MEAs). HD-MEAs enable to observe extracellular potentials and neural activity at subcellular resolution. We hypothesize that HD-MEAs may provide a valid alternative to conducting multiple simultaneous patch recordings.
 
To test this hypothesis, we built ground-truth samples from an available L5b cell model (Hay 2011), which was developed with multiple patch recordings (one somatic patch and two patches on the apical dendrites), and which is capable of reproducing properties of active dendrites. To do so, we extended the BluePyOpt software to use LFPy to simulate intra- and extracellular signals. We extracted features from both, simulated somatic voltage traces and extracellular action potentials. The extracted features were used to find an optimal set of parameters using a genetic algorithm approach.
 
In this in-silico study, we show that using a combination of patch-clamp and extracellular features allows for finding a much better fit of the dendritic parameters than the use of somatic features alone. This multimodal fitting strategy potentially yields a set of better constrained and more accurate multicompartment models.
coauthors: Alessio Paolo Buccino, ETH Zurich; Tanguy Damart, Blue Brain Project, EPFL; Darshan Mandge, Blue Brain Project, EPFL;  Werner Van Geit, Blue Brain Project, EPFL; Henry Markram, Blue Brain Project, EPFL; Andreas Hierlemann, ETH Zurich;
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Age-related differences in brain regions linked to visuo-spatial processing during landmark-based navigation
abstract: Healthy older adults are impaired in their capacity to navigate efficiently which significantly reduces their autonomy and mobility. Behavioral studies have revealed age-related changes in multiple visuospatial abilities including the capacity to perceive and integrate visual landmarks for spatial navigation (e.g., a lamppost). However, the functional and neurobiological factors underlying the decline of landmark processing in healthy ageing remain insufficiently characterized. To address this caveat, we used functional magnetic resonance imaging to investigate the brain activity associated with landmark-based navigation in young and older participants. 25 young and 17 older adults took part in an active virtual navigation task in which they had to orient in a simple maze using landmarks. Whole-brain as well as region-of-interest (ROI) analyses were conducted with a focus on high-level visual regions linked to navigational functions: the parahippocampal place area (PPA), the occipital place area (OPA) and the retrosplenial cortex (RSC). Results showed that older adults made more errors and that they relied on different navigational strategies to solve the task. Direct comparisons between groups revealed greater anterior temporal activity in young participants. In addition, only young adults showed activity in occipital areas dedicated to processing information from the central visual field. ROI analyses unveiled age-related differences exclusively in the OPA, with significantly higher OPA activity in older subjects. Overall, our results suggest that brain regions involved in the representation of fine-grained visual information may be disrupted in ageing which could in turn diminish the ability to use landmarks for navigation. This work helps towards a better comprehension of the neural dynamics subtending landmark-based navigation and it provides new insights on the impact of age-related visuospatial processing differences on navigation capabilities.
coauthors: Marion Durteste, Sorbonne Universités, INSERM, CNRS, Institut de la Vision, 17 rue Moreau, F-75012 Paris, France; Stephen Ramanoël, Sorbonne Universités, INSERM, CNRS, Institut de la Vision, 17 rue Moreau, F-75012 Paris, France/University of Côte d'Azur, LAMHESS, Nice, France; Marcia Bécu, Sorbonne Universités, INSERM, CNRS, Institut de la Vision, 17 rue Moreau, F-75012 Paris, France; Christophe Habas, CHNO des Quinze-Vingts, DHU Sight Restore, INSERM-DHOS CIC, 28 rue de Charenton, 75012 Paris, France; Angelo Arleo, Sorbonne Universités, INSERM, CNRS, Institut de la Vision, 17 rue Moreau, F-75012 Paris, France
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Do population differences in the human gut microbiome predict the prevalence of Alzheimer’s disease?
abstract:
The human microbiome is a complex and dynamic community of microbes, thought to have symbiotic benefit to its host. Given the scale and complexity of the microbiome, it is not surprising that the current literature increasingly suggests a substantial contribution to disease.

Previous studies have identified influences of the microbiome on brain microglia as a mechanism contributing to neurodegeneration in conditions such as motor neurone disease and Parkinson’s disease. However, Alzheimer’s disease (AD), regarded as the most prevalent neurodegenerative disease, remains a condition to be further investigated from the microbiome perspective. We further investigate this link by proposing correlations between population level differences in the gut microbiome and the prevalence of AD and other dementias within these regions.

Analyses were performed in R using microbiome and SIAMCAT packages using two large, open-access microbiome data sets (n=1006 & n >2000) (Lahti et al., 2014; Pasolli et al., 2017). Countries in these datasets were grouped based on AD prevalence and the microbiome profiles compared.

In regions and countries with a high prevalence of AD, there is a significantly lower diversity of the gut microbiome (p<0.0001). A PERMANOVA (p<0.05) revealed significant differences between several taxa in countries with high vs low prevalence of AD. Additionally, using machine learning, we were able to predict the prevalence of AD within a region or country based on the microbiome profile (Mean AUC 0.935 & 0.828). 
 
We conclude that differences in the microbiome between countries predict the varying prevalence of Alzheimer’s disease and other dementias in these countries. Our results support a key role of the microbiome in neurodegeneration, potentially via its effects on microglia.We propose further steps to include experimental models to directly investigate causation between the taxa identified and the risk of developing dementia such as Alzheimer’s disease.
coauthors: Amedra Basgaran, University College London; Eva Lymberopoulos, University College London; Maryam Reis-Dehabadi, University College London; Nikhil Sharma, University College London
institution: Institute of Neurology, University College London
theme: Theme A: Development, Neurodegenerative Disorders and Injury

title: Hypothalamic Oxytocin Neurons Respond to Infant Vocalizations via Noncanonical Auditory Pathway
abstract:
Mammalian babies are “sensory traps” for parents. Various sensory cues from the newborn are tremendously efficient in triggering parental responses in caregivers. We recently showed that core aspects of maternal behavior such as pup retrieval in response to infant vocalizations rely on active learning of auditory cues from pups facilitated by the neurohormone oxytocin (OT). Release of OT from the hypothalamus might thus help induce recognition of different infant cues but it is unknown what sensory stimuli can activate OT neurons.
I performed in vivo whole-cell and cell-attached recordings from optically-identified OT neurons in awake dams. I found that OT neurons, but not other hypothalamic cells, increased their firing rate after playback of pup distress vocalizations. Using anatomical tracing approaches and channelrhodopsin-assisted circuit mapping, I identified the projections and brain areas (including inferior colliculus, auditory cortex, and posterior intralaminar thalamus) relaying auditory information about social sounds to OT neurons. In hypothalamic brain slices, when optogenetically stimulating thalamic afferences to mimic high-frequency thalamic discharge, observed in vivo during pup calls playback, I found that thalamic activity led to long-term depression of synaptic inhibition in OT neurons. This was mediated by postsynaptic NMDARs-induced internalization of GABAARs. Therefore, persistent activation of OT neurons following pup calls in vivo is likely mediated by disinhibition. This gain modulation of OT neurons by infant cries, may be important for sustaining motivation. Using a genetically-encoded OT sensor, I demonstrated that pup calls were efficient in triggering OT release in downstream motivational areas. When thalamus projections to hypothalamus were inhibited with chemogenetics, dams exhibited longer latencies to retrieve crying pups, suggesting that the thalamus-hypothalamus noncanonical auditory pathway may be a specific circuit for the detection of social sounds, important for disinhibiting OT neurons, gating OT release in downstream brain areas, and speeding up maternal behavior.
coauthors: Silvana Valtcheva, Habon A. Issa, Robert C. Froemke
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Saccade-related potentials during task-related refixation behaviour
abstract: When a saccade is planned, attention shifts to the subsequent fixation location before the saccade is executed. In a free viewing task, this attention shift is biased by higher-order processes related to the task. We used EEG to study the dependence of pre-saccadic attention shifts on task-related processes. The EEG activity in the interval preceding a saccade is known as the saccade-related potential (SRP). We studied SRPs in a visual search task requiring memorization of multiple targets for subsequent change detection. Such a complex task naturally leads to refixations, i.e. the eyes returning to previously visited locations, depending on the task-relevance of the fixated item. We compared SRPs between first fixations and refixations for task-relevant (target) and task-irrelevant (distractor) items. Both task-relevance and type of fixation (first fixation vs refixation) affect working memory load, which biases pre-saccadic attention. Fixations on targets load working memory with both identity and location information, whereas fixations on distractors load working memory only with identity information. Higher working memory load is also observed in our task during first fixations, which are made for memorization of a new target in comparison to refixations, which are made for rehearsal of previously fixated items. First fixations had longer durations than refixations indicating a difference in pre-saccadic attention. Consistent with this finding, we observed an effect of both task-relevance and fixation type on the SRP in the interval preceding the saccade away from a target but we found no such effect for distractors. Higher SRP amplitudes were seen in the occipital region for first fixations than refixations with the opposite effect in the frontal region. Our results provide neurophysiological evidence for the effect of task-relevance and working memory load refixation on saccade planning.
coauthors: Cees van Leeuwen, Laboratory for Perceptual Dynamics, Brain & Cognition Research Unit, University of Leuven, Leuven, Belgium & Center for Cognitive Science, University of Kaiserslautern, Kaiserslautern, Germany; Marcello Giannini, Laboratory for Perceptual Dynamics, Brain & Cognition Research Unit, University of Leuven, Leuven, Belgium; Andrey R. Nikolaev, Department of Psychology, Lund University, Lund, Sweden & Laboratory for Perceptual Dynamics, Brain & Cognition Research Unit, University of Leuven, Leuven, Belgium
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Microglia modulate stable wakefulness via thalamic reticular nucleus
abstract: Microglia are involved with brain homeostasis and immunity, but their role in regulating vigilance remains unclear. We employed genetic, physiological, and metabolomic methods to examine microglial involvement in the regulation of wakefulness and sleep. Microglial depletion decreased stable nighttime wakefulness in mice by increasing transitions between wakefulness and non-rapid eye movement (NREM) sleep. Metabolomic analysis revealed that the diurnal variation of the brain ceramide disappeared in microglia-depleted mice. Ceramide preferentially influenced microglia in the thalamic reticular nucleus (TRN), and local depletion of TRN microglia produced similar impaired wakefulness. Chemogenetic manipulations of anterior TRN neurons showed that they regulated transitions between wakefulness and NREM sleep. Their firing capacity was suppressed by both microglial depletion and added ceramide. In microglia-depleted mice, activating anterior TRN neurons or inhibiting ceramide production both restored stable wakefulness. These findings demonstrate that microglia can modulate stable wakefulness through anterior TRN neurons via ceramide signaling
theme: Theme B: Neural Excitability, Synapses, and Glia

title: Development of Interactive Visualizations for Neuroscience Education
abstract:
We present preliminary development of interactive visualization games for education, focusing on mathematical concepts in neuroscience. 
        In teaching neuroscience, some beginning students have difficulties in understanding some mathematical objects, such as multivariate Gaussians, where interactive visualizations could empower them with the intuition to overcome the learning obstacle in a simplified way. Such demonstrations might also help communication of neuroscience ideas to the public. 
        For maximal flexibility and to facilitate future open source development work, we would like to mix different frameworks, ranging from embedded GIFs to Python widgets to 3D Unity games. Thus we propose to present visualizations as webpages with components hosted by game servers. So far we have provided interactive visualizations in Godot 2D & 3D engine that uses a python-alike programming language, as well as the Unity3D engine in C#. Then, for further context, we link the interactive visualization games’ web window into Jupyter notebooks, and add video and/or scientific Markdown for explanations of the content. Consequently, people can choose and embed specific visualizations into their Jupyter notebooks and PowerPoint slides.
	We have developed the prototype versions of two Gaussian widgets (2D and 3D), a head-orientation activity altering neuron visualization, and a linear dynamics state evolution visualization. We also developed intuitive on-screen gestures to interact with the mathematical content, which could be used on multi-touch devices including laptops, tablets, and mobile screens.
        In conclusion, we develop neuroscience interactive visualization games to help students turn abstract mathematical concepts into pictures, connect them to model parameters and the outputs of dynamic interactive models, and help them build intuition and understanding.
coauthors: Xaq Pitkow
theme: Theme F: History, Education and Society

title: Classification of Successful Sensorimotor Adaptation in Locomotion
abstract:
Introduction: Split-belt walking could serve as an intervention to correct hemiparetic gait due to brain lesions, such as stroke. However, not all participants respond similarly to the same split-belt protocol and it is unclear how to tailor the split-belt training for a given individual. Thus, there is a basic science and clinical interest to predict if a given protocol will be successful for a specific subject. 

Methods: We applied classification algorithms on an assembled large dataset (N=690 samples) of split-belt experiments to identify subject demographics (e.g., age, BMI, etc.) and protocol details (e.g., length of training, walking speed, etc.) strongly influencing whether a specific protocol would result in “good” or “poor” sensorimotor adaptation for a given individual.  A numerical approach was taken where many classifiers were trained and tested (e.g., logistic regression, random forest, etc.) on different subsets of the database with different model parameters. Performance metrics were computed (e.g., precision, recall, etc.) for each classifier type, subset of the data, and parameters for the classifier. For the performance metrics mentioned, a value closer to one indicates better classification performance than a value closer to zero.
