A focus on the integrated nature of cortical plasticity, which is the outcome of the emergent interactions between deprived and non-deprived areas in both hemispheres may have important implications for learning and rehabilitation.
coauthors: Jan A. Jablonka, Robert Bińkowski,  Elżbieta Fuszara, Maria Sadowska, Władek Sredniawa, Aleksandra Szlachcic, Paulina Urban, Ewa Kublik
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: New ways to analyze and visualize large-scale network activity in sea slugs with single-neuron, single-spike resolution
abstract: Despite an ever-growing body of research elucidating how neural networks produce behavior, the contributions of specific neurons within those networks are often poorly understood. In particular, achieving both the temporal and spatial resolution in activity recordings of neuronal populations required to develop detailed bottom-up insights about how behavior is generated has proven to be a challenge for network neuroscience. Simple nervous systems, like those of gastropod mollusks, comprise relatively few, large, mostly superficial and individually identifiable neurons. This enables both electrophysiological and optical recordings with single-neuron, single-spike specificity over significant portions of those nervous systems, allowing for more thorough neuroethological investigation. Here, we discuss several computational tools we have recently developed to visualize and animate optical data collected in the brains of gastropod mollusks as a part of a BRAIN Initiative project taking a multi-dimensional approach to understanding how networks produce behavior. Large-scale optical recordings are obtained of motor programs of interest, using a photodiode array imaging at 1,600 samples/s and a fast-absorbance voltage-sensitive dye. These signals are then blind source separated into individual neuronal activity traces using independent component analysis. A custom algorithm maps the individual neuronal signals onto their source neurons in the recorded brain region, and then animates these maps to generate audiovisual “playbacks” of network activity with high spatiotemporal resolution. Through the use of a previously developed unsupervised community detection algorithm, we can also derive the functional neuronal ensembles operating during behavioral programs. Together, these tools constitute an ultra-fast workflow that provides same-day insights about both single-cell activity and network organization in recorded brain regions. This approach is well-suited to exploring network function in little studied, nontransgenic species, such as we are currently doing with the nudibranch Berghia stephanieae.
coauthors: Jeffrey Brown, RFUMS; Evan Hill, RFUMS; William Frost, RFUMS
institution: Rosalind Franklin University of Medicine and Science (grid.262641.5)
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Exploring the Role of the Endoplasmic Reticulum in Regulating Activity-Driven Intracellular Calcium Signaling in Drosophila Elementary Motion Detection
abstract: Intracellular Ca2+ regulates several processes, including synaptic plasticity and neurotransmission. The endoplasmic reticulum (ER) is a major neuronal Ca2+ reservoir. Although much is known about the molecular mechanisms underlying ER Ca2+ uptake and release, it is unclear how these dynamics contribute to neuronal activity in vivo. In this work, we investigated the role of the ER in intracellular Ca2+ signaling in Drosophila local motion detection. Cell-types within this circuit exhibit cytosolic Ca2+ response kinetics spanning various timescales. This cell-type-specific temporal filtering is critical for motion detection, but the cellular mechanisms underlying temporal filtering are unknown. Since ER Ca2+ handling can regulate cytosolic Ca2+, we hypothesized that the ER tunes cell-type-specific temporal filtering properties in motion detection. To test this, we measured stimulus-evoked ER and cytosolic Ca2+ signals in neurons in flies using two-photon microscopy. We found, first, that visual stimuli drive different ER Ca2+ signals depending on the cell-type and compartment. For example, within Mi1 neurons, dendrites exhibit slow, sustained (~1s) ER Ca2+ release, and axon terminals exhibit rapid, sustained (~100ms-1s) Ca2+ uptake. Thus, the ER acts as a Ca2+ source or sink during activation over different timescales. Second, we found that RNAi knockdown of ER Ca2+ efflux channel inositol trisphosphate receptor (IP3R) perturbs ER and cytosolic Ca2+ signaling. IP3R knockdown reduces ER Ca2+ uptake in Mi1 axons and Ca2+ release in dendrites, suggesting that homeostatic mechanisms reduce Ca2+ uptake when Ca2+ release is impaired. Finally, we found that reduced ER Ca2+ uptake in Mi1 axon terminals after IP3R knockdown is associated with more sustained cytosolic Ca2+ responses to visual stimuli, suggesting that ER Ca2+ handling regulates temporal filtering properties underlying motion detection. Altogether, we propose that the ER plays a critical role in regulating activity-driven intracellular Ca2+ signals in neurons in vivo, thereby tuning single-cell processing and circuit function.
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Investigation of postsubicular head direction cells in the TgF344-AD rat model of Alzheimer’s disease
abstract: Spatial navigation and memory are impaired in early stages of Alzheimer's disease (AD) and are prominent behavioral markers of preclinical AD. The TgF344-AD rat model of AD exhibits similar behavioral and pathological features to humans and thus serves as an excellent model to investigate mechanisms underlying spatial impairment in AD. Previously, we found that 10-month-old TgF344-AD rats make progressively less spatially precise movements during a reference memory variant of the Morris water maze. TgF344-AD rats also exhibit progressive pathology in cortical areas involved in the coding of head direction. Thus, this study sought to characterize head direction (HD) cells in the postsubiculum, a prominent HD cell loci, in 15 - 19 month female TgF344-AD rats and aged matched F344 controls. Rats performed a pellet chasing task within a cylinder fitted with a white cue card during recordings. In some sessions, the cue card was rotated to assess landmark control. HD cells from TgF344-AD rats exhibited increased peak firing rates, but maintained directional firing characteristics similar to that of controls. Additionally, responses to the cue card rotation were similar to that of controls, but with greater variability. These results will be discussed in relation to the hypothesis that head direction cell dysfunction contributes to spatial impairment in Alzheimer’s disease.
coauthors: Laura E. Berkowitz, University of New Mexico; Ryan H. Harvey, University of New Mexico; Maria Gabaldon-Parish, University of New Mexico; Victoria J. Roy, University of New Mexico; and Benjamin J. Clark, University of New Mexico;
theme: Theme A: Development, Neurodegenerative Disorders and Injury

title: Eye movements in the formally blind
abstract: Sensitive periods have previously been identified for several human visual system functions. Yet, it is unknown to what degree the development of visually guided oculomotor control depends on early visual experience—for example, whether and to what degree humans whose sight was restored after a transient period of congenital visual deprivation are able to conduct visually guided eye movements. In the present study, we developed new calibration and analysis techniques for eye tracking data contaminated with pervasive nystagmus, which is typical for this population. We investigated visually guided eye movements in sight recovery individuals with long periods of visual pattern deprivation (3–36 years) following birth due to congenital, dense, total, bilateral cataracts. As controls we assessed (1) individuals with nystagmus due to causes other than cataracts, (2) individuals with developmental cataracts after cataract removal, and (3) individuals with normal vision. Congenital cataract reversal individuals were able to perform visually guided gaze shifts, even when their blindness had lasted for decades. The typical extensive nystagmus of this group distorted eye movement trajectories, but measures of latency and accuracy were as expected from their prevailing nystagmus—that is, not worse than in the nystagmus control group. To the best of our knowledge, the present quantitative study is the first to investigate the characteristics of oculomotor control in congenital cataract reversal individuals, and it indicates a remarkable effectiveness of visually guided eye movements despite long-lasting periods of visual deprivation.
coauthors: José Pablo Ossandón; Idris Shareef; Stefan Van der Stigchel; Ramesh Kekunnaya; Brigitte Röder
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Lateralized Short-Term and Long-Term Plasticity of Somatostatin-Positive Interneurons in Female Mouse Auditory Cortex
abstract:
There are multiple forms of synaptic plasticity, and distinct inputs onto the same postsynaptic neuron can have qualitatively different learning rules (Maheux et al. 2015). There is growing evidence that cortical inhibitory synapses are highly plastic, including differences in cell-type-specific GABAergic inputs onto layer 2/3 pyramidal neurons (Chiu et al. Neuron 2018). In the auditory cortex, we have found that an unusual left-lateralized form of short-term inhibitory depression might help enable longer-term changes to both excitation and inhibition for enhanced responses to pup calls in maternal mice (Marlin et al. Nature 2015, Schiavo et al. Nature 2020). 

Here we examined short-term and spike-timing-dependent plasticity (STDP) of different inhibitory inputs onto layer 2/3 pyramidal neurons of adult mouse auditory cortex in slices. STDP is a method for inducing input-specific and long-term modifications of synaptic strength, where short-term plasticity reflects the dynamic synaptic strength based on recent history. These mechanisms might underlie the synchronization of stimulus-evoked inhibitory input during development (Dorrn et al. Nature 2010, Field et al. Neuron 2020) and after conditioning or maternal experience. 
	
We utilized isolated expression of channelrhodopsin-2 in various GABAergic interneurons to selectively activate these inputs. Somatostatin interneurons are distinct physiologically, expressing STDP (169% potentiated current, n = 11, p < 0.05) as compared to PV, VIP and Layer-1 interneurons. Somatostatin also demonstrate differential depression to repetitive stimulation (df = 3, F = 3.26, p < 0.05), depending on hemisphere, as compared to PV. Our data suggest somatostatin interneurons are critical for laterality in the auditory cortex.
coauthors: Robert C. Froemke, NYU
theme: Theme B: Neural Excitability, Synapses, and Glia

title: Symposium on Cellular and molecular mechanisms of memory allocation and storage
abstract:
Yingxi Lin - neural ensembles of memory allocation

Steve Ramirez - Memory Cells and their manipulation 

David Glanzman - cellular mechanisms - does LTP have a role

Todd Sacktor - molecular mechanism of memory storage
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Whole-brain imaging of Danionella Translucida with oblique plane microscopy
abstract:
Because the fish Danionella translucida remains small and transparent even in adulthood, it is potentially possible to optically interrogate neuronal networks at single-cell resolution across an entire adult brain. However a suitable microscopy technique, which has a field of view encompassing the whole brain and permits to record at least at the speed on the order of the decay time of Calcium indicators, is lacking.
Here we present a novel microscope, which fulfils these criteria. By introducing a new solution for the central re-imaging geometry of oblique plane microscopy we extend the family of these microscopy techniques to larger field of views. We are therefore able to record from a volume of 2600 µm x 1000 µm x 850 µm at 1Hz, while maintaining an optical resolution below the size of a single cell. We use this technique to persistently record neural activity of a neural population distributed throughout the whole brain of Danionella translucida.
coauthors: Maximilian Hoffmann, Einstein Center for Neurosciences, NeuroCure Cluster of Excellence, Charité Universitätsmedizin, Berlin, Germany ; Jörg Heninnger,Einstein Center for Neurosciences, NeuroCure Cluster of Excellence, Charité Universitätsmedizin, Berlin, Germany; Benjamin Judkewitz,Einstein Center for Neurosciences, NeuroCure Cluster of Excellence, Charité Universitätsmedizin, Berlin, Germany;
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Experience replay supports non-local learning
abstract: To make effective decisions we need to consider the relationship between actions and outcomes. However, there are often substantial gaps between them in both space and time. The biological mechanism capable of spanning those gaps remains unknown. One promising, albeit hypothetical, mechanism involves neural replay of non-local experience. Using a novel task, that segregates direct from indirect learning, combined with magnetoencephalography (MEG), we probed the role of neural replay in non-local learning in humans. Following reward receipt, we found significant backward replay of non-local experience, with a 160 msec state-to-state time lag, and this replay facilitated learning of action values. This backward replay, combined with behavioural evidence of non-local learning, was more pronounced in experiences that were of greater benefit for future behavior, as predicted by theories of prioritization. These findings establish rationally targeted non-local replay as a neural mechanism for solving complex credit assignment problems during learning.
coauthors: Marcelo Matter, Princeton University; Tim Behrens, University of Oxford; Nathaniel Daw, Princeton University; Ray Dolan, University College London
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Exact neural mass model for synaptic-based working memory
abstract:
A synaptic theory of Working Memory (WM) has been developed in the last decade to overcome
several drawbacks related to the persistent spiking paradigm. Memory items are maintained in
the synaptic facilitation and refreshed thanks to Population Bursts (PBs) promoted by synaptic
depression. We have developed a neural mass model based on a recent study on the macroscopic
description of spiking neuronal networks and a well established model for plastic synapses. It is
capable of reproducing exactly the dynamics of heterogeneous spiking neural networks with short-
term synaptic plasticity. This neural mass model gives access not only to the population firing rate,
but also to the mean membrane potential. The latter is correlated to the Local Field Potentials
and to electroencephalographic signals, usually measured during WM tasks to characterize the brain
dynamics. The model is able to mimic several operations required by WM : memory loading, memory
maintenance, competition of memory items and multi-item memory juggling. Memory access and
loading is associated to self-sustained oscillations in the β-γ band and to transient evoked responses
in the δ band, analogous to what is observed in the prefrontal cortex of monkeys during object
recognition tasks. More items can be stored in the WM by considering neural architectures composed
by multiple excitatory populations and a common inhibitory pool. The items can be loaded and
maintained at the same time: they are represented as trains of PBs with the same period, but
delivered at evenly shifted phases. A memory competition is observable already by loading only two
items. Depending on the stimulation features we can observe three different outcomes: maintenance
of the first or second loaded item or their juggling in the memory. As reported in many experiments,
the γ-band power increases with the number of loaded items. The power in the α-β instead shows
a non monotonic behaviour. Finally, we report an expression for the maximal capacity adapted to
the present model and architecture.
coauthors: Halgurd Taher,  Inria Sophia Antipolis Méditerranée Research Centre; Alessandro Torcini, Laboratoire de Physique Théorique et Modélisation, Université de Cergy-Pontoise; Simona Olmi, Inria Sophia Antipolis Méditerranée Research Centre
institution: Research Centre Inria Sophia Antipolis - Méditerranée (grid.457356.6)
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Animal-to-Animal Variability in Hippocampal Remapping
abstract:
Hippocampal place cells form a unique map for each environment, a phenomenon known as hippocampal remapping.  What qualifies as a sufficiently different environment to give rise to a new hippocampal map is unclear, and different studies provide superficially conflicting results.  In particular, many experiments have observed unexplained variability in remapping behavior between different animals.
Recent work has organized disparate phenomena associated with remapping by framing the context identification problem that the hippocampus is ostensibly solving as a hidden state inference problem. Lack of access to objective hidden state labels lead to an inherent ambiguity in identifying which experiences deserve unique maps.  Animal variability can potentially be a result of different animals having characteristically different parameter settings in resolving this ambiguity.
We reanalyze a published data set collected from rats foraging in 11 different rooms, including a variety of types of repetitions of those rooms.  We find that variability between these animals in remapping behavior is highly structured: different animals have characteristically different remapping behaviors across different types of repetitions of these rooms.  For example, remapping between repetitions of an environment when the animal is not removed from a room correlate with remapping between repetitions of an environment much later in the day.  We also find heterogeneity in remapping behavior across the place cell population within an animal. Overall, we find evidence that different animals have consistently different remapping responses to the same experiences, emphasizing the subjective nature of hippocampal remapping.
coauthors: Parsa Nilchian, Florida International University and MIT Summer Research Program; Samuel Gershman, Department of Psychology and Center for Brain Science -- Harvard University; Matthew Wilson, Picower Institute and Department of Brain and Cognitive Sciences -- Massachusetts Institute of Technology; Honi Sanders, Center for Brains Minds and Machines and Department of Brain and Cognitive Sciences-- Massachusetts Institute of Technology
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Disruption of neonatal Purkinje cell function underlies injury-related learning deficits
abstract: It is hypothesized that perinatal cerebellar injury leads to long-term functional deficits due to circuit dysmaturation. Using a novel integration of GCaMP6f fiber photometry with automated measurement of cerebellar behavior using the ErasmusLadder, we causally link cerebellar injury to altered Purkinje cell responses during maladaptive behavior. Inhibition of Purkinje cells is sufficient to phenocopy the effects of perinatal cerebellar injury. Our results uncover a direct link between perinatal cerebellar injury and activity-dependent maturation of cerebellar cortex.
coauthors: Aaron Sathyanesan, Children's National Research Institute, Washington DC; Panagiotis Kratimenos, Children's National Research Institute, Washington DC; Vittorio Gallo, Children's National Research Institute, Washington DC
theme: Theme A: Development, Neurodegenerative Disorders and Injury

title: Task classification from pre-stimulus functional connectivity on EEG-data
abstract: Execution of cognitive tasks is associated with a task-specific pattern of the brain functional connectivity. However, much less attention is been drawn to pre-stimulus preparatory processes. Previously, the brain preparation topology was shown on fMRI-data, we aimed to replicate this result and distinguish pre-stimulus reconfiguration of brain functional network on EEG-data. During EEG recording 76 participants were asked to identify the correctness of stimuli, belonging to one of three types: sentence in the native language, algebraic equations and simple addition. 2 seconds before each stimulus, the cue was shown. Functional connectivity in this interval was estimated in sensor space via the imaginary part of coherency and graph was constructed from the 25% of strongest connections. Multiclass sparse logistic regression was used as the classifier on 5 global (median path length, assortativity degree, average clustering coefficient, global and local efficiency) and 5 local measures (degree, rich-club coefficient, clustering coefficient, betweenness centrality k-core index) and with Leave-one-out as the train-test split. We were not able to correctly classified pre-stimulus functional connectivity with accuracy ranging from 31% to 38% for the different frequency bands. This result might reflect several drawbacks in our analysis. First, the topological resolution of 64-channel EEG might be inadequate for the extraction of differences between stimuli. Second, issues with the graph construction, poor choice of synchronization measure or threshold of the strongest connections. Third, target differences could hide in the temporal dynamics of network reconfiguration, which is completely obscured by averaging across the whole pre-stimulus time window. We also want to point out that similar classification applied to participants shows accuracy from 61% to 90%, thus emphasizing the importance of individual differences in functional connectivity studies.
coauthors: Timofey Adamovich, Psychological Institute of Russian Academy of Education; Ilia Zaharov, Psychological Institute of Russian Academy of Education; Anna Tabueva, Psychological Institute of Russian Academy of Education
institution: Psychological Institute of Russian Academy of Education
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Universal guide for skull extraction and design of custom-fitted implants for continuous and discontinuous skulls
abstract:
Intracranial neurophysiological recordings require chronic implants to provide access to the brain through the cranium. Such implants are mounted to the skull and commonly build from hard, durable materials. Especially in larger animals, which participate in experiments over extended periods of time, implants should match the skull curvature to promote osseointegration and avoid tissue and bacterial ingress over time. 

Proposed CAD methods for designing implants to date have focused on naïve animals with continuous and even skull surfaces and calculate Boolean differences between implant and skull surface to fit the implant to the skull curvature. However, custom-fitting by calculating the difference fails if a discontinuous skull surface needs to be matched. Also, the difference method does not allow designs which require constant material thickness along the curvature after fitting.

We present a universal guide for custom-fitted design of skull implants and production. Its major advancement is its suitability to unusual skull conditions, such as discontinuities or irregularities on the skull surface. It furthermore provides a description of virtual implant bending to match the skull curvature while maintaining implant thickness, e.g. for using fixed screw lengths. The guide makes use of only a few software tools and the final virtual product can be manufactured using CNC milling or 3D printing. 
We demonstrate the process for a wide spectrum of scenarios ranging from complex-shaped single-pieced implants to detailed multi-component implant systems– built on even or discontinuous skull and report the experience over several years in four rhesus monkeys.
A detailed description of this process suitable for non-expert users will be available on GitHub including step-by-step video instructions.
coauthors: Naubahar Agha; Attila Trunk; Michael Berger; Alexander Gail
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Efficient coding of numbers explains decision bias and noise
abstract:
Multi-attribute decisions require the encoding of several pieces of information, followed by their aggregation. A simple example is averaging. When asked to compare averages of numbers, human subjects have been reported to differentially weight different numbers, even though these should be equally relevant to a correct decision. This selective weighting has been interpreted as resulting from a biased encoding of the numbers, that optimally compensates for the presence of internal noise arising later in the decision process (Spitzer et al., 2017). A natural alternative assumption is that numbers are encoded with noise, then optimally decoded from the noisy representations. Under the hypothesis of efficient coding, the degree of encoding noise should vary in an optimal way across the stimulus space, and should depend on the statistics of the numbers.
We investigate these predictions through a task in which subjects are asked to compare the averages of two series of numbers, each sampled from the same prior distribution, whose shape we manipulate across blocks of trials. We find that our subjects seem to encode the numbers with a bias, but also with a degree of noise that varies with the size of the number. In particular, numbers that are unlikely under the prior are encoded with greater noise. We further show that a maximum-likelihood decoding model captures subjects’ behavior, and indicates that the encoding is efficiently adapted to the prior, resulting in higher expected rewards in the task.
Furthermore, our model predicts a relation between the bias and the variability of estimates, thus providing a statistically-founded, parsimonious derivation of the “law of human perception” (Wei and Stocker, 2017). Our results both shed new experimental light on human processing of numerical information, and increase our theoretical understanding of an encoding-decoding paradigm in which efficient coding is combined with inference from noisy internal representations, resulting in biases and variability at the behavioral level.
coauthors: Michael Woodford, Columbia University
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Multi-modal representation of self-motion in the retrosplenial cortex
abstract: Successful navigation depends on animals’ ability to reliably track their orientation and heading direction. The internal representation of such directional sense requires angular head velocity (AHV) information. However, despite numerous studies on head direction, place, and grid cells, little is known about the computations underlying AHV signalling, and in particular, how this is achieved in higher order cortical regions in the mammalian brain. Using high-density single-unit recordings, we describe the activity of AHV neurons in the retrosplenial cortex (RSP) of mice exploring a large arena, and in response to vestibular and visual motion stimuli under controlled head-fixed conditions. We find that many AHV neurons display similar tuning properties during active (freely moving) and passive motion (head-fixed rotations in yaw), and combine vestibular and visual inputs to increase the gain and signal-to-noise ratio of angular velocity coding during navigation. Further, using a novel go/no-go task and computational methods, we demonstrate that vestibular-visual combination increases the perceptual accuracy of own velocity, and the fidelity of its representation by RSP neuronal ensembles. These findings provide novel insights into cortical computations underlying representation of self-motion during navigation.
coauthors: Edward F Bracey, Sainsbury Wellcome Centre, UCL; Dario Campagner, Sainsbury Wellcome Centre, UCL; Adam L Tyson, Sainsbury Wellcome Centre, UCL; Stephen C Lenzi, Sainsbury Wellcome Centre, UCL; Tiago Branco, Sainsbury Wellcome Centre, UCL; Troy W Margrie, Sainsbury Wellcome Centre, UCL
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Spatial Symmetry and its Relation to Grammatical Structures
abstract:
Although there has been substantial debate over the merits of neural versus symbolic models of cognition, both approaches face a similar fundamental challenge. In each case, the set of functions available to the modeller includes every computable function, and so the fundamental question of which subset of these functions is cognitively relevant still needs to be answered, whichever toolkit is chosen. Within the symbolic approach, the Chomsky hierarchy provides an important example of possible constraints on the computational power of a formal grammar, in relation to human linguistic behaviour. In contrast, the most important constraint employed within the field of deep learning, has been the translational symmetry of image processing as implemented in convolutional networks. 

Superficially at least, these appear to be two quite divergent means of limiting the space of functions, relating to the structure of space versus the syntax of natural languages. However, it is nonetheless possible to draw a connection between them. In particular, we show that imposing a convolutional structure on the memory cells of a recurrent network produces a stack like data structure, suitable for handling Context Free Grammars, the most common formalism applied to natural languages. Such an architecture reuses the symmetry under spatial translations employed within image processing applications as a method to obtain the uniformity across memory registers that is required for the same symbol to be represented at multiple locations. 

Thus, despite their differences, neural and symbolic researchers have found their attention drawn to spaces of functions that share a common ingredient, in terms of translation invariance across a set of equivalent positions. More abstractly, we argue that symmetry has an important role to play in delimiting sets of interesting functions, that goes beyond just spatial translations and convolution.
coauthors: Jeffrey S. Bowers, University of Bristol
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: The Psychophysics of Non-neuronal Cognition
abstract:
Non-neuronal cognition can be used to explain what appear to be neural behaviors in cellular-level systems. Examples include cellular decision-making (Perkins and Swain, 2009), information processing in regenerative processes (Baluska and Levin, 2016), and active perception among filopodia (Aspalter et.al, 2020). We characterize movement among colonies of the diatom genus Bacillaria as a collective pattern generator (CoPG). The CoPG is similar to a central pattern generator (CPG) found in insect nervous systems. Collective pattern generators are produced by the stretching motions produced by the actin filaments of two neighboring cells. These synchronized movements propagate down the colony in an undulating, accordion -like manner. While we can utilize a neural model to characterize the behavior of this type of multicellular colony, psychophysical models are used to characterize pseudo-neuronal behaviors. 

We will use a database of images and movies of Bacillaria movement (Alicea et.al, 2019) to capture measurements of colony movement and to train a generative model of movement dynamics. Using these data and a model, we can then establish an input/output curve that determines how much input results in a corresponding degree of output. From these input/output curves, we can derive just-noticeable differences and signal detection measurements. To model the movements that lead to statistical regularities, we propose a connectionist model in which nodes (neuronal units) can act as neuronal oscillators. Collectively, these nodes form the components of a CoPG. Meanwhile, connectivity is determined by the relative degree of synchronization between neighboring cells. 

References
Alicea, B., Gordon, R., Harbich, T., Singh, U., Singh, A., and Varma, V. (2019). Towards a Digital Diatom: image processing and deep learning analysis of Bacillaria paradoxa dynamic morphology. bioRxiv, doi:10.1101/2019.12.21.885897.

Aspalter, I.M. et.al (2020). Active Perception during Angiogenesis: filopodia speed up Notch selection of tip cells in silico and in vivo. bioRxiv, doi:10.1101/2020.08.22.261263.

Baluska, F. and Levin, M. (2016). On Having No Head: cognition throughout Biological Systems. Frontiers in Psychology, 7, 902.

Perkins, T.J. and Swain, P.S. (2009). Strategies for cellular decision-making. Molecular Systems Biology, 5, 326.
coauthors: Bradly Alicea, OpenWorm Foundation; Jesse Parent; Richard Gordon; Akshara Gopi; Thomas Harbich
theme: Theme B: Neural Excitability, Synapses, and Glia

title: Merging control strategies for the manipulation of complex objects
abstract:
Skilful object manipulation often combines different movement elements to achieve specific task goals. When swirling a glass of wine, the primary goal of control is to bring the wine (internal degree of freedom) into a rhythmic circular motion, whereas when bringing the glass of wine to the mouth, the main goal is to translate the glass itself. Smooth transition of control goals, from rhythmic to discrete, or from internal to external degrees of freedom, exemplifies the remarkable dexterity in manipulation, yet remains hardly explored. 
This study developed a novel paradigm to examine how humans combine such control goals when manipulating an object with internal dynamics, akin to swirling a glass of wine. Subjects grasped the handle of a custom-designed cup with a ball rolling inside, and rhythmically "swirled" the ball close to the rim, while remaining within a specified "home position". An audible cue signalled subjects to translate the cup in a reach-like movement to a target position. Such discrete translation could interrupt the ball rotation or cause the ball to fall out. Subjects were instructed to keep the ball rotation as steady as possible during and after the reach. Dependent measures were the amplitude and frequency of ball rotation and their deviation/error from a perfect circular motion, the ball phase when initiating the translation, and the duration of the translation.
With practice, subjects achieved smooth transitions between rhythmic (ball) and discrete (cup) movements by jointly modulating the ball phase at translation initiation, and the duration of the translation. These findings suggest that the motor system learns to merge the control goals by integrating the discrete cup movement into the rhythmic cycle of the ball rotation. The observed behaviour is discussed in the context of optimal control theory and dynamic primitives for the control of complex actions.
coauthors: Dagmar Sternad
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: The Molecular Mechanisms of Ethanol Cognitive Neuroadaptations
abstract: Alcohol consumption is known to induce cognitive impairments mainly affecting executive functions, episodic memory, and other capacities related to brain function. Nevertheless, the cellular and molecular mechanisms underlying such interactions is still unknown. Recent evidence has uncovered a similar interaction between ethanol exposure and cognitive function in the fruit fly, Drosophila melanogaster, which opens the way for molecular studies in a genetically tractable model system.  Using an olfactory conditioning assays where an odorant is used as a conditioned stimulus (CS) and is paired with a heat shock used as an unconditioned stimulus (US), it was shown that Drosophila larvae can learn to avoid the odor in future exposures. However, when the animals are exposed to a short acute dose of alcohol, they are no longer able to learn this association. Interestingly, larvae that have undergone prolonged chronic ethanol exposure seem to successfully avoid the odorant paired with the heat shock just as well as control ethanol-naive larvae, which is suggestive of ethanol-induced neuroadaptations. Our aim is to understand the genetic and cellular components responsible for this adaptation. For this, we employ RNA Sequencing technology to evaluate differences in gene expression in the brain of larvae chronically exposed to ethanol and in control larvae. Results from RNA sequencing suggest neuroadaptations are modulated by a diverse array of synaptic proteins within the larvae brain. With the knowledge obtained from this study, we could be able to understand ethanol’s effect on learning and memory and gain an insight into how addiction may be contributing to damages in this behavior.
coauthors: Alfredo Ghezzi, University of Puerto Rico at Río Piedras
institution: University of Puerto Rico at Río Piedras (grid.280412.d)
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Comparing 7T sequences to image human basal ganglia activity during performance on a visual cueing task
abstract: Although it is well established that expectations influence visual selection, our mapping of the neurophysiological infrastructure that instantiates this influence remains incomplete. Two known influences on visual selection; probabilistic and value-based learning, have been associated with the function of the human basal ganglia, yet the sensitivity of these nuclei to visual selection demands remains unknown. Imaging the activity of the basal-ganglia is a challenge, as the iron-rich nuclei suffer signal loss when using conventional imaging sequences. We therefore sought to determine which echo-planar imaging (EPI) parameters yield the best signal in the basal ganglia when participants perform a visual cueing task that pits spatial probabilities against reward incentives in relation to upcoming visual targets. We compared three sequences designed for use with 7T Magnetic Resonance Imaging, that sought to balance high spatial and temporal resolution with full brain coverage, varying in slice acceleration factors and echo times. Importantly, we compared the contrast-to-noise ratio (CNR) between sequences when both spatial probabilities and incentive-values influenced upcoming target discrimination performance, and when comparing the hand of response, which is in-line with the typical contrast used to determine optimal parameters for imaging the basal ganglia. We find that the sequence that provides the best CNR under varying visual selection manipulations is not the same as that found for the motoric contrast. Therefore, optimal imaging parameters for the basal ganglia during experiments that assess visual and cognitive manipulations may differ from the optimal parameters for imaging motoric-related activity.
coauthors: Christopher Nolan, University of Queensland; Ole Jensen, University of Birmingham; Markus Barth, University of Queensland; Marta Garrido, University of Melbourne
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Are colour experiences equivalent across the visual field?
abstract:
Perplexingly, our naïve impression of a vividly coloured experience across the visual field is challenged on empirical and theoretical grounds. Empirically, recent findings that subjects can be unaware of extensive desaturation of their peripheral vision demonstrates that our experiences have no guarantee of accuracy with respect to the external world (veridicality). Theoretically, objective verification of colour experience is hampered by claims that some subjective properties of experience are private and incommunicable. As a result, the connection between internal colour experience and external light properties seems arbitrary. This is epitomised by the "inverted qualia" argument, which posits the plausibility of different wavelength-experience mappings between individuals (e.g. colour inversion).
 
Here, we tested a reduced version of this claim by searching for evidence of colour inversion from central to peripheral vision within subjects. We sought to determine this by obtaining subjective similarity judgments between pairs of colours presented at varying eccentricities. We deemed colour experiences equivalent if stimuli presented at different eccentricities elicited equivalent similarity relationships.  We tested for the possibility of inversion by seeing whether artificially swapping peripheral colour labels during analysis would decrease these correlations. Additionally, we investigated whether the presence/absence of accounting for cortical magnification by using stimuli scaled by eccentricity affected these similarity judgments.
 
Using dissimilarity analysis, we found that the similarity judgments between experiences induced by coloured stimuli were highly correlated regardless of the eccentricity of presentation. Our preliminary analysis suggests that swapping the colour labels (e.g. inversion) produced detectable decreases in correlations between central and peripheral dissimilarity judgments. Additionally, we found that similarity judgments between experiences induced by unscaled (but not scaled) stimuli decreased in correlation as stimulus size decreased. 
 
These results do not support the possibility of colour inversion across the visual field and instead suggest the equivalence of central and peripheral colour experiences, irrespective of veridicality.
coauthors: Ariel Zeleznikow-Johnston, Monash University; Naotsugu Tsuchiya, Monash University
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Biophysically grounded mean-field models of neural populations under electrical stimulation
abstract:
Electrical stimulation of neural systems is a key tool for understanding neural dynamics and ultimately for developing clinical treatments. Many applications of electrical stimulation affect large populations of neurons. However, computational models of large networks of spiking neurons are inherently hard to simulate and analyze. 

We evaluate a reduced mean-field model of excitatory and inhibitory adaptive exponential integrate-and-fire (AdEx) neurons which can be used to efficiently study the effects of electrical stimulation on large neural populations. The rich dynamical properties of this basic cortical model are described in detail and validated using large network simulations. Bifurcation diagrams reflecting the network's state reveal asynchronous up- and down-states, bistable regimes, and oscillatory regions corresponding to fast excitation-inhibition and slow excitation-adaptation feedback loops. The biophysical parameters of the AdEx neuron can be coupled to an electric field with realistic field strengths which then can be propagated up to the population description.

We show how on the edge of bifurcation, direct electrical inputs cause network state transitions, such as turning on and off oscillations of the population rate. Oscillatory input can frequency-entrain and phase-lock endogenous oscillations. Relatively weak electric field strengths on the order of 1 V/m are able to produce these effects, indicating that field effects are strongly amplified in the network. The effects of time-varying external stimulation are well-predicted by the mean-field model, further underpinning the utility of low-dimensional neural mass models.
coauthors: Klaus Obermayer, Technische Universität Berlin
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Can we strategically reallocate memory resources?
abstract: We can selectively prioritize information during perception. In working memory, information can be similarly prioritized by a retro-cue. This is thought to occur due to reallocation of resources to prioritized items. Here we tested this by employing a working memory task with unequal item rewards to create uneven distribution of resources. Retro-cues then indicated which of three items could be dropped from memory. If reallocation occurs, then we should observe a larger benefit in memory when a high reward item versus a low reward item becomes irrelevant, since high reward items tie up more resources. We found that participants use both reward value and cue information to perform the task. There is better performance for items with higher reward values, F(2,90) = 10.85, p < .001, and for valid versus neutral cues, F(1,45) = 16.38, p < .001. However, our results show that removing a well-encoded item does not benefit performance more, t(45) = 0.05, p = .959 (JZS Bayes Factor = 6.245683). These findings challenge the dominant view that retro-cue benefits reflect reallocation of memory resources from removed items. Our results are more consistent with a benefit to cued items (such as retrieval protection or a general strengthening) that is independent of the memory strength of the de-prioritized item.
coauthors: Daryl Fougnie, New York University Abu Dhabi
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Alcohol addiction and Co-Morbid Adult Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder their correlation with Cardiac, Autonomic and Cognitive behavioral Response
abstract:
Background and Rationale: Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) is a childhood 
neurodevelopmental disorder which has a relation with development of substance use disorders in 
adulthood. Physiological link and cognitive correlations between the two disorders may involves the
common network activities of the central autonomic network and frontal cortex. Hence there is a 
need for further research on the correlation between the cardiac, cognitive and behavioral 
parameters. 
Materials and Methods: This is a pilot study which is a part of PhD Study titled “Evaluation of 
Neurobiological correlates in men with co morbid alcohol use disorder and adult ADHD” and here are
preliminary results. 16 Study subjects (males and aged 18-50 years) admitted to deaddiction 
department of NIMHANS were divided into 2 groups with 8 subjects in each group: Alcohol use 
disorder (AUD) with/without comorbid Adult ADHD (AUD+AADHD) and compared with Healthy 
controls from hospital staff and students of NIMHANS. Study groups were subjected to 
Echocardiography, Conventional autonomic function tests, Pupillometry, Go No Go task, stop signal 
task and paired pulse transcranial magnetic stimulation paradigms.
Results: AUD and AUD+AADHD groups showed moderate to severe cardiac autonomic dysfunction, 
decreased values in parasympathetic activity, end systolic volume, decreased reaction time implying 
more impulsivity. Increased sample size might provide some hints on the correlation links between 
various neurobiological measures like cardiac Autonomic & Neurobehavioral dysfunction between 
Alcohol addiction & Adult ADHD compared to healthy controls.
Conclusion: Our study demonstrates the importance of neurobiological measures that exist between 
ADHD and substance use disorders and subsequent need of comprehensive study-based diagnosis for 
improvement of their quality of life.
Keywords: ADHD, Alcohol, TMS, stop signal task, Go No Go task, Heart rate variability, Autonomic 
functions. 
Ethics statement: The experimental protocols were approved by the institutional human ethics 
committee, NIMHANS, Bengaluru.
Acknowledgements: I thank NIMHANS institutional fellowship for providing me financial support for 
conducting my research.
Conflicts of interest: No
coauthors: Mrudula, Dr. TN Sathyaprabha, Dr. Kaviraja Udupa, Dr. Arun Kandasamy,  Dr. Jamuna Rajeshwaran
institution: National Institute of Mental Health and Neurosciences (grid.416861.c)
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Data-driven automatic exercise feedback
abstract: The current approach to correct a trainee’s exercise technique relies on expert feedback based on visual and qualitative assessment. Emerging computer vision-based pose estimation algorithms, built using neural networks, have extraordinary potential to automate and quantify the process of exercise training and injury prediction from videos. In this study, we build an automated pipeline with computer vision, machine learning and predictive modeling to translate weightlifting videos into insights and feedback without human overview. We first curated over 600 videos of people performing a deadlift from online forums along with natural language feedback provided by forum users in the form of over 1500 comments. Body pose information from these videos were obtained with the use of a computer vision-based pose estimation software called OpenPose. The pose data thus obtained was processed  using dynamic time warping so as to align and normalize the videos with each other in time and space for ease of comparison. Using unsupervised machine learning in the form of principal component analysis and k-nearest neighbours clustering, we automatically classify well performed deadlifts from poorly performed ones. Further, we outline a procedure using natural language processing to create a virtual trainer who provides interpretable feedback by analyzing the nature of deviations in the movements of a given video from example expert movements. We envision the automated pipeline used here as being generalizable to other exercises thus, setting the stage for the use of artificial intelligence in exercise training and injury prediction.
coauthors: Titipat Achakulvisut, University of Pennsylvania; Vanessa Moody, University of Pennsylvania; Irene Jeong, University of Pennsylvania; Konrad Kording, University of Pennsylvania
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Hand localization shifts after different types of visual error feedback in reaching
abstract: Perturbed error feedback during reaching movements leads to adapted reaches, which involves at least two processes, as shown by a two-rate model (Smith et al., 2006). This model includes a fast and slow process, that respond differently to errors, and combine to change motor output, including those changes seen during rotated visual feedback training (McDougle et al., 2015). This model is specifically able to explain a rebound toward a previous performance when error feedback is removed. Adapting to rotated visual feedback also leads to shifted estimates of hand location, participants perceive their unseen hand as being closer to where they visually experienced the misaligned hand-cursor. Here we test how different types of feedback during training affect the rebound predicted by the two-rate model and shifts in proprioceptive-estimates of hand location. The feedback conditions include the typical continuous cursor feedback, and more “impoverished” conditions, terminal cursor feedback, and passive-exposure feedback. During rotated exposure feedback training, participants’ hands were moved by the robot with straight hand paths that perfectly countered any rotation, but with a normal error-clamp phase at the end. We find terminal cursor feedback produces a smaller rebound while the rebounds in the other conditions are indistinguishable. Regardless of the type of cursor feedback, perceived changes in hand location emerged very rapidly and with a similar time course throughout training across all three conditions. To further test the rapid changes in hand estimates, another group experienced a visuomotor rotation that changes every 12 trials. Participants attempted to learn each rotation with proprioceptive hand estimates again shifting quite rapidly following each change in rotation direction and size. However, the size of shift decrease slightly as training progressed, indicating a possible change in error sensitivity across time. These results underline the robustness and speed by which vision recalibrates proprioception.
coauthors: Jennifer Ruttle, York University; Bernard M. 't Hart, York University; Denise Henriques, York University
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Analysis of EEG event-durations
abstract:
Many EEG studies are analyzed using event-related potentials (ERP). But often, the experiments contains events of variable duration (e.g. reaction times, fixation durations, stimulus durations, movements). Due to a lack of analysis tools or plain unawareness, such durations are rarely modelled and typically a single ERP is calculated for all durations. This can lead to nonsensical, missleading or otherwise biased results, especially if event durations differ between conditions.

Using regression methods, I investigated this problem on real and simulated datasets. In the simulations, I systematically explore the effects of the ERP's waveform, different duration distributions, and noise, on multiple ways to model duration. Because varying event-durations co-ocur often with temporal overlap between events, I also investigate the influence of overlap and deconvolution based overlap-correction.

I conclude, that modelling event durations as a binned or linear predictor is not recommended. Non-linear effects can capture some of the patterns and are a promising candidate for further study.

This work is especially important for complex experiments for instance in virtual-reality or mobile EEG settings which naturally allow for eye-movements.
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Dendritic and synaptic inhomogeneity patterns between pyramidals as a complementary mechanism for flexible coding in PFC.
abstract:
The Prefrontal Cortex (PFC) displays flexibility in decision making, compared to other cortical areas. Also, it contains non perfectly tuned neurons, responding in a variable way. Yet can robustly discriminate and maintain memoranda in working memory (WM). We investigate the effect of synaptic and dendritic mechanisms, in a PFC model network during a WM task simulation, to establish a link between these mechanisms and discrimination and maintenance of WM memoranda. 
We propose the dendritic and synaptic inhomogeneity patterns between PFC pyramidals as a complementary mechanism for flexible coding in PFC, sufficient for performing stimulus dependent shifts of network activity, ultimately to be utilized downstream for different behavior. We do so by probing the spatial arrangement of synaptic inputs on a variable number of dendrites. Finally, we explore the structured, highly reciprocal PFC connectivity as an optimal neural connectivity substrate, best exploiting the dendritic and synaptic inhomogeneities for the above-mentioned computations. 
Our results show that the combination of dendritic and synaptic inhomogeneities and structured, highly reciprocal connectivity can enable a single PFC recurrent network model to rapidly discriminate and maintain memoranda, despite the variable individual neuronal responses. We report that the network can rapidly shift between different transient, yet robustly discriminable activity trajectories, that are maintained during post-stimulus epoch. Also, we show that the above connectivity predicts the best PFC WM storage ability, compared with a non-optimal i.e. non-biologically correct network connectivity.
coauthors: Stefanos Stefanou, IMBB,FORTH, Department of Biology, University of Crete, Heraklion, Crete; Athanasia Papoutsi, IMBB,FORTH;  Panayiota Poirazi, IMBB,FORTH;
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Proposal to use neuromorphic architecture to emulate neurological disease progression or neurotoxicity
abstract:
This is combining topics A and E - and is supposed to be not a real scientific talk but rather an open discussion about the roadmap to achieve a novel instrument which is using multi-scale (bottom up / top down) inputs to emulate ("in mimicko") two things. 1) disease progression and effect of drug to slow the progression - and 2) long-term neurotoxicity side effects. 
Topic1: the progression of neurological disease - over a very long range (computing 1h emulation  - resulting in 10 years "real life progression) for a speedup of 100k (e.g. using Spinnaker)). What is needed is a collaboration from neuroanatomists, pharmaceutics, neuromorphic modelling, neurology medical expertise, behavior modelling as well as a deep understanding of the mechanism of action for both the disease as well as the potential treatment. E.g. monitoring the onset of blurry vision in MS - and delay of this onset by drugs.
Topic2: using the same mechanism to emulate potential long term neurotoxic effects which accumulate over time given "drug exposure". This is more speculative.
The challenge is mapping neuroanatomic details to the emulation - as well as precise mapping of the biochemistry - including blood-brain barrier.
theme: Theme A: Development, Neurodegenerative Disorders and Injury

title: Online assessments of Word-Predictability: a feasible alternative to in-lab research
abstract: Recently, the use of web platforms for massive experiments has been rapidly growing. Online experiments allow to increase the number of participants to partake in the experiment, improving the quality of some measures. Also, using social media platforms one is able to reach people from several demographics making these results more diverse, and thus more representative. In order to understand how internal processes of the mind and external stimuli play together in the generation of action, reading may serve as an ideal paradigm since it requires language, reasoning and memory processes, to orchestrate the task. When we read printed text, we are continuously predicting upcoming words to integrate information and decide when and where we are going to move our eyes. The Predictability of each word can be estimated with a Cloze-Task Experiment. In it subjects have to read an incomplete text and guess the missing words given the preceding context. We studied whether online Cloze-Tasks could replicate in-lab ones, or even improve them as the sample size could be increased. In three experiments involving different corpora and online and in-lab setups, we observed that the online Cloze-Task replicates the results from the in-lab one and that the results were consistent between independent online experiments. Also, we showed that word-Predictability is highly dependent on large contexts, i.e. if the sentence is embedded in a story or not. Thus, online Cloze-Task could ease the collection for larger samples, generating robust and more precise measures.Recently, the use of web platforms for massive experiments has been rapidly growing. Online experiments allow to increase the number of participants to partake in the experiment, improving the quality of some measures. Also, using social media platforms one is able to reach people from several demographics making these results more diverse, and thus more representative. In order to understand how internal processes of the mind and external stimuli play together in the generation of action, reading may serve as an ideal paradigm since it requires language, reasoning and memory processes, to orchestrate the task. When we read printed text, we are continuously predicting upcoming words to integrate information and decide when and where we are going to move our eyes. The Predictability of each word can be estimated with a Cloze-Task Experiment. In it subjects have to read an incomplete text and guess the missing words given the preceding context. We studied whether online Cloze-Tasks could replicate in-lab ones, or even improve them as the sample size could be increased. In three experiments involving different corpora and online and in-lab setups, we observed that the online Cloze-Task replicates the results from the in-lab one and that the results were consistent between independent online experiments. Also, we showed that word-Predictability is highly dependent on large contexts, i.e. if the sentence is embedded in a story or not. Thus, online Cloze-Task could ease the collection for larger samples, generating robust and more precise measures.
coauthors: Bruno Bianchi,  Laboratorio de Inteligencia Artificial Aplicada, Instituto de Ciencias de la Computación, FCEyN, UBA - CONICET; Diego E Shalom, Departamento de Física, FCEyN, UBA; Juan E Kamienkowski ,Laboratorio de Inteligencia Artificial Aplicada, Instituto de Ciencias de la Computación, FCEyN, UBA - CONICET,Departamento de Física, FCEyN, UBA
institution: Laboratorio de Inteligencia Artificial Aplicada, Instituto de Ciencias de la Computación, FCEyN, UBA - CONICET
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Probabilistic Information Processing in Humans and Recurrent Neural Networks
abstract: In nature, sensory inputs are often highly structured, and statistical regularities of these signals can be extracted to form expectations about future sensori-motor associations, thereby facilitating optimal behavior. To date, the circuit mechanisms that underlie these probabilistic computations are not well understood. Through human  electrophysiolgical  experiment  and  a  recurrent  neural  network  (RNN) model, the present study investigates how the brain extracts, processes, and utilizes probabilistic  structures  of  sensory  signals  to  guide  behavior.  To  achieve  this goal, we first constructed and trained a biophysically constrained RNN model to perform a probabilistic decision-making task similar to the paradigm used in the human data.  Specifically, the training environment was probabilistic such that one stimulus was more probable than the others. We show that both humans and the RNN model successfully extract information about stimulus probability and integrate this knowledge into their decisions and task strategy in a new environment. Specifically, performance of both humans and the RNN model varied with the degree to which the stimulus probability of the new environment matched the formed expectations. In both humans and RNNs, this expectation effect was more prominent when the strength of sensory evidence was low. These findings suggest that both humans and our RNN model placed more emphasis on prior expectations (top-down signals) when the available sensory information (bottom-up signals) was limited.  Finally, by dissecting the trained RNN model, we demonstrate how competitive inhibition and recurrent excitation form the basis for neural circuitry optimized to perform probabilistic information processing.
coauthors: Robert Kim, Salk Institute for Biological Studies; Terrence J. Sejnowski, Salk Institute for Biological Studies
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Whether and how resource sharing resists scarcity : behavioral, neuroimaging, and endocrinological findings
abstract: Previous  findings support that resource deprivation significantly activates a strong self-serving bias and promotes selfish preference in sharing decision making. However, a large number of studies have shown that uncommon sharing behavior could still be observed in the condition of resource scarcity. It’s unclear how resource sharing persists under shortage. In the present study, we suggested that empathy has accounted for the inconsistent and heterogeneous results in literatures of sharing decision. Here we combined a novel within-subject paradigm- participant who own resource decided whether and how to share their survival resources with the other participant who has no resource-with functional Magnetic Resonance Imaging (fMRI) and intranasal oxytocin to characterize the neural mechanisms underlying the processing of sharing behavior under resource scarcity. At the behavioral level, we found that people kept more resources for themselves under insufficient condition relative to sufficient condition. And the stability of sharing behavior was significantly correlated with the cognitive empathy(CE) score (r = -0.48, p < 0.01). At the neural level, we found activation in the left and right temporal-parietal junction (TPJ) were suppressed while the bilateral inferior occipital gyrus (IOG) were enhanced in insufficient condition comparing to sufficient condition. Psychophysiological Interactions (PPI) further suggested that the functional connectivity from lIOG to rTPJ was positively associated with the stability of sharing behavior. Oxytocin experiment provided evidence that high CE participants receiving oxytocin showed a lower changing rate than those receiving placebo while the low CE participants show no oxytocin effect. These findings suggest cognitive empathy trait and the lIOG-rTPJ neural connectivity play a crucial role in maintaining the stability of sharing behavior under scarcity, and oxytocin may strengthen the relationship between the two.
coauthors: Jie Liu, School of Psychology, Shenzhen University, Shenzhen, China; Ruolei Gu, 3.	CAS Key Laboratory of Behavioral Science, Institute of Psychology, Beijing, China; Xiaoxuan Huang, 1.	School of Psychology, Shenzhen University, Shenzhen, China; Yue-jia Luo, 1.	School of Psychology, Shenzhen University, Shenzhen, China; Fang Cui, 1.	School of Psychology, Shenzhen University, Shenzhen, China
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Validation of a Convolutional Neural Network Model for Spike Transformation Using a Generalized Functional Additive Model
abstract:
Identification of causal relationships of neural activity is one of the most important problems in neuroscience and neural engineering. Past work has shown that cognitive processes such as memory formation rely on transformations of spatio-temporal patterns of spikes across different neural populations. Such transformations are highly nonlinear dynamical, and cannot be captured by basic linear models. Convolutional neural networks (CNN) can capture complex nonlinearity and abstract low-level and high-level features in natural images via the use of deep layers of nonlinear activation functions. It thus holds the promise of modeling complex neural spike transformations underlying cognitive processes.
We treat spatio-temporal patterns of past input spikes as binary images and use a CNN to predict spiking in a single output neuron in a binary classification task. We generate synthetic data using a generalized functional additive model (GFAM) with multiple neurophysiologically inspired functions (kernels) and a probit link function that is passed to a threshold to produce a binary neural time series representing spikes. A sliding window generates binary training images from this time series that are passed to a CNN with multiple layers of convolution with filters convolving over the time domain to capture temporal nonlinearity. The CNN is able to achieve a high correlation between the predicted probability of spiking in the output neuron and the true probability of spiking in the output neuron for the data generated with a generalized functional additive model. The CNN is also able to recover the ground truth kernels used to generate the probability of spiking in the output neuron during synthetic data generation. Based on the CNN's validation via a GFAM, our current work includes validation of our approach with non-linear models using data generated with more complex nonlinear kernels.
coauthors: Dong Song, University of Southern California
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Right and Left Neglect are not Anatomically Homologous: A Voxel-Lesion Symptom Mapping Study
abstract:
Visuospatial neglect is a heterogenous syndrome which can occur following damage to either right or left hemisphere areas. This study employs voxel-lesion symptom mapping to identify the neural correlates of left and right egocentric and allocentric neglect in large, representative acute stroke cohort.
499 acute stroke survivors (age=71.6, 41.5% female) completed neuropsychological neglect assessment and routine clinical imaging. Similar to previous investigations, left egocentric and left allocentric neglect were associated with damage to distinct clusters of voxels within the posterior parietal and temporo-parietal junction areas. Unlike previous investigations, right egocentric neglect was found to most strongly associated with damage to ipsilateral voxels within the right parietal operculum and superior longitudinal fasciculus. Interestingly, the left hemisphere homologues of the areas implicated in left-lateralised egocentric neglect were not found to act as significant predictors of right egocentric neglect impairment (F(7,317)=1.041, R2=0.028, p=0.396). Right allocentric neglect was found to be most strongly associated with damage to the anterior division of the left parahippocampal gyrus. 
The results of this investigation suggest that right egocentric neglect should not be characterised as a consequence of damage to left-hemisphere homologues of the right hemisphere attentional systems.  These findings support the characterisation of visuospatial neglect as a heterogenous cluster of impairments rather than a unitary syndrome and provide novel insight into the neural correlates of spatial attention.
coauthors: Celline Gilbert, KU Leuven; Nele Demeyere, University of Oxford
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Black In Neuro: Neuroracism Panel Discussion
abstract:
Black In Neuro will lead a panel discussion as the first installment of a 2-part event on neuroracism.

The NeuroRacism panel will center discussions on how we in academia collect, use and interpret data about Black people. Panelists will highlight ongoing biases and anti-Black racism that is currently embedded in the practices of neuro-related research. We will explore what it means to think about data critically, from a social justice oriented lens, and to question the current status quo.

Participants are encouraged to revisit Black in Neuro’s NeuroRacism panel from this summer to gain further context and perspectives. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=inYtc5apSuk&t=1458s

Moderator: De-Shaine Murray

Panelist: 
- Kafui Dzirasa, PhD

- Abeba Birhane, PhD Candidate

- Shalini Kantayya

title: Learning a Path-Integrating Circuit of the Drosophila Central Complex
abstract: Head direction cells are neurons that respond selectively to a specific head orientation in space. They are organized in a recurrent network, where the current head orientation is represented by a localized bump of neuronal activity. Path integration in the context of head direction cells is moving this bump of activity around the network respecting the animal's current head orientation, while using only self-motion cues. The one-dimensional ring attractor has been a popular approach to model the network of head direction cells, and one of the most long-lived attractor network models in Computational Neuroscience. Furthermore, this model has recently received experimental support in the fly's head direction system. However, it remains to date unclear how a path integrating circuit of head direction cells could self-organize through synaptic plasticity. Previous models showed circuits that either needed parameter tuning after training, or used biologically implausible learning rules.
coauthors: Pantelis Vafidis, Computation and Neural Systems, Division of Biology and Biological Engineering, California Institute of Technology, Pasadena, United States; Tiziano D'Albis, Institute for Theoretical Biology, Department of Biology, Humboldt-Universität zu Berlin, Berlin, Germany; David Owald, Institute of Neurophysiology, Charite – Universitatsmedizin Berlin, Berlin, Germany; Richard Kempter, Institute for Theoretical Biology, Department of Biology, Humboldt-Universität zu Berlin, Berlin, Germany;
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Metabolic state dependence of olfactory cortex flavor representation during binge eating in rodents
abstract:
Energy homeostasis is achieved by the complex regulatory network that involves a feedback circuit between dietary intake behavior and nutritional state. The uncoupling of dietary intake and nutritional state results in overeating. Hedonic overeating can escalate into binge eating, a heritable trait associated with binge eating disorder and bulimia. One factor that modulates this feedback loop is the sensory perception of flavors. Olfaction is a critical element of flavor perception and greatly influences the qualitative and hedonic evaluation of food items. Patients with olfactory chemosensory deficits commonly report a reduced appreciation of food items. Current evidence suggests that upon fasting, the olfactory system is necessary for triggering fasting-induced overeating. However, it is unclear how adaptations related to binge eating are reflected by the olfactory flavor responses. 

To understand the relationship between olfactory perception and binging, we developed an overeating behavioral paradigm that repeatedly delivers hedonic food (flavored milk) to mice. Implementing this with a head-mount miniaturized microscope allows us to measure neural responses upon overeating in the olfactory cortex (piriform cortex) in freely moving mice. We found that during a binge eating bout, the majority (~90%) of excitatory piriform neurons are suppressed. Whether this implies the involvement of inhibitory neurons during binging and/or whether the flavor representation adapts during the escalation of binging are the next steps of our examination.
coauthors: Anke Schönherr, Charité; Marion Rivalan, Humboldt University of Berlin; Katharina Stumpenhorst, Humboldt University of Berlin; York Winter, Humboldt University of Berlin; Dietmar Schmitz, Charité; Friedrich Johenning, Charité
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: A speech planning network for interactive language use
abstract: During conversation, people take turns speaking by rapidly responding to their partners while simultaneously avoiding interruption. Such interactions display a remarkable degree of coordination, as typical gaps between turns are ~200 ms – approximately the duration of an eyeblink. These response times are considerably shorter than those observed in simple word production tasks, indicating that speakers often plan their responses while they listen to their partners. Although a distributed network of brain regions has been implicated in speech planning, the neural dynamics underlying the specific preparatory processes which enable rapid turn-taking are poorly understood. Here we use intracranial electrocorticography to precisely measure rapidly evolving cortical activity associated with speech planning in participants performing interactive language tasks, and we isolate these dynamics to a spatially restricted planning network that is anatomically segregated from brain regions involved in speech perception and production. The core of this planning network is comprised of caudal inferior frontal gyrus (i.e., ‘Broca’s region’), which is crucial for language production, and caudal middle frontal gyrus, a region not normally implicated in speech planning. Using a series of motor tasks, we show that this planning circuit is selectively active when preparing speech but largely unrecruited when planning nonlinguistic orofacial and manual actions. We examine neural activity while participants engage in natural conversation and isolate planning dynamics that are largely identical to those observed our interactive tasks. Finally, we find that electrical stimulation of sites displaying planning activity can significantly lengthen the time until the onset of the opposing speaker’s turn and result in characteristic errors in responses. Taken together, identification of this speech planning circuit advances our understanding of naturalistic language generation by uncovering cortical dynamics central to spoken communication.
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: What is it like to have a disorder of consciousness? Interpreting neural measures of conscious “level”
abstract:
Disorders of consciousness (DOC) pose a significant clinical and ethical challenge because they allow for complex forms of conscious experience in patients where behavioural responses and communication are highly limited or non-existent. We currently know very little about what it is like to have a DOC, but richer information about the lived conscious experience of these patients could positively influence research and practice. For example, such knowledge may inform welfare-improving decisions about treatment, rehabilitation, social interaction and environmental enhancements for DOC patients. There has been considerable research into neuroscientific measures that could provide further insight by quantitatively assessing an unresponsive individual’s conscious “level” based on neural data. However, there is a growing consensus that consciousness is a multidimensional phenomenon and that unidimensional measures cannot capture all relevant kinds of variation in DOC consciousness. It remains unclear which dimensions of consciousness these unidimensional neural measures may reflect. 
Given the paucity of subjective reports about DOC consciousness, I propose that to make progress on this question, we can investigate how neural measures behave in other conscious states where subjective reports are available (like sleep, psychedelic experiences, and anaesthesia). I survey such evidence for neural measures of consciousness and based on this, I argue that these measures may often be sensitive to particular features of consciousness, like sensory richness and unconstrained mental activity, but cannot be thought to index conscious level per se. These neural measures, if conceived of and applied as markers of specific conscious or neurocognitive properties, may offer significant insight into the subjective quality of DOC experience and as such may inform treatment and welfare related decisions for this patient group.
theme: Theme F: History, Education and Society

title: Learning orthogonalizes visual cortical population codes
abstract:
A body of work argues that learning results in an increased representation of behaviorally relevant stimuli in cortex; however, understanding how learning changes population codes requires simultaneously recording large neural populations. To clarify the effects of learning in primary visual cortex (V1), we recorded from thousands of neurons in V1 in response to passive drifting gratings before and after training on a novel orientation comparison task. 

In the task, two gratings were presented simultaneously, each one of three orientations (45°, 68°, and 90°). Mice were rewarded for choosing 45° or rejecting 90°. Thus, 45° and 90° informed what action the mouse should take while 68° was a distractor. 

Task training affected orientation tuning curves in unexpected ways: a reduction in the number of neurons preferring the informative orientations (45° and 90°), asymmetric tuning curves, and suppression of responses to both informative orientations, most notably for weakly tuned neurons. 

These multifarious effects on tuning curves could be explained by a simple principle: sparsening of the population for informative orientations. This increase in population sparseness orthogonalized the population codes for informative stimuli to each other and to all other orientations (i.e., increased the angle between the population rate vectors). 

To elucidate the possible biological mechanism underlying these learning effects, we developed a simple computational model, in which a top-down “importance signal” modulated neuronal F-I curves.
