This model, which does not necessitate Hebbian-like plasticity, could successfully recapitulate the myriad impacts of learning on single-cell tuning curves by increasing population sparseness through F-I curve modulation. 

Our results show that learning sparsifies the representation of informative task stimuli in the brain, orthogonalizes their population codes, and may improve their differentiation by downstream regions of the brain.
coauthors: Samuel W. Failor, University College London; Matteo Carandini, University College London; Kenneth D. Harris, University College London
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Threat Neurocircuitry Predicts the Development of Anxiety and Depression Symptoms in a Longitudinal Study
abstract:
Dimensional models of anxiety and depression highlight symptom clusters that are thought to reflect disruptions in underlying functional processes. The current study investigates how longitudinal changes of symptom dimensions of anxiety and depression relate to threat neurocircuitry. 

Participants aged 18-19 years (N=269, 183 female) were enrolled to ensure a range of scores on symptom measures related to threat and reward sensitivity. Subjects went through self-report measures of anxiety and depression at baseline, 12, 24, and 36 months. Symptom dimensions of general distress, fear, and anhedonic depression were estimated through a tri-level factorial model for each time point. Linear slopes were extracted for the change of symptom dimensions over time. Additionally, functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) scans were obtained while participants performed Pavlovian fear acquisition, extinction, and extinction recall tasks at both baseline and 36 months. Neural activity in brain regions related to neural threat circuitry (e.g. amygdala, hippocampus, anterior insula) were extracted. 

Linear mixed models used to estimate relationships between the change of symptom dimensions over time and activation in neural threat circuitry revealed two major findings: (1) Neural threat reactivity during fear acquisition at baseline is positively associated with changes in fear symptoms over and above changes in general distress and anhedonia-apprehension, suggesting that greater sensitivity to fearful stimuli at baseline is associated with a greater increase in fear symptoms during the 3-year prospective period. (2) Neural responses to the extinguished stimulus during extinction recall at 36 months are negatively associated with changes in general distress, suggesting that greater increases in general distress over the 3 years are associated with deficits in extinction at 36 months. These findings show the promise of fMRI fear conditioning paradigms as a tool for classifying individuals into empirically established symptom profiles.
coauthors: Jeffrey D. Knotts, University of California, Los Angeles;  Katherine S. Young, King’s College London; Susan Y. Bookheimer, University of California, Los Angeles; Robin Nusslock, Northwestern University; Richard E. Zinbarg, Northwestern University; Michelle G. Craske, University of California, Los Angeles
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: A circuit-based theory of the impact of cortical state on information flow
abstract: Cortical state changes such as attention or arousal are a frequent topic of study as they allow for the inference of relationships between changes in cortical activity and behavior. Intuition for these links has been derived from how response properties often subject to cortical state modulation, like tuning and correlated variability, relate to information flow. However, despite the widespread use of these results in unpacking experimental observations, it remains to fully consider how modulation of cortical state affects stimulus processing. To this end we look at the effect of cortical state on information flow in cortical circuit models and find that linear Fisher information does not change with cortical state if the operating regime of cortex is well-described by a linear response function. This is because any state-dependent changes in response gain are canceled by changes in population variability. We show that if one restricts a decoder to a subset of a cortical population, information within the subpopulation can increase through modulation of cortical state. One clear example is that of excitatory and inhibitory cells in a network: only excitatory cells project along the cortical hierarchy, and are thereby the only targets of interest to a downstream decoder. Surprisingly, we find that only those cells which are not accessible to the decoder can modulate how information flow changes within the decoded population. Our theory additionally reveals a parametrically simplified and intuitive framework for analyzing the effects of modulation on information processing, thereby adding valuable insight into a widespread phenomenon across cortical networks.
coauthors: Chengcheng Huang, University of Pittsburgh; Brent Doiron, University of Chicago
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Black In Neuro: Screening of the film "Coded Bias"
abstract:
Black In Neuro will host a screening of the new film "Coded Bias"

RSVP to join us for a film on bias in artificial intelligence and the women data scientists and mathematicians fighting to expose its threat to civil liberties and democracy.

https://www.eventbrite.co.uk/e/neuromatch-conference-black-in-neuro-coded-bias-screening-event-tickets-126251394319

You will be sent a link to watch the film via email 10 minutes before the event start time.

Film Synopsis:
Coded Bias explores the fallout of MIT Media Lab researcher Joy Buolamwini’s startling discovery that facial recognition does not see dark-skinned faces accurately, and her subsequent journey to push for the first-ever US legislation to govern against bias in artificial intelligence. The documentary aims to shine a light on the threat artificial intelligence poses to civil rights and democracy.

title: Microsurgical lesions identify segmentally distinct responses of axotomized corticospinal neurons
abstract: It remains well established that the intrinsic ability of neurons for axon regeneration declines with age. Despite significant work, we still do not precisely know how and when do neurons lose this intrinsic ability during development. This is because conventional models of injury produce an injury response and disrupt potential guidance cues required for axon growth. Such models cannot therefore precisely delineate the intrinsic ability of neurons for axon regrowth. We aimed to investigate intrinsic ability of axonal regeneration during development, at a time when appropriate guidance cues are still expressed in their appropriate context. To this end, we have established a novel, reproducible, approach to transect developing corticospinal neuron (CSN) axons in the neonatal spinal cord. In this new approach, the corticospinal tract (CST) is injured using a beveled micropipette vibrating at ultrasonic frequency. This results in minimal glial scarring, inflammation and leaves the spinal environment largely unperturbed. This therefore enables a clear, unambiguous investigation of the intrinsic ability of axon regeneration through development. Our results surprisingly indicate that CSN axon regenerative ability is not lost uniformly across the different segments of the same axon. Specifically, CSN axons injured at postnatal day 7 (P7) at caudal thoracic T11 can fully regenerate and extend to lumbar segments. In striking contrast, CSN axons, when injured at high cervical C2, at an even earlier time, P4, completely fail to extend across this micro-lesion. This surprising finding indicates that CSN axons lose their regenerative ability at distinct times at distinct spinal segments. This new approach will now enable molecular delineation of specific mechanisms controlling the decline of CSN regenerative ability. Further, this also suggests that distinct therapeutic approaches will be required to target CST regeneration after spinal injuries at different spinal segmental levels. Finally, this novel microsurgical approach can now be used to specifically test whether candidate molecules can increase the intrinsic ability of CSN to extend axons after spinal cord injury.
coauthors: Vibhu Sahni, Ph.D.
theme: Theme A: Development, Neurodegenerative Disorders and Injury

title: Endothelin-1 signaling maintains glial progenitor proliferation in the postnatal subventricular zone
abstract: Signaling molecules that regulate neurodevelopmental processes in the early postnatal subventricular zone (SVZ) are critical for proper brain development yet remain poorly characterized. Here, we report that Endothelin-1 (ET-1), a molecular component of the postnatal SVZ, promotes radial glial cell maintenance and proliferation in an autocrine manner via Notch signaling. Loss of ET-1 signaling increases neurogenesis and reduces oligodendrocyte progenitor cell proliferation (OPC) in the developing SVZ, thereby altering cellular output of the stem cell niche. We also show that ET-1 is required for increased neural stem cell and OPC proliferation in the adult mouse SVZ following demyelination. Lastly, high levels of ET-1 in the SVZ of patients with Cathepsin A-related arteriopathy with strokes and leukoencephalopathy correlate with an increased number of SVZ OPCs, suggesting ET-1's role as a regulator of glial progenitor proliferation may be conserved in humans. ET-1 signaling therefore presents a potential new therapeutic target for promoting SVZ-mediated cellular repair.
coauthors: Giulia Riparini, University of Urbino "Carlo Bo", Italy; Payal Banerjee, Children's National Hospital, USA;  Marjolein Breur, VU University Medical Center, The Netherlands;  Marianna Bugiani, VU University Medical Center, The Netherlands;  Vittorio Gallo, Children's National Hospital, USA.
theme: Theme A: Development, Neurodegenerative Disorders and Injury

title: MULTINETWORK VISUOMOTOR TRAINING TO SYNTH-MUSIC INVESTIGATED WITH MOBILE EEG
abstract:
We investigated the contribution of multinetwork training with music to neurorehabilitation. Previous studies showed that dance-based learning over 8-months produced BOLD signal changes in SMA using fMRI (Bar & DeSouza 2016) and resting state alpha power increases in frontal cortex post-dance in people with Parkinson’s disease compared to controls (Levkov et al 2014). 
Our current project assesses the impact of motor learning while subjects (n=16) learn a 30-second choreography. Trials include watching VIDEO (4 times), watching LIVE performances of the choreography (6 times), moving with the teacher (LEARN; 6 to 20 times), imagining performing from a first-person perspective (IMAGINE; 6 times), and finally performing in space (PERFORM; 6 times).  Sessions were recorded at the Berlin Mobile Brain/Body Imaging lab (BeMoBIL) which allows for acquisition of motion capture data synced with continuous recording of wireless mobile EEG (Brain Products ActiCap; 128 electrodes) in a dedicated 150 m2 lab space Movements are measured using 10 HTC Vive trackers running on Steam VR; music was rated for valence pre/post learning. 
Preliminary results show a significant shift (p=.0009) in participants’ affective scoring of the music post-learning, suggesting that the experience of dance learning impacts perception of previously unfamiliar music. This is important, as music is a consistent factor in rehabilitation programs using dance; however, to this point, the effects of motor learning on affective music perception have not been studied in this context.  Additionally, all participants reached our target of 80% or higher accuracy in reproducing the movement sequence within 20 LEARN trials, with expertise correlating to fewer trials. Next steps include frequency analysis of EEG data pre/post and during learning, along with movement analysis to determine the contribution of motor learning to observed brain-based changes.
coauthors: Joseph FX DeSouza, York University; Lydia Jaufmann, Sein Jeung, Janna Protzak, Klaus Gramann, TU Berlin
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Functional brain network for perisaccadic visual processing: evidence from high resolution EEG and graph theory analysis
abstract: The cortical network involved in the perisaccadic visual processing is still poorly understood and debates remain to find how brain can integrate the information from two visual fields (i.e. pre- and post- saccadic fixation points). Here, we constructed functional brain networks from Electroencephalography (EEG) data in the perisaccadic interval. Then, we evaluated the topological and spectral properties of the perisaccadic network. EEG was recorded via 64 channels in two behavioral conditions (fixation and saccade). Participants (N=21) were pre-cued with a series 1-3 grids (three horizontal lines, 10° by 10°) located 5° below the central fixation-point. In the saccade condition, saccades (recorded by Electrooculography) were cued by a sudden shift of the fixation-point to 10° left/right. 100ms later, a stimulus (three vertical lines; same size/location) was briefly presented (for 70ms). Saccades were occurred after the stimulus presentation. Fixation condition was identical, except the fixation-point remained in the centre. LORETA source localization was performed on the 200ms period following the saccade cue, or the equivalent time during fixation trials. Lagged coherences were calculated between all pairs of 84 Brodmann areas. Graph theory analysis (GTA) was implemented to find clustering coefficient (C), global efficiency (E), energy (H), entropy (S). Nonparametric permutation test showed higher values for C, E, H, and S in all frequency bands for the saccade task (relative to the fixation task). These results suggest that the segregation, integration, synchronizability, and complexity of brain network were simultaneously enhanced during the perisaccadic interval (in comparison to the fixation). The increased network properties can suggest a mechanism for high-level information processing (that is related to increased entropy in the network) and high-speed information propagation (that is associated with higher energy, clustering coefficient, and efficiency in the network) during the perisaccadic interval.
coauthors: Amirhossein Ghaderi, Centre for Vision Research, York University, and Vision Science to Applications (VISTA) Program, York University, Toronto, ON, Canada;  Matthias Niemeier, 3Department of Psychology, University of Toronto Scarborough, Toronto, ON, Canada; John Douglas Crawford, Centre for Vision Research, York University, and Vision Science to Applications (VISTA) Program, York University, Toronto, ON, Canada
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: PsychRNN: An Accessible and Flexible Python Package for Training Recurrent Neural Network Models on Cognitive Tasks
abstract: Task-trained artificial recurrent neural networks (RNNs) provide a computational modeling framework of increasing interest and application in computational, systems, and cognitive neuroscience. RNNs can be trained, using deep learning methods, to perform cognitive tasks used in animal and human experiments, and can be studied to investigate potential neural representations and circuit mechanisms underlying cognitive computations and behavior. Widespread application of these approaches within neuroscience has been limited by technical barriers in use of deep learning software packages to train network models. Here we introduce PsychRNN, an accessible, flexible, and extensible Python package for training RNNs on cognitive tasks. Our package is designed for accessibility, for researchers to define tasks and train RNN models using only Python and NumPy without requiring knowledge of deep learning software. The training backend is based on TensorFlow and is readily extensible for researchers with TensorFlow knowledge to develop projects with additional customization. PsychRNN implements a number of specialized features to support applications in systems and cognitive neuroscience. Users can impose neurobiologically relevant constraints on synaptic connectivity patterns. Furthermore, specification of cognitive tasks has a modular structure, which facilitates parametric variation of task demands to examine their impact on model solutions. PsychRNN also enables task shaping during training, or curriculum learning, in which tasks are adjusted in closed-loop based on performance. Shaping is ubiquitous in training of animals in cognitive tasks, and PsychRNN allows investigation of how shaping trajectories impact learning and model solutions. Overall, the PsychRNN framework facilitates application of trained RNNs in neuroscience research.
coauthors: Daniel Ehrlich*, Yale University; Jasmine Stone*, Yale University, University of Cambridge; David Brandfonbrener, Yale University, New York University ; Alex Atanasov, Yale University, Harvard University ; John Murray, Yale University  (* indicates equal contribution)
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: The gradient of population receptive field stimulus-dependence in ventral visual cortex
abstract: Regions of ventral occipito-temporal (VOT) visual cortex are more responsive to written words than other categories of visual stimuli. We refer to these regions as the VOT reading circuitry (VOTRC). The population receptive field (pRF) of a voxel is the portion of the visual field in which stimuli evoke a response. The pRFs of voxels in the VOTRC are stimulus-dependent (Le et al., 2017). Measured with word stimuli, the pRF centers are mainly confined to the central visual field (with a clear contralateral bias); measured with checkerboard stimuli, the pRF centers span a wider range of locations,  extending to the periphery. To understand this stimulus dependence, we analyzed pRFs in visual field-maps (V1-3, hV4, VO1) whose signals are the likely inputs to the VOTRC. We measured pRFs in 34 subjects (20 only English; 14 Hebrew/English) using the moving bar paradigm with several types of contrast patterns within the bar (checkerboards, English and Hebrew words of different sizes, false fonts). We found that stimulus dependence emerges gradually along the visual field map hierarchy. The stimulus dependence is small in visual areas V1 and V2, becoming more pronounced in V3, hV4, and VO-1. The pRF center can be expressed in Cartesian [x,y] or Polar [eccentricity,angle] coordinates. The largest variation in stimulus dependence is the eccentricity of the pRF center; the angle remains relatively constant. Given that the pRF position is stimulus dependent, it may be important to use the relevant stimulus when using pRFs to model the visual components of different tasks. With an interest in reading development, it seems best to use word stimuli in a legible orthography. Establishing pRF properties using such stimuli in good readers may help understand the visual reading circuitry and provide a baseline for comparing responses in poor readers.
coauthors: Garikoitz Lerma-Usabiaga; Rosemary Le; Chen Gafni; Michal Ben-Shachar; Brian Wandell
institution: Basque Center on Cognition, Brain and Language (grid.423986.2)
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Is the Kiki-Bouba effect specific to pronounceable words?
abstract:
INTRODUCTION. Across cultures, people associate spiky shapes to the word “Kiki” and rounded shapes to the word “Bouba”. What causes this highly systematic shape-sound association? One possibility is that our mouth forms an angular shape while uttering the word “Kiki” and circular shape while saying “Bouba”. Alternatively, objects with sharp edges produce high-pitched (“Kiki”-like) sounds while those with rounded edges produce low-pitched (“Bouba”-like) sounds. Repeated cross-modal experiences could enable learning this association. Here, we investigated the reason behind this effect using a series of behavioral experiments.

METHODS. We conducted four online behavioral experiments using Google Forms. Ten spiky and ten rounded shapes were created. In Experiments 1 & 2, subjects had to associate each shape to a Kiki-like or Bouba-like word. In Experiment 3 & 4, multiple audio clips were played and subjects had to associate them with either a spiky or a rounded shape. The audio clips were either (1) pronounceable Kiki & Bouba words; (2) the same words but reversed in time so that they were no longer pronouncable, but contained the same sound frequencies; (3) pure tones matched to the mean frequency of the Kiki and Bouba words; and (4) Sounds produced by natural objects when struck.

RESULTS. In the shape-validation experiment, 80% of the subjects associated spiky shapes with Kiki-like words and rounded shapes with Bouba-like words. In Experiments 3 & 4, subjects associated Bouba-like words with rounded shapes (~85%), Kiki-like words with spiky shapes(~60%), reversed Bouba words with rounded shapes (~85%), reversed Kiki words with spiky shapes (~55%), metal clanks with spiky shapes (~90%) and pillow hits with rounded shapes (~55%). There was a strong positive correlation between mean frequency of sound and the Kiki-ness of the word.

CONCLUSIONS. We conclude that the Kiki-Bouba effect reflects a robust association between shapes and sound frequency irrespective of whether the sounds can be pronounced.
coauthors: SP Arun, Indian Institute of Science Bangalore
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Representing Altruism in Multi-agent Theory of Minds
abstract: Research on multi-agent theory of minds assumes that each agent is motivated by the maximization of either their own utility, or their team's collective utility. There is a significant gap in our understanding of how to represent perceived unselfish behavior in social interactions with multiple people and objectives. We address this gap by utilizing a multi-agent theory of minds framework and three-player stag hunt game to simulate a situation where social cooperation can only be inferred from other agent's actions. In addition to normal game actions, each agent has actions that allow them to advertise and elicit social preferences.  Agents can declare their altruistic intentions towards any other agent, without committing to altruistic gameplay. To elicit social preferences, each agent has the ability to make any other agent play the dictator game. The dictator game allows the agents to signal whether they are purely self-interested, or actually altruistic at a cost to the agent. Preliminary results without the dictator game show that higher level agents are more likely to declare altruism, and that an agent's altruistic declarations had a notable effect on the inferred teams and the other agents' following actions. We aim to utilize this environment to conduct experiments with depressed and nondepressed participants, in order to better understand how depression affects the perception of social cooperation and altruism.
coauthors: Joe Blanchard, University of Minnesota; Paul Schrater, University of Minnesota
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Priming Motor Learning through Exercise in those with Cerebellar Ataxia: A Pilot Study (PRIME-ATAXIA)
abstract:
Keywords (separated by semicolons)
Cerebellar Ataxia; Motor Learning; Exercise; Neuroplasticity; Neurorehabilitation; Reliability; Feasibility

Background: 
Impairments in gait and balance are hallmark symptoms for individuals with spinocerebellar Ataxias (SCAs) and they contribute to functional limitations including fall risk and loss of independent ambulation.  Rehabilitation interventions hold great promise for improving physical function and delaying disease progression, however research specifically in SCA remains limited, especially so for remote or hybrid delivered interventions. Recent literature supports priming aerobic exercise can enhance task-specific motor performance in individuals with neurological disorders. Activation of neural circuitries following aerobic exercise may lead to downstream retention of cognitive and motor skills, and may provide a crucial link to enhancing motor performance and facilitating motor learning in individuals with SCAs. Exercise interventions are therefore optimally positioned as both a method to improve motor symptoms and slow disease progression, as well as to evaluate the responsiveness of outcome measures for use in a range of clinical trials. Establishing the feasibility of a remotely delivered motor-priming exercise intervention is crucial to support clinical trial readiness. 

Aims: 
1.To determine the reliability and responsiveness of a remotely-administered standardized clinical outcome battery in individuals with SCA.  
2.To determine the feasibility of delivering a remotely-delivered 8-week high intensity exercise intervention in individuals with SCAs. 

Methods: 
The proposed aims will be nested in a single cohort study evaluating an 8-week remotely-delivered exercise intervention for individuals with genetically-confirmed SCAs (n=20). The intervention will be delivered twice a week for 8 weeks and consist of combined 30-minute high intensity interval training (HIIT) on a recumbent stationary cycle ergometer, followed immediately by intensive, individualized 20-minute balance training. A caregiver/support person will be required for engagement in intervention sessions. Participants and their caregiver/support person will be instructed in identifying a space at home to sufficiently and safely perform tests/interventions. Participants will use FitBit Wearable Activity Monitors with heart rate capabilities as a method to evaluate exercise intensity and duration. Remotely-administered standardized outcome battery will be conducted during two baseline assessments (1 week apart), mid-intervention (week 5) and post intervention (week 8) and will include the first 4-items of the Scale for Assessment and Rating of Ataxia (SARA), Cerebellar Cognitive Assessment Scale (CCAS), Neurologic Quality of Life (NeuroQOL), Timed Up and Go Test (TUG) and measures of postural sway through a smartphone app (Encephalog, Mon4t, LLC, Binyamina, Israel). To determine the test-retest reliability of the remotely-administered standardized clinical outcome battery, we will calculate intraclass correlation coefficients as well as minimal detectable change values. To determine the responsiveness of the outcome battery, we will calculate the effect estimates comparing baseline, mid-intervention and post intervention. To determine the feasibility of delivering a high intensity exercise intervention remotely, we will evaluate the safety, retention and adherence rates.  

Results/Conclusion: Participants are currently being recruited for this study. 

Clinical Implications: This project will provide knowledge on the feasibility of measuring clinical outcomes and delivering an exercise intervention remotely while additionally developing physiological and functional biomarkers for clinical trial readiness in SCA.
coauthors: Chelsea E. Macpherson, PT, DPT, NCS (affiliation: Biobehavioral Sciences Department, EdD student in Motor Learning and Control, Teachers College, Columbia University, New York, New York, USA) ; Lori Quinn, PT, EdD (affiliation: Biobehavioral Sciences Department, EdD student in Motor Learning and Control, Teachers College, Columbia University, New York, New York, USA); Sheng-Han Kuo, MD (affiliation: Department of Neurology, Columbia University Medical Center, New York, New York, USA)
theme: Theme A: Development, Neurodegenerative Disorders and Injury

title: Data Quality metrics to improve EEG / ERP research - the Standardized Measurement Error SME
abstract:
Using EEG / ERP data allows non-invasive brain recording with high temporal precision.It is well understood that signal-to-noise ratio is key in EEG / ERP data. While removing periods with artifacts and “noisy” subjects should generally improve this signal-to-noise ratio, the nature of this improvement is often poorly quantified.

Despite this, there is no widely accepted metric of ERP data quality.

Here, we propose a concrete, reportable, auto-documented, heuristic approach for assessing data quality in averaged ERPs.

We build upon 'standard error' (SE) as a well understood measure, and formalize a specific procedure for applying SE to ERPs, called 'Standardized Measurement Error' (SME). We implement this by declaring, for a given analysis, the ERP score measure type (say, 'Mean Amplitude'), and the time window of interest (say, 300 to 400 ms). With that, 

SME(score,time_period)= std_dev(score_value) / n_valid_epochs

A higher number indicates higher ‘spread’ or higher standard error, specifically at the score measure and time period of interest. We suggest that extensive use and reporting of SME would allow better calibration of researchers in assessing data quality. We include automatic calculation, saving, and parameter reporting of SME in our ERPLAB processing toolbox.

Preprint of paper at: https://psyarxiv.com/jc3sd/
ERPLAB v8 at: https://github.com/lucklab/erplab/releases
coauthors: Prof Steven J Luck, UC Davis
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Parallel ascending spinal pathways for affective touch and pain
abstract: Each day we experience myriad somatosensory stimuli: hugs from loved ones, warm showers, a mosquito bite, and sore muscles after a workout. These tactile, thermal, itch, and nociceptive signals are detected by peripheral sensory neuron terminals distributed throughout our body, propagated into the spinal cord, and then transmitted to the brain through ascending spinal pathways. Primary sensory neurons that detect a wide range of somatosensory stimuli have been identified and characterized. In contrast, very little is known about how peripheral signals are integrated and processed within the spinal cord and conveyed to the brain to generate somatosensory perception and behavioral responses. We tackled this question by developing new mouse genetic tools to define projection neuron (PN) subsets of the anterolateral pathway, a major ascending spinal cord pathway, and combining these new tools with advanced anatomical, physiological, and behavioral approaches. We found that Gpr83+ PNs, a newly identified subset of spinal cord output neurons, and Tacr1+ PNs are largely non-overlapping populations that innervate distinct sets of subnuclei within the lateral parabrachial nucleus (PBNL) of the pons in a zonally segregated manner. In addition, Gpr83+ PNs are highly sensitive to cutaneous mechanical stimuli, receive strong synaptic inputs from primary mechanosensory neurons, and convey tactile information bilaterally to the PBNL in a non-topographically organized manner. Remarkably, Gpr83+ mechanosensory limb of the anterolateral pathway controls behaviors associated with different hedonic values (appetitive or aversive) in a scalable manner. This is the first study to identify a dedicated spinal cord output pathway that conveys affective touch signals to the brain and to define parallel ascending circuit modules that cooperate to convey tactile, thermal and noxious cutaneous signals from the spinal cord to the brain. This study has also revealed exciting new therapeutic opportunities for developing treatments for neurological disorders associated with pain and affective touch.
coauthors: Junichi Hachisuka, University of Pittsburgh; Matthew A. Brett, Harvard Medical School; Alexandra Magee, Harvard Medical School; H. Richard Koerber, University of Pittsburgh; Sarah E. Ross, University of Pittsburgh; David D. Ginty, Harvard Medical School
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: A detailed computational model of thalamic and cortical microcircuits based on inference in a generative vision model
abstract: Understanding the information processing roles of cortical circuits is an outstanding problem in neuroscience and artificial intelligence. Theory-driven efforts will be required to tease apart the functional logic of cortical circuits from the vast amounts of experimental data on cortical connectivity and physiology. Although the theoretical setting of Bayesian inference has been suggested as a framework for understanding cortical computation, making precise and falsifiable biological mappings need models that tackle the challenge of real world tasks. Based on a recent generative model, Recursive Cortical Networks, that demonstrated excellent performance on visual task benchmarks, we derive a family of anatomically instantiated and functional cortical circuit models. Efficient inference and generalization guided the representational choices in the original computational model. The cortical circuit model is derived by systematically comparing the computational requirements of this model with known anatomical constraints. The derived model suggests precise functional roles for the feed-forward, feedback, and lateral connections observed in different laminae and columns, assigns a computational role for the path through the thalamus, predicts the interactions between blobs and inter-blobs, and offers an algorithmic explanation for the innate inter-laminar connectivity between clonal neurons within a cortical column. The model also explains several visual phenomena, including the subjective contour effect, and neon-color spreading effect, with circuit-level precision. Our work paves a new path forward in understanding the logic of cortical and thalamic circuits.
coauthors: Miguel Lázaro-Gredilla, Wolfgang Lehrach, Antoine Dedieu, Guangyao Zhou
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: The auditory oddball test for larval zebrafish
abstract: The auditory oddball test is used clinically to evoke a phenomenon in EEG recordings known as mismatch negativity (MMN), in which the response to an unexpected sound (oddball) is greater than the response to an expected sound. This test is useful for investigating differences in auditory processing in developmental disorders such as autism spectrum disorder (ASD). The larval zebrafish is uniquely useful for non-invasive in vivo imaging of the whole brain at the cellular level. It therefore presents an opportunity to investigate MMN responses at the single-cell level. We used selective plane illumination microscopy to record fluorescent responses to auditory oddball stimulus trains in the brains of zebrafish larvae expressing GCamP6. Preliminary tests reveal certain populations of neurons do show elevated responses to oddball stimuli, and that pure tones are more effective for producing this effect than bands of white noise. Future tests will compare oddball responses between wildtype larvae and those carrying mutations associated with ASD.
coauthors: Rebecca Poulsen, Queensland Brain Institute; Ethan Scott, Queensland Brain Institute
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Face processing in ecologically valid scenes:  Characterizing fixation related ERPs under free-viewing conditions
abstract:
Classically, the physiological mechanisms of face perception are studied under restricted, lab-based conditions. Specifically, visual stimuli are passively presented, no eye movements are allowed, and the timing is under the control of the experimenter, not the participant. While this approach yields high experimental control over factors influencing the signal of interest, it lacks natural validity. Here, we investigate whether we can replicate the N170, a face-sensitive ERP observed in classic experiments, in a free-viewing paradigm using natural scenes.
First, we use a passive control-condition to replicate the classical N170 findings. The same participants then view images taken from a head-camera in a local shopping center under free-viewing conditions. We model our data using the unfold toolbox, which also corrects for overlap effects and co-varying non-linear dependencies on different eye movement parameters. Additionally, we extend the analysis beyond classically electrode sites and time windows by employing TFCE.
In the classic setup, we replicate the face-object N170 contrast. In the free-viewing condition, we find a similar effect, but additionally, the amplitude of the P100 is also increased when a face is fixated. Underlining the usefulness of the more natural free-viewing approach the N170 face-effect correlates between the passive and active condition (r=0.78), and the variability within the subjects is decreased under free-viewing conditions. Interestingly, when looking at fERPs assigned by the category of the previous fixation, we find more positive fERPs for fixations originating from a face, even before fixation onset. This indicates an adaptation effect when moving from one to the next fixation. This effect becomes even stronger for two consecutive fixations within a face.

In summary, we demonstrate the feasibility of an ecologically valid study of face processing, uncovering neural aspects previously remaining unnoticed.
coauthors: Benedikt V. Ehinger, Stuttgart University; Silja Timm, Osnabrück University; Peter König*, Osnabrück University; Tim C. Kietzmann,  Donders Institute for Brain, Cognition and Behaviour
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Disrupted experience-dependent place cell coding in rats heterozygous for the calcium channel gene Cacna1c
abstract:
Genome-wide association studies reveal that variants of CACNA1C, a gene encoding the α1 pore-forming subunit of the L-Type calcium channel, confer risk for psychiatric disorders across diagnostic categories. Heterozygosity for this gene in rodents has been associated with hippocampal synaptic plasticity deficits and related cognitive impairment. What is not yet known however, is how synaptic deficits disrupt neuronal and network activity to compromise behavioural function. We sought to bridge this gap by quantifying place-cell dynamics in Cacna1c heterozygous (Cacna1c+/-) rats. 
We recorded dorsal CA1 single unit and local field potential activity in adult Cacna1c+/- rats during free exploration of familiar and novel environments, and during rest. Place-fields were normal in a novel environment yet enlarged on a linear track in Cacna1c+/- rats, with an associated reduction of place-cell spatial information. During rest, despite intact sharp-wave ripple oscillations, Cacna1c+/- rats exhibited overexcitation of place-cells during ripples. In contrast, cross-correlated activity between place-cell pairs during ripples was markedly impaired. In addition, a loss of correlation between spike-timing and place-field distance between cell pairs during ripples was observed during the rest period following free exploration in Cacna1c+/- rats, indicating an impairment in ripple-associated reactivation of spatial codes.
These results point towards a deficit in the consolidation of spatial memory in Cacna1c+/- rats, possibly arising due to impairments in schaffer-collateral plasticity. Such deficits may underlie Cacna1c-associated behavioural impairments, highlighting a potential mechanism underlying cognitive dysfunction in psychiatric disease.
coauthors: Jeremy Hall, Cardiff University; Lawrence S Wilkinson, Cardiff University; Matt W. Jones, University of Bristol
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Investigating brain development and neuronal circuit assembly in primary immunodeficiency WHIM syndrome models
abstract:
Chemokine signalling is essential for coordinated cell migration in multiple tissues and processes, and it is known to govern cell positioning in both physiological and pathological context. In particular, the relevance of CxCl12/CxCr4 axis has been extensively characterized in leukocytes migration and homing as well as tumour growth and invasion. In addition, the Cxcl12/Cxcr4 system has been centrally implicated in the developmental regulation of neuronal migration, in particular of GABAergic inhibitory neurons of cerebral cortex and the cerebellum (Purkinje cells). 
WHIM syndrome is a rare form of juvenile immunodeficiency characterized by Warts, Hypogammaglobulinemia, recurrent Infections and Myelokathexis, and it is caused by autosomal dominant CXCR4 mutation, which blocks the receptor internalization after Cxcl12 stimulation inducing the persistent activation of Cxcr4. WHIM patients are susceptible to potentially life-threatening bacterial, and to a less extent, to viral infections. The immunological signs of WHIM syndrome have been extensively investigated through the well-established genetic animal model, which faithfully recapitulates the immune phenotype. In this project, we aim at characterizing the effects of Cxcr4/Cxcl12 alterations on the development of the cerebral cortex and the cerebellum by integrating cellular, molecular and behavioural analysis of WHIM model. Our preliminary data suggest that GABAergic cortical and cerebellar systems are developmentally impaired in WHIM mice, at both molecular and morphological levels, with long lasting detrimental effects on neuronal wiring and socio-motor behaviours. It is compelling that the first neuro-psychological assessment of WHIM patients correlates with our experimental in vivo results. Thus, we aim at investigating the pathological mechanisms underlying these defects, to evaluate the neuronal phenotype- for long overlooked- and, ultimately identify specific therapeutic approaches for WHIM syndrome in humans.
coauthors: Sara Mancinelli, Neuro Center, IRCCS Humanitas Clinical and Research Center, Via Manzoni 56, Rozzano-Milan, Italy;  Monica Tambalo, Neuro Center, IRCCS Humanitas Clinical and Research Center, Via Manzoni 56, Rozzano-Milan, Italy; Marco Cremonesi, Neuro Center, IRCCS Humanitas Clinical and Research Center, Via Manzoni 56, Rozzano-Milan, Italy; Antonella Borreca, Neuro Center, IRCCS Humanitas Clinical and Research Center, Via Manzoni 56, Rozzano-Milan, Italy, Institute of Neuroscience, CNR, Milan, Italy; Cindy Cardenas Neuro Center, IRCCS Humanitas Clinical and Research Center, Via Manzoni 56, Rozzano-Milan, Italy; Raffaele Badolato, Universita’ degli Studi di Brescia, Via del Mercato 15, Brescia, Italy; Roberto Rusconi, Neuro Center, IRCCS Humanitas Clinical and Research Center, Via Manzoni 56, Rozzano-Milan, Italy, Humanitas University, Via Rita Levi Montalcini 4, Pieve Emanuele, Milan; Michela Matteoli, Neuro Center, IRCCS Humanitas Clinical and Research Center, Via Manzoni 56, Rozzano-Milan, Italy, Humanitas University, Via Rita Levi Montalcini 4, Pieve Emanuele, Milan; Marinos Kallikourdis, Neuro Center, IRCCS Humanitas Clinical and Research Center, Via Manzoni 56, Rozzano-Milan, Italy, Humanitas University, Via Rita Levi Montalcini 4, Pieve Emanuele, Milan; Simona Lodato, Neuro Center, IRCCS Humanitas Clinical and Research Center, Via Manzoni 56, Rozzano-Milan, Italy, Humanitas University, Via Rita Levi Montalcini 4, Pieve Emanuele, Milan.
theme: Theme A: Development, Neurodegenerative Disorders and Injury

title: A touch circuit in the skin for social and sexual behaviour
theme: Theme B: Neural Excitability, Synapses, and Glia

title: The structure of life sciences academia
abstract: Academia has a public image that in a lot of ways has diverges with how it actually works, both presenting a better version of itself in some aspects and a worse version in others. In my talk I will discuss the observations I made and the patterns I noticed about the way life sciences academia (with the focus on neuroscience) works after 2 years of research and conversations with more than 100 people involved with life sciences academia. Topics I will cover include the sincerity and hypocrisy of academia; the relative rigidity of academic career paths; the funding asymmetry and the power asymmetry between the young and the old researchers; cooperation and competition in academia.
theme: Theme F: History, Education and Society

title: Online Replication of Age Effects in Two Variants of the Mnemonic Similarity Task
abstract:
Performance on The Mnemonic Similarity Task (MST) has been shown to be sensitive to age-related changes in medial temporal lobe function. The traditional MST has participants see a set of images during an encoding phase and then test their memory for these images in a test phase where participants must judge whether the images they are seeing are repetitions of previous images, similar images to those they saw, or completely new images. Age-related changes have been shown to relate to the ability to discriminate similar images (Lures) from previously seen images. This sensitivity has led to widespread use of the task, and several of its variants to probe age-related changes within the temporal lobes. However, whether these effects replicate in an online setting are currently unknown. 

In this study we used two online versions of the MST-Objects version (MST-O)  on an online sample of Older and Younger adults. Using both paradigms, we replicate previously reported age effects in the online setting. Specifically, and in line with lab-based studies, we see age-dependent effect on lure discrimination, while finding no such age effect on recognition abilities. Additionally, we were able to replicate a similarity-dependent effect on Lure Discrimination, where the more similar a Lure is to its original image, the less likely it is to be correctly identified, regardless of age group. We were also able to show that behavior in both tasks correlate across both online versions, showing that we are able to capture some meaningful individual differences. Both online versions of the MST-O captures similar behavior, and age-related differences to the lab-based experiments which opens up the potential for using the MST on larger and more diverse samples than are typically possible in lab-based experiments.
theme: Theme A: Development, Neurodegenerative Disorders and Injury

title: Improving brain-machine interface robustness through deep learning-based manifold alignment
abstract:
Intracortical brain-computer interfaces (iBCIs) can restore voluntary movements to people with paralysis by translating brain activity directly into the motion of an external device. A major barrier to the long-term usage of iBCIs is the inability of the algorithms, or “decoders”, that do this translation to adapt to changes in the recorded neurons over time. These changes lead to degradation in decoding accuracy and necessitate periodic supervised decoder recalibration. An emerging approach to maintain decoder robustness consists in harnessing the stable relationship that exists between behavior and the latent manifold structure that underlies the activity of populations of neurons. One recent proof of concept (Degenhart et al., 2020) used an approach based on linear manifold discovery (Factor Analysis; FA). It achieved stable closed-loop BCI control over five days without recalibration. However, nonlinear manifold discovery methods produce estimates of manifold structure that are more informative about movement intention on a moment-by-moment basis. Thus, we aimed to develop a platform for nonlinear manifold alignment decoding (NoMAD) to achieve higher performing and stable BCIs.

NoMAD incorporates latent factor analysis via dynamical systems (LFADS), a deep learning approach that uncovers manifold structure by modeling the shared dynamics underlying population activity. NoMAD combines LFADS with unsupervised distribution alignment (Farshchian et al., 2019; Dyer et al., 2017) to produce consistent manifold estimates in the face of changing recorded neurons. We tested NoMAD in an offline analysis of motor cortical activity from a monkey performing an isometric wrist force task throughout 21 sessions spanning more than three months. NoMAD allowed stable, high performance decoding of the monkey’s force over all sessions without supervised recalibration. NoMAD’s force-decoding performance typically ranged from 0.85-0.90 R2, with all sessions exceeding 0.75. In comparison, FA-based stabilization achieved a median of only 0.45 R2, with significant performance fluctuations between sessions. Thus by combining accurate, nonlinear manifold discovery with the stability conferred by manifold alignment, NoMAD enables higher-performing and stable BCIs with greater suitability for real-world application.
coauthors: Lahiru Wimalasena, Emory University & Georgia Tech; Mohammad Reza Keshtkaran, Emory University & Georgia Tech; Yahia Ali, Emory University & Georgia Tech; Andrew Sedler, Georgia Tech; Ali Farschian, Northwestern University; Josie Walner, Northwestern University; Xuan Ma, Northwestern University; Ben Semel, Northwestern University; Kevin Bodkin, Northwestern University; Lee Miller, Northwestern University; Chethan Pandarinath, Emory University & Georgia Tech
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Dynamic analysis of eye-head movements for estimating visuo-cognitive demands during driving
abstract:
Driving is a complex activity involving visuo-cognitive processes and failure to meet visual and/or cognitive needs can potentially affect drivers’ safety. Previous studies have shown that eye and head movements contribute to attention reallocation and they are both modulated by visuo-cognitive demands (Doshi et al., 2012; Fang et al., 2015). This study seeks to investigate the effect of visual degradation and increased cognitive demands on drivers’ eye-head movements and their ability to maneuver a vehicle in a driving simulator.
Twenty-one participants (21-34 years old) completed a driving task in which they were asked to maintain their speed constant while doing a concurrent visual task. Every participant performed the experiment with normal vision and with contact lenses inducing a visual degradation. Parameters such as speed and car lateral position were measured in the driving simulator; eye and head movements were recorded through motion capture. Visual exploration was analyzed using spatial and dynamic parameters.
Our results revealed that driving speed, but not car lateral position, was affected by visuo-cognitive demands (p < 0.05). Spatio-temporal parameters typically used to describe visual exploration (i.e. fixation duration, gaze position along horizontal and vertical axes) were not modulated by the visual degradation (all p > 0.05). In contrast, entropy showed that visual scanning was less explorative (p < 0.05) and participants recruited more head movements for horizontal gaze shifts (p = 0.03) when vision was degraded.
In conclusion, we showed that participants’ ability to maneuvering a vehicle while engaged in a secondary task remains relatively intact when vision is not optimal. We also provided evidence that eye-head movements and dynamic visual exploration are sensitive to the quality of vision and could be used as potential indicators of visuo-cognitive demands in more naturalistic tasks, such as driving.
coauthors: Sergio Mejía-Romero, Université de Montréal; Romain Chaumillon, Université de Montréal; Amigale Patoine, Université de Montréal; Eduardo Lugo, Université de Montréal; Delphine Bernardin Université de Montréal, Essilor International; Jocelyn Faubert Université de Montréal
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Enhanced or impoverished recruitment of top-down attentional control of inhibition in test anxiety
abstract: Existing evidence shows that test anxiety impairs individuals’ inhibition. However, controversy exits as to whether a high test anxiety (HTA) individual, when completing an experimental task, increases or decreases top-down attentional control resources to maintain (high) task performance. To fill the gap, the present study examined whether a HTA individual will increase or decrease recruitment of top-down attentional control resources to complete inhibition task. In this flanker task experiment, individuals were confronted with a threat or no threat context in combination with a low or a high working memory load. Electroencephalography (EEG) data were collected and the Event Related Potential (ERP) N2 measured top-down attentional control resource allocation. The EEG results showed three crucial significant differences: in comparison to low test anxiety (LTA) individuals: (1) in a no threat and low working memory load condition, HTA individuals had larger incongruent N2 amplitudes; (2) in a no threat and high working memory load condition, HTA individuals had larger incongruent and congruent N2 amplitudes; and (3) in a threat and high working memory load condition, HTA individuals had smaller incongruent N2 amplitudes. This significance pattern: (1) clarifies the neural mechanism underlying the frontal lobe’s involvement in the processing of an inhibition task; (2) supports the idea that, in order to maintain (high) task performance, HTA individuals tend to engage in enhanced recruitment of top-down attentional control of inhibition; but also shows that (3) in case of a threat coinciding with a high working memory load, HTA individuals fail to employ this compensatory strategy as they display impoverished top-down attentional control of inhibition.
coauthors: Hua Wei,Southeast University;  Renlai Zhou,Southeast University
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: EEG Delta Rhythms in Visual Association Cortices Mark Syntactic Constituents
abstract: Recent work has suggested that syntactic processes may be indexed neurologically via amplitude changes in EEG delta oscillations (1-4Hz). However, these observations have been primarily limited to the frequency domain, and little is known of how delta oscillations are modulated in real-time while syntactic processes are performed. In the present study, we used time-frequency analysis to characterize delta responses at constituent boundaries in sentences with a fixed grammatical pattern in contrast to lexically-matched scrambled lists with no obvious syntactic structure. We also sought to identify whether delta activity is modulated by lexico-semantic content. To do this, we included two additional sentence types: Jabberwocky sentences with identical morpho-syntax to grammatical sentence stimuli but where all content words were replaced by nonsense words and a scrambled version of these sentences. Analyses were conducted on the basis of structure (English + Nonsense sentences with grammar vs. English + Nonsense sentences scrambled) and lexico-semantic content (English with Grammar + English scrambled vs. Nonsense with Grammar + Nonsense scrambled). Results of time-frequency analysis revealed no effect of lexico-semantic content; however, higher delta power was observed at constituent boundaries for sentences with grammatical structure relative to word-lists. Post-hoc source analyses identified left-fusiform gyrus as the primary generator of this difference. The fusiform gyrus has been suggested as an interface between the sensory and conceptual systems in order to facilitate efficient visual processing, and as such, it is frequently activated during reading tasks like the one used in the present study. Considering this, we argue that delta oscillations emanating from the fusiform gyrus may reflect the integration of visual information with top-down knowledge of syntactic structure.
coauthors: Devin M. Casenhiser
institution: University of Tennessee Health Science Center (grid.267301.1)
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Constrained brain volume in an efficient coding model explains the fraction of excitatory and inhibitory neurons in sensory cortices
abstract: The number of neurons in mammalian cortex varies by multiple orders of magnitude across different species. In contrast, the ratio of excitatory to inhibitory neurons (E:I ratio) varies in a much smaller range, from 3:1 to 9:1 and remains roughly constant for different sensory areas within a species. Despite this structure being important for understanding the function of neural circuits, the reason for this consistency is not yet understood. While recent models of vision based on the efficient coding hypothesis show that increasing the number of both excitatory and inhibitory cells improves stimulus representation, the two cannot increase simultaneously due to constraints on brain volume. In this work, we implement an efficient coding model of vision under a volume (i.e., total number of neurons) constraint while varying the E:I ratio. We show that the performance of the model is optimal at biologically observed E:I ratios under several metrics. We argue that this happens due to trade-offs between the computational accuracy and the representation capacity for natural stimuli. Further, we make experimentally testable predictions that 1) the optimal E:I ratio should be higher for species with a higher sparsity in the neural activity and 2) the character of inhibitory synaptic distributions and firing rates should change depending on E:I ratio. Our findings, which are supported by our new preliminary analyses of publicly available data, provide the first quantitative and testable hypothesis based on optimal coding models for the distribution of neural types in the mammalian sensory cortices.
coauthors: Ilya Nemenman, Emory University; Christopher Rozell, Georgia Institute of Technology
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Related Neural Networks Underlie Suppression of Emotion, Memory, Motor Processes as Identified by Data-Driven Analysis
abstract: Goal-directed behavior benefits from self-regulation of cognitive and affective processes, such as emotional reactivity, memory retrieval, and prepotent motor response. Dysfunction in self-regulation is a common characteristic of many psychiatric disorders, such as PTSD and ADHD. This study sought to determine whether common neural regions are involved in the regulation of emotion, motor, and memory, and if a data-driven approach using independent components analysis (ICA) would successfully identify intrinsic connectivity networks (ICNs) that contribute to inhibitory regulation. Eighteen participants underwent neuroimaging while completing an emotion regulation (ER) task, a memory suppression (think/no-think; TNT) task, and a motor inhibition (stop signal; SS) task. In the ER task, participants were presented with negatively valenced pictures and instructed to either feel or inhibit their emotions. In the TNT task, participants received training to remember face-picture (cue-target) pairs. Participants were then presented with only the cue and told to either recall the picture or try to block its retrieval. In the SS task, participants were presented with either a stop- or go-signal and instructed to press a button only at the go-signal – not before the go-signal or at the stop-signal. ICA (CONN; MATLAB) was conducted on the neuroimaging data. Corresponding components were selected across task based on interrelated patterns of activation. Subsequently, ICNs were correlated with behavioral variables. ICA indicated a common medial prefrontal network, striatal network, and frontoparietal executive control network, as well as down-regulation in task-specific ROIs. These results illustrate that overlapping ICNs were exhibited across three distinct inhibitory regulation tasks as successfully identified through a data-driven approach (ICA).
coauthors: Lindsay K. Knight, INSIGHTEC; Brendan E. Depue, University of Louisville
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Delayed maturation of input plasticity at lateral perforant path synapses onto adult-born dentate granule neurons.
abstract: In the mammalian brain, the dentate gyrus of the hippocampus uniquely generates new neurons throughout the lifetime of the animal. Adult-born granule cells undergo a period of maturation during which their membranes are more excitable and inputs from medial perforant path neurons can more easily induce long-term potentiation of synaptic responses. This previously described “critical window” exists between approximately four- and six-weeks of cell age. Whether signaling from the other major cortical input to the dentate gyrus—the lateral perforant path—undergoes the same timecourse of maturation remains unknown. We measured synaptic responses to lateral perforant path stimulation on adult-born granule cells between three- and thirty-weeks old. Surprisingly, we find that long-term potentiation of synaptic responses matures over an extended timecourse, with a peak at around 15-weeks of cell age. Cells between 4- and 6- weeks of age are more likely to experience long-term depression of lateral perforant path inputs than are older cells. We find that facilitation of transmitter release increases over a similar timecourse as long-term potentiation, and that the magnitude of the reduction of facilitation after induction of long-term potentiation predicts the magnitude of that potentiation. These data suggest that an increase in presynaptic release probability at lateral perforant path synapses is the major mechanism of long-term potentiation, and that this plasticity is more prominent at inputs onto older neurons.
coauthors: Jason Snyder, University of British Columbia
theme: Theme A: Development, Neurodegenerative Disorders and Injury

title: Behavioral models of visual working memory do not generalize to the whole-report paradigm
abstract: Many prominent behavioral models of visual working memory have been both motivated and validated by results from "single-report" change-detection and delayed estimation tasks. Recently, a new "whole-report" paradigm was introduced to address shortcomings with these canonical tasks, and to support claims about fundamental properties of visual working memory. However, it is unclear how well results from the relatively complex whole-report paradigm generalize to simpler tasks (and vice versa). Here, we use an existing whole-report dataset to show that participant responses exhibit statistical dependencies between simultaneously-presented stimuli that cannot be accounted for by an entire class of models that assumes independent encoding. We then fit several hierarchical encoding models (proposed to capture dependencies between stimuli) to the data, and find that this model class is also unable to account for whole-report behavior. Finally, we compare response distributions between stimulus types, and find that the dependencies exhibited when reporting hue are not present when reporting orientation, despite very similar overall task performance. Rather than proposing a model to capture behavior across all task paradigms, we suggest that this failure to generalize is the result of model mis-specification. We argue that some visual working memory models would be better conceptualized as models of change-detection or delayed estimation performance, and that more care should be taken when integrating results across stimulus modalities and behavioral paradigms into a single, unified theory.
coauthors: Dominic Standage, Queen's University, Martin Paré, Queen's University, Gunnar Blohm, Queen's University
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Optimizing detailed L5 pyramidal tract cell models in the rodent motor cortex to predict in vivo microcircuit function
abstract:
Detailed biophysical modeling techniques are beginning to be used in conjunction with anatomical, biophysical, and extracellular multi-electrode recordings to shed light on cellular functioning in vivo (e.g., Egger et al., 2020). However, biophysical single cell models of neurons are typically constrained by in vitro data. These properties are impacted by factors such as cellular morphology, variations in extrinsic inputs received by up to 10K synapses, and the neuromodulatory state. In contrast, in vitro the synaptic inputs (random neurotransmitter release or pre-synaptic AP firing) that affect membrane potential and input resistance are much less pronounced. Thus, our picture of the cell’s in vivo characteristics is incomplete. We attempt to bridge this gap by developing a detailed biophysical model constrained by in vivo data. 
We report the development of a morphologically realistic biophysical model of an L5 pyramidal tract neuron in the rodent primary motor cortex with active channels in the dendrites, including Nat, Ca, SK, Im, Ih, and a dense Ca2+ rich region at the base of the apical tuft. The model is used to conduct parametric studies to probe the effect that synaptic conductances, afferent firing rates, coherence of afferent spike times, and dendritic attenuation have on the baseline firing rate of the neuron. The single cell model will then be inserted into a network model of the motor cortex for investigating computations in motor cortex circuits during a voluntary reaching task.
coauthors: Adin Aberbach, University of Missouri; Drew B. Headley, Rutgers University; Satish S. Nair, University of Missouri
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Efficient coding in auditory cortex determines target detection behavior
abstract: Sensory systems are composed of neurons with limited dynamic range, but are required to accurately represent a world in which the dynamic range of incoming stimuli can vary wildly. To efficiently encode acoustic environments with different dynamic ranges (referred to here as contrast), neurons in auditory cortex (AC) adapt the gain of their response function to effectively match their dynamic range to that of the environment. However, it is not known whether these widespread changes in neural sensitivity have an impact on auditory percepts. To test this, we trained mice to detect auditory targets in backgrounds of different contrasts, and find that, 1) target detection and sensitivity were improved in low contrast, and, 2) the time-course of target detectability varied depending on contrast, decreasing rapidly after a transition to high contrast, and increasing at a slower rate after a transition to low contrast. These patterns of target detectability are recapitulated in populations of AC neurons simultaneously recorded with behavior and the magnitude of gain modulation in cortical neurons predicts behavioral performance of individual mice. Consistent with these results, a normative model in which neurons efficiently adapt their gain to optimize stimulus reconstruction also exhibits detection performance in line with our behavioral and neural results. Together, these results demonstrate that efficient neural codes in auditory cortex directly influence behavioral percepts.
coauthors: Chris Angeloni, University of Pennsylvania; Wiktor Mlynarski, IST Austria; Katherine Wood, University of Pennsylvania; Linda Garami, University of Pennsylvania; Anne Hermundstadt, Janelia HHMI; Maria Geffen, University of Pennsylvania
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Molecular pathways of glucocorticoids effects on neurodevelopment
abstract: The brain undergoes rapid growth and maturation during the prenatal period, thus it is highly susceptible to environmental stimuli. During this period increased glucocorticoid exposure of the embryo has been associated with adverse neurobehavioral, e.g. increased attention deficits, and physiological outcomes, e.g. brain structural and functional changes, later in life. Glucocorticoids are one of the main factors mediating stress effects prenatally and one of the main systems found dysregulated in stress-related psychiatric disorders. To investigate these processes in a human specific and reactive system, we used induced Pluripotent Stem Cells-derived 3-dimensional cerebral organoids to model prenatally mediated risk and response to stress and combined them with in vivo mouse models of neurodevelopment. We found a very promising candidate gene for neurodevelopmentally-relevant glucocorticoids response in ZBTB16, which had previously been shown to respond to glucocorticoids in human blood samples.  ZBTB16 is a transcription factor expressed during early development associated with maintenance of the neuronal progenitor pool. ZBTB16 is expressed dynamically throughout human neurodevelopment with high expression in the progenitor cells (PAX6+ cells) early on and downregulation when the first neuronal markers (MAP2, DCX) appear. Chronic dexamethasone exposure (100nM) of organoids for 7 days results in a robust increase of ZBTB16 expression in the progenitor cells. We used in utero electroporations in mice at different developmental time-points and ex vivo electroporations in human cerebral organoids to overexpress ZBTB16, mimicking the effect of glucocorticoids on the transcription factor. Overexpression of ZBTBT16 leads to increased time of proliferation of progenitor cells (PH3+cells) and increased neurogenic divisions of the intermediate progenitor cells (TBR2+ cells). We are working on the molecular signalling pathway of glucocorticoids through ZBTB16 using a ChIP-seq experiment for ZBTB16 in cerebral organoids. We identified ZBTB16 as a mediator of altered neuronal differentiation processes after glucocorticoids stimulation. The molecular mechanisms and pathways we shed light on in this work could have profound implications for our understanding risk to stress exposure during early brain development, and consequently psychopathology vulnerability.
coauthors: Anthi C. Krontira, 1Department of Translational Research in Psychiatry, Max Planck Institute of Psychiatry, Germany and International Max Planck Research School for Translational Psychiatry, Max Planck Institute of Psychiatry, Germany ; Cristiana Cruceanu, 1Department of Translational Research in Psychiatry, Max Planck Institute of Psychiatry, Germany ; Christina Kyrousi, 3Research group of Developmental Neurobiology, Max Planck Institute of Psychiatry, Germany ; Silvia Cappello, 3Research group of Developmental Neurobiology, Max Planck Institute of Psychiatry, Germany ; Elisabeth B. Binder, Department of Translational Research in Psychiatry, Max Planck Institute of Psychiatry, Munich, Germany
theme: Theme A: Development, Neurodegenerative Disorders and Injury

title: Direct brain recordings reveal occipital cortex involvement in memory development
abstract: Processing of low-level visual information shows robust developmental gains through childhood and adolescence. However, it is unknown whether low-level visual processing in the occipital cortex supports age-related gains in memory for complex visual stimuli. Here, we examined occipital alpha activity during visual scene encoding in 24 children and adolescents, aged 6.2–20.5 years, who performed a subsequent memory task while undergoing electrocorticographic recording. Scenes were classified as high- or low-complexity by the number of unique object categories depicted. We found that recognition of high-complexity, but not low-complexity, scenes increased with age. Age was associated with decreased alpha power and increased instantaneous alpha frequency during the encoding of subsequently recognized high- compared to low-complexity scenes. Critically, decreased alpha power predicted improved recognition of high-complexity scenes in adolescents. These findings demonstrate how the functional maturation of the occipital cortex supports the development of memory for complex visual scenes.
coauthors: Elizabeth L. Johnson, Wayne State University, University of California, Berkeley; Lingfei Tang, Wayne State University; Kurtis I. Auguste, University of California, San Francisco, Children’s Hospital and Research Center, Oakland; Robert T. Knight, University of California, Berkeley; Eishi Asano, Children’s Hospital of Michigan, Wayne State University; Noa Ofen, Wayne State University
theme: Theme A: Development, Neurodegenerative Disorders and Injury

title: Amplified representation of sound termination in the auditory cortex and its behavioral relevance
abstract:
Offset responses in auditory processing appear after a sound terminates. In the peripheral auditory system, neuronal circuits within the cochlear and superior paraolivary nuclei play a central role in generating offset responses. In the central auditory system, a recent study showed that neurons in the anterior auditory field (AAF) have significantly stronger responses to sound termination than those in the primary auditory cortex. The mechanisms that generate and drive offset responses within AAF as well as their behavioural relevance remain unknown.
To understand the role of AAF offset responses in sound perception, we asked whether detecting the end of a sound would be influenced by them. Using optogenetics, we showed that preventing AAF offset responses decreases the mouse performance to detect sound termination. 
Next, we combined electrophysiological recordings in auditory cortex and thalamus of awake mice with antidromic stimulation to better understand how cortical offset responses occur. We found that more than 80% of AAF inputs come from onset-offset responsive thalamic cells, indicating that a big portion of information on sound termination in AAF is inherited from the preceding nuclei. However, our results also demonstrate that cortical offset responses are amplified in comparison to the thalamic ones. 
Overall, our results reveal the importance of cortical offset responses in coding and perceiving sound termination. They might play a crucial role for advanced processing such as detecting changes within temporally discontinuous sounds.
coauthors: Tania Rinaldi Barkat, Brain & Sound Lab, Department of Biomedicine, Basel University, 4056 Basel, Switzerland
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Sensory processing in autism - Translational markers and circuit-level insights
abstract:
Atypical sensory experience is estimated to occur in as many as 90% of autistic individuals and to affect every sensory modality: taste, touch, audition, olfaction and vision. Because the neural computations underlying sensory processing are relatively well understood in typically developing individuals and are relatively conserved between humans and other animals, sensory paradigms have considerable potential for shedding light on autistic neurobiology. But are sensory traits, in fact, core phenotypic markers of autism? In this talk, I will argue that the answer is “yes” [1]. The evidence I review shows that the autistic cortex is affected by distinct, low-level changes in neural circuitry that is dedicated to perceptual processing (including primary sensory areas). Further, perceptual symptoms in individuals with autism are evident early in development, account for independent variance in diagnostic criteria of the condition, and show a persistent relationship to clinical measures of higher-order social cognition and behavior. Finally, I will present data from a recent line of work in my laboratory using behavioral, neuroimaging, pharmacological techniques to identify a marker of autism in low-level visual processing, which has provided concrete insight into the neurobiology of autism in humans [2-4].

-
[1] Robertson and Baron-Cohen (2017), Sensory Perception in Autism, Nature
Reviews Neuroscience.

[2] Robertson, C. E., Ratai, E. M. & Kanwisher, N. (2016). Reduced GABAergic
action in the autistic brain. Curr. Biol. 26, 80–85.

[3] Mentch, Spiegel, Ricciardi, Robertson. 2019. GABAergic Inhibition Gates Perceptual Awareness During Binocular Rivalry. J Neurosci. 39(42) 8398-8407.		

[4] Spiegel, Mentch, Robertson. 2019. Slower Rate of Binocular Rivalry in the Autistic Brain. Curr. Biol. 29, 1-6.
theme: Theme A: Development, Neurodegenerative Disorders and Injury

title: Vox2Vox: 3D-GAN for Brain Tumour Segmentation
abstract: Gliomas are the most common primary brain malignancies, with different degrees of aggressiveness, variable prognosis and various heterogeneous histological sub-regions, i.e., peritumoral edema, necrotic core, enhancing and non-enhancing tumor core. The treatment depends on the location and size of the tumour(s). Although both these brain tumour types can easily be detected using multi-modal MRI, to extract them using image segmentation is a challenging task. To perform manual segmentation can take 20 - 60 minutes for a single subject, and automatic brain tumor segmentation can save a lot of time for neuro radiologists. Hence, using the data provided by the BraTS Challenge 2020, we propose a 3D volume-to-volume Generative Adversarial Network for segmentation of brain tumours. The model, called Vox2Vox, generates realistic segmentation outputs from multi-channel 3D MR images, detecting the whole, core and enhancing tumor with median values of 93.39\%, 92.50\%, and 87.16\% as dice scores and 2.44mm, 2.23mm, and 1.73mm for Hausdorff distance 95 percentile for the training dataset, and 91.75\%, 88.13\%, and 85.87\% and 3.0mm, 3.74mm, and 2.23mm for the validation dataset, after ensembling 10 Vox2Vox models obtained with a 10-fold cross-validation. We decided to report median metric values because in these way dataset outliers are not taken into consideration, showing in this way a properer model performance on these two datasets.
coauthors: David Abramian, Department of Biomedical Engineering at Linköping University, Center for Medical Image Science and Visualization at Linköping University; Anders Eklund, Department of Biomedical Engineering at Linköping University, Center for Medical Image Science and Visualization at Linköping University
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Early sharp waves in the neonatal hippocampus
theme: Theme A: Development, Neurodegenerative Disorders and Injury

title: A deep generative modelling approach to detect epileptogenic lesions
abstract:
Purpose: Focal cortical dysplasias (FCDs) may be easily overlooked in conventional visual assessment of MRI. Automated approaches have been proven useful for the detection of FCDs and their use may enhance the postoperative outcome. However, as even most elaborate approaches do not yield satisfactory sensitivity, the development of novel approaches is warranted on clinical grounds. MRI features of FCD type IIb include cortical T2-signal hyperintensities but have sparse correlates in T1-weighted MR-volumes. We here describe an approach leveraging on this apparent difference in MR-modalities and the power of conditional generative adversarial networks (cGAN) in modality synthesis, by creating a difference image between the real FLAIR and a T1-based synthetic FLAIR mimicking healthy brain structures. We show that the integration of this information in a convolutional neural network (CNN) supports the automatized detection of FCDs.

Methods: We retrospectively collected and manually labelled T1w and FLAIR images of 42 patients (18 females; age=38.8±11.4 y) with an FCD type IIb. T1w images served as input for our cGAN, pre-trained on 80 datasets of healthy controls (37 females; age=44.8±10.6 y), to synthesize artificial FLAIR images. Real and synthetic FLAIR images were in turn subtracted. T1w, FLAIR and the difference images were passed to a multi-scale 3D CNN. Specificity was assessed on a separate cohort of 56 mesial temporal lobe epilepsy patients (35 females; age=39.2±11.5).

Results: The cGAN showed robust generation of synthetic FLAIR images on non-lesional brains (SSIM±σ = 0.92±0.04). Employing a five-fold cross-validation scheme, our CNN-classifier reached a sensitivity of 92.9% (39/42 FCDs detected), while maintaining a high specificity of 96.4% (54/56 true negatives).
