Conclusion: Our combined deep learning approach using a cGAN for modality synthesis followed by a CNN outperforms current state-of-the-art methods. Moreover, it is conceivable that our approach may generalize to any other pathology imaged with complementary imaging modalities.
coauthors: Leonie Henschel, German Center for Neurodegenerative Diseases (DZNE); Sailesh Conjeti, German Center for Neurodegenerative Diseases (DZNE); Fabiane Schuch, Department of Epileptology, University Hospital Bonn; Bernd Weber, Department of Epileptology, University Hospital Bonn; Elke Hatingen, Department of Neuroradiology, Goethe University Frankfurt; Christian Elger, Department of Epileptology, University Hospital Bonn; Martin Reuter, German Center for Neurodegenerative Diseases (DZNE), Martinos Center for Biomedical Imaging, Radiology, MGH / Harvard Medical School; Rainer Surges, Department of Epileptology, University Hospital Bonn; Theodor Rüber, Department of Epileptology, University Hospital Bonn, Epilepsy Center Frankfurt Rhine-Main, Department of Neurology, Goethe University Frankfurt, Center for Personalized Translational Epilepsy Research (CePTER), Goethe- University Frankfurt
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: A Gaussian Noise Neural Channel Modulated the Functional Connectivity
abstract:
Information transfer among brain regions is the fundamental intelligence computing in the primate brain. The local and global topology connectivity among functional brain regions directly driven human cognitive behaviors. The real neural signal includes the real neural firing and neural self-noise. Neural self-noise non-regular firing or synchronization will cause severe neuron disease and it also plays a very important role in the functional connectivity. Therefore, how the neural self-noise affect the information flow among brain regions? Firstly, Phase Locking Value(PLV) can investigate task-induced neural synchronization from the EEG signal [1]. Secondly, Shannon’s information theory and its extensions framework can be used to quantitative the maximum information capacity in the noise neural channel. The basic idea is 1) simulation: the fake neural signal (EEG) produced by setting certain time points, number of subjects, and number trials with neural self-noise. The amplitude of neural signals can be changed according to given parameters. 2) Phase Locking Value (PLV) measured among brain regions with setting different parameters of time series. 3) redundancy measured among brain regions with Total Correlation (TC)/Multivariate Mutual Information. [2] 4) Compared different measure results and check how the neural self-noise affects the information flow in the brain. The result shown 1) neural-self noise directly affect functional connectivity among brain regions (increase neuron self-noise will reduce PLV and TC) 2) TC has stronger statistical power than PLV in the quantitative functional connectivity

Appendix:
The Matlab demo used in this short research can get from here: https://github.com/sinodanish/NeuroMatch3.0

References:
[1] Lachaux, Jean‐Philippe, et al. “Measuring phase synchrony in brain signals.” Human brain mapping 8.4 (1999): 194-208. 
[2] Watanabe, S.  Information theoretical analysis of multivariate correlation.IBM Journal of research anddevelopment1960,4, 66–82.
coauthors: Qiang Li, University of Valencia;
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Task state reactivation during aversive learning and avoidance
abstract: Many symptoms of mood and anxiety disorders are associated with simulation of potential aversive outcomes. However, the fundamental computational and neural mechanisms that might support this phenomenon remain unknown. In this study, we sought to identify neural mechanisms supporting task state reactivation as a potential mechanism that might underlie these symptoms. Subjects completed an task that involved navigating through a maze of unique task states during MEG scanning. Critically, some states were probabilistically associated with electric shock, and subjects were required to use their knowledge of the task state space to successfully avoid shock. Behaviourally, subjects used model-based inference to successfully avoid shock, and at a neural level this was linked to reactivation of subsequently chosen goal states during planning. Following outcome receipt, we observed reactivation of the unchosen goal state, potentially facilitating counterfactual updating. Finally, we found that reactivation strength was linked to activity in the medial temporal lobe, suggesting that regions such as the hippocampus might support this process. These results indicate that the brain simulates potential outcomes of hypothetical actions during avoidance, providing a candidate mechanism in which dysfunction might lead to symptoms of mood and anxiety disorders.
coauthors: Yunzhe Liu;Fatima Chowdhury;Raymond J Dolan
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Is motherhood a moderator of empathy for pain? An fMRI study
abstract: Social competencies such as empathy and understanding others’ minds are vital for parents towards successful parenting. They not only allow adequate reactions to a child’s needs but since parents are important role models, they are also passed on to the children (Kluczniok et al. 2016). To date, little is known about the modulating effect of motherhood on social understanding and specifically on the understanding of a child’s mind versus an adult’s mind. In this study, we used functional Magnetic Resonance Imaging (fMRI) to investigate empathy for pain in mothers and women without children. Our task used both adult and children as protagonists in the stimulus material. Women were recruited that were either i) mothers of one child between 4 and 10 years old (corresponding to the age of the children in the stimulus material), or ii) had no children and also did not interact with them on a regular basis. Univariate analyses of our neuroimaging data show significant differences between the conditions empathy with a child versus empathy with an adult in the left SMG. Additionally, mothers and women without children show significantly different activation patterns with stronger activation in the bilateral anterior insula when asked to imagine people in painful scenarios while viewing pictures showing these scenarios. This hints at differences in strategies in reacting to people in painful situations with mothers recruiting more strongly those areas traditionally related to empathy. Successful classification based on both motherhood and protagonist of the stimuli strengthens these findings.
coauthors: Hindi Attar; Dziobek; Bermpohl
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Neural Signature of Subjective Confidence in Perceptual Decision Making
abstract:
Drift diffusion models propose that decisions are formed by continuously accumulating sensory information. Once the accumulated evidence reaches a boundary, a decision is made. Stronger evidence is accumulated faster and reaches the decision boundary quicker. According to some proposals, confidence in the accuracy of a decision depends on the same accumulated evidence underlying the choice. The central parietal positivity (CPP) component of the human event-related potential (ERP) has been demonstrated to encode accumulated evidence for a decision, like the ramping activity found in the parietal cortex of monkeys during evidence accumulation. As the buildup rate of the CPP indicates how quickly evidence is accumulated, it would be reasonable to expect that the CPP indexes confidence. In this study, we examined how evidence strength influences subjective reports of confidence in observers’ perceptual decisions and how the CPP changes with different levels of evidence strength and confidence. Electroencephalographic (EEG) recordings were measured while participants (n=25) performed a two-alternative dot-motion discrimination task with six motion coherence levels. Consistent with previous research, we found that the buildup rate of the CPP increased with stronger evidence and faster responses, indicating the build-to-bound dynamic of a decision variable. More interestingly, the buildup rate scaled with the confidence rating on the decision, suggesting that evidence accumulation in the brain (i.e. CPP) is tightly linked to the subjective perceptual experience of the sensory information favoring the decision. Further analysis showed that the response-aligned CPP ramped up faster for higher confidence when holding motion coherence constant. We conclude that, independent of the influence of objective evidence strength, 
CPP reflects subjective confidence.
coauthors: Jason Samaha
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Computation noise promotes cognitive resilience to adverse conditions in humans and recurrent networks
abstract: Random noise in information processing systems is widely seen as detrimental to function. But despite the large trial-to-trial variability of neural activity, humans show a remarkable adaptability to unexpected adverse events during goal-directed behavior. The origin of this cognitive ability, described as constitutive of general intelligence, is still disputed. In this talk, I will show that implementing computation noise in recurrent neural networks boosts their cognitive resilience to a variety of adverse events entirely unseen during training, in a way that strikingly resembles human cognition in similar conditions. In contrast to neural networks featuring exact computations, noisy networks and humans acquire behavioral hallmarks of Bayesian inference in a ‘zero-shot’ fashion – without prior experience with conditions that require these computations for maximizing rewards. These findings suggest that human intelligence may ride on computation noise to promote near-optimal behavior in adverse conditions without any engineered cognitive sophistication.
coauthors: Charles Findling, École Normale Supérieure
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Rhythmic synchronous features in cortical neurons of songbirds
abstract: How vocal communication signals are represented in the cortex is a major challenge for behavioral neuroscience. Beyond a descriptive code, it is relevant to unveil the dynamical mechanism responsible for the neural representation of auditory stimuli. In this work, we report evidence of synchronous neural activity in cortical neurons of canaries (Serinus canaria), in response to auditory playback of the bird’s own song. The rhythmic features of canary  song allowed us to show that this synchronization was locked to syllabic repetition rates of song phrases. We recorded neurons in a brain region where sensorimotor integration occurs, showing that these neurons are activated at specific temporal instances during song playback.
coauthors: Gabriel B. Mindlin, University of Buenos Aires; Ana Amador, University of Buenos Aires
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Blaming blunders on the brain: can indifferent choices be driven by range adaptation or synaptic plasticity?
abstract: Computational  investigations  of  learning  and  decision  making suggestthat systematic  deviations  to adaptive  behavior  may  be  the  incidental  outcome  of biological  constraints imposed  on  neural informationprocessing.   In   particular,   recent   studies   indicate   that   range   adaptation,   i.e.,the mechanism by which neurons dynamically tune their output firing properties to match the changing statistics of their inputs, may drive plastic changes in the brain’s decision system that induce systematic deviations  to  rationality.  Here,  we  ask  whether  behaviorally-relevant  neural  information  processing may  be  distorted  by  other incidental, hard-wired,biological  constraints,  in  particular:  Hebbian plasticity. One of our main contributionsis to propose a simple computational method for identifying (and comparing) the neural signature of such biological mechanisms or constraints. Using ANNs (i.e., artificial neural network models) and RSA (i.e.,representational similarity analysis), we compare the neural  signatures  of  two  types  of  hard-wired  biological  mechanisms/constraints:  namely,  range adaptation  and Hebbian  plasticity.  We  apply  the  approach totwo  different open fMRI  datasets acquired  when  people  make  decisions  under  risk.  In  both  cases,  we  show  that  although peoples' apparentindifferent choicesarewell explainedby  biologically-constrained  ANNs,  choice  data  alone does  not  discriminate  between  range  adaptation  and  Hebbian  plasticity.  However,  RSA shows  that neural  activity  patterns in  bilateral Striatum  and Amygdala are  more  compatible  withHebbian plasticity.  Finally,  the  strength  of  evidence forHebbian  plasticity  in  these  structures  predicts  inter-individual differences in choice inconsistency.
coauthors: Jean Daunizeau, Institut du Cerveau et de la Moelle Épinière
institution: Institut du Cerveau et de la Moelle Épinière (grid.425274.2)
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Role of Path Information in Visual Perception of Joint Stiffness
abstract: Humans have an astonishing ability to extract hidden information from the movement of others. In previous work, subjects observed the motion of a simulated stick-figure, two-link planar arm and estimated its stiffness. Fundamentally, stiffness is the relation between force and displacement. Given that subjects were unable to physically interact with the simulated arm, they were forced to make their estimates solely based on observed kinematic information. Remarkably, subjects were able to correctly correlate their stiffness estimates with changes in the simulated stiffness, despite lack of force information. We posit that subjects were only able to do this because the controller used to produce the simulated arm’s movement, composed of oscillatory motions driving mechanical impedances, resembled the controller humans use to produce their own movement. However, it is still unknown how this controller is encoded in the nervous system, and consequently, what motion features subjects used to determine their stiffness rating. Human motion exhibits systematic velocity-curvature patterns, and these patterns play an important role in perceiving and interpreting motion. Thus, we hypothesized that manipulating the velocity profile should affect subjects’ ability to estimate stiffness. To test this, we changed the velocity profile of the simulated two-link planar arm while keeping the simulated endpoint paths the same. Even with manipulated velocity signals, subjects were still able to estimate changes in simulated joint stiffness with the same level of accuracy observed in the original experiment. These results suggest that path information predominates over temporal information when humans use visual observation to estimate stiffness.
coauthors: Aaron Michael West Jr., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Massachusetts Institute of Technology; Meghan Huber, Mechanical and Industrial Engineering, University of Massachusetts Amherst; Neville Hogan, Department of Mechanical Engineering and the Department of Brain and Cognitive Sciences, Massachusetts Institute of Technology
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Biomimetic stimulation improves accuracy of vestibular prosthesis-evoked vestibulo-ocular reflex (VOR) responses
abstract: The vestibular system is crucial for maintaining visual stability via the vestibulo-ocular reflex (VOR).  Accordingly, patients with bilateral vestibulopathy suffer debilitating oscillopsia and dizziness. To improve patients’ quality of life, one emerging approach is a prosthesis that senses head rotation and transforms the movement into vestibular afferent stimulation, substituting for the damaged periphery. Though such devices can partially restore VOR function, current approaches do not represent the specific high-pass dynamics by which actual vestibular afferents encode head motion. We hypothesized that a more biomimetic design would improve performance. To test this, we incorporated afferent-like dynamics into our vestibular prosthesis. Two rhesus monkeys with bilateral vestibular hypofunction were implanted with unilateral prosthesis (targeting horizontal canal afferents). At 7 rotation frequencies (0.2 – 20 Hz), we recorded the VOR eye movements evoked by 5 different mappings: 1) no dynamics (constant gain and no phase lead), 2) regular afferent-like dynamics, 3) irregular afferent-like dynamics, 4) the combination of the two, and 5) very high-pass irregular dynamics. The gain and phase of the evoked VOR response were then analyzed. All 4 afferent-like mappings yielded constant gains up to ~5 Hz while the gains remained constant only up to 1 Hz without the afferent-like dynamics. The phase of the 4 biomimetic mappings was more compensatory (temporally precise) across a range of frequencies. In contrast, the mapping without dynamics did not maintain accurate timing and showed increasing phase lag as a function of frequency, consistent with an uncompensated fixed delay. Overall, our results show that a mapping that mimics regular afferents best maintains the VOR gain and compensatory phase response across frequencies. Further, our results have a direct clinical significance, providing support for a more biomimetic approach to improve prosthesis performance and, in turn, functional outcomes of patients with bilateral vestibulopathy.
coauthors: Dale C Roberts, Johns Hopkins University; Charles C Della Santina, Johns Hopkins University; Kathleen E Cullen, Johns Hopkins University
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Is left-behind a real reason for children’s social cognition deficit? An fNIRS study on the effect of social interaction on left-behind preschooler’s prefrontal activation
abstract: Parent out-migration has marked a common social issue in the rural area of China.  Accumulated researches provided evidences that, early parent-child separation leads to the deficits in cognitive processes, education, emotion and health. However, the neural level of deficits of social cognition, which induced by parent-child separation in rural China is unclear. To evaluate these, we compared brain activation (the social interaction difference) and behavioral differences between 81 non /partially /completely left-behind children ages of 52-76 months (mean = 64.98 ± 6.321 months) in two joint attention tasks, i.e., IJA: initiating joint attention and RJA: response to joint attention, which was implemented with different interactive objects (teacher and stranger). Results demonstrated that higher prefrontal cortex (PFC) activation during joint attention tasks, higher activation in responding to stranger than teacher, especially in IJA, and the activation of joint attention positively associated with language score, cognitive flexibility and facial expression recognition. More importantly, partially-left-behind children evoked a higher brain activation in IJA tasks and presented a higher language level than completely/non-left-behind children. This study provided insight to neural basis in the development of left-behind children in rural China and revealed ‘Left-behind’ would not take the full responsibility of children’s social cognition deficits, family economic level and ‘left-behind’ together could contribute to the lower social cognition and brain development in children.
coauthors: Keya Ding, Key Laboratory of Child Development & Learning Science, Ministry of Education, School of Biological science and medical Engineering, Southeast University, Nanjing, China; Chuanjiang Li, Hangzhou College of Early Childhood Teacher's Education, Zhejiang Normal University, Hangzhou, China; Huibin Jia, School of Psychology, Henan University, Kaifeng, China; Mingming Zhang, School of Psychology, Shanghai Normal University, Shanghai, China; Dongchuan Yu, Key Laboratory of Child Development & Learning Science, Ministry of Education, School of Biological science and medical Engineering, Southeast University, Nanjing, China.
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Study of states of consciousness under the effects of anesthetics through the use of information quantifiers
abstract: In the surgical practice it is of critical importance to know the state of consciousness that the patient has. Generally, this work is done by anaesthesiologists using visual inspection. To deal with this problem for some time, indices have been developed that allow to quantify the patient’s state of consciousness. However, these measures often have a great computational cost or needed expensive equipment. This generates the demand to develop new indexes, based on fast algorithms and open source. In this work we analyse electrocorticogram monkeys records under different anaesthesia using information quantifiers. The results showed that the use of these measures allows to detect the different states of consciousness of the monkeys. In addition, it could be seen that the effect of anaesthesia on brain dynamics varies depending on the anaesthetic used. These results show that these metrics could be used as indices of consciousness in patients under anesthesia.
coauthors: Nicolás Fuentes, Facultad de Ciencias Exactas, Físicas y Naturales. Universidad Nacional de Córdoba;Alexis García,Facultad de Ciencias Exactas, Físicas y Naturales (Universidad Nacional de Córdoba);Diego Mateos,Consejo Nacional de Investigaciones Científicas y Técnicas de Argentina (CONICET),Facultad de Ciencia y Tecnología. Universidad Autónoma de Entre Ríos (UADER),Instituto de Matemática aplicada del Litoral (IMAL-CONICET-UNC);Ana Carolina Maldonado,Centro de Investigación y Estudios de Matemática (CIEM-CONICET). FAMAF.Universidad Nacional de Córdoba
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Trajectory Prediction in a Biologically Inspired Network with a Strong Inductive Bias
abstract:
Animals are able to track objects through a visual space and make predictions about future locations after relatively few observations, even when the dynamics governing the trajectory are relatively novel. In contrast, machine learning techniques typically generalize poorly when presented with dynamics which don't match the training data. Here we introduce a model architecture which attempts to bridge this gap, by incorporating principles of hierarchical predictive coding. 

The essential component of this model is a predictive module which takes in two sequential observations, and outputs a prediction of the next observation of that same state space. Internally, each module has four layers: two inputs, a transformation layer that computes the difference between subsequent observations, and a prediction layer which takes in the more recent observation and the transition layer. These modules can operate on observations either directly from the target space, or the internal state from another predictive module. When training a network out of these modules, learning is on a per-module level based on its predicted value compared to the next observed input. 

We tested generalization of the model by using two test datasets, and comparing to a standard LSTM. In-domain generalization was tested with datasets which matched the dynamics of the training set, but with unseen initial conditions. Out of domain generalization was tested using PDEs of the same order and dimensionality, but different parameterizations, as the training set. 

We found that the models perform approximately the same for in-domain generalization with teacher forcing. For out of domain data, the predictive module network accumulates error at approximately half the rate as the LSTM model. 

These results demonstrate how an appropriately structured network utilizing a single local loss-function can perform similarly to globally optimized models, while generalizing better.
coauthors: G. William Chapman IV; Michael E. Hasselmo
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Language networks reorganization in neurodegenerative disorders: behavioral, structural, and functional evidence from semantic variant of Primary Progressive Aphasia.
abstract:
Primary Progressive Aphasia (PPA) is a clinical syndrome in which patients progressively lose speech and language abilities due to neurodegeneration of left-hemisphere language networks. Three variants are recognized, associated respectively with phonology and/or short-term verbal memory deficits (logopenic variant), grammar and/or speech-motor deficits (nonfluent variant), or semantic deficits (semantic variant, or svPPA). svPPA patients manifest a deep, generalized, loss of semantic knowledge and relatively focal anterior temporal (ATL) lobe atrophy. 
Here, we capitalize on this unique clinical model and MEG recordings to investigate the spatiotemporal features of language networks and in particular the crucial role of the ATL in semantic processing. 
First, we show that svPPA patients over-rely on dorsal, occipito-parietal brain regions during irregular word reading. This evidence corroborates a dual-route model where reading aloud is mediated by the interplay between a ventral lexico-semantic system and a dorsal sub-lexical/phonological one.
Second, we find that, during a semantic categorization task, svPPA patients show greater activation over bilateral occipital cortices and superior temporal gyrus, as well as inconsistent engagement of frontal regions. These findings indicate a pervasive reorganization of brain networks in response to ATL neurodegeneration: defective semantic representations are compensated via enhanced perceptual processing (in occipital regions) and semantic control (in the fronto-parietal network).
Finally, we demonstrate that the error patterns in an auditory verb generation task depend on the breakdown of different neurocognitive mechanisms across PPA variants. Specifically, svPPA patients produce the highest percentage of unrelated-verb responses and the highest number of light verbs, providing additional evidence of the critical role played by the ATL in semantic processing.
Taken together, our findings have important implications for clinical phenotyping and differential diagnosis of PPA variants, as well as for theoretical model of the neurobiology of language.
coauthors: Borghesani, V., UdeM; Lukic, S., UCSF; Hinkley, L.B.N., UCSF; Licata, A., UCSF; Bogley, R., UCSF; Weis, E., UCSF; Welch, A., UCSF; Mizuiri, D., UCSF; Miller, B., UCSF; Miller, Z., UCSF; Houde, J.F., UCSF; Nagarajan, S.S., UCSF; Gorno-Tempini, M.L. UCSF;
theme: Theme A: Development, Neurodegenerative Disorders and Injury

title: Emotion and Working Memory Circuits Examined via Inhibition Tasks in Prefrontal Cortex: An fNIRS Study
abstract: Emotion is a wide hub involving limbic system and neocortical structures and shares a part of functional network with cognition. Neuropsychological studies have shown that emotion and cognition processes are both appearent in the prefrontal cortex. Although they are overlapping seperate functions, recent neuroimaging studies present a wide literature on mutual or adjacent brain areas host these feaures. In this study, we aimed to show whether inhibition processes are shared on PFC during event related emotional and color-word Stroop tasks. We collected fNIRS data from prefrontal regions of 5 healthy young people without any neuropsychiatric conditions. Emotional Stroop task presented via happy and sad faces with congruent and incongruent words in the middle of the picture. In color-word Stroop task, we used color words painted in red, yellow, green and blue. We requested from participants to tap 1 for congruent and 2 for incongruent trials. All analyzing processes applied using NIRSLAB. fNIRS data are filtered, averaged and then contrasted in a binary model in which incongruent trials are main sets and congruent trials are substracted properties for SPM. We observed right dorsolateral prefrontal area is the most differentiated region regarding oxyhemoglobin concentration change during both inhibition tasks when right dorsomedial prefrontal and left inferior frontal areas are additionally distinguished in emotional Stroop task. The present data indicates that there is shared cortical networks especially on right PFC during emotional and cognitive conflict monitoring while emotional processing also requires medial-frontal structures. Further research studies should consider fNIRS as a comprehensive method for assessing higher cognitive functions.
coauthors: Kubra Kadak, Istanbul Medipol University; Lutfu Hanoglu, Istanbul Medipol University
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: SciComm: Discussion with CNN's Tom Foreman on effective science communication
abstract:
Today more than ever we see how critical it is for scientists to communicate clearly with the general public and policymakers. As neuroscience and neurotechnology advances in ways that have increasing impact outside the lab, it is especially important that this community is engaged in science communication either as a vocation or in parallel with their own research. To start a 2-part event, we will host a discussion with CNN broadcast journalist Tom Foreman about effective science communication. The discussion will include time for Q&A from the audience, so come prepared with questions!

Moderator:
Chris Rozell (Georgia Institute of Technology)

Tom Foreman biosketch:
Tom Foreman is an Emmy award-winning journalist whose experience spans more than three decades, and touches virtually every major news story in that time period. Foreman joined CNN in 2004 and is based in the network's Washington, D.C. bureau, where he covers a wide-range of topics for the network and reports for programs across the spectrum. Foreman has pioneered much of CNN's work in new media, by playing a key role in the development of an immersive, 3-D Virtual Studio which has taken viewers into space to study satellites, travels onto distant battlefields to promote better understanding of dangerous conflicts and takes a deep dive analysis on the 2016 election cycle. He leads the network's fact checking initiative and in 2013 Foreman and the fact checking team were awarded the Walter Cronkite/Brooks Jackson Award. Prior to working at CNN, Tom was the senior anchor for National Geographic and managing editor for Inside Base Camp, for which he won his second Emmy Award as best interviewer.

title: Stable representational similarity despite drifting population activity in a network model of noisy representation learning
abstract: Stable neural representations are generally associated with robust behavior and physiological functions. However, recent experiments have shown that neural population codes in many brain areas continuously change even when the animals have learned and stably perform their tasks. This representational ``drift'' naturally leads to questions about its causes, dynamics and functions. To address these questions, we consider a basic and biologically-plausible model of representation learning, the Hebbian/anti-Hebbian network, and hypothesize that drifting representation is due to noisy synaptic updates and turnover. We find that while the receptive fields of individual neurons change significantly over time, representational similarity of population codes is stable over time, providing a substrate for robust downstream readout by a Hebbian neuron. We investigate the dynamics of the drift, and find that the drift speed can be quantified by a rotational diffusion constant, which is determined by the learning rate, noise level and upstream input statistics. Our model accounts for many of the recent observed experimental observations in hippocampus and cortices related to sensorimotor tasks.
coauthors: Shanshan Qin, Harvard University; Cengiz Pehlevan, Harvard University
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Spinal inhibitory Ptf1a-derived neurons prevent self-generated itch
abstract: Chronic itch represents an incapacitating burden on patients suffering from a wide spectrum of diseases. Despite recent advances in our understanding of the cells and circuits implicated in the processing of itch information, chronic itch often presents itself without an apparent cause. Here, we identify a spinal subpopulation of inhibitory neurons defined by the expression of Ptf1a, involved in gating mechanosensory information self-generated during movement. These neurons receive tactile and motor input and establish presynaptic inhibitory contacts on mechanosensory afferents. Loss of Ptf1a neurons leads to increased hairy skin sensitivity and chronic itch, partially mediated by the classic itch pathway involving gastrin releasing peptide receptor (GRPR) spinal neurons. Conversely, chemogenetic activation of GRPR neurons elicits itch which is suppressed by concomitant activation of Ptf1a neurons. These findings shed new light on the circuit mechanisms implicated in chronic itch and open novel targets for therapy developments.
coauthors: Ruediger Klein
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: A novel, high-throughput monitoring system for maternal behavior in mice
abstract:
Understanding the neural circuitry of maternal behavior requires a comprehensive
functional analysis of the repertoire an animal has developed in an ecologically valid setting to ensure its survival. To achieve this, we designed an ethological automated habitat for mice, where behavioral data can be collected for months at a time and that supports gain/loss-of- function interventions and neural recordings. Our naturalistic enclosure is soundproofed and temperature and humidity-controlled to simulate the conditions of a mouse burrow in the wild.

Previously, our lab found that the neuropeptide oxytocin could promote long-term plasticity and mediate experience-dependent changes in neural circuits that serve to increase the sensitivity to pup cues, thereby facilitating behavioral responses to pup distress. These behavioral responses to pup social signals continues throughout life, possibly benefitting future offspring. Central and peripheral release of oxytocin during pregnancy and perinatally has been shown to support the onset of maternal behavior and facilitate attachment, bonding, and breastfeeding, both by increasing the salience of social cues and by interacting with reward systems that reinforce mother-infant interactions

As proof of concept, we used this comprehensive behavioral phenotyping tool to investigate mother-pup interactions in the nest across consecutive litters. To elucidate the effects of oxytocinergic variability in maternal bonding, we monitored four wild-type female mice across pregnancies (two of them from mating to their third pregnancy), as well as two oxytocin receptor knockout females over mating and first pregnancy. We found that primiparous dams spend less time in the nest as these same animals then do in later pregnancies. We also found that perinatal nest quality is a robust predictor of the survival of the litter; the lower the nest integrity, the higher the likelihood the litter won’t survive. Interestingly, wild-type dams who neglect or cannibalize their pups show similar nest-building patterns and time spent in the nest as oxytocin receptor knockout mice who tend to have notoriously high pup mortality.
coauthors: Robert Froemke, PhD, New York University/Skirball Institute of Biomolecular Medicine/Neuroscience Institute; Adam Mar, PhD, New York University/Neuroscience Institute
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: The influence of target reward on motor planning and online motor decision
abstract: The central nervous system uses sophisticated strategies to plan and execute upper limb reaching movements. Motor planning involves the selection of a goal amongst multiple options that is biased by factors such as the biomechanical cost or the expected gains of the potential movements. Likewise, motor execution is influenced by parameters such as reward, which invigorates reaching movements in a way that is coherent with robust optimal feedback control models. To date, the effect of costs and rewards on planning and control has been studied separately, and it remains unknown whether and how target selection may be influenced by reward following disturbances during ongoing actions. To address this question, we designed an experiment in which we sought to determine whether the distribution of rewards amongst three potential options (either all targets had the same reward or the lateral targets had smaller reward) had an influence on motor planning and execution in presence of unexpected mechanical perturbations. We observed a decrease of the online change in target goal when the lateral targets had smaller rewards, for all mechanical perturbation levels. Interestingly we observed, when all the targets had the same reward, a negative correlation between the EMG activity of muscles and the propensity to switch target online: higher activity correlated with smaller change propensity. In order to confirm this effect, we designed a similar second experiment in which a leftward background load was applied through some trials to pre-excite the muscles. Remarkably, we observed that the application of the leftward background load decreased the frequency of switch toward the leftward target at all perturbation levels. In all, our study revealed that multiple mechanisms underlie reward-dependent planning and control of movement: a robust control strategy that leverages gain-scaling and a more flexible control strategy that enables rapid and online target changes.
coauthors: Frederic Crevecoeur, Université catholique de Louvain; Philippe Lefèvre, Université catholique de Louvain
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Effects of moderate prenatal alcohol exposure on long-term potentiation and rhythmic activity in the dentate gyrus.
abstract: The hippocampus is susceptible to the effects of prenatal alcohol exposure (PAE) that can result in persistent cognitive impairments. Although there have been many investigations, deficits in synaptic plasticity remains poorly understood. Previous studies have identified deficits in long-term potentiation (LTP) in the perforant pathway to dentate gyrus synapses as a robust consequence of PAE. This study sought to investigate how PAE effects LTP in the dentate gyrus and how PAE influences continuous EEG signaling and time-frequency relationships in evoked responses after high-frequency stimulation (HFS). We utilized a rat model of moderate PAE (60 mg/dl peak blood alcohol content). Thirteen urethane-anesthetized adult male rats were implanted with monopolar electrodes in the dorsal dentate gyrus and in the entorhinal cortical perforant pathway. Evoked responses were recorded (1/30s) at 20KHz and continuous data were obtained at 1KHz throughout sessions. Synaptic potentiation was induced by 5 trains of HFS over 25ms with 30s inter-train intervals. PAE rats displayed reduced LTP of the fEPSP (p = 0.01). Data were analyzed using fast Fourier transformation (FFT) within the delta to gamma frequency bands, as well individual frequencies ranging from 1-16 Hz, including slow oscillatory activity (<1Hz) and rhythmic slow activity (3-15Hz). At baseline, the PAE group displayed a trend toward increased delta power (p = 0.055) and significantly increased 2-3Hz power (p = 0.042). There were no group differences following HFS or in relative power for any phase. Time frequency analyses performed on individual evoked responses revealed a greater increase in power associated with the fEPSP in SAC rats, whereas PAE displayed increased power in later portions of the evoked response that reflect feedback signaling from local interneurons. These observations suggest that deficits in LTP following PAE may be related to alterations in local inhibitory interneuron activity and rhythmic activity in the dentate gyrus.
coauthors: Savage DD, Department of Neurosciences - University of New Mexico; Hamilton DA, Department of Psychology - University of New Mexico
theme: Theme B: Neural Excitability, Synapses, and Glia

title: Selective impacts of sleep deprivation on brain and behavior
abstract:
Sleep is essential to brain functioning and lack of sleep greatly impairs behavior, yet the mechanisms underlying the detrimental effects of sleep deprivation remain largely unclear. Here we investigate how sleep deprivation influences the structure of neural connections and the function of neural communications that, in turn, lead to the behavioral impairments. 

Using a combination of quantitative structural MRI, multi-compartment diffusion MRI, resting-state functional MRI, task functional MRI, behavioral testing and physiological monitoring, we traced the changes in brain structural indices (axon density, axon diameter, myelination), functional indices (signal propagation speed, signal-to-noise ratio, coding accuracy), behavioral indices (perception, decision making, introspection, attention, vigilance, action, emotion) and physiological indices (pupillary light reflex, resting heart rate, resting breathing pattern), across 36 hours of sleep deprivation and one night of recovery sleep, in 14 healthy young adults. 

Analysis of behavioral data revealed that the time course of performance detriment is largely dissociable between behavioral domains. The detriment was first observed in vigilance and mood ratings, followed by perceptual decision making and introspection. By contrast, visual spatial attention and perception remain relatively unaffected by sleep deprivation. The heterogeneous changes in behavioral performances hint towards a stronger impact of sleep deprivation on prefrontal cortex than on parietal-occipital cortex, which we are currently testing via analysis of brain structural and functional data.
coauthors: Chunxiang Jiang, Cardiff University Brain Research Imaging Centre, Cardiff University, Cardiff, UK  and Paul C. Lauterbur Research Center for Biomedical Imaging, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Shenzhen, China; Ilenia D'Onofrio, Cardiff University Brain Research Imaging Centre, Cardiff University, Cardiff, UK; Zhishan Liu, Cardiff University Brain Research Imaging Centre, Cardiff University, Cardiff, UK; Chen Song, Cardiff University Brain Research Imaging Centre, Cardiff University, Cardiff, UK  and Department of Psychiatry, University of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, USA
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Task-specificity and neural adaptations after balance learning in healthy young adults
abstract:
Introduction: Only 30 minutes of balance skill training lead to significant improvements in behavioral and neuromuscular outcome measures. However, it is unclear if such a rapidly acquired skill is also retained and transferred to other untrained balance tasks. Therefore, the purpose of this study was to examine the effects of a single balance training on balance skill acquisition, retention, and transferability and to examine the underlying neural plasticity by intermuscular coherence and transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS).
Methods: Healthy young adults (n=36, age 20.9, 18M) were randomly assigned to learn balancing on a wobble board (BAL), cycle while seated (CYC) or sit and rest (CON) for 20 minutes. Before, immediately and ~7 days after the exercise session, we assessed performance of the trained and several untrained balance tasks. Potential underlying neural mechanisms were examined by intermuscular coherence of lower extremity muscles and by TMS. 
Results: BAL improved balance performance in the trained task by 338.9% (±257.2, effect size [d]=1.94), while CT (21.5% ±70.3, d=0.07) and NC (25.8% ± 85.3, d=0.05) did not. BAL retained the acquired skill after a 1-week-long off-line, no-training period (256.0% ±165.5). No changes occurred in 12 measures of untrained balance outcomes, 8 measures of intermuscular coherence, and in 4 TMS measures of supra-spinal plasticity (all p>0.05).
Conclusions: A single unstable balance-board training session but not cycling or rest improved the trained balance skill by margins observed in long term studies without transfer to other balancing skills or changes in neural plasticity. Future studies will examine in more detail and by additional methods the neuromechanical mechanisms and the time course underlying the remarkable level of specificity of learning a balance skill.
coauthors: T. Nandi, Nuffield Department of Clinical Neurosciences, University of Oxford, United Kingdom; C.J.C. Lamoth, University of Groningen, University Medical Center Groningen, the Netherlands; T. Hortobágyi, University of Groningen, University Medical Center Groningen, the Netherlands
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Cellular mechanisms of consciousness and dreaming
abstract:
Recent breakthroughs in neurobiology indicate that the time is ripe to understand how cellular-level mechanisms are related to conscious experience. We  propose that consciousness depends on the integration between two different parts of the cortical pyramidal neuron. In conscious states, these parts are coupled, thus enabling complex signal propagation and sustained dynamics within the thalamocortical system.  When these parts of the pyramidal cell are functionally torn apart, such signal propagation is prohibited and consciousness breaks down. Hence, differences in global dynamics of large scale networks between conscious and unconscious states are controlled by local gates within pyramidal cells.

We further suggest that the hallmark of conscious processing is the flexible integration of bottom-up and top-down data streams enabled through dendritic integration on a cellular level. This cellular integration mechanism provides the foundation for Dendritic Information Theory (DIT). DIT offers a natural explanation for why conscious experience is modulated by context and prior knowledge.

We then explain how this mechanism can shed light on the neural mechanisms dreaming. We posit that during dreams neurons are in a state where they are driven top-down by the generative model. High acetylcholine and low noradrenaline put the pyramidal cells in a specific mode, where they are driven internally and activated through their apical dendrites. This could also be the neural mechanism for imagery and hallucinations.

Taken together, we propose a theory of how top-down and bottom-up information streams are combined on the cellular level. We think that besides illuminating the neural basis of consciousness and dreaming these ideas are relevant for figuring out the neural implementation of predictive processing and for developing novel AI algorithms.
coauthors: Mototaka Suzuki, Humboldt University Berlin; Francesca Siclari, Centre Hospitalier Universitaire Vaudois Lausanne; William Phillips, University of Stirling; Johan F. Storm, University of Oslo; Matthew Larkum, Humboldt University Berlin
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Machine Learning and Mathematical Methods for the Brain Age Problem
abstract: Overall, the global population is aging and, as a result, there is an increasing frequency of age-related  diseases. Researchers have tried to establish neuroanatomical biomarkers of aging and understand how the healthy adult brain changes with age. This is the Brain Age Problem (BAP). Our research concentrates on the use of brain biometrics, machine learning methods, and pure mathematics to improve the current answers to the Brain Age Problem (BAP). In this work, we derived the Normalized Stretching Ratio (NSR) given by (Thickness)^2/(Surface Area), which is a surrogate of the isoperimetric ratio that quantifies the stretching of a brain region. We used the NSRs of 68 brain regions as the predictors of a classification model on a freely available data set of young adults, collected by the Human Connectome Project. Our model does not sacrifice prediction accuracy when compared to a similar model on the raw data and so the dimensionality reduction provided by the NSRs yields a simpler explanation of the changes that occur in the brain. Our model reduces the gap between explainability and prediction accuracy by merging ideas from pure mathematical fields, such as differential geometry, machine learning, and neuroscience. This is joint work with my students Justin Asher, Khoa Tan Dang, Peter Klopfenstein, Maxwell Masters, and Jucoen Yeater.
coauthors: Justin Asher, Purdue University Fort Wayne; Khoa Tan Dang, Purdue University Fort Wayne; Peter Klopfenstein, Purdue University Fort Wayne; Maxwell Masters, Purdue University Fort Wayne; Jucoen Yeater, Purdue University Fort Wayne
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Controlling the flow: GABAergic interneurons in neonatal cortex
theme: Theme A: Development, Neurodegenerative Disorders and Injury

title: Temporal regularity is an essential social cue in mouse vocal communication
abstract:
Animals navigating the real world continuously face large amounts of complex sensory information. One of the strategies used by the brain to perceptually compress multidimensional input is to selectively extract the features relevant for behaviour and survival. Like humans and many other mammals, mice communicate using acoustically complex vocal sequences. However, little is known about what acoustic information listeners monitor and use from these sensory streams during social interactions. 
Here, we utilized female mice’s natural behavioural response to male courtships songs to identify the relevant acoustic dimensions used by listeners in their social decisions. Using playbacks of intact and acoustically manipulated songs in an ethologically-relevant assay, we evaluated the behavioural relevance of several candidate acoustic features in mouse communication.
We found that female listeners were highly sensitive to disruptions of song temporal regularity and preferentially approached playbacks of intact male songs over rhythmically irregular versions of the songs. In contrast, female behaviour was invariant to manipulations affecting the global structure of the song, such as randomized sequential organization and song temporal reversal. Similarly, manipulating the local spectro-temporal structure of individual syllables, such as phase-scrambling or pure tone approximation, did not influence female behaviour to male song playback.
Our findings highlight temporal regularity in vocal sequences as a key acoustic cue extracted by listeners during natural vocal-directed behaviour. By identifying which acoustic dimensions in vocal sequences are behaviourally-relevant, respectively less informative, to listeners, this work frames ongoing electrophysiological investigations into the neuronal substrates supporting the perception of vocal sequences.
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Atypical Development of Working Memory of Biological Motion in Autism Spectrum Disorder and Its Relation to Core Autistic Symptoms
abstract: Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) is a neurodevelopmental disorder whose core symptoms include impaired social interaction and interpersonal communication. Elucidating their developmental trajectory of social information processing is important for advancing theories of etiology and intervention of ASD. While previous research has charted the development of joint attention and theory of mind, the development of perception of biological motion (BM) among children with ASD is still understudied. By viewing point-light displays of human movements, typically-developed (TD) people is capable of inferring others’ identity, gender or emotion with ease. Our recent study has found that working memory of BM (WM-BM) develops rapidly around age 4 and 5 among TD children. Here we examine whether children with ASD has similar critical development of BM. We tested WM-BM as well as that of inverted biological motion (WM-IBM) among children with and without ASD aged between 4 and 6 yrs. For TD children, both WM-BM and WM-IBM capacity increased steadily between age 4 and 6. Children with ASD had similar performance as TD children at age 4 and 5 but lagged behind at age 6. For them, only WM-IBM but not WM-BM capacity increased with age, highlighting a specific slow-down in development of social information processing. Importantly, we found that the WM-BM capacity correlated with the severity of core symptoms of autism among children with ASD, suggesting that our working memory test based on BM is a good indicator of social development in this population. Since the preference for BM stimuli is reduced among high-risk autism infants as early as 8-month old, our results suggest that early deviation in preference and perception of social stimuli would lead to impaired high-level cognition (i.e., WM here) of related stimuli years later, a developmental path that might be shared by various social-cognitive abilities among individuals with ASD.
coauthors: Linlin Gong, School of Psychological and Cognitive Sciences, Peking University, Beijing, China; Yiyang Cai, School of Psychological and Cognitive Sciences, Peking University, Beijing, China; Dong Guo,  Department of Psychology and Behavioral Sciences, Zhejiang University, Xixi Campus, Hang Zhou, China; Yajie Liu, School of Psychological and Cognitive Sciences, Peking University, Beijing, China;Shaolin Zeng, Zaifeng Gao,  Department of Psychology and Behavioral Sciences, Zhejiang University, Xixi Campus, Hang Zhou, China;Kunlin Wei, School of Psychological and Cognitive Sciences, Peking University, Beijing, China
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Chasing the light: Mechanistically informed statistical models of dynamics
institution: Gatsby Computational Neuroscience Unit, University College London
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Pre-training RNNs on ecologically relevant tasks explains rats suboptimal behavior in a simple categorization task
abstract:
In order to make optimal decisions in real-world environments it is fundamental to take into account recent stimuli and the actions made in response to them, together with the outcomes of those actions. A recent study (Hermoso-Mendizabal et al.) has shown that rats are able to leverage the information contained in the trial history of a perceptual two-alternative forced choice (2AFC) task that includes serial correlations in the trial sequence. However, rats only used this trial history information after correct trials and failed to do so after error trials, when they temporarily followed a strategy only based on the current stimulus. Here we use RNNs to investigate whether this reset strategy reflects an adaptive mechanism or alternatively reveals fundamental limits in the capacity of simple neural circuits to perform counterfactual inference.     
We trained Recurrent Neural Networks (RNNs) in the same 2AFC task used for rats and found that the networks, like the rats, learned to leverage the sequence partial predictability  to increase their categorization accuracy after correct trials. However, RNNS also used this predictability after error trials departing from the reset strategy of the rats and resembling the behavior of an optimal agent that can perform counterfactual inference. 
We hypothesize that the discrepancy between the rats and RNNs behavior is due to the fact that networks are fully optimizing their performance in the 2AFC task whereas the brain of rats has been shaped by evolution in order to optimize their performance in more ecological environments. As a consequence, although rats manage to perform well in the task, they are not able to fully adapt their behavior to it. We show that by pre-training the RNNs in the same task but using a number of choices larger than two, they exhibit  the reset strategy displayed by the rats, which is close to an optimal behavior in a more complex environment with multiple options.
Our results suggest that seemingly sub-optimal behaviors in laboratory tasks (e.g. the reset strategy) can be a byproduct of the adaptation to more complex environments. Furthermore, our work demonstrates the usefulness of pre-training artificial neural networks in ecologically plausible environments before testing them on the task of interest.
coauthors: Manuel Molano-Mazon, IDIBAPS, Barcelona, Spain; Daniel Duque-Doncos, IDIBAPS, Barcelona, Spain; Guangyu Robert Yang, Center for Theoretical Neuroscience, Columbia University, New York, USA; Jaime de la Rocha, IDIBAPS, Barcelona, Spain;
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Area-specific and frequency-dependent relationship between local field potentials and neural population dynamics
abstract:
Local field potentials (LFPs) are generated by the summed synaptic input currents to local neurons. Many studies have shown that the activity of populations of cortical neurons is well described by low-dimensional, population-wide “latent dynamics”. Here we provide the first investigation of how much information is shared between these latent dynamics and the LFPs that ostensibly drive them. 

We used microelectrode arrays to record LFPs and single neuron activity from premotor, primary motor and primary somatosensory cortex as monkeys performed an instructed delay reaching task. We calculated the latent dynamics from the single unit activity using principal component analysis. We computed the LFP power in eight standard frequency bands as well as the “local motor potential”, the moving average of the broadband LFP.

We first examined the relationship between each LFP band and the latent dynamics separately for each cortical area using canonical correlation analysis, a method that quantifies the correlation between the dynamics of two sets of signals. Although for all three areas the lowest and highest LFP frequency bands were strongly correlated with the latent dynamics, the LFP-to-latent dynamics correlations at mid-frequencies were quite variable across areas. 

We obtained these results by focusing on one particular aspect of the behaviour: movement preparation for premotor cortex, and movement execution for primary motor and sensory cortices. We asked whether the area-specific relationships were preserved across these different aspects of the behaviour. We computed the canonical correlations between LFP and latent dynamics for both behavioural epochs, then compared the two sets of correlations. Remarkably, for both areas, these correlations were the same during movement planning and execution, and greatly exceeded the correlations observed when monkeys were not engaged in the task. Adopting a neural population view thus allows stable area-specific and frequency-dependent relationships between neural activity and LFPs to be identified.
coauthors: Matthew G. Perich, Raeed H. Chowdhury, Lee E. Miller, Juan A. Gallego
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Body Part- and Location-Selectivity Surrounding hMT in BOLD Responses to Naturalistic Stimuli
abstract: Information about body pose is critical for social communication and human interaction. In this work, we aim to clarify the extent to which potentially multiple regions of lateral occipitotemporal cortex (LOTC) encode information about the locations of body parts. To this end we applied voxel-wise modeling to BOLD responses for five participants across three diverse naturalistic stimulus sets: static natural images, natural movie clips, and computer-rendered scenes. From each stimulus set we used a deep neural network (OpenPose) to extract the locations and identities of different body parts. We then applied regularized linear regression to these features to estimate the relationship between each body feature and the BOLD responses of individual voxels. We validated our regression model by calculating prediction accuracies at each voxel. In addition to FFA, OFA, and pSTS, our model accurately predicted BOLD responses in voxels surrounding hMT, confirming body part selectivity in these regions. Variance partitioning incorporating motion energy features and binary ‘building present’ and ‘human present’ labels revealed unique variance explained by our body model in these regions, suggesting our prediction performance in these voxels is not merely due to naturalistic stimulus confounds. Finally, we contrasted voxel-wise model weights corresponding to different body features to measure differences in tuning based on body part identity and visual field location. This analysis revealed patchy selectivity for hands compared to faces around hMT and selectivity for the contralateral visual field throughout LOTC, particularly near the Lateral Occipital Sulcus. These results argue for an anatomically-circumscribed model of body-selectivity in LOTC and lend support to previous reports positing the existence of multiple sub-regions of EBA.
coauthors: Matthew W. Shinkle, Mark D. Lescroart
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: The response to background motion: characteristics of a hand stabilization mechanism
abstract: When making goal-directed movements towards a target, our hand deviates from its path in the direction of sudden background motion. We introduce the Hand Stabilization Hypothesis to explain this ‘manual following response’. This hypothesis suggests that any abrupt background motion near the desired endpoint of one’s action is attributed to that point having moved relative to oneself. This leads to the hand following any motion within that relevant region to stabilize the ongoing movement. In six experiments, we accumulate evidence in support of this hypothesis. Participants were asked to intercept a moving target when it reached a certain area and, at a fixed moment during the hand’s interceptive action, background structures started to move either leftward or rightward. We determined the response of the hand by subtracting its velocity when the background moved leftward from its velocity when the background moved rightward. The participants’ hand responded to background motion even if the majority of background structures remained static or if background structures were only briefly visible. Thus, the response cannot be driven by judgments of self-motion based on the instantaneous optic flow within the relevant part of the background. The response was most sensitive to motion close to where the target was to be hit, both in the visual field and in depth. Even motion of only three small dots in that area was sufficient to elicit a response. Together these experiments characterise the fast and simple hand stabilization mechanism that is likely to be relevant for the control of an ongoing hand movement in a dynamic environment.
coauthors: Emily M. Crowe, Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam; Jeroen B. J. Smeets, Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam; Eli Brenner, Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: A large-scale neural network training framework for generalized estimation of single-trial population dynamics
abstract: Large-scale recordings of neural activity are becoming ubiquitous, providing new opportunities to study network-level dynamics in diverse brain areas and during increasingly complex, natural behaviors. However, the sheer volume of data and its dynamical complexity are critical barriers to uncovering and interpreting these dynamics. Deep learning methods are a particularly promising approach due to their ability to uncover meaningful relationships from large, complex, and noisy datasets. One such method, latent factor analysis via dynamical systems (LFADS), uses recurrent neural networks to infer latent dynamics from high-D neural spiking data. When applied to motor cortical (M1) activity during stereotyped behaviors, LFADS substantially improved the ability to uncover dynamics and their relation to subjects’ behaviors on a moment-by-moment, millisecond timescale. However, applying LFADS to less-structured behaviors, or in brain areas that are not predominantly driven by intrinsic dynamics, is far more challenging. This is because LFADS, like many deep learning methods, requires careful hand-tuning of complex model hyperparameters (HPs) to achieve good performance. Here we demonstrate AutoLFADS, a large-scale, automated model tuning framework that can characterize dynamics in diverse brain areas without regard to behavior. AutoLFADS uses distributed computing to train dozens of models simultaneously while using evolutionary algorithms to optimally tune HPs in a completely unsupervised way. AutoLFADS required 10-fold less data to uncover dynamics from macaque M1/PMd, with better generalization to unseen behavioral conditions than previous LFADS models. We then tested data from the somatosensory and dorsomedial frontal cortices, areas with very different dynamics from M1/PMd. AutoLFADS produced estimates of population dynamics that were precisely linked to behavior without any prior knowledge of the areas’ dynamics, tasks, or subjects’ behaviors, outperforming any individually-trained LFADS model obtained through random HP searches.
coauthors: Mohammad Reza Keshtkaran (co-first author),  Emory/Georgia Tech; Raeed H. Chowdhury, U of Pittsburgh; Raghav Tandon, Georgia Tech; Diya Basrai, UCSD; Sarah L. Nguyen, Georgia Tech; Hansem Sohn, MIT; Mehrdad Jazayeri, MIT; Lee E. Miller, Northwestern U; Chethan Pandarinath, Emory/Georgia Tech;
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Preferential subspace identification (PSID) for modeling behaviorally relevant neural dynamics
abstract: In addition to any specific behavior of interest, neural activity often relates to other brain functions as well as brain states with distributed representations such as thirst. Dissociating these behaviorally irrelevant neural dynamics from the behaviorally relevant ones is key in understanding how neural dynamics explain behavior. We develop a novel algorithm termed PSID for dissociating and modeling behaviorally relevant neural dynamics. PSID models the temporal structure of neural activity in terms of a latent brain state that dissociates the behaviorally relevant dynamics from other dynamics. First, with extensive numerical simulations, we show that PSID learns behaviorally relevant neural dynamics much more accurately, using orders of magnitude less training data and latent states with fewer dimensions. Next, we use PSID to study motor cortical dynamics in two non-human primates performing 3D reach-return movements toward targets while all joint angles in their upper-extremity were being tracked. PSID reveals that behaviorally relevant neural dynamics are markedly lower dimensional than implied by standard methods. In addition, PSID uncovers distinct rotational dynamics in neural activity during reach and return movements that are missed by standard methods and are significantly more predictive of behavior. Moreover, PSID learns more accurate behaviorally relevant dynamics from almost all recording channels and for almost all joints. Finally, to show that the benefit of PSID is due to its novel two-stage learning algorithm that considers both neural activity and behavior and can dissociate behaviorally relevant dynamics, we compare the results with example nonlinear modeling methods and find that PSID more accurately learns the behaviorally relevant neural dynamics. Taken together, PSID provides a new tool for studying and modeling behaviorally relevant neural dynamics that can otherwise be missed. PSID also serves as a dynamic dimension reduction method that can preserve behaviorally relevant neural dynamics. Finally, PSID can also be used to model shared dynamics between any two signals, e.g. neural activity in two brain regions.
coauthors: Hamidreza Abbaspourazad, University of Southern California; Yan Wong, New York University; Bijan Pesaran, New York University; Maryam Shanechi, University of Southern California
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Nonlinear stimulus representations in neural circuits with approximate excitatory-inhibitory balance
abstract: Balanced excitation and inhibition is widely observed in cortex. How does this balance shape neural computations and stimulus representations? This question is often studied using computational models of neuronal networks in a dynamically balanced state. But balanced network models predict a linear relationship between stimuli and population responses. So how do cortical circuits implement nonlinear representations and computations? We show that every balanced network architecture admits stimuli that break the balanced state and these breaks in balance push the network into a “semi-balanced state” characterized by excess inhibition to some neurons, but an absence of excess excitation. The semi-balanced state produces nonlinear stimulus representations and nonlinear computations, is unavoidable in networks driven by multiple stimuli, is consistent with cortical recordings, and has a direct mathematical relationship to artificial neural networks. In addition, we study the synaptic plasticity and learnings in semi-balanced networks, and aim to build a more direct analogue between ANNs and neuronal networks in the cerebral cortex. This will open a highway of shared information between neuroscience and machine learning, resulting in rapid advances in each field.
coauthors: Vicky Zhu, University of Notre Dame; Cody Baker, University of Notre Dame;Robert Rosenbaum, University of Notre Dame
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Current status of Nanomedicine in Glioblastoma Multiforme - A Systematic Review.
abstract:
Background: With all the current therapeutic advancements, Glioblastoma multiforme (GBM) is still an incurable disease with a median overall survival of a mere 15 months. Owing to their small size, high surface to volume ratio and ability to cross the blood brain barrier, nanoparticles are being employed in therapeutics, diagnostics and theranostics for GBM.
Objective: In this systematic review, we describe the basis and types of nanoparticles utilized for treatment of GBM and further evaluate the outcomes of clinical trials involving nanotherapy in patients with GBM.
Methodology: Ten clinical trials conducted between 2001 until 2020 were analyzed the PRISMA 2009 guidelines. 225 patients were further sub-grouped as either primary or recurrent GBM.
Results: The primary outcome of median overall survival (mOS) was 8.2 months for the pooled sample, 6.75 months for primary GBM and 9.7 months for recurrent GBM.  The median KPS improved from 80 to 90 after therapy.  Number of adverse events due to nanotherapy were n=32 (14.2%). The results show that existing nanotherapeutic strategies were able to extend the survival as well as quality of life with an acceptable adverse event rate.
Conclusion: While nanotechnology has shown much potential in being a futuristic medicine to treat GBM, it is far from achieving superiority amongst other “second line” options. Possible reasons and future directions are discussed.
coauthors: Dr Hrishikesh Sarkar, Senior Consultant Neurosurgeon Department of Neurological Sciences Kokilaben Dhirubhai Ambani Hospital, 4 Bunglows, Mumbai, India  - 400061
institution: Narsee Monjee Institute of Management Studies (grid.444588.1)
theme: Theme A: Development, Neurodegenerative Disorders and Injury

title: Maximum Entropy Models for Connectivity Estimation in Neural Signals
abstract: Maximum Entropy (ME) models, specifically the Ising model, have been proposed as estimators of connectivity in biological neural networks, although their efficacy for this purpose is not well characterized. Moreover, existing ME estimators are constrained to binary signals, which limit their application to non-spiking, continuous signals. This works proposes the Q-Potts model from statistical physics as an alternative Maximum Entropy-based connectivity estimation framework which enables the use of signals with Q discrete levels. A comparison between Potts estimators using a range of Q parameters is carried out. The methods are compared across several network topologies, including common-input networks which have been shown to cause systematic errors across connectivity inference methods. Simulated data is generated from the topologies using  Multi-Variate Autoregressive (MVAR) Models and Dynamic Potts (DP) models. The Ising estimator, equivalent to a 2-Potts estimator, is shown to be a robust estimator of connectivity compared to higher-order Q-Potts estimator, even when data is generated with a model that matches the latter. When compared to widely used information-theoretic connectivity estimators, the Ising model performs at a similar level for data generated through MVAR models, and outperforms them in DP-generated models. While ME models remain susceptible to systematic errors in connectivity estimation, they are shown to be robust estimators of connectivity with some tolerance to model mismatch compared to other common methods. The possibility of hardware-accelerated inference for ME models make them a strong candidate for rapid online connectivity estimation for clinical purposes.
coauthors: Ali Haydaroglu, University College London; Taufik A. Valiante, University of Toronto
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Evidence accumulation determines conscious access
abstract: A fundamental scientific question concerns the neuronal basis of perceptual consciousness, which can encompass both perceptual experience and reflexive monitoring associated with a sensory event. Although recent human studies identified individual neurons reflecting stimulus visibility, their functional role for perceptual consciousness remains unknown. Here, we provide neuronal and computational evidence indicating that perceptual and reflexive consciousness are governed by an all-or-none process involving accumulation of perceptual evidence. We recorded single-neuron activity in a participant with a microelectrode implant in the posterior parietal cortex, considered a substrate for evidence accumulation, while he detected vibrotactile stimuli around detection threshold and provided confidence estimates. We found that detected stimuli elicited firing rate patterns resembling evidence accumulation during decision-making, irrespective of response effectors. Similar neurons encoded the intensity of task-irrelevant stimuli, suggesting their role for consciousness per se, irrespective of report. We generalized these findings in healthy volunteers using electroencephalography and reproduced their behavioral and neural responses with a computational model of evidence accumulation. This model considered stimulus detection if accumulated evidence reached a bound, and confidence as the distance between maximal evidence (over time) and that bound. Apart from reproducing neural responses, detection rates and confidence ratings distributions, our model also reproduced higher variance for confidence in hits vs. misses and metacognitive sensitivity between participants. Applying this mechanism to our neuronal data, we were able to decode single-trial confidence ratings both for detected and undetected stimuli. Our results show that the specific gradual changes in neuronal dynamics during evidence accumulation govern perceptual consciousness and reflexive monitoring in humans. Furthermore, the model we propose offers a plausible mechanism for confidence in the absence of conscious detection.
coauthors: Michael Pereira;Pierre Megevand;Mi Xue Tan;Wenwen Chang;Shuo Wang;Ali Rezai;Margitta Seeck;Marco Corniola;Shahan Momjian;Fosco Bernasconi;Olaf Blanke;Nathan Faivre
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Multiscale low-dimensional neural dynamics underlie naturalistic reach-and-grasp movements
abstract: Studies of low-dimensional dynamics of neural population activity have largely focused on analyses of spiking activity of a population of neurons. However, motor function involves multiple spatiotemporal scales of brain activity ranging from small-scale processes measured by spiking activity to larger-scale brain network activity reflected in local field potentials (LFP). How low-dimensional dynamics of spiking and LFP activity relate to each other remains elusive to date. Further, for naturalistic reach-and-grasp movements, low-dimensional neural dynamics are relatively under-explored even for spiking population activity. We learn novel multiscale latent state-space models for spiking, LFP and combined spike-LFP activities recorded from non-human primates performing a naturalistic reach-and-grasp movement to diverse locations in 3D space and continuously in time without a trial structure. We partitioned the latent state into several dynamical modes, each characterized with a unique decay-frequency pair which described how fast neural dynamics decayed in time and with what frequency they ringed over time. We then quantified how predictive of behavior each mode was. In both spiking and LFP network activity, there existed a mode that was dominantly predictive of behavior compared to other modes. Interestingly, while spiking and LFP network activity displayed several distinct modes, this predictive mode was shared between them, i.e. had similar decay-frequency characteristics. This implied that the predictive mode was multiscale. Interestingly, the multiscale predictive mode was also shared across sessions and monkeys, but was not simply a replicate of modes in behavior. Finally, the multiscale predictive mode existed in both low-frequency and high-frequency LFP bands. Multiple convergent analysis showed that both the multiscale predictive mode’s decay and frequency explained naturalistic behavior. The predictive mode’s time-decay was ~1s, which was longer than all other modes, suggesting that naturalistic behavior relies on integrating multiscale neural dynamics over longer time-periods. In addition, its frequency was ~0.2 Hz, characterizing how fast the underlying neural dynamics tended to rotate in time. We propose that multiscale, low-dimensional motor cortical dynamics underlie naturalistic reach-and-grasp movements due to the prominent role of large-scale brain networks in these movements.
coauthors: Hamidreza Abbaspourazad, Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Southern California; Mahdi Choudhary, Center for Neural Science, New York University; Yan T Wong, Department of Physiology, Electrical and Computer Systems Engineering, Monash University; Bijan Pesaran, Center for Neural Science, New York University; Maryam M Shanechi, Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Neuroscience Graduate Program, University of Southern California
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Decoding visual colour from scalp electroencephalography measurements
abstract: Recent advances have made it possible to decode various aspects of visually presented stimuli from patterns of scalp EEG measurements. As of recently, such multivariate methods have been commonly used to decode visual-spatial features such as location, orientation, or spatial frequency.
