However the interpretation is quite ambiguous and the correlation could also originate via feedback from decision-making mechanisms downstream of the sensory representation. Its meaning can be better understood in the light of population-wide correlations among sensory neurons. 
The middle temporal (MT) area contains both sensory and choice information and is known to be the key sensory area for visual motion perception. Using a statistical nonlinear dimensionality reduction technique on single-trial ensemble recordings during perceptual-decision-making, we extracted low-dimensional latent factors that captured the population-wide fluctuations and dissected the particular contributions of sensory-driven versus choice-correlated activity in the low-dimensional population code.
We found that the latent factors strongly encoded the direction of the stimulus in a single dimension with a temporal signature similar to that of single MT neurons. If the downstream circuit were optimally utilizing this information, choice-correlated signals should be aligned with this stimulus encoding dimension. Thus the decision-making process may be corrupting the sensory representation. Surprisingly, we found that the sensory stimuli and choice variables are separate at the population level contradicting the optimal readout view. This misaligned choice information allows the feedforward sensory information to coexist with the decision-making process. The time course of these signals suggest that this misaligned contribution likely is feedback from the downstream areas.
This new insight postulates how neural systems can maintain a mixed representation while allowing learning and adaptation.
coauthors: Yuan Zhao,  Department of Neurobiology and Behavior, Stony Brook University; Jacob L. Yates,  Brain and Cognitive Science, University of Rochester; Aaron J. Levi,  Center for Perceptual Systems, Departments of Neuroscience & Psychology,The University of Texas at Austin; Alexander C. Huk,  Center for Perceptual Systems, Departments of Neuroscience & Psychology, The University of Texas at Austin; Il Memming Park,  Department of Neurobiology and Behavior, Stony Brook University
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Proprioception After Stroke - A Complicated Relationship with Motor Control and Visual Feedback
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: The Sense of Joint Agency in Sensorimotor Interaction
abstract:
Computational models have provided important contributions to unveiling the mechanisms underlying individual action and the sense of self agency – the subjective feeling of being in control of our own actions. The development of computational models is even more necessary to understand the mechanisms underlying joint actions and the subjective experiences of control which emerge during this kind of situations. 
Understanding the partner and choosing mutually satisfactory strategies are key components in joint action and in the development of the sense of joint agency. The development of a partner representation is incorporated in the process of state estimation and, with the body predictions, determines the selection of the control strategies. Game theory - the study of strategic interaction of self-interested agents – constitutes a natural extension of optimal control when multiple agents are involved.
Here we propose a modular computational architecture, which integrates the classical motor control theories - optimal estimation and optimal control - and extends them to reconcile the sense of self and joint agency during interactions. 
Models and simulations based on optimal estimation and game theory provide insights regarding what we represent of a partner, which strategies we adopt and how these strategies evolve with time and training during joint action. They also provide a conceptual basis for extending the notion of self agency to that of joint agency. 
The sense of agency is described in probabilistic terms, as a dynamic decision process, which continuously evaluates the assumptions underlying each observer-controller pair of the proposed modular architecture. Agency relates to reasoning about ourselves: our role in the action, the perceived features of our body and environment, presence of additional partners or opponents; their actions and intentions. During movements, the sense of agency gates each control signal thus providing the basis for optimal action selection.
coauthors: Vinil T. Chackochan, Bournemoth University; Vittorio Sanguineti, University of Genoa
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Neural measures of subsequent memory reflect endogenous variability in cognitive function
abstract:
Human cognition exhibits a striking degree of variability: Sometimes we rapidly forge new associations whereas at other times new information simply does not stick. Correlations between neural activity during encoding and subsequent retrieval performance have implicated such "subsequent memory effects" (SMEs) as important for understanding the neural basis of memory formation. Uncontrolled variability in external factors that also predict memory performance, however, confounds the interpretation of these effects. By controlling
for a comprehensive set of external variables, we investigated the extent to which neural correlates of successful memory encoding
reflect variability in endogenous brain states. We show that external variables that reliably predict memory performance have relatively
small effects on electroencephalographic (EEG) correlates of successful memory encoding. Instead, the brain activity that is
diagnostic of successful encoding primarily reflects fluctuations in endogenous neural activity. These findings link neural activity during learning to endogenous states that drive variability in human cognition.
coauthors: Christoph T. Weidemann, Swansea University & Columbia University; Michael J. Kahana, University of Pennsylvania
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Surprisingly little evidence for task- or belief-dependent signals in macaque V1
abstract: We set out to test two general predictions of how approximate Bayesian inference may manifest in sensory neural activity: that choice probabilities and noise correlations contain significant feedback components reflecting variability in posterior beliefs about a category. Specifically, a general prediction of optimal Bayesian learning and inference is excess choice-related variability in the direction of neural sensitivity, f’ (Lange & Haefner 2020). We trained two macaque monkeys to switch between two coarse orientation discrimination tasks while we recorded simultaneously from dozens of V1 units using planar 10x10 multi-electrode arrays. This is a rich dataset, including neural data recorded over the course of learning and while monkeys randomly switched discrimination tasks, cued at the start of each trial. Despite our original goal of extending previous experimental results on purported feedback both in choice probabilities and in noise correlations (Cohen & Newsome 2008, Nienborg & Cumming 2014, Rabinowitz et al 2015, Haefner et al 2016, Bondy et al 2018), we failed to find both main effects. Our experiment design and analysis pipeline include numerous stages designed to reduce possible confounds, such as the selection of neurons with diverse tuning properties, automatic outlier detection, spike detection designed to minimize spurious coincident spikes across channels, and regression methods that account for both pseudo-replication and measurement error. We were also able to recover post-mortem histology from these animals and thus assign each electrode on the array to a cortical layer. Our results on choice probabilities are consistent with Jasper et al (2019), who similarly used electrode arrays in V1. We invite further discussion of possible methodological or theoretical failures both on our part and on the part of earlier studies. Alternatively, we may conclude that choice-related signals in V1 are weaker or contain different structure than previously thought.
coauthors: Camille Gomez-Laberge, Harvard Medical School; Ariana Sherdil, Harvard Medical School; Richard Born, Harvard Medical School; Ralf Haefner, University of Rochester
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Reward modulates cortical representations of action
abstract: People are capable of rapid improvements in action performance when they are presented with large prospective incentive cues. The neural mechanism by which this performance enhancement occurs remains unclear. We investigated this phenomenon by offering prospective offers of monetary reward to human participants, contingent on their successful production of sequential actions. We found that people executed cued actions more quickly and accurately when they were offered large rewards. Reward offers were associated with elevated activity throughout the brain and fine-grained patterns in these regions encoded information about future action. Follow-up analyses provided evidence that action-coding in action preparation regions of the frontal lobe enhanced by reward and related to subsequent performance. This work sheds light on the neurocognitive mechanisms underlying the incentive-motivated performance of action, suggesting that it may depend critically on the fidelity of prospective action representations in the frontal lobe.
coauthors: Tyler Adkins, University of Michigan Department of Psychology; Taraz Lee, University of Michigan Department of Psychology.
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Exploring the CellF
abstract:
from http://guybenary.com/work/cellf/

CellF is the world’s first neural synthesiser. Its “brain” is made of biological neural networks that grow in a Petri dish and controls in real time it’s “body” that is made of an array of analogue modular synthesizers that work in synergy with it and play with human musicians. It is a completely autonomous instrument that consists of a neural network that is bio-engineered from my own cells that control a custom-built synthesizer. There is no programming or computers involved, only biological matter and analogue circuits; a ‘wet-analogue’ instrument.

There is a surprising similarity in the way neural networks and analogue modular synthesizers function, in that for both, voltages are passed through components to produce data or sound. The neural interface we developed juxtaposes these two networks and in a sense creates a continuum that creates one unified network. With CellF, the musician and musical instrument become one entity to create a cybernetic musician, a rock star in a petri dish.

...
theme: Theme F: History, Education and Society

title: The color of the flash attenuates its mislocalization in the flash-jump illusion
abstract: Recent studies have demonstrated the modulatory role of task-irrelevant color on higher-level cognitive tasks involving response inhibition. In this study, we investigated whether color also affects visual perception earlier in the visual processing hierarchy, using the flash-jump illusion. In this illusion when an apparent motion stimulus, i.e. a rectangular bar appearing at different locations along a trajectory, changes color at a single position, observers perceive this color change as occurring farther along the trajectory of motion. This mislocalization error has been shown to be dependent on responses in area V4, an intermediate stage in the ventral visual stream. Our results demonstrated that the color of the flash modulated the magnitude of the flash-jump effect such that participants reported less of a shift, i.e. a more veridical flash location, for both red and blue flashes, as compared to green and yellow. This pattern of color effects was present for both accuracy and precision in localizing the flash. Given that neural correlates of the flash jump effect are found in area V4, our findings suggest that color-dependent modulations of perceptual processes can occur as early as the intermediate stages of visual processing. Since the color of the flash affected its localization, these color modulations must be inherent and automatic in visual processing.
coauthors: Heather Jordan, York University; Mazyar Fallah, York University
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: I would have found it by now: Metacognitive contributions to search termination
abstract: When searching for a target object among distractors, a robust finding in cognitive science is that search time varies as a function of the number of distractors and their similarity to the target object. This is true not only for the time taken to say a target is present, but also for the time taken to terminate a search and conclude that a target object is absent. However, while models of visual search have successfully characterized contributions to target detection (such as salience or pop-out), the mechanisms underpinning when to terminate a search and conclude that a target is absent are poorly understood. In other words, when do people decide to give up and conclude that nothing is there? One hypothesis is that efficient search termination involves metacognitive knowledge such as the expected difficulty of the search, target salience, or fluctuations in one’s attentional state. By focusing on the first few trials in a visual search task in a large online sample, here we control participants’ ability to base their search termination on metacognitive knowledge before engaging with the task, and to directly measure the effect of experience on the shaping of this knowledge. In a first pilot experiment (N=181), we find a qualitative change in search termination efficiency before and after experiencing finding a target, in line with a metacognitive learning account.
coauthors: Stephen M. Fleming
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: The strategy of learning a new visuomotor skill and the underlying neural mechanisms are age-dependent
abstract: Motor learning is accompanied by experience-dependent neural plasticity of motor-related areas in the brain. Oscillatory brain activity in the alpha and beta frequency bands has been identified as a possible neural marker of this process. Although an age-specific increase in desynchronization of alpha and beta power during movement is frequently reported, if and how old age affects functional reorganization after a period of motor practice is incompletely understood. Therefore, the aim of the current study was to determine the effects of age on task-related brain activation before and after motor skill acquisition and at 24-h retention of a mirror star tracing task. We used electroencephalography (EEG) to assess task-related power (TR-Power) in the alpha (8-12 Hz) and beta (12-30 Hz) frequency bands before, immediately after and 24-h after motor practice of a mirror star tracing task in younger (N=36, age=21.1±1.3yr) and older (N=36, age=70.4±4.1yr) adults. While both speed and accuracy of the motor task improved directly after practice in both age groups, younger adults only consolidated improvements in speed, whereas older adults only consolidated improvements in accuracy. In younger adults, task-related power was observed in the hemisphere contralateral to the practicing right hand, while older adults showed a more bilateral activation pattern. There was an increase in task-related alpha and beta desynchronization immediately, but not 24h after practice, indicative of early neural plasticity. Interestingly, this change in desynchronization after practice was larger for older compared to younger adults. Together, these results indicate that both the strategy for learning a mirror star tracing task as well as the underlying neural mechanisms are age-dependent.
coauthors: Simone R. Caljouw, University Medical Center Groningen; Menno P. Veldman, KU Leuven; Natasha M. Maurits, University Medical Center Groningen; John C. Rothwell, University College London; Tibor Hortobágyi, University Medical Center Groningen
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Spontaneous shifts of arousal state shape behavior in perceptual decision-making
abstract: Arousal levels perpetually rise and fall to control behavior. While extreme arousal states clearly indicate behavioral extremes, from sleep to escape from danger, little is known about the behavioral relevance of intermediate arousal levels fluctuating spontaneously in waking humans. Here, we simultaneously monitored magnetoencephalography and pupil size in healthy volunteers (N=24) at rest and during a perceptual decision-making task with long inter-trial intervals. We first identified how the two commonly used markers of arousal - pupil size and spectral power of brain activity – relate to one another at rest, and then show how prestimulus fluctuations in these markers shape subsequent perceptual decisions. We found that spontaneously varying pupil size correlates with power of brain activity in all frequency bands and in all large-scale cortical networks. Prestimulus pupil size correlates with subsequent shifts in detection bias (c) and sensitivity (d’), which was fully explained by large-scale spectral power variation. When dissociated from pupil-linked state, delta power of dorsal attention and default networks predicts bias and alpha power of visual network predicts sensitivity. Spontaneous pupil constriction and dilation events correlate with large-scale brain activity as well, but not with behavior. Our results illuminate the large-scale electrophysiological neural correlates of pupil-linked arousal and show the effects of arousal states on human perceptual decision-making.
coauthors: Ella Podvalny; Leana E. King; Biyu J. He
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Representation learning for neural population activity with Neural Data Transformers
abstract:
Neural populations are theorized to have an underlying dynamical structure which drives the evolution of population activity over time. This structure can be explicitly modeled with recurrent neural networks (RNNs), leading to state of the art modeling methods such as latent factor analysis via dynamical systems (LFADS). 

However, explicitly modeling a recurrent state can require sequential processing of recorded activity, slowing real-time applications such as brain-computer interfaces or closed-loop control of network states. Here we introduce the Neural Data Transformer (NDT), a non-recurrent alternative. Its non-recurrence enables 3ms inference, comfortably within the loop time of real-time applications. In contrast, common LFADS inference times exceed 24 ms.

Though the NDT lacks an explicit dynamics model, it can still predict dynamical activity. We first evaluate the NDT on large synthetic datasets (i.e. an order of magnitude larger than real-world data) with autonomous dynamics of varying complexity. Here, the NDT accurately infers neural firing rates with performance that matches LFADS (i.e., within 1% R2). Further, we develop an NDT variant that better models non-autonomous dynamics. When tested on firing rate inference of synthetic data with unpredictable perturbations, the NDT achieves 0.73 R2, approaching the 0.83 R2 of LFADS. Finally, to test performance in smaller real-world datasets, we apply the NDT to motor cortical data from a monkey performing a reaching task. We show that the NDT uncovers representations that enable behavioral decoding within 15% of the performance achieved by LFADS, outperforming spike-smoothing.

Though the NDT’s speed and competent accuracy is already useful, the NDT is a forward-looking proposal. Transformers have attracted much attention in deep learning communities for their ability to scale to larger datasets and longer timescales than RNNs. We anticipate that new recording technologies, along with dataset standardization and aggregation, will further improve the NDT’s performance and applicability.
coauthors: Chethan Pandarinath, Emory University and Georgia Institute of Technology
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Data-driven discovery of dynamical relationships within electroencephalographic spectra in sleep
abstract:
Sleep is a decidedly nonstationary and multiplex process, and its dynamics, as measured by electroencephalography, are marked by the coupled evolution of bandlimited activities. Many of these activities are tied to neurological processes involved in regeneration, learning and memory consolidation, and an open question in sleep epidemiology is how best to compactly quantify an individual's sleep dynamics in a data-driven manner, for demographic analysis. 

To address this question, we first apply a “cool-start” nonnegative matrix factorization technique to separate epoch-level spectrograms into nonindependent, nonstationary time and frequency factors. The frequency factors recapitulate classical frequency bands with well-known demographic correlates, but they also admit variability in these bands across individuals. The temporal factors are found suitable for fitting systems of ordinary differential equations, which can compactly describe how the frequency factors evolve and influence one another. 

We first apply this approach to data from the childhood adenotonsillectomy study (n=464), a publicly available sleep dataset. During the sleep onset period, highly significant linear differential interactions are found among individualized sigma, delta, and beta factors, essentially blindly confirming a previous model of those interactions. However, we find little evidence that sleep onset dynamics are trait-like in this sample. To conclude, we discuss several challenges in the method's implementation to sleep data at the epidemiological scale, as well as further potential applications to cross-species homology, sleep microarchitecture, and neural time-series outside sleep.
coauthors: Shaun Purcell, Harvard Medical School
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Effects of Traumatic Brain Injury on the structure of BA4a and BA4p
abstract:
Introduction: ALS is a universally fatal neurodegenerative disorder with no effective treatment. Recent reports (NEJM) suggest that subjects with traumatic brain injury (TBI) are 4 times more likely to develop ALS than non-TBI subjects. It is not clear why TBI should increase the incidence of ALS. The cortico-motoneurones - which originate in the posterior part of the motor cortex (BA4p) - have long been implicated in ALS. It is conceivable that TBI selectively damages BA4p that predisposes individuals to ALS. We hypothesised that subjects with TBI would have low grey matter density in the left BA4p compared to BA4a in TBI patients versus non-TBI. 

Methods: We used the open ADNI-DOD data set (https://ida.loni.usc.edu/login.jsp?project=ADNIDOD). Vietnam War Veterans (mean age = 68.8, ADNI-DOD) with a history of war-related TBI (n=55) and those without TBI (n=34) were included in the study. We initially explored the parcellation of the motor cortex into BA4a and BA4p regions from Freesurfer (5.3.0). 

Results: Our preliminary results show the total BA4 thickness in the left hemisphere was smaller, but does not show a significant decrease in thickness (t = 0.731, p-value = 0.4667) in TBI versus nTBI. The cortical thickness in the LH BA4p seem to show more thinning however this was not statistically significant compared to the LH BA4a or to control regions, in the initial sMRI analysis (BA4p, t = 1.2546, p-value = 0.2136; BA4a, t = 1.2546, p-value = 0.9503)

Conclusions: We report that the structures of the subdivisions of BA4 are differentially affected by TBI, implicating that the BA4p structure may be more critical in the development of motor neurone disease. 
Results are preliminary-Future work will refine this further by examining the subdivision of the motor cortex using other imaging modalities suggest at fMRI & DTI.
coauthors: Nikhil Sharma, University College London, Francesco Grillo, University College London
theme: Theme A: Development, Neurodegenerative Disorders and Injury

title: Stability and Control of Walking at Various Speed-Slope Combinations
abstract: Walking on sloped surfaces is a common part of navigating our streets and buildings. Understanding sloped walking is especially important because slopes are common as an alternative to stairs for people with disabilities. Persons with lower-limb disability are not able to adjust their gait to walk on slopes without direct neural control (Rábago et al. 2016). While past work has explored the differences in biomechanics between sloped and level ground walking (Pickle et al. 2016), there is very little work in understanding gait stability and control in walking on slopes. Here, we investigate how the foot placement control strategies used on level ground walking (Wang and Srinivasan, 2014) are modulated when walking on a slope. Using human subject experiments and computer simulations, we investigate how deviations in the center of mass states occurring due to small intrinsic perturbations, are corrected using foot placement during sloped walking. We collected kinematic data on healthy humans while walking on an inclined-treadmill during ascent for several speed-slope combinations. We fit linear models between hip states at mid-stance and the next foot position to infer control strategies of sloped walking. Furthermore, we simulated a walking controller using experimentally obtained linear coefficients on a computational point-mass telescoping leg model. The linear models and computer simulations show what aspects of the controller are preserved (foot placement control) and what aspects change (push-off or power stroke) as humans walk stably up a range of slopes. These findings will inform control of prosthetic limbs by providing a human-derived controller that is stable on both level-ground and slopes.
coauthors: Manoj Srinivasan, The Ohio State University; Nidhi Seethapathi, University of Pennsylvania
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Reductions in Parkinson’s Disease symptoms and alpha rhythm modulations as a result of multinetwork learning to music over 3-years.
abstract: Parkinson’s Disease (PD) has a fast progression of motor dysfunction within the first 5 years with annual rates of decline of 5.2 to 8.9 points on the MDS-Unified Parkinson’s Disease Rating Scale (UPDRS).  We aimed to extend research on the short-term benefits of Dance for PD and determine improvements over 3 years while participating in weekly classes. We collected EEG, mood (PANAS-X), cognitive (MMSE, PD-NMS & MDS-UPDRS Parts I, II & IV) and motor (MDS-UPDRS Part III) assessments with the goal to examine a continuous PD long-term program that can serve to compliment traditional medical treatments and examine whether disease progression is modified.  We conducted two studies: (1) examined the short-term benefits of dance (N=17) and (2) measured PD symptom progression over a 3-year period (N=32). Our results indicated that rsEEG global alpha power was highest after a single dance class in comparison to before, F(1,26) = 6.928, p < .025, η2 = .210. Individuals with PD participating in 3-yrs of dance showed no progression of motor symptoms across time (p=0.817).  Further no impairment was shown for daily living (p=0.329), motor experiences of daily living (p=0.540) and for non-motor complications (p=0.390).  To examine disease progression directly in our cohort, we matched data from Parkinson’s Progression Markers Initiative as our non-dance PD comparison group (PD-MJFF-Com).  A significant Group (PD-Dancers and PD-MJFF-Com) by Days interaction showed that PD who train in dance have less motor impairment (M=18.75) than PD-MJFF-Com who do not dance (M=24.61) and over time (p< 0.05). As expected, and in stark contrast to our PD-Dancers the PD-MJFF-Com showed motor impairment (UPDRS III) across time (p< 0.01). UPDRS I and II showed disease progression of PD over time (p<0.005), and (p<0.01), whereas UPDRS IV showed no progression (p= 0.365) over the same 2-year period.  Thus, multinetwork training to music is effective at slowing motor and non-motor PD symptoms.
coauthors: Joseph F. X. DeSouza
theme: Theme A: Development, Neurodegenerative Disorders and Injury

title: The Social Neuroscience of empathy - from shared affect to self-other distinction
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Neurophysiological Correlates of Dual Tasking in People with Parkinson’s Disease and Freezing of Gait
abstract:
Objective: Freezing of gait in people with Parkinson’s disease (PwP) is associated with executive dysfunction and motor preparation deficits. We have recently shown that electrophysiological markers of motor preparation, rather than decision-making, differentiate PwP with freezing of gait (FOG+) and without (FOG-) while sitting. To examine the effect of locomotion on these results, we measured behavioural and electrophysiological responses in PwP with and without FOG during a target response time task while sitting (single-task) and stepping-in-place (dual-task).  
Methods: Behavioural and electroencephalographic data were acquired from 18 PwP (eight FOG+) and seven young controls performing the task while sitting and stepping in place. 
Results: FOG+ had slower response times while stepping compared with sitting. However, response times were significantly faster while stepping compared with sitting for controls. Electrophysiological responses showed no difference in decision-making potentials (Centroparietal Positivity) between groups or conditions but there were differences in neurophysiological markers of response inhibition (N2) and motor preparation (Lateralized Readiness Potential, LRP) in FOG+ while performing a dual-task. 
Conclusion: This suggests that the addition of a second complex motor task (stepping-in-place) impacts automatic allocation of resources in FOG+, resulting in delayed response times.  The impact of locomotion on the generation of the N2 and LRP potentials, particularly in freezers, indirectly implies that these functions compete with locomotion for resources. 
Significance: In the setting of multiple complex tasks or cognitive impairment, severe motor dysfunction may result, leading to freezing of gait.
coauthors: John S. Butler, School of Mathematical Sciences, Technological University Dublin, Kevin Street, Dublin, Ireland; Conor Fearon,Trinity Centre for Bioengineering, Trinity College, The University of Dublin, Dublin 2, Ireland; Saskia M. Waechter, Trinity Centre for Bioengineering, Trinity College, The University of Dublin, Dublin 2, Ireland;  Isabelle Killane, School of Mechanical and Design Engineering, Technological University Dublin, Kevin Street, Dublin, Ireland; Simon P. Kelly, 6School of Electrical & Electronic Engineering, University College Dublin, Dublin 4, Ireland; Richard B. Reilly,Trinity Centre for Bioengineering, Trinity College, The University of Dublin, Dublin 2, Ireland; & Timothy Lynch, Dublin Neurological Institute at the Mater Misericordiae University Hospital, Dublin 7, Ireland
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Chronic intermittent theta burst stimulation (iTBS) effects on adult hippocampal neurogenesis in males and females
abstract: Intermittent theta burst stimulation (iTBS) is a promising form of non-invasive stimulation therapy for a variety of psychiatric illnesses. Currently iTBS is administered similarly across males and females, but it is not known whether iTBS’s mechanism of action is affected by patient sex. As hippocampal neurogenesis plays a critical role in stress adaptation and antidepressant course of action, we examined adult hippocampal neurogenesis in male and female mice following a chronic iTBS protocol similar to those used in the clinics. Although chronic iTBS does not exert dramatic effects on neurogenesis, we found that there is a trend for greater population of immature neurons after iTBS in males, but not females. Females do not respond to iTBS with respect to any hippocampal neurogenesis related measures. There is no effect on iTBS on survival of neurons born one week before stimulation for either sex. We also examined the morphology of new-born neurons and found that iTBS produced a trend for slight decrease in spines in stimulated animals compared to sham stimulated animals. New neurons generated in either sex have a normal morphology, similar to non-stimulated control animals, with the exception of females overall have lower total dendritic length compared to males. Otherwise, all comparisons between male and female new-born neurons are consistent with each other, indicating that baseline neurogenesis levels and new-born neuron morphological features are comparable between sexes. Our findings suggest that iTBS’s primary target on neuroplasticity may not be adult hippocampal neurogenesis, however there may be physiological differences of new-born neurons that are influenced by iTBS that remains to be further explored.
coauthors: Tian Rui Zhang; Baran Askari; Aydan Kesici; Evelyn Guilherme; Fidel Vila-Rodriguez; Jason Snyder
theme: Theme A: Development, Neurodegenerative Disorders and Injury

title: Does functional connectivity reflect anatomical connectivity? A simulation study
abstract:
The human brain is a complicated network of 100 billion neurons connected by 100 trillion synapses. Experiments attempting to calculate connectivity typically quantify “functional connectivity,” or large-scale statistical correlations in activity between brain regions. Despite the prevalence of functional connectivity studies in neuroscience, there is no clear understanding of how it relates to anatomical synaptic connectivity. In this work we develop a platform to characterize the relationship between the two forms of connectivity.
	Our platform consists of a large-scale (>100,000 neuron) simulation of virtual neurons with connectivity structure mimicking that of a section of primate cortex. This simulation generates readouts of voltages at surface and intracortical locations, analogous to how local-field potential (LFP) recordings are sampled from the cortex via electrodes. The model corresponds to a section of primate cortex of size 1.5mm x 1.5mm x 2.6mm, which is on the order of recent experiments quantifying functional connectivity between electrodes on a neural implant, such as between Utah array electrodes (Bloch 2019). The model is developed using VERTEX (Tomsett 2015), and the connectivity structure is largely informed by (Binzegger 2004).
        Using our platform we calculate functional connectivity metrics from the recorded LFP signals and compare them to the virtual anatomical connectivity specified by the model. We first compute anatomical connectivity strength between distinct electrode locations. We then compute standard functional connectivity metrics such as coherence and Granger causality from the LFP signals collected from the electrodes, and use correlational analysis to investigate their relationship. 
        Functional connectivity is a contentious topic in neuroscience. Although studies investigating functional connectivity are widespread, its synaptic underpinnings remain mysterious. In this work we develop a computational platform to calculate functional and anatomical connectivity in a biorealistic virtual brain, and characterize their relationship to a degree that until now has been impossible.
coauthors: Julien Bloch, University of Washington; Eric Shea-Brown, University of Washington; Azadeh Yazdan-Shahmorad, University of Washington
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: AR spatial test for AD diagnosis
abstract: Alzheimer’s disease (AD) has been around for more than a hundred years, and so far, there is still no cure. However, the disease can be slowed down significantly if detected in its early stages. The problem is that it can only be detected through expensive means like MRI and PET scanning. Therefore, there is an increasing need to find new methods for the diagnosis of Alzheimer’s in its presymptomatic phase. This presents some challenges because the disease is thought to start way before clinical symptoms emerge. We therefore propose a new generation of realistic cognitive tests that can target early cognitive deficits of dementia much better than conventional tests used in the clinic. In particular, we propose to use Augmented Reality (AR) which can open the door for much more flexibility in designing and monitoring these tasks remotely.
coauthors: Sandy Rihana, USEK
theme: Theme A: Development, Neurodegenerative Disorders and Injury

title: Clusters of Müller glia display sporadic radial burst of activity after eye opening
abstract:
Müller glia are an import populations of cells in the retina mediating  a wide array of functions including immune response, neurotransmitter recycling, structural support, metabolic support and light-guidance. Although they have been known to connect to each other via gap junctions, their ability to propagate waves of activity, similar to retinal and cortical astrocytes, has never been demonstrated. 
We characterized the live spontaneous calcium dynamics of neurons and glia throughout the layers of murine retinas expressing GCaMP6f in neurons and glia (under the NG2 promoter) at key developmental stages: Stage II retinal Waves (P10-11), Eye opening (P14-15), Early vision (P20-22), and Adult Vision (P60-90). Calcium dynamics were imaged using multiphoton microscopy on live ex-vivo retinal explants of 6 mice per condition.
Groups of Muller glia displayed spontaneous burst of calcium fluorescence, in a coordinated manner, and displaying a radial propagation profile. These spontaneous coordinated events were abolished by the pharmacological application of glutamate antagonists, indicating a potential point of origin. Interestingly, these events only appeared regularly after eye opening. In the 9 explants (n = 6 mice) investigated aged P10-11, only 1 such event was observed, whilst they displayed average frequencies over 0.12 (± 0.03 SEM) events/min after eye opening. 
Our investigations provide a novel observation in an understudied cell-type which could lead to a better understanding of the signaling between neurons and glia in visual signal processing of the retina.
coauthors: Cyril Eleftheriou, Burke Neurological Institute; Carlo Corona, Burke Neurological Institute; Paola Bianchimano, Burke Neurological Institute; Elena Ivanova, Burke Neurological Institute; Botir Sagdullaev, Burke Neurological Institute
theme: Theme A: Development, Neurodegenerative Disorders and Injury

title: MEG visual gamma oscillations reflect individual differences in sensory sensitivity
abstract: Visual gamma oscillations arise through interplay between excitatiory (E) and inhibitory (I) neurons  in the brain and are characterized by high reliability and heritability. Therefore gamma oscillations in the visual cortex were proposed as a biomarker of E/I balance, which is related to neural processing and is disturbed in many psychiatric conditions. Little is known, however, about how gamma oscillations are related to individual differences in perception, and in particular, how it is related to sensitivity to sensory stimuli. In a recent magnetoencephalography (MEG) study in a sample of neurotypical males and in males with ASD we found that less efficient gamma response (GR) suppression in response to increase of motion of high-contrast gratings is associated with greater sensory sensitivity to stimuli in the everyday life. In this MEG study we replicated this result in a sample of neurotypical females. We found that efficacy of GR attenuation by  visual stimuli of different intensity predicts individual differences in sensory sensitivity. This finding extends our previous result and demonstrates that the observed correlation is not sex-specific. Besides, this suggests that intensity-related changes in power of gamma oscillations may provide useful information about E/I balance in the visual cortex.
coauthors: E.N. Rostovtseva, Center for Neurocognitive Research (MEG Center) of MSUPE; A.O. Prokofiev, Center for Neurocognitive Research (MEG Center) of MSUPE; T.A. Stroganova, Center for Neurocognitive Research (MEG Center) of MSUPE; E.O. Orekhova, Center for Neurocognitive Research (MEG Center) of MSUPE
institution: National Research University Higher School of Economics (grid.410682.9)
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Excitatory vestibular interneuron identity is spatiotemporally organized and develops independently of motoneurons in the larval zebrafish
abstract: Neural circuits must achieve precise wiring between distinct cell subtypes to produce appropriate behaviors. Identity specification and wiring precision in the circuit that stabilizes gaze is a particular case of this general developmental problem. Vertebrates stabilize gaze using excitatory vestibular interneurons that relay head and body destabilization to motoneurons that counter-rotate the eyes. Precise connectivity between directionally-sensitive interneuron subtypes and particular motoneurons is therefore crucial for behavior. The developmental mechanisms that specify excitatory vestibular interneuron identity and connectivity are unresolved, though previous work has suggested a role for spatiotemporal cues and/or motoneuron-derived factors. We tested these hypotheses in the tangential nucleus (TAN) of the larval zebrafish, which contains the excitatory vestibular interneurons necessary for vertical gaze stabilization. We first developed an assay using 2-photon and swept, confocally-aligned planar excitation (SCAPE) microscopy to rapidly and reliably define functional nose-up and nose-down vestibular interneuron subtypes. We used this assay to ask whether functional subtypes are spatiotemporally organized and discovered functional organization complementary to spatiotemporal development. Our results are the first demonstration of functional sub-organization within a vestibular nucleus and reflect a putative role for spatiotemporal factors in identity specification. Next, to investigate the requirement of motoneuron-derived signals for TAN identity specification, we used these functional assays to measure changes in TAN identity following constitutive motoneuron knockouts. Our results demonstrate that TAN functional identity and organization is preserved in the absence of motoneurons, arguing against a role for motoneuron-derived cues. Taken together, we predict that spatiotemporally-linked factors organize TAN subtypes into dorsoventral and rostrocaudal microdomains. We propose that functional identity acquisition and organization occurs in a motoneuron-independent manner.
coauthors: Marie R. Greaney, New York University; Basak Rosti, New York University; Venkatakaushik Voleti, Columbia University; Citlali Perez Campos, Columbia University; Kripa B. Patel, Columbia University; Wenze Li, Columbia University; Elizabeth M.C. Hillman, Columbia University; David Schoppik, New York University
theme: Theme A: Development, Neurodegenerative Disorders and Injury

title: Vagolytic effect of Zolpidem on Sleep-dependent Memory: A Trade-off between Working Memory and Long-term Memory
abstract: Sleep benefits learning, including long-term memory (LTM) and working memory (WM). However, it’s unclear whether sleep features of central nervous system (CNS) and autonomic nervous system (ANS) causally interplay in supporting different types of sleep-dependent cognitive enhancement. Here, we used Zolpidem to manipulate spindles (measured by sigma power) and vagal activity (measured by high-frequency HRV; HF) and investigated the trade-off between improvement in LTM and WM performance. We used a double-blind, placebo-controlled within-subjects design (N=38; Mage = 20.85 ± 2.97 years, 19 Females) to test if Zolpidem increases performance on a word paired-associates task by boosting spindles, while decrease performance on the operation-span WM task by suppressing vagal tone, during the night of sleep. We explored the impact of Zolpidem on ANS profiles during sleep and showed that Zolpidem increased heart rate and decreased vagal activity during sleep, suggesting a vagolytic effect. Also, Zolpidem increased LTM retention but decreased overnight WM improvement, compared to Placebo. We found a positive correlation between WM improvement and vagal activity, while a negative correlation between LTM retention and vagal activity, suggested a functional role of vagal activity on WM and LTM. Using effective connectivity, we showed that Zolpidem increased the causal effect of sigma on HF. Such causal information flow was correlated with the difference between overnight LTM and WM changes: the more sigma’s causal effect over HF, the more hippocampal-dependent sleep benefits (LTM) than the prefrontal-dependent task (WM). These findings suggested a causal role of vagal activity on sleep-dependent cognition, and an antagonist role of spindles and vagal activity, which implicates a trade-off between LTM and WM processing during sleep.
coauthors: Hamid Niknazar, University of California Irvine; Lauren N. Whitehurst, University of California San Francisco; Sara C. Mednick, University of California Irvine
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: A Neural Coactivity Code for Dynamic Memory
abstract: Information is encoded in the combined activity of multiple neurons. Notably, millisecond-timescale coactivity provides fundamental building blocks for some neural codes. Such short-timescale coactivity binds neurons with related tuning to external variables, giving rise to population-based representations congruent with those of their participating neurons. Alternatively, groups of neurons that are not individually tuned to a given variable may nevertheless encode such a variable as a function of their coactivity. While this type of emergent coding has been described for physically well-defined variables such as specific sensory inputs and actions, its possible cognitive function has not been explored. Here we show that coactivity-based representations provide a neural code for dynamic memories, where animals rapidly learn and flexibly retrieve short-lived behavioural contingencies every day. We trained mice to discriminate two new behavioural contingencies each day, while monitoring and manipulating neural ensembles in the hippocampal CA1. We found that short-timescale coactivity contained robust contingency information. Unlike coactivity patterns encoding space, which comprised neurons with overlapping place fields, coactivity-based contingency discrimination was unrelated to the tuning of individual neurons but instead an emergent property of their combined activity. Such millisecond, but not longer, timescale coactivity was flexibly reinstated to predict trial-by-trial memory performance. Moreover, optogenetic suppression of synaptic inputs from the upstream CA3 region selectively during learning impaired coactivity-based contingency information in CA1 and subsequent dynamic memory retrieval. These findings show that short-timescale coactivity stitches together individually untuned neurons to represent abstract, task-relevant variables in support of dynamic memory retrieval. Millisecond coactivity-based representations may preferentially exhibit the rapid dynamics needed to mnemonically process short-lived cognitive variables.
coauthors: Hayley M Reeve; Vítor Lopes-dos-Santos; Natalia Campo-Urriza; Pavel V Perestenko; Alexander Morley; Lauren Strickland; István P Lukács; Ole Paulsen; David Dupret
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Hebbian plasticity in parallel synaptic pathways: A circuit mechanism for systems memory consolidation
abstract:
Systems memory consolidation can transfer declarative memories which initially depend on the hippocampal formation into long-term memory traces in neocortical networks. This consolidation process is thought to involve the replay of recently acquired memories, but the cellular and network mechanisms that mediate the memory transfer are poorly understood. Here, we suggest that systems memory consolidation could arise from Hebbian plasticity in networks with parallel synaptic pathways — two ubiquitous features of neural circuits in the brain.
We explore this hypothesis in a computational model and show that it is in quantitative agreement with lesion studies in rodents and that the mechanism can be hierarchically iterated to yield power-law forgetting as observed in psychophysical studies in humans.
Further, we show that the proposed mechanism can lead to the forgetting of episodic details in memories and the extraction of semantic generalizations, whereby neural replay enhances the speed of consolidation and can even be necessary for the extraction of semantic memories.
Finally, we hypothesize that the hierarchical iteration of the mechanism may provide a mechanistic basis for the spatial and temporal gradients of episodic and semantic memories observed in lesion studies, which suggest that episodic content decreases and semantic content increase with distance from the hippocampus.
The predicted circuit mechanism bridges spatial scales from single cells to cortical areas and time scales from milliseconds to years.
coauthors: Michiel Remme, Humboldt-Universität zu Berlin; Urs Bergmann, Humboldt-Universität zu Berlin; Susanne Schreiber, Humboldt-Universität zu Berlin; Henning Sprekeler, Technische Universität; Richard Kempter, Humboldt-Universität zu Berlin
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Learning and attention increase neuronal response selectivity in mouse primary visual cortex through distinct mechanisms
abstract: Response selectivity of cortical neurons can increase for behaviorally relevant stimuli across days as animals learn a novel stimulus-reward association, and across seconds when animals transiently attend to sensory stimuli. While both phenomena can act on the same cortical circuit, it is unknown whether they rely on the same mechanisms. We imaged activity of the same neuronal populations in primary visual cortex as mice learned a visual discrimination task and subsequently performed an attentional switching task. Selectivity changes due to learning and attention were largely uncorrelated at the single-cell level. Selectivity increases after learning were mainly due to selective suppression of responses to one of the task relevant stimuli but relied on both selective enhancement and suppression during attention. Furthermore, learning and attention differentially affected interactions between excitatory and different inhibitory cell classes. Circuit modelling revealed that cell class specific top-down inputs best explained attention modulation, while reorganization of local functional connectivity accounts for specific learning related changes. These results suggest that distinct mechanisms underlie increased discriminability of relevant sensory stimuli across longer and shorter time scales.
coauthors: Jasper Poort; Katharina Wilmes; Antonin Blot; Angus Chadwick; Maneesh Sahani; Claudia Clopath; Thomas Mrsic-Flogel; Sonja Hofer
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: In vivo Perturb-seq: study gene function at scale
abstract: The number of disease risk genes and loci identified through human genetic studies far outstrips our capacity to systematically study their functions. I will discuss our attempt to develop a scalable genetic screen approach, in vivo Perturb-Seq, and apply this method to the functional evaluation of 35 autism spectrum disorder (ASD) de novo loss-of-function risk genes. Using CRISPR-Cas9, we introduced frameshift mutations in these risk genes in pools, within the developing mouse brain in utero, followed by single-cell RNA sequencing of perturbed cells in the postnatal brain. We identified cell type-specific and evolutionarily conserved gene modules from both neuronal and glial cell classes. Recurrent gene modules and cell types are affected across this cohort of perturbations, representing key cellular effects across sets of ASD/ND risk genes. In vivo Perturb-Seq pilots a systems genetics approach to investigate at scale how diverse mutations affect cell types and states in the developing brain, and can be used in various in vivo and in vitro model organisms and systems.
coauthors: Xin Jin, Society of Fellows, Harvard University; Sean K. Simmons, Broad Institute of MIT and Harvard; Ashwin S. Shetty, Department of Stem Cell and Regenerative Biology, Harvard University; Joshua Z. Levin, Broad Institute of MIT and Harvard; Aviv Regev, Broad Institute of MIT and Harvard, MIT; Feng Zhang, Broad Institute of MIT and Harvard, McGovern Institute of Brain Science, MIT; Paola Arlotta, Department of Stem Cell and Regenerative Biology, Harvard University
theme: Theme A: Development, Neurodegenerative Disorders and Injury

title: Synchronization of adaptive networks of Sakaguchi-Kuramoto oscillators
abstract: Sakaguchi-Kuramoto model is a generalization of the well-known Kuramoto model including a phase-lag or frustration parameter. In this work we study the structure and synchronization dynamics of adaptive networks of  Sakaguchi-Kuramoto oscillators based on Hebbian and anti-Hebbian learning rules. We show that following anti-Hebbian learning the structure of network is gradually evolved such that the global synchronization is enhanced. On the other hand,  Hebbian learning  leads to the local synchronization and clustering structure of the network. Moreover, in the presence of frustration the connectivity patterns of the oscillators changes asymmetrically with respect to the mean frequency of the oscillators. In other words, the connectivity patterns of the oscillators with high and low natural frequencies would be different in the evolved networks. Previous studies have also shown that oscillators on the human connectome  follow a hierarchy of timescales, i.e.  highly connected regions have low natural frequencies and peripheral regions have high natural frequencies. In addition, we found that the value of the frustration parameter affects the size and the number of the clusters in the networks that are evolved based on the Hebbian learning rule.
coauthors: Erfan Deris, Institute for Advanced Studies in Basic Sciences; Mina Zarei, Institute for Advanced Studies in Basic Sciences; Nahid Azimi, Institute for Advanced Studies in Basic Sciences;
institution: Institute for Advanced Studies in Basic Sciences (grid.418601.a)
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Population coding of saccadic eye movements by Purkinje cells of the marmoset cerebellum
abstract:
To move accurately, the brain relies on the cerebellum to build internal models that predict the consequences of motor commands. A major difficulty has been to understand the language with which the cerebellum encodes internal models. For example, while damage to the cerebellum impairs the timing of commands that control saccadic eye movements, resulting in dysmetria, activities of individual Purkinje cells (P-cells) have no obvious relationship with the ongoing movement: P-cell activity during saccades are often modulated much longer than movement duration. However, anatomy of the cerebellum suggests that P-cells organize in small groups, together projecting onto a single output nucleus neuron. This anatomy implies that the fundamental computational unit of the cerebellum is not a single P-cell, but a population of P-cells. The critical problem is to identify the membership of each population. We recently hypothesized that P-cells that belong to a single population may be identified by a critical feature: they receive a common error signal from the inferior olive [1,2]. Thus, P-cells that belong to a single population may share the same complex spike tuning. Our earlier work in macaques had found evidence for this conjecture. Here, we tested the generality of this conjecture across primates by recording from the marmoset cerebellum. 
We trained two monkeys [3] to perform visually guided saccades (Fig. 1). To induce errors, we moved the target during the saccade, thus producing a visual prediction error at the offset of a saccade. We used multi-contact electrodes to simultaneously isolate multiple P-cells within and across various lobules of the vermis, finding strong saccade related activity in lobules VIIa and VIIb. We recorded from 110 well-isolated P-cells from two marmosets (65 P-cells from monkey M, 45 P-cells from monkey R), as identified via their simple and complex spikes (Fig. 2). Each P-cell recording included an average of 485±300 (mean±std) correct trials (53,000 total trials). On average, P-cells had simple spike (SS) firing rate of 62.5±17.5 Hz and complex spike (CS) firing rate of 0.85±0.18 Hz (mean±std). We observed that upon presentation of a visual stimulus, the P-cells produced a CS with a probability that depended on the direction of the visual stimulus with respect to the fovea (Fig. 3). That is, each P-cell had a complex spike tuning with respect to stimulus direction. As the saccade took place, we moved the primary target to a random location (Fig. 1B). This induced an error, encouraging the monkey to produce a secondary saccade. The P-cells produced a CS in response to this visual error, and the tuning of CS in the period before the corrective saccade was similar to the tuning with respect to the primary saccade (Fig. 3B). Thus, P-cells in the oculomotor vermis each had preference for a specific visual error (Fig. 3A). In contrast, the SS of individual P-cells were quite diverse: pausing in some directions, bursting in some directions, and a mixture of the two in other directions (Fig. 2B). Critically, SS modulation often outlasted the saccade by about 100ms. Remarkably, when P-cells were organized into a population based on their CS tuning (CS-on), the resulting population response precisely predicted the duration of the saccade (Fig. 4). For example, when the saccade was toward the CS+180 direction, the population response exhibited activity that resembled acceleration of the eyes. 
	In summary, our results demonstrate that across two species of primates, population coding in the cerebellum may be via a collection of P-cells that share the same preference for error. When P-cells that share the same CS tuning are organized into a population, their combined SS response predicts motion of the eye.
coauthors: Paul Hage, Jay Pi, Reza Shadmehr
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Evidence of Social Buffering in Rats Housed in Individually Ventilated Cages (IVCs)
abstract:
Rodent research facilities are increasingly adopting the use of individually ventilated cages (IVCs), despite initial evidence that these hermetically sealed housing units might be inherently stressful. As well, maintaining IVCs under positive air pressure could be more stressful than negative air pressure, in that the former (but not the latter) completely isolates rodents from the smells and sounds of other conspecifics in the colony. We asked if social housing, known to buffer rats’ responses to acute and/or chronic stress, serves a similar, protective role when rodents are housed in IVCs, and further, whether “social buffering” depends on the type of air pressure adopted. Rats were randomly assigned to either single- or paired-housing in each of the two air pressure conditions. After eight weeks in their respective housing condition, rats were tested in the shock-probe burying test, and then their brain tissue was processed to determine oxytocin-immunoreactivity (OT-ir) in the hypothalamus. Independent of air pressure, single-housed rats displayed marked reductions in probe burying relative to pair-housed rats. Given that chronic stress reduces active coping responses, including shock-probe burying, it might be the case that chronic stress-related outcomes linked to IVCs can be buffered by social housing. Our OT findings partially support this, in that the number of OT-ir cells was reduced in the posterior parvocellular region of the PVN of single-housed rats, but only if they were housed under negative air pressure. This suggests that these effects of air pressure condition were buffered by social housing. These findings inform efforts to improve housing conditions for animals used in research.

Acknowledgements: Research Supported by NSERC
coauthors: Benjamin Streatch; Samantha Irwin; Emma Littler; Janet Menard, Queen's University Department of Psychology
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: LFP Phase Synchronization is Predictive of Performance in a Working Memory Task
abstract: Neuronal activity in the primate lateral prefrontal cortex is innately specialized for the representation of visual-spatial information. However, the underlying dynamic changes in neuronal activity during the flexible execution of working memory tasks are still largely unknown. Here, we assess the neural oscillatory rhythms of high-density local field potentials (LFP) recorded using a 64 chronic electrode array implanted in the lateral prefrontal cortex from 225 sessions from two monkey.  Oscillatory dynamics such as distinct and bandlimited phase synchronization at the millisecond range is a ubiquitous signature of neuronal processing for basic and high-order control function. We used weighted-phase lag index (w-PLI) as index of the LFP synchronization. We found that phase synchronization of LFP at the beta frequency (20-35 Hz) oscillations was enhanced during training to perform a working memory task. Neuronal oscillations were more synchronized in the beta frequency range during correct than incorrect trials. Neuronal oscillations in error trials desynchronized especially during the stimulus presentation periods, as compared to baseline period in beta frequency.  The preferred phase is initiated the synchronization or desynchronization of the neural oscillatory dynamics for cognitive control. These findings demonstrate that plastic formation induces in working memory by responsive neural activity. Importantly, these finding suggest the notion that preferred phase in specific frequency strengthen the synchronization among proximal and distal local field potentials.
coauthors: Dr. Mitchell Riley, Wake Forest School of Medicine, Department of Psychology, Vanderbilt University; Dr. Xue-Lian Qi, Wake Forest School of Medicine;Dr. Christos Constantinidis,Wake Forest School of Medicine
theme: Theme D: Cognition, Motivation and Emotion

title: Sensorimotor adaptation by task-irrelevant feedback
abstract: Learning by doing is the first tenet of sensorimotor learning. Some motor learning methods, e.g., observational learning, circumvent physical practice of actions, but they still demand deliberate mental simulation of to-be-learned actions with the aid of task-relevant feedback. Here we demonstrate that people can obtain long-term learning in a sensorimotor adaptation task based on task-irrelevant feedback. Participants were required to control a hand-cursor to reach to a target while ignoring a directionally-deviated cursor (the double cursor) moving simultaneously with the hand. Participants were able to suppress this task-irrelevant cursor's influence and perform the task without any sign of implicit learning or adaptive strategy. However, in delayed retention tests, they adapted significantly faster to a standard visuomotor rotation perturbation than naïve controls. Participants also showed this saving effect if the double cursor moved in the opposite direction of the visuomotor rotation in the retention test, if it moved with a random direction, or if it moved in mirror-symmetrical directions (mirror reaching is widely regarded as a skill acquisition task). Thus, given that the effect is direction-invariant and across-task, it appears that participants abstract the spatial relationship of visuomotor rotation from the double cursor. They did not show any implicit learning or explicit strategy initially, and their savings was supported only by the faster formation of explicit motor strategies.  Furthermore, we found no saving effect if the double cursor was not directionally deviated but amplitude scaled to the actual hand movement, further collaborating that people deduce an angular concept from the task-irrelevant feedback. Hence, sensorimotor adaptation can be facilitated without deliberate practice and without overt behavioral measures such as explicit strategy or aftereffect. While sensorimotor adaptation is widely considered as a combination of explicit strategy and implicit adaptation, our findings suggest that the motor concept, perhaps a third component, might affect adaptation.
coauthors: Kunlin Wei, Yajie Liu, Wanyin Jiang, Yuqing Bi
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Energy landscape analysis of EEG of Alzheimer’s patients reveals alterations of state transitions dynamics
abstract: Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is one of the most common neurodegenerative diseases with around 30 million patients worldwide. Accessible and non-invasive methods of diagnosing and characterising AD are therefore desirable. Electroencephalography (EEG) fulfils these criteria and is often used when studying AD. Several features derived from EEG were shown to be able to predict AD with high accuracies, e.g. signal complexity and synchronisation. However, the dynamics of how the brain transitions between stable states have not been properly studied in case of AD and EEG data. Energy landscape analysis is a method that can be used to quantify these dynamics. This work presents the first application of this method to both AD and EEG. Energy landscape assigns energy value to each possible state, i.e. pattern of activations. The energy is inversely proportional to probability of occurrence. Therefore, high energy states have low probability of occurrence. Studying the features of energy landscapes of 20 AD patients and their healthy age-matched counterparts, significant differences were found. The dynamics of AD patients’ EEG were showed to oscillate between more stable states. Moreover, the pathways used for transitions between stable states in AD patients were found to be longer. Finally, we show that features derived from energy landscapes can potentially be used for predicting AD with high accuracy. The results reported in this work suggest that brains of AD patients adapt to the damage and death of neurons by finding novel albeit suboptimal pathways for transitioning between stable states.
coauthors: Fei He, Coventry University
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Black In Neuro Mentorship Workshops: Getting the most out of your mentor-mentee relationship (Trainee workshop)
abstract:
Note: zoom links for this event will not be posted until shortly before the session. Please refresh the website right before the meeting for the current link.

In this interactive workshop, we will examine the concept of “mentoring up”. Through discussion and case study analysis we will outline effective strategies trainees can use to strategically find and maintain strong mentoring relationships and build communication skills as a means to enhance self-advocacy in your research training and beyond.

Leaders:
- Paige Cooper, PhD

- Johnna Frierson, PhD

title: Local sleep in the waking brain impairs attention: A pharmacological study
abstract:
Local sleep (LS) describes dissociative states in which parts of a globally awake brain show
sleep-like activity. LS has been associated with deficits in sustained attention (SA) but the
causal involvement of LS in attentional lapses remain unclear. This study aimed at addressing
this knowledge gap by directly manipulating LS and SA through pharmacological means. In a
double-blind, randomised-control trial, 32 participants received methylphenidate,
atomoxetine, citalopram or placebo during four separate experimental sessions. During each
session, electroencephalography measured LS whilst participants completed a visual SA task.
Methylphenidate, which increases wake-promoting noradrenaline and dopamine, decreased
LS and improved performance (lower reaction time (RT), and less misses). Atomoxetine,
which increases noradrenaline, decreased LS but increased RT. Conversely, citalopram,
which increases sleep-promoting serotonin, increased LS and RT. Mediation analysis
confirmed the causal relationship of LS on SA. These results suggest that LS could represent
a mechanism for the effect of fatigue on attention.
coauthors: Paul M. Dockree, Trinity College; Jessica J. Barnes, The University of Queensland; Natasha Matthews, The University of Queensland; Angela J. Dean, The University of Queensland;  Rafael Abe, Monash University; L. Sanjay Nandam, The University of Queensland; Simon P. Kelly, University College Dublin; Redmond G. O’Connell, Monash University; Mark A. Bellgrove, Monash University; Thomas Andrillon, Monash University
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: The role of frontal cortex in multisensory decision-making
abstract:
The ability to combine visual and auditory cues to localize objects in space is critical to many organisms, whether prey, predator, or pedestrian crossing the street. Recent studies have shown that the mouse frontal cortex plays a key role in transforming sensory stimuli into appropriate motor actions during decision-making tasks. However, real-world decisions are invariably multisensory. Where is the relevant multimodal information combined in the brain, and are separate modalities independently represented in frontal cortex?

To answer these questions, we trained mice to perform an audiovisual spatial task where animals turn a wheel to indicate whether a stimulus appeared on the left or right. The stimuli can be auditory, visual, or a combination of the two, presented in coherent or conflicting locations. We optogenetically inactivated different spots across dorsal cortex on individual trials while mice performed this task.

We found that auditory and visual primary sensory cortices were both required for the processing of modality-specific sensory information, and that the effect of inactivation in these regions was highly lateralized. Conversely, inactivation of secondary motor cortex (M2) had robust, modality-independent effects on behavior.

To determine whether frontal cortex contains separate representations of both modalities, or a modality-independent representation of the decision process, we recorded neural activity in M2 with Neuropixels probes in behaving mice. In preliminary analyses, we have observed a variety of response patterns, including neurons that are selective for both spatial location and stimulus modality. Overall, our results suggest a key role for M2 in multisensory decisions.
coauthors: Philip Coen, University College London; Timothy P. Sit, University College London; Miles J. Wells, University College London; Matteo Carandini, University College London; Kenneth D. Harris, University College London
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: The neuroprotective role of orphan nuclear receptor NR5A2/LRH-1 against oxidative stress
abstract: Oxidative stress is a major underlying factor that is a key player in the initiation and/or progression of various fatal neurodegenerative diseases and other brain-related neuropathological conditions. Up to this date there is no established therapy or pharmaceutical strategy to tackle this mutifactorial condition within the context of neurodegeneration, thus identification of new molecular pathways with neuroprotective action against oxidative stress-induced apoptosis may be proven essential for novel therapeutic approaches. To this end, we identify orphan nuclear receptor NR5A2 as a critical protective factor in neuronal cells against H2O2, a well-established oxidative stress model. More specifically, we provide evidence that adenoviral-mediated overexpression of NR5A2 significantly decreases apoptosis and promotes survival of H2O2-treated SH-SY5Y cells and ex vivo cultured murine cortical neurons. Most importantly, dilauroyl-phosphatidylcholine (DLPC), an efficient, FDA-approved pharmacological agonist of NR5A2, is sufficient to recapitulate its neuroprotective action in primary neuronal cells. In an attempt to unravel the molecular mechanism of NR5A2 neuroprotective function, we identify key anti-apoptotic genes, such as Bcl-xl and Bcl-2, as well as genes regulating cellular response to oxidative stress, such Sod2 and Nrf2, as potential downstream targets. Future analyses will include ChIP and transcriptional assays to test the direct binding of NR5A2 on these targets. Collectively, our observations render NR5A2 as a critical neuroprotective factor and promising drug target for brain-related diseases.
coauthors: Ismini Rozani, Center for Basic Research, Biomedical Research Foundation of the Academy of Athens; Efstathia Tetringa, Center for Basic Research, Biomedical Research Foundation of the Academy of Athens; Dimitrios Gkikas, Center for Basic Research, Biomedical Research Foundation of the Academy of Athens; Matina Tsampoula, Center for Basic Research, Biomedical Research Foundation of the Academy of Athens; Panagiotis K. Politis, Center for Basic Research, Biomedical Research Foundation of the Academy of Athens
institution: Center for Basic Research, Biomedical Research Foundation of the Academy of Athens, Greece
theme: Theme A: Development, Neurodegenerative Disorders and Injury

title: Symmetric behavior from asymmetric wiring
abstract:
Caenorhabditis elegans maintains symmetric dorsal/ventral bending waves for locomotion in all developmental stages, during which its motor circuit undergoes significant rewiring. In adult, cholinergic motor neurons innervate and stimulate body wall muscles, and GABAergic motor neurons contra-laterally inhibit both sides. In the first larval (L1) stage however, a partial electron microscopy reconstruction suggests that cholinergic motor neurons only innervate dorsal muscles, and GABAergic motor neurons only innervate ventral muscles. How does such an asymmetric circuit produce symmetric output? 

To answer this long-standing question, we undertook anatomical and functional analyses of the L1 larva motor circuit. We reconstructed the neural connectivity of a complete L1 larva by electron microscopy, from which we identified previously uncharacterized muscle innervating cells. 

To elucidate the roles of these cells, we developed a novel all-optical manipulation methodology that allows bidirectional and systemic probing of neural circuits. We then combined calcium imaging, cellular ablation, chemogenetics, optogenetics, and all-optical interrogation to pinpoint mechanisms for symmetric muscle output. However, we found that the candidate cells identified from electron microscopy fail to explain output symmetry. Instead, we revealed that it is the excitatory premotor interneurons that provide extrasynaptic cholinergic activation to ventral muscles. Additionally, we found that ventral-innervating motor neurons provide extrasynaptic GABAergic relaxation to dorsal muscles. Thus, extrasynaptic pathways intricately compensate asymmetric synaptic wiring, allowing gait symmetry of newborn larvae.

These findings addressed the question of whether and how a neural circuit is able to operate symmetrically without structural symmetry. Our study highlighted the role of extrasynaptic transmission in regulating behavior, and demonstrated the dual role of both inter- and motor neurons in neuronal circuitry. It is possible that such mechanism is also utilized by other species to maintain stable behavioral output at different developmental stages, and beyond.
theme: Theme C: Sensory & Motor Systems, and Physiology/Behavior

title: Symposium on Chronic Neural Interface Technology
abstract:
This symposium will feature three leading neural interface engineers that are creating next generation microelectrode array technologies for large-scale and long-term neural recording and stimulation in the brain, spinal cord, and peripheral nerve.  Although metal microelectrodes are perhaps the oldest neural interface technology, they remain the most commonly used tool for measuring and stimulating neural activity in the brain, especially in applications that require realtime processing and control, such as brain-machine interfaces. Due to recent advances in materials and microfabrication methods, modern microelectrodes retain the same basic functionality of traditional microelectrodes but with several important new features, including ultrathin and compliant substrates that lead to reduced tissue damage and improved chronic stability. These devices provide hundreds of discrete channels for interfacing with the brain for long time spans, enabling new research paradigms for studying neural circuit function and creating promising new treatments for neurological disorders.

Speaker 1: Stephanie Lacour, Professor, EPFL Center for Neuroprosthetics
Talk title: Soft, microfabricated and multimodal neural interfaces
 
Speaker 2: Lan Luan, Assistant Professor, Rice University
Talk title: Ultra-flexible Neural Electrodes for Brain Disorders

Speaker 3: Cindy Chestek, Associate Professor, University of Michigan
Talk title: Neural Interfaces for Controlled Individuated Finger Movements

Moderator: Jordyn Ting, PhD student, University of Pittsburgh
theme: Theme E: Computational modelling and Techniques

title: Approaching Artificial Intelligence as an Embodied Developmental Process
abstract:
In this submission, we will lay out an argument for building artificial intelligence (AI) based on biological development. A developmental AI consists of three components: an embodied input/output network, a critical period for information acquisition and connectivity, and a network topology that expands over time according to the principles of contingency and developmental freedom. Developmental contingency restricts the developmental neural network to an increasingly limited set of possible trajectories. While contingency results in earlier developmental events (cell differentiation) to constrain the range of possibilities for future developmental events (formation of a network motif), developmental freedom is the tendency for information and representations in particular to take advantage of a stable underlying topology. This contributes to an artificial brain that acts as a generative network with a further capacity for behavioral complexity. 

We will demonstrate examples for each of these points using developmental Braitenberg Vehicles (dBVs) as the subject of thought experiments. These thought experiments will take the form of a contingency analysis of a typical dBV input/output network topology. This analysis shows how embodiment developmental agents provide three potentially powerful mechanisms for the emergence of adaptive intelligent systems. First, the presence of an embodied input/output network can act to structure input data. Secondly, the existence of a critical period embedded within the developmental process acts to structure association-building through network complexity.
